Ramban on Genesis
רמב"ן על בראשית
Commentary on the Torah by Ramban (Nachmanides). Translated and annotated by Charles B. Chavel. New York, Shilo Pub. House, 1971-1976
https://www.nli.org.il/he/books/NNL_ALEPH002108945/NLI

Ramban on Genesis

Introduction

In the name of <i>the great G-d, and the fearful</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">Daniel 9:4. It could not be Deuteronomy 10:17 since there the attribute <i>mighty</i> is mentioned. It is possible that the author chose the verse from Daniel rather than that of Deuteronomy in order to allude to the rest of the verse there: <i>And I prayed unto the Eternal my G-d, and made confession and said, O, Eternal the great and fearful G-d, and Who keepest the covenant and mercy with them that love Thee and keep Thy commandments</i>. There is thus here an allusion to a prayer for G-d’s mercy in the author’s work before him.</i> I will begin to write novel interpretations On the explanation of the Torah, With terror, with fear, With trembling, with sweat, with dread,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">See Berachoth 22 a, where it is explained that these are the ways in which the Torah was given and by which it was studied.</i> Praying and confessing With a humble heart and a broken spirit, Asking forgiveness, Seeking pardon and atonement,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">That is, in case he errs in his interpretations and especially in his refuting the opinions of the other masters.</i> With bowing to the ground, With kneeling, with prostration, Until all the vertebrae of the spine Seem to be loosened.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">Berachoth 28 b.</i> <i>And that my soul knoweth right well</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 139:14.</i> In clear awareness, That the egg of the ant is not as small In comparison to the outermost sphere As is my little wisdom And brief knowledge Against the hidden matters of the Torah<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">A reference to the Cabala — the mystic teachings of the Torah — elements of which the author intends to include in his commentary, but here he confesses his brief knowledge thereof.</i> That lie hidden in her house, Concealed in her room; For every precious thing and every wonder, Every profound mystery and all glorious wisdom Are stored up with her, Sealed up in her treasure By a hint, by a word, In writing and in speaking; Just as the prophet — who was adorned With royal garments and a crown, The annointed of the G-d of Jacob,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">II Samuel 23:1.</i> The author of the sweetest of songs — said: <i>I have seen an end</i> <i>To every purpose;</i> <i>But Thy commandment</i> <i>Is exceedingly broad</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 119:96.</i> And it is said, <i>Thy testimonies are wonderful;</i> <i>Therefore doth my soul keep them</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 129.</i>
But what shall I do Since my soul craves for Torah And she is in my heart As a consuming, burning fire<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">See Jeremiah 20:9.</i> In my kidneys restrained; To go forth in the steps Of the former ones, The lions of the group,<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">A reference to the most distinguished scholars of the generations.</i> The exalted of the generations, The men of might;<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">That is, in their knowledge of the Torah. “A man of might” is he who knows to answer in a discussion of the Torah. (Sanhedrin 93 b.)</i> To enter with them “The thickest part of the beam,<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">The heart of the problem.</i> To write as they did Explanations of the verses, And Midrashic interpretations On the precepts, And the <i>Agadah</i> [homily], <i>Ordered in all things, and sure</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">II Samuel 23:5. The preceding part of the verse reads: <i>For an everlasting covenant he hath made with me</i>. Ramban thus suggests that his part in the Torah was assured from on high, and therefore he need not fear to go forth in the steps of the former giants of the Torah.</i> I will place as an illumination before me The lights of <i>the pure candelabrum</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 31:8.</i> The commentaries of our Rabbi Shlomo [Rashi], <i>A crown of glory, and a diadem of beauty</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 28:5.</i> Adorned in his ways, In Scripture, Mishnah and Gemara. The right of the first-born is his.<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 21:17. A reference to the fact that Rashi’s commentary to the Torah was the first great commentary to be accepted by all Israel.</i> In his words will I meditate, And in their love will I ravish,<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">See Proverbs 5:19.</i> And with them we will have Discussions, investigations and examinations, In his plain explanations And Midrashic interpretations, And every difficult <i>Agadah</i> Which is mentioned in his commentaries. And with Abraham the son of Ezra We shall have open rebuke and hidden love.<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 27:5. The exact quotation: <i>Better is open rebuke than love that is hidden</i>. Ramban thus suggests that while he will criticize Ibn Ezra openly on many of his interpretations, yet his admiration of his work will not be lessened.</i>
And G-d Whom alone I shall fear He shall save me from <i>the day of wrath</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">Zephaniah 1:15.</i> He shall keep me from mistakes And from all sin and transgression, And He shall lead me in the straight way And open for us the gates of light, And He shall deem us worthy To see the day of tidings,<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">“The day of tidings” was to Ramban a reality which was to transpire in the very near future. See his commentary further, 2:3, towards the end of the verse.</i> As it is written: <i>How beautiful upon the mountains</i> <i>Are the feet of the messenger of good tidings</i> <i>That announceth peace</i>, <i>The harbinger of good tidings</i> <i>That announceth salvation</i>, <i>That saith to Zion:</i> <i>‘Thy G-d reigneth.’</i><sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 52:7.</i>
<i>Thy word is tried to the uttermost</i>, <i>And Thy servant loveth it</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 119:140.</i>
<i>Thy righteousness</i> <i>Is an everlasting righteousness</i>, <i>And Thy law is truth</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 142.</i>
<i>Thy testimonies are righteous forever;</i> <i>Give me understanding</i>, <i>And I shall live</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 44. (See my Hebrew commentary, p. 20, for the reason why Ramban mentions these three verses from Psalms.)</i>

Foreword

Moses our teacher wrote this book of Genesis together with the whole Torah from the mouth of the Holy One, blessed be He. It is likely that he wrote it on Mount Sinai for there it was said to him, <i>Come up to Me unto the mount, and be there; and I will give thee the tablets of stone and the Torah and the commandment which I have written, to teach them</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 24:12.</i> <i>The tablets of stone</i> include the tablets and the writing that are the ten commandments. <i>The commandment</i> includes the number of all the commandments, positive and negative. If so, the expression <i>and the Torah</i> includes the stories from the beginning of Genesis [and is called <i>Torah</i> — teaching] because it teaches people the ways of faith.
Upon descending from the mount, he [Moses] wrote the Torah from the beginning of Genesis to the end of the account of the tabernacle. He wrote the conclusion of the Torah at the end of the fortieth year of wandering in the desert when he said [by command of G-d], <i>Take this book of the law, and put it in the side of the ark of the covenant of the Eternal your G-d</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 31:26.</i> This view accords with the opinion of the Talmudic sage who says<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">Gittin 60 a. The name of the authority is Rabbi Yochanan.</i> that the Torah was written in sections.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">When a section was declared to Moses, he immediately wrote it down. When all the sections were completed, he compiled them together into one Torah. Rashi, <i>Ibid.</i></i> However, according to the sage who says that the Torah was given in its entirety,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">Resh Lakish is the authority who maintains that Moses wrote the whole Torah at one time after all sections had been given to him intermittently during the forty years and were properly systematized in his mind.</i> everything was written in the fortieth year when he [Moses] was commanded, <i>Now write ye this song for you and teach it unto the children of Israel; put it in their mouths</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 31:19.</i> and, as he was further instructed, <i>Take this book of the law, and put it in the side of the ark of the covenant of the Eternal your G-d</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 31:26.</i>
In either case it would have been proper for him to write at the beginning of the book of Genesis: “And G-d spoke to Moses all these words, saying.” The reason it was written anonymously [without the above introductory phrase] is that Moses our teacher did not write the Torah in the first person like the prophets who did mention themselves. For example, it is often said of Ezekiel, <i>And the word of the Eternal came unto me saying: ‘Son of man,’</i><sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">Ezekiel 3:16—17; 12:1, etc.</i> and it is said of Jeremiah, <i>And the word of the Eternal came unto me</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">Jeremiah 1:4.</i> Moses our teacher, however, wrote this history of all former generations and his own genealogy, history and experiences in the third person. Therefore he says <i>And G-d spoke to Moses, saying to him</i><sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 6:2.</i> as if he were speaking about another person. And because this is so, Moses is not mentioned in the Torah until his birth, and even at that time he is mentioned as if someone else was speaking about him.
Now do not find a difficulty in the matter of Deuteronomy wherein he [Moses] does speak about himself — [as he says,] <i>And I besought the Eternal;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 3:23.</i> <i>And I prayed unto the Eternal</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 9:26.</i> — for the beginning of that book reads: <i>These are the words which Moses spoke unto all Israel</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 1:1.</i> Thus throughout Deuteronomy he is like one who narrates things in the exact language in which they were spoken.
The reason for the Torah being written in this form [namely, the third person] is that it preceded the creation of the world,<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">Shabbath 88 b.</i> and, needless to say, it preceded the birth of Moses our teacher. It has been transmitted to us by tradition that it [the Torah] was written with letters of black fire upon a background of white fire.<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">Yerushalmi Shekalim 13 b. See also Rashi on Deuteronomy 33:2.</i> Thus Moses was like a scribe who copies from an ancient book, and therefore he wrote anonymously. However, it is true and clear that the entire Torah — from the beginning of Genesis to <i>in the sight of all Israel</i><sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 34:12.</i> [the last words in Deuteronomy] — reached the ear of Moses from the mouth of the Holy One, blessed be He, just as it is said elsewhere, <i>He pronounced all these words unto me with his mouth, and I wrote them with ink in the book</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">Jeremiah 36:18. Baruch, Jeremiah’s scribe, is explaining the manner in which he wrote down his master’s prophecies: <i>he</i> [Jeremiah] <i>pronounced all these words</i>, etc.</i>
G-d informed Moses first of the manner of the creation of heaven and earth and all their hosts, that is, the creation of all things, high and low. Likewise [He informed him of] everything that has been said by prophecy concerning the esoterics of the Divine Chariot [in the vision of Ezekiel]<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">Ezekiel, Chapter 1.</i> and the process of Creation, and what has been transmitted about them to the Sages. [Moses was informed about these] together with an account of the four forces in the lower world: the force of minerals, vegetation in the earth, living motion, and the rational soul. With regard to all of these matters — their creation, their essence, their powers and functions, and the disintegration of those of them that are destroyed<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">The rational soul in man is not subject to destruction. Hence Ramban writes of “<i>those of them</i> that are destroyed,” not all.</i> — Moses our teacher was apprised, and all of it was written in the Torah, explicitly or by implication. Now our Sages have already said:<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">Rosh Hashanah 21 b.</i> “Fifty gates [degrees] of understanding were created in the world, and all were transmitted to Moses with one exception, as it is said, <i>Thou hast made him but little lower than the angels</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 8:6.</i>
[Concerning this statement of the Sages] that in the creation of the world there are fifty gates of understanding, it is as if it said that there is one gate of understanding pertaining to the creation of the minerals, their force and their effects, one gate of understanding pertaining to the creation of the vegetation in the earth, and similarly, as regards the creation of trees, beasts, fowl, creeping things and fish, that there pertains to each of these one gate of understanding. This series culminates in the creation of the rational soul [for the gate pertaining to this latter creation] enables man to contemplate the secret of the soul, to know its essence and its power in “its palace” [namely, the body]<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">See Ibn Ezra’s commentary on Deuteronomy 32:2, which states that the body is the palace of the soul.</i> and to attain [that degree of understanding] which is alluded to in the saying of the Sages:<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">Heichaloth Rabboth 1:3.</i> “If a person stole, he [who has the aforesaid understanding] knows and recognizes it on him; if a person committed adultery, he knows and recognizes it on him; if one is suspected of having intercourse with a woman in her state of uncleanness, he knows and recognizes it on him. Greater than all is he who recognizes all masters<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">“Masters”; in Heichaloth Rabboth: “kinds.”</i> of witchcraft.” And from [that level of understanding] a man can ascend to the understanding of the spheres, the heavens and their hosts, for pertaining to each of these there is one gate of wisdom which is unlike the wisdom of the others. The total number of different gates as ascertained by tradition is fifty less one. It is possible that this fiftieth gate concerns a knowledge of the Creator, blessed be He, which is not transmittable to any created being. Pay no regard to the Sages’ saying that [“Fifty gates of understanding] <i>were created</i>,”<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">Since the fiftieth gate of understanding was never transmitted to any created being, how could the Sages say that fifty “were created”? The answer is that the statement relates to the majority of the gates.</i> for that statement relates to the majority even though one gate was indeed not created. This number [49] is clearly alluded to in the Torah in the counting of the <i>Omer</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 23:15:<i>Seven weeks shall there be complete…</i>.</i> and in the counting of the Jubilee,<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i> 25:8.</i> the secrets of which I will disclose when I attain thereto by the Will of the Holy One, blessed be He.
Everything that was transmitted to Moses our teacher through the forty-nine gates of understanding was written in the Torah explicitly or by implication in words, in the numerical value of the letters or in the form of the letters, that is, whether written normally or with some change in form such as bent or crooked letters and other deviations, or in the tips of the letters and their crownlets, as the Sages have said:<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote">Menachoth 29 b.</i> “When Moses ascended to heaven he found the Holy One, blessed be He, attaching crownlets to certain letters of the Torah. He [Moses] said to Him, ‘What are these for?’ He [G-d] said to him, ‘One man is destined to interpret mountains of laws on their basis.’”<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i> Moses said to G-d: “Show me this man.” G-d showed him Rabbi Akiba sitting with eight ranks of disciples. Moses sat down in the eighth rank but was not able to follow the discussions, a fact which deeply grieved him. But then he heard the disciples asking Rabbi Akiba, “Whence dost thou know this?” See now in text of Ramban.</i> “‘Whence dost thou know this?’ He [Rabbi Akiba] answered them: ‘This is a law given to Moses on Mount Sinai.’”<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote">Now Moses was content. <i>Ibid.</i></i> For these hints cannot be understood except from mouth to mouth [through an oral tradition which can be traced] to Moses, who received it on Sinai.
Based on this tradition, the Sages have said in Shir Hashirim Rabbah<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">Not found in our text. See, however, Shir Hashirim Rabbah 3:3, and see also my Hebrew commentary, p. 4, for further reference on this matter.</i> concerning King Hezekiah [when he was visited by a delegation from the king of Babylon]:<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah, Chapter 39.</i> “He showed them the Book of <i>Tagin</i> [crownlets].” This book is known and is available to everyone. In it is explained how many crownleted <i>alephs</i> there are in the Torah, how many <i>beths</i>, and the [frequency of the] rest of the letters and the number of crownlets on each one. The praise which the Sages bestowed on this book and the disclosure of Hezekiah’s secret to the delegation were not for the crownlets themselves but rather for a knowledge of their essence and their meanings, which consist of many exceedingly profound secrets. There, in the Midrash Shir Hashirim Rabbah,<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote">1:28.</i> they [the Sages] have also said: “It is written, <i>And He declared unto you His covenant</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 4:13.</i> which means: <i>He declared unto you</i> the Book of Genesis, which relates the beginning of His creation;<sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote">The interpretation is based upon the similarity between the words <i>b’riyah</i> (creation) and <i>b’ritho</i> (His covenant).</i> <i>which He commanded you to perform, even the ten words</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 4:13.</i> meaning the ten commandments, ten for Scripture and ten for Talmud.<sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote">“Ten for Scripture and ten for Talmud.” Thus the Oral Law is made equal to the Written Law. The basis for the interpretation seems to be the extra word <i>la’asoth</i> (to perform), which is taken to refer to the Oral Law since it teaches us how to perform the commandments.</i> For from what source did Elihu the son of Barachel the Buzite<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote">Job 32:2.</i> come and reveal to Israel the secrets of the behemoth<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 40:15. See following note.</i> and the leviathan?<sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 40:25. The Behemoth and the Leviathan are mentioned in G-d’s response to Job (Chapter 40) and are not found in Elihu’s speeches. Rabbi David Luria (in his notes to the Midrash) amends the text of the Midrash to read: “the secrets of the winds and the rains.” These are mentioned by Elihu in Chapter 37.</i> And from what source did Ezekiel come and reveal to them the mysteries of the Divine Chariot?<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">Ezekiel, Chapter 1.</i> It is this which Scripture says, <i>The king hath brought me into his chambers</i>,”<sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote">Song of Songs 1:4.</i> meaning that everything can be learned from the Torah.
King Solomon, peace be upon him, whom G-d had given wisdom and knowledge, derived it all from the Torah, and from it he studied until he knew the secret of all things created, even of the forces and characteristics of plants, so that he wrote about them even a Book of Medicine, as it is written, <i>And he spoke of trees, from the cedar that is in Lebanon even unto the hyssop that springeth out of the wall</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote">I Kings 5:13.</i>
Now I have seen the Aramaic translation of the book called <i>The Great Wisdom of Solomon</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote">One of the books of the Apocrypha. In Weisel’s Hebrew edition, Verses 4-6 in Chapter 7 come close to the text here mentioned.</i> and in it is written: “There is nothing new in the birth of a king or ruler; there is one entrance for all people into the world, and one exit alike. Therefore I have prayed, and the spirit of wisdom was given to me, and I have called out and the spirit of knowledge came to me; I chose it above scepter and throne.”
And it is further said there: “It is G-d alone Who gives knowledge that contains no falsehood, [enabling one] to know how the world arose, the composition of the constellations, the beginning, the end and middle of the times, the angles of the ends of the constellations, and how the seasons are produced by the movement of heavens and the fixed positions of the stars, the benign nature of cattle and the fierceness of beasts, the power of the wind and the thoughts of man, the relationship of trees and the forces of roots; everything hidden and everything revealed I know.” All this Solomon knew from the Torah, and he found everything in it — in its simple meanings, in the subtleties of its expressions and its letters and its strokes, as I have mentioned.
Scripture likewise relates concerning him, <i>And Solomon’s wisdom excelled the wisdom of all the children of the east</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">42</sup><i class="footnote">I Kings 5:10.</i> That is to say, he was better versed than they in divination and enchanting, for this was their wisdom, as it is said, <i>For they are replenished from the east, and with soothsayers like the Philistines</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 2:6.</i> (The Sages similarly said:<sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote">Pesikta of Rabbi Kahana, <i>Parah</i>. Bamidbar Rabbah, Chapter 19.</i> “What was the wisdom of the children of the east? They knew and were crafty in the divination of birds.”) <i>And all the wisdom of Egypt</i><sup class="footnote-marker">42</sup><i class="footnote">I Kings 5:10.</i> means that Solomon was better versed in sorcery, which is the wisdom of Egypt, and in the nature of growing things. As is known from the Book of Egyptian Agriculture,<sup class="footnote-marker">45</sup><i class="footnote">Mentioned in Rambam’s Moreh Nebuchim III, 29-30. Ramban also mentions it further, 11:28. Abraham ibn Ezra refers to it in his Commentary to Exodus 2:10.</i> the Egyptians were very well versed in the matters of planting and grafting different species. Thus the Sages have said:<sup class="footnote-marker">46</sup><i class="footnote">Tanchuma, <i>Kedoshim</i> 10.</i> “Solomon even planted peppers in the Land of Israel. How was he able to plant them? Solomon was a wise man, and he knew the essence of the foundation of the world. Why was this? [It is written] <i>Out of Zion, the perfection of beauty, G-d hath shined forth</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">47</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 50:2.</i> Out of Zion the whole world was perfected. How is this known? Why was it called ‘the Foundation Stone?’ Because the world was founded from it. Now Solomon knew which of its arteries extends to Ethiopia, and upon it he planted peppers, and immediately it produced fruits, for so he says, <i>And I planted trees in them of all kinds of fruit</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">48</sup><i class="footnote">Ecclesiastes 2:5.</i>
We have yet another mystic tradition<sup class="footnote-marker">49</sup><i class="footnote">Zohar <i>Yithro</i> 87a: “The whole Torah is the Name of the Holy One, etc.” See also my Hebrew commentary, p. 6 for a broader discussion of this matter.</i> that the whole Torah is comprised of Names of the Holy One, blessed be He, and that the letters of the words separate themselves into Divine Names when divided in a different manner, as you may imagine by way of example that the verse of <i>Bereshith</i> divides itself into these other words: <i>berosh yithbare Elokim</i>. This principle applies likewise to the entire Torah, aside from the combinations and the numerical equivalents of the Holy Names. Our Rabbi Shlomo [Rashi] has already written in his commentaries on the Talmud<sup class="footnote-marker">50</sup><i class="footnote">Sukkah 45 a.</i> concerning the manner in which the Great Divine Name of seventy-two letters is derived from the three verses: <i>And he went</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 14:19.</i> <i>And he came</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">52</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 20.</i> <i>And he stretched out</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">53</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 21.</i> It is for this reason that a Scroll of the Torah in which a mistake has been made in one letter’s being added or subtracted is disqualified [even though the literal meaning remains unchanged], for this principle [that the whole Torah comprises Names of the Holy One, blessed be He], obligates us to disqualify a scroll of the Torah in which one letter <i>vav</i> is missing from the word <i>otham</i> — of which there are thirty-nine fully-spelled ones in the Torah — [despite the fact that the same word appears many times without a <i>vav</i>], or if he [the Scribe] were to add a <i>vav</i> to any of the other deficient ones [that is, words which could be written with an additional <i>vav</i> but are not so written]. So it is in similar cases even though it matters not one way or another on cursory thought.
It is this principle which has caused the Biblical scholars to count every full and defective word in the Torah and Scripture and to compose books on the Masoretic text, going back as far as Ezra the Scribe and Prophet,<sup class="footnote-marker">54</sup><i class="footnote">Megillah 15 a. Malachi (the prophet) is identical with Ezra.</i> so that we should be heedful of this, as the Sages derived it from the verse, <i>And they read in the book in the Law of G-d, distinctly; and they gave the sense, and caused them to understand the reading</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">55</sup><i class="footnote">Nehemiah 8:8. The Sages’ interpretation is found in Nedarim 37 b: “<i>And they read in the book in the law of G—d</i>, this means the written text; <i>distinctly</i>, this is the Targum [translation]; <i>and they gave the sense</i>, this has reference to the division in verses; <i>and they caused them to understand the reading</i>, this means the punctuating signs [or accents], and some Rabbis say that this is the <i>Masoreth</i> [the traditions regarding the full or defective <i>words</i>].”</i> It would appear that the Torah “written with letters of black fire upon a background of white fire”<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">Yerushalmi Shekalim 13 b. See also Rashi on Deuteronomy 33:2.</i> was in this form we have mentioned, namely, that the writing was contiguous, without break of words, which made it possible for it to be read by way of Divine Names and also by way of our normal reading which makes explicit the Torah and the commandment. It was given to Moses our teacher using the division of words which expresses the commandment, and orally it was transmitted to him in the rendition which consists of the Divine Names. Thus masters of the Cabala<sup class="footnote-marker">56</sup><i class="footnote">Literally, “reception.” In the Talmud the word <i>cabala</i> denotes the whole body of the oral tradition in contrast to the written word of G—d, the Torah. Here, however, as well as in later Hebrew usage the word denotes the system of mystic lore and philosophy which constitutes a distinctive body of esoteric thought.</i> write the letters of the Great Name I have mentioned [namely, the Name containing seventy-two letters] all close to each other, and then these are divided into words consisting of three letters and many other divisions, as is the practice among the masters of the Cabala.
And now, know and see what I shall answer to those who question me concerning my writing a commentary of the Torah. I shall conduct myself in accordance with the custom of the early scholars to bring peace of mind to the students, tired of the exile and the afflictions, who read in the <i>Seder</i><sup class="footnote-marker">57</sup><i class="footnote">The portion of the Torah assigned for reading on a particular Sabbath or festival.</i> on the Sabbaths and festivals, and to attract them with the plain meanings of Scripture and with some things that are pleasant to the listeners and which give grace<sup class="footnote-marker">58</sup><i class="footnote">The Hebrew word <i>chein</i> (grace) is here an abbreviation for the Hebrew words <i>chochmah nistarah</i> [the hidden wisdom or the Cabala].</i> to the scholars. And may the gracious G-d <i>be merciful unto us and bless us</i><sup class="footnote-marker">59</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 67:2.</i> so that we shall <i>find grace and good favor in the sight of G-d and man</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">60</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 3:4.</i>
Now behold I bring into a faithful covenant and give proper counsel to all who look into this book not to reason or entertain any thought concerning any of the mystic hints which I write regarding the hidden matters of the Torah, for I do hereby firmly make known to him [the reader] that my words will not be comprehended nor known at all by any reasoning or contemplation, excepting from the mouth of a wise Cabalist speaking into the ear of an understanding recipient.<sup class="footnote-marker">61</sup><i class="footnote">The Hebrew is <i>Mekabel mevin</i>, which may also mean “an understanding Cabalist,” thus suggesting that the recipient too has already been initiated into these mysteries to a lesser degree.</i> Reasoning about them is foolishness; any unrelated thought brings much damage and withholds the benefit. <i>Let him not trust in vanity, deceiving himself</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">62</sup><i class="footnote">Job 15:31.</i> for these reasonings will bring him nothing but evil as if they spoke falsely against G-d, which cannot be forgiven, as it is said, <i>The man that strayeth out of understanding shall rest in the congregation of the shades</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">63</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 21:16.</i> <i>Let them not break through unto the Eternal to gaze</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">64</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 19:21 and 24.</i> <i>For the Eternal our G-d is a devouring fire, even a G-d of jealousies</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">65</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 4:24.</i>
And He will show those who are pleasing to Him wonders from His Torah. Rather let such see in our commentaries novel interpretations of the plain meanings of Scripture and Midrashim, and let them take moral instruction from the mouths of our holy Rabbis:<sup class="footnote-marker">66</sup><i class="footnote">Bereshith Rabbah 8:2.</i> “Into that which is beyond you, do not seek; into that which is more powerful than you, do not inquire; about that which is concealed from you, do not desire to know; about that which is hidden from you, do not ask. Contemplate that which is permitted to you, and engage not yourself in hidden things.”





Chapter 1



Verse 1

IN THE BEGINNING G-D CREATED. Rabbi Yitzchak said: The Torah, which is the book of laws, should have begun with the verse, <i>This month shall be unto you the first of the months</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 12:2.</i> which is the first commandment given to Israel.<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">It is true the book of Genesis contains three commandments (1:28; 17:10; 32:33), but after the Revelation on Sinai these laws became incumbent upon Israel. Hence the verse <i>this month</i>, etc., is “the <i>first</i> commandment given to Israel” as a people.</i> What then is the reason that it begins with the creation? Should the nations of the world say to Israel, “You are robbers because you took unto yourselves the lands of the seven nations of Canaan,” they [Israel] may reply to them, “The whole world belongs to the Holy One, blessed be He. He gave it to whom He pleased, and according to His Will, He took it [the land] from them and gave it to us.”<br>This is a homiletic exposition<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">Found in Tanchuma (Buber), <i>Bereshith</i> 11. See also Rashi (Berliner) p. 424.</i> as quoted by Rabbi Shlomo [Rashi] in his commentaries.<br>One may object that it was indeed very necessary to begin the Torah with the chapter of <i>In the beginning G-d created</i> for this is the root of faith, and he who does not believe in this and thinks the world was eternal denies the essential principle of the [Judaic] religion and has no Torah at all.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">A person who thinks the world is eternal cannot believe in miracles since, if G-d did not create the world, He cannot possibly change it. Ramban explains in many places (e.g., see further, 17:1; 46:15) that all Divine promises concerning the blessings or imprecations which will follow upon our observance or disregard of the Torah are miraculous in nature of “invisible miracles.” A person who believes that the world is eternal thus has “no Torah at all.” See further my English work, Ramban: His Life and Teachings, Chapter 13.</i><br>The answer is that the process of creation is a deep mystery not to be understood from the verses, and it cannot truly be known except through the tradition going back to Moses our teacher who received it from the mouth of the Almighty, and those who know it are obligated to conceal it.<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">Chagigah 11 b: “The process of Creation may not be expounded before two.”</i> It is for this reason that Rabbi Yitzchak said that it was not necessary for the Torah to begin with the chapter of <i>In the beginning G-d created</i> and the narration of what was created on the first day, what was done on the second and other days, as well as a prolonged account of the creation of Adam and Eve, their sin and punishment, and the story of the Garden of Eden and the expulsion of Adam from it, because all this cannot be understood completely from the verses. It is all the more unnecessary for the story of the generations of the flood and of the dispersion to be written in the Torah for there is no great need of these narratives, and, for people who believe in the Torah, it would suffice without these verses. They would believe in the general statement mentioned to them in the Ten Commandments: <i>For in six days the Eternal made heaven and earth, the sea, and all that is in them, and rested on the seventh day</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 20:11.</i> and the knowledge of the process of creation would remain with individuals as a tradition from Moses who received the law on Sinai together with the Oral Torah.<br>Rabbi Yitzchak then gave a reason for it. The Torah began with the chapter of <i>In the beginning G-d created</i> and recounted the whole subject of creation until the making of man, how He [G-d] granted him dominion over the works of His hands, and that He put all things under his feet;<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">See Psalms 8:7.</i> and how the Garden of Eden, which is the choicest of places created in this world, was made the place of his abode until his sin caused his expulsion therefrom; and how the people of the generation of the flood were completely expelled from the world on account of their sin, and the only righteous one among them — he [Noah] and his children — were saved; and how the sin of their descendants caused them to be scattered to various places and dispersed to different countries, and how subsequently they seized unto themselves places <i>after their families, in their nations</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 10:5.</i> as chance permitted. If so, it is proper that when a people continues to sin it should lose its place and another people should come to inherit its land, for such has been the rule of G-d in the world<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">The Hebrew word <i>ba’aretz</i> (world) may also refer here to “the land,” especially the Land of Israel. See Ramban further, 26:5.</i> from the beginning. This is true all the more regarding that which is related in Scripture, namely that Canaan was cursed and sold as a servant forever.<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 9:25.</i> It would therefore not be proper that he inherit the choicest of places of the civilized world. Rather, the servants of G-d — the seed of His beloved one, Abraham<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">See Isaiah 41:8.</i> — should inherit it, even as it is written, <i>And He gave them the lands of the nations, and they took the labor of the peoples in possession; that they might keep His statutes, and observe His laws</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 105:44-45.</i> That is to say, He expelled those who rebelled against Him, and settled therein those who served Him so that they know by serving Him they will inherit it, whereas if they sin against Him, the land will vomit them out, just as it vomited out the nation before them.<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">See Leviticus 18:28.</i><br>Elucidating the explanation I have written are the words of the Sages in Bereshith Rabbah, wherein they say as follows:<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">1:3.</i> “Rabbi Yehoshua, of the city of Siknin, in the name of Rabbi Levi opened [his discourse on this chapter of Creation with the verse]: <i>He hath declared to His people the power of His works</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 111:6.</i> Why did the Holy One, blessed be He, reveal to Israel what was created on the first day and what was created on the second day? It is on account of the seven nations who inhabited the land of Canaan, so that they should not taunt Israel and say to them: ‘Are you not a nation of robbers?’ Israel could then reply to them: ‘And you, is it not booty in your hands? <i>Have not the Caphtorim that came forth from Caphtor destroyed them and dwelt in their stead?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 2:23.</i> The world and the fullness thereof belong to the Holy One, blessed be He. When He willed it, He gave it to you, and when He willed it, He took it from you and gave it to us.’ It is this which Scripture says, <i>To give them the heritage of the nations</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 111:6.</i> <i>He hath declared to His people the power of His works</i> in order <i>to give them the heritage of the nations</i>. Hence He told them the account of creation.”<br>There is yet another source for the subject I have mentioned: the mysteries in the process of creation. It is what our Rabbis of blessed memory have said:<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">This Midrash is quoted by Rambam in his Preface to Moreh Nebuchim. See Batei Midrashoth, ed. Wertheimer, I, p. 251.</i> <i>“He hath declared to His people the power of His works</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 111:6.</i> To declare the power of the process of creation to a mortal being is impossible. Therefore, Scripture closed the matter: <i>In the beginning G-d created.”</i> Thus is elucidated what we have said on this subject.<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">That the details in the process of creation and the settlement of the earth were written for the purpose of justifying Israel’s possession of the land while the essential process of creation itself remains a mystery.</i>
IN THE BEGINNING G-D CREATED. Rashi wrote: “This verse calls aloud for elucidation,<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">The difficulties in the verse are: (a) The word <i>bereshith</i> (in the beginning) appears throughout the Bible in a construct form such as: <i>In the beginning of the reign of Jehoiakim</i> (Jeremiah 27:1). But here it cannot be in construct form since such a form can be used only in connection with a noun, and the word <i>bara</i> (He created) is a verb. (b) Again, it cannot be said that here <i>bereshith</i> is actually in a construct form and that a missing noun is implied, thus making the sense of the verse, “in the beginning of all, G—d created…,” for if so, the following difficulty presents itself: since Scripture, according to this interpretation, sets out to tell us the order in which things were created, why does it say in Verse 2 <i>And the spirit of G-d hovered over the face of the waters</i> when it has not yet told us when water was created? Hence Rashi turns to a Midrashic interpretation in which the word <i>reshith</i> is another name for the Torah and Israel. The word <i>bereshith</i> is thus not in a construct form but stands by itself, and the sense conveyed is: “For the sake of that which is <i>reshith</i> [Torah and Israel] G-d created.”</i> as our Rabbis have explained it:<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">Bereshith Rabbah 1:6; Tanchuma (Buber) <i>Bereshith</i> 3.</i> “For the sake of Torah which is called <i>reshith</i>, as it is said, <i>The Eternal made me as ‘reshith’</i> (the beginning) <i>of His way</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 8:22.</i> and for the sake of Israel who is called <i>reshith</i>, as it is said, <i>Israel is the Eternal’s hallowed portion, the ‘reshith’</i> (first-fruits) <i>of His increase</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">Jeremiah 2:3.</i><br/>This Midrash of our Rabbis is very hidden and secret for there are many things the Rabbis found that are called <i>reshith</i> and concerning which they give Midrashic interpretations, and those wanting in faith count their multitude. For example, they [the Rabbis] have said:<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">Bereshith Rabbah 1:6.</i> “For the merit acquired by [fulfilling the commandments associated with] three things has the world been created: for the merit of the Dough-offering, for the merit of Tithes and for the merit of the First-fruits. <i>In the beginning G-d created. Reshith</i> surely signifies the Dough-offering, as it is said, <i>The first of your dough</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 15:20.</i> <i>Reshith</i> surely signifies the Tithes, as it is said, <i>The first of thy corn</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 18:4.</i> <i>Reshith</i> surely signifies the First-fruits, as it is said, <i>The first-fruits of thy land</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 23:19.</i><br/>The Rabbis have further said:<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">Bereshith Rabbah 1:6.</i> “For the merit acquired by Moses [the world has been created], as it is said, <i>And he chose a first part for himself</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 33:21. Reference here is to Moses who took the territory of Kings Sihon and Og as he knew that his grave was to be therein. (See Rashi, <i>ibid.</i>) It was thus for the sake of this meritorious person, of whom <i>reshith</i> was said, that the world was created.</i><br/>Their intent in the above texts is as follows: the word <i>bereshith</i> alludes to the creation of the world by Ten Emanations, and hints in particular to the emanation called Wisdom, in which is the foundation of everything, even as it says, <i>The Eternal hath founded the earth by wisdom</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 3:19.</i> This is the Heave-offering [referred to in the Midrash mentioned above], and it is holy; it has no precise measure,<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote">By law of the Torah, the Heave-offering given to the priest has no fixed measure; the owner may give according to his discretion. “Even one grain frees the whole mound” (Kiddushin 58 b). Similarly, our conception of Divine wisdom is infinitesimal in relation to its true scope.</i> thus indicating the little understanding created beings have of it. Now just as a man counts ten measures — this alludes to the Ten Emanations — and sets aside one measure of the ten as a Tithe, so do the wise men contemplate the tenth Emanation and speak about it. The Dough-offering, which is the single commandment pertaining to the dough, alludes to this. Now Israel, which is called <i>reshith</i> as mentioned above, is “the congregation of Israel,” which is compared in the Song of Songs to a bride and whom Scripture in turn calls “daughter,” “sister” and “mother.” The Rabbis have already expressed this in a homiletic interpretation of the verse, <i>Upon the crown wherewith his mother hath crowned him</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">Song of Songs 3:11.</i> and in other places. Similarly, the verse concerning Moses, <i>And he chose a first part for himself</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 33:21. Reference here is to Moses who took the territory of Kings Sihon and Og as he knew that his grave was to be therein. (See Rashi, <i>ibid.</i>) It was thus for the sake of this meritorious person, of whom <i>reshith</i> was said, that the world was created.</i> which they [the Rabbis in the above Midrash] interpret to mean that Moses our teacher contemplated [the Deity] through a lucid speculum,<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">So clearly stated in Yebamoth 49b.</i> and he saw that which is called <i>reshith</i> (the first) for himself, and therefore he merited the Torah. Thus all the above Midrashim have one meaning. Now it is impossible to discuss this explanation at length in writing, and even an allusion is dangerous since people might have thoughts concerning it which are untrue. But I have mentioned this [i.e., the above brief explanation] in order to close the mouths of those wanting in faith and of little wisdom, who scoff at the words of our Rabbis.
IN THE BEGINNING. Rashi wrote: “If you wish to explain it [the word <i>bereshith</i>] in accordance with its plain meaning, explain it thus: at the beginning of the creation of the heaven and earth, and the earth was formless and void and there was darkness, the Holy One, blessed be He, said, <i>Let there be light</i>.” If so, the whole text leads into the creation of light.<br/>Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra explained it in an identical way. However, he established that the letter <i>vav</i> in the word <i>veha’aretz</i> (and the earth) does not şerve [as a connecting letter as it normally does and which would mean “and,” but it serves rather as the word “when.”] There are many such examples in Scripture. The meaning then according to Rabbi Abraham would be: at the beginning of the creation of heaven and dry land, there was no habitable place on earth; rather, it was unformed and void and covered with water, and G-d said, <i>Let there be light</i>. According to Abraham ibn Ezra’s opinion, only light<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote">According to Rashi in Verse 6 (also 2:4), the sun, etc., was also created on the first day.</i> was created on the first day.<br/>The difficulty which Rabbi Shlomo [Rashi] had which led him to the above interpretation is, as he said: For if Scripture intended to teach the order in which the acts of creation took place, it should have written <i>barishonah</i> [instead of <i>bereshith</i>], since wherever the word <i>reshith</i> occurs in Scripture it is in the construct state. But there is the verse, <i>Declaring the end ‘mereshith’ [from the beginning]</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 46:10. Here the word <i>reshith</i> is not in the construct state.</i> And if one will connect it with the missing word <i>davar</i> [thing — thus making the verse read: “Declaring the end of a thing from the beginning of a thing”—] here too it could be connected to a missing word.<sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote">Thus reading: <i>Bereshith kol</i>, (In the beginning of everything [G—d created]).</i> There is also the verse, <i>And he chose ‘reshith’ (a first part) for himself</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 33:21. Reference here is to Moses who took the territory of Kings Sihon and Og as he knew that his grave was to be therein. (See Rashi, <i>ibid.</i>) It was thus for the sake of this meritorious person, of whom <i>reshith</i> was said, that the world was created.</i> [Here again the word <i>reshith</i> is not used in the construct state.] And Rashi raised other objections.<br/>Now listen to the correct and clear explanation of the verse in its simplicity. The Holy One, blessed be He, created all things from absolute non-existence. Now we have no expression in the sacred language for bringing forth something from nothing other than the word <i>bara</i> (created). Everything that exists under the sun or above was not made from non-existence at the outset. Instead He brought forth from total and absolute nothing a very thin substance devoid of corporeality but having a power of potency, fit to assume form and to proceed from potentiality into reality. This was the primary matter created by G-d; it is called by the Greeks <i>hyly</i> (matter). After the <i>hyly</i>, He did not create anything, but He formed and made things with it, and from this <i>hyly</i> He brought everything into existence and clothed the forms and put them into a finished condition.<br/>Know that the heavens and all that is in them consist of one substance, and the earth and everything that is in it consist of one substance. The Holy One, blessed be He, created these two substances from nothing;<sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote">Such is also the theory of Rambam: “All things on earth have one common substance; the heavens and the things in them have one substance different from the first” (Moreh Nebuchim II, 26).</i> they alone were created, and everything else was constructed from them.<br/>This substance, which the Greeks called <i>hyly</i>, is called in the sacred language <i>tohu</i>, the word being derived from the expression of the Sages:<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote">Kiddushin 40b.</i> “<i>betohei</i> (when the wicked bethinks himself) of his doings in the past.” If a person wants to decide a name for it [this primordial matter], he may bethink himself, change his mind and call it by another name since it has taken on no form to which the name should be attached. The form which this substance finally takes on is called in the sacred language <i>bohu</i>, which is a composite word made up of the two words <i>bo hu</i> (in it there is [substance]). This may be compared to the verse, <i>Thou art not able ‘asohu’ (to perform it)</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 18:18.</i> in which case the word <i>asohu</i> is missing a <i>vav</i> and an <i>aleph</i> [and is a composite of the two words] <i>aso hu</i>. It is this which Scripture says, <i>And he shall stretch over it the line of ‘tohu’ (confusion) and the stones of ‘bohu.’</i><sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 34:11. “The stones,” which are forms in the building (as explained later on by Ramban), thus constitute substance as expressed in the Hebrew <i>bohu</i>.</i> [The <i>tohu</i> in Hebrew or <i>hyly</i> in Greek] is the line by which the craftsman delineates the plan of his structure and that which he hopes to make. This is derived from the expression, <i>Kavei (Hope) unto G-d</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 27:14.</i> <i>The stones</i> are forms in the building. Similarly it is written, <i>They are accounted by Him as nought and ‘tohu,’</i><sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 40:17.</i> as <i>tohu</i> comes after nothingness and there is nothing yet in it.<br/>So the Rabbis have also said in Sefer Yetzirah:<sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote">2:6. Sefer Yetzirah (Book of Creation) is one of the earliest Hebrew books of the Cabala tradition. (See introduction to Bereshith, Note 56.) Some of the profoundest mystic commentaries have been written on this book. See my Hebrew work, Kithvei Haramban, Vol. 2, pp. 451-461.</i> “He created substance from <i>tohu</i>, and made that which was nothing something.”<br/>They have furthermore said in the Midrash of Rabbi Nechunya ben Hakanah:<sup class="footnote-marker">42</sup><i class="footnote">Called also Sefer Habahir (Book of the Bright Light), 2. This book too is a classic in the mystic teachings of the Cabala. It was written in the style and manner of the Midrashim.</i> “Rabbi Berachyah said: ‘What is the meaning of the verse, <i>And the earth was ‘tohu’ (without form) ‘vavohu’</i> (<i>and void</i>)? What is the meaning of the word “was?” It had already been <i>tohu</i>. And what is <i>tohu</i>? It is a thing which astonishes people. It was then turned into <i>bohu</i>. And what is <i>bohu</i>? It is a thing which has substance, as it is written, [<i>bohu</i> is a composite of the two words] ‘<i>bo hu</i>’ (in it there is substance).’”
AND ‘ELOKIM’ (G-D) SAID. The word <i>Elokim</i> means “the Master of all forces,” for the root of the word is <i>e-il</i>, meaning force, and the word <i>Elokim</i> is a composite consisting of the words <i>e-il heim</i>, as if the word <i>e-il</i> is in a construct state, and <i>heim</i>, [literally] “they,” alludes to all other forces. Thus <i>Elokim</i> means “the Force of all forces.” A secret will yet be disclosed in connection with this.<sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote">See Ramban, Exodus 20:3.</i><br>If so, the simple correct explanation of the verse is as follows: <i>In the beginning</i><sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote">Ramban thus indicates his opinion that the word <i>bereshith</i> is not in a construct state. This is contrary to Rashi, as explained above.</i> <i>G-d created the heavens</i> means He brought forth their matter from nothing; <i>and the earth</i> means that He brought forth its matter from nothing. <i>And the earth</i>, includes all the four elements,<sup class="footnote-marker">45</sup><i class="footnote">Fire, wind, water, and earth.</i> [not merely the land] as in the verse, <i>And the heaven and the earth were finished</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">46</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 2:1.</i> which includes the entire lower sphere, and in <i>Praise the Eternal from the earth, ye sea-monsters, and all deeps</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">47</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 148:7.</i> and as in many other verses. Now with this creation, which was like a very small point having no substance, everything in the heavens and on the earth was created. The word <i>eth</i> —[<i>eth hashamayim ve’eth ha’aretz</i>] — is like “the essence of a thing.” The Sages have always set it forth as serving to include,<sup class="footnote-marker">48</sup><i class="footnote">Pesachim 22b.</i> since it is derived from the expression, <i>The morning ‘atha’ (cometh), and also the night</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">49</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 21:12.</i> And so did our Rabbis say:<sup class="footnote-marker">50</sup><i class="footnote">Bereshith Rabbah 1:19.</i> “<i>‘Eth hashamayim (the heavens)’ — eth</i> includes the sun, moon, stars and constellations. <i>‘Ve’eth ha’aretz (and the earth)’ — ve’eth</i> includes the trees, herbs, and the Garden of Eden.” These include all created things which are corporeal.<br>Now after having said that with one command G-d created at first the heavens and the earth and all their hosts, Scripture returns and explains that the earth after this creation was <i>tohu</i>, that is, matter without substance. It became <i>bohu</i> when He clothed it with form. Then it [Scripture] explains that in this form was included the form of the four elements: fire, water, earth, and air. The word <i>ha’aretz</i> (the earth) includes these four elements. In this verse, the element of fire is called “darkness”<sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote"><i>And darkness was upon the face of the deep</i>. So also explained in the Moreh Nebuchim, II:30: “By <i>Choshech</i> the element fire is meant, nothing else.” Ramban’s reasoning on this point is also found there.</i> because the elemental fire is dark. Were it red, it would redden the night for us. The element of water with which the dust was kneaded is here called “deep.”<sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote"><i>And darkness was upon the face of the deep</i>. So also explained in the Moreh Nebuchim, II:30: “By <i>Choshech</i> the element fire is meant, nothing else.” Ramban’s reasoning on this point is also found there.</i> This is why the waters of the oceans are called “the deeps,” as it is written, <i>The deeps cover them;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">52</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 15:15.</i> <i>The deeps were congealed;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">53</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 8.</i> <i>The deep was round about me</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">54</sup><i class="footnote">Jonah 2:6.</i> The bottom of the ocean is also referred to as “deep:” <i>And He rebuked the Red Sea, and it was dried up, and He led them through the depths, as a wilderness;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">55</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 106:9.</i> <i>He led them through the deep as a horse in the wilderness</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">56</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 63:13.</i> And the element air is here called “spirit.”<sup class="footnote-marker">57</sup><i class="footnote"><i>And the spirit of G-d hovered over the face of the waters</i>.</i><br>Now it is already known that the four elements fill up the whole space with matter.<sup class="footnote-marker">58</sup><i class="footnote">“This sphere in its totality is composed of the celestial orbs, the four elements and their combinations; there is no vacuum whatever therein, but the whole space is filled up with matter.” (Guide of the Perplexed, Friedlander’s translation, I, 72.)</i> That which stands still is the sphere of earth. The waters surround the earth, the air encompasses the waters, and the fire envelopes the air.<sup class="footnote-marker">59</sup><i class="footnote">From the language of Rambam, <i>ibid.</i> It is to be noted that Ramban follows Yehudah al Charizi’s translation of Rambam’s philosophic work and not that of Shmuel ibn Tibbon. See my Hebrew work, The Life of Ramban, pp. 23-24, on the far-reaching significance of this point.</i> Scripture thus states that the earth took on form, and the fire above enveloped the intermingled waters and dust, and the wind blew and rose in the darkness and hovered over the waters.<br>It appears to me that this [primeval] point, [which G-d created out of absolute nought], which took on form and became <i>bohu</i>, is what the Sages call:<sup class="footnote-marker">60</sup><i class="footnote">Yoma 54b. This “foundation rock” is the stone on which the Ark of the Covenant rested in the Holy of Holies in King Solomon’s Temple.</i> “‘The rock of foundation’ from which the world was founded.”<br>The purport of the verses is thus: In the beginning G-d created the heavens from nought, and He created the earth from nought. The earth, when created, was <i>tohu</i> and then it became <i>bohu</i>, and in these there were “darkness” [i.e., fire, as explained above], water, dust and the wind blowing upon the water. Thus everything was created and made. The reason why <i>ruach</i> (wind) is attached to the name of G-d [as it says, <i>and the spirit of God</i>] is that it is the least substantial of all elements<sup class="footnote-marker">61</sup><i class="footnote">Although fire is thinner than wind, since the element of fire is alluded to in the verse by the word “darkness,” as explained above, it would not be fitting to attach it to the name of G—d. (Bachya).</i> and is above them, hovering upon the face of the waters only by command of the Holy One, blessed be He.<br>In case you seek information concerning the creation of the incorporeal angels, you will not find it explained in the Torah. The Sages, however, have explained concerning them that they were created on the second day, so that you should not say that they assisted in the creation of the world.<sup class="footnote-marker">62</sup><i class="footnote">Bereshith Rabbah 3:11.</i> But if you will merit and understand the secret of the word <i>bereshith</i> and why Scripture does not begin by saying, “G-d created in the beginning,” you will know that, in the way of truth,<sup class="footnote-marker">63</sup><i class="footnote">A reference to the true wisdom of the Cabala which enables one to grasp the mysteries of the Torah.</i> Scripture tells about the lower creations and alludes to the higher ones and that the word <i>bereshith</i> refers covertly to the Emanation called Wisdom, which is the head of all beginnings, as I have mentioned. This is why they translated <i>bereshith</i> in the Jerusalem Targum to mean “in wisdom,” and the word is adorned in the Torah with a crown on the letter <i>beth</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">64</sup><i class="footnote">The adornment on the top of the letter <i>beth</i> hints at the <i>Kether</i> (Crown) above, from which all emanations issue. It is also referred to as <i>Ein Sof</i> (the Infinite). See my Hebrew commentary, p. 15.</i>

Verse 2



Verse 3

AND G-D SAID, ‘LET THERE BE LIGHT.’ The word “saying” here indicates Will, as in the verse, <i>What dost thy soul say, that I should do it for thee?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">65</sup><i class="footnote">I Samuel 20:4.</i> which means, “What do you want and desire?” Similarly, <i>And let her be thy master’s son’s wife, as the Eternal hath spoken</i><sup class="footnote-marker">66</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 24:51.</i> means, “…as He hath willed, for such is the Will before Him.” Or, it may be [that the word “saying” here means] “thinking,” as in the verses, <i>Thou sayest in thy heart;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">67</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 47:8.</i> <i>And the chiefs of Judah shall say in their heart</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">68</sup><i class="footnote">Zechariah 12:5.</i> The purport is to state that the creation was not done with toil. Our Rabbis have also called this “thought.” Thus they have said:<sup class="footnote-marker">69</sup><i class="footnote">Bereshith Rabbah 12:14.</i> “The thought [concerning what was to be created on a particular day] was during the day; the deed itself was at sunset.” This teaches that creation was thought out, that there is a reason for everything created, that creation was not a simple manifestation of mere Will alone.<br>The word “being” [<i>Let there ‘be’</i>] indicates a deed for the present time,<sup class="footnote-marker">70</sup><i class="footnote">Thus unlike Rashi and R’dak (Rabbi David Kimchi), who hold that the reference here is to the creation of the luminaries, such as the sun, moon, etc., which were not suspended in the firmament until the fourth day (see Rashi, Verse 14), Ramban explains that the light of the first day was of a special substance; hence Scripture does not say, <i>And it was so</i>, since that light did not remain forever in its original state.</i> just as: <i>And thou wouldst be their king</i><sup class="footnote-marker">71</sup><i class="footnote">Nehemiah 6:6.</i> [meaning: their king from this moment on]. Therefore Scripture says that when He created the substance of the heavens, He said that from that substance there should come forth a shining matter called “light.”
AND THERE WAS LIGHT. The verse does not say, “And it was so,” as it is said on other days, because the light did not remain in this state all the time, as did the other creations. Concerning this matter, our Rabbis have an interpretation with a profound secret.<sup class="footnote-marker">72</sup><i class="footnote">Ramban’s hint here is to the Sefer Habahir, 190. See my Hebrew commentary pp. 15—16.</i><br>Know that the term “day” as used in the story of the creation was, in the case of the creation of heaven and earth, a real day, composed of hours and seconds, and there were six days like the six days of the workweek, as is the plain meaning of the verse. In the profounder sense, the Emanations issuing from the Most High are called “days,” for every Divine Saying<sup class="footnote-marker">73</sup><i class="footnote">The tenfold expression, <i>And G-d said</i>, found in the chapter of Creation.</i> which evoked an existence is called “day.” These were six, for <i>Unto G-d there is the greatness, and the power</i>, etc.<sup class="footnote-marker">74</sup><i class="footnote">I Chronicles 29:11.</i> The Sayings,<sup class="footnote-marker">73</sup><i class="footnote">The tenfold expression, <i>And G-d said</i>, found in the chapter of Creation.</i> however, are ten because regarding the first three Emanations, the term “day” does not apply at all. The explanation of the order of the verses in terms of this profound interpretation is sublime and recondite. Our knowledge of it is less than that of a drop from the vast ocean.

Verse 4

AND G-D SAW THE LIGHT, THAT IT WAS GOOD. Rabbi Shlomo [Rashi] wrote: “Here too<sup class="footnote-marker">75</sup><i class="footnote">A reference to Rashi’s similar comment on the first word of the Torah — <i>bereshith</i> (see above). The difficulty here in the text is twofold: (a) It is first written, <i>and darkness was upon the face of the deep</i>, and then G—d said, <i>Let there be light</i>. Thus there already was a separation between light and darkness. Why then does Scripture continue by stating, <i>and G—d divided the light from the darkness?</i> (b) Concerning all other acts of creation, the expression “And G—d saw that it was good” is found at the completion of the act of creation, while here this phrase is written (in the beginning of Verse 4) <i>before</i> the completion. The Agadah, which Rashi quotes, answers: (a) <i>vayavdel</i> means here that He set apart the light for the righteous in the world to come. (b) <i>ki tov</i> (that it was good) could not have been written <i>after</i> the separation of the light for the righteous from the ordinary light, since the remaining light was no longer perfect. Therefore, <i>ki tov</i> is mentioned <i>before</i> the setting aside of the light.</i> we must depend on the words of the homiletic Agadah G-d saw that the wicked were unworthy of using the light, and so He set it aside for the righteous in the World to Come. But according to the plain meaning of the verse, explain it thus: He saw that the light was good, and that it was not seemly for it and the darkness to function in a confused manner. He therefore assigned the one’s sphere of activity to the daytime and the one’s sphere of activity to the nighttime.”<br>And Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra said: “The word <i>vayar (and He saw)</i> has the same meaning here as in <i>Vera’iti ani (And I saw)</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">76</sup><i class="footnote">Daniel 10:7.</i> which refers to the thought in the heart. <i>And He divided</i> refers to His giving them different names.”<sup class="footnote-marker">77</sup><i class="footnote">Ibn Ezra’s opinion is thus that the division was not because it was unseemly that the light and darkness function in a confused manner, but it was for the purpose of assigning each one a separate name.</i><br>But the words of both Rashi and Ibn Ezra are incorrect for if they were, it would appear that there was on the part of G-d a change of mind and new counsel, as if to say that after G-d said, <i>‘Let there be light’ and there was light</i>, He saw that it was good, and therefore He divided between it and darkness just as a human being who does not know the nature of something until it comes into existence! Rather, the order followed in the process of creation is that the bringing forth of things into actual existence is called <i>amirah</i> (saying). Thus: <i>And G-d said, ‘Let there be light;’ And G-d said, ‘Let there be a firmament;’</i><sup class="footnote-marker">78</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 6.</i> <i>And G-d said, ‘Let the earth put forth grass.’</i><sup class="footnote-marker">79</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 11.</i> And the permanence of things called forth into existence is called <i>re’iyah</i> (seeing), as <i>And I saw</i> in Ecclesiastes,<sup class="footnote-marker">80</sup><i class="footnote">2:13.</i> and similarly, <i>And the woman saw that the tree was good for food</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">81</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 3:6.</i> In the language of the Rabbis we also find, “I see the words of Admon.”<sup class="footnote-marker">82</sup><i class="footnote">Kethuboth 109a.</i> Likewise, <i>And the king said unto Zadok the priest, ‘Seest thou? return into the city in peace.’</i><sup class="footnote-marker">83</sup><i class="footnote">II Samuel 15:27.</i> The purport of the word “seeing” is thus to indicate that their continuing existence is at His Will, and if that Will should for a second depart from them, they will turn into nought. Now just as Scripture says in connection with the work of each day, <i>And G-d saw that it was good</i> and on the sixth day when everything was completed it says, <i>And G-d saw everything that He had made, and behold, it was very good</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">84</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 31.</i> so does it say on the first day when light came into existence, <i>And G-d saw … that it was good</i>, meaning He desired its existence forever. The verse adds “the light” [<i>And G-d saw ‘the light’ that it was good</i>], because had it just said, “And G-d saw that it was good,” it would have referred to the creation of the heaven and the earth, and at that time He had not yet decreed for them permanence, as they did not remain as they were. Instead, from the substance created on the first day, the firmament was made on the second day, and on the third the waters and the dust were separated and the dry land — which He called “earth” — was formed. He then decreed for them permanence, and said concerning them, <i>And G-d saw that it was good</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">85</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 10.</i>
AND G-D DIVIDED THE LIGHT FROM THE DARKNESS. This is not “the darkness” mentioned in the first verse<sup class="footnote-marker">86</sup><i class="footnote">“First verse.” It is actually mentioned in Verse 2. However, in view of Ramban’s interpretation above that the first two verses tell of everything else to come, he refers to Verse 2 as “the first verse.”</i> which, as explained above, refers to the element of fire; rather, the “darkness” mentioned here means the absence of light, since G-d gave a length of time to the light and decreed that it be absent afterwards until it returns.<br>Now some commentators<sup class="footnote-marker">87</sup><i class="footnote">Reference here is to Yehuda Halevi who, in his philosophic work Al Khazari, sets forth this theory: The first light was created at the time of sunset, and it was an illumination which soon passed away, leaving the world in darkness. The established order was then that night preceded day, as it is written, <i>It was evening and it was morning</i> (2:20, Hirschfeld’s translation). See also my Hebrew commentary, 2d edition, p. 547, that Ramban may also refer here to Rabbeinu Zerachyah Halevi, who was of a similar opinion.</i> have said that this light was created in front of the Holy One, blessed be He, that is to say, in the west,<sup class="footnote-marker">88</sup><i class="footnote">In accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Abahu who says, “The Divine Presence is in the West” (Baba Bathra 25a).</i> and He immediately caused it to disappear for the period of the night, and afterwards it gave light for the period of the day. This is the reason for the verse, <i>And there was evening and there was morning</i>, since the night came first and afterwards the day, and both of them came after the existence of the light.<br>But this is not correct at all, for in this way they might add a short day to the six days of creation.<sup class="footnote-marker">89</sup><i class="footnote">Since night and day were <i>after</i> the creation of light, and light was created at the time of sunset, it follows that there was a short day (that is, light without darkness) preceding the <i>first</i> day. Thus a short day is added to the six days of creation.</i> It is possible, however, to say that the light was created in front of Him, blessed be He, but did not extend over the four elements mentioned [in the second verse, as explained above] and then He divided between it and the darkness by assigning to each a certain period. Light now remained before Him for the length of night, and then in the morning, He caused the light to shine upon the elements. In this way night preceded day.<br>It is further possible that we should say that when the heavens and the earth came forth from nought into existence, as mentioned in the first verse, time came into being, for although our time consisting of minutes and hours is measured in light and darkness, yet from the moment some substance came into existence time was already part of it. If so, after the heavens and the earth were created they so remained for the length of a night without light. Then He said, <i>‘Let there be light,’ and there was light</i>, and He decreed that it remain the same period as the first, and that after that it be absent from the elements. Thus, <i>there was evening, and there was morning</i>.

Verse 5

AND G-D CALLED THE LIGHT DAY. The verse states that time was created, and G-d made the length of the day and the length of the night.<br>The purport of the word <i>vayikra (And He called)</i> is [to indicate that] since Adam later gave names [to all the beasts, the fowl, etc.],<sup class="footnote-marker">90</sup><i class="footnote">Further,2:20.</i> it states that those things which were made before his existence were given names by G-d. This is the opinion of Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra.<sup class="footnote-marker">91</sup><i class="footnote">In Verse 8.</i><br>The correct interpretation is that the matter of calling a name here indicates the division which bounded them when they assumed their form. Thus did the Rabbis say:<sup class="footnote-marker">92</sup><i class="footnote">Bereshith Rabbah 3:7.</i> “[G-d said to the light,] ‘The day shall be your boundary,’ [and to darkness He said,] ‘The night shall be your boundary.’”
AND THERE WAS EVENING AND THERE WAS MORNING. There was evening and there was morning of one day. The beginning of the night is called <i>erev</i> [which also means “mingling”] because shapes of things appear confused in it, and the beginning of the day is called <i>boker</i> [which also means “examining”] because then a man can distinguish between various forms. This coincides with the explanation of Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra.<br>By way of the simple explanation of Scripture, it could not have said, [<i>And there was evening and there was morning</i>] “the first day,”<sup class="footnote-marker">93</sup><i class="footnote">Instead, it says <i>one day</i>. See Rashi who says that according to the regular mode of expression it should have really said “the first day.” He explains, however, the expression “one day” on the basis of the Midrash: It is “because the Holy One, blessed be He, was then the Only One (the Sole Being) in His universe, since the angels were not created until the second day.” <i>One day</i> thus means “the day of the One Being.” It is this interpretation of Rashi that Ramban alludes to when he comments that according to the simple meaning of Scripture it could not have said, “the first day.”</i> because the second had not yet been made; “the first” precedes a “second” in number or degree but both exist, whereas “one” does not connote the existence of a second.<br>Some scholars explain<sup class="footnote-marker">94</sup><i class="footnote">Ibn Ezra, Verse 5, and Rambam, Moreh Nebuchim, II, 30.</i> that <i>one day</i> is a reference to the rotation of the sphere upon the face of the whole earth in twenty-four hours, as every moment thereof is morning in some different place and night in the opposite place.<sup class="footnote-marker">95</sup><i class="footnote"><i>One day</i> thus means that the entire day consists of evening and morning occurring simultaneously in different places.</i> If so, the verse alludes to that which will take place in the firmament after the luminaries will be placed in the firmament of the heavens.

Verse 6

LET THERE BE A FIRMAMENT.
