G-d now said that the substance which had come into being first — that which He created from nought — should be a firmament, stretched as a tent in the midst of the waters, separating between waters and waters. It is possible that this is what the Rabbis intended by their saying,<sup class="footnote-marker">96</sup><i class="footnote">Bereshith Rabbah 4:1.</i> “Rav said, ‘The heavens were in a fluid form on the first day, and on the second day they solidified.’ Rav thus said, ‘<i>Let there be a firmament</i> means let the firmament become strong.’ Rabbi Yehudah the son of Rabbi Shimon said, ‘Let the firmament become like a plate, just as you say in the verse, <i>And they did beat</i> — [<i>vayerak’u</i> contains the same root as <i>raki’a</i>, firmament] — <i>the gold into thin plates</i>.’”<sup class="footnote-marker">97</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 39:3.</i>
IN THE MIDST OF THE WATERS. This means in the center of the waters, between the higher waters and the lower waters. For there is the same distance between the firmament and the waters upon the earth as between the higher waters and the firmament. Thus you may infer that the upper waters are suspended in space by the command of G-d. Thus it is explained in Bereshith Rabbah<sup class="footnote-marker">98</sup><i class="footnote">4:2.</i> and in Rashi’s commentary. This is part of the process of creation [which those who know it are obliged to conceal]; so do not expect me to write anything about it, as the subject is one of the mysteries of the Torah, and the verses in their plain meaning do not require such an interpretation since Scripture itself did not go into it at length, and to give the interpretation is forbidden even to those who know it, and so much the more to us.

Verse 7

AND G-D MADE THE FIRMAMENT. The word <i>asi’yah</i> (doing) always means adjusting something to its required proportion.
AND IT WAS SO. On the first day, <i>And there was light</i> is written after <i>And G-d said, ‘Let there be light,’</i> in order to explain that after the command of G-d, it [the light] came forth into actuality and was as He decreed it to be. But here, after the command, <i>Let there be a firmament</i>, it is written, <i>And G-d made the firmament, and divided</i>, etc.; why then has Scripture added here, <i>And it was so?</i> It is to tell us that it was to be ever so, for all times.<br>But Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra explained that the expression <i>and it was so</i> is attached to the verse which follows, meaning <i>when</i> it was so, G-d called the firmament Heaven. That is not correct.<br>In Bereshith Rabbah<sup class="footnote-marker">99</sup><i class="footnote">4:7.</i> the Rabbis have said: <i>“And G-d made the firmament</i>. This is one of the verses which Ben Zoma<sup class="footnote-marker">100</sup><i class="footnote">A colleague of Rabbi Akiba. He was one of the four men of his time who were deeply engaged in the interpretation of the mystical doctrine of creation. See Chagiga 14b.</i> found difficult:<sup class="footnote-marker">101</sup><i class="footnote">Literally: “caused the world to shake.”</i> <i>And G-d made</i>, etc. But was not [the world created] by command, as it is written, <i>By word of the Eternal were the heavens made?”</i><sup class="footnote-marker">102</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 33:6.</i> Now Ben Zoma’s difficulty was not only on account of the word <i>vaya’as (And He made)</i>, since on the fourth,<sup class="footnote-marker">103</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 16.</i> fifth,<sup class="footnote-marker">104</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 21. On the fifth day the word <i>vaya’as</i> is not found; only <i>vayibra (and He created)</i>.</i> and sixth day,<sup class="footnote-marker">105</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 25.</i> <i>vaya’as</i> is also written. Rather, his difficulty was, as I have said, that on the other days, immediately after G-d’s command, it is written, <i>And it was so</i>, indicating that it came into being immediately after the command, but here on the second day, after it says, <i>And G-d said — vaya’as (And He made)</i> is written! This was his question. Perhaps Ben Zoma had some secret interpretation which he did not want to reveal. This is the explanation of the cause of his difficulty.

Verse 8

AND G-D CALLED THE FIRMAMENT HEAVEN. On the second day He gave them this name when He clothed them with the form of the firmament for on the first day the heavens were still in the process of creation, but the name was not attached to them until they took on this form.<br>The meaning of this name [<i>shamayim</i> — heavens] is as if it had the sign of a <i>segol</i> under the letter <i>shin</i> [the prefix <i>shin</i> thus voweled means “that” or “for”] just as in <i>Shalamah (For why) should I be as one that veileth herself?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">106</sup><i class="footnote">Song of Songs 1:7. The letter <i>shin</i> there stands for <i>asher - asher lamah</i> (for why). Similarly in Ibn Ezra, <i>ibid.</i> Likewise here, the word <i>shamayim</i> is as if it said <i>asher mayim</i> (that waters), as is explained further in the text.</i> It is thus as if He said that they [the heavens] are waters which have congealed and stretched like a tent in the midst of the upper and lower waters. By this name <i>shamayim</i> He has made known the secret of their creation.<br>In the <i>Gemara</i> Tractate Chagigah,<sup class="footnote-marker">107</sup><i class="footnote">12a.</i> the Rabbis have said, “What is the meaning of the word <i>shamayim</i>? It means <i>shem mayim</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">108</sup><i class="footnote">“It is a name for water.” So clearly explained further on by Ramban.</i> If so, there is one <i>mem</i> missing here in the word <i>shamayim</i> on account of the adjoining of two similar letters, just as in the word <i>yeruba’al</i> [which stands for <i>yareb bo ba’al</i> — let Baal contend against him].<sup class="footnote-marker">109</sup><i class="footnote">Judges 6:32.</i> The word <i>shamayim</i> is thus as if it said <i>shem mayim</i>, meaning that “heaven” is the name given the waters when they took on a new form. This is the plain meaning of the verses in accordance with the way of Rashi’s writing,<sup class="footnote-marker">110</sup><i class="footnote">“The word <i>shamayim</i> [may be regarded as made up of either of these words]: <i>sa mayim</i> (carries water), etc.” Rashi.</i> and it conforms with the opinion of Rav<sup class="footnote-marker">111</sup><i class="footnote">Mentioned above: that the heavens were in a fluid form on the first day, and on the second day they solidified.</i> which we have mentioned. Thus the names “heaven” and “earth” mentioned in the first verse point to the names by which they would be called in the future, as it would be impossible to make them known in any other manner. It is, however, more correct in accordance with the meaning of the verses that we say that the heavens mentioned in the first verse are the upper heavens, which are not part of the lower spheres but are above the <i>merkavah</i> (the Divine Chariot), just as it is stated, <i>And over the heads of the living creatures there was the likeness of a firmament, like the color of the transparent ice, stretched forth over their heads above</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">112</sup><i class="footnote">Ezekiel 1:22.</i> It is on account of these higher heavens that the Holy One, blessed be He, is called <i>He Who rideth upon the heavens</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">113</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 33:26.</i> Scripture, however, did not relate anything concerning their creation, just as it did not mention the creation of the angels, the <i>chayoth</i> of the <i>merkavah</i>, and all Separate Intelligences which are incorporeal. Concerning the heavens, it mentioned only in a general way that they were created, meaning that they came forth from nought. On the second day He said that there should be a firmament in the midst of the waters, meaning that from the waters, the creation of which had already been mentioned, there should come forth an extended substance separating them [into two distinct waters]. These spherical bodies He also called “heavens” by the name of the first upper heavens. This is why they are called in this chapter “the firmament of the heaven” [rather than “heavens”] — <i>And G-d set them in the firmament of the heaven</i><sup class="footnote-marker">114</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 17.</i> — in order to explain that they are not the heavens mentioned by that name in the first verse but merely the firmaments <i>called</i> “heavens.”<br>This likewise is the opinion of our Rabbis mentioned in Bereshith Rabbah,<sup class="footnote-marker">115</sup><i class="footnote">4:1.</i> who state, “All Rabbis say it in the name of Rabbi Chananyah the son of Rabbi Pinchas, and Rabbi Yaakov the son of Rabbi Avin says it in the name of Rabbi Shmuel the son of Rabbi Nachman: <i>Let there be a firmament in the midst of the waters</i> — the middle drop of water congealed, and the lower heavens and the highest heaven of heavens were formed.” This saying of the Rabbis refers to the spherical bodies in which there are the lower heavens and the upper ones, called “the heavens of heavens,” as it is written: <i>Praise ye Him, sun and moon; praise Him, all ye stars of light. Praise Him, ye heavens of heavens, and ye waters that are above the heavens</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">116</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 148:3-4.</i> The heavens mentioned here in the first verse, in which is the Throne of the Holy One, Blessed be He, as it is written, <i>The heaven is My throne</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">117</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 66:1.</i> are the ones mentioned in the beginning of that Psalm: <i>Praise ye the Eternal from the heavens; praise Him in the heights. Praise ye Him, all His angels</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">118</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 148:1-2.</i><br>This interpretation is correct as far as the simple meaning of the verses is concerned. But there is yet a sublime and hidden secret in the name “the heaven” and in the name “the throne” for there is a heaven to the heavens, and a throne to the throne. Based on this, the Sages use the expressions, “In order that a man may first take upon himself the yoke of the kingdom of Heaven,”<sup class="footnote-marker">119</sup><i class="footnote">Berachoth 13a.</i> and “the fear of Heaven.”<sup class="footnote-marker">120</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 7a.</i> Scripture likewise says, <i>That the heavens do rule</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">121</sup><i class="footnote">Daniel 4:23.</i> The Sages also have a remarkable Midrash on the verse, <i>And Thou hear in heaven</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">122</sup><i class="footnote">I Kings 8:32. The Midrash referred to is in Sefer Habahir, 100, and found in Zohar 2, p. 271. See my Hebrew commentary, p. 19, note 58.</i> The worthy one will see all this alluded to in the first verse.<br>Thus the verses have explained that the first created things were from nought, and the rest were derived from the first created substance.<br>See no objection to this explanation from the saying of Rabbi Eliezer the Great,<sup class="footnote-marker">123</sup><i class="footnote">Found in Pirke d’Rabbi Eliezer, 3. See also Moreh Nebuchim II, 26, where Rambam discusses this saying of Rabbi Eliezer and concludes that he is not able to explain it sufficiently. Ramban, however, explains it further on in the text in a way which makes it consistent with the theory of creation from absolute nought.</i> who states, “Whence were the heavens created? From the light of the garment of the Holy One, blessed be He.” [This would apparently indicate that the heavens were not created from nought but from another preceding substance.] This opinion is also found in Bereshith Rabbah.<sup class="footnote-marker">124</sup><i class="footnote">12:1.</i> Since the Sages wanted to elevate the first substance to the utmost and make it ethereal, they did not find it feasible that the heavens, which are moving corporeal bodies possessing matter and form, were created from nought. Instead, they said “the light of the garment” was created first, and from it came forth the real substance of the heavens. And to the earth He gave another substance,<sup class="footnote-marker">125</sup><i class="footnote">This is based on the concluding statement of Rabbi Eliezer the Great: “Whence was the earth created? From the snow under the Throne of Glory.” (See Note 123.)</i> not as minute as the first [substance from which the heavens were formed], and that is “the snow under the Throne of Glory,” for the Throne of Glory was first created, and from it came forth “the snow” under it, and from it [the “snow”] was formed the substance of the earth, which was third<sup class="footnote-marker">126</sup><i class="footnote">The Throne of Glory, the snow, the earth. In the case of the heavens, however, creation was completed in the second stage: ‘the light of the garment’ and then the heavens. This accords with the theory explained above (see Note 35) that the substance of the heavens is unlike that of the earth.</i> in the order of creation.

Verse 9

LET THE WATERS UNDER THE HEAVEN BE GATHERED TOGETHER. The deep, which is water and sand, was like turbid waters, and He decreed concerning the waters that they be gathered together in one place, surrounded on all sides, and He further decreed concerning the sands that they rise up until they be seen above the waters and that they become dry, so that there be a stretch of dry land suitable for settlement thereon. And so it is written: <i>To Him that spread forth the earth above the waters</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">127</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 136:6.</i> Or perhaps G-d’s decree was that the earth be spherical, partly visible and mostly submerged in the waters, as the Greeks imagine in their proofs, apparent or real. Thus there were two decrees, that is, two matters done by the Will of G-d that are contrary to their natural inclination. For in view of the heaviness of earth [which would cause it to sink] and the lightness of the waters [which would cause them to rise], it would have been natural that the pillar of the earth be in the center and that the waters should cover it, thus surrounding it from all sides.<sup class="footnote-marker">128</sup><i class="footnote">But instead He decreed that the waters which filled the whole world should go down as would be natural for the earth, and that the earth should come up as would be natural for the water.</i> Therefore, He said, <i>Let the waters under the heaven be gathered together</i>, that is to a lower place, and then He said, <i>And let the dry land appear</i>. He gave them names as they assumed these forms, for at the beginning their collective name was “the deep.”

Verse 10

AND G-D CALLED THE DRY LAND EARTH. The verse states that the proper name for it would be <i>yabashah</i> (dry land) for as the waters are separated from the sand it becomes dry. However, He called it <i>eretz</i> (earth) as the name which included the four elements created on the first day. The reason for this is that they were all created for the sake of the earth in order that there be a habitation for man, since among the lower creatures no one but man recognizes his Creator.<sup class="footnote-marker">129</sup><i class="footnote">This is a major principle in Ramban’s thought, that the purpose of all existence is that man acknowledge his Creator. “We have no other reason for the Creation.” (See end of <i>Seder Bo</i> in the Book of Exodus).</i><br>And the gathering together of the waters He called <i>‘yamim’ (seas)</i>. It is as if [the word <i>yamim</i>, (seas) combines the two words] <i>yam</i> and <i>mayim</i> (a sea of waters), for the bottom of the ocean is called <i>yam</i>, as it is written, <i>As the waters cover the sea</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">130</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 11:9.</i> and likewise, <i>And he took down the sea from off the brazen oxen</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">131</sup><i class="footnote">II Kings 16:17.</i> It is called “sea” because there was a large gathering of water in it.
AND G-D SAW THAT IT WAS GOOD. This means that their continued existence was by His Will, and the purport is that when He clothed them with this form He desired them to be so and their existence was thus established as I have explained.<sup class="footnote-marker">132</sup><i class="footnote">In Verse 4.</i> This conforms to what our Rabbis have said:<sup class="footnote-marker">133</sup><i class="footnote">Bereshith Rabbah 4:8.</i> “Why is it not stated in reference to the work of the second day <i>that it was good?</i> Because the work associated with the waters was not completed until the third day. Therefore on the third day, [the words <i>ki tov — that it was good</i>] are repeated, once in reference to the completion of the work associated with the waters, and once in reference to [the completion of the other work of] that day.”

Verse 11

AND G-D SAID: ‘LET THE EARTH PUT FORTH GRASS.’ He decreed that there be among the products of the earth a force which grows and bears seed so that the species should exist forever. It is possible that the name “earth” mentioned in the first verse already contains a hint that a force which causes things to grow should spring up from the earth, and it was from this force that the foundations of all vegetations according to their kinds emanated. From them sprang the grass and trees in the garden of Eden, and from them came those in the world. This is what the Rabbis have said:<sup class="footnote-marker">134</sup><i class="footnote">The source is not definite. See Pirke d’Rabbi Eliezer, Chapter 3.</i> “On the third day He created three creations: trees, grass, and the garden of Eden.” They have also said:<sup class="footnote-marker">135</sup><i class="footnote">Bereshith Rabbah 10:7.</i> “There is not a single blade of grass below [that does not have] a constellation in heaven that smites it and says to it, ‘Grow.’ It is this which Scripture says, <i>Knowest thou the ordinances of the heavens? Canst thou establish ‘mishtaro’ (the dominion thereof) in the earth?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">136</sup><i class="footnote">Job 38:33.</i> — [<i>mishtaro</i> being derived from the root] <i>shoter</i> (executive officer).”<br>And He said that all this vegetation should be <i>after its kind</i>. This is the basis of the prohibition of sowing mixed kinds of seeds,<sup class="footnote-marker">137</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 19:19.</i> since he who sows them works contrary to the power of the work of creation. I will yet explain this<sup class="footnote-marker">137</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 19:19.</i> with the help of G-d.<br>Now Rabbeinu Shlomo [Rashi] wrote: “<i>Deshe essev (grass, herb). Deshe</i> does not mean the same as <i>esev</i> and <i>esev</i> does not mean the same as <i>deshe</i>, for by <i>deshe</i> is meant that which forms the covering of the ground when it is filled with vegetation, and it is not linguistically correct to say ‘this or that <i>deshe</i>.’ Each by itself is called this or that <i>esev</i>.”<br>This interpretation of Rashi is not correct. For if it were so, the word <i>deshe</i><sup class="footnote-marker">138</sup><i class="footnote">Chullin 60a.</i> could have no plural, and yet we find the Sages saying, “If a person grafted together two kinds of <i>deshaim</i>, what should the law be?”<sup class="footnote-marker">138</sup><i class="footnote">Chullin 60a.</i> And the Rabbi himself<sup class="footnote-marker">139</sup><i class="footnote">Rashi. The title <i>Harav</i> (the Rabbi, the Master) without specification of the name is used by Ramban only with reference to Rashi or Rambam. It is the highest mark of respect. Precedent for it is found in the Talmud where just the title <i>Rabbi</i> meant Rabbi Yehudah Hanasi, redactor of the Mishnah, and the title <i>Rav</i> was a reference to Abba Arucha, founder of the Babylonian Academy of Sura.</i> mentions <i>deshaim</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">140</sup><i class="footnote">That is, when Rashi writes, “For the species of <i>deshaim</i> are different; each by itself called this or that <i>esev</i>.”</i> Rather, <i>deshe</i> is the young growing plant, and <i>esev</i> is the mature product which produces seeds. This is why Scripture says, <i>‘tadshei ha’aretz’ (let the earth put forth) ‘deshe’ (young plants)</i>, and it would not be correct usage to say <i>ta’asiv</i> [for the word <i>esev</i> applies to mature products which produce seeds]. And every young thing that grows from the earth is called <i>deshe</i>, even trees. Therefore <i>tadshei ha’aretz</i> in the verse extends also to the expression <i>etz pri</i> (the fruit-tree). [This interpretation is necessary] since He did not say, “Let the earth put forth <i>deshe esev</i> and <i>let it bring forth</i> the fruit-tree.” The word <i>deshe</i> thus has the same meaning as <i>tz’michah</i> (growing). Similarly we find: <i>For the pasture of the wilderness ‘dash’u’ (do spring), for the tree beareth its fruit</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">141</sup><i class="footnote">Joel 2:22.</i><br>I wonder why Scripture did not mention the creation of fruitless trees, and how is it that He commanded only concerning fruit-trees? Perhaps this is what induced our Rabbis to say,<sup class="footnote-marker">142</sup><i class="footnote">Bereshith Rabbah 5:9.</i> “Even the presently barren trees at first bore fruit.” If so, we must say that since the imprecation [which was visited upon Adam for his sin] — <i>Cursed be the ground for thy sake</i><sup class="footnote-marker">143</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 3:17.</i> — barren trees came into existence. But it is possible that the explanation of the verse before us is as follows: “Let the earth bring forth growing things, and herbs which yield seed and trees which bear fruit.” Thus He decreed at first the creation of barren herbs and barren trees in general, and then He specified herbs which yield seed and trees which bear fruit. From what He said later on — <i>bearing fruit… wherein is the seed thereof</i> — we may derive that all trees were to grow from their seed although it is the custom with some trees to be propagated by planting a branch.

Verse 12

AND G-D SAW THAT IT WAS GOOD. This affirms the existence of the various kinds forever.<br>There was no special day assigned for this command for vegetation alone, since it is not a unique work. The earth, whether it brings forth anything or is salt land, is one.

Verse 13



Verse 14

LET THERE BE LIGHTS. Now the light was created on the first day, illuminating the elements, but when on the second day the firmament was made, it intercepted the light and prevented it from illuminating the lower elements. Thus, when the earth was created on the third day there was darkness on it and not light. And now on the fourth day the Holy One, blessed be He, desired that there be in the firmament luminaries, the light of which would reach the earth. This is the meaning of the words, <i>in the firmament of the heaven to give light upon the earth</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">144</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 17.</i> for there already was light above the firmament which did not illuminate the earth.<br>The meaning of the words, <i>Let there be lights</i>, is as follows: He decreed on the first day that from the substance of the heavens there should come forth a light for the period of the day, and now He decreed that it become corporeal and that a luminous body come forth from it which would give light during the day with a great illumination, and that another body of lesser light [should come into existence] to illumine at night, and He suspended both in the firmament of the heavens in order that they illumine below as well.<br>It is possible that just as He endowed the earth with the power of growth in certain places thereof, so He placed in the firmament certain areas that are prepared and ready to receive the light, and these bodies which receive the light reflect it, just as window-panes and onyx stones. This is why He called them <i>me’oroth</i> and not <i>orim</i>. [<i>Orim</i> would imply that they have their own light; <i>me’oroth</i> on the other hand implies that they reflect the light which they receive], even though they are called <i>orim</i>, in the Psalm.<sup class="footnote-marker">145</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 136:7. <i>To Him that made great ‘orim’ (lights)</i>.</i>
TO DIVIDE THE DAY FROM THE NIGHT. Rashi wrote: “This took place after the primeval light was concealed for the righteous, but during the six<sup class="footnote-marker">146</sup><i class="footnote">In our text of Rashi: “seven.” See my note to Berliner’s edition of Rashi (p. 436) that both texts can be explained as correct.</i> days of creation the [primeval] light and darkness functioned, one by day and one by night.”<sup class="footnote-marker">147</sup><i class="footnote">In our text of Rashi: “functioned together both by day and by night.” However, during the seven days of creation it was the primeval light that functioned, its concealment taking place on the eve following the Sabbath (so clearly explained in Maharal’s commentary on Rashi — Gur Aryeh).</i><br>Now I do not see that this is the opinion of our Rabbis who mention concealment in connection with the primeval light. In their opinion, rather, the primeval light functioned for three days, and on the fourth an emanation took place from which was formed these two luminaries, just as the Rabbis have said,<sup class="footnote-marker">148</sup><i class="footnote">Bereshith Rabbah 17:7.</i> “The sphere of the sun is an offshoot of the upper light.” For since this world was not deserving of being served by this primeval light without an intermediary, He concealed it for the righteous in the World to Come, and He made use of this offshoot of the upper light from the fourth day on. Thus the Rabbis said in Bereshith Rabbah:<sup class="footnote-marker">149</sup><i class="footnote">3:6.</i> “It was taught: The light which was created during the six days of creation could not give light at daytime because it would then dim the sphere of the sun; at night it could not give light, since it was created to light only at daytime. So where is it? It was concealed. And where is it? It is prepared for the righteous in the hereafter, as it is said, <i>And the light of the moon shall be as the light of the sun, and as the light of the seven days</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">150</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 30:26.</i> ‘Seven?’ I wonder! Were they not three?<sup class="footnote-marker">151</sup><i class="footnote">For since the present light was created on the fourth day, the primeval light functioned only for the first three days during Creation.</i> It is like a man who says thus: ‘I am keeping this for the seven days of my wedding feast.’” That is to say, it is common parlance that one say: “I am keeping and guarding this meat for the seven days of my wedding festivity.” It is not that this would suffice him for all seven days, only that he will use it during that time. In the same way the Rabbis explained the expression <i>seven days</i>, meaning as the light which functioned during some of those days.<br>There in Bereshith Rabbah the Rabbis also said:<sup class="footnote-marker">152</sup><i class="footnote">3:7.</i> “<i>And He separated the light</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">153</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 4.</i> Rabbi Yehudah the son of Rabbi Simon said, ‘He separated it for Himself.’<sup class="footnote-marker">154</sup><i class="footnote">Just as the verse says, <i>And the light dwelleth with Him</i>. (Daniel 2:22).</i> And the Rabbis say, ‘He separated it for the righteous in the hereafter.’” Now if you could know the intent of the Rabbis in their saying in the Blessing of the Moon,<sup class="footnote-marker">155</sup><i class="footnote">Sanhedrin 42a.</i> “A crown of glory to those borne by Him from the birth,” you would know the secret of the primeval light, the conserving thereof, and the matter of separation mentioned [in the words of Rabbi Yehudah the son of Rabbi Simon] — i.e., “He separated it for Himself” — as well as the secret of “the two kings making use of one crown,”<sup class="footnote-marker">156</sup><i class="footnote">Chullin 60 b, and mentioned in Rashi here, Verse 16: “The sun and the moon were created of equal size. When the moon complained, ‘It is impossible for two kings to make use of one crown,’ G-d said to it, ‘Go and diminish thyself.’”</i> as will indeed be the case at the end when <i>the light of the moon shall be as the light of the sun</i> after <i>the light of the sun shall be sevenfold</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">150</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 30:26.</i>
AND THEY SHALL BE FOR SIGNS. These are the changes which they will bring forth, making signs and wonders <i>in the heavens and in the earth, blood, and fire, and pillars of smoke</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">157</sup><i class="footnote">Joel 3:3.</i> This is similar in meaning to the expression, <i>And be not dismayed at the signs of heaven</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">158</sup><i class="footnote">Jeremiah 10:2.</i>
AND FOR SEASONS. This means <i>seedtime and harvest, and cold and heat, and summer and winter</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">159</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 8:22.</i>
AND FOR DAYS. This means the length of day and the length of night.
AND YEARS. The luminaries are to complete their orbit and then traverse again the same course they followed, thus making the solar year consist of 365 days and the lunar year consist of [lunar cycles, each approximately] 30 days.

Verse 15

AND THEY SHALL BE FOR LIGHTS IN THE FIRMAMENT OF THE HEAVEN TO GIVE LIGHT UPON THE EARTH. He added here that their light should reach the earth since it is possible for the light to be seen in the heavens and perform all mentioned functions without lighting upon the earth. Hence He said that it <i>be for lights in the firmament of the heaven</i>, directed toward the earth and shining upon it.

Verse 16

AND G-D MADE. 17. AND G-D SET THEM. This teaches us that these lights were not made from the body of the firmament, rather, they were bodies set into it.

Verse 17



Verse 18

AND TO RULE OVER THE DAY AND OVER THE NIGHT. The matter of rulership is a different matter from the function of light which He mentioned, since it includes that which He stated at first, <i>And they shall be for signs, and seasons</i>. Their rulership over the earth comprises the changes which they cause in it and the power of bringing about the existence and deterioration of all things in the lower world since the sun, by its rule during the day, causes the sprouting, the propagation and the growth of all the warm and dry things, while the moon by its rule increases the springs and the oceans, and all liquid and cold things. Therefore He said in a general way, <i>And to rule over the day and over the night</i>, because theirs is the dominion over things in the lower world.<br>It is possible that the rulership given to them contains also a power of emanation for they are the leaders of things in the lower world, and with their power, every ruling power in nature holds sway. Thus the constellation which comes up by day rules during it, even as it is written, <i>The sun and the moon and the stars… which the Eternal thy G-d hath allotted unto all the peoples</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">160</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 4:19.</i> And this is what Scripture means when it says, <i>He counteth the number of the stars; He giveth them all their names</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">161</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 147:4.</i> likewise, <i>He calleth them all by name</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">162</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 40:26.</i> For the calling of names signifies the differentiation in their respective powers, giving to this one the power of justice and righteousness, and to that one the power of blood and the sword, and similarly all other powers, as is known in astrology. And all is done by the power of the Most High and in accordance with His Will. Therefore it says, <i>Great is our Lord, and mighty in power</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">163</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 147:5.</i> for He is greatest of all and mightiest in power over them. And similarly it says, <i>He calleth them all by name by the greatness of His might and the strength of His power</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">162</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 40:26.</i> In accord with the secret I have hinted to you, the matter of rulership is completely true.
AND TO DIVIDE THE LIGHT FROM THE DARKNESS. Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra said: “By the coming forth of the sun at daytime and the light of the moon at night, they shall divide the light from the darkness.”<sup class="footnote-marker">164</sup><i class="footnote">Ibn Ezra’s opinion is that the word <i>ul’havdil</i> (and to divide) refers to both the sun and moon, that each in coming forth separates between light and darkness. (Tur.)</i> In my opinion, the light mentioned here refers to the day, and the darkness is the night for such are their names, as it says, <i>And G-d called the light Day, and the darkness He called Night</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">165</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 5. Thus according to Ramban, the meaning of the verse is: “and to divide <i>the day</i> from <i>the night</i>,” meaning, that light is to serve at daytime and darkness at night. (Tur.)</i><br>Now in connection with all the works of creation, Scripture mentions the Divine command and then tells of the deed. And here too He commanded, <i>And they shall be for lights</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">166</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 15.</i> and then it relates, <i>And G-d set them</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">167</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 17.</i> He further said, <i>And to rule over the day and over the night</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">168</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 18.</i> meaning that one is to rule by day and the other by night, the rulership being that which He commanded when He said, <i>And they shall be for signs, and for seasons</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">169</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 14.</i> And now He related that the rulership of the two is not alike but instead consists of dividing the darkness from the light. The greater luminary will rule by day and light will be everywhere, even where the sun does not reach, and the smaller luminary will rule by night, and there will be darkness except that the moon will lighten its darkness. This then is the command He gave in order <i>to divide the day from the night</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">169</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 14.</i> as it says, <i>And G-d divided the light from the darkness</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">153</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 4.</i>

Verse 19



Verse 20

LET THE WATERS SWARM WITH ‘SHERETZ’ (SWARMS) OF LIVING CREATURES. Rashi wrote: “Every living creature that does not rise much above the ground is called <i>sheretz</i>, [e.g., species] of winged creatures such as flies; of abominable creatures such as ants and worms; of larger creatures such as the mole and the mouse and others of the same kind, and all fishes.”<br>But what will the Rabbi<sup class="footnote-marker">170</sup><i class="footnote">Rashi. See Note 139.</i> say of the verse, <i>And you, be ye fruitful, and multiply; ‘shirtzu’ (swarm) in the earth and multiply therein</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">171</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 9:7.</i> which was said to Noah and his sons? Likewise, the verse stating, <i>which ‘hamayim’ (the waters) swarmed</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">172</sup><i class="footnote">In Verse 21.</i> should, according to this opinion of Rashi, read: “Which swarmed <i>bamayim</i> (in the waters).”<sup class="footnote-marker">173</sup><i class="footnote">Since, according to Rashi, they swarm <i>in</i> the waters.</i> Again there are many winged creatures that do not rise in height above the ground even as much as the mole and mouse, and the bat has very small legs, so why should it not be called <i>sheretz ha’oph</i> (a winged swarming thing)?<br>Onkelos’ opinion is that the term <i>shritzah</i> (swarming) has an implication of movement. Thus he says of both <i>sheretz</i> and <i>remes: richasha d’rachish</i> (moving things that move).<sup class="footnote-marker">174</sup><i class="footnote">This expression of Onkelos is found in Leviticus 11:44, where the Hebrew reads, <i>hasheretz haromes</i>, which Onkelos translated, <i>richasha d’rachish</i>. Thus it is obvious that Onkelos understood both words <i>(sheretz</i> and <i>remes)</i> as conveying a sense of movement.</i> He has explained it correctly. <i>Shratzim</i> are so called because of their constant movement. It is possible that it is a composite word: <i>sheretz, shehu ratz</i> (that which runs). <i>Remes</i> is so called because it creeps upon the earth and is never quiet or at rest.<br>Know that every winged creature that has four legs is called <i>sheretz ha’oph</i> (a winged creeping<sup class="footnote-marker">175</sup><i class="footnote">“Creeping,” according to Rashi, would be “swarming.”</i> thing) because it leans on its legs and moves like <i>shratzim</i>, and a winged creature which is not so is called <i>oph kanaph</i> (winged fowl) because its main method of movement is flying. The meaning of the verse, <i>‘Veshartzu’ in the earth and be fruitful, and multiply upon the earth</i><sup class="footnote-marker">176</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 8:17.</i> is thus: that they may walk<sup class="footnote-marker">177</sup><i class="footnote">Translations which read “that ‘they may swarm’ in the earth” are thus according to Rashi’s interpretation. Ramban, as here explained, understands the sense of the verse to be: “‘that they may move about’ the earth.”</i> upon the entire earth, and be fruitful and multiply upon it. <i>‘Shirtzu’ in the earth and multiply therein</i><sup class="footnote-marker">171</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 9:7.</i> means “move about the entire earth and multiply thereon.” This is the reason for the repetition of the word <i>ur’vu (and ye multiply)</i> in the verse.<sup class="footnote-marker">178</sup><i class="footnote">Quoted above: <i>And you be ye fruitful and multiply, ‘shirtzu’ in the earth and multiply therein</i> [9:7]. Thus the first expression <i>and multiply</i> establishes the commandment of procreation; the second refers to the duty of making the whole earth habitable for people.</i> This being so, we will explain the expression, <i>which the waters ‘shartzu,’</i><sup class="footnote-marker">172</sup><i class="footnote">In Verse 21.</i> as meaning “which the waters have moved and brought forth.” Similarly, the expression, <i>‘Vesharatz’ the river with frogs</i><sup class="footnote-marker">179</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 7:28.</i> [means that the river moved and brought forth frogs]. Also, <i>And the children of Israel were fruitful ‘vayishr’tzu,’</i><sup class="footnote-marker">180</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 1:7.</i> means that they were fruitful and they multiplied and moved about because of their multitude until the land was filled with them.<br>Onkelos, however, interpreted the verse, <i>‘Shirtzu’ in the earth</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">171</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 9:7.</i> as having reference to propagation. He thus translated, “Propagate in the land,” since he understood the word <i>shirtzu</i> — a verb — as being borrowed from the noun <i>shratzim</i> (reptiles). [The verse, according to Onkelos, thus states:] “And you, be ye fruitful and multiply, as the prolific creatures in the earth, and multiply therein.” Similarly, <i>And the children of Israel were fruitful ‘vayishr’tzu’</i><sup class="footnote-marker">180</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 1:7.</i> means they brought forth progeny abundantly as the prolific creatures.
AND LET FOWL FLY ABOVE THE EARTH. On this fifth day the command of creation was given to the waters, and on the sixth day it was given to the earth. If so, the expression, <i>and let fowl fly above the earth</i>, must be interpreted as being connected with [the beginning of the verse which has the following meaning]: “Let the waters swarm with swarms of living creatures and with fowl that will fly.” And the verse stating, <i>And the Eternal G-d formed out of the ground every beast of the field, and every fowl of the air</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">181</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 2:19.</i> [which seems to indicate that the fowl were created from the ground, not from the water, must be understood] as if it said: “And the Eternal G-d formed out of the earth every beast of the field, and He also formed every fowl of the air out of the water.” There are many verses like this. So also is the opinion of Rabbi Eliezer the Great in his Chapters,<sup class="footnote-marker">182</sup><i class="footnote">Beginning of Chapter 9.</i> where he says: “On the fifth day he caused all winged fowl to swarm from the waters.” However, in the <i>Gemara</i><sup class="footnote-marker">183</sup><i class="footnote">Chullin 27b.</i> the Sages differ on this point. Some, agreeing with the previously mentioned interpretation, say that all winged fowl were created from the waters, and some say that they were created from both — in their words, “they were created from the swamps.” If so, since the fowl sprang from the waters, and the swamps are at the bottom of the ocean, this is why the command concerning their creation took place on the fifth day.<br>Similarly He said, <i>Let the waters swarm with swarms of living creatures</i>, since both the body and soul of fish come from the waters by word of G-d Who brought upon them a spirit from the elements, unlike man, in whom He separated the body from his soul, as it is said, <i>And the Eternal G-d formed man of the dust of the ground, and breathed into his nostrils the breath of life</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">184</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 2:7.</i> On the third day of creation when the plants came into being, He mentioned nothing at all concerning a soul because the power of growth which resides in plants is not a “soul;” only in moving beings is it a “soul.” And in the opinion of the Greeks, who say that just as in moving beings the power of growth is only through the soul, so also in the case of plants is the power of growth through a soul. The difference between them will be that the one [the moving being] is a <i>nefesh chayah (a living soul)</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">185</sup><i class="footnote">In Verse 20: <i>Let the waters swarm with swarms of ‘nefesh chayah’ (a living soul)</i>. Same in Verse 24, in the creation of beasts, etc.</i> that is, a soul in which there is life, for there is a soul which has no life and that is the soul of plants. Our Rabbis have mentioned “desire” in connection with date trees.<sup class="footnote-marker">186</sup><i class="footnote">Bereshith Rabbah 44:1.</i> Perhaps this is a force in growth, but it cannot be called “a soul.”

Verse 21

AND G-D CREATED THE GREAT SEA-MONSTERS. Because of the great size of these creatures, some consisting of many Persian miles — the Greeks in their books even relate that they knew some of them to be 500 Persian miles long, and our Rabbi likewise spoke of them in magnifying terms<sup class="footnote-marker">187</sup><i class="footnote">Baba Bathra 73b.</i> — on account of that, Scripture explicitly ascribes their creation to G-d for He brought them forth from nought from the beginning, as I have explained the expression <i>b’riyah</i> (creation). Similarly, Scripture does so in the case of man<sup class="footnote-marker">188</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 27: <i>And G-d created man in His own image</i>.</i> on account of his exaltedness, thus informing us that man, with his mind and reason, also came forth from nought.<br>I wonder why it does not say “and it was so” on this day? Perhaps it would not have been possible to mention <i>And He created</i> after saying, “and it was so,” since it refers to the preceding.<sup class="footnote-marker">189</sup><i class="footnote">If Verse 20 (<i>Let the waters swarm with swarms of living creatures</i>, etc.) would have concluded with the expression <i>and it was so</i>, it would have implied the creation of the sea-monster, since they also swarm in the waters. How then could it say in the following verse, <i>And G-d created the sea-monster</i>, as if it were another act of creation? To say, <i>and it was so</i> after <i>vayibra</i> (And He created) is also not possible for this would be redundant. Hence on the fifth day, the expression <i>and it was so</i> does not appear in Scripture.</i><br>Our Rabbis have said<sup class="footnote-marker">190</sup><i class="footnote">Baba Bathra 74b.</i> that <i>the great sea-monsters</i> are the Leviathan and its mate which He created male and female. He then slew the female and preserved it in salt for the benefit of the righteous in the hereafter. It is possible that on account of this it would not have been appropriate to say concerning their creation, “and it was so,” since they did not continue to exist [in the form in which they were created].

Verse 22

AND G-D BLESSED THEM SAYING. He decreed the blessing on them and said of them that they should be fruitful and multiply, meaning that they should bring forth abundantly, that one creature should bring forth many like itself. The purport of the blessing is procreation, even as it says, <i>And I will bless her, and she shall be a mother of nations</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">191</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 17:16.</i> In connection with plants also, the term “blessing” applies: <i>Then I will command My blessing upon you in the sixth year</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">192</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 25:21.</i> However, it does not say so on the third day [when the plants and trees were created] because all created <i>living</i> beings were only a single pair, male and female, according to their kind, and therefore they were in need of a blessing to bring forth abundantly; but in the case of plants, they sprang up over the face of the entire earth in great abundance, just as they exist today. Nor did He mention a blessing on the sixth day for cattle and beasts because in the decree of abundancy which He decreed for the moving souls in the waters there were included the moving souls on the earth, as all living souls that do not speak are in the same class of creation. And our Rabbis have said<sup class="footnote-marker">193</sup><i class="footnote">Bereshith Rabbah 11:2, and quoted here in Rashi.</i> that they [the fish and fowl] were in need of a blessing because people hunt them and eat them.<sup class="footnote-marker">194</sup><i class="footnote">“Beasts also were in need of a blessing [for the same reason, namely, that people decrease their numbers by hunting them and eating them], but on account of the serpent that was to be cursed in the future, G-d did not bless them, in order that it might not be included in the blessing. “ Rashi.</i>
AND FILL THE WATERS IN THE SEA. He blessed them that in their abundancy they would fill the seas, the streams and the pools. Or it may be that their “filling” is to be in the seas only for in the streams they are few.
AND LET FOWL MULTIPLY IN THE EARTH. Although the fowl were created out of the waters, their blessing — that they be fruitful and multiply — was to be on the earth for there is no fowl that lays its eggs in the waters and has them grow there. Even those fowl which abide always in the waters and derive their food from them lay their eggs on the earth, and there they are born.

Verse 23



Verse 24

CATTLE. These are the species that eat grass, whether domestic animals or those of the wilderness.
AND BEAST OF THE EARTH. Those which eat flesh are called <i>chayoth</i> (beasts), and they all seek and seize prey.
VAREMES’ (AND CREEPING THING). Rashi wrote: “These are creeping swarms that creep low upon the earth, appearing as though they are dragged along.” Now in this chapter we find: <i>And over every animal ‘haromeseth’ (that creepeth) upon the earth;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">195</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 28. Here Rashi’s interpretation could not apply to animal.</i> and it is further written, <i>And all flesh ‘haromes’ (that moved) upon the earth perished, both fowl and cattle, and beasts, and every swarming thing that swarmeth upon the earth;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">196</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 7:21.</i> also, <i>Wherein all the beasts of the forest ‘tirmos’ (do creep forth)</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">197</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 104:20.</i> But the meaning of <i>r’misah</i> is as if it were written with the letter <i>samech</i>, as in <i>The foot tirm’senah (shall tread it down)</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">198</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 26:6.</i> and other related expressions. He thus says of beasts and cattle, <i>‘romes’ (that tread) on the earth</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">199</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 26.</i> and of creeping things that drag along, <i>‘remes’ (that creep) upon the ground</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">200</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 25.</i> because they tread on the ground with their entire body.

Verse 25



Verse 26

AND G-D SAID: ‘LET US MAKE MAN.’ There was a special command dedicated to the making of man because of his great superiority since his nature is unlike that of beasts and cattle which were created with the preceding command.<br>The correct explanation of <i>na’aseh (let us make)</i> [which is in the plural form when it should have been in the singular] is as follows: It has been shown to you that G-d created something from nothing only on the first day, and afterwards He formed and made things from those created elements.<sup class="footnote-marker">201</sup><i class="footnote">Fire, wind, water, and earth.</i> Thus when He gave the waters the power of bringing forth <i>a living soul</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">202</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 20.</i> the command concerning them was <i>Let the waters swarm</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">202</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 20.</i> The command concerning cattle was <i>Let the earth bring forth</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">203</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 24.</i> But in the case of man He said, <i>Let us make</i>, that is, I and the aforementioned earth, let us make man, the earth to bring forth the body from its elements as it did with cattle and beasts, as it is written, <i>And the Eternal G-d formed man of the dust of the ground</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">204</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 2:7.</i> and He, blessed be He, to give the spirit from His mouth, the Supreme One, as it is written, <i>And He breathed into his nostrils the breath of life</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">204</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 2:7.</i> And He said, <i>In our image, and after our likeness</i>, as man will then be similar to both. In the capacity of his body, he will be similar to the earth from which he was taken, and in spirit he will be similar to the higher beings, because it [the spirit] is not a body and will not die. In the second verse, He says, <i>In the image of G-d He created him</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">205</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 27.</i> in order to relate the distinction by which man is distinguished from the rest of created beings. The explanation of this verse I have found ascribed to Rabbi Joseph the Kimchite,<sup class="footnote-marker">206</sup><i class="footnote">The father of Rabbi David Kimchi (R’dak, the famous grammarian and commentator of the Bible). The explanation is found in R’dak’s commentary to the Torah here as well as in his Sefer Hamichlal. In his works on Hebrew grammar and Bible, R’dak often mentions the interpretation of his father. Moses Kimchi, a second son to Joseph, also continued the tradition of the family.</i> and is the most acceptable of all interpretations that have been advanced concerning it.<br>The meaning of <i>tzelem</i> is as the word <i>to’ar</i> (appearance), as in <i>‘Vetzelem’ (And the appearance) of his face was changed;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">207</sup><i class="footnote">Daniel 3:19.</i> similarly, <i>Surely ‘b’tzelem’ (as a mere appearance) man walketh;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">208</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 39:7.</i> <i>When Thou arousest Thyself ‘tzalmam’ (their appearance) Thou wilt despise</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">209</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 73:20.</i> that is, the appearance of their countenance. And the meaning of the word <i>d’muth</i> is similarity in form and deed, as things that are akin in a certain matter are called similar to each other. Thus man is similar both to the lower and higher beings in appearance and honor, as it is written, <i>And Thou hast crowned him with glory and honor</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">210</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 8:6.</i> meaning that the goal before him is wisdom, knowledge, and skill of deed.<sup class="footnote-marker">211</sup><i class="footnote">Ecclesiastes 2:21;4:4.</i> In real likeness his body thus compares to the earth while his soul is similar to the higher beings.
AND LET THEM HAVE DOMINION OVER THE FISH OF THE SEA. On account of his [man’s] being male and female, he said, <i>And let ‘them’ have dominion over the fish of the sea</i>, in the plural.<br>In Bereshith Rabbah, the Rabbis have said:<sup class="footnote-marker">212</sup><i class="footnote">7:7.</i> “<i>Let the earth bring forth a living soul after its kind</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">203</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 24.</i> Said Rabbi Elazar: ‘<i>A living soul</i> — this has reference to the spirit of the first man.’” Now it is impossible that Rabbi Elazar should say that the expression, <i>Let the earth bring forth</i>, be explained as having reference to the soul of the first man at all.<sup class="footnote-marker">213</sup><i class="footnote">Since man did not at all derive his higher soul from the earth at all.</i> Instead, his intent is to say what I have mentioned, that the formation of man as regarding his spirit, namely, the soul which is in the blood, that was done from the earth, just as in the command of formation of the beasts and cattle. For the souls of all moving things were made at one time, and afterwards He created bodies for them. First He made the bodies of the cattle and the beasts, and then the body of man into whom He imparted this soul [which resides in the blood, and is akin to that of the cattle and beasts], and afterwards, He breathed into him a higher soul. For it is concerning this separate soul that a special command was devoted by G-d Who gave it, as it is written, <i>And He breathed into his nostrils the breath of life</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">204</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 2:7.</i><br>The way of truth in this verse [as to why Scripture begins with “man” in the singular — <i>let us make ‘man’</i> — and then uses the plural, <i>let ‘them’ have dominion</i>] will be known to him who understands the following verse [27, where the same change appears. It begins by stating, <i>in the image of G-d He created ‘him,’</i> and then uses the plural: <i>male and female He created ‘them’</i>.]<br>It is possible that Rabbi Elazar meant to explain the expression <i>Let the earth bring forth</i> as meaning “the earth of eternal life,” that it bring forth a living soul after its kind that will exist forever. Similarly, [we explain that when Scripture] said, <i>male and female He created them</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">205</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 27.</i> it is because man’s creation at first was male and female, and His soul was included in both of them. However, in the formation, man was formed first, and then He built the woman from the rib of man, as Scripture tells later. Therefore Scripture mentioned here the term “creation,” and in the chapter below it mentioned “formation.”<sup class="footnote-marker">204</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 2:7.</i> The person learned [in the mysteries of the Torah] will understand.<br>The meaning of <i>let them have dominion</i> is that they shall rule vigorously over the fish, the fowl, the cattle, and all creeping things — “the cattle” here includes the beast.<br>And He said, <i>And over all the earth</i>, to indicate that they are to rule over the earth itself, to uproot and to pull down, to dig and to hew out copper and iron. The term <i>r’diyah — [’v’yirdu’ over the fish … and over all the earth]</i> — applies to the rule of the master over his servant.

Verse 27



Verse 28

AND G-D BLESSED THEM. This is an actual blessing [unlike Verse 22 where the blessing of the fish and fowl consisted of bestowing upon them the power of procreation]. Therefore, it is written here, <i>And G-d blessed them, and G-d said unto them</i>. But above in Verse 22 it is written, <i>And G-d blessed them, saying</i>, [the word <i>saying</i> indicating] that the blessing is the command of procreation, that He gave them the power of bringing forth offspring, and no other command with which they are to be blessed. [But in the case of man, in addition to the power of being fruitful, he was also blessed that he have dominion over the earth, hence Scripture continues, <i>and G-d said unto them</i>.]
AND REPLENISH THE EARTH. This is a blessing that they fill the earth because of their numbers. In my opinion, He blessed them that they fill the whole earth, and that the nations should disperse according to their families and should populate the far ends of the world because of their numbers and not be concentrated in one place, as was the thought of the men of the generation of the dispersion.
AND SUBDUE IT. He gave them power and dominion over the earth to do as they wish with the cattle, the reptiles, and all that crawl in the dust, and to build, <i>and to pluck up that which is planted</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">214</sup><i class="footnote">Ecclesiastes 3:2.</i> and from its hills to dig copper, and other similar things. This is included in what He said <i>and over all the earth</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">199</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 26.</i>
AND HAVE DOMINION OVER THE FISH OF THE SEA. He said that they should also have dominion over the fish that are concealed from them, <i>And over the fowl of the heaven</i> which are not on the ground, and also <i>over every wild animal</i>. He thus mentioned them in the order of their creation: first the fish and fowl, and afterwards the animals. So likewise Scripture says, <i>Thou hast made him have dominion over the works of Thy hands; Thou hast put all things under his feet: sheep and oxen, all of them, yea, and the beasts of the field, the fowl of the air, and the fish of the sea</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">215</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 8:7-9. In Keseph Mezukak the author notes that this Scriptural quote should be preceded by the expression, “even if Scripture elsewhere does <i>not</i> state them in this order” since in this quotation fowl and fish are after all mentioned last in order.</i> Our Rabbis, however, have made a distinction between <i>kvishah</i> (subduing) and <i>r’diyah</i> (having dominion).<sup class="footnote-marker">216</sup><i class="footnote">Thus the Rabbis, in Bereshith Rabbah 8:12, say that while the terms <i>kvishah</i> and <i>r’diyah</i> imply power and dominion, <i>r’diyah</i> also suggests <i>yeridah</i> (sinking low). Thus, if man is worthy he dominates (<i>rodeh</i>) over the beasts and cattle; if he is not worthy, he sinks lower (<i>yarud</i>) than they, and the beasts rule over him.</i>

Verse 29

BEHOLD, I HAVE GIVEN YOU EVERY HERB YIELDING SEED. He did not permit Adam and his wife to kill any creature and eat its meat, but all alike were to eat herbs. But when the era of “the sons of Noah” came, He permitted them to eat meat, as it is said, <i>Every moving thing that liveth shall be for food for you; as the green herb have I given you all;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">217</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 9:3.</i> even as the green herb that I permitted to the first man, so do I permit you everything. Thus is the language of Rashi. And so did the Rabbi<sup class="footnote-marker">218</sup><i class="footnote">Rashi.</i> explain it in Tractate Sanhedrin:<sup class="footnote-marker">219</sup><i class="footnote">59b.</i> <i>“And to every beast of the earth</i><sup class="footnote-marker">220</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 30.</i> — to you and to the beasts I have given the herbs and the fruits of the trees, <i>and every green herb for food.”</i><sup class="footnote-marker">220</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 30.</i><br>But if so, then we must explain the expression, <i>every green herb for food</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">220</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 30.</i> to mean “<i>and</i> every green herb.”<sup class="footnote-marker">221</sup><i class="footnote">The intent of Ramban’s remark is as follows: if, as according to Rashi, man and beast were made alike with respect to their permitted food, then Verse 29, which specifies the food for man, and Verse 30, which begins with <i>and to every beast of the earth</i> and concludes with <i>every green herb for food</i>, are to be understood as one command since both man and beast were permitted the same food. In that case, Verse 30 should read: “<i>and</i> every green herb,” that is, in addition to <i>every herb yielding seed… and every tree, in which is the fruit of a tree yielding seed</i> mentioned in Verse 29, they could also eat <i>every green herb</i>.</i> But this is not so. Rather, He gave to man and his wife every herb yielding seed and all fruit of the trees [as mentioned in Verse 29], and to the beasts of the earth and the fowl of the heaven He gave all green herb [as mentioned in Verse 30] but neither the fruit of the tree nor the seeds. The food of all of them was thus not the same. However, meat was not permitted to them until the time of the “sons of Noah,”<sup class="footnote-marker">222</sup><i class="footnote">After the flood all people of all time were commanded to observe as a minimum the following seven precepts: (a) to establish courts of justice; (b) to abstain from idolatry; (c) incest; (d) murder; (e) robbery; (f) blasphemy; and (g) eating flesh cut from living animals. These are the laws of Noachids, or “sons of Noah.” (See further Ramban 34:13.) At that time permission was given them to eat meat, the reason for which is explained in the text.</i> as is the opinion of our Rabbis. And this is the plain meaning of the verse.<br>The reason for this [prohibition of eating meat] was that creatures possessing a moving soul have a certain superiority as regards their soul, resembling in a way those who possess the rational soul: they have the power of choice affecting their welfare and their food, and they flee from pain and death. And Scripture says: <i>Who knoweth the spirit of man whether it goeth upward, and the spirit of the beast whether it goes downward to the earth?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">223</sup><i class="footnote">Ecclesiastes 3:21.</i><br>But when they sinned, and <i>all flesh had corrupted its way upon the earth</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">224</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 6:12.</i> and it was decreed that they die in the flood, and for the sake of Noah He saved some of them to preserve the species, He gave the sons of Noah permission to slaughter and eat them since their existence was for his sake.<sup class="footnote-marker">225</sup><i class="footnote">That is, Noah’s sake. The Tur’s version reads “<i>their</i> sake,” a reference to all three sons of Noah who were also righteous. See Ramban further, 2:3, where he discusses the profounder meanings of the elements created on the second day, and he writes that they symbolize Noah and his sons as all having been <i>tzadikim</i> (righteous men).</i> Yet with all this, He did not give them permission regarding the soul thereof, and He prohibited them from eating a limb cut off from a living animal, and in addition He gave us [the children of Israel] the commandment prohibiting the eating of all blood because it is the basis of the soul, as it is written: <i>For the life of all flesh, the blood thereof is all one with the life thereof; therefore I said to the children of Israel: Ye shall eat the blood of no manner of flesh; for the life of all flesh is the blood thereof</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">226</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 17:14.</i> Thus He has permitted the eating of the body of dumb animals after death, but not the soul itself.<br>This indeed is the reason for the commandment of killing [animals in the prescribed manner before eating their flesh], and for the saying of the Rabbis:<sup class="footnote-marker">227</sup><i class="footnote">Shabbath 128b.</i> “The duty of relieving the suffering of beasts is a Biblical requirement.” And this is the meaning behind the benediction which we make before killing animals: “[Blessed art Thou, O Eternal our G-d, king of the universe] Who hast sanctified us by His commandments and commanded us concerning the killing [of animals].” I will yet discuss the purport of the commandment prohibiting the eating of blood when I reach thereto,<sup class="footnote-marker">228</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 17:14.</i> if G-d will reward me.<br>The meaning of the expression, <i>every herb yielding seed… and every tree, in which is the fruit of a tree yielding seed; to you it shall be for food</i>, is that they should eat the seeds of herbs, such as the grains of wheat, barley, beans, and the like, and that they should eat all fruits of the tree; but the tree itself was not given to them for food, nor was the herb itself until man was cursed and he was told, <i>And thou shalt eat the herb of the field</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">229</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 3:18.</i>

Verse 30



Verse 31

AND, BEHOLD, IT WAS VERY GOOD. This signifies their permanent existence, as I have explained.<sup class="footnote-marker">230</sup><i class="footnote">Above in Verses 4 and 12.</i> The meaning of the word <i>me’od</i> (very) is “mostly.” On this sixth day He added this word because he is speaking of creation in general which contains evil in some part of it. Thus He said that <i>it was very good</i>, meaning its <i>me’od</i> is good [thus conveying the thought that even the small part of it which is evil is basically also good, as is explained further on]. It is this thought which is the basis of the saying of the Rabbis in Bereshith Rabbah:<sup class="footnote-marker">231</sup><i class="footnote">9:5.</i> “<i>And, behold, it was very good. And, behold, it was good</i> — this refers to death.” Similarly the Rabbis mentioned, “This means the evil inclination in man,”<sup class="footnote-marker">232</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 9. “Were it not for the evil inclination, no one would build a house or marry a woman.”</i> and, “This means the dispensation of punishment.”<sup class="footnote-marker">233</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i> “He considers well how to mete it out” so as to cause a minimum of suffering.</i> Onkelos also intended to convey this thought for he said here, “And, behold, it was very orderly,” meaning that the order was very properly arranged since the evil is needed for the preservation of the good, just as it is said, <i>To every thing there is a season, and a time to every purpose under the heaven</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">234</sup><i class="footnote">Ecclesiastes 3:1.</i> Some Rabbis explain<sup class="footnote-marker">235</sup><i class="footnote">Bereshith Rabbah 9:14.</i> that on account of the superiority of man, He added special praise on his formation, i.e., that he is “very good.”

Chapter 2



Verse 1

AND ALL THE HOST OF THEM. “The host of the earth” are those which have been mentioned: beasts, creeping things, fish, and all growing things, and also man. “The host of the heavens” are the two luminaries and the stars, mentioned above, just as it is written: <i>And lest thou lift up thine eyes unto heaven, and when thou seest the sun and the moon and the stars, even all the host of heaven</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">236</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 4:19.</i> It also includes the Separate Intelligences,<sup class="footnote-marker">237</sup><i class="footnote">Intelligences without matter, generally referring to the angels and spheres. See Rambam, Hilchoth Yesodei Hatorah 3:9. Also Moreh Nebuchim, I, 49: “The angels are likewise incorporeal; they are intelligences without matter, etc.” (Friedlander’s translation.)</i> just as it is written: <i>I saw the Eternal sitting on His throne, and all the host of heaven standing by Him;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">238</sup><i class="footnote">I Kings 22:19.</i> also, <i>The Eternal will punish the host of the high heaven on high</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">239</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 24:21.</i> It is here [in the expression, <i>all the host of them</i>], that He has hinted at the formation of the angels in the work of creation. Similarly, the souls of men are included in the host of heaven.<sup class="footnote-marker">240</sup><i class="footnote">Ramban is thus inferring that the souls of all men of all generations were created at the beginning of creation. This thought is clearly expressed in the other writings of Ramban. (See Ramban’s letter to Rabbeinu Yonah, Kithvei Haramban, Vol. I, 383. See also in same volume his Commentary to Job 38:21, p. 117).</i>

Verse 2



Verse 3

AND G-D BLESSED THE SEVENTH DAY AND HE SANCTIFIED IT. He blessed it through the Manna. [On all other days of the week there fell one portion per person, whereas on the sixth day — the eve of the Sabbath — a double portion fell.] And He sanctified it through the Manna [by not having it fall on the Sabbath]. And the verse is written here with reference to the future. Thus are the words of Rabbeinu Shlomo [Rashi] as quoted from Bereshith Rabbah.<sup class="footnote-marker">241</sup><i class="footnote">11:2.</i> In the name of the Gaon Rav Saadia<sup class="footnote-marker">242</sup><i class="footnote">Mentioned in Ibn Ezra here.</i> they have said that the blessing and sanctification refer to those who observe the Sabbath, meaning that they will be blessed and sanctified. However, from the intimation of the verse it does not appear that it refers to something which will happen in the future.<br>And Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra said that the blessing signifies additional well-being, that on the seventh day there is a renewal of procreative strength in the body, and in the soul, a greater capacity in the functioning of the reasoning power. <i>And He sanctified it</i> by not working on it as He did on the other days. Now Ibn Ezra’s interpretation is correct to those who believe in it for this additional well-being he speaks of is not perceptible to human senses.<br>The truth is that the blessing on the Sabbath day is the fountain of blessings and constitutes the foundation of the world. <i>And He sanctified it</i> that it draw its sanctity from the Sanctuary on high. If you will understand this comment of mine you will grasp what the Rabbis have said in Bereshith Rabbah<sup class="footnote-marker">243</sup><i class="footnote">11:9.</i> concerning the Sabbath: [“Why did He bless the Sabbath? It is] because it has no partner,”<sup class="footnote-marker">244</sup><i class="footnote">“Because it has no…” (<i>l’phi sh’e</i>) is a direct quote from the Midrash there. (See Theodore’s ed. of Bereshith Rabbah, p. 95, variants.) In the printed edition of the Midrash, the word <i>l’phi</i> (because) is missing.</i> and that which they have further related [that G-d said to the Sabbath]: “The congregation of Israel will be thy partner.” And then you will comprehend that on the Sabbath there is truly an extra soul.
WHICH G-D IN CREATING HAD MADE. The work which should have been done on the Sabbath, He did in the double work which He executed on the sixth day, as it is explained in Bereshith Rabbah.<sup class="footnote-marker">245</sup><i class="footnote">11:10.</i> So says Rashi.<br>Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra, however, explained simply that <i>His work</i> refers to the roots of all species to which He gave the power <i>to make</i> [i.e., to produce] after their own kind. [Thus the verse would translate: <i>which G-d had created in order to make it</i>.]<br>To me, the explanation appears to be that <i>He rested from all His work which He created</i> out of nothing; <i>to make</i> from it all the works mentioned on the six days. Thus the verse is stating that G-d rested from creating and forming — from the creation He created on the first day, and from the formation He formed on the rest of the days. And it is possible that the word <i>la’asoth</i> (to make) is connected with the expression above in the verse, <i>that in it He rested from all His work which He created</i> from <i>making</i>, [thus making the word <i>la’asoth</i> to be understood as <i>mila’asoth</i> (from making)]. So also are the verses: <i>Until he ceased ‘lispor’</i><sup class="footnote-marker">246</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 41:49.</i> <i>(to count)</i>, which means <i>milispor</i> (until he left off counting); <i>And they ceased ‘livnoth’ (to build) the city</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">247</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 11:8.</i> which means <i>milivnoth; Take heed to yourselves, that ye go not up into the mount;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">248</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 19:12. <i>Aloth</i> (going up) should be understood as <i>me’aloth</i> (from going up).</i> <i>And they departed not ‘mitzvath’ (the commandment of the king</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">249</sup><i class="footnote">II Chronicles 8:15.</i> which should be understood as <i>mimitzvath</i> (from the commandment); and thus in many other cases.<br>Know that in the word <i>la’asoth</i> (to make, to do) is also included a hint that the six days of creation represent all the days of the world, i.e., that its existence will be six thousand years. For this reason the Rabbis have said:<sup class="footnote-marker">250</sup><i class="footnote">Bereshith Rabbah 19:14. It is noteworthy here that Ramban’s explanation of the history of the world in terms of the six days of Creation was regarded with approval by many later authors. Bachya ben Asher (see my edition, I, pp. 54-6) and Menachem Ricanti copied it verbatim. Surprisingly it found its way into Egypt, and was wholly incorporated into the Midrash Rabbi David Hanagid, (Book of Exodus, pp. 201-2, ed. by A. Katz), grandson of Maimonides.</i> “A day of the Holy One, blessed be He, is a thousand years.” Thus on the first two days the world was all water, and nothing was perfected during them. They allude to the first two thousand years when there was no one to call on the name of the Eternal. And so the Rabbis said:<sup class="footnote-marker">251</sup><i class="footnote">Avodah Zarah 9a.</i> “The first two thousand years there was desolation.” However, there was the creation of light on the first day corresponding to the thousand years of Adam who was the light of the world<sup class="footnote-marker">252</sup><i class="footnote">Yerushalmi Shabbath 2, 6: “The first man was the light [literally: the candle] of the world.”</i> and who recognized his Creator. Perhaps Enosh did not worship idols<sup class="footnote-marker">253</sup><i class="footnote">See further, 4:26, Rashi.</i> until the death of the first man.<br>On the second day G-d said, <i>‘Let there be a firmament… and let it divide,’</i><sup class="footnote-marker">254</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 1:6.</i> for on that “day” [i.e., the second thousand-year period] Noah and his sons — the righteous ones —<sup class="footnote-marker">255</sup><i class="footnote">See Note 225 above.</i> were separated from the wicked, who were punished in water.<br>On the third day, the dry land appeared; plants and trees began growing, and fruits ripened. This corresponds to the third thousand-year period which begins when Abraham was forty-eight years old,<sup class="footnote-marker">256</sup><i class="footnote">In Avodah Zarah 9a it appears that Abraham, at the end of the first 2000 years, was 52 years old.</i> for then he began to call the name of the Eternal. <i>A righteous shoot</i><sup class="footnote-marker">257</sup><i class="footnote">Jeremiah 23:5.</i> did then spring forth in the world for he attracted many people to know the Eternal, just as the Rabbis interpreted the verse: <i>And the souls that they had gotten in Haran</i><sup class="footnote-marker">258</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 12:5. “These are the converts which they converted.” (Bereshith Rabbah 39:21.)</i> — and he commanded his household and his children after him, <i>and they shall keep the way of the Eternal, to do righteousness and judgment</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">259</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 18:19.</i> This course continued until his descendants received the Torah on Sinai and the House of G-d was also built on that “day,” and then all commandments — which are “the fruits” of the world — were affirmed.<br>Know that from the time twilight falls it is already considered as the following day. Therefore, the subject of every “day” begins somewhat before it, just as Abraham was born at the end of the second thousand years. And you will see similar examples for each and every day.<br>On the fourth day the luminaries — the large and the small and the stars — were created. Its “day,” in the fourth thousand-year period, began seventy-two years after the First Sanctuary was built and continued until one hundred seventy-two years after the destruction of the Second Sanctuary. Now on this “day,” <i>the children of Israel had light</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">260</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 10:23.</i> <i>for the glory of the Eternal filled the house of the Eternal</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">261</sup><i class="footnote">I Kings 8:11.</i> and the light of Israel became the fire upon the altar in the Sanctuary, resting there like a lion<sup class="footnote-marker">262</sup><i class="footnote">So in Yoma 21b. Maharsha explains there the symbolism of <i>the lion</i> and <i>the dog</i>, that the first Sanctuary was built by King Solomon who was of the tribe of Judah, likened to a lion (see Genesis 49:9), while the second Sanctuary was built by the government of the Persians, symbolized by the dog (see Rosh Hashanah 4 a).</i> consuming the offerings. Afterwards their light diminished and they were exiled to Babylon just as the light of the moon disappears before the birth of the new moon. Then the moon shone for them all the days of the Second Sanctuary, and the fire upon the altar rested on it like a dog.<sup class="footnote-marker">262</sup><i class="footnote">So in Yoma 21b.
