Maharsha explains there the symbolism of <i>the lion</i> and <i>the dog</i>, that the first Sanctuary was built by King Solomon who was of the tribe of Judah, likened to a lion (see Genesis 49:9), while the second Sanctuary was built by the government of the Persians, symbolized by the dog (see Rosh Hashanah 4 a).</i> And then the two luminaries disappeared towards eventide and the Sanctuary was destroyed.<br>On the fifth day the waters swarmed with living creatures and fowl flying above the earth. This was a reference to the fifth thousand-year period which began one hundred seventy-two years after the destruction of the Second Sanctuary since, during this millennium, the nations will have dominion, and man will be made <i>as the fishes of the sea, as the creeping things, that have no ruler over them; they take up all of them with the angle, catch them in their net and gather in their drag</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">263</sup><i class="footnote">Habakkuk 1:14-15.</i> and no one seeks the Eternal.<br>On the sixth day in the morning, G-d said: <i>‘Let the earth bring forth the living creature after its kind, cattle and creeping thing, and beast of the earth after its kind.’</i><sup class="footnote-marker">264</sup><i class="footnote">Above 1:24.</i> Their creation took place before sunrise, even as it is written, <i>The sun ariseth, they withdraw, and crouch in their dens</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">265</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 104:22.</i> Then man was created in the image of G-d, and this is the time of his dominion, as it is written, <i>Man goeth forth unto his work and to his labor until the evening</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">266</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 23.</i> All this is an indication of the sixth thousand-year period in the beginning of which the “beasts,” symbolizing the kingdoms <i>that knew not the Eternal</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">267</sup><i class="footnote">Judges 2:10.</i> will rule, but after a tenth thereof — in the proportion of the time from the first sparklings of the sun to the beginning of the day<sup class="footnote-marker">268</sup><i class="footnote">In Pesachim 94a it is so explained that the time from the beginning of the day to the first sparklings of the sun is one tenth of the day.</i> — the redeemer will come, as it is said concerning him, <i>And his throne is as the sun before Me</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">269</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 89:37.</i> This is the son of David, who was formed in the image of G-d, as it is written, <i>And behold, there came with the clouds of heaven, one like unto a son of man, and he came even to the Ancient One of days, and he was brought near before Him. And there was given him dominion, and glory, and a kingdom</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">270</sup><i class="footnote">Daniel 7:13-14.,</i> This will take place one hundred eighteen years after the completion of five thousand years,<sup class="footnote-marker">271</sup><i class="footnote">This corresponds to the year 1358 C.E. See my biography of Ramban, p. 141, for further discussion of this matter.</i> that the word of the Eternal by the mouth of Daniel might be accomplished:<sup class="footnote-marker">272</sup><i class="footnote">See Ezra 1:1.</i> <i>And from the time that the continual burnt-offering shall be taken away, and the detestable thing that causeth appalment set up, there shall be a thousand two hundred and ninety days</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">273</sup><i class="footnote">Daniel 12:11. <i>Yamim</i> here means “years.” Thus 172 years after the destruction of the Second Temple, the fifth millennium began. Add this to the 118 years after the beginning of the sixth millennium, and you have 1290 years, as mentioned in the verse.</i><br>It would appear from the change of days — from the swarms of the waters and the fowl created on the fifth day to the beasts of the earth created on the sixth day — that in the beginning of the sixth thousand-year period a new ruling kingdom will arise, <i>dreadful and terrible, and strong exceedingly</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">274</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 7:7. Ramban refers here to rise of Islam.</i> and approaching the truth more than the preceding ones.<br>The seventh day which is the Sabbath alludes to the World to Come, “which will be wholly a Sabbath and will bring rest for life everlasting.”<sup class="footnote-marker">275</sup><i class="footnote">Tamid VII, 4.</i><br>And may G-d guard us during all the days and set our portion with His servants, the blameless ones.

Verse 4

THESE ARE THE GENERATIONS OF THE HEAVEN AND THE EARTH WHEN THEY WERE CREATED. Scripture now relates the account of the heaven and the earth as regards rain and growth after they had been created and put in proper order, <i>that the heavens shall give their dew</i><sup class="footnote-marker">276</sup><i class="footnote">Zechariah 8:12.</i> and rain, <i>and the ground shall give her increase</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">276</sup><i class="footnote">Zechariah 8:12.</i> these making possible the existence of all living beings. And in the word <i>b’hibaram</i> (when they were created) — [which could be read as if it were two words: <i>b’hei baram</i>] — Scripture alludes to what the Rabbis have said:<sup class="footnote-marker">277</sup><i class="footnote">Menachoth 29b.,</i> “He created them with the letter <i>hei</i>” [which is the last of the four letters of the Tetragrammaton]. It is for this reason that Scripture until this point mentioned only the word <i>Elokim</i>. This is explained in the verse: <i>For all these things hath My hand made;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">278</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 66:2. The last letter (<i>hei</i>) of the Tetragrammaton is in the Cabala considered the <i>yad hashem</i> (the hand of G-d). See my Hebrew commentary, p. 32.</i> and so did Job say, <i>Who knoweth not among all these, that the hand of the Eternal hath wrought this?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">279</sup><i class="footnote">Job 12:9.</i> This being so, the expression, <i>in the day that the Eternal G-d made</i>, refers covertly to the word <i>bereshith</i> (in the beginning).<sup class="footnote-marker">280</sup><i class="footnote">See Ramban above at the end of 1:1 and see also Note 64.</i>

Verse 5

AND EVERY SHRUB OF THE FIELD. In the opinion of our Rabbis in Bereshith Rabbah,<sup class="footnote-marker">281</sup><i class="footnote">See Bereshith Rabbah 12:4 for a similar text. See also Rashi here.</i> [every herb of the field created] on the third day [did not come forth above the ground but] they remained just below the surface of the earth, and on the sixth day they grew after He caused rain to fall on them.<br>In my opinion, in accordance with the plain meaning of Scripture, on the third day the earth did bring forth the grass and the fruit trees in their full-grown stature and quality as He commanded concerning them. And now Scripture tells that there was no one to plant and sow them for future purposes, and the earth would not produce until a mist would come up from it and water it, and man was formed who would work it — to seed, to plant, and to guard. This is the meaning of the <i>shrub of the field… had not yet grown</i>. It does not say “the shrub of the ground” for only a place which is cultivated is called “field,” as in <i>Which thou hast sown in the field</i><sup class="footnote-marker">282</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 23:16.</i> and <i>We will not pass through field or through vineyard</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">283</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 20:17.</i> This is the course of the world that was to be following the six days of creation and forever after, that due to the mist the heavens will bring down rain, and due to the rains the earth will make the seeds that are sown in it to spring up.

Verse 6



Verse 7

AND HE BREATHED INTO HIS NOSTRILS THE BREATH OF LIFE. This alludes to the superiority of the soul, its foundation and secret, since it mentions in connection with it the full Divine Name.<sup class="footnote-marker">284</sup><i class="footnote"><i>And the ‘Eternal G-d’ formed… and He breathed into his nostrils…</i>.</i> And the verse says that He breathed into his nostrils the breath of life in order to inform us that the soul did not come to man from the elements, as He intimated concerning the soul of moving things, nor was it an evolvement from the Separate Intelligences.<sup class="footnote-marker">237</sup><i class="footnote">Intelligences without matter, generally referring to the angels and spheres. See Rambam, Hilchoth Yesodei Hatorah 3:9. Also Moreh Nebuchim, I, 49: “The angels are likewise incorporeal; they are intelligences without matter, etc.” (Friedlander’s translation.)</i> Rather, it was the spirit of the Great G-d: <i>out of his mouth cometh knowledge and discernment</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">285</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 2:6.</i> For he who breathes into the nostrils of another person gives into him something from his own soul.<sup class="footnote-marker">286</sup><i class="footnote">Similarly, since G-d breathed into man’s nostrils, it follows that the soul in man is of Divine essence.</i> It is this which Scripture says, <i>And the breath of the Almighty giveth them understanding</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">287</sup><i class="footnote">Job 32:8.</i> since the soul is from the foundation of <i>binah</i> (understanding) by way of truth and faith.<sup class="footnote-marker">288</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Truth and faith</i> here signify Cabalistic concepts. See my Hebrew commentary, p. 33.</i> This corresponds to the saying of the Rabbis in the Sifre:<sup class="footnote-marker">289</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers, beginning of <i>Seder Matoth</i>.</i> “Vows are like swearing ‘by the life of the King:’ oaths are like swearing ‘by the King Himself.’ Although there is no proof for it in Scripture, there is an allusion to it: <i>By the living G-d, and by the life of your soul</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">290</sup><i class="footnote">II Kings 4:30. Here in the verse where an oath is being expressed, it says, <i>by the living G-d</i>. It does not say “by the life of G-d,” which would indicate that His life is independent of Him; rather it says, <i>by the living G-d</i>, thus indicating that life is His very essence. (The correctness of this translation is indicated by the <i>patach</i> under the word <i>chai</i>, which is not in the construct state, and therefore means “<i>the living</i> G-d.”) See my Hebrew commentary, p. 33, for further elucidation of this point. Thus there is an allusion here to the teaching of the Sifre that “an oath is like swearing ‘by the King Himself,’” since in this verse quoted, where an oath is being given, it says, <i>by the living G-d</i>. This is an oath “by the King Himself.” In the case of a person, however, it says “by the life of your soul,” thus indicating that in a human being his life and his soul are two independent things. This explains the <i>tzere</i> under the word <i>chei</i>, which indicates a construct state combining two independent nouns. Thus there is an allusion to “Vows are like swearing ‘by the life of the King.’” See also Note 293.</i> And in the Midrash of Rabbi Nechunya ben Hakanah we find:<sup class="footnote-marker">291</sup><i class="footnote">Sefer Habahir, 57. See above, Note 42.</i> “What is the meaning of the word <i>vayinafash</i> (and He rested)?<sup class="footnote-marker">292</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 31:17.</i> It teaches us that the day of the Sabbath preserves all souls, for it is <i>vayinafash</i>” [i.e., from the word <i>nefesh</i>, soul]. It is from here that you will understand the expression, <i>speaking the oath of G-d</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">293</sup><i class="footnote">Ecclesiastes 8:2. This denotes that an oath is like swearing “by G-d Himself.” See Note 290 above.</i> The person learned in the mysteries of the Torah will understand.<br>Know that those who engage in research have differed concerning man. Some say that man has three souls. One is the soul of growth, like that in a plant; or you may call this “the force of growth.” Then there is also a soul of movement in him, which Scripture mentioned concerning fish, animals, and everything that creeps upon the earth. The third is the rational soul. And there are some philosophers who say that this soul in man which comes from the Most High comprises these three forces while the soul is but one.<sup class="footnote-marker">294</sup><i class="footnote">The division of opinion among the philosophers as to the nature of the soul is clearly marked in Jewish philosophy. Ibn Ezra (Ecclesiastes 3:7) writes at length to prove that the soul in man consists of three parts. He quotes Saadia Gaon to be of the same opinion. The poet-philosopher Solomon ibn Gabirol (M’kor Chayim 5:20) also held this theory. Rambam, however, in his Sh’monah P’rakim, Chapter 1, holds that man’s soul is but one.</i> This verse in its plain meaning so indicates for it states that <i>G-d formed man of the dust of the ground</i>, but he lay there lifeless like a dumb stone, and the Holy One, blessed be He, <i>breathed into his nostrils the breath of life, and then man became a living soul</i>, able to move about by virtue of this soul, just like the animals and the fish, concerning which He said: <i>‘Let the waters swarm with swarms of living creatures,’</i><sup class="footnote-marker">295</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 1:20.</i> and <i>‘Let the earth bring forth the living creature.’</i><sup class="footnote-marker">296</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 24.</i> This is the meaning of the expression here, <i>‘lenefesh chayah’ (into a living soul) man was made</i>, meaning man turned into a soul in which there is life, after having been <i>as a potsherd with the potsherds of the earth</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">297</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 45:9.</i> For the letter <i>lamed</i> in the word <i>lenefesh</i> indicates the opposite, [namely, that from being a potsherd he became a living soul]. And so it is in the verses, <i>And the water shall turn ‘ledam’ (into blood) upon the dry land;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">298</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 4:9.</i> <i>And it turned ‘lenachash’ (into a snake);</i><sup class="footnote-marker">299</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 3.</i> <i>And He made the sea ‘lecharavah’ (into dry land)</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">300</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 14:21.</i><br>Onkelos, however, said: “And it became a speaking soul in man.” From this it would appear that his opinion coincides with those who say that man has various souls and that this rational soul which G-d breathed into his nostrils became a speaking soul.<br>It appears to me that this also is the opinion of our Rabbis, as we may deduce from what they said:<sup class="footnote-marker">301</sup><i class="footnote">Sanhedrin 65b.</i> “Rava created a man. He sent him to Rabbi Zeira who spoke to him but he did not answer. Said Rabbi Zeira to him: ‘You are created by one of the colleagues; return to your dust.’”<sup class="footnote-marker">302</sup><i class="footnote">This story indicates that man has various souls, since Rava was able to bestow the soul of movement upon the man he created, but he could not give him the soul of speech.</i> And in Midrash Vayikra Rabbah we find written:<sup class="footnote-marker">303</sup><i class="footnote">32:2.</i> “Said Rabbi Avin: When a man sleeps, the body tells the <i>neshamah</i> (the moving spirit), and the <i>neshamah</i> tells the <i>nefesh</i> (the rational soul), and the <i>nefesh</i> tells the angel.”<sup class="footnote-marker">304</sup><i class="footnote">The Midrash there concludes that each soul in man communicates to the other its sense of agreement that G-d’s judgment is just. At the same time it is obvious from this Midrash that the Rabbis are of the opinion that there are various souls in man.</i> So also the verse, <i>He gathers unto Himself his spirit and his breath</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">305</sup><i class="footnote">Job 34:14.</i> indicates, according to its plain meaning, that <i>his spirit and breath</i> are two distinct things.<br>That being so, the verse, <i>And the Eternal G-d formed man</i>, states the formation of movement, that man was formed into a creature capable of movement since “formation” denotes life and perception by virtue of which he is a man and not a kneaded mass of dust, just as it is said, <i>And the Eternal G-d formed out of the ground every beast of the field, and He brought them unto the man</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">306</sup><i class="footnote">Further, Verse 19.</i> And after He formed him with the power of perception, He breathed into his nostrils a living soul from the Most High, this soul being in addition to the formation mentioned, <i>and the</i> whole <i>man became a living soul</i> since by virtue of this soul he understands and speaks and does all his deeds and all other souls and their powers in man are subject to it. The letter <i>lamed</i> in the word <i>lenefesh</i> is thus the <i>lamed</i> indicating possession, just as in the following verses: <i>My lord, O king, ‘lecha ani’ (I am thine), and all that I have;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">307</sup><i class="footnote">I Kings 20:4.</i> <i>‘lakoneh’ (to him that bought) it, throughout his generations;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">308</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 25:30.,</i> <i>‘lecha ani’ (I am thine), save me</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">309</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 119:94.</i> Or, it may be that the verse is stating that man wholly became a living soul and was transformed into another man, as all His formations were, from now on, directed towards this soul.

Verse 8

AND THE ETERNAL G-D PLANTED A GARDEN ‘MIKEDEM’ (EASTWARD) IN EDEN. Rashi explained that “in the east of Eden He planted the garden.” But Onkelos translated <i>mikedem</i> to mean “previously,” [that is, before man was created]. And so have the Rabbis said in Bereshith Rabbah,<sup class="footnote-marker">310</sup><i class="footnote">15:4.</i> and this is the correct explanation.<br>The meaning of <i>vayita</i> (and He planted) is not that He brought the trees from another place and planted them here for it was from that place that He caused them to grow, just as it is said, <i>And out of the ground the Eternal G-d caused to grow every tree</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">311</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 9.</i> But the purport of the expression, <i>and the Eternal G-d planted</i>, is to state that it was <i>the planting of the Eternal</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">312</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 61:3.</i> for before He decreed upon the earth, <i>Let the earth put forth grass</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">313</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 1:11.</i> He had already decreed that in that place there be a garden, and He further said: “Here shall be this tree, and here that tree,” like the rows of planters. It was unlike the rest of the places on the earth concerning which He said, <i>Let the earth put forth grass… and fruit-tree</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">313</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 1:11.</i> and it then grew without order. Now concerning the trees of the garden of Eden He decreed that they grow branches and bear fruit forever, the root thereof was never to wax old in the earth, and the stock thereof was never to die in the ground.<sup class="footnote-marker">314</sup><i class="footnote">See Job 14:8.</i> These trees were not to need any one to tend and prune them. For if they were in need of cultivation, who tended them after man was driven therefrom? This also is the meaning of the expression, <i>And the Eternal G-d planted</i>, that they were His plantings, the work of His hands,<sup class="footnote-marker">315</sup><i class="footnote">See Isaiah 60:21.</i> and existing forever, even as it is said, <i>Its leaf shall not wither, neither shall the fruit thereof fail … because the waters thereof issue out of the sanctuary</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">316</sup><i class="footnote">Ezekiel 47:12.</i> If so, what then is the meaning of the verse: <i>And He put him into the garden of Eden to cultivate it and to keep it?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">317</sup><i class="footnote">Further, Verse 15.</i> He put him [man] there so that he should sow for himself wheat and all kinds of produce, and every herb bearing seed, and rows of spices, reaping and plucking and eating at his will. This also is the meaning of <i>to cultivate it and to keep it</i><sup class="footnote-marker">317</sup><i class="footnote">Further, Verse 15.</i> — to cultivate the ground of the garden by the rows he [man] would make there, for the part of the garden where the trees were was not to be cultivated.<br>It is possible that [in the words <i>le’ovdah uleshomrah</i> — literally, <i>to cultivate her and to keep her</i>,] He refers to the garden in the feminine gender, just as in the verses: <i>And as the garden causeth the things that are sown in her to spring forth;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">318</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 61:11.</i> <i>And plant gardens</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">319</sup><i class="footnote">Jeremiah 29:5. <i>Ganoth</i> (gardens) is here in the feminine gender.</i> Our Rabbis noted this use of the feminine gender, saying in Bereshith Rabbah:<sup class="footnote-marker">320</sup><i class="footnote">16:8.</i> <i>“Le’ovdah uleshomrah (to cultivate her and to keep her)</i> — these words refer to the sacrifices, as it is said, <i>‘Ta’avdun’ (Ye shall serve) G-d upon this mountain</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">321</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 3:12.</i> It is this which Scripture says, <i>‘Tishm’ru’ (Ye shall keep) to offer unto Me in its appointed season.”</i><sup class="footnote-marker">322</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 28:2.</i> The intent of the Rabbis in this interpretation is that plants and all living beings are in need of primary forces from which they derive the power of growth and that through the sacrifices there is an extension of the blessing to the higher powers. From them it flows to the plants of the garden of Eden, and from them it comes and exists in the world in the form of “rain of goodwill and blessing,”<sup class="footnote-marker">323</sup><i class="footnote">Taanith 19a.</i> through which they will grow. This conforms to what the Rabbis have said:<sup class="footnote-marker">324</sup><i class="footnote">Bereshith Rabbah 15:1.</i> “<i>The trees of the Eternal have their fill, the cedars of Lebanon, which He hath planted</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">325</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 104:16.</i> Rabbi Chanina said: Their life shall have its fill; their waters shall have their fill; their plantings shall have their fill.” “Their life” refers to their higher foundations; “their waters” refer to <i>His good treasure</i><sup class="footnote-marker">326</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 28:12.</i> which brings down the rain; and “their plantings” refer to their force in heaven, just as the Rabbis have said:<sup class="footnote-marker">327</sup><i class="footnote">Bereshith Rabbah 10:7. This text is also quoted above 1:11 (Notes 135-6).</i> “There is not a single blade of grass below that does not have a constellation in heaven that smites it and says to it, ‘Grow.’ It is this which Scripture says, <i>Knowest thou the ordinances of the heavens? Canst thou establish ‘mishtara’ (the dominion thereof) in the earth</i> — [<i>mishtara</i> being derived from the root] <i>shoter</i> (executive officer).”

Verse 9

AND THE TREE OF LIFE IN THE MIDST OF THE GARDEN AND THE TREE OF KNOWLEDGE OF GOOD AND EVIL. Since Scripture says, <i>And the tree of life in the midst of the garden</i>, and does not say “in the garden,” and, moreover, since it says, <i>But of the fruit of the tree which is in the midst of the garden, G-d hath said: ‘Ye shall not eat of it,’</i><sup class="footnote-marker">328</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 3:3.</i> and does not mention it or refer to it by another name, we must say, according to the simple meaning of Scripture, that it was a known place in the garden which was “in the midst” thereof. This is why Onkelos translated: “in the middle of the garden.” Thus according to Onkelos the tree of life and the tree of knowledge were both in the middle of the garden. And if so, we must say that in the middle of the garden there was the likeness of an enclosed garden-bed made which contained these two trees. This “middle” means near its middle for with respect to the exact middle, they have already said<sup class="footnote-marker">329</sup><i class="footnote">If Ramban is stating a specific mathematical principle, its source is unknown to me. His intent may, however, be general. If so, the source may be found in Berachoth 3b, where it is stated that the exact point of midnight is known only to G-d.</i> that no one knows the true central point except G-d alone.<br><i>And the tree of life</i>. This was a tree the fruit of which gave those who ate it long life.<br><i>And the tree of the knowledge of good and evil</i>. The commentators<sup class="footnote-marker">330</sup><i class="footnote">Mentioned in R’dak in the name of the “commentators.”</i> have said that the fruit thereof caused those who ate it to have a desire for sexual intercourse, and therefore Adam and Eve covered their nakedness after they ate of it [the fruit]. They quote a similar expression [where “good and evil” refers to such desire], the saying of Barzilai the Gileadite: <i>Can I distinguish between good and bad?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">331</sup><i class="footnote">II Samuel 19:36.</i> — meaning that this sexual desire was already removed from him. But in my opinion this interpretation is not correct since the serpent said, <i>And ye shall be as ‘Elohim,’ knowing good and evil</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">332</sup><i class="footnote">The <i>Elohim</i> here means angels, who have no such desire (R’dak).</i> And if you will say that the serpent lied to her, now [Scripture itself attests to the truth of his statement in the verse], <i>And the Eternal G-d said, ‘Behold man has become like one of us knowing good and evil.’</i><sup class="footnote-marker">333</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 3:22.</i> And the Rabbis have already said:<sup class="footnote-marker">334</sup><i class="footnote">In Pirka D’Rabbeinu Hakadosh, Section 3. See my Hebrew commentary, p. 36, Note 84, for variants.</i> “Three stated the truth and perished from the world, and these are: the serpent, the spies,<sup class="footnote-marker">335</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers, Chapters 13-14. Sanhedrin 108a.</i> and Doeg the Edomite.<sup class="footnote-marker">336</sup><i class="footnote">I Samuel 22:9-10. Sanhedrin 90a. The Hebrew text here also contains an additional word, “the Beerothite.” See II Samuel, Chapter 4. Ramban’s general thought is clear: the saying of the Rabbis proves that the serpent spoke the truth. Hence the serpent’s statement, <i>And ye shall be as ‘Elohim,’ knowing good and evil</i>, was true. Now since sexual desire is not spoken of in connection with the angels, the expression <i>knowing good and evil</i> cannot refer to such desire.</i><br>The proper interpretation appears to me to be that man’s original nature was such that he did whatever was proper for him to do naturally, just as the heavens and all their hosts do, “faithful workers<sup class="footnote-marker">337</sup><i class="footnote">Who do not veer from their prescribed course (Rashi, Sanhedrin 42 a). See, however, Tosafoth there which mentions a variant reading, “A faithful Worker,” which refers to G-d. Our version of this benediction in the Prayer Book is based on this reading.</i> whose work is truth, and who do not change from their prescribed course,”<sup class="footnote-marker">338</sup><i class="footnote">The source of this expression, in connection with the blessing for the new moon, is found in Sanhedrin 42a.</i> and in whose deeds there is no love or hatred. Now it was the fruit of this tree that gave rise to will and desire, that those who ate it should choose a thing or its opposite, for good or for evil. This is why it was called <i>‘etz hada’ath’ (the tree of the knowledge) of good and evil</i>, for <i>da’ath</i> in our language is used to express will. Thus in the language of the Rabbis: “They have taught this only with regards to one <i>sheda’ato</i> (whose will) is to return;”<sup class="footnote-marker">339</sup><i class="footnote">Pesachim 6a. If his will (or wish) is to return to his house during the days of Passover, then he must search his house for leaven before leaving his house even if he leaves more than 30 days before Passover.</i> and “his will is to clear” [the produce in the store-room in his house before Passover].<sup class="footnote-marker">340</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, In that case too he must search for leaven which lies under the produce even more than 30 days before Passover.</i> And in the language of Scripture, <i>Eternal, what is man ‘vateida’ehu,’</i><sup class="footnote-marker">341</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 144:3.</i> meaning that “Thou shouldst desire and want him;” <i>yedaticha beshem</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">342</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 33:12. Literally, <i>I know thee by name</i>.</i> meaning “I have chosen thee of all people.” Similarly, Barzilai’s expression, <i>Ha’eda (Can I distinguish) between good and bad</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">331</sup><i class="footnote">II Samuel 19:36.</i> means that he lost the power of thought, no longer choosing a thing or loathing it, and he would eat without feeling taste and hear singing without enjoying it.<br>Now at that time sexual intercourse between Adam and his wife was not a matter of desire; instead, at the time of begetting offspring they came together and propagated. Therefore all the limbs were, in their eyes, as the face and hands, and they were not ashamed of them. But after he ate of the fruit of the tree of knowledge, he possessed the power of choice; he could now willingly do evil or good to himself or to others. This, on the one hand, is a godlike attribute; but as far as man is concerned, it is bad because through it, he has a will and desire. It is possible that Scripture intended to allude to this matter when it said, <i>That G-d made man upright, but they have sought out many inventions</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">343</sup><i class="footnote">Ecclesiastes 7:29.</i> The “uprightness” is that man should keep to one right path, and the “seeking out of many inventions” is man’s search for deeds which change according to his choice. Now when the Holy One, blessed be He, commanded Adam concerning the tree, that he should not eat of its fruit, He did not inform him that it has this quality. He told him without any qualification, <i>But of the fruit of the tree which is in the midst of the garden</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">328</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 3:3.</i> that is to say, the one that is known by its central position, <i>thou shalt not eat thereof</i>. And this was what the woman said to the serpent. And the verse which states, <i>But of the tree of the knowledge of good and evil, thou shalt not eat of it</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">344</sup><i class="footnote">Further, Verse 17.</i> mentions it to us by its true name.

Verse 10



Verse 11

THE LAND OF HAVILAH, WHERE THERE IS GOLD. This is to explain that it is not the Havilah of Egypt, concerning which it is said, <i>And they dwelt from Havilah unto Shur, that is before Egypt</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">345</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 25:18.</i> for this one [referred to here] is in the extreme east. The verse mentions also, <i>There is the bdellium</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">346</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 12.</i> in praise of the river, that in the sand that is in it and on its bank there is found that good gold, the bdellium and the onyx stone. For these things are found in rivers; in some, silver can be found. Similarly, the bdellium and precious stones are found mostly in rivers.<br>In the opinion of former scholars,<sup class="footnote-marker">347</sup><i class="footnote">Rabbeinu Saadia Gaon and Rashi.</i> Pishon is the Nile of Egypt; it compasses this entire land of Havilah, and comes from there and passes the whole land of Egypt until it falls into the great sea at Alexandria in Egypt.

Verse 12



Verse 13



Verse 14



Verse 15



Verse 16



Verse 17

THOU SHALT NOT EAT OF IT. He admonishes him against eating the fruit, for the tree itself is not edible. And so it says further on: <i>But of the fruit of the tree which is in the midst of the garden</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">328</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 3:3.</i> Similarly, <i>And eat ye every one of his vine, and every one of his fig tree</i><sup class="footnote-marker">348</sup><i class="footnote">II Kings 18:31.</i> [means “of the fruit of his vine and of the fruit of his fig-tree].” Likewise, <i>In toil shalt thou eat it</i><sup class="footnote-marker">349</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 3:17.</i> means “eat its fruit.”
IN THE DAY THOU EATEST THEREOF THOU SHALT SURELY DIE. At the time you eat of it, you will be condemned to die. Similarly, we find: <i>On the day thou goest out, and walkest abroad any whither, thou shalt surely die</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">350</sup><i class="footnote">I Kings 2:42. Said by Solomon to Shimi, that on the day he goes outside of the limits of Jerusalem he <i>shall surely die</i>.</i> This does not mean that he [Shimi] is to die immediately on that day; nor does it refer to his mere knowledge thereof, namely that he is to know that he will die eventually <i>for</i> all <i>the living know that they shall die</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">351</sup><i class="footnote">Ecclesiastes 9:5.</i> But it does mean that at the time he [Shimi] goes forth from Jerusalem, he is liable to death at the hand of the king, and he will slay him when he pleases. [Similarly, in the verses:] <i>But they shall not go in to see the holy things as they are being covered, lest they die;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">352</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 4:20.</i> <i>And they shall not bear sin for it, and die thereby</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">353</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 22:9.</i> Their intent is [not that those who transgress against these prohibitions will die immediately], but only that they will be liable to death and will die on account of this sin of theirs.<br>Now in the opinion of men versed in the sciences of nature, man was destined to die from the beginning of his formation, on account of his being a composite [of the four elements, and everything that is composite must revert to its original components]. But now He decreed that if he will sin he will die on account of his sin, like those who are liable to death at the hands of Heaven for such sins as a non-priest eating the Heave-offering, or a priest who has drunk wine or who does not wear the [required number of priestly] garments when performing the Service in the Sanctuary, and other cases. There the intent is that they will die prematurely on account of their sin. This is why in stating the punishment [after Adam ate of the fruit of the tree of knowledge] He said, <i>Till thou return to the ground; for out of it wast thou taken; for dust thou art, and unto dust shalt thou return</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">354</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 3:19.</i> by your nature. In the beginning before he sinned, Adam also ate of the fruit of the tree and of the seeds of the earth; and if so, there was bound to be depletion in his body, and he was subject to the cause of existence and destruction. [Thus the opinion of the men of science.]<br>But in the opinion of our Rabbis,<sup class="footnote-marker">355</sup><i class="footnote">Shabbath 58b.</i> if Adam had not sinned he would have never died, since the higher soul bestows life forever, and the Will of G-d which is in him at the time of his formation would always cleave to him and he would exist forever, as I have explained in the verse, <i>And G-d saw that it was good</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">356</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 1:10.</i><br>Know that composition indicates destruction only in the opinion of those wanting in faith, who hold that creation came by necessity. But in the opinion of men of faith who say that the world was created by the simple Will of G-d, its existence will also continue forever as long as it is His desire. This is clear truth. That being so, <i>In the day thou eatest thereof thou shalt surely die</i> means that then you will be condemned to die since you will no longer exist forever by My Will. And the matter of eating [from the other trees] was to Adam at first only a source of enjoyment.<sup class="footnote-marker">357</sup><i class="footnote">Ramban is aiming to answer the question: If Adam was destined at first to exist forever on account of his superior soul, what purpose did his eating serve? Ramban answers that, according to this theory, he ate not out of necessity but for enjoyment.</i> And it is possible that the fruits of the garden of Eden were absorbed in his limbs as the Manna, and they sustain those that eat them. But when He decreed upon him, <i>And thou shalt eat the herb of the field</i><sup class="footnote-marker">358</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 3:18.</i> and with the sweat of his face he shall eat bread of the earth,<sup class="footnote-marker">359</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 19.</i> this [the food] became a cause for decomposition since he is dust, and dust he eats, and unto dust he shall return.

Verse 18

IT IS NOT GOOD THAT THE MAN SHOULD BE ALONE. It does not appear likely that man was created to be alone in the world and not beget children since all created beings — male and female of all flesh — were created to raise seed. The herb and trees also have their seed in them. But it is possible to say that it was in accordance with the opinion of the Rabbi who says:<sup class="footnote-marker">360</sup><i class="footnote">Berachoth 61a. The name of the Rabbi is Yirmeyahu the son of Rabbi Elazar.</i> “Adam was created with two faces [i.e., male and female persons combined],” and they were so made that there should be in them an impulse causing the organs of generation to produce a generative force from male to female, or you may say “seed,” in accordance with the known controversy concerning pregnancy,<sup class="footnote-marker">361</sup><i class="footnote">See Ramban, beginning of <i>Seder</i> Thazria concerning the opinion of the doctors and the Greek philosophers.</i> and the second face was a help to the first in the procreative process. And the Holy One, blessed be He, saw that it is good that “the help” stand facing him, and that he should see and be separated from it or joined to it at his will. This is the meaning of what He said in the verse, <i>I will make him a helper opposite him</i>.<br>The meaning of the expression, <i>it is not good</i>, is that it cannot be said of man that “it is good” when he is alone for he will not be able to so exist. In the work of creation, “the good” means existence, as I have explained on the text, <i>And G-d saw that it was good</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">362</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 1:10.</i>

Verse 19

AND WHATSOEVER ‘YIKRA LO HA’ADAM NEFESH CHAYAH’ (THE MAN WOULD CALL EVERY LIVING CREATURE). Rashi comments: “Invert [the phrasing of the sentence] and explain it thus: and every living creature to which Adam would give a name, that should remain its name forever.” And Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra said that the letter <i>lamed</i> of the phrase, <i>that the man called ‘lo’ (it)</i>, is carried forward [to the word <i>nefesh</i>, making it <i>lenefesh</i> (<i>to</i> the creature), thus]: and whatever the man called <i>to</i> every living creature, that was to be its name.<br>It is possible that the phrase be explained in connection with the matter of “the help” that G-d gave to Adam, and the meaning is that <i>ha’adam nefesh chayah</i> (man is a living soul), as it is said, <i>And man became a living soul</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">363</sup><i class="footnote">Above, Verse 7.</i> and it is as I have explained it there. And He brought before him all species so that every one of them unto which Adam would give a name and say that it is a living soul like himself, that would remain its name and be a help to him. So Adam gave names to all, but as for himself he found no help which he would be able to call “a living soul” like his own name.

Verse 20

BUT FOR ADAM THERE WAS NOT FOUND A HELP MEET FOR HIM. Rashi comments: “When He brought them, He brought them before him as male and female. Thereupon Adam said, ‘All of them have a mate, and I have no mate!’ Immediately, <i>the Eternal G-d caused a deep sleep to fall</i> upon him.” Rashi explained it well for by Scripture’s bringing the verses concerning “the calling of names” into the matter of “the help” that G-d gave Adam, it proves that this interpretation mentioned above is correct.<br>“The calling of names,” in the opinion of the commentators,<sup class="footnote-marker">364</sup><i class="footnote">Rashi and R’dak.</i> is to be understood in its plain sense, namely, that everyone should have a name for himself so that they be known and recognized in their progeny by the names Adam would call them, names which would be valid forever. Now when the Holy One, blessed be He, wanted to make “the help” for Adam He brought all species before him since He had to bring them before him in pairs so that he should also give a name to the females of the species; for in some [species, both male and female] are called by one name, and in others they differ, such as bull and cow, <i>tayish</i> (he-goat) and <i>eiz</i> (she-goat), sheep and ewe, and others. When Adam saw them mating with each other, he had a desire for them, but as he found among them no help for himself, he was saddened and fell asleep. G-d then caused a deep sleep to fall upon him so that he should not feel the removal of a rib from his body.<br>In my opinion, however, “the calling of the names” is identical with “the help” [as I explained in the above verse], and the purport thereof is as follows: the Holy One, blessed be He, brought before Adam all the beasts of the field and all the fowl of the heavens, and he, recognizing their nature, called them names, that is, names appropriate to them. By the names it was made clear who is fit to be the help for another, meaning, fit to procreate with one another. Even if we are to believe that names are merely a matter of consensus and not of nature, [i.e., that they do not reflect the essence of the object bearing the name], we can say that “the calling of the names” means the division of the species as — male and female — they passed before Adam and he contemplated their nature as to which of them would be a help to each other in procreation so that they should beget offspring. Thus he called the large creatures by one name and the beasts by another so they would not beget offspring from one another, and so on for all species. And among them all he did not find a natural help for himself so that it could be called by his name for “the calling of the names” signifies the division of the species and the separation of their powers from each other, as I have explained above. Now it does not mean that it was in Adam’s power to find a help for himself among them since they were all created with natures [different from that of man]. But it means that if Adam was to find satisfaction with one of the species and he would choose it for his help, the Holy One, blessed be He, would adapt its nature to him, as He did with the rib, and He would not have found it necessary to build “a new structure.”<sup class="footnote-marker">365</sup><i class="footnote">“A new structure” is a reference to the explanation of the Rabbis: “<i>Vayiven (And He built… the rib)</i> — this teaches us that He <i>built</i> Eve after the fashion of a store-house.” (Eruvin 18a.)</i> This is the meaning of the verse, <i>And whatsoever the man would call every living creature, that was its name;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">366</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 19.</i> that is to say, that was to be its name, for the Holy One, blessed be He, would so preserve it along the lines which I have explained.<br>In my opinion it is correct to say that it was His will, blessed be He, not to take Adam’s rib from him to make him a wife until he himself would know that among the created beings there is no help suitable for him and until he would crave to have a help suitable for him like her. This was why it was necessary to take one of his ribs from him. This is the meaning of the verse, <i>But for Adam there was not found a help meet for him;</i> that is to say, but for the name <i>Adam</i> (man), he found no help suited to be opposite him and to be called by his name so that he should beget children from that “help”. We need not resort here, therefore, to the words of the commentators<sup class="footnote-marker">367</sup><i class="footnote">Ibn Ezra and R’dak.</i> who say that the name “Adam” comes here in place of the reflexive pronoun [“himself.” The verse would thus read: “But for himself] he found no help meet for him,” just as, <i>Ye wives of Lemech</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">368</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 4:23.</i> [which should read, “<i>my</i> wives”]; <i>And Jephthah, and Samuel</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">369</sup><i class="footnote">I Samuel 12:11. The words were spoken by Samuel.</i> [which should read, “and Jephthah and myself”]. This is the meaning of Adam’s saying: <i>This is now bone of my bones;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">370</sup><i class="footnote">Further Verse 23.</i> that is to say, “This time I have found a help for me which I did not find till now among the other species, for she is <i>bone of my bones, and flesh of my flesh</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">370</sup><i class="footnote">Further Verse 23.</i> and is fit to be actually called by my name for we shall propagate together.”<br>In the word <i>zoth</i> (this, this time) there is a secret; it will be made known from our words in the section <i>Vezoth habracha</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">371</sup><i class="footnote">See Ramban, Deuteronomy 33:1, in the commentary beginning, “the man of G-d.”</i> if my Rock will bless me, enabling me reach thereto. This is why Adam repeats, <i>because ‘zoth’ (this) was taken out of man</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">370</sup><i class="footnote">Further Verse 23.</i> [Delve into it] and understand.

Verse 21



Verse 22



Verse 23



Verse 24

THEREFORE SHALL A MAN LEAVE HIS FATHER AND HIS MOTHER, AND SHALL CLEAVE TO HIS WIFE. The Divine Spirit says this, thus prohibiting immoral relationships to “the sons of Noah.”<sup class="footnote-marker">372</sup><i class="footnote">See above, Note 222.</i>
AND THEY SHALL BE ONE FLESH. The child is created by both parents, and there in the child, their flesh is united into one. Thus the words of Rashi. But there is no point to this since in beast and cattle too, their flesh is united into one in their offspring.<br>The correct interpretation appears to me to be that in cattle and beast the males have no attachment to their females. Rather, the male mates with any female he finds, and then they go their separate ways. It is for this reason that Scripture states that because the female of man was bone of his bones and flesh of his flesh, he therefore cleaves to her and she nestles in his bosom as his own flesh, and he desires to be with her always. And just as it was with Adam, so was his nature transmitted to his offspring, that the males among them should cleave to their women, leaving their fathers and their mothers, and considering their wives as if they are one flesh with them. A similar sense is found in the verses: <i>For he is our brother, our flesh</i>;<sup class="footnote-marker">373</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 37:27.</i> <i>to any that is near of his flesh</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">374</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 18:6.</i> Those who are close members of the family are called <i>sh’eir basar</i> (near of flesh). Thus man will leave “the flesh” of his father and his mother and their kin and will see that his wife is nearer to him than they.

Chapter 3



Verse 1



Verse 2



Verse 3



Verse 4



Verse 5



Verse 6

THAT THE TREE WAS GOOD FOR FOOD. She [Eve] had thought that the fruit of the tree was bitter and poisonous and this was why He admonished them against eating thereof, but now she saw that it was good and sweet food.
AND THAT IT WAS A DELIGHT TO THE EYES, i.e., that by means of its fruit, one attains desire and goes about after his own eyes.
AND THAT THE TREE WAS TO BE DESIRED TO MAKE ONE WISE for by means of its fruit, one becomes wise to desire. Now she ascribed “delight” to the eyes and “desire” to the mind. The principle is that [by eating the fruit of the tree], one can will and desire a thing or its opposite.

Verse 7

AND THE EYES OF THEM BOTH WERE OPENED. Scripture speaks here with reference to intelligence, and not with reference to actual seeing. The end of the verse proves this: <i>and they knew they were naked</i>. [Even a blind person knows when he is naked! It must therefore refer to intelligence], as [explained in] the words of Rashi. In a similar sense is the verse, <i>Open thou mine eyes, that I may behold wondrous things out of Thy law</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">375</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 119:18. Here too “the opening of eyes” has reference to understanding.</i>

Verse 8

AND THEY HEARD THE VOICE OF THE ETERNAL G-D WALKING IN THE GARDEN. The Rabbis have said in Bereshith Rabbah:<sup class="footnote-marker">376</sup><i class="footnote">19:12.</i> “Rabbi Chilfi said that from here we may learn that a voice ‘walks,’ for it is said, <i>And they heard the voice of the Eternal G-d walking</i>.” And so did the Rabbi [Moshe ben Maimon] write in Moreh Nebuchim.<sup class="footnote-marker">377</sup><i class="footnote">I, 24: “It is <i>the voice</i> that is modified by <i>walking</i>.”</i> And so is the opinion of Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra that “walking” refers to “the voice,” just as in the verse: <i>The sound thereof shall go like the serpent’s</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">378</sup><i class="footnote">Jeremiah 46:22.</i> And Ibn Ezra further says that the meaning of <i>toward the cool of the day</i> is that they heard the voice towards evening. And he mentioned in the name of Rabbi Jonah ibn Ganach<sup class="footnote-marker">379</sup><i class="footnote">Also known as Jonah ibn Janach (990-1050), considered the greatest Hebrew grammarian. He is the author of the Rikmah (Many Colored Web) and the Book of Roots, a lexicon.</i> that the meaning of the verse is: “and man was walking in the garden toward the cool of the day,” [the sense of the verse thus being that while man was walking in the garden, he heard the voice of G-d].<br>In my opinion, the sense of <i>walking in the garden</i> of Eden is similar to that of the verses: <i>And I will walk among you;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">380</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 26:12.</i> <i>And the Eternal went as soon as He had finished speaking with Abraham;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">381</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 18:33.</i> <i>I will go and return to My place</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">382</sup><i class="footnote">Hosea 5:15.</i> All these verses indicate a revelation of the Divine Presence in that place or the departure from the place wherein He was revealed. The sense of the expression, <i>toward the cool of the day</i>, is that with the revelation of the Divine Presence comes a great and strong wind, even as it says, <i>And, behold, the Eternal passed by, and a great and strong wind rent the mountains, and broke in pieces the rocks before the Eternal</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">383</sup><i class="footnote">I Kings 19:11.</i> Similarly we find: <i>Yea, He did swoop down upon the wings of the wind;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">384</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 18:11.</i> and in the book of Job it is written, <i>Then the Eternal answered Job out of the whirlwind</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">385</sup><i class="footnote">Job 38:1.</i> Therefore Scripture says here that <i>they heard the voice of G-d</i> as the Divine Presence was revealed in the garden approaching them in the wind of the day, <i>because the breath of the Eternal blew upon it</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">386</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 40:7.</i> that is, in the garden, like the wind of ordinary days, not a great and strong wind as in the vision of other prophecies, in order that they should not be frightened or terrified. Yet Scripture says that in spite of this they hid themselves on account of their nakedness. In Bereshith Rabbah<sup class="footnote-marker">387</sup><i class="footnote">19:13.</i> we find that the Rabbis also said: “Said Rabbi Aba the son of Kahana: ‘<i>Mehalech</i> (walking) is not written here but <i>mith’halech</i> (meaning “it leaped and ascended).”<sup class="footnote-marker">388</sup><i class="footnote">This means that when Adam sinned, the Divine Presence went from the earth to the first heaven, and then with every successive generation of sinners it departed to yet another higher heaven. This is so clearly explained in Bereshith Rabbah there (19:12).</i> Rabbi Aba thus interpreted the word <i>mith’halech</i> similarly to that of <i>And the Eternal went</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">381</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 18:33.</i> as we have explained the term “walking,” except that he explained the verse before us as referring to the withdrawal of the Divine Presence that dwelt in the garden of Eden and its retiring therefrom on account of the sin of Adam, even as it says, <i>I will go and return to My place</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">382</sup><i class="footnote">Hosea 5:15.</i> We interpret it to mean the revelation of the Divine Presence in that place, which is the correct and fitting explanation of the verse.

Verse 9



Verse 10



Verse 11



Verse 12

THE WOMAN WHOM THOU GAVEST TO BE WITH ME. The sense of it is to say: “The woman whom Thy Honor Himself gave me for a help, <i>she gave me of the tree</i>, and I thought that whatever she says to me is a help and benefit to me.” This is why He said when meting out his punishment, <i>Because thou hast hearkened unto the voice of thy wife</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">389</sup><i class="footnote">Further, Verse 17.</i> meaning “You should not have transgressed My commandment on account of her advice.” Our Rabbis have called Adam “ungrateful” for this remark.<sup class="footnote-marker">390</sup><i class="footnote">Avodah Zarah 5b.</i> By this they mean to explain that the sense of his answer was: “Thou caused me this stumbling for Thou gavest me a woman as a help, and she counselled me to do evil.”<sup class="footnote-marker">391</sup><i class="footnote">He thus ascribed his sin to G-d’s giving him Eve as a help. (Rashi, <i>ibid.</i>) In this he spoke ungratefully.</i>

Verse 13

WHAT IS THIS THOU HAST DONE to transgress My commandment? For the woman was included in the admonition given to Adam since at that time she was yet bone of his bones, and similarly she was included in his punishment. The reason why G-d did not say to the woman, “and thou hast eaten of the tree,” is that she was punished for both her eating and her advice, just as the serpent was punished for the advice. This is why she said, <i>The serpent beguiled me, and I did eat</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">392</sup><i class="footnote">In the verse before us. Thus she mentioned both the eating and the advice.</i> as the punishment for the beguiling was greater than that for the eating. [Hence as soon as she mentioned that the serpent beguiled her, G-d meted out his punishment immediately, as is stated in the following two verses.] Thus we may derive from here the principle of punishment for those that cause people to sin in any matter, just as our Rabbis have derived it from the verse, <i>Thou shalt not put a stumbling-block before the blind</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">393</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 19:14. In Pesachim 22 b, the verse is interpreted to mean: do not give a person who is “blind” in a matter advice which is improper for him. Advising or causing one to sin is thus included in this prohibition. Ramban is here suggesting that while the admonition against causing people to sin is derived from the verse in Leviticus, the principle of punishment for such advice is derived from here.</i>

Verse 14

FROM AMONG ALL CATTLE, AND FROM AMONG ALL BEASTS OF THE FIELD. From a study of this verse, Rabbi Yehoshua the son of Chananya derived the fact that a serpent gives birth once in seven years;<sup class="footnote-marker">394</sup><i class="footnote">Bechoroth 8a. See my Hebrew commentary, p. 41.</i> this they investigated and found to be so.<sup class="footnote-marker">395</sup><i class="footnote">See Bereshith Rabbah 20:7.</i> For the Midrashic interpretations of Scripture and their allusions are all traditional, and they found in them profound secrets on procreation and all matters, as I mentioned in my introduction.

Verse 15

AND THOU SHALT BRUISE THEIR HEEL. This means man will have an advantage over you [the serpent] in the enmity between him and you for he will bruise your head but you will bruise him only in his heel, with which he will crush your brain.

Verse 16

‘T’SHUKATHECH’ (AND THY DESIRE) SHALL BE TO THY HUSBAND, meaning for cohabitation. Yet you will not have the boldness to demand it by word, rather <i>he shall rule over thee</i>. It will all be from him and not from you. Thus are the words of Rashi. But this is not correct, for modesty is praiseworthy in a woman, just as the Rabbis have said:<sup class="footnote-marker">396</sup><i class="footnote">Eruvin 100b.</i> “This is a good quality in women.”<br>Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra said: “<i>And thy desire shall be to thy husband</i>, meaning your obedience.” This means you will obey whatever he commands you for you are under his authority to do his desire. However, I have found the expression <i>t’shukah</i> used only in connection with desire and lust.<br>The correct interpretation appears to me to be that He punished her that her desire for her husband be exceedingly great and that she should not be deterred by the pain of pregnancy and birth or that he keeps her as a maid-servant. Now it is not customary for a servant to desire to acquire a master over himself, rather his desire is to flee from him. Thus her punishment is measure for measure; she gave [the fruit of the tree of knowledge] also to her husband and he ate at her command, and He punished her that she should no longer command him, but instead he should command her entirely at his will.

Verse 17



Verse 18



Verse 19



Verse 20



Verse 21



Verse 22

AND NOW, LEST HE PUT FORTH HIS HAND. The Holy One, blessed be He, wanted His decree concerning the death of Adam to be fulfilled, and if he were to eat of the tree of life which was created to give everlasting life to those who ate of its fruit, the decree would be nullified; for either he would not die at all or his day of death would not come at the time it was decreed for him and his descendants to die.<sup class="footnote-marker">397</sup><i class="footnote">See above, 2:17, where Ramban explained two theories. The teaching of the Rabbis is that man was originally designed to live forever. By having sinned, death was decreed upon him; by eating of the tree of life, he would thus restore himself to his original position of immortality. The opinion of the philosophers, however, is that man was originally destined to die; by having sinned, it was decreed that he die before the time designated at first. By eating of the tree of life he would thus live a long time and not die at the time decreed for him as punishment for his sin. This is the deeper meaning of Ramban’s words here in the text, “for either he would not die at all, etc.”</i> And now that Adam had the power of choice, He therefore guarded this tree from him for at first Adam did only what he was commanded and he did not eat thereof as he did not need it.<br>Know and believe that the garden of Eden is on this earth<sup class="footnote-marker">398</sup><i class="footnote">See my Kitvei Haramban, Vol. 1, p. 309, in notes, as to why this point that the Garden of Eden is on this earth is of such vital importance to Ramban that he writes: ‘<i>Know and believe</i> that the garden….’”</i> as are also the tree of life and the tree of knowledge, and from there the river comes forth and is divided into four heads<sup class="footnote-marker">399</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 2:10.</i> which are visible to us. For the Euphrates<sup class="footnote-marker">400</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 2:14.</i> is in our land and within our border,<sup class="footnote-marker">401</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 1:1.</i> and Pishon,<sup class="footnote-marker">402</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 2:11.</i> according to the words of the former scholars, is the Nile of Egypt.<sup class="footnote-marker">402</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 2:11.</i> But as these are on earth so are there also in the heavens things similarly named, and those in the heavens are the foundations of these on earth, just as the Rabbis have said:<sup class="footnote-marker">403</sup><i class="footnote">Midrash Shir Hashirim Zuta, 1:4, (Buber ed., pp. 9-10).</i> “<i>The king hath brought me into his chambers</i><sup class="footnote-marker">404</sup><i class="footnote">Song of Songs 1:4.</i> — this teaches us that the Holy One, blessed be He, is destined to show Israel the treasures on high that are chambered in the heavens. Another interpretation of <i>The king hath brought me into his chambers</i> is that these are the chambers of the garden of Eden. It is on the basis of this that they have said: ‘The work of the garden of Eden is like the work of the firmament.’” The rivers correspond to the four camps of angels on high, and it is from there that the power of the kingdoms on earth is derived, just as it is written, <i>The host of the high heaven on high, and the kings of the earth upon the earth</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">405</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 24:21.</i> Thus the Rabbis said in Bereshith Rabbah,<sup class="footnote-marker">406</sup><i class="footnote">16:7.</i> “<i>Into four heads</i><sup class="footnote-marker">407</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 2:10.</i> — these are the four kingdoms. <i>The name of the first is Pishon</i><sup class="footnote-marker">408</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 2:11.</i> — this is Babylon, etc.” And the things called the tree of life and the tree of knowledge on high — their secret is high and lofty. Adam sinned with the fruit of the tree of knowledge below and on high, in deed and thought.<br>Now if the fruit of the tree were good for food and he desired it to become wise, why did He withhold it from him? Indeed, G-d is kind and dealeth kindly; <i>He will withhold no good thing from them that walk uprightly!</i><sup class="footnote-marker">409</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 84:12.</i> The serpent, moreover, has today no speaking faculty, and if it did have it at first, He would surely have mentioned in His curse that its mouth become dumb, as this would have been the most grievous curse of all. But all these things are twofold in meaning, the overt and the concealed in them both being true.<br>In Bereshith Rabbah the Rabbis say:<sup class="footnote-marker">410</sup><i class="footnote">16:8. Mentioned also above, 2:8.</i> “Another interpretation of <i>Le’ovdah uleshomrah (to cultivate her and to keep her)</i><sup class="footnote-marker">411</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 2:15.</i> is that these words refer to the sacrifices, as it is said, <i>‘Ta’avdun’ (Ye shall serve) G-d upon this mountain</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">412</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 3:12.</i> It is this which Scripture says, <i>‘Tishm’ru’ (Ye shall keep) to offer unto Me in its appointed season</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">413</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 28:2.</i> By this Midrash, the Rabbis hinted that the sacrifices will cause growth and expansion in the tree of life and the tree of knowledge and all other trees in the garden of Eden. It is this which constitutes their cultivation and care.<br>Now Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra denies what the scholars have said, namely, that Pishon is the Nile, because they found that the Nile comes from the Mountain of Frankincense [far south of the equator], and therefore it swells during the days of summer.<sup class="footnote-marker">414</sup><i class="footnote">For when it is summer time in the northern hemisphere, it is the time of the rainy season in the southern hemisphere. Hence the Nile, the source of which is in the southern hemisphere, swells during the summer time. And “we know that the Garden of Eden is near the equator, where day and night are always equal” (Ibn Ezra), it follows that Pishon is not the Nile, since the Nile originates far south of the equator. This is the opinion of Ibn Ezra. Ramban replies: “But it is already known, etc.”</i> But it is already known that many rivers come from their source and flow for a great distance and enter the bowels of the earth for a journey of many days, and then break forth again, and flow from under one of the mountains in a distant place. [This being the case, it is possible that Pishon <i>is</i> the Nile.]

Chapter 4



Verse 1

AND SHE CONCEIVED AND BORE CAIN. The sense of it is that she gave birth to a son, and she called his name Cain [from the word <i>kanah</i>, acquisition], because she said, <i>I have gotten a man with</i> [the help of] <i>the Eternal</i>. In a similar sense is the verse, <i>And she conceived and bore Enoch</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">415</sup><i class="footnote">Further, Verse 17.</i> and many similar verses in this chapter and in other places.<br>“<i>Eth Hashem</i> (with the Eternal). When He created me and my husband He created us by Himself, but in the case of this one, we are co-partners with him.” Thus the words of Rashi.<br>The correct interpretation appears to me to be that she said: “This son will be for me an acquisition for the Eternal, for when we shall die he will exist in our stead to worship his Creator.” This is also the opinion of Onkelos who translated <i>eth hashem</i> to mean “before the Eternal.” [The word <i>eth</i> in the following verses is translated] in a similar sense: <i>And it shall be shown ‘eth hakohen’ (the priest)</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">416</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 13:49.</i> meaning to the priest; <i>And David came near ‘eth ha’am’ (the people)</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">417</sup><i class="footnote">I Samuel 30:21.</i> meaning to the people. Or it may be that <i>eth hashem</i> has the same interpretation as in the verses: <i>And Enoch walked ‘eth ha’elokim’ (with G-d);</i><sup class="footnote-marker">418</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 5:22. See following note.</i> <i>Noah walked ‘eth ha’elokim’ (with G-d)</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">419</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 6:9. The sense here in the verse before us would thus be: I have acquired a man to walk with G-d.</i><br>Now she [Eve] called one son by a name indicating “acquisition,” and the second one she called Abel, denoting “vanity” because man’s acquisition is likened to vanity. But she did not wish to say so explicitly. Therefore, no reason is written for the name of the second son. The secret received by tradition concerning Abel is very profound.<sup class="footnote-marker">420</sup><i class="footnote">See my Hebrew commentary, p. 43.</i>

Verse 2



Verse 3

AND CAIN BROUGHT OF THE FRUIT OF THE GROUND AN OFFERING UNTO THE ETERNAL. 4. AND ABEL, HE ALSO BROUGHT. These men [Cain and Abel] understood the great secret of the sacrifices and the meal-offerings. So also did Noah, [who likewise offered sacrifices].<sup class="footnote-marker">421</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 8:20.</i> Our Rabbis have said that the first man also sacrificed a bullock.<sup class="footnote-marker">422</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 69:32. Chullin 60a.</i> This should close the mouth of those who speak foolishness<sup class="footnote-marker">423</sup><i class="footnote">Reference is made here to the Moreh Nebuchim, III, 46, where it is stated that the laws concerning the sacrifices were intended as a guard against idolatry. It is this theory that Ramban intends to refute when he says that in the days of Adam, Cain and Abel, there was no idolatry and yet they brought sacrifices. There is thus a positive aspect to the sacrifices which Rambam did not take into account.</i> concerning the reason of the sacrifices. I will yet intimate a great principle concerning this matter with the will of the Holy One, blessed be He.<sup class="footnote-marker">424</sup><i class="footnote">See Ramban on Leviticus 1:9.</i>

Verse 4



Verse 5



Verse 6



Verse 7

IS IT NOT THUS, IF THOU MENDEST ‘SE’EITH’. In the opinion of the commentators,<sup class="footnote-marker">425</sup><i class="footnote">Reference is here to R’dak. So also in Onkelos.</i> this means there is a “lifting” or forgiveness of your sin. And in the opinion of Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra it means a “lifting” of your face in contrast to [the question G-d asked of Cain]: <i>Why is thy face fallen?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">426</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 6.</i> For he who is ashamed presses his face downward. Similarly, it is said, <i>And the light of my countenance they cast not down</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">427</sup><i class="footnote">Job 29:24.</i> whereas one who honors him is as if he raises his face upward. This is the sense of the verses: <i>Perhaps he will lift my face;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">428</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 32:21. Meaning, perhaps he will accept me.</i> <i>Do not lift the face of the poor</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">429</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 19:15. Meaning, do not respect the person of the poor in judgment, but judge in righteousness.</i><br>In my opinion the verse means: “If you will mend your ways you will have your rightful superiority in <i>se’eith</i> (dignity) over your brother since you are the firstborn.” And this is the meaning of [G-d’s question to him]: <i>Why art thou wroth?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">426</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 6.</i> For by virtue of his feeling ashamed before his brother, his face fell, and because of his jealousy of him he killed him, and now the Eternal told him: <i>Why art thou wroth</i> regarding your brother, <i>and why is thy face fallen</i> on account of him? <i>Is it not thus! If thou mendest</i>, you will have superiority in <i>dignity</i> over your brother, <i>and if thou dost not mend</i>, evil will come upon you not only because of him [your brother], for <i>at the door</i> of your house your <i>sin lurks</i> causing you to stumble in all your endeavors.
AND UNTO THEE IS ITS LONGING, for your sin longs to cleave to you at all times. Nevertheless <i>thou mayest rule over it</i> if you so desire, for you may mend your ways and remove it from upon you. Thus He taught him [Cain] concerning repentance, that it lies within his power to return anytime he desires and He will forgive him.

Verse 8

AND CAIN SPOKE TO ABEL HIS BROTHER. He began a conversation of argument and contention with him in order to seek a pretext against him and so kill him. This is the language of Rashi. Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra said that the interpretation that appears most likely to him is that Cain related to Abel all the chastisements with which G-d had reprimanded him [and Cain accused Abel of having brought them upon him].<br>But in my opinion it is connected with the following words of Scripture: <i>and it came to pass, when they were in the field</i>, meaning that Cain said to Abel, “Let us go forth into the field,” and there he secretly killed him.<br>It is possible that his intention in killing Abel was that the world be built up from himself for he thought that his father would not have any more children. He also feared that the main building up of the world might be from his brother, [which seemed likely since it was he] whose offering had been favorably accepted.

Verse 9



Verse 10



Verse 11

CURSED ART THOU FROM THE GROUND — more than it has already been cursed on account of its sin. In this, too, it has further sinned in that <i>it hath opened its mouth to take thy brother’s blood</i>. Therefore, I impose upon it an additional curse: <i>it shall not continue to give unto thee her strength</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">430</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 12.</i> Thus the words of Rashi.<br>But this is not correct since here He did not curse the ground because of him as He did in the case of his father, rather He said that he be cursed through the ground. The explanation of the curse is that the earth shall not continue to give him its strength, and that he be a fugitive and a wanderer in it,<sup class="footnote-marker">430</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 12.</i> and He further stated, “<i>When thou tillest the ground</i><sup class="footnote-marker">430</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 12.</i> with all your efforts to cultivate it properly by plowing and hoeing, <i>and in all manner of service in the field</i><sup class="footnote-marker">431</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 1:14.</i> and by properly sowing it, <i>it shall not continue to give unto thee her strength</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">430</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 12.</i> Instead, you will sow much and harvest little.” This then was the curse, in the same sense as in the verse: <i>And I will curse your blessings</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">432</sup><i class="footnote">Malachi 2:2.</i> Thus He uttered the curse in connection with his occupation for <i>he was a tiller of the ground</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">433</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 2.</i> and so He cursed his work. This then is the sense of the expression, <i>it shall not continue to give unto thee her strength</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">430</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 12.</i> meaning, “It will no longer yield to you its full produce as it had done till now when you cultivated it.” And so did Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra explain it.<br>It is possible that He also cursed him though the ground in that it should no longer yield its strength to him of its own accord; the fig-tree and the vine would not yield their strength<sup class="footnote-marker">434</sup><i class="footnote">See Joel 2:22.</i> in his estate, and the trees of the field would not yield him their fruit.<sup class="footnote-marker">435</sup><i class="footnote">See Leviticus 26:4.</i> Then He added, “Even when you work the ground by plowing and sowing, it will not continue to give you its strength as before.” Thus there were two curses relating to his occupation, and a third one — that he be a fugitive and a wanderer in the world. This means that his heart will not be at rest, and he will lack the tranquility to remain in one place on the earth; he will wander forever for the punishment of murderers is exile.<br>The expression <i>in that it hath opened its mouth to take thy brother’s blood</i> means: “You have killed your brother and covered his blood with the earth, and I will decree upon it that it uncover its blood, <i>and she shall no more cover her slain</i><sup class="footnote-marker">436</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 26:21.</i> for it will be punished together with all that is covered up in it, such as seed and plant.” This is the punishment for all blood-letting on the earth, even as it is written, <i>For blood, it polluteth the land</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">437</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 35:33.</i> The pollution of the land consists of a curse upon its produce, as it is written: <i>When one came to a heap of twenty measures, there were but ten; when one came to the wine vat to draw out fifty press-measures, there were but twenty</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">438</sup><i class="footnote">Haggai 2:16.</i>

Verse 12



Verse 13

MY SIN IS GREATER THAN I CAN BEAR. This is in the form of a question: “You bear the worlds above and below, and is it impossible for You to bear my sin?” Thus the words of Rashi quoting Bereshith Rabbah.<sup class="footnote-marker">439</sup><i class="footnote">22:25.</i><br>The correct plain interpretation is that it is a confession. Cain said: “It is true that my sin is too great to be forgiven, and <i>Thou art righteous, O Eternal, and upright are Thy judgments</i><sup class="footnote-marker">440</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 119:137.</i> even though You have punished me exceedingly. And now <i>behold, Thou hast driven me out this day from the face of the land</i><sup class="footnote-marker">441</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 14.</i> for in being a fugitive and a wanderer unable to stay in one place, behold, I am driven from the land and there is no place where I can find rest. <i>And from Thy face shall I be hid</i><sup class="footnote-marker">441</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 14.</i> whereas I will not be able to stand before You to pray or bring a sacrifice and meal-offering for <i>I was ashamed, yea, even confounded, because I did bear the reproach of my youth</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">442</sup><i class="footnote">Jeremiah 31:19.</i> But what shall I do? <i>Whosoever findeth me shall slay me</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">441</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 14.</i> and You in Your manifold loving-kindness did not decree death upon me.” The sense of this is that Cain said before G-d: “Behold, my sin is great, and You have punished me exceedingly, but guard me that I should not be punished more than You have decreed upon me for by being a fugitive and wanderer and unable to build myself a house and fences at any place, the beasts will kill me for your shadow has departed from me.”<sup class="footnote-marker">443</sup><i class="footnote">See Numbers 14:9 and Ramban there.</i> Thus Cain confessed that man is impotent to save himself by his own strength but only by the watchfulness of the Supreme One upon him.

Verse 14



Verse 15

Now because Scripture says, <i>And the Eternal appointed a sign for Cain</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">444</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 15.</i> and it does not say, “and G-d gave him a sign,” or “made him a sign,” it indicates that He appointed for him a steady sign which would always be with him. Perhaps it indicates that as he wandered from place to place he had a sign from G-d indicating the way in which he should walk, and by that he knew that no misfortune would overtake him on that road.<br>In Bereshith Rabbah<sup class="footnote-marker">445</sup><i class="footnote">22:27.</i> the Rabbis similarly stated, “Rabbi Aba said: ‘He gave him a dog.’” Since he feared the beasts, He gave him one of them to walk before him, and wherever the dog turned to go, Cain knew that G-d commanded him to go there and that he would not be killed by any living creature.
