Now the Sages singled out a contemptible sign [a dog] as was befitting him, but the intent is that there was with him a perpetual sign showing him the way to go for such is indicated in the word <i>vayasem (and He appointed)</i>.

Verse 16

AND CAIN WENT OUT FROM THE PRESENCE OF THE ETERNAL. The sense thereof is that he never stood before Him any more, as he meant when he said, <i>and from Thy face shall I be hid</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">441</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 14.</i> [as explained above].<br><i>And he dwelt in the land of Nod</i>. The sense thereof is that Cain did not traverse the entire world, but he dwelt in that land, perpetually wandering therein and not resting at all in any one place thereof, and so it was forever called “the land of <i>Nod</i> (wandering)” after him.

Verse 17

AND HE BUILDED A CITY, AND CALLED THE NAME OF THE CITY AFTER THE NAME OF HIS SON ENOCH. For at first Cain thought that he would be childless on account of his sin, but after a child was born to him he began to build a city for his son to dwell therein. But because he himself was cursed and his works would not prosper, he called the city “Enoch,” thus proclaiming that he did not build it for himself since he has no city or dwelling place in the land because he was a fugitive and wanderer; rather, the building would be for Enoch, and it is as if Enoch had built it for himself.<br>Now since it does not say <i>vayiven ir</i> (and he built a city) — [but rather, <i>vayehi boneh ir</i>, which literally means “and he was building a city,”] as it says elsewhere, <i>vayiven (and he builded) Nineveh;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">446</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 10:11.</i> <i>And the children of Gad built Dibon</i><sup class="footnote-marker">447</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 32:34.</i> — it indicates that he was building the city all his days because his works were cursed. Thus he would build a little with effort and toil, and then move and wander off from that place and return there and build a little more, but he would not prosper in his ways.<br>The descendants of Cain and his works were recorded in Scripture in order to make known that G-d is long-suffering and that He prolonged the time of his punishment,<sup class="footnote-marker">448</sup><i class="footnote">See Exodus 34:6. This constitutes one of the Thirteen Attributes of G-d.</i> for he begot children and children’s children, and then it relates how He visited <i>the iniquity of the fathers upon the children</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">449</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 7.</i> and his descendants perished. Our Rabbis say<sup class="footnote-marker">450</sup><i class="footnote">Koheleth Rabbah 6:3.</i> that Cain lived many years and that he died in the flood. Thus his hoary head did not go down to the grave in peace,<sup class="footnote-marker">451</sup><i class="footnote">See I Kings 2:6.</i> rather he saw his destruction <i>and all his seed with him</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">452</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 46:6.</i><br>It would appear that Cain’s descendants consisted of only six generations<sup class="footnote-marker">453</sup><i class="footnote">Enoch, Irad, Mehujael, Methusael, Lamech, Jabal and Jubal and Tubal-Cain (three brothers). Scripture does not relate any history beyond the children of Lamech for they all perished in the flood.</i> until the flood, while among the descendants of Seth [the third son of Adam] there were an additional two generations before the flood.<sup class="footnote-marker">454</sup><i class="footnote">Enosh, Kenan, Mahalalel, Jared, Enoch, Methuselah, Lamech and Noah.</i> [It may be that Cain’s descendants consisted of more than six generations before the flood, but Scripture] had no need to relate anything concerning them. It recorded only the names of those who began the building of cities, the grazing of sheep, the art of music, and the skill of working with metals. Scripture also recorded Lamech’s chastisement of his wives in order to tell us that he did beget children but his sons perished before they begot offspring.

Verse 18



Verse 19



Verse 20



Verse 21



Verse 22

FORGER OF EVERY CUTTING INSTRUMENT OF BRASS AND IRON. He was a forger and cutter of all brass and iron.<sup class="footnote-marker">455</sup><i class="footnote">The translation preserving the order of the Hebrew words is: “the forger of all cutters in copper and iron.” Ramban transposes the words to read: “the forger and cutter in all copper and iron.”</i> Scripture thus states that he was a forger and cutter in all works of brass and iron. A similar [usage in transposing a word is found in the verse]: <i>Forgive all iniquity, and accept that which is good</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">456</sup><i class="footnote">Hosea 14:3. The order preserving translation of the Hebrew would be: “All forgive iniquity….” Here too a transposition of words is necessary as above.</i> In the opinion of Onkelos, however, this is connected with the first verses, meaning he was the father of every forger and cutter in brass and iron.
AND THE SISTER OF TUBAL-CAIN WAS NAAMAH. This is as if Scripture would say: “and a sister was born to him and her name was Naamah.” A similar sense is found in the verses: <i>And Lotan’s sister was Timnah;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">457</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 36:22.</i> <i>And Miriam their sister;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">458</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 26:59.</i> <i>His sister’s name was Maacah</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">459</sup><i class="footnote">I Chronicles 7:15.</i><br>In Bereshith Rabbah<sup class="footnote-marker">460</sup><i class="footnote">23:4.</i> there are some Rabbis who say that Naamah was Noah’s wife. “And why did they call her Naamah [which means lovely]? Because her deeds were lovely and pleasant.” By this the Rabbis meant to say that she was famous in those generations because she was a righteous woman and she gave birth to righteous children. This was why Scripture mentioned her. If so, a small remembrance of Cain was left in the world. However, if we say that she was not the woman from whom Noah begot his three sons, there is no reason for Scripture mentioning her. However, our Rabbis have another Midrash<sup class="footnote-marker">461</sup><i class="footnote">Pirkei d’Rabbi Eliezer, Chapter 22.</i> concerning her which states that she was the very beautiful woman in whom the <i>bnei ha’elohim</i><sup class="footnote-marker">462</sup><i class="footnote">See further 6:2, 4.</i> erred. This is hinted in the verse, <i>And the ‘bnei ha’elohim’ saw the daughters of men</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">463</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 2.</i> as mentioned in Pirkei d’Rabbi Eliezer.<sup class="footnote-marker">461</sup><i class="footnote">Pirkei d’Rabbi Eliezer, Chapter 22.</i> But other sources<sup class="footnote-marker">464</sup><i class="footnote">Mentioned in Midrash Hane’elam. (See my Hebrew commentary, p. 46, Note 3.)</i> have it that Naamah was the wife of Shamdon, the mother of Ashmedai,<sup class="footnote-marker">465</sup><i class="footnote">Chief of demons.</i> and it is from her that the demons were born for her name is indeed found in the writings of “the use of the demons.” Scripture hints and deals briefly with such hidden matters.

Verse 23

AND LAMECH SAID UNTO HIS WIVES. For the sense of this verse, the commentators have depended on the opinion of Onkelos who explained <i>therefore whosoever slayeth Cain vengeance shall be taken on him ‘shivatha’im’</i><sup class="footnote-marker">466</sup><i class="footnote">Above, Verse 15.</i> as meaning that at the end of seven generations, vengeance shall be taken on him [Cain], but not now<sup class="footnote-marker">467</sup><i class="footnote">The sense of the verse, according to Onkelos, would thus be: “Therefore, all ye who would slay Cain, know that seven generations later vengeance will be taken on him (Cain), but not now.”</i> because G-d would be long-suffering with him. Now Lamech’s wives feared to bear children because they would be the seventh generation to Cain, but he comforted his wives by saying that G-d would be forbearing with him for yet seventy-seven generations because he would pray before Him, for He is long-suffering and would have mercy upon him. Or it may be that Lamech’s words were an absurd <i>a fortiori</i> argument, in accordance with the Midrash that Rashi mentioned, [namely: “For if so, the Holy One, blessed be He, could never exact His debt nor fulfill His word.”] If so, Scripture is stating: “Therefore whosoever slayeth Cain, vengeance shall be taken of the seventh generation” and not in his days. And this is the translation of Onkelos: “All who would slay Cain! In seven generations, punishment will be exacted of him [Cain].” But if so, it would have been proper that the verse, <i>And Lamech said unto his wives</i>, appear before [Verse 20: <i>And Adah</i> — Lamech’s wife — <i>bore Jabal</i>].<br>In my opinion, the word <i>shivatha’im</i> does not mean “seven generations” because this word is not used for seven separate units but rather for the multiplying of one thing seven times, such as: <i>refined ‘shivatha’im’ (sevenfold);</i><sup class="footnote-marker">468</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 12:7.</i> <i>restore ‘shivatha’im’ (sevenfold);</i><sup class="footnote-marker">469</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 6:31.</i> <i>and the light of the sun shall be ‘shivatha’im’</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">470</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 30:26.</i> meaning doubled and redoubled seven times. But the meaning of <i>therefore, whosoever slayeth Cain</i><sup class="footnote-marker">466</sup><i class="footnote">Above, Verse 15.</i> is, according to its real sense, that G-d said: “Therefore, whosoever slayeth Cain will have vengeance taken on him sevenfold, for I will punish his slayer seven times for his sin, since I have promised Cain that he will not be slain in view of his fear of Me and his confession before Me.” However, the matter of Lamech and his wives is not mentioned clearly in Scripture. We could also say that they feared lest Lamech be killed as a punishment for his ancestor’s sin since G-d did not tell Cain, “I have forgiven you.” Instead, He promised him only that he will not be slain, but He would collect His debt from his children, and they did not know when. And so indeed the matter happened. Lamech, however, comforted them by saying that G-d would have mercy on him even as He had mercy on Cain, for he had cleaner hands than Cain, and he also would pray before Him and He would hear his prayer.<br>However, it appears to me that Lamech was a very wise man in every craft, and he taught his eldest son [Jabal] the business of pasturing according to the nature of the cattle. To the second son [Jubal] he taught the art of music, and he taught the third one [Tubal-Cain] to forge metals and to make swords, spears, javelins, and all instruments of war. His wives were then afraid that he might be punished because he brought the sword and murder into the world, and he thus retained in his hand the evil deed of his ancestor [Cain] since he was a descendant of the first murderer and he created <i>the waster to destroy</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">471</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 54:16.</i> But he [Lamech] told them: “I did not slay a man by wounds, nor a child by bruises,<sup class="footnote-marker">472</sup><i class="footnote">See Verse 23 in this chapter.</i> as did Cain, and G-d will not punish me. Instead, He will guard me from being killed moreso than Cain” He [Lamech] mentioned this in order to say that man cannot kill only with the sword and javelin; death caused by wounds and bruises is a worse death than by the sword. Therefore, the sword is not the cause of murder, and there is no sin upon him who made it.

Chapter 5



Verse 1

THIS IS THE BOOK OF THE GENERATIONS OF ADAM. These are the children He will mention in the chapter.<sup class="footnote-marker">473</sup><i class="footnote">So Rashi and Ibn Ezra.</i> In my opinion, this alludes to the entire Torah, for the entire Torah is <i>the book of the generations of Adam</i>. Therefore, He says here “book” and does not say, “And these are the generations of Adam,” as He says in other places, e.g. <i>And these are the generations of Ishmael;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">474</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 25:12.</i> <i>And these are the generations of Isaac</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">475</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 19.</i> and so in all such cases.

Verse 2

AND HE BLESSED THEM. This means that He gave them the power of procreation, to be blessed forever with very many sons and daughters. The intent is to state that begetting offspring comes as a blessing of G-d, for Adam and Eve were not born but were created from nothing and they were blessed to do so [to beget offspring].
AND HE CALLED THEIR NAME ADAM. Since the name <i>Adam</i> (man) is a generic name for the whole human species, Scripture mentions that G-d called the first pair by that name because all generations were potentially in him. It is with reference to them that Scripture says, <i>This is the book of the generations of Adam</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">476</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 1.</i><br/>Rabbeinu Sherira Gaon<sup class="footnote-marker">477</sup><i class="footnote">A famous Gaon of the academy of Pumbeditha who flourished in the second half of the tenth century. He is the author of the letter to the Jews of Kairwan giving a historical account of how the Mishna was written and how the traditions were transmitted through the generations following the era of the Mishna. He was the father of Rav Hai Gaon, the last of the Gaonim.</i> wrote<sup class="footnote-marker">478</sup><i class="footnote">See my Kitvei Haramban, I, p. 161.</i> that the Sages transmitted to one another [the principles of knowledge concerning] “the recognition of faces” and the arrangements of the lines in the face. Some of these principles are stated in the order of the words of the verse, <i>This is the book of the generations of Adam</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">476</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 1.</i> and some in the order of the following verse, <i>Male and female He created them</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">479</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 2.</i> But the secrets and mysteries of the Torah are transmitted only to those in whom we see signs indicating that he is worthy of it. These are the words of the Gaon, but we have not merited to understand them.

Verse 3

AND HE BEGOT A SON IN HIS OWN LIKENESS, AFTER HIS IMAGE. It is known that all who are born from the living are in the likeness and in the image of those who give birth to them, [so why was this verse necessary?] However, because Adam was elevated in his likeness and image in that Scripture said of him, <i>In the likeness of G-d He made him</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">476</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 1.</i> Scripture explains that his offspring were also in this ennobled likeness. Scripture did not state this concerning Cain and Abel for it did not want to prolong the discussion of them. It explains it, however, in the case of Seth because the world was founded from him, [Noah being his direct descendant]. Or it may be that because Adam was created with absolutely perfect form, Scripture relates concerning Seth that he was like him [Adam] in strength and beauty.

Verse 4

AND THE DAYS OF ADAM AFTER HE BEGOT SETH WERE EIGHT HUNDRED YEARS. Because of the long lives of these first men, Scripture states their ages before they begot children and also afterwards, and then sums them all up in the end until the generations which followed the flood.<br>The reason for their longevity is that the first man, the handiwork of the Holy One, blessed be He, was made in absolute perfection as regards beauty, strength, and height. Even after it was decreed upon him that he be mortal, it was in his nature to live a long time. But when the flood came upon the earth, the atmosphere became tainted, and as a result their days kept on decreasing. Until the flood, their days were about the length of Adam’s; some even lived longer than Adam.<sup class="footnote-marker">480</sup><i class="footnote">Jered lived 962 years (Verse 20), and Methuselah lived 969 (Verse 27) while Adam lived 930 years (Verse 5).</i> And Shem [Noah’s son], who was born before the flood, lived six hundred years;<sup class="footnote-marker">481</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis, 11:10-11.</i> he benefitted from his innate strength, but the tainted air after the flood caused him harm, [hence he died at a younger age than that attained by the preceding generations]. The days of his sons who were born after the flood were still more shortened until they came down to four hundred years.<sup class="footnote-marker">482</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verses 10-17.</i> You can see that this degree of longevity remained with them until the generation of the Dispersion, when the change of climates caused by the Dispersion affected them, and their days were again shortened. Thus you find that the life of Peleg, <i>in whose days the earth was divided</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">483</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 10:25.</i> came down to half their days, i.e., two hundred years.<sup class="footnote-marker">484</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 11:19.</i><br>It would appear that in the generations of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob, people lived seventy and eighty years, just as Moses, our teacher, mentioned in his prayer.<sup class="footnote-marker">485</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 90:10. <i>The days of our years are threescore years and ten, or even by reason of strength fourscore years</i>.</i> But as for the righteous ones in their generations, <i>The fear of the Eternal prolongeth days</i><sup class="footnote-marker">486</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 10:27.</i> for them. For Pharaoh wondered about Jacob’s old age, and Jacob in turn spoke to him about the long days of his fathers, even as he said, <i>And they have not attained unto the days of the years of the life of my fathers in the days of their sojournings</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">487</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 47:9.</i><br>Now what the Rabbi<sup class="footnote-marker">488</sup><i class="footnote">Rabbi Moshe ben Maimon (Rambam). See above, Note 139.</i> has written in the Moreh Nebuchim<sup class="footnote-marker">489</sup><i class="footnote">II, 47.</i> does not seem right to me, namely, that the longevity was only in those individuals mentioned, while the rest of the people in those generations lived lives of ordinary natural length. He further said that this exception was due to the mode of living and food of such people or by way of a miracle. But these are words without substance. Why should this miracle have happened to them since they were neither prophets nor righteous, nor worthy that a miracle be done for them, especially for generation after generation. And how could a proper mode of living and proper food prolong their years to the extent that they are so many times greater than that of the entire generation? It is possible that there were also others who observed such a mode of living, in which case all or most of them should have attained similar longevity. And how did it happen that enough of the wisdom concerning this good mode of living did not come down to just one of all the sons of Noah after the flood [to enable him to match the longevity of his ancestors], for there was among them a little wisdom of their ancestors even though it steadily decreased from generation to generation?

Chapter 6



Verse 1

AND IT CAME TO PASS, WHEN MEN BEGAN TO MULTIPLY ON THE FACE OF THE EARTH. When Scripture mentioned Noah and his sons and wanted to begin the account of the flood, it said that as soon as men began to multiply they began to sin, and they continued their sinful ways for many years until Noah was four hundred and eighty years<sup class="footnote-marker">490</sup><i class="footnote">Noah begot children at the age of 500 (Verse 32 in Chapter 5). Twenty years before, G-d decreed the advent of the flood. (See Rashi here, Verse 3.)</i> of age. Then the Holy One, blessed be He, decreed against them that “His spirit will not abide in them forever,”<sup class="footnote-marker">491</sup><i class="footnote">See Verse 3.</i> but that He will prolong their years until their measure of sin is full, for such is the way of G-d’s judgment.

Verse 2

BNEI HA’ELOHIM. The sons of princes and rulers. This is the language of Rashi, and so it is in Bereshith Rabbah.<sup class="footnote-marker">492</sup><i class="footnote">26:8.</i> If so, Scripture relates that the judges whose duty it was to administer justice among them committed open violence without anyone interfering.
‘KI’ (WHEN) THEY WERE FAIR. [The meaning of the word <i>ki</i> here] is the same as in the verses: <i>‘Ki’ (when) thou seest the ass of him that hateth thee;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">493</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 23:5.</i> <i>‘ki’ (when) a bird’s nest chance to be before thee</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">494</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 22:6.</i> When the daughters of men were fair, they would take them forcibly as wives for themselves. Thus Scripture tells of the violence and mentions further, <i>whomsoever they chose</i>, in order to include those who were married to others. Scripture, however, did not mention the prohibition concerning them clearly, and the punishment decreed upon them was only because of the violence,<sup class="footnote-marker">495</sup><i class="footnote">Further, Verse 13.</i> because this is a reasoned concept and does not require the Torah to prohibit it.

Verse 3

‘BESHAGAM’ (FOR THAT ALSO) HE IS FLESH. It is as if <i>beshagam</i> were written <i>beshegam</i> with a <i>segol</i> under the <i>shin</i>. And Rashi explained: “This quality is also in him, that he is only flesh, and yet he is not humble before Me. What would he do if he were made of fire or some hard substance.” This explanation has neither rhyme nor reason.<br>Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra explained that G-d said, “My spirit will not abide in man forever because of this violence and also because man is flesh, and when he reaches a certain age he disintegrates.” Ibn Ezra thus understands the verse as if it said, <i>gam beshehu basar</i> (also because he is flesh). But what need is there for stating this contention when it is known <i>that they were but flesh</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">496</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 78:39.</i> and death had been decreed on them, as it says, <i>For dust thou art, and unto dust shalt thou return?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">497</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 3:19.</i><br>The correct interpretation appears to me to be that G-d said: “My spirit shall not abide in man forever because man also is flesh as all flesh that creepeth upon the earth in the forms of fowl and cattle and beast, and it is not fitting that the spirit of G-d be within him.” The purport is to state <i>that G-d made man upright</i><sup class="footnote-marker">498</sup><i class="footnote">Ecclesiastes 7:29.</i> to be like the ministering angels by virtue of the soul He gave him. But he was drawn after the flesh and corporeal desires; <i>he is like the beasts that perish</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">499</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 7:13.</i> and therefore the spirit of G-d will no longer be sheathed in him for he is corporeal and not godly. However, He will prolong for them [this withdrawal of spirit] if they repent. The sense of this verse is thus similar to [the verse in Psalm 78]: <i>So He remembered that they were but flesh, a wind that passeth away, and cometh not again</i>.

Verse 4

THE NEPHILIM. Rashi comments: “[They were called <i>nephilim</i> because] they fell (<i>naphlu</i>) and caused the downfall (<i>hipilu</i>) of the world.” This is found in Bereshith Rabbah.<sup class="footnote-marker">500</sup><i class="footnote">26:7.</i> The masters of language<sup class="footnote-marker">501</sup><i class="footnote">Found in R’dak.</i> say that they [the <i>Nephilim</i>] were so called because the heart of man fell from fear of them. The same applies to the word <i>ha’eimim</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">502</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 14:5. <i>Eimah</i> means terror. The <i>Eimim</i> thus induced terror into the hearts of those who saw them.</i>
IN THOSE DAYS. Rashi comments: “in the days of the generation of Enosh. AND ALSO AFTER THAT. Although they witnessed the destruction of the generation of Enosh when the ocean rose and flooded a third of the world, still they did not humble themselves and take a lesson from them.”<br>Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra explained: <i>“also after</i> the flood, since the sons of <i>Anak</i><sup class="footnote-marker">503</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 13:33. The giants.</i> were of the family of <i>bnei ha’elohim.”</i> If so, we must say that either the wives of Noah’s sons were of their [the <i>Nephilim’s</i>] descendants and resembled them or that ibn Ezra will accept the statement of the Rabbi<sup class="footnote-marker">504</sup><i class="footnote">Rabbi Yochanan (Niddah 61 a).</i> who advanced the interpretation that Og<sup class="footnote-marker">505</sup><i class="footnote">Og, King of Bashan (Numbers 21:33). It is he, according to Rabbi Yochanan, of whom Scripture says: <i>And there came one that had escaped</i> (Genesis 14:13); i.e., <i>escaped</i> from the flood.</i> escaped from the flood, to which Rabbi Abraham will add that others too escaped with him [since the verse states: <i>“The ‘Nephilim’</i> — (in the plural) — <i>were in the earth…and also after that”</i>, which Ibn Ezra interprets as meaning after the flood].<br>The correct interpretation appears to me to be that Adam and his wife are called <i>bnei ha’elohim</i> because they were G-d’s handiwork and He was their father; they had no father besides Him. And he [Adam] begot many children, as it is written, <i>And he begot sons and daughters</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">506</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 5:4.</i> Now these men, first to be born of a father and mother, were of great perfection in height and strength because they were born in the likeness of their father, as it is written concerning Seth, <i>And he [Adam] begot a son in his own likeness, after his image</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">507</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 3.</i> And it is possible that all the children of the first generations — Adam, Seth, Enosh — were called <i>bnei ha’elohim</i> because these three men were in the likeness of G-d. But then the worship of idols commenced, and there came upon men a weakness and slackness.<br>And so they said in Bereshith Rabbah:<sup class="footnote-marker">508</sup><i class="footnote">24:6.</i> “<i>This is the book of the generations of Adam</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">509</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 5:1.</i> Are not the first ones <i>toldoth</i> (offspring)! But what are they? [They are in the image and likeness of] G-d. They raised a question before Aba Kohen Bardela: ‘Adam, Seth, Enosh?’ At first, he was silent, but then he said to them: ‘Up to here [Seth] they were in the image and likeness of G-d; after that, Kenan, vexers.’”<sup class="footnote-marker">510</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Kenan, vexers</i>. Enosh’s son was Kenan (Above, 5:9), which name is interpreted as having the same root as the word <i>kanteir</i> (he who makes himself disagreeable).</i><br>Now when men began to multiply and daughters were born to them, the men of these first generations were in their strength, and because of their great desire they would choose the beautiful women of tall stature and good health. Now first Scripture tells that by force they took them unto themselves as wives, and afterwards it tells that they came in a promiscuous manner to the daughters of men who were not of that high degree, and the matter was not known until they begot children for them, and everyone recognized that they were not the offspring of other people but that they had been born to these <i>bnei ha’elohim</i> because these children were very tall. They were, however, inferior to their fathers in height and strength, [This is the meaning of the name <i>Nephilim</i> — inferior ones], just as the word <i>Nephilim</i> is used in the expression: <i>I am not ‘nophel’ (inferior) to you</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">511</sup><i class="footnote">Job 12:3.</i> Still they were mighty men in comparison with the rest of the people. And Scripture tells that this happened in the first generation to those who were called <i>bnei ha’elohim</i> because they were of absolute perfection, and it is they who caused the daughters of men to beget <i>nephilim</i> (inferior ones); <i>and also after that</i>, for the <i>nephilim</i> themselves begot <i>nephilim</i> from them.<br>The meaning of the expression, <i>that were of old</i>, is that after the flood, the men, upon seeing the mighty, would remember these <i>nephilim</i> and say: “There have already been mightier men than these in the ages which were before us.” They were <i>the men of</i> renown in all generations afterward. This is a fitting explanation of this chapter. But the Midrash of Rabbi Eliezer the Great,<sup class="footnote-marker">512</sup><i class="footnote">Chapter 22.</i> in the chapters concerning the angels that fell from their place of holiness in heaven — as is mentioned in the Gemara of Tractate <i>Yoma</i> —<sup class="footnote-marker">513</sup><i class="footnote">67b.</i> fits into the language of the verse more than all other interpretations. But it would necessitate delving at length into the secret of this subject.

Verse 5



Verse 6

AND THE ETERNAL REPENTED… AND IT GRIEVED HIM AT HIS HEART. The Torah speaks in the language of men. The purport is that <i>they rebelled, and grieved His holy spirit</i><sup class="footnote-marker">514</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 63:10.</i> with their sins. The sense of the expression <i>at His heart</i> is that He did not tell this to a prophet, a messenger of G-d. This expression is also found with respect to thinking, just as: <i>to speak to my heart</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">515</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 24:45.</i> and other similar expressions.<br>In Bereshith Rabbah<sup class="footnote-marker">516</sup><i class="footnote">27:6.</i> there is a significant matter concerning this, expressed by a parable which the Rabbis bring of an agent and an architect.<sup class="footnote-marker">517</sup><i class="footnote">Rabbi Berachyah said: “It is like a king who had a palace built by an architect, and when he saw it, it displeased him. Against whom is he to complain? Surely against the architect.” Rabbi Assi said: “It is like one who traded through an agent and suffered a loss. Whom does he blame? The agent. Here too <i>It grieved Him at His heart</i>.”</i> This constitutes a great secret which is not permitted to be written down. The one who knows it will understand why here the Tetragrammaton is written while in the whole of the rest of the chapter and the account of the flood, the name <i>Elokim</i> is used.

Verse 7



Verse 8

BUT NOAH FOUND GRACE IN THE EYES OF THE ETERNAL. The meaning thereof is that all his deeds were pleasing and sweet before Him. Similarly: <i>For thou hast found grace in My sight, and I know thee by name</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">518</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 33:17.</i> This is like the verses: <i>And He gave him favor in the sight of the keeper of the prison;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">519</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 39:21.</i> <i>And Esther obtained favor in the sight of all of them that looked upon her</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">520</sup><i class="footnote">Esther 2:15.</i> Scripture mentions this in contrast to what it said concerning his [Noah’s] generation, namely, that all their deeds brought grief before Him, blessed be He. But of Noah it says that he found grace in His eyes, and afterwards it tells<sup class="footnote-marker">521</sup><i class="footnote">In the following <i>Seder Noach</i>.</i> why he was pleasing before G-d: because he was a perfectly righteous man.<br>Noach

Verse 9

THESE ARE ‘TOLDOTH’ NOAH. Commentators<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">Ibn Ezra and R’dak. These commentators felt the difficulty in explaining <i>toldoth</i> to mean “progeny” or “generations” since it further states, <i>And Noah begot three sons</i>.</i> have explained the word <i>toldoth</i> to mean “his experiences” [or “his events”] much the same as the sense of: <i>what a day ‘yeiled’ (may bring forth)</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 27:1.</i><br>In this way the word <i>toldoth</i> refers to the entire section [since all the events of the flood are occurrences in the life of Noah]. But this does not appear to me to be correct since the external events in the life of a person, [over which he has no control], are not his <i>toldoth</i>.<br>The correct interpretation is that the word <i>toldoth</i> here retains its literal meaning of “progeny,” just as, <i>These are ‘toldoth’ (the progeny of) the sons of Noah;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 10:1.</i> <i>And these are ‘toldoth’ (the progeny of) Ishmael</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 25:12.</i> Thus Scripture is saying, “These are the progeny of Noah: Shem, Ham, and Japheth.”<br>Scripture however repeats, <i>And Noah begot three sons</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 10.</i> because [at the end of the first verse] it interrupted by saying, <i>Noah was a righteous man, and whole-hearted</i>, in order to inform us why He commanded him concerning the ark. And even though Scripture has already stated above, <i>And Noah was five hundred years old; and Noah begot Shem, Ham, and Japheth</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 5:32.</i> it returns to mention them a second time in order to relate that Noah was unlike all his ancestors who begot daughters and sons. This is the meaning of the words, <i>three sons;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 10.</i> Scripture mentions their number in order to say that these three alone were his progeny, and they were saved by his merit, <i>and by them was the whole earth overspread</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 9:19.</i>
HE WAS A RIGHTEOUS MAN AND WHOLE-HEARTED. Scripture mentions that he was guiltless and perfect in his righteousness in order to inform us that he was worthy to be saved from the flood without any punishment whatever since he was whole-hearted in righteousness. For a <i>tzadik</i> (a righteous person) is one who is found guiltless in judgment as opposed to the wicked person, as Scripture says, <i>And they come unto judgment, and the judges judge them, by justifying the righteous, and condemning the wicked;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 25:1.</i> and also, <i>For Thou art just in all that has come upon us, for Thou hast dealt truly;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">Nehemiah 9:33.</i> similarly, <i>In righteousness shalt thou judge thy neighbor</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 19:15.</i> But in the case of Abraham, concerning whom it says, <i>that he will command his children to do ‘tz’dakah’</i> and <i>‘mishpat,’</i><sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 18:19.</i> Scripture praises him for righteousness which is synonymous with judgment, and for mercy which is synonymous with <i>tz’dakah</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">Ramban is thus saying that where Scripture uses <i>tzedek</i> alone it means “guiltless in judgment,” but in the case of Abraham where in addition to <i>tzedek</i> (or <i>tz’dakah</i>) Scripture also mentions <i>mishpat</i>, (judgment) <i>mishpat</i> of necessity means “guiltless in judgment,” while <i>tz’dakah</i> in this case means “mercifulness.”</i><br>And Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra said, “<i>Righteous</i> in deeds; <i>whole-hearted</i> in his heart.” However, it is written, <i>Thou art whole-hearted in thy ways;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">Ezekiel 28:15.</i> [the term “whole-hearted” is thus used in connection with “ways” and <i>not</i> with matters of the heart].<br>Now after Scripture said that Noah was a righteous man, meaning that he was neither a man of violence nor one who perverted his ways as did the guilty ones of his generation, it further said that he walked with the glorious Name,<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">See Deuteronomy 28:58.</i> fearing Him alone. He was not enticed by the astrologers, enchanters and soothsayers, and surely not by idolatry, and he paid no heed to them at all; to G-d alone he did always cleave, and he walked in the way G-d chose or taught him for he was a prophet. This is analogous in meaning to the verse, <i>After the Eternal your G-d shall ye walk, and Him shall ye fear</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 13:5.</i> which is stated in connection with the removal of him who prophesies to encourage the worship of idols and gives a sign or wonder to verify his words, as I will explain. I will again mention this in connection with the verse, <i>Walk before Me, and be thou whole-hearted</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 17:1.</i> if He Who is perfect in knowledge<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">See Job 36:4.</i> will be with me.<br>Now since Noah was a righteous man and undeserving of punishment, it was fitting that his sons and his household be saved by his merit for if his sons were to perish, it would have been a punishment upon him. Or it may be said that he was a perfectly righteous man, and his sons and household were also righteous since he taught them; this is analogous to that which is written concerning Abraham: <i>For I have known him, to the end that he may command his children and his household</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 18:19.</i>
IN HIS GENERATIONS. Some of our Rabbis explained it to his credit, [i.e., he was righteous despite his generation]; it follows all the more had he lived in a generation of righteous people. Others explain it to his discredit. [In comparison with his own generation he was considered righteous, but had he lived in the generation of Abraham he would not have been considered of any consequence.] Thus the language of Rashi.<br>The correct interpretation according to the plain meaning of Scripture appears to be that he alone was a righteous man in those generations, there being no righteous or whole-hearted men except him in those generations. In a similar sense is the verse, <i>For thee I have seen righteous before Me in this generation</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 7:1.</i> meaning that there is no other in the generation worthy of being saved. Scripture says, <i>in his generations</i> —[using the plural form]— because many generations passed since the time men had become corrupted, and there was no righteous man besides him. Let not the word of our Rabbis concerning Methuselah,<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">Bereshith Rabbah 32:10.</i> [which said that he was a righteous man], cause you difficulty for Scripture tells only that there was no righteous man worthy of being saved from the flood in all those generations except Noah.

Verse 10

SHEM, HAM, AND JAPHETH. It appears to me that Japheth was the oldest, as it is said, <i>the brother of Japheth the elder</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 10:21.</i> and so in counting their generations, Scripture mentions the children of Japheth first.<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 10:2.</i> Ham was the youngest of all, as it is said, <i>And [Noah] knew what his youngest son had done unto him</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 9:24.</i> Here, however, Scripture mentions Shem first because of his superiority and then Ham, for they were born in that order. Thus Japheth is left at the end. But Scripture did not want to say, “Shem and Japheth and Ham,” because in that case all of them would have been mentioned out of the order of their birth, and Japheth had no outstanding quality to merit that the order of birth be dispensed with on his account. Shem, however, is mentioned here first because of his superiority even though in the account of the generations he is last.<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 10:21.</i> Similarly, [we find the verses]: <i>The sons of Abraham: Isaac and Ishmael;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">I Chronicles 1:28. Here too Isaac is mentioned first because of his superiority although Ishmael was older.</i> <i>And I gave to Isaac Jacob and Esau</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">Joshua 24:4. This also is similar to the above case.</i>

Verse 11



Verse 12

FOR ALL FLESH HAD CORRUPTED THEIR WAY. If we were to explain <i>all flesh</i> in its usual sense and thus say that even cattle, beasts and fowl corrupted their way by consorting with other species, as Rashi has explained, we must then say that the expression, <i>for the earth is filled with violence through them</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 13.</i> does not mean “because of all of them” but only because of some of them [since “violence” does not apply to beasts and cattle], and Scripture tells of the punishment of man alone [even though <i>all flesh</i> corrupted their way]. Or we may say that the cattle, beasts, and fowl also did not follow their natural instincts, and all cattle seized prey and all fowl became birds of prey; thus they too committed violence.<br>By way of the simple meaning of Scripture, <i>all flesh</i> means “all men.” Further on Scripture says explicitly: <i>all flesh wherein is the breath of life;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 7:15.</i> <i>and of every living thing of all flesh</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 6:19.</i> meaning all living bodies. But here it says <i>all flesh</i>, meaning all people. Similarly [we find the verses]: <i>All flesh shall come to worship before Me</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 66:23.</i> [meaning “all people”]; <i>Or when the flesh hath in the skin thereof</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 13:24.</i> [where again reference is only to people].

Verse 13

VIOLENCE, that is, robbery and oppression. Now G-d gave Noah the explanation [that the flood was due to the fact that the “the earth is filled with] violence” and did not mention “the corruption of the way” [recorded in the preceding verse] because violence is a sin that is known and widely publicized. Our Rabbis have said<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">Sanhedrin 108a.</i> that it was on account of the sin of violence that their fate was sealed. The reason for it is that the prohibition against violence is a rational commandment,<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">Likewise Ramban above 6:2. See also Yehudah Halevi’s Al Khazari, II, 48, that “the rational laws are the basis and preamble of the divine law, preceding it in character and time, and being indispensable in the administration of every human society.” (Hirschfeld’s translation.)</i> there being no need for a prophet to admonish them against it. Besides, it is evil committed against both heaven and mankind. Thus He informed Noah of the sin for <i>which the end is come</i> — the doom is reached.<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote">See Ezekiel 7:6-7.</i>
AND BEHOLD, I WILL DESTROY THEM ‘ETH’ THE EARTH. This is similar to saying “<i>from</i> the earth.” So also: <i>When I go forth ‘eth’ the city</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 9:29.</i> [meaning “<i>from</i> the city”]; <i>he suffered ‘eth’ his feet</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote">I Kings 15:23.</i> [meaning “<i>from</i> his feet”]. Another interpretation is that <i>eth ha’aretz</i> means “with the earth” for even the land was blotted out to the depth of a furrow of three handbreadths. Thus the language of Rashi quoting Bereshith Rabbah.<sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote">31:7.</i><br>And Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra said that the word <i>mashchitham (destroy them)</i> draws along with it a similar word, [meaning it is as if the verb “destroy” appears twice in the verse], thus stating, “And behold, I will destroy them and destroy the earth.”<br>By way of the truth [the mystic teaching of the Cabala],<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote">See Bereshith, Note 63.</i> this is like the verse, <i>eth hashamayim ve’eth ha’aretz (the heaven and the earth)</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 1:1.</i> thus intimating that “the earth”<sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote">Here referring to “the earth of immortal life.”</i> will be destroyed, and with the destruction of the earth they too will be destroyed and thus they will be blotted out from the World to Come, just as is intimated in the verse: <i>and it grieved Him at His heart</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 6:6. See Ramban there.</i> It is to this that the Rabbis alluded in Bereshith Rabbah:<sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote">31:7.</i> “This is like a master’s son who had a wet-nurse; whenever he would commit an offense the wet-nurse would be punished.”<sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote">“So, said the Holy One, blessed be He: ‘I will destroy them and destroy the earth with them.’” (Bereshith Rabbah.)</i>

Verse 14



Verse 15



Verse 16



Verse 17

AND, BEHOLD, I DO BRING THE FLOOD. “Now I agree with those angels who long ago said to Me [when I was about to create man], <i>What is man that Thou art mindful of him</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">42</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 8:5.</i> Thus the words of Rashi quoting Bereshith Rabbah.<sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote">31:15.</i><br>But I wonder: in what way did He “agree” with them since He left man a remnant for a great deliverance through Noah and his sons and all living things to increase their seed as the sand! Perhaps this agreement with their opinion signified [His intent which was to come to fruition] when He would show them no mercy. [However, when the Divine quality of mercy was introduced, it resulted in the deliverance of mankind through Noah.]<br>By way of the truth [the mystic lore of the Cabala], <i>va’ani (And I)</i> is similar to: <i>And I also will chastise you;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 26:28. The word <i>va’ani</i> (And I) thus intimates the attribute of judgment.</i> so also, <i>I am He! behold, My covenant is with thee;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">45</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 17:4.</i> <i>And as for Me, this is My covenant</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">46</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 59:21.</i> The verse here thus states: “I also will have My hand on them for having destroyed the earth.” This is why He said [after the flood]: <i>This is the token of the covenant which I make</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">47</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 9:12.</i> — <i>He maketh sore, and He bindeth up</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">48</sup><i class="footnote">Job 5:18.</i> The learned student [in the mystic lore of the Cabala] will understand.

Verse 18

AND I WILL ESTABLISH MY COVENANT. Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra said that this is a sign that G-d had sworn to Noah that during the flood, neither he nor his children would die even though it is not clearly written at first. This is similar to what we find in Deuteronomy: <i>And ye came near unto me every one of you, and said: Let us send men before us, that they may search the land for us</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">49</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 1:22. This account, narrated by Moses, is not explicitly stated in Numbers, Chapter 13, which begins with G-d saying: <i>Send thou men…</i> Ramban cites this as another case where the first account lacks some of the details of the later account.</i><br>The meaning of <i>V’hakimothi (And I will establish)</i> is “I will fulfill My oath.” It appears likely to me that this covenant mentioned here refers to the rainbow, [Thus G-d hinted to Noah that after the flood He will make a covenant with him if he will fulfill the commandment concerning the making of the ark.] The meaning of the word <i>b’rith</i> (covenant) is an agreement and accord which two have chosen, stemming from the root, <i>‘b’ru’ (choose) you</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">50</sup><i class="footnote">I Samuel 17:8.</i> And the word <i>b’rith</i> takes the same form in construct and in separateness. A similar case is [the word <i>sh’vith</i>, captivity]: <i>‘sh’vith’ (the captivity of) Jacob;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 85:2. Here the word <i>sh’vith</i> is in construct.</i> <i>And his daughters ‘bash’vith’ (in captivity)</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">52</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 21:29. Here the word <i>bash’vith</i> is separate.</i> And some say that the word <i>b’rith</i> means the establishment of a boundary [to which each party to the covenant should adhere]. All these are Abraham ibn Ezra’s words.<br>A more correct explanation in line with the simple meaning of Scripture is that the purport of the expression, <i>And I will establish My covenant</i>, is, “At the time of the coming of the flood, My covenant will be established with you so that you and your family and two of all flesh will come into the ark to remain alive, that is to say, so that you will live there and maintain yourself in order to go forth from there alive.” And <i>b’rith</i> (covenant) means G-d’s word when He decrees something without any condition and residuary and fulfills it. Now He mentions the <i>b’rith</i> and mentions that it will be fulfilled, [which, according to the present interpretation is an apparent redundancy], just as we find the verse, <i>The Jews ordained and took upon them, and upon their seed</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">53</sup><i class="footnote">Esther 9:27.</i> meaning they accepted upon themselves a matter which was to exist. [Thus our verse is to be explained in a similar way, i.e., He established an unconditional covenant.]<br>By way of the truth, [the mystic lore of the Cabala], the <i>b’rith</i> is <i>everlasting</i>, the word being derived from. <i>In the beginning G-d ‘bara’ (created)</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 1:1.</i> Thus <i>brithi</i> (My covenant) is similar to <i>b’riyothi</i> (My creation), and the word is alike in construct form because it is adjoined to the times there were before us. He thus commanded that the <i>b’rith</i> exist and be with the righteous one [Noah]. In a similar sense are the verses: As for <i>Me, behold, I establish My covenant with you;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">54</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 9:9.</i> <i>My covenant was with him</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">55</sup><i class="footnote">Malachi 2:5.</i> The learned student [in the mystic lore of the Cabala] will understand.

Verse 19

OF ALL FLESH. It is known that there are a great many beasts, and some of them — such as elephants, rams and others — are very large; likewise, the creeping things upon the earth are very many. Of the fowl of the heaven there are also innumerably many kinds, just as our Rabbis have said:<sup class="footnote-marker">56</sup><i class="footnote">Chullin 63b. However, instead of 120 kinds, the figure mentioned there is 100.</i> “There are one hundred and twenty kinds of unclean birds in the east, and all of them belong to the species of <i>ayah</i> (kite).”<sup class="footnote-marker">57</sup><i class="footnote">See Leviticus 11:14.</i> Clean fowl are innumerable. Noah was thus obligated to bring all of them into the ark in order that they may beget their like. If you would gather a full year’s supply of food for all of them, [you would find] that this ark and ten others like it could not hold it! But this was a miracle of a small space containing a great quantity. And in case you suppose that he should have made it [the ark] very small and rely on this miracle, the answer is that the Holy One, blessed be He, saw fit to make it large so that the people of his generation should see it, wonder at it, converse about it, and speak of the subject of the flood and the gathering of the cattle, beast, and fowl into it so that perhaps they would repent. Furthermore, he made it large in order to reduce the miracle for such is the way with all miracles in the Torah or in the Prophets: whatever is humanly possible is done, with the balance left to Heaven. Now be not persuaded to say as Ibn Ezra that the three hundred cubits [of the length of the ark were measured] in cubits of a man like Noah, who was unusually tall. If so, the other people were also tall, and the beasts and fowl of those generations were also tall until the world was struck by the flood! Moreover, the cubits here are the standard cubits of the Torah.<sup class="footnote-marker">58</sup><i class="footnote">See Erubin 3b.</i>
THOU SHALT BRING INTO THE ARK, TO KEEP THEM ALIVE WITH THEE. G-d thus commanded Noah that he concern himself with and help them in their entering the ark and that he strive on behalf of their existence even as he would for his own life.

Verse 20

TWO OF EVERY SORT SHALL COME UNTO THEE, TO KEEP THEM ALIVE. G-d thus informed Noah that two of every sort would come of their own accord, and he would not find it necessary to hunt for them in the mountains and distant lands, and he would bring them into the ark after that. At the actual narration [of their coming, Scripture] explains<sup class="footnote-marker">59</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 7:16.</i> that they came male and female; this is implied here. After that, He commanded him to take seven and seven of every clean beast.<sup class="footnote-marker">60</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 7:2.</i> Concerning these, G-d did not say that they would come of their own accord but that Noah should take them.<sup class="footnote-marker">61</sup><i class="footnote">The verse states: <i>Of every clean beast thou shalt ‘take’ to thee seven and seven</i>. Noah brought sacrifices after the flood from the clean beasts and fowl. (See Chapter 8, Verse 20.)</i> The reason for this is that those who came to be saved and to keep their seed alive<sup class="footnote-marker">62</sup><i class="footnote">Chapter 7, Verse 3.</i> did come of their own accord, but for those who were to be sacrificed as whole offerings, G-d did not decree that they come of their own accord to be slaughtered. Rather, Noah took them since the purpose of the command to take seven and seven was that Noah bring a sacrifice from them after the flood.<br>The meaning of the word “clean” is that the Holy One, blessed be He, explained to Noah the signs of ritual cleanliness for beast and fowl. Scripture, however, refers to it briefly by saying, “clean,” in accordance with the Torah.<sup class="footnote-marker">63</sup><i class="footnote">See Leviticus, Chapter 11.</i> But Rashi wrote: “<i>Clean</i>, meaning that which in the future will be permitted to Israel as clean; we thus learn that Noah studied the Torah.”<br>From here we derive that the sacrifices of the sons of Noah<sup class="footnote-marker">64</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Seder Bereshith</i>, Note 222.</i> must also be only of the clean beast and the clean fowl. So also it is said of the sacrifice of Abel: <i>of the first-born of his flock and of the fat thereof</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">65</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 4:4.</i> However, all clean species are permissible for them to bring as sacrifices as it is written: <i>And he took of every clean beast, and of every clean fowl, and offered burnt-offerings on the altar</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">66</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 8:20.</i> [Later, when the Torah was given, G-d] added a commandment to Israel that all their sacrifices be only <i>of the beasts and of the herd</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">67</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 1:2.</i> <i>of the turtledoves and of the young pigeons</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">68</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 14.</i><br><i>Of the fowl also of the heaven, seven and seven</i><sup class="footnote-marker">69</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 7:3.</i> — this means the clean fowl for the verse is a continuation of the verse above: [<i>Of every ‘clean’ beast shalt thou take to thee seven and seven</i>].<sup class="footnote-marker">70</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 2.</i>

Verse 21



Verse 22

AND NOAH DID THUS; ACCORDING TO ALL THAT G-D HAD COMMANDED HIM, meaning that he constructed the ark and gathered the food. Scripture’s intent in saying, <i>And Noah did… so did he</i>, is to explain that he did not omit a thing from all that G-d had commanded him.

Chapter 7



Verse 1

AND THE ETERNAL SAID TO NOAH. G-d informed Noah that with the attribute of mercy [as indicated by the use of the Tetragrammaton, “the Eternal,”] He will save him and his family and that He will give life to their seed for all generations. This is the meaning of the phrase, <i>to keep seed alive upon the face of all the earth</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">71</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 3.</i> At first He said, <i>to keep them alive with thee;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">72</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 6:19.</i> but now with the attribute of mercy He hinted to him concerning the sacrifice to inform him that he will have regard for his offering and that by the merit of his offering, the world will exist, never again to be cut off by the waters of the flood.<sup class="footnote-marker">73</sup><i class="footnote">See further, 9:11.</i> This is why the Tetragrammaton is mentioned here for in all matters concerning the sacrifices, Scripture does not mention <i>Elokim</i> (G-d), as I will elucidate when I reach there<sup class="footnote-marker">74</sup><i class="footnote">See Ramban, Leviticus 1:9.</i> with the help of G-d.
COME THOU AND ALL THY HOUSE INTO THE ARK. Noah constructed the ark many days before the flood, and when the time of the flood arrived on the tenth day of the second month, He again commanded him that he and all his household come into the ark. This is why He said to him at first: <i>thou, and thy sons, and thy wife, and thy sons’ wives with thee</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">75</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 6:18.</i> He thereby informed him that on account of his merit alone they will be saved since He did not say, “Ye [in the plural] I have seen righteous before Me.” And He commanded that he take and bring of the clean beasts and clean fowl seven and seven, and then He informed him of the day of the flood, at which time he was to come into the ark. And Noah did so for <i>in the selfsame day came Noah… into the ark</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">76</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 13. This refers to the day when the rains began, namely, the seventeenth day of the second month.</i> This is the meaning of [the verse: <i>And Noah came in… into the ark</i>] <i>because of the waters of the flood</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">77</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 7.</i> But Rashi wrote: “Noah also was one of those who have little faith, and he did not enter the ark until the waters forced him to do so.” In the words of Bereshith Rabbah:<sup class="footnote-marker">78</sup><i class="footnote">32:9.</i> “Noah was lacking in faith. Had the waters not reached his ankles he would not have entered the ark.” But if so, let him say that Noah did not enter there until the waters greatly increased and covered the whole face of the earth and he saw that he was drowning!

Verse 2



Verse 3



Verse 4



Verse 5



Verse 6



Verse 7



Verse 8

OF CLEAN BEASTS, AND OF BEASTS THAT ARE NOT CLEAN. TWO AND TWO THERE CAME IN UNTO NOAH. Rashi explained: “They were all equal with respect to this number for the least number of any species was two.” Others<sup class="footnote-marker">79</sup><i class="footnote">R’dak.</i> said that the meaning of “two” is pairs, meaning that they came couplewise, male and female together.<br>In my opinion, the matter was thus: two — a male and a female — came of their own accord from each species, and Noah added by bringing six additional pairs from the clean ones since those that came to be saved arrived of their own accord while he busied himself for the sake of the commandment with those that were destined for sacrifice, for so it was told to him.<sup class="footnote-marker">80</sup><i class="footnote">See Ramban above, 6:20.</i> And the meaning of the verse, <i>And Noah did according unto all that the Eternal commanded him</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">81</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 5.</i> is, as the Rabbis have said in Bereshith Rabbah,<sup class="footnote-marker">78</sup><i class="footnote">32:9.</i> that he was to prepare to bring in the cattle, beast, and fowl, meaning the clean ones, those which he himself went after and brought to his house. The verse which states a third time, <i>as G-d hath commanded Noah</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">82</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 9.</i> means that he did as He had commanded him concerning entering the ark, for this verse is connected with the above verse: <i>And Noah came in</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">77</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 7.</i> The verse thus states that Noah and his sons and his wife and his sons’ wives came into the ark along with two and two of the cattle and fowl and creeping things that came to him in order to enter into the ark. All of them came with him, entering the ark <i>because of the waters of the flood</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">77</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 7.</i> as G-d commanded him. Scripture then returns and sets forth the month and the day in which the flood came<sup class="footnote-marker">83</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 11.</i> and how he entered the ark, stating that on that selfsame day when the rains began — and not before — Noah entered the ark, and with him were all living things.

Verse 9



Verse 10



Verse 11



Verse 12



Verse 13



Verse 14



Verse 15

AND THEY CAME IN UNTO NOAH INTO THE ARK. The intent of this is to make known that the beasts, fowl, etc., did not gather to him at all, nor did they come until that selfsame day when the rains came. And he came into the ark for it was G-d that <i>hath commanded and His breath which hath gathered them</i><sup class="footnote-marker">84</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 34:16.</i> in one moment.

Verse 16

AND THEY THAT CAME IN, CAME IN MALE AND FEMALE OF ALL FLESH. The intent of this is that those who came into the ark were male and female for so Noah brought them in. This is why Scripture says, <i>as G-d hath commanded him</i>, since it was He who commanded him to bring them into the ark.<br>But the opinion of Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra is that the verse, <i>And Noah came in, and his sons, and his wife, and his sons’ wives with him, into the ark</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">77</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 7.</i> does not mean that they entered it but that they all came to Noah on the tenth day of the second month for his house was near the ark. [He thus interprets the verse as meaning “to the ark,” rather than “into the ark.”] Ibn Ezra explains the phrase, <i>because of the waters of the flood</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">77</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 7.</i> to mean “on account of the fear of the waters of the flood.” At the end of the seven days came the waters of the flood, and then they all gathered in the ark, and Noah closed the door and the window.<sup class="footnote-marker">85</sup><i class="footnote">See above, 6:16.</i> But Ibn Ezra’s words are not correct.<sup class="footnote-marker">86</sup><i class="footnote">As explained above in Verses 1 and 8, when the time of the flood arrived G-d again commanded Noah that he and all his household come into the ark, and He further informed him of the day of the flood.</i><br>It is possible that the verses, <i>And Noah did according to all that the Eternal hath commanded him, And Noah was six hundred years old</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">87</sup><i class="footnote">Verses 5-6.</i> and the succeeding verses until, <i>In the six hundredth year</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">88</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 11.</i> do not recount a narrative. Rather, <i>And Noah did according to all that the Eternal commanded him</i> generalizes the entire matter. It states that he did everything as he was commanded, not omitting a thing: he constructed the ark and assembled the food and took of the clean beasts and fowl seven and seven on the day He commanded him. When he was six hundred years old and the flood came down upon the earth, he came with his household and with the clean beasts and all living things into the ark, as G-d had commanded him. After that, Scripture narrates the event, <i>And it came to pass after the seven days … in the six hundredth year</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">89</sup><i class="footnote">Verses 10-11.</i> and completes the subject.

Verse 17



Verse 18

AND THE WATERS PREVAILED (‘Vayigb’ru’). AND THE WATERS ‘GAVRU’ (PREVAILED). This means that they increased exceedingly, for the Hebrew language calls great abundance <i>gvurah</i> (strength, power). So too, <i>And their transgressions which ‘yithgavru’ (have prevailed)</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">90</sup><i class="footnote">Job 36:9.</i> meaning increased exceedingly; <i>His mercy ‘gavar’ (has prevailed) toward them that fear Him</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">91</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 103:11.</i> meaning increased. And so also: <i>If ‘bigvuroth’ four-score years</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">92</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 90:10.</i> meaning with great abundance.<br>It is conceivable that the meaning of <i>vayigb’ru</i> is that the rains came in a rushing downpour, uprooting trees and toppling buildings, since power is called in Hebrew <i>gvurah</i> (strength) because strength lies in power. In a similar sense are the verses: <i>They also ‘gavru’ (wax mighty) in power;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">93</sup><i class="footnote">Job 21:7.</i> <i>‘Vehigbir brith’ (And he shall make a strong covenant) with many for one week</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">94</sup><i class="footnote">Daniel 9:27.</i> meaning he will establish the covenant with firmness. And in the words of the Sages, [we find the expression], <i>gvuroth geshamim</i> (the powers of the rains),<sup class="footnote-marker">95</sup><i class="footnote">Taanith 2a.</i> because they come down with strength. It is possible that the verse, <i>If ‘bigvuroth’ four-score years</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">92</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 90:10.</i> is of the same sense, i.e., if his bones and body be strong, and he is a man of power, he will live four-score years. And if so, <i>‘gavru’ upon the earth</i><sup class="footnote-marker">96</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 19.</i> will mean that the waters were in their complete strength, overcoming even the high mountains and inundating them.

Verse 19



Verse 20



Verse 21



Verse 22



Verse 23

AND HE BLOTTED OUT EVERY LIVING SUBSTANCE WHICH WAS UPON THE FACE OF THE EARTH. After having said, <i>And all flesh perished</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">97</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 21.</i> and having said, <i>whatever was in the dry land, died</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">98</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 22.</i> Scripture continues to say, <i>And He blotted out</i>, meaning that the bodies dissolved and became water, just as is in the verse, <i>And he shall blot them out in the water of bitterness</i><sup class="footnote-marker">99</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 5:23.</i> — for the waters of the flood were hot, as our Rabbis have said.<sup class="footnote-marker">100</sup><i class="footnote">Sanhedrin 108b.</i> But if so, the fish also would have died. Perhaps it was as the Rabbis have said in Bereshith Rabbah:<sup class="footnote-marker">101</sup><i class="footnote">32:19.</i> “<i>Whatever was in the dry land died</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">98</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 22.</i> but not the fish in the sea. And some authorities say that they too were destined to be destroyed, but they fled to the Mediterranean.”<sup class="footnote-marker">102</sup><i class="footnote">Literally, <i>Okeanus</i> (ocean), but usually meaning the Mediterranean Sea. (See Jastrow.)</i> Either way the fish were saved.<br>Both of these opinions are plausible. For it is conceivable that the hot waters of the flood mingled with the seas, heating only their upper waters, while the fish descended to the depths of the ponds and lived there. Or, in accordance with the opinion of some authorities,<sup class="footnote-marker">103</sup><i class="footnote">Mentioned in the Midrash quoted above, that the fish too were destined to be destroyed, but they fled to the Mediterranean.</i> it is possible that the fish in the waters of the countries near the Mediterranean<sup class="footnote-marker">102</sup><i class="footnote">Literally, <i>Okeanus</i> (ocean), but usually meaning the Mediterranean Sea. (See Jastrow.)</i> fled there when they felt the heat of the water, and were thus saved. And even if all those outside the Mediterranean died, since the majority of fish are in the Mediterranean<sup class="footnote-marker">102</sup><i class="footnote">Literally, <i>Okeanus</i> (ocean), but usually meaning the Mediterranean Sea. (See Jastrow.)</i> where the waters of the flood did not come down — as it is said, <i>And the rain was upon the earth</i><sup class="footnote-marker">104</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 12.</i> — the fish were thus saved. For none of the fish were brought into the ark to keep their seed alive, and at the time of the covenant it is said, <i>I establish My covenant with you… and with every living creature that is with you, the fowl, and cattle, and every beast of the earth with you; of all that go out of the ark</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">105</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 9:9-10.</i> but it does not mention the fish of the sea.
AND THEY WERE BLOTTED OUT FROM THE EARTH. The commentators<sup class="footnote-marker">106</sup><i class="footnote">Ibn Ezra and R’dak.</i> have explained that the reason for the double [expression, <i>And He blotted out … and they were blotted out</i>], is that their remembrance was forgotten since they had no seed. But what need is there to say that after we are told that they all died? Perhaps on account of the fowl and some creeping things, Scripture tells that none of their eggs were left on any tree or under the earth for everything was blotted out. It is probable that the sense of the verse is as follows: “And He blotted out every living substance which was upon the face of the earth, for from man to beast to creeping things and to fowl of the heaven, they were blotted out from the earth, only Noah remaining alive.” Now our Rabbis have expounded:<sup class="footnote-marker">100</sup><i class="footnote">Sanhedrin 108b.</i> “<i>And He blotted out</i>, meaning from this world. <i>And they were blotted out from the earth</i>, meaning from the World to Come.” The Rabbis thus explained “the earth” mentioned here as meaning “the land of eternal life.” I have already alluded to its secret.<sup class="footnote-marker">107</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 6:13.</i>

Chapter 8



Verse 1

AND G-D REMEMBERED NOAH, AND EVERY LIVING THING, AND ALL THE CATTLE. The remembrance of Noah was because he was a perfectly righteous man, and He had made a covenant with him to save him. The word “Noah” here includes his children that were there with him. Scripture did not mention them specifically, though, for they were saved by his merit. However, the remembrance stated concerning beast and cattle was not on account of merit, for among living creatures there is no merit or guilt save in man alone. But the remembrance concerning them was <i>Because He remembered His holy word</i><sup class="footnote-marker">108</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 105:42.</i> which He had spoken, causing the world to come into existence, and the Will which was before Him at the creation of the world arose before Him and He desired the existence of the world with all the species that He created therein. Thus He now saw fit to bring them forth so that they should not perish in the ark. Scripture does not mention the fowl and the creeping things for the remembrance of <i>the living thing</i> is similar to their remembrance, and <i>the companion thereof telleth concerning it</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">109</sup><i class="footnote">Job 36:33. That is, since the remembrance of the fowl and creeping things would be the same type of remembrance as that of all animals—i.e., the remembrance of His holy word—one implies the other.</i>

Verse 2



Verse 3



Verse 4

AND THE ARK RESTED IN THE SEVENTH MONTH, ON THE SEVENTEENTH DAY OF THE MONTH. Rashi wrote: “From here you may infer that the ark was submerged in the water to a depth of eleven cubits.” This he wrote on the basis of the calculation written in his commentaries, and it is so found in Bereshith Rabbah.<sup class="footnote-marker">110</sup><i class="footnote">33:10.</i> But since in certain places Rashi minutely examines Midrashic traditions and for the same verses also takes the trouble to explain the simple meanings of Scripture, he has thus given us permission to do likewise for there are seventy ways of interpreting the Torah,<sup class="footnote-marker">111</sup><i class="footnote">Midrash Othiyoth d’Rabbi Akiba.</i> and there are many differing Midrashim among the words of the Sages. And so I say that this calculation which they have mentioned does not fit into the language of Scripture unless we bear with that which explains <i>And the ark rested in the seventh month</i> as referring to that day mentioned above [in Verses 2-3] when the rain was withheld and the waters receded from the earth and decreased continually. [This interpretation of the seventh month is] unlike the counting of <i>the second month</i><sup class="footnote-marker">112</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 7:11.</i> mentioned in the beginning of the section, [which Rashi explains there as being “the second month” of the creation calendar], and unlike the counting stated at the end of the section [in Verse 13: <i>in the first month</i>, which Rashi similarly explains as being “the first month” of the creation calendar]! And how is it possible that in the second verse Scripture should immediately retract [from using the withholding of the rain as a reference point for counting] and state, <i>until the tenth month</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">113</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 5.</i> and proceed to another reference point, counting it, as Rashi explains, as the tenth month with reference to the coming of the rains!<br>The evidence Rashi brings from the submergence of the ark in the waters is no proof for he attributes an equal decrease of water to each of the days — namely, a cubit every four days — and it is known in nature concerning the decrease of water that a great river which decreases at first a cubit every four days will at the end decrease four cubits in a day. Thus according to this calculation of Rashi, on the first day of the month of Ab the tops of the mountains were seen,<sup class="footnote-marker">114</sup><i class="footnote">Rashi, <i>ibid.</i></i> and on the first day of Tishri the earth dried.<sup class="footnote-marker">115</sup><i class="footnote">Rashi, Verse 13.</i> Thus in sixty days the waters decreased the entire height of the high mountains consisting of many thousands of cubits, [surely a greater rate than four cubits a day, as Rashi would have it]! Besides, when Noah sent forth the dove on the seventeenth day of the month of Ellul,<sup class="footnote-marker">116</sup><i class="footnote">The raven was sent by Noah forty days after the tops of the mountains were seen on the first day of Ab. (See Verses 5-6). This brings us to the tenth of Ellul. Seven days later, on the seventeenth day of Ellul, he sent forth the dove.</i> the waters were yet on the face of the entire earth,<sup class="footnote-marker">117</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 9.</i> and the trees were covered, and in a matter of twelve days<sup class="footnote-marker">118</sup><i class="footnote">From the eighteenth of Ellul to the first of Tishri is a period of twelve days.</i> the whole earth dried! And by way of reason, if the ark was submerged in the waters eleven cubits, that being more than a third of its height [which was thirty cubits],<sup class="footnote-marker">119</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 6:15.</i> it would have sunk because it was wide at the bottom and finished to a cubit at the top,<sup class="footnote-marker">120</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 16.</i> contrary to the structure of ships, and there was also in it great weight!<br>From the simple interpretation of Scripture it appears that the hundred and fifty days mentioned in connection with the prevailing of the waters<sup class="footnote-marker">121</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 7:24.</i> include the forty days of the coming down of the rains<sup class="footnote-marker">122</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 12.</i> since the main increase and prevailing of the waters took place during these days. Thus the waters began decreasing on the seventeenth day of Nisan,<sup class="footnote-marker">123</sup><i class="footnote">From the seventeenth day of Cheshvan (the beginning of the rains) to the seventeenth day of Nisan there are 150 days. This is contrary to Rashi, who said that the decrease of the waters began forty days later on the first of Sivan.</i> and thirty days later — the seventeenth day of the month Iyar,<sup class="footnote-marker">124</sup><i class="footnote">According to Rashi this was on the seventeenth of Sivan.</i> which was the seventh month from the time the rain began to fall<sup class="footnote-marker">125</sup><i class="footnote">According to Rashi, “the seventh month,” mentioned in connection with the resting of the ark upon the Ararat mountains, was the seventh month after the rains stopped, as explained above.</i> — the ark rested upon the mountains of Ararat. Seventy-three days later, on the first of Ab, which was the tenth month from the time the rain began to fall, the tops of the mountains were seen.
