We have thus made a small correction in the interpretation of the language of Scripture, [namely, that all counting begins from the time the rain began to fall].<br>But the correct interpretation appears to me to be that the hundred and fifty days<sup class="footnote-marker">121</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 7:24.</i> were from the seventeenth day of the second month, namely, the month of Marcheshvan, to the seventeenth day of the seventh month, namely, the month of Nisan, and that was the day when the ark rested on the mountains of Ararat.<sup class="footnote-marker">126</sup><i class="footnote">This is unlike his opinion above that the ark rested thirty days after the seventeenth of Nisan.</i> For then G-d caused <i>a strong east wind</i> to pass <i>all the night and made</i> the waters <i>dry land</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">127</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 14:21. Also see Verse 1 here in Chapter 8.</i> meaning that they decreased very much, and the ark rested. The proof for this is that Scripture does not say here, “and the waters decreased on such a month and on such a day and the waters decreased continually until the seventh month, and the ark rested, etc.,” as it said concerning the other decrease when the tops of the mountains were seen, for on the very day the waters began decreasing, the ark rested. The order of events in this matter was thus: on the day the rain began to fall <i>all the fountains of the great deep were broken up</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">112</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 7:11.</i> and the windows of the heavens were opened and the rain came down for forty days. During that time the waters prevailed fifteen cubits above<sup class="footnote-marker">128</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 7:19.</i> [the summits of all the mountains]. The rain stopped at the end of forty days, but “the fountains of the deep” and “the windows of the heavens” remained open. The atmosphere was very damp, and the whole earth was full of water, not like waters poured down a precipice,<sup class="footnote-marker">129</sup><i class="footnote">See Micah 1:4.</i> nor ever to become dried. And they stood thus in their power until one hundred and fifty days from the day the rain began were completed. Then G-d caused a very powerful wind to pass through the heavens and over the earth, <i>and the fountains of the deep were stopped</i><sup class="footnote-marker">130</sup><i class="footnote">Verses 1-2.</i> for the water that flowed from them returned to its place until the deep filled up as it was before the flood, and the openings of its fountains were locked, as were “the windows of the heavens.” And the air was dried very much by a drying wind, and the water on the earth was licked up.<sup class="footnote-marker">131</sup><i class="footnote">See I Kings 18:38.</i> Thus the waters decreased exceedingly on that day, and the ark, which was submerged in the waters about two to three cubits, rested. Seventy-three days after that — on the first day of the tenth month, namely, the month of Tammuz — the tops of the mountains were seen. At the end of forty additional days — on the tenth day of the eleventh month, Ab — Noah opened the window of the ark, and three weeks later the dove left him; thirty days later, he removed the covering of the ark.
AND G-D MADE A WIND TO PASS OVER THE EARTH.<sup class="footnote-marker">132</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 1.</i> This means that there was a great and powerful wind coming out from the bowels of the earth over the face of the deep and hovering over the waters, and the fountains of the deep were stopped thereby. This is so since Scripture does not say, “and G-d made a wind to pass over the waters.”
AND THE WATERS ASSUAGED (‘VAYASHOKU’).<sup class="footnote-marker">132</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 1.</i> This means that the waters which were flowing from the deep subsided. It is the same expression as, <i>Then the king’s wrath ‘shachachah’ (assuaged)</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">133</sup><i class="footnote">Esther 7:10.</i> meaning that his anger subsided. Or it may be that this is an expression of a thing being concealed and swallowed up. Thus the verse teaches that the waters of the deep were swallowed up in their place. And so did the Rabbis say in Seder Olam:<sup class="footnote-marker">134</sup><i class="footnote">Chapter 4. The Seder Olam (Order of the World) is a historical record of events from the time of creation to the destruction of the Second Temple. It was authored by Rabbi Yosei, a disciple of Rabbi Akiba.</i> “The waters that went up were dried by the wind, and those that went down were swallowed in their place.”
AND THE RAINS FROM THE HEAVENS WERE WITHHELD.<sup class="footnote-marker">135</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 2.</i> This means that no more rain came down until they [Noah and his family and all living creatures] went out of the ark for by this wind [which G-d made to pass over the earth] the heavens became as iron.<sup class="footnote-marker">136</sup><i class="footnote">See Leviticus 26:19.</i> Neither dew nor rain came down, the air lost its moisture, and the waters dried up for the rain of the flood completely stopped after the fortieth day.
AND THE WATERS RETURNED FROM OFF THE EARTH CONTINUALLY.<sup class="footnote-marker">137</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 3.</i> The verse states that the waters decreased gradually until <i>the face of the ground was dried up</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">138</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 13.</i><br><i>And after the end of a hundred and fifty days the waters decreased</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">137</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 3.</i> This is connected with the following verse, <i>And the ark rested</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">139</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 4.</i> thus stating that on that day there was a great decrease in the waters which enabled the ark to rest [on the mountains of Ararat], as I have explained.

Verse 5

AND THE WATERS DECREASED CONTINUALLY UNTIL THE TENTH MONTH. This verse is to be interpreted by transposition: the waters decreased continually until the tops of the mountains were seen in the tenth month, which is the month of Tammuz. Scripture thus informs us that during seventy-three days<sup class="footnote-marker">140</sup><i class="footnote">From the seventeenth of Nisan, which marked the end of the 150 days during which the waters prevailed, as explained above in Verse 4, to the first day of Tammuz.</i> the waters decreased fifteen cubits.<sup class="footnote-marker">141</sup><i class="footnote">See above, 7:20.</i> But we do not know the amount of the original decrease which enabled the ark to rest since Scripture did not find it necessary to inform us either of the number of cubits that the ark was submerged in the waters or of the amount of the decrease.<br>In the matter of the floating of the ark, it appears to me that because the waters flowed from the deeps and were hot, as our Rabbis have said,<sup class="footnote-marker">100</sup><i class="footnote">Sanhedrin 108b.</i> the ark therefore floated upon the face of the waters. Were it not for that, it would have sunk on account of its weight for there were many living things in it, as well as a great deal of food and drink. But as soon as the waters subsided from their flowing or from their heat and they decreased on account of the wind, the ark at once entered into the midst of the waters due to the weight of its load, and it rested on the mountain.<br>In the opinion of the commentators,<sup class="footnote-marker">142</sup><i class="footnote">Ibn Ezra and R’dak. See my Hebrew commentary, p. 59.</i> the Scriptural accounts concerning the total of one hundred and fifty days during which the waters prevailed, the resting of the ark, the visibility of the tops of the mountains and the succeeding forty days — all these events we know by way of prophecy for Scripture so informs us, but Noah knew only that he felt that the ark had rested, and he waited a period of time which, in his opinion, was sufficient for the waters to abate.<br>Now according to our words, as well as those of our Rabbis and all commentators, the mountains of Ararat, which are among the highest mountains under the heavens, had fifteen cubits of water above their summit.<sup class="footnote-marker">143</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 7:20.</i> Therefore this difficulty is to be posed: it is known that the Greek mountain Olympus is very much higher than they, and the land of Ararat, which is near Babylon,<sup class="footnote-marker">144</sup><i class="footnote">See Ramban further 11:2.</i> lies in the lower part of the globe! Perhaps we should then say that the decrease of waters which took place on the seventeenth day of the seventh month<sup class="footnote-marker">145</sup><i class="footnote">That is, the seventeenth day of Nisan, on which date the ark rested.</i> was very much more than fifteen cubits, and at first the tops of the high mountains were seen, not the mountains of Ararat, and it just happened that the ark was in the land of Ararat during the seventh month and it rested on the tops of those mountains.<br>Now Noah, from the time the rains ceased, would open and close the window at his will. Seventy-three days<sup class="footnote-marker">140</sup><i class="footnote">From the seventeenth of Nisan, which marked the end of the 150 days during which the waters prevailed, as explained above in Verse 4, to the first day of Tammuz.</i> after the resting of the ark he looked forth from the window and the tops of the mountains of Ararat were visible to him, and he again closed the window. Scripture then relates that forty days later he sent forth the raven. Scripture does not say, “and it was in such-a-month and on such-a-day that Noah opened the window,” but instead it says, <i>And it came to pass at the end of forty days</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">146</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 6.</i> in order to declare that from the time the tops of the mountains were seen by Noah, he waited forty days for he thought that by then the towers would be seen and the trees would become visible and the fowls would thus find in them a place to nest, and so he opened the window in order to send forth the raven. In the first month, which is the month of Tishri, <i>the waters were dried up</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">138</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 13.</i> and in the second month, which is the month of Marcheshvan, on the twenty-seventh day thereof, <i>was the earth dry</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">147</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 14.</i> and on that day they went out of the ark. Thus all calculations of the section are in accordance with the simple explanation of Scripture and its usual sense.<br>Know that after the Sages agreed that it was in the month of Tishri that the world was created<sup class="footnote-marker">148</sup><i class="footnote">In Tractate Rosh Hashana, 11 a, it is recorded that there was a difference of opinion on this matter. Rabbi Eliezer maintained that the world was created in Tishri while Rabbi Yehoshua taught that the world was created in the month of Nisan. The consensus of the Sages conformed with Rabbi Eliezer’s view (<i>ibid.</i>, 27 a). This is the intent of Ramban’s saying here: “Know that after the sages agreed, etc.” See also Ramban further, 17:26.</i> — as [is evidenced by the text of the prayer for the New Year which] they formulated, i.e., “This day, on which was the beginning of Thy work, is a memorial of the first day,” and by the fact that the Scriptural order of the seasons is <i>seedtime and harvest, and cold and heat</i><sup class="footnote-marker">149</sup><i class="footnote">Further, Verse 22. Thus the winter precedes the summer.</i> — that the beginning of the year is reckoned from Tishri. And so also were the months reckoned from Tishri until we reached the exodus from Egypt. Then the Holy One, blessed be He, commanded us to reckon the months according to another count, [namely, from the going forth from Egypt, which occurred in the month of Nisan], as it is said, <i>This month shall be unto you the beginning of months; it shall be the first month of the year to you</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">150</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 12:2.</i> Thenceforth in all of Scripture, Tishri is reckoned as the seventh month. But as far as the years are concerned, the reckoning from Tishri was still retained, as it is written, <i>And the feast of ingathering at the turn of the year</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">151</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 34:22.</i> And so did Jonathan the son of Uziel<sup class="footnote-marker">152</sup><i class="footnote">A disciple of Rabbi Yochanan ben Zakkai and one of the early Tannaitic sages. He wrote a <i>Targum</i> or Aramaic version of the books of the Prophets. It is similar in scope to that of Onkelos on the Five Books of Moses.</i> translate the verse, <i>In the month of Eithanim which is the seventh month</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">153</sup><i class="footnote">I Kings 8:2.</i> saying, “in the month which the ancients called the first month and which is now the seventh month.” And in the Mechilta we also find:<sup class="footnote-marker">154</sup><i class="footnote">Mechilta, Exodus 12:2.</i> “<i>This month</i> [<i>Nisan</i>] <i>shall be unto you</i>. But the first man did not reckon by it; [he reckoned Tishri as the first month].”

Verse 6



Verse 7



Verse 8



Verse 9

AND THE DOVE FOUND NO REST. It is not customary for fowl to rest on the tops of the high mountains on the earth which are bare of trees and surely not when <i>the waters were on the face of the whole earth</i>. Therefore, the dove found no rest suitable for her. But as soon as she saw the trees she went her own way<sup class="footnote-marker">155</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 12.</i> for in their branches she would build her nest.

Verse 10



Verse 11

AND LO AN OLIVE LEAF. From the plain meaning of this verse it would appear that the trees were not uprooted or blotted out in the flood because there was there no flooding stream since the whole world became full of water. But in Bereshith Rabbah the Rabbis have said,<sup class="footnote-marker">156</sup><i class="footnote">33:9.</i> “From where did the dove bring the olive leaf? Rabbi Levi said, ‘She brought it from the Mount of Olives since the land of Israel was not inundated by the waters of the flood. This is as the Holy One, blessed be He, said to the prophet Ezekiel: <i>Son of man, say unto her: Thou art a land that is not cleansed, nor rained upon in the day of indignation</i>.’<sup class="footnote-marker">157</sup><i class="footnote">Ezekiel 22:24.</i> Rabbi Biryei said, ‘The gates of the garden of Eden were opened for the dove and from there she brought the leaf.’” Thus the intent of the Rabbis is that the trees were uprooted and blotted out in those places where the flood was, and surely the leaf faded.<sup class="footnote-marker">158</sup><i class="footnote">See Jeremiah 8:13.</i> Similarly the Rabbis said,<sup class="footnote-marker">159</sup><i class="footnote">Bereshith Rabbah 28:3.</i> “Even the [solid substance of the] lower stationery millstone was blotted out in the flood,” and [to substantiate this statement] they expounded the verse, <i>The waters wore the stones</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">160</sup><i class="footnote">Job 14:19.</i> [as referring to the waters of the flood which wore down stones]. And their saying that “the Land of Israel was not inundated by the flood” is to be understood as meaning that the rain of the flood was not there, as it is written, <i>nor rained upon;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">157</sup><i class="footnote">Ezekiel 22:24.</i> <i>the fountains of the great deep</i><sup class="footnote-marker">161</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 7:11.</i> were not therein. But the waters did spread over the whole world, and <i>all the high mountains that were under the whole heaven were covered</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">162</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 19.</i> as it is clearly written, and there is no partition around the Land of Israel to prevent the waters from entering. And so did the Sages say in Pirkei d’Rabbi Eliezer:<sup class="footnote-marker">163</sup><i class="footnote">Chapter 23.</i> “The waters of the flood did not come down from heaven upon the land of Israel, but they rolled in from other lands and came there, as it is said, <i>Son of man, say unto her</i>, etc.”<sup class="footnote-marker">157</sup><i class="footnote">Ezekiel 22:24.</i> Now according to the opinion of Rabbi Levi, [mentioned above, that the dove brought the olive leaf from the Mount of Olives], it was because the torrential rain did not come down upon the land of Israel and <i>the windows of heaven</i><sup class="footnote-marker">161</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 7:11.</i> were not opened there that the trees remained there while in the rest of the world they were broken and uprooted by the flood and <i>His mighty rain</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">164</sup><i class="footnote">Job 37:6.</i><br>But I wonder about their saying that [the olive leaf was brought by the dove] from the garden of Eden. If it were so, then Noah did not know that <i>the waters abated from off the earth</i> for there [in Eden] the waters of the flood did not enter. But perhaps its gates were closed so that the waters did not enter there, but when the waters abated they were opened. [Thus the olive leaf indicated the opening of the gates which in turn indicated that the waters had abated.]<br>It is on the basis of this opinion of theirs [—that the trees were broken and uprooted in the entire world during the flood — that the Rabbis] have said there in Bereshith Rabbah,<sup class="footnote-marker">165</sup><i class="footnote">36:4.</i> “<i>And he [Noah] planted a vineyard</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">166</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 9:20.</i> And from where did he have a branch? Said Rabbi Abba bar Kahana, ‘When he went into the ark he had taken with him branches of the vine, shoots of fig trees, and stumps of olive trees.’”
‘TARAPH’ (PLUCKED) IN HER MOUTH. Rashi wrote: “I am of the opinion that the dove was a male and that therefore Scripture sometimes speaks of it as masculine<sup class="footnote-marker">167</sup><i class="footnote">It is indicated by <i>taraph</i> (he plucked) rather than <i>tarpha</i> (she plucked).</i> and sometimes as feminine<sup class="footnote-marker">168</sup><i class="footnote">It is indicated by the word <i>b’phiha</i> (in her mouth).</i> because where the word <i>yonah</i> (dove) occurs in Scripture it is spoken of as feminine. <i>Taraph</i> however means ‘<i>he</i> plucked.’ But a Midrashic explanation takes it [<i>taraph</i>] as meaning ‘food,’ and the word <i>b’phiha</i> (in her mouth) it explains as meaning ‘speaking.’ Thus she said: ‘Rather that my food be bitter as an olive and come by the hand of the Holy One, blessed be He, than as sweet as honey and from the hand of mortal man.’”<br>All this does not appear to me to be correct for there is no reason why Scripture should change its reference to doves from feminine to masculine in one place in the same section. And if it is proper language to always speak of <i>yonah</i> in Scripture as feminine, why did it change here? Similarly, their Midrashic explanation does not at all make the word <i>b’phiha</i> to mean “speaking.” Instead, their Midrash is based on the fact that she brought this kind of leaf for if we should say that it just happened [that she brought an olive leaf], it cannot be in vain that Scripture mentioned it since it should have said, “And, lo, in her mouth a leaf freshly plucked.” Besides, the olive does not come from the very high trees that the fowl should nest there on account of its long branches. It was for this reason that the Sages said that there was in this a hint that it is more pleasing to the fowl to have their food bitter as wormwood from the hand of the Holy One, blessed be He, and not have it be good and sweet as honey from the hand of mortal man, and surely, all the more, people do not wish to be dependent for their livehood upon one another. In the words of Bereshith Rabbah:<sup class="footnote-marker">156</sup><i class="footnote">33:9.</i> “Rabbi Abahu said, ‘If the dove brought the olive leaf from the garden of Eden, could she not have brought something exceptional such as either cinnamon or balsam? But it was a hint which she gave to Noah: rather something even more bitter than this from the hand of the Holy One, blessed be He, than something sweet from your hand.’” But in the Gemara<sup class="footnote-marker">169</sup><i class="footnote">Erubin 18b. See my Hebrew commentary, p. 61, Note 28.</i> they [the Sages] added: “What evidence is there that the word <i>taraph</i> means food? It is written, <i>‘Hatripheni’ (Feed me) with mine allotted bread</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">170</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 30:8.</i> It is due to the reason we have stated, [namely, that Scripture mentioned the name of the tree in order to indicate this hint] for which the Rabbis found support in the word <i>hatripheni</i>, implying that it is as if Scripture said, “And, lo, an olive-leaf of <i>tereph</i> (food)<sup class="footnote-marker">171</sup><i class="footnote">And not <i>taraph</i> (he plucked), as it is actually vocalized.</i> in her mouth.”<br>As for the plain meaning of Scripture, the commentators<sup class="footnote-marker">172</sup><i class="footnote">Ibn Ezra and R’dak.</i> have explained that the word <i>taraph</i> modifies the word “leaf,” thus stating, “And, lo, a plucked olive leaf was in her mouth.” Proof for this [i.e., that <i>taraph</i> modifies “leaf” rather than acting as a verb] is that <i>taraph</i> is wholly vocalized with the <i>kamatz</i>, as is the rule.<sup class="footnote-marker">173</sup><i class="footnote">If it were a verb, it would have been vocalized with a <i>kamatz</i> followed by a <i>patach</i>.</i> It is, however, found in irregular forms: <i>For ‘taraph’ (He hath torn), and He will heal us;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">174</sup><i class="footnote">Hosea 6:1. Here the word is vocalized wholly with the <i>kamatz</i>, and yet it is a verb rather than an adjective.</i> <i>And he shall restore that which ‘gazal’ (he took by robbery);</i><sup class="footnote-marker">175</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 5:23. Similar to the above.</i> <i>The error which ‘shagag’ (he committed);</i><sup class="footnote-marker">176</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 18. This too is similar to the above.</i> and many other additional verses.

Verse 12



Verse 13



Verse 14



Verse 15



Verse 16



Verse 17



Verse 18



Verse 19



Verse 20



Verse 21

AND THE ETERNAL SAID IN HIS HEART. He did not reveal the matter to a prophet at that time, but on the day He commanded Moses concerning the writing of the Torah He revealed to him that as Noah brought his sacrifice it mounted pleasingly, and He decreed that He will no more smite every living thing. In this regard, I have already written of a secret<sup class="footnote-marker">177</sup><i class="footnote">See Ramban above, 6:6.</i> hinted at by our Rabbis.<br>The sense of the expression, <i>I will not again curse the ground any more for man’s sake</i> is that they were punished because of him for if man had not sinned, they have been spared even though they had also corrupted their ways.
FOR THE IMAGINATION OF MAN’s HEART IS EVIL FROM HIS YOUTH. He ascribes merit to men because by their very creation they have an evil nature in their youthful days but not in their mature years. If so, for these two reasons,<sup class="footnote-marker">178</sup><i class="footnote">First, that by his very creation, man’s heart is evil, and second, that this evil persists only when he is young but not when he matures. Therefore, for these two reasons it is not proper that every living thing be smitten on account of man.</i> it is not proper to smite every living thing. The reason for the prefix <i>mem</i> [which signifies “from” in the word] <i>min’urav</i> (from his youth) is to indicate that the evil imagination is with men from the very beginning of their youth, just as the Rabbis have said:<sup class="footnote-marker">179</sup><i class="footnote">Bereshith Rabbah 34:10.</i> “From the moment he awakes to go forth from his mother’s womb the evil impulse is placed in him.” It is possible that the verse is saying that it is from youth — meaning, on account of youth — that the evil inclination is in man, for youth causes him to sin. And some say<sup class="footnote-marker">180</sup><i class="footnote">I have not identified the source of this opinion.</i> that it is as if it said “in his youth,” [<i>min’urav</i> being interpreted as if it were <i>bin’urav</i>]. Similarly we find <i>‘Miterem’ (Before) a stone was laid upon a stone in the temple of the Eternal</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">181</sup><i class="footnote">Haggai 2:15.</i> [where the word <i>miterem</i> is interpreted as <i>beterem</i>]; so too, <i>This is the land which ye shall divide ‘minachlah’ (by lot) unto the tribes of Israel</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">182</sup><i class="footnote">Ezekiel 48:29.</i> [where <i>minachlah</i> is interpreted as <i>benachlah</i>].

Chapter 9



Verse 1



Verse 2



Verse 3

EVERY ‘REMES’ (MOVING THING) THAT LIVETH. This refers to cattle, beasts and fowl — and also the fish in the sea — since all of them are called “moving things,” just as it is written: <i>Every living creature ‘haromeseth’ (that creepeth) wherewith the waters swarmed</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">183</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 1:21.</i>

Verse 4

ONLY FLESH WITH THE LIFE THEREOF, THE BLOOD THEREOF, SHALL YE NOT EAT. Rashi wrote: “This prohibition applies while the animal’s life is still in the blood. Thus, you should not eat flesh as long as there is life in it, meaning a limb cut from a living animal, nor shall you eat its blood together with its life, meaning the blood of a living animal.”<sup class="footnote-marker">184</sup><i class="footnote">Rashi thus connects <i>b’naphsho</i> (with its life) with the preceding word, <i>basar</i>, and also with the succeeding word, <i>damo</i> (its blood), although the text reads, <i>basar b’naphsho damo</i>. Ramban objects that if so the text should have said, <i>v’damo</i> (and its blood), instead of <i>damo</i>.</i> But if this be so Scripture should have said, “flesh, so long as there is life in it, <i>and</i> also its blood ye shall not eat.” But according to the simple meaning of Scripture, this interpretation is incorrect, and according to the Midrash it is not true, for the sons of Noah<sup class="footnote-marker">64</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Seder Bereshith</i>, Note 222.</i> have been admonished against eating a limb cut from a living animal, as is the opinion of the Sages, but not the blood of a living animal, as is the opinion of Rabbi Chanina ben Gamliel.<sup class="footnote-marker">185</sup><i class="footnote">Sanhedrin 59a.</i> Rather, the interpretation of the verse is as follows: “only flesh with the life thereof, which is the blood thereof, shall you not eat,” <i>for the life of all flesh is the blood thereof</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">186</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 17:14.</i>

Verse 5

AND SURELY YOUR BLOOD ‘LENAPHSHOTHEICHEM’ (OF YOUR LIVES) WILL I REQUIRE. This is as if it were written, <i>your blood ‘naphshotheichem,’</i> [without the letter <i>lamed</i>], and meaning “your blood which is your lives.” This is similar to the verse, <i>‘Lechol’ (To all) the instruments of the tabernacle</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">187</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 27:19.</i> [which means all the instruments needed for the tabernacle, the letter <i>lamed</i> in the word <i>lechol</i> being redundant]. So also, <i>the third ‘l’Avshalom’ (to Absalom)</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">188</sup><i class="footnote">I Chronicles 3:2.</i> [which means, “the third, Absolom,” the lamed in the word <i>l’Avshalom</i> is redundant].<br>It is possible to explain <i>your blood ‘lenaphshotheichem’</i> as meaning <i>benaphshotheichem</i> (<i>in</i> your souls), <i>for the life of all flesh, the blood thereof is all one with the life thereof</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">189</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 17:14.</i> Likewise, <i>And ye shall eat no manner of blood in all your dwelling places, ‘la’oph velabeheimah’ (to fowl and to cattle)</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">190</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 7:26.</i> which is to be explained as “in fowl or in beast.”<br>The correct interpretation is that Scripture is saying, “the blood which is the life in you I will require.” He is thus declaring that the blood is one with the life, and He intimates that one incurs the death penalty for spilling the blood upon which life depends, but not for spilling the blood of those limbs on which life is not dependent. Our Rabbis have expounded this verse as an injunction against suicide,<sup class="footnote-marker">191</sup><i class="footnote">Baba Kamma 91b.</i> the verse stating, “I will require your blood from your own souls.”
AT THE HAND OF EVERY BEAST WILL I REQUIRE IT. I wonder: if “the requiring” is here meant in its usual sense, i.e., from the hand of the beast as well as from the hand of man, in both cases there will be punishment in the matter, but the beast has no reason [with which to discern between good and evil] so that it should be punished or rewarded! Perhaps this principle applies only to spilling man’s blood; every beast that will devour him will itself be devoured, for such is the decree of the King. And this is the reason [why Scripture says of an ox that killed a human being], <i>the ox shall surely be stoned, and its flesh shall not be eaten</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">192</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 21:28.</i> This is not a form of monetary punishment for the owner since even an ownerless ox is subject to the death penalty,<sup class="footnote-marker">193</sup><i class="footnote">Baba Kamma 44b.</i> and the command applies alike to the sons of Noah<sup class="footnote-marker">64</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Seder Bereshith</i>, Note 222.</i> and to the Israelites. The meaning of <i>Who so sheddeth man’s blood</i><sup class="footnote-marker">194</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 6.</i> would thus be, “all shedders” whether beast or man, their blood will be required by the Court on earth and<sup class="footnote-marker">195</sup><i class="footnote">“And.” The Tur, quoting Ramban, has “or.”</i> by the hand of Heaven.<br>It is possible that the meaning of the expression, <i>at the hand of every beast</i>, is that the vengeance upon the shedder of blood will be at the hand of every beast, just as it is said, <i>That she hath received of the Eternal’s hand double of all her sins</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">196</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 40:2.</i> Thus He says, “Surely your blood will I require and avenge <i>at the hand of every beast</i> for I will send against the murderer all beasts of the earth, and I will also send against him <i>the hand of man</i>, and he will not escape them.” Similarly, <i>Because of all mine adversaries I am become a reproach</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">197</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 31:12.</i> meaning “because of the hand of all mine adversaries;” <i>This is the portion of a wicked man from G-d, and the heritage appointed unto him by G-d</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">198</sup><i class="footnote">Job 20:29.</i> [meaning this is the portion of a wicked man by the hand of G-d].<br>Perhaps the requiring at the hand of the beast means that she should not devour man for so He established their nature. The secret of the matter is that at the time of creation He gave man <i>every herb bearing seed… and every tree in which is the fruit of a tree… for food</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">199</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 1:29.</i> and to the beast He gave <i>every green herb for food</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">200</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 30.</i> and Scripture says, <i>and it was so</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">200</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 30.</i> meaning that such was their nature and habit. But now when He said of man that he may slaughter the lower living creatures for food and it was so placed in nature or habit that living creatures should eat each other, it became necessary to command that the other living creatures be unto men <i>a prey to their teeth</i><sup class="footnote-marker">201</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 124:6.</i> while they are to fear men and not devour them. And He said, <i>And surely, your blood of your lives will I require</i>, in order to hint that He will not require the blood of one beast from the hand of another. This being so, it was thus left to them to devour one another. And this is the reason why He mentioned here the prohibition of spilling the blood of man; it is on account of the permission given here for slaughtering, which became the customary way of spilling blood since in the opinion of our Rabbis,<sup class="footnote-marker">202</sup><i class="footnote">Sanhedrin 56b.</i> Adam had already been admonished against spilling blood. But on account of the permission for slaughtering, it became necessary for Him to say, “I have permitted you to spill the blood of every living thing except your own blood. This is forbidden to you as well as to all living things for it will not be their nature to spill it.”

Verse 6



Verse 7

AND YOU, BE YE FRUITFUL, AND MULTIPLY. The plain meaning thereof is as its Midrash, i.e., that it is a commandment.<sup class="footnote-marker">203</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 59b.</i> A similar verse mentioned with reference to Adam,<sup class="footnote-marker">204</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 1:28.</i> also one with reference to the sons of Noah<sup class="footnote-marker">205</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 1 here.</i> in conjunction with the statement that G-d blessed them, constitutes a blessing, just as it is said concerning the fish.<sup class="footnote-marker">206</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 1:22.</i> Now because He spoke here of the other living things and said, <i>that they may swarm in the earth, and be fruitful, and multiply upon the earth</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">207</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 8:17.</i> He said here, <i>And you</i> — man — <i>be ye fruitful and multiply</i>. He continued saying, <i>swarm in the earth, and multiply therein</i>, in order to repeat the commandment for the purpose of emphasis, thus stating that they should be engaged in it with all power [since those who came forth from the ark were few]. Perhaps He commanded them concerning the settlement of the whole earth, as I have explained in <i>Seder Bereshith</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">204</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 1:28.</i><br>Now Rashi wrote, “According to the plain interpretation, the first time [this was said to man it was said] as a blessing; here it is a command. According to the Midrashic explanation, [this command is mentioned here after the prohibition of murder] in order to liken one who abstains from having children to one who sheds blood.” Now the Rabbis have derived this Midrash only from the juxtaposition of the verses, but the verse itself was written as a commandment, and the first [time this was said to man it was] as a blessing. [This is contrary to Rashi who implies that the Midrashic explanation differs from the plain interpretation.] And so the Rabbis have said in Tractate Sanhedrin,<sup class="footnote-marker">203</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 59b.</i> “But the commandment to be fruitful which was declared to the sons of Noah — as it is written, <i>And you, be ye fruitful and multiply</i>,….”

Verse 8

AND G-D SPOKE TO NOAH AND TO HIS SONS. The meaning thereof is that He spoke to the sons by means of their father for his sons were not prophets, and Ham did not reach the level of prophecy. Likewise, “And the Eternal spoke to Ahaz,”<sup class="footnote-marker">208</sup><i class="footnote">Reference is to the verse, <i>Once more the Eternal spoke to Ahaz</i>. (Isaiah 7:10.)</i> [which means that G-d spoke to him through Isaiah].<sup class="footnote-marker">209</sup><i class="footnote">See R’dak there.</i> And so also, <i>And the Eternal spoke unto Moses and unto Aaron</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">210</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 7:8 and others.</i> which according to the words of our Rabbis<sup class="footnote-marker">211</sup><i class="footnote">Torath Kohanim <i>Vayikra</i>, 1.</i> means He spoke to Moses so that he would in turn speak to Aaron. And so Scripture makes explicit at the end of the present chapter: <i>And G-d spoke to Noah</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">212</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 17 here.</i>

Verse 9



Verse 10



Verse 11



Verse 12

THIS IS THE SIGN OF THE COVENANT WHICH I MAKE. It would appear from this sign that the rainbow in the cloud was not part of creation and that now G-d created a new thing by making a rainbow in the heavens on a cloudy day. Now commentators have said<sup class="footnote-marker">213</sup><i class="footnote">I have found this opinion in Chizkuni.</i> concerning the meaning of this sign that He has not made the rainbow with its feet bent upward because it might have appeared that arrows were being shot from heaven, as in the verse, <i>And He sent out his arrows and scattered them</i><sup class="footnote-marker">214</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 18:15.</i> on the earth. Instead He made it the opposite of this — [with the feet bent downward] — in order to show that they are not shooting at the earth from the heavens. It is indeed the way of warriors to invert the instruments of war which they hold in their hands when calling for peace from their opponents. Moreover, [with the feet of the bow being turned downward towards the earth, it can be seen] that the bow has no rope upon which to bend the arrows.<br>We must perforce believe the words of the Greek [philosophers who maintain] that the rainbow is a natural result of the heat of the sun falling upon damp air for even in a vessel containing water which stands in the sun there is the appearance of the rainbow. When contemplating the language of Scripture we will understand that it is so, for He said, <i>I have set My bow in the cloud</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">215</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 13 here.</i> [the use of the past tense indicating that He had already set it so from the beginning and it is not a new creation]. He did not say, “I set in the cloud,” even as He said, <i>This is the sign of the covenant which I make</i>. Moreover, the word <i>kashti</i> (My bow) — [in the possessive form] — indicates that He possessed the bow previously. Therefore, we shall explain the verse thus: “The rainbow which I have set in the clouds from the day of creation will be from this day on a sign of covenant between Me and you; whenever I will see it I will remember that there is a covenant of peace between Me and you.”<br>And should you want to know how the rainbow can be a sign, the answer is that it has the same meaning as the verse, <i>This stone-heap be witness, and this pillar be witness;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">216</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 31:52.</i> likewise, <i>For these seven ewe-lambs shalt thou take of my hand, that it may be a witness unto me.</i><sup class="footnote-marker">217</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 21:30.</i> Every visible object that is set before two parties to remind them of a matter that they have vowed between them is called a “sign,” and every agreement is called a “covenant.” Similarly, in the case of circumcision, He said, <i>And it shall be a token of a covenant between Me and you</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">218</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 17:11.</i> because of the agreement that all seed of Abraham be circumcised <i>to serve Him with one consent</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">219</sup><i class="footnote">Zephaniah 3:9.</i> Moreover, when the above-mentioned rainbow is seen in its inverted form, [namely, with the feet of the bow turned downward], it is a reminder of peace, as we have written. Thus, whether the bow was a newly established phenomenon or one that always existed in nature, the significance thereof as a sign is the same.<br>Our Rabbis however have a profound secret in this section. They have said in Bereshith Rabbah:<sup class="footnote-marker">220</sup><i class="footnote">35:3.</i> “<i>I have set ‘kashti’ (My bow) in the cloud</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">215</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 13 here.</i> This means, ‘My likeness, that which resembles Me.’ But is that possible? It is possible only as the straw resembles the fruit. <br><i>And it shall come to pass, when I bring a cloud over the earth</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">221</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 14 here.</i> Rabbi Yudan said in the name of Rabbi Yehudah the son of Rabbi Shimon, ‘This is like one who had in his hand some heated flour which he wanted to cast upon his son, but [because of his compassion for him] he cast it upon his servant.’”<sup class="footnote-marker">222</sup><i class="footnote">In the same way, when the generation is wicked and deserves destruction, G-d instead punishes the fruit of the earth.</i> There in Bereshith Rabbah it also says:<sup class="footnote-marker">223</sup><i class="footnote">35:4.</i> “<i>And the bow shall be in the cloud, and I will look upon it, that I may remember the everlasting covenant between G-d</i><sup class="footnote-marker">224</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 16 here.</i> — this alludes to the attribute of Justice on high. <i>And every living creature of all flesh that is upon the earth</i><sup class="footnote-marker">224</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 16 here.</i> — this alludes to the attribute of justice on earth. The heavenly attribute of justice is stern; the earthly one is sparing.” And you already know the saying of the Rabbis concerning one who gazes at the rainbow:<sup class="footnote-marker">225</sup><i class="footnote">Chagigah 16a.</i> “Whosoever takes no thought for the honor of his Maker would have been better off had he not come into the world.” And if you will be worthy to understand the words of the Rabbis, you will know that the explanation of the verses is as follows: <i>My bow</i> — [<i>kashti</i> shares a common root with the word <i>kasheh</i> (hard, stern)] — which is symbolic of the attribute of justice, set in the cloud, shall be at the time of judgment <i>for a token of the covenant</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">215</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 13 here.</i> 
<i>And it shall come to pass when I bring clouds over the earth</i><sup class="footnote-marker">221</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 14 here.</i> — meaning that when G-d will not make His countenance shine upon<sup class="footnote-marker">226</sup><i class="footnote">See Numbers 6:25.</i> the earth on account of the sins of its inhabitants— “My attribute of justice will be seen in the cloud, and I will remember the covenant in a remembrance of mercy, and I will have compassion on the little ones that are on the earth.” Thus, this token and the covenant are like the token of circumcision and the covenant thereof,<sup class="footnote-marker">227</sup><i class="footnote">See Ramban further, 17:13.</i> and the language of the verses is very appropriate for the subject. And thus the Rabbis in the above Midrash have explained the expression <i>between G-d</i><sup class="footnote-marker">224</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 16 here.</i> as referring to the attribute of justice on high, which is <i>gevurah</i> (strength), and <i>that which is upon the earth</i><sup class="footnote-marker">224</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 16 here.</i> as being the attribute of justice on earth, which is a kindly attribute, conducting the world together with the attribute of mercy, for Scripture does not say “that which is <i>in</i> the earth,” [which would have alluded to “the earth above”], but only “that which is <i>on</i> the earth.” I have already hinted<sup class="footnote-marker">228</sup><i class="footnote">See Ramban above, 6:13.</i> at the secret of the Rabbis concerning the name “earth.” But Rashi wrote, “<i>Between G-d</i><sup class="footnote-marker">224</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 16 here.</i>— between the attribute of justice on high and you.” But our Rabbis did not intend to imply this interpretation in their Midrash.

Verse 13



Verse 14



Verse 15



Verse 16



Verse 17



Verse 18

AND HAM IS THE FATHER OF CANAAN. Rashi explained, “Because this section goes on to deal with Noah’s family,<sup class="footnote-marker">229</sup><i class="footnote">“Family.” The first edition of Rashi concurs with this quote. In our texts of Rashi: “drunkenness.”</i> relating that Ham sinned and through him Canaan was cursed, and since the generations of Ham have not yet been mentioned [to let us know that Canaan was his son], it was necessary to state here that Ham is the father of Canaan.”<br>And Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra said that Ham only saw the nakedness of his father and informed his brothers while Canaan did him the evil, the nature of which Scripture does not reveal,<sup class="footnote-marker">230</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 24 here.</i> and this is the meaning of the verse, <i>And he knew what his youngest son had done unto him</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">230</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 24 here.</i> since Canaan was the youngest of Ham’s sons, as Scripture enumerates them, <i>And the sons of Ham: Cush, and Mitzraim, and Phut, and Canaan.</i><sup class="footnote-marker">231</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 10:6.</i> [Ibn Ezra thus interprets “son” to mean “grandson.”] Now here Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra abandoned his method of explaining Scripture according to its plain meaning and began to declare statements contrary to the truth.<sup class="footnote-marker">232</sup><i class="footnote">For Scripture in no way ascribes the act of evil done to Noah by Canaan. Instead, it mentions only Ham, (Verse 22). Thus what made Ibn Ezra say that it was Canaan that did it?</i><br>The correct interpretation appears to me to be that Ham was the youngest of Noah’s sons as I have explained at the beginning of this portion of the Torah, and Canaan was Ham’s oldest son. And as for the verse which states, <i>And the sons of Ham: Cush, and Mitzraim, and Phut, and Canaan</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">231</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 10:6.</i> [which indicates that Canaan was the youngest son], this was stated after he was sold to be <i>a servant of servants;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">233</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 25 here.</i> Scripture gave his brothers preference over him. Now when this event happened to Noah, Ham had no other children except Canaan. This explains the verse, <i>And Ham, the father of Canaan, saw</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">234</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 22.</i> for Ham had no other son then, and when he sinned unto his father, he cursed his seed. Now if Noah had said, “cursed be Ham, a servant of servants shall he be,” the punishment would have been only his since the seed already born to him is not part of him, and perhaps Ham would no longer beget children. In that case Noah would not have taken his vengeance of him for who knows what shall be after him.<sup class="footnote-marker">235</sup><i class="footnote">See Ecclesiastes 3:22.</i> Therefore, he cursed the son he had. Even if he will later beget a hundred children,<sup class="footnote-marker">236</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>ibid.</i>, 6:3.</i> it is enough that the oldest son — and all his seed with him — were cursed.<br>The sin committed was that Ham saw the nakedness of his father<sup class="footnote-marker">234</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 22.</i> and did not act respectfully. He should have covered his nakedness and concealed his shame by not telling even his brothers, but he told the matter to his two brothers in the presence of many people in order to deride him [Noah]. This is the meaning of the word <i>outside</i><sup class="footnote-marker">237</sup><i class="footnote"><i>And he told his two brethren outside</i>. (Verse 22.)</i> And so did Onkelos translate it as “in the market-place.” The meaning of the verse, <i>And</i> [Noah] <i>knew what he had done unto him</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">230</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 24 here.</i> is that he knew that Ham had disclosed his disgrace to many, and he was ashamed of the matter. Our Rabbis have mentioned an additional sin that Ham committed.<sup class="footnote-marker">238</sup><i class="footnote">Sanhedrin 70a. See Rashi at the end of Verse 22.</i>

Verse 19



Verse 20

‘ISH’ (A MAN) OF THE GROUND. Rashi explained it as “the master [owner or lord] of the ground. This is similar to the expression, <i>‘ish’ (the man) of Naomi</i>,”<sup class="footnote-marker">239</sup><i class="footnote">Ruth 1:3.</i> [which means the master of Naomi]. But this is not so. <i>‘Ish’ Naomi</i> is an expression of the marital state, just as: <i>‘ish ve’ishto’ (a man and his wife)</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">240</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 7:2.</i> Others<sup class="footnote-marker">241</sup><i class="footnote">Found in R’dak’s Book of Roots.</i> have said that it means “the outstanding one of the earth, and its leader,” and they brought proof from similar verses: <i>Gideon the son of Joash, ‘ish’ (a man) of Israel</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">242</sup><i class="footnote">Judges 7:14.</i> [meaning a chief of Israel]; <i>Both ye sons of ‘adam’ and ye son of ‘ish;’</i><sup class="footnote-marker">243</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 49:3. Translated: both low and high.</i> <i>Art thou not ‘ish’ (a man)? And who is like to thee in Israel?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">244</sup><i class="footnote">I Samuel 26:15.</i> And there are many other similar verses according to their opinion.<br>In my opinion, <i>Gideon the son of Joash ‘ish’ of Israel</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">242</sup><i class="footnote">Judges 7:14.</i> refers to his genealogy, i.e., that he was an Israelite. <i>Art thou not a man?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">244</sup><i class="footnote">I Samuel 26:15.</i> means that “there is no one like you in Israel.” Similarly, <i>strengthen yourselves, and be men</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">245</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 4:9.</i> means that they should not be weak like women. <i>Both ye sons of ‘adam’ and ye sons of ‘ish,’</i><sup class="footnote-marker">243</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 49:3. Translated: both low and high.</i> [means “both ye low-born and] ye men of higher station.” However, <i>a man of the ground</i> is like <i>the men of the city</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">246</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 19:4.</i> since Noah lived all over the earth and never built a city or country to which he should relate himself. Similarly, <i>a man of the field</i><sup class="footnote-marker">247</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 25:27.</i> means one who constantly stayed there. In the Mishnah we find:<sup class="footnote-marker">248</sup><i class="footnote">Aboth, I, 4.</i> “Yosei ben Yoezer a man of Tzreidah, and Yosei ben Yochanan a man of Jerusalem.”<br>[It may be that <i>a man of the ground</i> means] that he was determined to work the ground, to sow and to plant, because he found the earth had been laid waste, for whoever dedicates himself to a certain purpose is so called, [i.e., <i>ish</i> of that purpose]. <i>The men of the city</i><sup class="footnote-marker">246</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 19:4.</i> means those that dwell in it. <i>The men of David</i><sup class="footnote-marker">249</sup><i class="footnote">I Samuel 23:3.</i> are his servants, and <i>a man of G-d</i><sup class="footnote-marker">250</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 33:1.</i> is one who is dedicated to His service. And so the Rabbis have said in Bereshith Rabbah:<sup class="footnote-marker">251</sup><i class="footnote">36:6.</i> “<i>A man of the ground</i> [is so called just] as the castle guard is called by the name of the castle.” And the Rabbis also said<sup class="footnote-marker">252</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 36:5.</i> that Noah had a passion for agriculture. Thus [the word <i>ish</i> is here used to signify] a relationship.<br>The meaning of the word <i>vayachel (and he began)</i> is that he commenced the planting of vineyards. The preceding men had planted single vines, but Noah began to plant many rows of vines, which together comprise a vineyard. On account of his desire for wine, he did not plant the vine singly as other trees; rather, he made a vineyard.

Verse 21



Verse 22



Verse 23



Verse 24



Verse 25



Verse 26

BLESSED BE THE ETERNAL G-D OF SHEM, AND MAY CANAAN BE SERVANT TO THEM. Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra explained that <i>to them</i> means that Canaan be servant to G-d and to Shem since Shem will compel him to worship G-d. And the second time [this expression is repeated — in Verse 27: <i>May G-d enlarge Japheth, and may He dwell in the tents of Shem, and may Canaan be servant to them</i> — Ibn Ezra] explained that Canaan would be a servant to Japheth and Shem. But if this be so, Noah came to curse his enemies, and behold he blessed<sup class="footnote-marker">253</sup><i class="footnote">See Numbers 24:10.</i> Canaan that he be a servant to G-d!<br>But Rashi wrote: “<i>Blessed be the Eternal G-d of Shem</i>, Who will in days to come carry out His promise to the descendants of Shem to give them the land of Canaan, and may Canaan pay them tribute. This is repeated again [in Verse 27, as explained above], in order to state that even when the children of Shem will be in exile, the children of Canaan will be sold to them as slaves.” [Thus Rashi interprets <i>to them</i> as referring to the descendants of Shem.]<br>The correct interpretation appears to me to be that at first he [Noah] cursed him that he be a servant of servants to the entire world, and whosoever will find him will enslave him, for the meaning of <i>unto his brethren</i><sup class="footnote-marker">233</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 25 here.</i> is “unto all men,” just as in the verse, <i>For I will set all men every one against his neighbor</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">254</sup><i class="footnote">Zechariah 8:10.</i> and as is the sense of the expression, <i>Every man his fellow</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">255</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 3:5.</i> It may that <i>unto his brethren</i><sup class="footnote-marker">233</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 25 here.</i> refers to Shem and Japheth for his father’s brothers are called “his brothers,” just as in the expression, <i>that his brother was taken captive</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">256</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 14:14.</i> [which refers to Lot who was a son of Abraham’s brother]. And some say — as found in Ibn Ezra — that <i>unto his brethren</i> means his father’s children [namely, Cush, Mitzraim and Phut, who are his father’s children].<sup class="footnote-marker">231</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 10:6.</i> Thus, after being made a servant to his father’s children and to Shem and Japheth, he was a servant to the whole world. Now Noah first blessed the G-d of Shem, thereby letting it be known that Shem will be a servant of G-d while Canaan will be subject to him. And <i>to them</i> alludes to the seed of Shem who were many. It is possible that <i>to them</i> reverts also to his brothers already mentioned. Then he blessed Japheth with an enlargement of the boundary, he blessed Shem with the dwelling of G-d in his tents, and finally said that Canaan be a <i>servant to them</i>, meaning to the two of them. He made Canaan subservient to Shem twice, [in Verses 26 and 27, as explained above], thus hinting that the seed of Shem will inherit his land and all that he has, for that which a slave acquires belongs to his master.<sup class="footnote-marker">257</sup><i class="footnote">Pesachim 88b.</i><br>This section was written in Scripture in order to make known that it was on account of his sin that Canaan became a servant forever and that Abraham was favored with his land. The subject of the wine’s effect on Noah was written because it contains a greater warning against drunkeness than that of the section on the Nazirite:<sup class="footnote-marker">258</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 6:1-21.</i> even the perfectly righteous man — whose righteousness saved the whole world — even he sinned on account of wine, and it brought him to disgrace and the cursing of his seed.

Chapter 10



Verse 1

AND UNTO THEM WERE SONS BORN AFTER THE FLOOD. The intent thereof is to imply that even though they were fit to have children before the flood — for in those generations it was normal to beget children at about sixty years of age<sup class="footnote-marker">259</sup><i class="footnote">See above, 5:15, 21.</i> — these did not beget children even at the age of a hundred, only until after the flood, for G-d restrained them from having children in order that they should not perish in the flood or that it [not] be necessary to save many persons in the ark. And so also did G-d do to this entire family: Lamech was delayed in begetting Noah until more than twice the age of his ancestors,<sup class="footnote-marker">260</sup><i class="footnote">Enoch begot Methuselah at the age of sixty-five (above, 5:21), and Lamech begot Noah at the age of 182 (<i>ibid.</i>, Verse 28). Noah begot his sons when he was five hundred years old (<i>ibid.</i>, Verse 32).</i> and Noah much more. This is already mentioned in the commentary of Rashi<sup class="footnote-marker">261</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 5:32.</i> who quotes from Bereshith Rabbah.<sup class="footnote-marker">262</sup><i class="footnote">26:2.</i>

Verse 2

THE SONS OF JAPHETH: GOMER. Scripture begins with Japheth for he was the oldest. After him, it mentions Ham [even though he was the youngest]<sup class="footnote-marker">263</sup><i class="footnote">See Ramban above, 6:10.</i> for Scripture wanted to delay the account of the generations of Shem in order to place side by side the two sections dealing with Shem’s children since it is important to dwell at length on the generations of Abraham.

Verse 3



Verse 4



Verse 5

FROM THERE WERE PARTED THE INHABITANTS OF THE MARITIME SETTLEMENT OF THE NATIONS IN THEIR LANDS. The meaning of this is that the children of Japheth are those who dwell on the isles of the sea, and they are separated, each one of his sons residing singly on another isle, and their countries are far from each other. This was indeed the blessing of their father Noah, who said, <i>May G-d enlarge Japheth</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">264</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 9:27.</i> meaning that they be numerous in the expanses of the earth. The sons of Ham, however, are all near one another as they dwell on the continents. Therefore Scripture said, <i>And the boundary of the Canaanite was from Sidon…in their lands and in their nations</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">265</sup><i class="footnote">Verses 19-20 here.</i> The same is true of the sons of Shem.<br>Now Scripture narrates all this in order to inform us of Abraham’s lineage from Shem, and Ham’s descendants are mentioned to inform us of those nations whose lands Abraham was favored with on account of the sin of their fathers. Therefore it tells also of Japheth and of the dispersion<sup class="footnote-marker">266</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 11:1-9.</i> in order to inform us of the cause of the difference in languages and the scattering of the nations to the ends of the earth in a short period of time after the first man. Moreover, this narration serves to let us know the kindness of G-d and His keeping the covenant He made with Noah that he would not destroy them.<br>The Rabbi<sup class="footnote-marker">267</sup><i class="footnote">Rabbi Moshe ben Maimon (Rambam or Maimonides). See <i>Seder Bereshith</i>, Note 139.</i> said in Moreh Nebuchim<sup class="footnote-marker">268</sup><i class="footnote">III, 50.</i> that the genealogy of the nations verifies to those that hear it the principle of the creation of the world.<sup class="footnote-marker">269</sup><i class="footnote">“It is one of the fundamental principles of the Torah that the universe has been created out of nothing, and that of the human race, one individual being, Adam was created. As the time which elapsed from Adam to Moses was not more than about two thousand five hundred years, people would have doubted the truth of that statement if no other information had been added, seeing that the human race was apread over all parts of the earth in different families and with different languages, very unlike the one to the other. In order to remove this doubt the Law gives the genealogy of the nations [Genesis 5 and 10], and the manner how they branched off from a common root. It names those of them who were well known, and tells who their fathers were, how long and where they lived. It describes also the cause that led to the dispersion of men over all parts of the earth, and to the formation of their different languages, after they had lived for a long time in one place, and spoken one language [<i>ibid.</i>, 11], as would be natural for descendants of one person.” (<i>Ibid.</i>, Friedlander’s translation III, p. 273.)</i> This also is true, for our father Abraham <i>will command his children and his household after him</i><sup class="footnote-marker">270</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 18:19.</i> and will affirm to them the narration concerning Noah and his sons who saw the flood and were in the ark. Thus he, [Abraham, not having seen the flood but hearing of it], was witness from mouth to mouth in the whole matter of the flood, and he was a fourth witness to creation since Noah saw his father Lamech who saw Adam. Isaac and Jacob saw Shem, the witness of the flood, and Jacob told all this to those that went down to Egypt, as well as to Pharaoh and the people of his generation. The people in every generation similarly know from their fathers who tell them the deeds and progeny of the four to five previous generations.

Verse 6



Verse 7

AND THE SONS OF CUSH: SEBA AND HAVILAH, ETC. These sons became the heads of nations, and the two sons of Raamah [namely, Sheba and Dedan] became two nations. Nimrod the son of Cush, however, did not become the head of a nation. Therefore, Scripture wrote afterward, <i>And Cush begot Nimrod</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">271</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 8.</i> and did not say, “and the sons of Cush: Nimrod, and Seba, and Havilah” [which would have indicated that Nimrod, like Seba and Havilah, also became the head of a nation]. But Phut the son of Ham<sup class="footnote-marker">272</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 6.</i> became only one people, and not various nations as was the case with Mitzraim<sup class="footnote-marker">273</sup><i class="footnote">Verses 13-14.</i> and Canaan,<sup class="footnote-marker">274</sup><i class="footnote">Verses 15-18.</i> the sons of Ham.<sup class="footnote-marker">272</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 6.</i> Therefore, Scripture did not return [to tell of the progeny of Phut, as it did with the other sons of Ham, namely, Cush, Mitzraim and Canaan]. In Bereshith Rabbah we find:<sup class="footnote-marker">275</sup><i class="footnote">37:2.</i> “Said Resh Lakish, ‘We might have thought that the family of Phut was swallowed up, but Ezekiel came and explained, <i>Phut, and Lud, and all the Arabians</i>,’”<sup class="footnote-marker">276</sup><i class="footnote">Ezekiel 30:5.</i> The meaning of the Midrash is that because Scripture did not return to tell about Phut, we might have thought that his seed intermingled with the children of Canaan and they neither became a nation, nor did they inherit a land called by their name. [The prophet Ezekiel thus clarified that the children of Phut existed as a separate nation in their own land.] However, in the case of <i>Magog, and Madai…and Tubal, and Meshech, and Tiras</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">277</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 2.</i> — the children of Japheth — Scripture also did not mention the families of their progeny: And so also with <i>the sons of Shem: Elam, and Asshur, and Arpachshad</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">278</sup><i class="footnote">“Arpachshad.” In this case Scripture does record his progeny (Verses 24-29). The Tur in quoting the language of Ramban rightly omits Arpachshad. Neither is it found in Ramban Mss.</i> <i>and Lud</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">279</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 22.</i> who became heads of nations; Scripture did not mention their progeny since each one just became one people inhabiting one country, and they did not give rise to various nationalities.

Verse 8

HE BEGAN TO BE A MIGHTY ONE IN THE EARTH. Rashi wrote, “<i>Mighty</i> in causing the entire world to rebel against the Holy One, blessed by He, by the plan he devised for the generation that witnessed the dispersion of the races.” But if so, <i>he began</i> means that he began after the flood [for it could not mean that he was the first ever to begin to rebel against G-d] since in the days of the generation of Enosh, such rebellion had already begun.<sup class="footnote-marker">280</sup><i class="footnote">See above, 4:26, Rashi. See also Rambam in the beginning of “Laws of Idolatry,” wherein he describes the process of how mankind was misled into the worship of the idols during the generation of Enosh.</i> It is possible that we should say that rebellion against G-d began in the generation of the dispersion while in the days of Enosh, people were not yet among those <i>that rebel against the light;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">281</sup><i class="footnote">Job 24:13.</i> rather, they also worshipped other gods.

Verse 9

HE WAS A MIGHTY HUNTER BEFORE THE ETERNAL. He ensnared the minds of people by his words, misleading them to rebel against the Omnipresent. Therefore it is said regarding any man who brazenly acts wickedly, knowing his Master and yet intentionally rebelling against Him — it is said, “This man is like Nimrod.” Thus the language of Rashi, and so is the opinion of our Rabbis.<sup class="footnote-marker">282</sup><i class="footnote">Bereshith Rabbah 37:2.</i><br>But Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra explained the matter in the opposite way, by way of the plain meaning of Scripture, for he interpreted the verses thus: <i>He began to be a mighty one</i> over the animals in hunting them. <i>Before the Eternal</i>, Ibn Ezra explained, means that he would build altars and offer the animals as whole-offerings before G-d. But Ibn Ezra’s words do not appear to be correct, and lo <i>he justifieth the wicked</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">283</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 17:15.</i> for our Rabbis knew by tradition of Nimrod’s wickedness.<br>The correct interpretation appears to me to be that Nimrod began to be a ruler by force over people, and he was the first monarch. Until his era there were no wars and no reigning monarchs; it was he who first prevailed over the people of Babylon until they crowned him.<sup class="footnote-marker">284</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 10 here.</i> After that he went to Assyria,<sup class="footnote-marker">285</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 11.</i> <i>and he did according to his will, and magnified himself</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">286</sup><i class="footnote">Daniel 8:4.</i> and there he built fortified cities with his power and with his might. This is what Scripture intended when it said, <i>And the beginning of his kingdom was Babel…and Accad…and Shinar</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">284</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 10 here.</i>

Verse 10



Verse 11

OUT OF THAT LAND — when Nimrod reigned over it — WENT FORTH ASSHUR, meaning he went forth to Asshur for Asshur was one of the sons of Shem.<sup class="footnote-marker">279</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 22.</i> This usage is similar to that found in the verses: <i>And it shall go forth Hazar-addar, and pass along to Azmon</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">287</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 34:4.</i> [which means that it shall go forth <i>to</i> Hazzar-addar]; <i>And Og the king of Bashan came out against us Edrei</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">288</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 3:1.</i> [which means <i>at</i> Edrei]; <i>And he shall return his own land with great substance</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">289</sup><i class="footnote">Daniel 11:28.</i> [which means that he shall return <i>to</i> his own land]; and many other similar verses. This is why the land of Assyria is called the land of Nimrod, just as it is said, <i>And they shall waste the land of Assyria with the sword, and the land of Nimrod with the keen-edge sword</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">290</sup><i class="footnote">Micah 5:5.</i> alluding to Nineveh, and the city of Rehoboth, and Calah.<sup class="footnote-marker">285</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 11.</i> Scripture tells yet more about Nimrod’s prowess — i.e., that <i>he was a mighty hunter</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">291</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 9 here.</i> prevailing also over the animals and ensnaring them. Scripture said, <i>Before the Eternal</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">291</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 9 here.</i> to suggest wonderment for there was no one under the heaven like him in strength. Similarly, <i>And the earth was corrupt before G-d</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">292</sup><i class="footnote">Above 6:11.</i> means that everything before Him on the earth was corrupt. This is like the verse, <i>That soul shall be cut off from before Me</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">293</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 22:3.</i> since every place is “before Him.”

Verse 12



Verse 13

AND MITZRAIM BEGOT. Scripture mentions the descendants of Mitzraim but does not specify their habitation as it does concerning the others. With the sons of Japheth it mentioned the isles,<sup class="footnote-marker">294</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 5 here.</i> with the sons of Cush it mentioned the land of Shinar<sup class="footnote-marker">284</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 10 here.</i> and Asshur,<sup class="footnote-marker">285</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 11.</i> and with the sons of Canaan it mentioned the boundaries of their land,<sup class="footnote-marker">295</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 19.</i> and likewise with the sons of Shem.<sup class="footnote-marker">296</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 30.</i> This was because <i>Mitzraim</i> (Egypt), the land of his habitation, was known for it was called by his name, and all his children lived around Egypt, and the names of their countries were also like their names. Thus we find for Pathrusim,<sup class="footnote-marker">297</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 14.</i> [one of the children of Mitzraim], the land of Pathrus, which is part of the land of Egypt, as it says, <i>And I will put a fear in the land of Egypt. And I will make Pathros desolate;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">298</sup><i class="footnote">Ezekiel 30:13-14.</i> <i>Into the land of their origin</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">299</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 29:14. The verse reads: <i>And I turn the captivity of Egypt, and will cause them to return into the land of Pathros, into the land of their origin</i>. This shows that the land of Pathros is near Egypt.</i> Similarly, <i>Lud and all the Arabians</i><sup class="footnote-marker">300</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 30:5.</i> were also around Egypt, and the names of their countries were like their names. So also the land of the Philistines was called Philistia, and so it is written [in Exodus 15:14], <i>the inhabitants of Philistia</i>.<br>But Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra said that these [names — <i>Ludim, and Anamim</i>, etc., in Verses 13-14] — are names of countries, and in each and every country there dwelled one family. This is why the names are all in the plural form, [that is, on account of the persons in the family, hence <i>Ludim</i> and not “Lud”]. And the real proof [that these are names of countries is the expression], <i>‘misham’ (whence) went forth</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">297</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 14.</i> for this word <i>misham</i> alludes to a place. In the opinion of the commentators,<sup class="footnote-marker">301</sup><i class="footnote">Rashi and Ibn Ezra.</i> the meaning of the expression, <i>that went forth</i>, is that they begot them, just as in the expression, <i>And kings shall come out of thy loins</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">302</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 35:11.</i> Now Rashi wrote: “They [the Philistines] were descended from both of them [the Pathrusim and the Casluhim], for the Pathrusim and Casluhim used to live together in promiscuous intercourse, and the Philistines were their offspring. Thus in Bereshith Rabbah.”<sup class="footnote-marker">303</sup><i class="footnote">37:8.</i><br>In my opinion, by way of the plain meaning of Scripture, the Casluhim dwelled in a city of that name — which was part of the land of Caphtor where the Caphtorim their brethren were — and <i>they went forth from there</i>, meaning from the Caphtorim who were of the seed of Casluhim. And they went in order <i>to look for a resting-place for themselves</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">304</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 10:33.</i> and they left the land to their brethren and conquered for themselves a land by the name of Philistia, after which they came to be called Philistines. This is why Scripture says, <i>The Caphtorim, that came forth out of Caphtor, destroyed them, and dwelt in their stead</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">305</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 2:22.</i> the Caphtorim being of the sons of Casluhim, dwellers of the land of Caphtor.

Verse 14



Verse 15

AND CANAAN BEGOT ZIDON HIS FIRST-BORN. These were the ten<sup class="footnote-marker">306</sup><i class="footnote">“Ten.” There are eleven children of Canaan mentioned here. Ramban will explain later in the text that one did not develop into a separate nation.</i> nations, sons of Canaan, whose lands were given to our father Abraham since all seed of Canaan were sold into servitude forever. These were the ones that were given to Abraham. Their names, however, changed for the most part in the days of Abraham; here they were inscribed according to the names their father called them on the days of their birth, but after they parted according to their lands and their nations, they were called by other names.<sup class="footnote-marker">307</sup><i class="footnote">Compare Verses 15-18 here with Verses 19-21 in Chapter 15.</i> Perhaps they were called by the names of the land in which they settled, as we have explained.<sup class="footnote-marker">308</sup><i class="footnote">Above, at the end of Verse 13 concerning the origin of the name Philistines.</i> Likewise, <i>Se’ir the Horite</i><sup class="footnote-marker">309</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 36:20.</i> was so called because the name of the city was Se’ira. And there are many similar names. It may be that the Arkite and the Sinite<sup class="footnote-marker">310</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 17 here.</i> did beget families but were cut off from them, and their children were, for example, <i>the Kenite, and the Kenizzite</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">311</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 15:19.</i> These became the heads of families, the entire nation being called by their name as was customary among the tribes of Israel. Now in His gift [of the land of Abraham, G-d] called the ten nations by the names by which they were known in the time of Abraham.<sup class="footnote-marker">312</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verses 19-21.</i><br>Proof of this, [namely, that some of the names of the sons of Canaan changed in the time of Abraham], is that the Hivite mentioned here<sup class="footnote-marker">310</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 17 here.</i> is not mentioned in the gift to Abraham,<sup class="footnote-marker">312</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verses 19-21.</i> and yet he was among them, as it is said, <i>And He shall cast out many nations before thee, the Hittite, and the Girgashite, and the Amorite, and the Canaanite, and the Perizzite, and the Hivite, and the Jebusite, seven nations</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">313</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 7:1.</i> So also in every place [Scripture counts the Hivite among the nations that inhabited the land of Canaan]. Now the Canaanite is counted in the gift to Abraham among his [Canaan’s] children,<sup class="footnote-marker">314</sup><i class="footnote">As the verse states: <i>And the Amorite and the Canaanite</i>… . Further, 15:21.</i> but only ten are counted [there<sup class="footnote-marker">312</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verses 19-21.</i> — while eleven children of Canaan are mentioned here] —<sup class="footnote-marker">315</sup><i class="footnote">Verses 15-18 here.</i> because one of his sons did not prevail like his other brothers, and so he was called together with his brother [the Hivite] by the name of his father, [thus bringing to a total of ten the number of nations whose lands were given to Abraham]. It is possible also that it was Zidon, Canaan’s first-born who was called the Canaanite together with his brother, [the eleventh son of Canaan], who did not become a nation, [thus making ten the total number of lands given to Abraham].<br>Do not find it difficult that the land of the Philistines was also given to Abraham — as it is written, <i>Sojourn in this land … for unto thee, and unto thy seed, I will give all these lands</i><sup class="footnote-marker">316</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 26:3.</i> — and yet the Philistines were of the sons of Mitzraim [and not of Canaan]! Scripture said, <i>Counted to the Canaanites were the five lords of the Philistines</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">317</sup><i class="footnote">Joshua 13:3. Hence their lands were also given to Abraham even though the Philistines themselves were not of the seed of Canaan.</i> because the Philistines conquered part of the land of the Canaanites and settled thereon. And here in Scripture you will see [that the Philistines captured part of the Canaanite land], <i>for the boundary of the Canaanite was from Sidon, as thou comest to Gerar, unto Gaza</i><sup class="footnote-marker">318</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 19 here.</i> yet we find that these were Philistine cities, since Abimelech, king of the Philistines, was king of Gerar,<sup class="footnote-marker">319</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 20:2.</i> and Gaza belonged to the Gazites. Similarly, <i>For Gaza one</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">320</sup><i class="footnote">I Samuel 6:17.
