This is counted among the guilt-offerings the five Philistine cities sent along with the Ark of G-d which they were returning.</i> Sidon also belonged to the Philistines, for it is written, <i>All the Zidonians will I drive out from before the children of Israel; only allot thou it unto Israel for an inheritance;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">321</sup><i class="footnote">Joshua 13:6.</i> and again, <i>And also what are ye to Me, O Tyre, and Zidon, and all the regions of Philistia?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">322</sup><i class="footnote">Joel 4:4.</i> Perhaps the rest of the land of the Philistines, excluding that of these five of their lords,<sup class="footnote-marker">323</sup><i class="footnote">Joshua 13:3.</i> was not given to Israel.<br>Know that the land of Canaan with its boundaries, <i>since it became a nation</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">324</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 9:24.</i> was qualified for Israel, and this was the lot of their inheritance, as it is said, <i>When the Most High gave to the nations their inheritance, when He separated the children of men, He set the borders of the peoples according to the number of the children of Israel</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">325</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 32:8.</i> But at the time of the dispersion of the nations, the Holy One, blessed be He, gave it to Canaan, on account of his being a servant, to keep it for Israel. This is just as a man who deposits for safe-keeping the belongings of the master’s son with his servant until such time as the son will grow up and acquire the belongings as well as the servant. I will explain this yet<sup class="footnote-marker">326</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 2:23.</i> with the help of G-d, exalted be He.

Verse 16



Verse 17



Verse 18



Verse 19



Verse 20



Verse 21

AND UNTO SHEM, TO HIM ALSO WERE CHILDREN BORN. Since Scripture delayed the narration of the generations of Shem and related the generations of his younger brother as if Shem had no children, it therefore says here, <i>to him also</i>.
THE FATHER OF ALL THE CHILDREN OF ‘EBER.’ This means that he was the father of all who dwelled beyond (<i>eber</i>) the Euphrates River, which was the place of Abraham’s family. But it is not possible that <i>Eber</i> in this context be the name of the person who was the father of Peleg<sup class="footnote-marker">327</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 25 here. So too the opinion of Ibn Ezra and R’dak.</i> for why would Scripture connect the children of Eber with Shem [moreso than with any of his other offspring]?
THE BROTHER OF JAPHETH THE ELDER. It is the way of Scripture to record a younger brother beside the oldest of his brothers, and not beside a younger one than himself.<sup class="footnote-marker">328</sup><i class="footnote">See above, 6:10, that Ramban’s opinion is that Noah’s children were born in this order: Japheth, Shem, and Ham. Ramban thus says here that it is customary for Scripture to record a second son (Shem) beside the oldest (Japheth) even though Shem had a younger brother, Ham. Thus Scripture writes, <i>the brother of Japheth the elder</i>, rather than “the elder brother of Ham.”</i> And similarly, we find the verse, <i>Miriam the prophetess, the sister of Aaron</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">329</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 15:20. Even though Moses was younger than Miriam, Scripture records the younger Miriam beside the elder Aaron, rather than say, “the older sister of Moses.”</i> The reason for mentioning this altogether is to state that he [Shem] is the brother of the honorable Japheth, comparable to him in distinction. Scripture thus declares that the reason it delayed telling of his genealogy is not because Ham was more distinguished than he.<br>It appears to me that “the elder” is descriptive of Shem,<sup class="footnote-marker">330</sup><i class="footnote">Ramban, in this final paragraph, sets forth his principle that Shem was really the oldest of the three brothers. The order of their birth was thus: Shem, Japheth and Ham. This is completely unlike the theory of Rashi (5:32; 9:24) who holds that they were born in this order: Japheth, Ham and Shem. R’dak here conforms with Ramban’s theory, as is clear from R’dak’s following words: “The word <i>hagadol (the elder)</i> is descriptive either of Japheth or of Shem. If so, <i>the elder</i> refers to age in years for in my opinion Shem was the oldest of the brothers while, in the opinion of most commentators, Japheth was the oldest. It is also possible to explain <i>the elder</i> as referring to distinction, and it may also be descriptive of either of them.”</i> meaning that he was the older brother of Japheth, as Ham was the youngest of all, even though Scripture mentioned Japheth first. So, likewise, in all places in Scripture, the descriptive noun refers to the subject spoken of, such as: <i>Isaiah the son of Amoz the prophet</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">331</sup><i class="footnote">II Kings 20:1.</i> [the term “the prophet” refers to Isaiah, who is the subject of the narration]; <i>Unto Hobab, the son of Reuel the Midianite, Moses’ father-in-law</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">332</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 10:29.</i> [here, “Moses’ father-in-law” refers back to Hobab]. But Rashi wrote: “<i>The brother of Japheth</i>. It does not state “the brother of Ham” because these two [Shem and Japheth] honored their father whereas Ham put him to shame.” This interpretation also declares that the sense of the verse is that Shem is the brother of the righteous brother, and not the brother of the wicked brother even though he is counted after him.

Chapter 11



Verse 1



Verse 2

AS THEY JOURNEYED FROM THE EAST. Rashi comments: “They journeyed from where they were then dwelling, as it is written above, <i>And their dwelling was from Mesha, as thou goest toward Sephar, unto the mountain of the east</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">333</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 10:30.</i> From there they journeyed to search out for themselves a place that would accomodate them all, but they found none except Shinar.” But this is not correct for this is the account of the children of Shem only, concerning whom it was so said [that they dwelled at “the mountain of the east”], and why should Scripture attribute the dispersion to the descendants of Shem when the children of Japheth and of Ham were more numerous than they? Besides, their habitation in their countries was from Mesha to the mountain of the east,<sup class="footnote-marker">333</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 10:30.</i> and the dispersion of the nations took place before they settled there, for the children of Japheth surely did not come from the isles of the sea<sup class="footnote-marker">334</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 5.</i> to the land of Shinar; rather, it was during the dispersion that <i>G-d scattered them abroad upon the face of all the earth</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">335</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 9 here.</i> and at that time they were settled <i>in their lands, after their nations</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">336</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 10:31.</i><br>And Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra explained that the mountains of Ararat are in the east. [Thus the verse before us which states, <i>as they journeyed from the east</i>, means as they journeyed from the mountains of Ararat.] That which he said is correct for the mountains of Ararat are in the east near Assyria, as it is said, <i>And they escaped into the land of Ararat</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">337</sup><i class="footnote">II Kings 19:37. The reference there is to the sons of Sennacherib of Assyria, who slew their father and fled to the nearby land of Ararat.</i> And when Noah came down from the mountain [upon which the ark had rested],<sup class="footnote-marker">338</sup><i class="footnote">Above 8:4.</i> he and his sons settled in those lands, and when they increased they journeyed from there to this valley called Shinar.<br>According to our Rabbis,<sup class="footnote-marker">339</sup><i class="footnote">Sanhedrin 109a.</i> the men of the dispersion rebelled against their Creator. But those who pursue the plain meaning of Scripture say<sup class="footnote-marker">340</sup><i class="footnote">This opinion is found in R’dak.</i> that their idea was only to be closely united, for Scripture declares their intention, <i>lest we be scattered</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">341</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 4 here.</i> and does not relate any other matter [motive] concerning them. But if it be as those commentators say, then the men of the dispersion were fools for how could one city and one tower suffice for all people of the world? Or perhaps they thought that they would not be fruitful and multiply, as it is written, <i>and the seed of the wicked will be cut off</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">342</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 37:28.</i><br>However, he who knows the meaning of the word “name” — as they said, <i>and we will make for us a name</i><sup class="footnote-marker">341</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 4 here.</i> — will understand their intent and will know the extent of their evil intention in constructing the tower. And then he will understand the whole subject, namely, that theirs was an evil thought, and the punishment that came over them — to be dispersed in their languages and countries — was meted out measure for measure for “they mutilated the shoots” [of faith by seeking to undermine the principle of the Unity]. Thus their sin was comparable to that of their father Adam.<sup class="footnote-marker">343</sup><i class="footnote">See Ramban above, 3:22.</i> Perhaps on account of this the Sages expounded:<sup class="footnote-marker">344</sup><i class="footnote">Bereshith Rabbah 38:12.</i> “<i>And the Eternal came down to see… which the children of men had built</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">345</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 5 here.</i> Said Rabbi Berachyah, ‘[Whose children could they have been but the children of men?] Perhaps the children of donkeys or camels? Rather it means the children of the first man, etc.’” Contemplate further that in the entire subject of the flood, Scripture mentions <i>Elokim</i> (G-d), while in the entire matter of the dispersion it mentions the Tetragrammaton; the flood came on account of the corruption of the land, and the dispersion came because “they mutilated the shoots” of faith and therefore their punishment was meted out by His Great Name. This explains the “coming down”<sup class="footnote-marker">345</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 5 here.</i> and also the Divine measure meted out in Sodom.<sup class="footnote-marker">346</sup><i class="footnote">See Ramban further, 19:24.</i> The student learned [in the mystic lore of the Cabala] will understand.
