Verse 26



Verse 27



Verse 28

AND HARAN DIED IN THE PRESENCE OF HIS FATHER TERAH IN THE LAND OF HIS BIRTH IN UR OF THE CHALDEES. In accordance with the words of our Rabbis, Rashi wrote, “Terah accused his son Abram before Nimrod of having broken his idols, and he cast him into a fiery furnace. Meanwhile Haran waited and said to himself, ‘if Abram proves triumphant I will be on his side, and if Nimrod wins I shall be on his.’ When Abram was saved, they said to Haran, ‘On whose side are you?’ He replied, ‘I am on Abram’s side.’ They therefore cast him into the fiery furnace, and he was burnt to death. It is to this event that the name <i>Ur Kasdim</i> (fire of the Chaldees) alludes. Menachem ben Saruk,<sup class="footnote-marker">347</sup><i class="footnote">Menachem ben Saruk was a great grammarian who lived in the middle of the tenth century in southern Spain. He composed the first dictionary covering the entire field of the Biblical language. His work is called Machbereth (literally, “a joining of words”). Rashi, in his commentary on the Torah and other books of the Bible, made great use of this work.</i> however, explained the word <i>ur</i> as meaning ‘valley.’ So also, <i>Therefore glorify ye the Eternal ‘ba’urim’ (in the valleys)</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">348</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 24:15.</i> and also, <i>‘me’urath’ (the den of) the basilisk</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">349</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 11:8.</i> Every hole or deep cleft may be called <i>ur</i>.” This matter received by our Rabbis through tradition is the truth, and I will elucidate it.<br>Our father Abraham was not born in the land of Chaldaea. His ancestors were descendants of Shem, and Chaldaea and the whole land of Shinar were countries inhabited by the sons of Ham,<sup class="footnote-marker">350</sup><i class="footnote">See above, 10:10-12.</i> and Scripture states, <i>And he told to Abram the ‘Hebrew,’</i><sup class="footnote-marker">351</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 14:13.</i> not Abram the Chaldean. And it is further written, <i>Your fathers dwelt in days of old beyond the river, Terah the father of Abraham, and the father of Nahor</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">352</sup><i class="footnote">Joshua 24:2.</i> the word <i>mei’olam (of old)</i> teaching that his origins were always from there. And again Scripture states, <i>And I took your father Abraham from beyond the river</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">353</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i> 3.</i> Proof of the matter is that we find Nahor [Abraham’s brother] in Haran.<sup class="footnote-marker">354</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 29:4-5.</i> Now if Terah’s place were in Ur of the Chaldees in the land of Shinar and Scripture relates that upon Terah’s going forth from Ur of the Chaldees he took with him only his son Abram, his grandson Lot the son of Haran, and Sarai his daughter-in-law,<sup class="footnote-marker">355</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 31 here.</i> then Nahor was left in the land of Chaldaea, [and yet we find that he was in Haran,<sup class="footnote-marker">354</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 29:4-5.</i> which is in the land of Mesopotamia, as explained further].<br>But the truth of the matter is that the country of the birth of Abraham’s ancestors was the land of Aram, which is beyond the River Euphrates; this was always the habitat of his ancestors. Thus Scripture says concerning the children of Shem, <i>And their dwelling was from Mesha, as thou goest toward Sephar, unto the mountain of the east</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">333</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 10:30.</i> this being a generic name applicable to all their countries, as it is written there, <i>in their land, after their nations</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">336</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 10:31.</i> and again it is written, <i>From Aram Balak bringeth me, the king of Moab from the mountains of the east</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">356</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 23:7.</i> [proving that Aram is in the land of “the mountains of the east”]. Thus it is clear that Abram and his ancestors always lived in the land of Aram. Furthermore, we find in the Talmud<sup class="footnote-marker">357</sup><i class="footnote">Baba Bathra 91a.</i> that Abraham was imprisoned [by Nimrod because he broke the idols] in Cuthah, and that city is not in the land of Chaldaea, for it is written, <i>And the king of Assyria brought men from Babylon, and from Cuthah, and from Avva, and from Hamath</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">358</sup><i class="footnote">II Kings 17:24.</i> and it is further written, <i>And the men of Babylon made Succoth-benoth, and the men of Cuth made Nergal</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">359</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 30.</i> But it would appear that Cuthah is a city beyond the river, in the land of Mesopotamia, for Haran is the name of a city in the land of Mesopotamia, as it is written, <i>And he went to Aram-naharaim</i> [Mesopotamia], <i>unto the city of Nahor</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">360</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 24:10.</i> which is Haran. Furthermore, we have investigated and know it from the word of many students<sup class="footnote-marker">361</sup><i class="footnote">This alludes to the time during the last three years of his life when Ramban lived in the land of Israel and there gathered around him students from nearby countries. It was from these students, who came from the eastern countries, that he sought first-hand knowledge to illumine the problems he had in his commentary. Concerning this fascinating period in the life of Ramban, see his biography, pp. 191-206 in my Hebrew work, pp. 60-65 in the English edition.</i> who lived in that country that Cuthah is a large city between Haran and Assyria, far from the country of Babylon. The distance between it and Haran is about that of a six-day journey. It is, however, included in the term, “beyond the river,”<sup class="footnote-marker">353</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i> 3.</i> because it lies between Mesopotamia and the River Euphrates — which is the border of the land of Israel<sup class="footnote-marker">362</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 15:18.</i> — and <i>the Tigris which goeth towards the east of Assyria</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">363</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 2:14.</i> Thus Terah begot his older sons, Abraham and Nahor, in the area “beyond the river,” the land of his ancestors. He then went with his son Abram to the land of Chaldaea, where his youngest son, Haran, was born. His son Nahor, however, remained “beyond the river,” in the city of Haran. It may be that he was born there or that he came to settle there from Cuthah. This is the meaning of [the verse here which says of Haran], <i>in the land of his birth, in Ur of the Chaldees</i>, since that was the birthplace of Haran alone [among Terah’s children].<br>This matter received through tradition [that Cuthah was the birthplace of Abraham] is also found in a book called The Antiquities of the Nations, as the Rabbi<sup class="footnote-marker">267</sup><i class="footnote">Rabbi Moshe ben Maimon (Rambam or Maimonides). See <i>Seder Bereshith</i>, Note 139.</i> wrote in the Moreh Nebuchim<sup class="footnote-marker">364</sup><i class="footnote">III, 29. Ramban is following Al-Charizi’s translation, and not Ibn Tibbon’s. See notes in my Hebrew commentary, pp. 72-73.</i> that in the book of Egyptian Agriculture it is mentioned that Abraham, who was born<sup class="footnote-marker">365</sup><i class="footnote">“Born.” Ibn Tibbon has, “grew up.”</i> in Cuthah, differed with the opinion of the people who worshipped the sun, and the king put him in prison, but he continued to argue against them for many days. At last the king was afraid that he might corrupt his land and turn the people away from their religion, and so he expelled him to the far land of Canaan, after confiscating all his wealth.<br>Thus in any case it was in this place, the land of Chaldaea, that a miracle — or more exactly a hidden miracle<sup class="footnote-marker">366</sup><i class="footnote">See Ramban further, 17:1, concerning the two kinds of miracles.</i> — was done to our father Abraham, for G-d put it into the heart of that king to save him and not to kill him, and so he released him from prison to go where he desires. It may be that it was an overt miracle,<sup class="footnote-marker">366</sup><i class="footnote">See Ramban further, 17:1, concerning the two kinds of miracles.</i> i.e., that the king threw him into a fiery furnace, and he was saved, as our Rabbis have stated.<sup class="footnote-marker">367</sup><i class="footnote">As mentioned in Rashi, quoted at the beginning of this verse.</i><br>Let not Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra mislead you with his questions,<sup class="footnote-marker">368</sup><i class="footnote">In Verse 26.</i> saying that Scripture has not narrated this wonder, for I will yet give you<sup class="footnote-marker">369</sup><i class="footnote">See Ramban further, 46:15.</i> a reason for the omission and proof of the verity of this and other miracles like it. These peoples, however, did not mention it in their books because they differed with his [the Patriarch’s] opinion, and they thought his miracle was a deed of sorcery, just as was the case with our teacher Moses in his confrontation with the Egyptians at the beginning of his deeds. It is on account of this that Scripture no longer mentions this miracle [of Abraham] for it would have had to mention the words of those who differed with him, as it mentioned the words of the Egyptian magicians, and Abraham’s words were not as openly verified to them as were ultimately the words of our teacher Moses, [which were established by ten clearly revealed miracles]. Thus Scripture says, <i>I am the Eternal that brought thee out of Ur of the Chaldees to give thee this land to inherit it</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">370</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 15:7.</i> for the word <i>hotzeisicha (brought thee out)</i> points to a miracle. It does not say, “that took thee from Ur of the Chaldees;” instead it says, <i>that brought thee out</i>, meaning that He brought out a prisoner from the dungeon<sup class="footnote-marker">371</sup><i class="footnote">See Isaiah 42:7.</i> just as in the verse: <i>that brought thee out from the land of Egypt</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">372</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 20:2.</i> And He said to Abraham, <i>to give thee this land to inherit it</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">370</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 15:7.</i> because from the time that G-d brought him out of Ur of the Chaldees, it was His Will, exalted be He, to make him into a great nation and to give him this land of Canaan. From that day on which Abraham was saved, Terah — his father — and Abraham had in mind to go to the land of Canaan, a distant point far from the land of Chaldaea, out of fear of the king, since Haran, [the city of their inhabitance], was near them [the Chaldeans], and they were one people with one language since Aramaic was their common language. They [Terah and Abraham] wanted to go to a nation where their speech would not be understood by that king and his people. This is the meaning of the verse, <i>And they went forth with them from Ur of the Chaldees, to go into the land of Canaan, and they came unto Haran</i><sup class="footnote-marker">373</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 31 here.</i> where their families and ancestors ever lived, and they settled among them, staying there for many days. It was there that Abraham was commanded to do what he had intended, i.e., to go to the land of Canaan, and so he left his father, who later died there in Haran,<sup class="footnote-marker">374</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 32.</i> his country, and went with his wife and Lot, his brother’s son, to the land of Canaan.<sup class="footnote-marker">375</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 12:5.</i> Thus Scripture says, <i>And I took your father Abraham from beyond the river, and led him throughout all the land of Canaan</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">353</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i> 3.</i> for Abraham was commanded concerning this when he was yet “beyond the river,” and from there G-d took him and led him throughout all the land of Canaan.<br>Now according to the opinion of our Rabbis [that Nimrod threw Abraham into a fiery furnace, the name] <i>Ur Kasdim</i> will be understood as the plain meaning indicates, [namely, “Fires of the Chaldees”], from the same expression: <i>I am warm, I have seen ‘ur’ (the fire).</i><sup class="footnote-marker">376</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 44:16.</i> Scripture thus says, <i>And they went forth with them from Ur of the Chaldees</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">373</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 31 here.</i> even though Terah did not go forth from the fiery furnace. However, since Abram is the main [person of interest, it mentions <i>Ur Kasdim</i> although the name has reference to him alone]. It may be that on account of the miracle the place came to be so called, just as we find, <i>And at Taberah, and at Massah, and at Kibroth-hattaavah</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">377</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 9:22. — These places were so named because of the events that occurred there. See Numbers 11:3, 34. Exodus 17:7.</i> and others. Scripture thus alludes that when Abram went forth from the fiery furnace, they all fled from that country.<br>And the meaning of the verse, <i>Glorify ye the Eternal ‘ba’urim,’</i><sup class="footnote-marker">348</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 24:15.</i> is in my opinion consonant with that which the Rabbis have said [concerning <i>Ur Kasdim</i>, namely, that it means “the Fire of the Chaldees”], for <i>urim</i> are the high mountains on which they make fires and “kindle the flares”<sup class="footnote-marker">378</sup><i class="footnote">Rosh Hashana 22b. The subject there concerns the kindling of flares on the tops of the hills to declare that the day of the New Moon had been declared.</i> to make the new events known quickly in distant places, even as it says [in the second half of the verse]: <i>In the isles of the sea, the name of the Eternal, the G-d of Israel</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">348</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 24:15.</i> The sense of that verse is thus that for the glory of G-d they should let the whole world know the miracle and the wonder which had been done to them. So also, <i>‘Me’urath’ the basilisk</i><sup class="footnote-marker">349</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 11:8.</i> means his [the serpent’s] hole, where his fire and great heat are, just as he is indeed called <i>saraph</i> [the serpent, but literally, “the burning one”]. And I have seen in the Midrash:<sup class="footnote-marker">379</sup><i class="footnote">Pesikta d’Rabbi Kahana, 21.</i> “<i>Arise, ‘uri’ (shine)</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">380</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 60:1.</i> Therefore <i>glorify ye the Eternal ‘ba’urim.’</i><sup class="footnote-marker">348</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 24:15.</i> How do you glorify Him? Rabbi Yeivo bar Kahana said, ‘With these torches such as the lanterns which burn in synagogues<sup class="footnote-marker">381</sup><i class="footnote">This is one of the earliest sources for establishing the religious duty of kindling lights in a synagogue. See my edition of Kithvei Rabbeinu Bechaya, pp. 89-90.</i> in all places, even <i>in the isles of the sea</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">348</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 24:15.</i> to the glory of G-d.’” Thus it is clear that the Rabbis understood the word <i>ba’urim</i> as an expression of fire, in accordance with its simple sense.

Verse 29



Verse 30



Verse 31

AND THEY WENT FORTH WITH THEM FROM UR OF THE CHALDEES. Because Abram was more important than his father and those that followed his counsel and for whose sake they went, Scripture says, <i>And they went forth</i>, [rather than “he went forth”] even though it says at the beginning of the verse, <i>And Terah took</i>. Lot and Sarai, however, went with them to the land of Canaan on account of Abram, for even after Abram separated from his father they went along with him.<sup class="footnote-marker">382</sup><i class="footnote">The Tur concludes: “Thus it should have said, ‘and they walked with <i>him</i>,’ that is with Abram. But out of respect to his father, Scripture ascribes it to both of them.”</i>

Verse 32

AND TERAH DIED IN HARAN. After Abram had left [Haran, as related in the next chapter, and had come to the land of Canaan], Terah remained alive for many years after that.<sup class="footnote-marker">383</sup><i class="footnote">Abram was seventy-five years old when he left Haran (12:4), and Terah was seventy years of age when Abram was born (11:26), making Terah 145 years old at the time Abram left Haran. Terah thus lived for sixty more years as he died at the age of 205 (11:32).</i> Why then does Scripture mention the death of Terah before the departure of Abram? [The answer is that Scripture does so] in order that this matter [of leaving his home during his father’s lifetime] might not become publicized to all, lest people say that Abram did not show a son’s respect to his father and mother<sup class="footnote-marker">384</sup><i class="footnote">“And mother.” Not in our text of Rashi.</i> as he left his father in his old age and went his way. That is why Scripture speaks of Terah as dead. Moreover,<sup class="footnote-marker">385</sup><i class="footnote">“Moreover.” Not in our text of Rashi.</i> for the wicked, even while alive, are called dead. Thus the words of Rashi which are found in Bereshith Rabbah.<sup class="footnote-marker">386</sup><i class="footnote">39:7.</i><br>But I wonder about their words for this is the customary way for Scripture to relate the life of a father, his begetting a son, and his death, and afterwards to begin the narration of the son in all generations. This is the usual manner of Scripture. Noah himself lived yet in the days of Abraham,<sup class="footnote-marker">387</sup><i class="footnote">Noah lived 350 years after the flood (9:28), and the total number of years of all ten generations from Noah to Abraham was less than 300 years. Thus Noah was still alive in the time of Abraham.</i> and his son Shem lived thoughout Abraham’s life span.<sup class="footnote-marker">388</sup><i class="footnote">Shem lived 500 years after the flood (11:11). See also Baba Bathra 121 b: <i>“Jacob saw Shem.”</i></i> Now it is possible that the Rabbis came to conclusion of this Midrash because with respect to Terah, Scripture departed from the format of the entire chapter. Regarding Shem and his descendants, Scripture did not mention their death at all, nor did it total the sum of their years. But here with Terah it again follows the first order it used concerning the longevity of the people from Adam to Noah<sup class="footnote-marker">389</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 5:5-31.</i> and totals up all the days of Terah and mentions his death. In addition, it mentions the place of death as having been in Haran, the same place it had mentioned concerning Abraham, [i.e., that he had gone there, in Verse 31]. That is why the Rabbis expounded that all this was to make it easily apparent that Abraham was there with Terah when he died. Moreover, because Scripture had already begun the subject of Abraham and told how he had gone forth with his father <i>from Ur of the Chaldees to go into the land of Canaan</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">390</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 31 here.</i> the Rabbis found it difficult to understand why Scripture did not systematically arrange Terah’s life and death, and write it chronologically. [That is why they made the aforementioned interpretation.]<br>And as for that which the Rabbis also said in Bereshith Rabbah<sup class="footnote-marker">386</sup><i class="footnote">39:7.</i> — “First you interpret<sup class="footnote-marker">390</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 31 here.</i> that the wicked, even while alive, are called dead” — this too I find surprising, for the Sages<sup class="footnote-marker">391</sup><i class="footnote">Bereshith Rabbah 34:4; 38:18.</i> have already deduced from the verse,<sup class="footnote-marker">392</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 15:15.</i> “<i>And thou shalt come to thy fathers in peace</i>. [His father was an idolater, and yet G-d informed Abraham that after death he would go to him! Clearly the verse teaches you] that He announced to Abraham that his father would have a portion in the World to Come.” Perhaps the intent of the Rabbis was that Terah repented at the time of death, but he lived all his days in wickedness and therefore was called “dead.” In the words of Rashi:<sup class="footnote-marker">392</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 15:15.</i> “Scripture teaches you that Terah did repentance at the time of death.” Perhaps it may be that our Sages, of blessed memory, say<sup class="footnote-marker">393</sup><i class="footnote">Sanhedrin 104a.</i> that Terah has a portion in the World to Come by virtue of his son. And that was the announcement, for Abraham did not know it until he was informed of it at the time G-d told him, <i>And thou shalt come to thy fathers in peace</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">392</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 15:15.</i> And so I found in a Midrash:<sup class="footnote-marker">394</sup><i class="footnote">Possibly Ramban refers to Vayikra Rabbah at the beginning of Chapter 7.</i> “All kinds of wood were valid for use in the altar fire save only the wood of the olive and the vine,<sup class="footnote-marker">395</sup><i class="footnote">Tamid 2:3. One of the reasons stated for this law is that it maintains the cultivation of <i>Eretz Yisrael</i>.</i> for since oil and wine were offered upon the altar, the fruits save the trees. And so we find in the case of Abraham that he saved Terah, as it is said, <i>And thou shalt come to thy fathers in peace</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">392</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 15:15.</i><br>Lech Lecha

Chapter 12



Verse 1

AND THE ETERNAL SAID UNTO ABRAHAM ‘LECH LECHA’ (GET THEE OUT). This means, “For your own benefit and for your own good. And there I will make of you a great nation whilst here you will not merit the privilege of having children.” Thus the language of Rashi.<br>Now there is no need for it<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">Ramban’s intent is that it is unnecessary to explain the word <i>lecha</i> (literally, “to you”) as meaning “for your own benefit” for it is merely the idiomatic usage of the Hebrew language, as explained further in the text.</i> for such is the normal expression of the Hebrew language as in the verses: <i>The rain is over and gone ‘lo’;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">Song of Songs 2:11. Literally, “gone to itself.”</i> <i>I will get ‘li’ unto the great men;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">Jeremiah 5:5. Literally, “get to me.”</i> <i>Rise up, and get ‘lachem’ over the brook Zered;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 2:13. Literally, “and get to you.”</i> and many similar examples. Our Rabbis, however, have made a Midrash — (a homiletical interpretation) — concerning the verses [addressed to Moses] which state, <i>And thou shalt make ‘lecha’ an ark of wood</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 10:1. Literally, “make to thee.” The Midrash of the Rabbis is as follows: “Here the verse states, <i>And ‘thou’ shalt make an ark</i>, meaning Moses, but in Exodus (25:10) it states, <i>And ‘they’ shall make an ark!</i> This teaches us that the people of a community are commanded to do the work of a Torah-scholar who resides in their midst.” (Yoma 72b.)</i> <i>and Make ‘lecha’ two trumpets of silver</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 10:2. Literally, “make to thee.” The Rabbis commented: “As though it were possible, I would prefer it to be from that which is thine to that which is theirs.” (Yoma 3b.)</i> since it was not his work and it would have been proper for these verses to be stated in the same way as that concerning the tabernacle, i.e., <i>And thou shalt make the tabernacle</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 26:1.</i>
OUT OF THY COUNTRY, AND FROM THY BIRTHPLACE. Rashi wrote,<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">In Verse 2 here.</i> “But had he not already departed from there together with his father and reached as far as Haran?<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 11:31.</i> But thus, in effect, did the Holy One, blessed be He, say to him, ‘Go still further away from thy father’s house.’”<br/>And Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra explained the verse as follows: “And G-d had already said to Abram, ‘Get thee out of thy country,’ since this command came to him when he was still in Ur of the Chaldees, and there He commanded him to leave his country, his birthplace and his father’s house, in which he was.”<br/>But this is not correct, for if so, it would follow that Abram was the central figure in the journey from his father’s house by command of G-d, while Terah his father voluntarily went with him. Yet Scripture says, <i>And Terah took Abram his son</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 11:31.</i> which teaches us that Abram followed his father and that it was by his counsel that Abram went forth from Ur of the Chaldees to go to the land of Canaan! Furthermore, [according to Ibn Ezra, who says that the above command came to Abram when he was still in Ur of the Chaldees], the verse stating, <i>And I took your father Abraham from beyond the river and led him throughout all the land of Canaan</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">Joshua 24:3.</i> should have stated, “And I took your father from Ur of the Chaldees and led him throughout all the land of Canaan,” for it was from there that he was taken, and it was there that he was given this command. In addition, the following difficulty may be put to Rashi and Ibn Ezra: when Abraham commanded Eliezer to get a wife for his son, he said to him, <i>‘But thou shalt go unto my country and to my birthplace,’</i><sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 24:4. The word <i>moladeti</i>, generally translated “my kindred,” connotes, according to Ramban, both “my birthplace” and “my family.” This is made clear further on in the text.</i> and he went to <i>Aram-naharaim, to the city of Nahor</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 10. Aram-naharaim is Mesopotamia. See Ramban above, 11:28.</i> If so, that is his “country” and his “birthplace!” And there, Scripture further says [when Eliezer recounts Abraham’s charge to him], <i>But thou shalt go unto my father’s house and to my family</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 38.</i> thus clearly indicating that there (in Mesopotamia) were his father’s house and his family which is “his kindred.” This is not as Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra erred in interpreting, “<i>Unto my country</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 24:4. The word <i>moladeti</i>, generally translated “my kindred,” connotes, according to Ramban, both “my birthplace” and “my family.” This is made clear further on in the text.</i> Haran; <i>and to my birthplace</i>, Ur of the Chaldees.” Now since Ibn Ezra says here that in Ur of the Chaldees it was said to Abraham, <i>Get thee out of thy country, and from thy kindred, and from thy father’s house</i>, Abraham would thus have many countries!<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">Ramban points out the following contradiction in Ibn Ezra’s interpretation: Here in our verse he says that the command was given to Abraham in Ur of the Chaldees. Accordingly, Ur of the Chaldees is Abraham’s “country” for the verse says, <i>from thy country</i>. And further (Chapter 24, Verse 4) Ibn Ezra interprets <i>my country</i> as meaning “Haran,” which is Mesopotamia! Thus Ibn Ezra has “many countries” assigned to Abraham.</i> But the essential principle you already know from what we have written in the preceding <i>Seder</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 11:28.</i> namely, that Haran is Abraham’s country, and there is his birthplace, it having always been his father’s country, and there Abraham was commanded to leave them. In Bereshith Rabbah,<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">39:8. The Rabbis here interpret the double expression of the verse as signifying two departures which Abraham is to make: one from Mesopotamia generally, and one from his city in particular.</i> the Rabbis similarly say “<i>Lech lecha:</i> one departure from Aram-naharaim, and one from Aram-nahor.”<br/>The reason for mentioning <i>out of thy country, and from thy birthplace, and from thy father’s house</i> is that it is difficult for a person to leave the country wherein he dwells, where he has his friends and companions. This is true all the more if this be his native land, and all the more if his whole family is there. Hence it became necessary to say to Abraham that he leave all for the sake of his love of the Holy One, blessed be He.<br/>UNTO THE LAND THAT I WILL SHOW THEE. He wandered and went about <i>from nation to nation, from kingdom to another people</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 105:13.</i> until he came to the land of Canaan, where He said to him, <i>Unto thy seed will I give this land</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 7 here.</i> Then the promise, <i>Unto the land that I will show thee</i>, was fulfilled, and Abraham tarried and settled there. The verse which states, <i>And they went forth to go into the land of Canaan</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 5.</i> means that he was not heading for Canaan for the purpose of settling there since he did not as yet know that he had been commanded concerning this land. Rather, the righteous one<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">Abraham.</i> set his goal towards the land of Canaan for that was his intention as well as that of his father when they originally set forth from Ur of the Chaldees. This is the reason why Abraham later said, <i>And it came to pass, when G-d caused me to wander from my father’s house:</i><sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 20:13.</i> he was indeed <i>gone astray like a lost sheep</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 119:176.</i><br/>It is possible to say that Abraham knew from the first that the land of Canaan was “the inheritance of the Eternal,” destined that His special Providence be bestowed upon it, and he believed that the Divine promise, <i>Unto the land that I will show thee</i>, alluded to the land of Canaan either in its entirety or to one of all those lands [which together comprise Canaan]. He set his direction towards the land of Canaan generally for [he was certain that] there was the land which He would indeed show him.
UNTO THE LAND THAT I WILL SHOW THEE. He wandered and went about <i>from nation to nation, from kingdom to another people</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 105:13.</i> until he came to the land of Canaan, where He said to him, <i>Unto thy seed will I give this land</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 7 here.</i> Then the promise, <i>Unto the land that I will show thee</i>, was fulfilled, and Abraham tarried and settled there. The verse which states, <i>And they went forth to go into the land of Canaan</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 5.</i> means that he was not heading for Canaan for the purpose of settling there since he did not as yet know that he had been commanded concerning this land. Rather, the righteous one<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">Abraham.</i> set his goal towards the land of Canaan for that was his intention as well as that of his father when they originally set forth from Ur of the Chaldees. This is the reason why Abraham later said, <i>And it came to pass, when G-d caused me to wander from my father’s house:</i><sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 20:13.</i> he was indeed <i>gone astray like a lost sheep</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 119:176.</i><br>It is possible to say that Abraham knew from the first that the land of Canaan was “the inheritance of the Eternal,” destined that His special Providence be bestowed upon it, and he believed that the Divine promise, <i>Unto the land that I will show thee</i>, alluded to the land of Canaan either in its entirety or to one of all those lands [which together comprise Canaan]. He set his direction towards the land of Canaan generally for [he was certain that] there was the land which He would indeed show him.

Verse 2

AND BE THOU A BLESSING. You will be the blessing by whom people will be blessed, saying, “G-d make thee as Abraham.” To this He added that <i>all families of the earth</i><sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 3 here.</i> will cite him in blessing, not just the people of his country alone. It may be that the expression, <i>And in thee shall all the families of the earth be blessed</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 3 here.</i> means that they will all be blessed on his account.<br>Now this portion of Scripture is not completely elucidated. What reason was there that the Holy One, blessed be He, should say to Abraham, “Leave your country, and I will do you good in a completely unprecedented measure,” without first stating that Abraham worshipped G-d or that he was <i>a righteous man</i>, [and] <i>perfect?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 6:9. As was the case with Noah.</i> Or it should state as a reason for his leaving the country that the very journey to another land constituted an act of seeking <i>the nearness of G-d</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 73:28. This may indeed be an illuminating personal remark shedding light on Ramban’s journey, towards the end of his life, to the Land of Israel; the very journey constituted to him a religious experience of “seeking the nearness of G-d.”</i> The custom of Scripture is to state, “<i>Walk before Me</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 17:1.</i> and hearken to My voice, and I will do good unto you,” as is the case with David<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote">See I Kings 2:4.</i> and Solomon,<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 3:13-14.</i> as well as throughout the Torah: <i>If ye walk in My statute;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 26:3.</i> <i>And it shall come to pass, if thou shalt hearken diligently unto the voice of the Eternal thy G-d</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 28:1.</i> And in the case of Isaac, it says, <i>For My servant Abraham’s sake</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 26:24.</i> But there is no reason for G-d to promise [Abraham a reward merely] for his leaving the country.<br>However, the reason [for G-d’s promising Abraham this reward] is that the people of Ur of the Chaldees did him much evil on account of his belief in the Holy One, blessed be He, and he fled from them to go to the land of Canaan, tarrying for a time at Haran, whereupon the Eternal told him to leave these places as well and to fulfill his original intention that his worship be dedicated to Him alone and that he call upon people [for the worhip of] the Name of the Eternal in the Chosen Land. There He would make his name great, and these nations would bless themselves by him, not as they treated him in Ur of the Chaldees, where they abused and cursed him, put him in prison or in the fiery furnace. He further told Abraham that He will bless those who bless him, and if some individual will curse him, he will be cursed in turn.<br>This then is the meaning of this portion of Scripture. The Torah, however, did not want to deal at length with the opinions of idol worshippers and explain the matter between him and the Chaldeans in the subject of faith, just as it dealt briefly with the matter of the generation of Enosh<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 4:26. See also above in <i>Seder Noach</i>, Note 280.</i> and their thesis concerning the idol-worship which they instituted.

Verse 3



Verse 4



Verse 5



Verse 6

AND ABRAM PASSED THROUGH THE LAND. I will tell you a principle by which you will understand all the coming portions of Scripture concerning Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob. It is indeed a great matter which our Rabbis mentioned briefly, saying:<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote">Tanchuma <i>Lech Lecha</i>, 9.</i> “Whatever has happened to the patriarchs is a sign to the children.” It is for this reason that the verses narrate at great length the account of the journeys of the patriarchs, the digging of the wells, and other events. Now someone may consider them unnecessary and of no useful purpose, but in truth they all serve as a lesson for the future: when an event happens to any one of the three patriarchs, that which is decreed to happen to his children can be understood.<br>Concerning all decisions of “the guardians [angels],”<sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote">Daniel 4:14.</i> know that when they proceed from a potential decree to a symbolic act, the decree will in any case be effected. It is for this reason that the prophets often perform some act in conjunction with the prophecies, just as Jeremiah commanded Baruch his disciple, <i>And it shall be, when thou hast made an end of reading this book, that thou shalt bind a stone to it, and cast it into the midst of the Euphrates, and thou shalt say: Thus shall Babylon sink</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote">Jeremiah 51:63-64.</i> Likewise is the matter of Elisha when he put his arm on the bow [held by Joash, King of Israel]: <i>And Elisha said, Shoot. And he shot. And he said, The Eternal’s arrow of victory, even the arrow of victory against Aram</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote">II Kings 13:17.</i> And it is further stated there, <i>And the man of G-d was wroth with him, and said, Thou shouldst have smitten five or six times; then hadst thou smitten Aram till thou hadst consumed it whereas now thou shalt smite Aram but thrice</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 19.</i> It is for this reason that the Holy One, blessed be He, caused Abraham to take possession of the Land and symbolically did to him all that was destined to happen in the future to his children. Understand this principle. Now, with the help of G-d, I will begin to explain in detail the subject matter of the verses.<br><i>And Abram passed through the land unto the place of Shechem</i>. This is the city of Shechem for such was the name of this place,<sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote">Ramban differs with Ibn Ezra’s comment that the name Shechem was non-existent in the days of Abraham but is used here because Moses called it by the name by which it was known in his time.</i> and Shechem the son of Hamor<sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 34:2.</i> was called by the name of his city. Now Rashi wrote, “He entered it <i>unto the place of Shechem</i> in order to pray on behalf of Jacob’s sons when they would come grieved from the field.”<sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 34:7. In our text of Rashi: “when they would come to fight against Shechem.”</i> This is correct. And I add that Abraham took possession of this place at the very beginning, even before the land was given to him.<sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote">As told later in Verse 7. His taking possession of Shechem is stated in the preceding Verse 6.</i> It was thus hinted to him that his children would first conquer this place<sup class="footnote-marker">42</sup><i class="footnote">Reference is to the capturing of the city by the sons of Jacob. See further, 34:25.</i> before they would merit it and before the guilt of the dwellers of the land was full<sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 15:16.</i> to warrant their exile therefrom. It is for this reason that the verse here states, <i>And the Canaanite was then in the land</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote">He took possession of this place even though the Canaanite was yet in the land. (Tur.)</i> And when the Holy One, blessed be He, gave him the land by His Word, Abraham journeyed from there and pitched his tent between Beth-el and Ai for this was the place that Joshua captured first.<sup class="footnote-marker">45</sup><i class="footnote">In battle. (Joshua 8:1-24.) The capture of Jericho earlier was effected by a miracle.</i><br>It is possible that Scripture mentions, <i>And the Canaanite was then in the land</i>, to teach us concerning the substance of this chapter, i.e., to state that Abram came into the land of Canaan, but G-d did not show him the land He had promised him. He passed to the place of Shechem while the Canaanite, <i>that bitter and impetuous nation</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">46</sup><i class="footnote">Habakkuk 1:6.</i> was yet in the land, and Abram feared him. Therefore he did not build an altar to G-d. But when he came to the vicinity of Shechem at the oak of Moreh, G-d appeared to him and gave him the land, and as a result his fear departed from him for he was already assured in <i>the land that I will show thee</i>, and then he built an altar to G-d in order to worship Him openly.<br>Now <i>eilon Moreh</i> (the oak of Moreh) is in the vicinity of Shechem and is also called <i>eilonei Moreh</i>, as it is written <i>over against Gilgal, beside ‘eilonei Moreh.’</i><sup class="footnote-marker">47</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 11:30.</i> There in Shechem, near the Jordan, are Mount Gerizim and Mount Ebal, where the Israelites arrived at the beginning of their entrance into the land.<sup class="footnote-marker">48</sup><i class="footnote">Sotah 36 a: “On the day Israel crossed the Jordan, they came to Mount Gerizim and Mount Ebal.”</i> <i>Eilonei Mamre</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">49</sup><i class="footnote">“The oaks of Mamre.” (Genesis, 18:1.)</i> however, is a place in the land of Hebron,<sup class="footnote-marker">50</sup><i class="footnote">As is clearly stated: <i>Mamre… the city of Arba which is Hebron</i>. (<i>Ibid.</i>, 35:27.)</i> far from the Jordan.<br>Know that wherever Scripture states, <i>eilonei Mamre</i>, the name Mamre is on account of an Amorite by that name to whom the place belonged, just as it says, <i>And he dwelt at the oaks of Mamre the Amorite, brother of Eshkol and brother of Aner</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 14:13.</i> and wherever it says, <i>eilon moreh</i> or <i>eilonei moreh</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">52</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 11:30.</i> the places were so called on account of a man by the name of Moreh, but he was a Canaanite from <i>the land of the Canaanites, who abide in the plains</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">53</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i> The end of this verse reads: <i>beside the oaks of Moreh</i>. From this Ramban derives the fact that Moreh was a Canaanite, unlike Mamre who was an Amorite.</i> When Scripture mentions Mamre alone, it means the name of a city, just as it is said: <i>And Jacob came unto Isaac his father unto Mamre, the city of Arba, which is Hebron;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">54</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 35:27.</i> <i>Before Mamre which is Hebron</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">55</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 23:19.</i> The man to whom the oaks belonged was called after the name of the city. A similar case is that of Shechem the son of Hamor, who was called Shechem after the name of the city Shechem.<br>In Bereshith Rabbah<sup class="footnote-marker">56</sup><i class="footnote">42:14.</i> it is said, “In the opinion of Rabbi Yehudah, Mamre is the name of a place, and in the opinion of Rabbi Nechemyah, it is the name of a person.”

Verse 7

The sense of the expression, <i>And there he built an altar unto the Eternal, who appeared unto him</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">57</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 7 here.</i> is that he gave praise to the <i>Glorious Name</i><sup class="footnote-marker">58</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 28:58.</i> and offered unto Him a sacrifice of thanksgiving for His having appeared to him. Until now G-d had not appeared to him neither in a <i>mar’eh</i> nor in a <i>machzeh</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">59</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Mar’eh</i> and <i>Machzeh</i> are terms for different degrees of prophetic vision. See Ramban further, 15:1. See also Moreh Nebuchim, II, 41-5, for full discussion of these terms and other prophetic experiences.</i> Rather, the command, <i>Get thee out of thy country</i>, was said to him in a nocturnal dream or through <i>Ruach Hakodesh</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">60</sup><i class="footnote">Literally, “The Holy Spirit.” See <i>ibid.</i>, Chapter 45, beginning: “second degree of prophecy.”</i> It is possible that the expression, <i>Who appeared unto him</i>, alludes to the mystery of the sacrifice. The one enlightened [in the mysteries of the Torah] will understand.

Verse 8

AND HE CALLED UPON THE NAME OF THE ETERNAL. Onkelos explained it as meaning that he prayed there, just as in the verse, <i>I called upon Thy name, O Eternal, out of the lowest dungeon</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">61</sup><i class="footnote">Lamentations 3:55.</i><br>The correct interpretation is that Abraham loudly proclaimed the name of the Eternal there before the altar, informing people of Him and of His Divine essence. In Ur of the Chaldees he taught people but they refused to listen. Now, however, that he had come to the land concerning which he had been promised, <i>And I will bless them that bless thee</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">62</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 3 here.</i> he became accustomed to teach and to proclaim the Deity. Scripture likewise tells of Isaac — when he went to the valley of Gerar where he was promised, <i>Fear not, for I am with thee</i><sup class="footnote-marker">63</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 26:24.</i> — that he built an altar there <i>and invoked the name of the Eternal</i><sup class="footnote-marker">64</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 25.</i> since he had come to a new place where they had not heard of His fame or seen His glory, and he proclaimed His glory among these nations.<sup class="footnote-marker">65</sup><i class="footnote">See Isaiah 66:19.</i> Now a similar statement is not made concerning Jacob, [i.e., that he proclaimed the name of the Eternal before the peoples of the land of Canaan], for since he begot many children — all of whom were worshippers of G-d — and he had a great community, which was called “the congregation of Israel,”<sup class="footnote-marker">66</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 12:3, <i>et al.</i></i> it was through them that the Faith was proclaimed and became known to all people. Besides, the Faith had been proclaimed throughout the entire land of Canaan since the days of his ancestors. In Bereshith Rabbah<sup class="footnote-marker">67</sup><i class="footnote">39:24.</i> the Rabbis similarly say, “<i>And he called upon the name of the Eternal</i>. This teaches us that he caused the name of the Holy One, blessed be He, to be in the mouth of all people.”

Verse 9

TOWARDS THE SOUTH. Rabbeinu Shlomo [Rashi] wrote, “To go to the southern part of the land of Israel, which is in the territory of the sons of Judah who took their portion in the south of the land of Israel.” This was also to happen to Abraham’s offspring in the future, as it is said, <i>Judah shall go up</i><sup class="footnote-marker">68</sup><i class="footnote">Judges 1:2.</i> first.

Verse 10

AND THERE WAS A FAMINE IN THE LAND. Now Abraham went down to Egypt on account of the famine to dwell there in order to keep himself alive in the days of the drought, but the Egyptians oppressed him for no reason [and attempted] to take his wife. The Holy One, blessed be He, avenged their cause with great plagues, and brought him forth from there <i>with cattle, with silver, and with gold</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">69</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 13:2.</i> and Pharaoh even commanded his men to escort them from the land.<sup class="footnote-marker">70</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 20 here.</i> He thereby alluded to Abraham that his children would go down to Egypt on account of the famine to dwell there in the land, and the Egyptians would do them evil and take the women<sup class="footnote-marker">71</sup><i class="footnote">Shemoth Rabbah 1:22. See also following note.</i> from them, just as Pharaoh said, <i>And every daughter ye shall save alive</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">72</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 1:22. They were to be saved alive for unchaste purposes.</i> but the Holy One, blessed be He, would avenge their cause with great plagues until He would bring them forth with silver and gold, sheep and oxen, very rich in cattle, with the Egyptians pressuring to send them out of the land.<sup class="footnote-marker">73</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 12:33.</i> Nothing was lacking in all the events that happened to the patriarch that would not occur to the children.<br>The Rabbis have explained this subject in Bereshith Rabbah:<sup class="footnote-marker">74</sup><i class="footnote">40:8.</i> “Rabbi Pinchas said in the name of Rabbi Oshaya that the Holy One, blessed be He, said to Abraham, ‘Go forth and tread out a path for your children!’ Thus you find that whatever is written concerning Abraham is also written concerning his children. In connection with Abraham it is written, <i>And there was a famine in the land;</i> in connection with Israel, it is written <i>For these two years hath the famine been in the land</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">75</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 45:6.</i><br>Know that Abraham our father unintentionally committed a great sin by bringing his righteous wife to a stumbling-block of sin on account of his fear for his life. He should have trusted that G-d would save him and his wife and all his belongings for G-d surely has the power to help and to save. His leaving the Land, concerning which he had been commanded from the beginning, on account of the famine, was also a sin he committed, for in famine G-d would redeem him from death.<sup class="footnote-marker">76</sup><i class="footnote">See Job 5:20.</i> It was because of this deed that the exile in the land of Egypt at the hand of Pharaoh was decreed for his children.<sup class="footnote-marker">77</sup><i class="footnote">See my Hebrew commentary, pp. 79-80, for sources and differing opinions on the view of Ramban expressed in this paragraph.</i> In the place of justice, there is wickedness<sup class="footnote-marker">78</sup><i class="footnote">See Ecclesiastes 3:16.</i> and sin.

Verse 11

BEHOLD NOW, I KNOW, ETC. 13. SAY, I PRAY, THOU ART MY SISTER. I do not know why Abraham was more fearful for her now than before. And if we say, as Rashi explains, that it was because the Egyptians were black and repulsive, now, to Abimelech, king of the Philistines, he also said so,<sup class="footnote-marker">79</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 20:2.</i> he as well as Isaac,<sup class="footnote-marker">80</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 26:7.</i> who lived in that land by command of G-d.<sup class="footnote-marker">81</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 3.</i> Perhaps the Canaanites in that generation were steeped in idolatry but restrained from unchastity more than the Egyptians and the Philistines. But this is not correct. It is possible that Abraham and Sarah had no fear until they came into a royal city for it was their custom to bring the king a very beautiful woman and to slay her husband through some charge they would contrive against him.<br>It appears to me correct that such was their procedure from the time they left Haran. At every place he would say, “She is my sister,” for so Abraham said, <i>And it came to pass, when G-d caused me to wander from my father’s house</i>, etc.<sup class="footnote-marker">82</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 20:13.</i> Scripture, however, mentions it only concerning those places where something happened to them on account of it. Thus Abraham now alerted Sarah as he had charged her from the beginning. Isaac, on the other hand, was not afraid in his country and in his city. Only when he came to the land of the Philistines did he adopt his father’s way.<br>He [Abraham] said, <i>That it may be well with me for thy sake, and that my soul live because of thee</i>, meaning “as long as we are strangers in this land, until the famine will pass,” for Abraham came to live in the land of Egypt on account of the famine. When the famine passes, he would return to the land concerning which he had been commanded and which G-d had given to him and his children. He thus thought that they [he and his wife] would live through the famine and that relief and succor will come to them from G-d enabling them to return, or that it may be possible for them to flee to the land of Canaan when they<sup class="footnote-marker">83</sup><i class="footnote">“They” are the Egyptians. They will no longer guard them for they will consider them permanent settlers in the land. Then they (Abraham and Sarah) will be able to flee the country and return to the land of Canaan.</i> will give them up.<br>Now Rashi wrote, “ <i>‘Hinei na’ (Behold now), I know</i>. A Midrash Agada:<sup class="footnote-marker">84</sup><i class="footnote">A Midrash by that name. See Buber’s edition of this Midrash, p. 27.</i> Until now he had not perceived her beauty on account of her<sup class="footnote-marker">85</sup><i class="footnote">In our text of Rashi: “on account of the modesty of both of them.” The Midrash Agada ascribes the modesty to Abraham.</i> modesty. Now, however, [he became cognizant of it] through an event.<sup class="footnote-marker">86</sup><i class="footnote">Wading through a stream, he saw the reflection of her beauty in the water. (Midrash Agada.)</i> Another interpretation is that because of the exertion of travelling a person usually becomes uncomely, but she [Sarah] has retained her beauty. Still the plain sense of the text is this: ‘Behold, now the time has come to be anxious because of your beauty. I have long known that you are a woman of beautiful appearance, but now we are travelling among black people, brethren of the Ethiopians, who have never been accustomed to see a beautiful woman.’ A similar example [where the Hebrew word <i>na</i> does not denote a request, as it usually does, but means “now”] is found in the verse, <i>Behold ‘na’ (now), my lords, turn aside, I pray you</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">87</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 19:2. The Hebrew reads, <i>hinei na adonai suru na</i>. Now since the request is covered by the second <i>na (suru na — turn aside, I pray you)</i>, the first <i>na</i> (at the beginning of the expression) can no longer mean a request; rather it means “now.”</i> All this is the language of the Rabbi [Rashi].<br>This Midrash concerning the modesty between Abraham and Sarah is traditional and it has been adjoined to the verse, but there is no need for all these matters. The word <i>na</i> [<i>hinei na — behold now</i>] does not indicate only a newly arisen matter; it may be used with reference to anything which is presently in existence for it is a statement alluding to the present state of things. <i>Behold now I know</i> — from then until now — <i>that thou art a woman of beautiful appearance</i>. Of similar meaning is the verse, <i>Behold ‘na’ (now), the Eternal hath restrained me from having children</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">88</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 16:2.</i> meaning from my youth until this day. Likewise is the verse, <i>Behold ‘na’ (now), I have two daughters</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">89</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 19:8.</i> for they were not born to him now. All [verses containing this expression] are to be interpreted in like manner.<br>It would seem from the simple meaning of the verses that Sarah did not obligate herself to say so, [i.e., that she is Abraham’s sister], but when the Egyptians, who were wicked and sinners exceedingly,<sup class="footnote-marker">90</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 13:13.</i> saw her <i>and they praised her to Pharaoh</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">91</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 15 here.</i> she was taken to his house. They did not ask them at all whether she is his wife or his sister, and she remained silent and did not tell them that she is his wife. It was Abraham himself who told them that she is his sister, and therefore they did well by him for her sake.<sup class="footnote-marker">92</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 16.</i> This is the intent of the verse quoting Pharaoh, which says, <i>What is this that thou hadst done unto me? Why didst thou not tell me that she was thy wife?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">93</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 18.</i> He [Pharaoh] accused him for when he saw the princes of Pharaoh taking her, he should have told Pharaoh that she is his wife. Again, he accused him for saying afterwards to the princes and the household of Pharaoh that she is his sister.<sup class="footnote-marker">94</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 19.</i> But he did not at all accuse the woman for it is not proper that she contradict her husband, the suitable thing being for her to remain silent.

Verse 12



Verse 13



Verse 14



Verse 15

AND THE PRINCES OF PHARAOH SAW HER. The purport<sup class="footnote-marker">95</sup><i class="footnote">Ramban is aiming to answer the following question: In the preceding verse it says, <i>And the Egyptians saw the woman</i>. Why does it say here again, <i>And the princes of Pharaoh saw her?</i></i> thereof is that when the Egyptians saw her they said, “This one is worthy of the great princes,” and so they brought her before them. But they were also afraid of touching her for due to her great beauty, they knew that the king would desire her exceedingly. “<i>And they praised her</i> among themselves saying, ‘This one is worthy of the king.’” Thus the language of Rashi.<br>This is in accordance with the opinion of Onkelos who says, “And they praised her <i>for</i> Pharaoh.”<sup class="footnote-marker">96</sup><i class="footnote">Meaning that they praised her among themselves by saying that she is suitable <i>for</i> Pharaoh.</i> Or it may be that they praised her to the king himself, and he sent for her and took her.

Verse 16



Verse 17

BECAUSE OF SARAI ABRAM’s WIFE. This means that because of the wrong done to Sarah, as well as to Abraham, and the merit of both of them, these great plagues came upon Pharaoh and his house.

Verse 18

AND PHARAOH CALLED ABRAM. It is possible that when the plagues suddenly came upon him and his house at the very time Sarah was taken to his house, he thought to himself, <i>What is this that G-d hath done unto us?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">97</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 42:28.</i> And so he asked her, and she told him that she is Abraham’s wife. For this reason he called Abraham and accused him. Or it may be, as our Rabbis say,<sup class="footnote-marker">98</sup><i class="footnote">Bereshith Rabbah 41:2. It is also mentioned in Rashi.</i> that Pharaoh was smitten with a certain skin disease which is aggravated by intimacy with a woman. Therefore he suspected that perhaps she is Abraham’s wife, and so he said to him with uncertainty, <i>What is this that thou hast done unto me</i>?, in order to draw the truth from him. Were she his sister, he would say, “Indeed, she is my sister.” And Pharaoh further said to him, <i>Now therefore behold thy wife, take her, and go thy way</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">94</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 19.</i> He said this in order to see what he would say, and now he would answer his reproof. But Abraham remained silent and did not answer him a word out of his great fear. Then Pharaoh understood that she is his wife as he had suspected, and then Pharaoh commanded his men to send him away.

Verse 19

SO THAT I TOOK HER TO BE MY WIFE. The meaning thereof is that it was Pharaoh’s intention that she be his regal wife, not just his concubine. Pharaoh mentioned this to Abraham so that he should confess to him if she is his sister, as I have explained.

Chapter 13



Verse 1

HE, AND HIS WIFE, AND ALL THAT HE HAD. The purport thereof is to let us know that they did not rob him of any of all the great gifts they gave him on account of Sarah who was to be for the king. They did not say, “You have tricked us, and the gift was given by mistake.” This was a miraculous event.

Verse 2



Verse 3



Verse 4



Verse 5



Verse 6



Verse 7

AND THERE WAS A QUARREL. Rashi wrote, “Because Lot’s shepherds grazed their cattle in other people’s fields, Abram’s shepherds rebuked them for this act of robbery, but they replied, ‘The land has been given to Abram, and he has no [son as an] heir, and so Lot will be his heir. Hence this is not robbery.’ Scripture however states, <i>And the Canaanite and the Perrizite abode then in the land</i>, so that Abram was not yet the legitimate owner.” This is a Midrash of our Rabbis.<sup class="footnote-marker">99</sup><i class="footnote">Bereshith Rabbah 41:6.</i><br>But I wonder: The gift of the Land declared to Abram was for <i>his</i> children, as it is said above, <i>Unto thy seed will I give this land</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">100</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 12:7.</i> so how can Lot inherit it? Perhaps the shepherds heard of the gift and they mistook its meaning, for Scripture states that in the meantime, the land belonged neither to Abram nor to Lot. Accordingly, the verse stating at the outset, <i>for their possessions were great</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">101</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 6 here.</i> intended to say that because of their extensive possessions, the land could not support them, and Lot’s shepherds therefore found it necessary to bring their cattle into fields that had owners. This was the cause of the quarrel.<br>By way of the plain meaning of Scripture the quarrel concerned the pasture as the land could not support them both. When Abram’s cattle were grazing in the pasture, Lot’s shepherds would come into their territory and graze their cattle there. Now Abram and Lot were both strangers and sojourners in the land. Abram, therefore, feared that the Canaanite and the Perrizite, who inhabit the land, might hear of the abundance of their cattle, [whose great number was made apparent when Lot’s shepherds encroached on Abram’s land, thereby combining the flocks], and drive them out of the land or slay them by sword and take their cattle and wealth since the mastery of the land belonged to them, not to Abram. This is the purport of the verse, <i>And the Canaanite and the Perrizite</i>. Scripture thus mentioned that there were many peoples dwelling in that land, they and their cattle being innumerable, and the land could not support them and Abram and Lot.<br>From the word <i>oz (then)</i> — [<i>And the Canaanite and the Perrizite abode ‘then’ in the land</i>] — it appears to me that the nations dwelling in the land at that time were those who live in tents and have cattle, some of them converging on one district and grazing there for a year or two and then journeying from there to another district in which they had not previously pastured. And so they continued to do, as is customary among “the children of the east.”<sup class="footnote-marker">102</sup><i class="footnote">See Judges 6:3.</i> The Canaanite and the Perrizite were thus “then” in the land of the south, and in the following years the Jebusite and the Amorite would come there.

Verse 8



Verse 9



Verse 10

AS THE GARDEN OF THE ETERNAL, LIKE THE LAND OF EGYPT. The verse states that the whole land of the Plain was adequately irrigated from the Jordan by working with the foot, just as was done with the garden of G-d, concerning which it is stated, <i>And a river went out of Eden to water the garden</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">103</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 2:10.</i> and as is the way in the land of Egypt, concerning which it is stated, <i>And thou didst water it with thy foot</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">104</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 11:10.</i> The verse mentions both places: it says that the land of the Plain was as adequately irrigated as the garden of the Eternal, which is the most perfect place on this earth, and it also mentions, <i>like the land of Egypt</i>, a place well known for pasture.<br>Our Rabbis have said,<sup class="footnote-marker">105</sup><i class="footnote">Sifre <i>Ekev</i>, 38. The Sifre is a Tannaitic Midrash on the book of Numbers and the book of Deuteronomy.</i> “<i>As the garden of the Eternal</i> for trees; <i>Like the land of Egypt</i> — for herbs.” Their intent was to explain that there were large rivers in the Plain, which watered the trees of the gardens, as was the case in the garden of G-d, and that there were also ponds in it, as in the land of Egypt, from which vegetable gardens were watered. Lot chose this part, for a land which is so irrigated is unlikely to suffer from a drought and is good for pasture.

Verse 11



Verse 12

ABRAM DWELT IN THE LAND OF CANAAN. The meaning thereof is that he dwelt in the remainder of the entire land of Canaan; he did not stay in one place but abode in the entire land of Canaan while Lot settled in one place thereof, namely, the cities of the Plain, for the cities of the Plain are part of the land of Canaan. The meaning of [the plural “cities” in the expression, <i>and Lot dwelt in</i>] <i>the cities of the Plain</i>, is that he dwelt for a time in this city and a time in the other on account of his many cattle. This is the reason that the verse says, <i>So Lot chose him all the plain of the Jordan;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">106</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 11 here.</i> he made a condition with Abram that he [Abram] should not come into the entire Plain.

Verse 13

NOW THE MEN OF SODOM WERE WICKED AND SINNERS. The purport thereof, as Rashi wrote, is that Scripture accuses Lot for not restraining himself from dwelling with them and also speaks of the merit of the righteous one [Abraham] whose lot did not fall in a place of wickedness <i>for the rod of wickedness shall not rest upon the lot of the righteous</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">107</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 125:3.</i> And all the cities of the Plain <i>were wicked and sinners against the Eternal exceedingly</i>. This was why they alone were overthrown even though all the Canaanites were people of great abominations, for so it is written.<sup class="footnote-marker">108</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 18:3.</i>

Verse 14



Verse 15



Verse 16



Verse 17

ARISE, WALK THROUGH THE LAND IN THE LENGTH AND IN THE BREADTH OF IT. It is possible that this is a matter of option, depending on his will.<sup class="footnote-marker">109</sup><i class="footnote">It is not a command that he go through the entire land, rather it is a promise that he need not fear whenever and wherever he will go.</i> The Eternal thus told Abraham, “Go wherever you wish to go in the land for I will be with you and guard you from the evil of the nations, <i>for unto thee will I give it</i>, that is to say, the land will be yours.” And if it be a command that Abraham should traverse the length and breadth of the land in order to take possession of his gift, as I have explained,<sup class="footnote-marker">110</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 12:6.</i> he was not commanded to do this immediately. He did so ultimately for he was now in the east, and afterwards he went to the land of the Philistines which is in the west, and thus he fulfilled the command during his lifetime.<br>The meaning of the expression, <i>to thee… and to thy children</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">111</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 15 here.</i> is that you are to take possession of the gift now, in order to transmit it to your children, even as our Rabbis have said:<sup class="footnote-marker">112</sup><i class="footnote">Baba Bathra 119b.</i> “The land of Israel is an inheritance to the people of Israel from their patriarchs.”<br>By way of the plain meaning of Scripture, it is possible that the meaning of the verse is that Abraham was to be a ruler over the land and <i>a prince of G-d</i> in its midst,<sup class="footnote-marker">113</sup><i class="footnote">See Genesis 23:6.</i> wherever he will go in this land.

Chapter 14



Verse 1

AND IT CAME TO PASS IN THE DAYS OF AMRAPHEL KING OF SHINAR. This event happened to Abraham in order to teach us that four kingdoms will arise to rule the world. In the end, his [Abraham’s] children will prevail over them, and they will all fall into their hands. Then they will return all their captives and their wealth. The first one mentioned here is the king of Babylon<sup class="footnote-marker">114</sup><i class="footnote">Shinar is Babylon. See Onkelos.</i> for so it was to be in the future, as it is written, <i>Thou art the head of gold</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">115</sup><i class="footnote">Daniel 2:38. This was said by Daniel to Nebuchadnezzar, king of Babylon, when interpreting the king’s dream of the four kingdoms that will rule the world.</i> Perhaps Ellasar, mentioned here second, is the name of a city in Media or Persia,<sup class="footnote-marker">116</sup><i class="footnote">Since Media and Persia ruled over Babylon.</i> and Elam, mentioned third, is the city in which the first Greek king — Alexander — was crowned. From there his kingdom spread after he was victorious over Darius, [king of the Persians]. Our Rabbis have already mentioned this matter:<sup class="footnote-marker">117</sup><i class="footnote">Abodah Zarah 10a.</i> “Rabbi Yosei said, ‘For six years the Greeks ruled in Elam, and after that their kingdom spread over the entire world.’” The <i>king of Goiim</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">118</sup><i class="footnote">Rashi explains <i>Goiim</i> as the name of a place. Ramban explains it as meaning “nations,” and it is hence an allusion to Rome, whose kings ruled over many nations.</i> [the last of the four kings mentioned here], who ruled over various nations that had made him their head and leader, is an allusion to the king of Rome who ruled over a city comprised of many peoples: Kittim, Edom, and the rest of the nations. Thus the Rabbis said in Bereshith Rabbah,<sup class="footnote-marker">119</sup><i class="footnote">42:2.</i> “Rabbi Avin said, ‘Just as Abraham’s grief began with four kingdoms, so will it end for his descendants only with four kingdoms.’” And it further says there:<sup class="footnote-marker">120</sup><i class="footnote">42:4.</i> “<i>And it came to pass in the days of Amraphel king of Shinar</i> — this is Babylon; <i>Arioch king of Ellasar</i> — this is Media; <i>Chedorlaomer king of Elam</i> — this is Greece; <i>And Tidal king of Goiim</i> — this is that kingdom (Rome) which writes out a levy [and collects assessment] from all nations of the world.”

Verse 2

AND THE KING OF BELA. The reason [why Scripture does not mention his name as it does with the kings of Sodom, <i>et al</i>], is that he ruled over a small city with few men in it and he had no generally recognized reputation.
