Verse 4



Verse 5



Verse 6

‘EIL PARAN.’ It is translated in the Targum as “Plain of Paran.” But I say that the word <i>eil</i> does not signify a plain. Rather, the lowland of Paran was called <i>Eil</i>, that of Mamre was named <i>Eilonei</i>, that of the Jordan was called <i>Kikar</i>, and that of Shittim was <i>Abel</i>. All these are translated in the Targum as <i>meishra</i> (plain), but each really had its own particular name. Thus the language of Rashi.<br>But if it were so,<sup class="footnote-marker">121</sup><i class="footnote">That <i>Eil, Eilonei</i> and <i>Kikar</i> are the proper names of these places.</i> Onkelos would have mentioned them in his Targum by their name — i.e., “<i>Eila</i> of Paran,” “<i>Eilonei</i> of Mamre,” — as is his custom with names. Besides, who told him<sup class="footnote-marker">122</sup><i class="footnote">“Him” refers both to Rashi and Onkelos.</i> whether these many places were all plains or high mountains [if <i>Eil, Eilonei</i> and <i>Kikar</i> were but proper names of these places]? Again, Mamre is the name of a person — as it is written, <i>brother of Eshcol, and brother of Aner, and they were confederate with Abram</i><sup class="footnote-marker">123</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 13 here.</i> — and that place was his, just as it says, <i>‘Eilonei’ Mamre the Amorite</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">124</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i> Ramban’s intent is to argue that since Mamre is the name of an individual, the word <i>Eilonei</i> could not be a proper name since two names cannot be in the constructive state.</i> as I have explained.<sup class="footnote-marker">125</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 12:6.</i> Rather, <i>Eil paran</i> means a place of terebinths, as it is said, <i>For they shall be ashamed ‘me’eilim’ (of the terebinths) which ye have desired;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">126</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 1:29.</i> <i>eilonei</i> is a place of oaks, as it is said, <i>As a terebinth, ‘veka’alon’ (and as an oak)</i><sup class="footnote-marker">127</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 6:13.</i> <i>Of the ‘alonim’ (oaks) of Bashan</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">128</sup><i class="footnote">Ezekiel 27:6.</i> It was customary among them that these terebinths and oaks be planted in the plains before the cities which serve them as “an open land.” And so did Onkelos translate <i>alon bachuth</i><sup class="footnote-marker">129</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 35:8. <i>And Deborah Rebekah’s nurse died, and she was buried below Beth-el under the ‘alon’ and he called its name ‘Alon Bachuth.’</i></i> as “the plain of Bechuta.” There the word <i>alon</i> is surely not a proper noun of the location<sup class="footnote-marker">130</sup><i class="footnote">As opposed to Rashi who says that the name of the place was Alon.</i> but only the name of the species of tree planted there, as is made explicit [in the same verse: <i>and she was buried</i>] <i>…under the ‘alon.’</i><sup class="footnote-marker">129</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 35:8. <i>And Deborah Rebekah’s nurse died, and she was buried below Beth-el under the ‘alon’ and he called its name ‘Alon Bachuth.’</i></i> Onkelos’ intent, however, is to convey the sense of the expression and not to merely translate the words.<br>Now the Targum Yerushalmi says with respect to both <i>eil Paran</i> and <i>eilonei Mamre</i> that they mean the plain of Paran and Mamre as Onkelos said, but in the case of <i>alon bachuth</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">129</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 35:8. <i>And Deborah Rebekah’s nurse died, and she was buried below Beth-el under the ‘alon’ and he called its name ‘Alon Bachuth.’</i></i> he [Targum Yerushalmi] says it is the nut-tree of Bachut for he considers <i>alon bachuth</i> to be the name of a tree and not a place.<sup class="footnote-marker">130</sup><i class="footnote">As opposed to Rashi who says that the name of the place was Alon.</i> Onkelos, however, thought that <i>alon bachuth</i> is the name of a place, so called because there were many oak trees there, just as <i>Eilonei Mamre</i> [is the name of a place]. It is for that reason that Scripture there uses the word <i>ha’alon</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">131</sup><i class="footnote"><i>And she was buried below Beth-el under ‘ha’alon’ (the oak)</i>. See Note 129 above. Ramban’s intent is to say that since the word <i>alon</i> appears there with the definite article, (namely, <i>ha-alon</i>), it could not be a proper noun since the definite article is never attached to a proper noun. Hence in the end of the verse, which reads, <i>And he called its name ‘alon bachuth,’</i> the word <i>alon</i> is also not a name designating a particular tree but a descriptive noun referring to a place containing many oaks. Hence Onkelos translates <i>alon Bachuth</i> as “the plain of Bechuta.” According to Targum Yerushalmi, who takes <i>alon bachuth</i> to be the name of a particular kind of tree, the verse should have read, “And she was buried below Beth-el under <i>alon</i>,” not <i>ha-alon</i>.</i> Thus according to Onkelos they are all<sup class="footnote-marker">132</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Eil Paran, Eilonei Mamre</i> and <i>alon bachuth</i>. Hence in all these cases Onkelos translated “the plain of Paran… Mamre… Bechuta” as meaning a plain containing oak trees. Onkelos does this in keeping with his general method of conveying the intent of the verse rather than its strict translation since <i>eil, eilonei</i> and <i>alon</i>, strictly speaking, mean particular kinds of trees. Onkelos however felt free to say “<i>the plain</i> of Paran… Mamre… Bachuth” for his intent is but to convey the general meaning. Ramban continues to point that out in <i>kikar hayarden</i>, (13:11), where Onkelos said, “the plain of the Jordan,” that is indeed the exact translation of the word <i>kikar</i>.</i> descriptive nouns.<br>But <i>kikar hayarden</i><sup class="footnote-marker">133</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 13:10.</i> is indeed the actual word for a plain, for <i>kikar</i> in the Sacred Language is the name for the place where the natural streams of rivers overflow. It is for this reason that the messenger who came to rescue Lot said, <i>Stay not in all ‘hakikar’ (the plain; escape to the mountain</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">134</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 19:17.</i> Of similar usage are the expressions, <i>Kar nirchav (wide pasture);</i><sup class="footnote-marker">135</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 30:23.</i> <i>‘Karim’ (the meadows) are clothed with flocks; the valleys also are covered over with corn</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">136</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 65:14.</i> Sometimes Scripture doubles the first letter of the word <i>kar</i> (meadow), making it <i>kikar</i>, and at other times Scripture discards the double form, as in, <i>bath ayin (the apple of the eye)</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">137</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 17:8. The double letter form of the word would be <i>babath ayin</i>, with a double <i>beth</i>.</i> There are many other such cases.<br>Swift couriers are also called by this name <i>kar</i>, as in <i>‘lakari velaratzim;’</i><sup class="footnote-marker">138</sup><i class="footnote">II Kings 11:4. It is usually translated: <i>of the Carites and of the guard</i>. According to Ramban its meaning is: <i>of the couriers and the dispatchers</i>.</i> <i>The captains over hundreds and ‘hakari.’</i><sup class="footnote-marker">139</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 19. Here too the usual translation is: <i>the Carites</i>. According to Ramban it means: <i>the couriers</i>.</i> The word <i>bakirkaroth</i><sup class="footnote-marker">140</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 66:20.</i> is also of the same root. It is the name for speedy camels such as “the flying camel” mentioned in the Talmud.<sup class="footnote-marker">141</sup><i class="footnote">Makkoth 5a.</i> The word <i>mecharkar</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">142</sup><i class="footnote">II Samuel 6:14. <i>And David ‘mecharkar’ (danced) before the Eternal with all his strength</i>.</i> containing the double use of <i>kar</i>, is a derivative of this word.<br><i>Abel Hashittim</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">143</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 33:49.</i> and also <i>Abel Mecholah</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">144</sup><i class="footnote">Judges 7:22.</i> they<sup class="footnote-marker">145</sup><i class="footnote">Onkelos and Jonathan</i> translated to mean the plain of Shittim and Mecholah. It is [called <i>Abel</i>, which in Hebrew means “mourning”], because it is a desolate place, without plantings or structures for the word <i>abel</i> is, to them, an expression of destruction and waste, as in the verses: <i>‘Vaya’avel’ (And He made to mourn) the rampart and the wall;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">146</sup><i class="footnote">Lamentations 2:8.</i> <i>The new wine ‘aval’ (faileth), the vine fadeth</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">147</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 24:7.</i>

Verse 7

TO EIN MISHPAT, WHICH IS KADESH. It is named [Ein Mishpat, meaning, “the Well of Judgment”] on account of a future event, for Moses and Aaron will be judged because of what will occur at that fountain.<sup class="footnote-marker">148</sup><i class="footnote">See Numbers 20:7-13.</i> Thus the words of Rashi based upon an <i>Agadah</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">149</sup><i class="footnote">Tanchumah <i>Chukath</i>, 11. So also in Targum Jonathan here.</i><br>But I do not understand this for this Kadesh [mentioned here] is Kadesh-barnea which is in <i>El-paran which is by the desert</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">150</sup><i class="footnote">As mentioned here in Verse 6.</i> and it is from there that the spies were sent by Moses in the second year following the Exodus from Egypt, as it is said, <i>Unto the wilderness of Paran, to Kadesh</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">151</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 13:26.</i> And it is further written, <i>And we came to Kadesh-barnea… and ye said, Let us send men before us</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">152</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 1:19, 22.</i> and there Israel <i>abode many days</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">153</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 46.</i> But the Kadesh where the judgment of the righteous ones<sup class="footnote-marker">154</sup><i class="footnote">Moses and Aaron.</i> took place is in the wilderness of Zin, which they entered in the fortieth year following the Exodus, as it is said, <i>And the children of Israel, even the whole congregation, came into the wilderness of Zin in the first month, and the people abode in Kadesh</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">155</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 20:1.</i> and finish the chapter.<sup class="footnote-marker">156</sup><i class="footnote">A charge by the author to finish the chapter containing the account of the smiting of the rock by Moses to bring forth water and his consequent punishment.</i> Perhaps the Midrash [mentioned above] alludes only to the name, meaning that a place bearing this name Kadesh will become “the Well of Judgment.”<br>Now Onkelos said, “the plain of <i>pilug dina</i>,” but I do not know what this means. Perhaps the word <i>pilug</i> is derived from [the Hebrew word used in the following verses]: <i>‘Plagim’ (Streams)</i> and watercourses;<sup class="footnote-marker">157</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 30:25.</i> <i>Who ‘pilag’ (hath cleft) a channel for the waterflood</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">158</sup><i class="footnote">Job 38:25.</i> Similarly, in the language of the Sages we find,<sup class="footnote-marker">159</sup><i class="footnote">Esther Rabbah, 5.</i> “<i>Pilgo</i> (The openness) of the sea.” The verse thus states that on that plain there will flow “a fountain of judgment” entering the depth of the case, as this was a fitting plain destined for kings who would sit there to judge all the peoples of these lands.
THE COUNTRY OF THE AMALEKITES. Rashi comments: “Amalek, it is true, was not yet born, but it is so named here because of the name it would bear in the future.”<br>Now I do not know whether Rashi’s intent is to say that Moshe Rabbeinu called the place by the name it was referred to in his time, but if this be the case, there is no reference to future events involved. Or [if Rashi’s intent is that the nations of Abraham’s era called it by that name] what is being foretold by the nations’ prophetic naming of this place?<br>But the language of Bereshith Rabbah<sup class="footnote-marker">160</sup><i class="footnote">42:11.</i> is as follows: “Amalek was not yet born and yet you say, ‘All the country of the Amalekites!’ However, the Torah <i>declares the end from the beginning</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">161</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 46:10.</i> This method of <i>d’rash</i><sup class="footnote-marker">162</sup><i class="footnote">Homiletical interpretation of Scripture.</i> of the Sages is found in many places. Concerning the rivers of the garden of Eden they also made a similar statement.<sup class="footnote-marker">163</sup><i class="footnote">“<i>That</i> [river] <i>is the one which surrounds the whole land of Havilah</i>. (Genesis 2:11). Havilah was not yet in existence, and yet the verse says, <i>the whole land of Havilah!</i> However, the Torah <i>declares the end from the beginning</i>.” (Bereshith Rabbah 16:2.)</i> The intent of the Rabbis is to say that from the time the rivers came forth it was already declared that a particular river go towards a land which is destined to be called Assyria.<sup class="footnote-marker">164</sup><i class="footnote">Reference here is to the third river, namely, the Tigris. (Above, 2:14.)</i><br>The correct interpretation concerning “the country of the Amalekites” mentioned here is that there was in ancient times some honorable person of the sons of the Horites, the inhabitants of the land,<sup class="footnote-marker">165</sup><i class="footnote">See further, 36:20.</i> by the name of Amalek, who ruled over this place. Eliphaz, Esau’s firstborn, named his son after this man.<sup class="footnote-marker">166</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 12.</i> Perhaps this Amalek mentioned here was of the family of Timna, his mother,<sup class="footnote-marker">166</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 12.</i> and he also ruled in that place and was chieftain over them.

Verse 8



Verse 9



Verse 10

‘BE’EROTH BE’EROTH CHEIMAR’ (FULL OF SLIME PITS). There were many pits there since they removed earth to be used as clay for building purposes. The Midrashic explanation is that the clay was closely kneaded together in them, [that is, it was very sticky], but a miracle happened to the king of Sodom and he escaped from there. This miracle occurred because there were some among the nations who did not believe that Abram had been delivered from the fiery furnace, but as soon as this one escaped from the slime, in retrospect they believed in Abram. Thus the language of Rashi.<br>There is no doubt that the meaning of <i>be’eroth cheimar</i> is “pits containing mud and slime,” even as it is written, <i>And in the pit there was no water, but mire, and Jeremiah sank in the mire</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">167</sup><i class="footnote">Jeremiah 38:6.</i> and it is further written, <i>He brought me up out of the tumultuous pit, out of the miry clay</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">168</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 40:3.</i> And it is possible that the king of Sodom went out from there naturally, without a miracle.<br>And I wonder concerning the above Midrashic explanation, for those nations that did not believe that the Holy One, blessed be He, had performed a miracle for Abraham would not have their faith in the Holy One, blessed be He, augmented by witnessing the miracle which befell the king of Sodom. The king of Sodom was an idol worshipper, and his miracle would either strengthen the hands of the idol worshippers or it would cause them to believe that all miracles are done by witchcraft or are due to some remotely possible chance. His miracle would thus cast doubt into the hearts of those who believed in Abraham’s miracle! Perhaps [the Rabbis who authored this Midrashic explanation] will interpret the verse, <i>And the king of Sodom went out to meet him</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">169</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 17 here.</i> as implying that “he went out” from the pit when Abraham passed by for it was in honor of Abraham that a miracle was done to him so that he could go forth to meet him in order to honor and bless Abraham.<br>And it is possible that Abraham, upon his return, looked into that pit for he wanted to save the kings and return their wealth to them, and then the miracle happened on his account. Now if a miracle was done to the king of Sodom in honor of Abraham, the nations could now believe all the more that a miracle would be done to Abraham himself in order to rescue him from death.<br>We must further say that the king of Gomorrah had already died<sup class="footnote-marker">170</sup><i class="footnote">Hence he did not come out from the pit.</i> when Abraham passed him by or that he had fallen into another pit, as the word “there”<sup class="footnote-marker">171</sup><i class="footnote"><i>And they fell ‘there.’</i> The word “there” does not refer to the pit, in which case it would then imply that all five kings fell into one pit. Rather it refers to <i>‘the vale’ of Siddim</i>. Thus the king of Gomorrah fell into a different pit, near which Abraham did not pass.</i> refers to “the vale.”

Verse 15

AND HE DIVIDED HIMSELF, BY NIGHT. Rashi wrote: “In accordance with the plain sense of the verse it means [that they divided into groups] as is the manner of those who pursue their enemies when they flee in different directions. <i>By night</i> means that even after it became dark, they did not cease pursuing them.”<br>The correct interpretation is that he pursued the enemies to Dan during the daytime with his entire army. When it became dark and he was not able to see by which road they fled, he divided his people and servants into two or three groups, taking one part with him, and they pursued them on all roads, smiting them as far as <i>Hobah, which is on the left hand of Damascus</i>. Then he returned from pursuing them. The order of the words [in the verse are thus interpreted as follows]: “And he divided himself, he and his servants, by night.”
AND HE PURSUED THEM UNTO HOBAH, WHICH IS ON THE LEFT HAND OF DAMASCUS. It is known that there is a great distance from the oaks of Mamre in Hebron in the land of Judah, to Damascus, which is outside the Land. If so, he pursued them for many days until he forced them to leave the land for they were returning to Babylon, their country. Or possibly there occurred here a great miracle, just as our Rabbis expounded from the verse, <i>The way with his foot he treadeth not</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">172</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 41:3. This is interpreted in Bereshith Rabbah (43:7) as referring to Abraham and asserting that he took such long steps that he traveled a mile without setting foot on the ground.</i>

Verse 16



Verse 17



Verse 18

AND MELCHIZEDEK KING OF SALEM. This is Jerusalem, just as it is said, <i>In Salem is set His tabernacle</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">173</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 76:3.</i> In the days of Joshua, its king was also called Adoni-zedek.<sup class="footnote-marker">174</sup><i class="footnote">Joshua 10:1.</i> Since time immemorial the nations knew that this place, which was the choicest of all places, is in the center of the inhabited region. Or perhaps they knew of its superiority by tradition, i.e., that it is exactly opposite the Heavenly Sanctuary, where the Divine Glory of the Holy One, blessed be He, who is called <i>Tzedek (Righteousness)</i> abides.<sup class="footnote-marker">175</sup><i class="footnote">This explains why the early inhabitants of Jerusalem called their king <i>Malki tzedek</i>, literally, “My king is righteousness.”</i><br>In Bereshith Rabbah<sup class="footnote-marker">176</sup><i class="footnote">43:6.</i> [we find that Jerusalem is called <i>Tzedek</i> because] “this place makes its inhabitants righteous. <i>And Melchizedek</i> means ‘the lord of Zedek.’<sup class="footnote-marker">177</sup><i class="footnote">The Midrash is thus teaching that his name was not “Tzedek” but that he was the lord of a place called Zedek.</i> Jerusalem is called <i>Tzedek</i>, as it is said, <i>‘Tzedek’ (Righteousness) lodged in it</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">178</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 1:21.</i>
AND HE WAS PRIEST OF G-D THE MOST HIGH. This is stated in order to inform us that Abraham would not give a tithe to the priest of other gods, but since he knew that <i>he was a priest of G-d the Most High</i>, he gave him the tithe as an honor to G-d. He alluded to Abraham through this episode that the House of G-d will be there, and there his descendants will bring the tithe and the Heave-offering,<sup class="footnote-marker">179</sup><i class="footnote">Malachi 3:8.</i> and there they will bless the Eternal.<br>Now according to the opinion of our Rabbis<sup class="footnote-marker">180</sup><i class="footnote">Nedarim 32b.</i> who say that Melchizedek was Shem, the son of Noah, we must say that he left his country in the east<sup class="footnote-marker">181</sup><i class="footnote">See above, 10:30.</i> and came to Jerusalem to worship the Eternal. He became the people’s priest of G-d the Most High since he was the honored one among their father’s brothers,<sup class="footnote-marker">182</sup><i class="footnote">That is, of the three sons of Noah — Shem, Ham and Japheth — Shem was the most honored. Now since according to the Rabbis, Melchizedek is none other than Shem, the Canaanites who were then in possession of Jerusalem recognized in Shem their father Ham’s most honored brother and therefore appointed him “priest of G-d the Most High.”</i> as Jerusalem was ever in the boundary of the Canaanites.<br>Now Rashi wrote above, “<i>And the Canaanite was then in the land</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">183</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 12:6.</i> They were gradually conquering the land of Israel from the descendants of Shem, the ancestor of Abraham, for it had fallen to the share of Shem when Noah apportioned the earth among his sons, as it is said, <i>And Melchizedek king of Salem</i>.”<br>This is not correct because <i>the boundary of the Canaanite was from Sidon</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">184</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 10:19.</i> which includes all of the land of Israel. The boundary of the children of Shem, on the other hand, was to the east of Mesha,<sup class="footnote-marker">185</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 30.</i> far from the land of Israel. But if Noah apportioned the countries among his sons and gave Shem the land of Israel, it would be similar to the case of a person who apportions his goods by word of mouth.<sup class="footnote-marker">186</sup><i class="footnote">Baba Bathra 156a. That the land of Israel should belong to the descendants of Shem would thus be a special oral provision by Noah since all their other lands were to the east of Mesha, far from the land of Israel.</i> Meanwhile, the children of Canaan, [who were the descendants of Ham], settled there until the time came when G-d caused the seed of His friend Abraham<sup class="footnote-marker">187</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 41:8. <i>The seed of Abraham My friend</i>.</i> to inherit it, as I have already mentioned.<sup class="footnote-marker">188</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 12:6.</i>
AND HE WAS PRIEST OF G-D THE MOST HIGH. Since there were, among all nations, priests serving the angels called <i>eilim</i> (the mighty ones) — even as it is said, <i>Who is like unto Thee ‘ba’eilim’ (among the mighty)</i><sup class="footnote-marker">189</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 15:11.</i> — the Holy One, blessed be He, is called <i>G-d the Most High</i>, the purport thereof being “the Mighty One, Who is Supreme over all,” as in the verse, <i>It is ‘ba’eil’ (the power of) my hand</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">190</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 31:29.</i> Now Melchizedek did not mention the Eternal, whereas Abraham said, <i>the Eternal, G-d of the Most High</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">191</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 22 here.</i>

Verse 19

KONEI (POSSESSOR) OF HEAVEN AND EARTH. Rashi wrote: “<i>Konei</i> is similar to <i>osei</i> (maker);<sup class="footnote-marker">192</sup><i class="footnote">In our text of Rashi, <i>‘Osei’ (Maker) of heaven and earth</i>. Psalms 134:3.</i> through His having made them He acquired them as His possession.”<br>But these are really two different interpretations.<sup class="footnote-marker">193</sup><i class="footnote">From Rashi it would appear that <i>osei</i> and <i>kinyan</i> — making and acquiring — constitute but one interpretation when in fact they are two: <i>konei</i> is similar to <i>osei</i>, and <i>konei</i> is like <i>kinyan</i> (acquisition).</i> Perhaps it is indeed the case that the word <i>kinyan</i> (acquisition) is also used in the case of <i>asiyah</i> (making). Thus you find, <i>For Thou ‘kanita’ (hast made) my reins</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">194</sup><i class="footnote">Pslams 139:13.</i> repeating the thought [expressed in the second half of the verse], <i>Thou hast knit me together in my mother’s womb</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">195</sup><i class="footnote">Ramban’s point is that since the second half of the verse clearly speaks of the making of man, the first half of the verse which uses the word <i>kanita</i> must also refer to “making,” rather than “acquiring.”</i> A similar case is the verse, <i>Is He not ‘konecha’ thy father? Hath He not made thee, and established thee?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">196</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 32:6. Here too the word <i>konecha</i> is used together with <i>asiyah</i>, indicating that they have a similar connotation.</i> Thus the Sacred Language uses <i>kinyan</i> in the case of “making.” Conversely, <i>And the souls which ‘asu’</i> [literally, <i>they made</i>] <i>in Haran</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">197</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 12:5.</i> means “they <i>acquired</i>.” <i>And of that which was our father’s ‘asah’ (hath he made)</i><sup class="footnote-marker">198</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 31:1.</i> — [here too it means “hath he <i>acquired</i>.”]<br>That which Rashi says further — “He acquired them as His possession,” is correct, for whatever belongs to a person is called <i>kinyano</i> (his acquisition). Sheep are called <i>mikneh</i> because they constitute the main wealth of a person. In the language of the Sages: “He who picks up a find for his friend, his friend <i>kanah</i> [has taken title to it];”<sup class="footnote-marker">199</sup><i class="footnote">Baba Metziah 10a. Here the word <i>konah</i> does not mean that he acquired it from the other since he never picked it up for himself. Instead, it means taking title to it.</i> “watching gives <i>‘keniya’</i> (the right of possession) in ownerless property;”<sup class="footnote-marker">200</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 118a. Here too <i>konah</i> does not mean that he acquired it from another person but that he took title to it.</i> “a man’s yard <i>koneh</i> (obtains title) for him without his knowledge.”<sup class="footnote-marker">201</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 11a. This too is a similar case.</i> Similarly, the Sages, in all places, use the expression of <i>kinyan</i> for taking possession, meaning that it is his. This was the intention of Onkelos when he translated <i>konei (of heaven and earth) as d’kinyanei</i>, [meaning “<i>Whose possessions</i> are heaven and earth”], and he did not say <i>kanah</i> (who acquired).

Verse 20

AND HE GAVE HIM A TENTH OF ALL. Abraham did not wish to take for himself <i>from a thread even to a sandal tie</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">202</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 23 here.</i> But the part of the Most High he set aside in order to give it to the priest. Now the king of Sodom went out to meet Abraham at the vale of Shaveh<sup class="footnote-marker">203</sup><i class="footnote">Above, Verse 17.</i> in his honor, and he accompanied him to the city of Salem where Melchizedek brought out bread and wine for the people that followed him. The king of Sodom did not ask anything of Abraham, but when he saw his generosity and righteousness in giving the tithe to the priest, then he also asked for the souls<sup class="footnote-marker">204</sup><i class="footnote">The prisoners. Verse 21 here.</i> by way of charity. Abraham, trusting that his G-d will give him riches, possessions and honor, did not wish to take anything from him, and so he returned all the wealth of Sodom which belonged to him, and all the wealth of Gomorrah for it to be returned to its owners. The king of Sodom had asked above all for the souls,<sup class="footnote-marker">204</sup><i class="footnote">The prisoners. Verse 21 here.</i> but Abraham’s consideration above all was that they should not say that they made Abram rich.<sup class="footnote-marker">202</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 23 here.</i> Now the other places mentioned<sup class="footnote-marker">205</sup><i class="footnote">Admah, Zeboim and Bela. Verse 2.</i> had been destroyed by the enemy in battle; only the wealth of Sodom and Gomorrah, among the cities of the five kings, fell into the hands of the enemy because since their kings were lost in the slime pits, their cities remained defenseless.<sup class="footnote-marker">206</sup><i class="footnote">Hence the four kings were able to plunder Sodom and Gomorrah, and when Abraham recaptured it from them he restored it to its original owners. The other three cities (see preceding note) defended themselves and were completely destroyed in battle.</i><br>It is possible<sup class="footnote-marker">207</sup><i class="footnote">Ramban is now suggesting that the four kings had taken plunder from the other three cities as well and that is alluded to in the verse, as will be explained.</i> that [the plunder from the other three cities is alluded to] in the words of Abraham: “<i>If from a thread even to a sandal tie</i><sup class="footnote-marker">202</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 23 here.</i> will remain with me of all the wealth that has come to me from all of you;<sup class="footnote-marker">208</sup><i class="footnote">“From all of you,” i.e., from all the five cities.</i> <i>and if I take anything that is thine</i><sup class="footnote-marker">202</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 23 here.</i> of your wealth which you, the king of Sodom, gave me.”

Verse 21



Verse 22

I HAVE LIFTED UP MINE HAND TO THE ETERNAL. This is an expression signifying an oath: “I lift up my hand to G-d Most High.”<sup class="footnote-marker">209</sup><i class="footnote">Besides explaining that this is an expression signifying an oath, Rashi also states that even though the verse uses a past tense <i>harimothi</i>, the sense is that of the present tense: “I lift up my hand.”</i> Similarly, the verse, <i>By myself have I sworn</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">210</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 22:16. Here too the verse uses a past tense, but its meaning is that of the present tense.</i> means “By Myself do I swear.” Thus the language of Rashi.<br>I have found a similar text in the Sifre:<sup class="footnote-marker">211</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Vaethchanan</i> 33.</i> “We find in the case of all the righteous that they bring their inclination under oath in order not to do evil. In the case of Abraham, he says, <i>I have lifted up mine hand to the Eternal</i>.” It is thus similar to the verse, <i>And he lifted up his right hand and his left hand unto heaven, and swore by Him that liveth forever</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">212</sup><i class="footnote">Daniel 12:7.</i><br>But Onkelos said, “I have lifted my hand in prayer before the Eternal.” The intent of Abraham’s words according to Onkelos is: “I have prayed to G-d, with my hands spread forth toward heaven,<sup class="footnote-marker">213</sup><i class="footnote">See I Kings 8:22.</i> if I take anything that is thine.” That is to say, “<i>G-d do so to me, and more also</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">214</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 2:23.</i> if I take, etc.”<br>The correct interpretation appears to me to be that Abraham said, “I have lifted my hand to G-d to make those things Sacred and Devoted<sup class="footnote-marker">215</sup><i class="footnote">See Leviticus 27:28.</i> to Him, were I to take from that which is thine.” Declaring things to be sacred to Him is called in Hebrew “lifting of a hand,” just as in the verses: <i>Every one that did lift up a heave offering of silver and copper;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">216</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 35:24.</i> <i>and every man that offered a wave offering of gold unto the Eternal</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">217</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 22.</i> This Abraham said because having given a tenth of it to the priest, he declared that whatever he takes from the king of Sodom would be a heave offering to G-d, from which he would derive no benefit.<br>In Bereshith Rabbah<sup class="footnote-marker">218</sup><i class="footnote">43:12.</i> it is similarly said, “Abraham made it a heave offering, even as it is said, <i>And ye shall heave a heave offering of it for the Eternal</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">219</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 18:26.</i>

Chapter 15



Verse 1

THE WORD OF THE ETERNAL CAME UNTO ABRAM IN A VISION. Abraham now merited that the word of G-d should come to him in a daytime vision for at first his prophecy came to him in nocturnal visions. The meaning of the word <i>bemachzeh</i> (in a vision) is as in the meaning of the verse, <i>And all the people saw the thunderings</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">220</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 20:18.</i> and the secret thereof is known to those who are learned in the mysteries of the Torah.
FEAR NOT ABRAM. Abraham feared two things: that the four kings — either they or their successors — might increase their forces against him and he would go down into the battle and perish, or that his day shall come to die without child. [To remove these two fears from Abraham, the Eternal] promised him that He will be his shield against them, and that his reward for walking with G-d shall be very great.

Verse 2

AND ABRAM SAID, O LORD ETERNAL, WHAT WILT THOU GIVE ME? “Behold, Thou hast saved me from the kings, but Thou hast not assured me against extinction. Thou hast only said that Thou wilt give me great reward, but what can my reward be without children?”<br>Now it had not occurred to Abraham that this great reward would be in the World to Come for there is no necessity for such a promise; every servant of G-d will find life in the hereafter before him. But in this world <i>there are righteous men, unto whom it happened according to the work of the wicked</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">221</sup><i class="footnote">Ecclesiastes 8:14.</i> It is for this reason that the righteous have need of assurance. Moreover, <i>very great</i><sup class="footnote-marker">222</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Thy reward shall be ‘very great.’</i></i> implies that he will merit both worlds<sup class="footnote-marker">223</sup><i class="footnote">“Both worlds,” literally “two tables,” a Rabbinic figure of speech (Berachoth 5 b) signifying access to the best of this world and also of the hereafter.</i> with all the best therein without any punishment whatever as befits the really righteous people. Moreover, an assurance is given for that which a person fears. [Hence, he needed no assurance concerning the hereafter. But he feared being childless; therefore G-d] rejoined and explained that His assurance included that he should not fear this either, as He will make his children <i>as the stars of heaven for multitude</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">224</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 1:10.</i><br>You may ask: Has it not been told to Abraham already, <i>For all the land which thou seest, to thee will I give it, and to thy seed forever. And I will make thy seed as the dust of the earth</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">225</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 13:15-16.</i> and so, how could Abraham now say, <i>Since I go childless…lo, my household slave will be mine heir?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">226</sup><i class="footnote">Verses 2-3 here.</i> And why did he not believe in the first prophecy, as he would believe in this [second one which G-d will now relate to him?] The answer is that the righteous ones have no trust in themselves, fearing they might have sinned in error. Thus it is written <i>At one instant I may speak concerning a nation, and concerning a kingdom, to build and plant it; but if that nation turn and do evil before Me, then I repent of the good</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">227</sup><i class="footnote">Jeremiah 18:7-10, with some changes.</i> Now when Abraham saw himself advanced in years and the first prophecy concerning him had not yet been fulfilled, he thought that his sins had withheld that good from him.<sup class="footnote-marker">228</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>ibid.</i>, 5:25.</i> And perhaps he now feared that he would be punished for the people that he killed in the war, as our Rabbis have said.<sup class="footnote-marker">229</sup><i class="footnote">Bereshith Rabbah 44:5.</i> They have expressed a similar thought in Bereshith Rabbah:<sup class="footnote-marker">230</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 76:2.</i> “<i>Then Jacob was greatly afraid and was distressed</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">231</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 32:8.</i> From this we derive the principle that there is no assurance for the righteous ones in this world, etc.”
WHAT WILT THOU GIVE ME, SINCE I ‘HOLECH’ (GO) CHILDLESS? They<sup class="footnote-marker">232</sup><i class="footnote">Jonathan and R’dak. Jonathan translates: “For I pass from the world.” R’dak expressly says that Abraham feared that he might “die” childless.</i> have explained the word <i>holech</i> as meaning “I die childless,” even as is the meaning of that word in the verse, <i>For man is ‘holech’ (going) to his eternal home</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">233</sup><i class="footnote">Ecclesiastes 12:5. Now just as <i>holech</i> here refers to death, so in the words of Abraham it has the same connotation.</i><br>The correct interpretation appears to me to be that at first he [Abraham] complained: “What can my reward be since I have no children and I go as a vagrant and vagabond alone in a strange land, <i>like a tamarisk in the desert</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">234</sup><i class="footnote">Jeremiah 17:6.</i> <i>no one going out, and no one coming in</i><sup class="footnote-marker">235</sup><i class="footnote">Joshua 6:1.</i> in my house except Eliezer, a stranger that I brought to me from Damascus, not from my family, and not from my country.” Then Abraham said, “<i>Behold, to me Thou hast given no seed</i><sup class="footnote-marker">236</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 3 here.</i> as Thou hast promised me, and lo my household slave, the one mentioned, will be mine heir, as I am old without child, and my time will come to die childless. I am thus punished, having lost the reward which Thou hast promised me at first.”

Verse 3



Verse 4

AND, BEHOLD, THE WORD OF THE ETERNAL CAME UNTO HIM, SAYING: THIS MAN SHALL NOT BE THINE HEIR. Since Abraham had his son who would be his heir after his old age, the Eternal assured him only concerning the inheritance,<sup class="footnote-marker">237</sup><i class="footnote">Ramban here suggests that Abraham’s faith in the first promise (see above, Note 223) remained unshaken. However, as he grew older, he feared that if his son will be born near the time of his death, Eliezer will do with the child as he pleases, and he instead will become his heir. On this matter of inheritance G-d now assured Abraham that he should not worry for his seed will inherit him. (Tur.)</i> i.e., that he should not worry, and his seed will inherit it.<br>The meaning of the expression, <i>And, behold, the word of the Eternal came unto him</i>, is that while Abraham was still saying, <i>And, lo, my household slave will be mine heir</i>, the word of G-d suddenly came to him, saying <i>This man shall not be thine heir</i>.

Verse 5

AND HE BROUGHT HIM FORTH OUTSIDE. According to the simple interpretation of Scripture it means that He brought him forth from his tent into the open so that he could see the stars. And according to the Midrash its explanation is as follows: G-d said to him, “Leave your astrological speculations, for you have seen by the constellations that you are not destined to raise a son. “Abram” indeed may not have a son, but “Abraham” will have a son; “Sarai” will not bear a child, but “Sarah” will bear a child. Thus the language of Rashi.<br>But ‘Abram’ did have Ishmael!<sup class="footnote-marker">238</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 16:15. How then could the Midrash say, “‘Abram’ indeed may not have a son?”</i><br>The meaning of the Midrash, however, is that Abram sought a son who would qualify to become his heir, [which excluded Ishmael, who would not inherit him], even as he said, <i>And, lo, my household slave will be mine heir</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">236</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 3 here.</i> The Holy One, blessed be He, then said to him, “This man shall not be thine heir, but one born of thine own body shall be thine heir,<sup class="footnote-marker">239</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 4 here.</i> and leave your astrological speculations. ‘Abram’ will not have a son as his heir, but ‘Abraham’ will have a son as his heir.”<br>It is also possible that the astrological speculation concerned the pair together, namely, the “Abram and Sarai” as a pair will not beget children, and the Eternal now assured him that “Abraham and Sarah” will beget children. In my opinion, however, [the Divine assurance now given to Abraham did not mention Sarah, rather], her name is an addition on the part of the Midrash, meaning that such indeed was the case also with Sarah.<sup class="footnote-marker">240</sup><i class="footnote">That “Sarai” will not bear a child, but “Sarah” will.</i> The Holy One, blessed be He, however, did not assure him concerning Sarah at the present time. Even at the time of the prophecy concerning the circumcision, Abraham was still in doubt whether “Sarah” would bear a child.<sup class="footnote-marker">241</sup><i class="footnote">See further, 17:17.</i>

Verse 6

AND HE BELIEVED IN THE ETERNAL; AND HE ACCOUNTED IT TO HIM FOR RIGHTEOUSNESS. Rashi’s explanation is: The Holy One, blessed be He, accounted it to Abraham for righteousness and merit because of the faith with which he had trusted in Him.<br>But I do not understand the nature of this merit. Why should he not believe in the G-d of truth, and he himself is the prophet, and <i>G-d is not a man, that He should lie?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">242</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 23:29.</i> Furthermore, he who believed [and on the basis of this belief was ready] to sacrifice his only son, the beloved one, and withstood the rest of the trials, how could he not believe a good tiding?<br>The correct interpretation appears to me to be that the verse is stating that Abraham believed in G-d and he considered it due to the righteousness of the Holy One, blessed be He, that He would give him a child under all circumstances, and not because of Abram’s state of righteousness and his reward, even though He told him, <i>Your reward shall be very great</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">243</sup><i class="footnote">Above, Verse 1.</i> Thus from now on he would no longer have to fear that sin might prevent the fulfillment of the promise. Now although in the case of the first prophecy<sup class="footnote-marker">244</sup><i class="footnote">See above, Note 223, and Ramban to Verse 2.</i> Abraham had thought that the promise was conditional upon the recompense for his deeds, yet now since He promised him that he should have no fear on account of sin and that He will give him a child, he believed that <i>the thing is established by G-d</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">245</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 41:21.</i> <i>truth He will not turn from it</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">246</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 132:11.</i> For since this is a matter of the righteousness of G-d, it has no break in continuity, even as it is written, <i>By Myself have I sworn, saith the Eternal, the word is gone forth from My mouth in righteousness, and shall not come back</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">247</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 45:23. “Saith the Eternal” is here an addition based upon Genesis 22:16.</i><br>It may be that the verse is stating that Abraham believed that he would have a child as an heir under all circumstances, but the Holy One, blessed be He, accounted to him that this promise He had assured him would in addition be as righteousness<sup class="footnote-marker">248</sup><i class="footnote">Ramban is now suggesting that Abraham did consider his having a child as being a reward for his deeds, but the Holy One, blessed be He, accounted it to him as an act of righteousness in order not to diminish his future reward for his good deeds.</i> since in His righteousness G-d did so, just as it says, <i>G-d thought it for good</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">249</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 50:20.</i> A similar case is the verse regarding Phinehas: <i>And that was accounted unto him for righteousness</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">250</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 106:31.</i> meaning that the trust he [Phinehas] has in G-d when committing that particular deed<sup class="footnote-marker">251</sup><i class="footnote">See Numbers 25:7-8.</i> was accounted as righteousness unto all generations since G-d will forever keep His righteousness and kindness for every generation on account of [Phinehas’ deed, and this recompense transcends any strictly merited reward]. This is similar to that which is stated, <i>Forever will I keep for him My mercy</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">252</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 89:29.</i>

Verse 7

I AM THE ETERNAL WHO BROUGHT THEE OUT OF UR OF THE CHALDEES, TO GIVE THEE THIS LAND TO INHERIT IT. I have already explained this verse<sup class="footnote-marker">253</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 11:28.</i> as stating: “From the time I brought you out of Ur of the Chaldees and performed a miracle for you [which saved your life], it was the Will before Me to give you this land.” But at this present moment He did not decree giving it to Abraham, rather he said that He had brought him out of Ur of the Chaldees with the intention of giving it to him. It was for this reason that Abraham feared lest a condition of good deeds be attached to the inheritance of the land even though He already had told him twice, <i>Unto thy seed will I give this land</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">254</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 12:7; 13:15.</i> since He did not decree the gift of the land now as He did decree to give him a child. Therefore, Abraham said, <i>Whereby shall I know that I shall inherit it?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">255</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 8. Meaning: “How shall I know that this gift of the land will be an enduring one, unaffected by my sins?” This interpretation is clearly stated by Ramban further on in the text.</i> This is not similar to the question of Hezekiah, <i>What shall be the sign that the Eternal will heal me?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">256</sup><i class="footnote">II Kings 20:8.</i> The Holy One, blessed be He, also did not act with Abraham as He did with the other signs by showing him a sign or wonder in some miraculous matter.<sup class="footnote-marker">257</sup><i class="footnote">Instead, He made a covenant with him to inherit the land by all means. (Tur.)</i> But Abraham desired to have definite knowledge that he would inherit the land and that neither his sin nor that of his seed would withhold it from them. Or perhaps the Canaanites might repent, in which case the following verse might apply to them: <i>At one instant I may speak concerning a nation, and concerning a kingdom, to pluck up and to break down and destroy it; but if that nation turn from their evil… I repent of the evil that I thought to do unto it</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">258</sup><i class="footnote">Jeremiah 18:7-8.</i> And then the Holy One, blessed be He, made a covenant with him that he will inherit the land under all circumstances.

Verse 8



Verse 9

A HEIFER ‘MESHULESHETH’ AND A SHE-GOAT ‘MESHULESHETH.’ Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra explained the word <i>meshulesheth</i> as meaning three years old. But Onkelos said “three.”<sup class="footnote-marker">259</sup><i class="footnote">“Three heifers and three she-goats.” (Onkelos.)</i> This is indeed correct since a three-year old cow is no longer called <i>eglah</i> (heifer), just as we have learned in a Mishnah:<sup class="footnote-marker">260</sup><i class="footnote">Parah 1:1. And here when the verse says <i>eglah</i> (heifer) it cannot therefore refer to a three-year old, as Ibn Ezra says.</i> “But the Sages say that an <i>eglah</i> (heifer) is two years old; a <i>parah</i> (cow) is three years old.”<br>The allusion here is to the three sacrifices<sup class="footnote-marker">261</sup><i class="footnote">The heifer, the she-goat and the ram.</i> which his seed will bring from them before Him: the Whole-offering, the Sin-offering and the Peace-offering. And as for the Guilt-offering, that is like the Sin-offering,<sup class="footnote-marker">262</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 7:7.</i> the difference between them being merely in the name.<br>It is possible that the meaning of the word <i>meshulesheth</i> is that he bring the three of them consecutively, each kind remaining separate. A similar use of this word is found in the verse, <i>For they were in ‘meshulashoth’ (three) stories</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">263</sup><i class="footnote">Ezekiel 42:6.</i> meaning that there were upper, middle and lower chambers.

Verse 10

AND HE DIVIDED THEM IN THE MIDST. This he did in order that He make the covenant with him, to pass between these parts.<br>He thereby alluded to Abraham that all sacrifices of cattle and fowl will be from these species since the <i>gozeil</i> (young pigeon) mentioned here<sup class="footnote-marker">264</sup><i class="footnote">In Verse 9 above.</i> is identical with the <i>ben yonah</i> (young pigeon) mentioned in the Book of Leviticus.<sup class="footnote-marker">265</sup><i class="footnote">1:14.</i> Here it is called <i>gozeil</i> to indicate that only the young of this specie are fit for sacrifices. Now even though all young fowl are called <i>gozlim</i> — as it is said, <i>As an eagle that stirreth up her nest, hovereth over ‘gozalav’ (his young ones)</i><sup class="footnote-marker">266</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 32:11.</i> — Abraham understood on his own that the command of the Eternal applied to the kind which was to be selected [by the Torah, namely, young pigeons]. It may be that Abraham followed his own will in offering a young pigeon, and Scripture selected forever the specie which the patriarch had offered.<br>Thus did Abraham know that the sacrifices would be of these species and that all of them would be divided into parts: the Whole-offering into its pieces,<sup class="footnote-marker">267</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 1:12.</i> the Peace-offering into the breast, shoulder and fats,<sup class="footnote-marker">268</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 7:30-32</i> and the Sin-offering and the Guilt-offering into their fats.<sup class="footnote-marker">269</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 4:31; 7:2-5.</i>
BUT THE BIRD HE DID NOT SPLIT. He placed the turtle-dove<sup class="footnote-marker">264</sup><i class="footnote">In Verse 9 above.</i> and the young pigeon opposite each other for they too were in the covenant, but Abraham did not split them in the middle since concerning all fowl offered on the altar it says, <i>He shall not separate it</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">270</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 1:17.</i> In Bereshith Rabbah the Sages said,<sup class="footnote-marker">271</sup><i class="footnote">44:14.</i> “The Holy One, blessed be He, indicated to him that in a bird Whole-offering, the ministering-priest severs both the gullet and the windpipe, but in a bird Sin-offering he does not sever” [the head from the body, as he must cut one and not both of the organs].<sup class="footnote-marker">272</sup><i class="footnote">See Rashi, Leviticus 1:15 and 5:8. The principle is derived from the following textual inference: Since Abraham was asked to bring both “a turtle-dove and a young pigeon,” why does Scripture conclude by saying, <i>And the bird</i> [<i>hatzipor</i> — singular] <i>he did not split?</i> This is to indicate that of the two kinds of sacrifices to be brought from fowl, namely, the Sin-offering and the Whole-offering, only one would be subject to the injunction not to separate it, and Scripture later specifies that this is the bird Sin-offering. (Leviticus 5:8.)</i>

Verse 11

AND THE BIRDS OF PREY CAME DOWN UPON THE CARCASSES. [They came down] to eat them, as is the nature of birds.
AND ABRAM DROVE THEM AWAY. It was thus alluded to Abraham that the nations would come to abolish the sacrifices, but the children of Abraham would drive them away.

Verse 12

AND LO, A DREAD, EVEN A GREAT DARKNESS FELL UPON HIM. The Rabbis in the Midrash have interpreted this fourfold<sup class="footnote-marker">273</sup><i class="footnote">“A dread,” “a great,” “darkness,” “fell.”</i> expression to be an allusion to the servitude of the four exiles,<sup class="footnote-marker">274</sup><i class="footnote">Mentioned further in the text.</i> for the prophet<sup class="footnote-marker">275</sup><i class="footnote">See Ramban further, Verse 17, as to the nature of the prophetic vision.</i> Abraham found his soul overtaken by “a dread,” followed by “darkness,” which in turn became “a great darkness,” and then he felt as if an overwhelmingly heavy load “fell” upon him. Thus the Rabbis have said:<sup class="footnote-marker">276</sup><i class="footnote">Bereshith Rabbah 44:20.</i> “<i>A dread</i>, this is Babylon. <i>Darkness</i>, this is Media that darkened the eyes of Israel with fasting<sup class="footnote-marker">277</sup><i class="footnote">A reference to the fasting in the time of Mordecai and Esther. (Esther 4:16.)</i> and affliction. <i>Great</i>, this is the kingdom of Antiochus.<sup class="footnote-marker">278</sup><i class="footnote">By prohibiting the practice of the commandments of the Torah, the Greeks caused “a great” darkness to descend upon the descendants of Abraham.</i> <i>Fell upon him</i>, this is Edom.<sup class="footnote-marker">279</sup><i class="footnote">Edom being a synonym for Rome.</i><br>This experience came to Abraham because when the Holy One, blessed be He, made a covenant with him to give the land to his children as an everlasting possession, He said to him, by way of a residuary of His gift, that during the four exiles the nations will subjugate his children and rule in their land, subject to the condition that they sin before Him. Following this general allusion, He then informed him explicitly concerning another exile into which they will first go, namely, the Egyptian exile with which he had already been punished, as I have explained.<sup class="footnote-marker">280</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 12:10.</i>

Verse 13

THAT THY SEED SHALL BE A STRANGER. This is a verse that is to be transposed, its purport being that “thy seed shall be a stranger for four hundred years in a land that is not theirs, and they shall enslave them, and they shall afflict them.” He has thus not specified the length of the period of servitude and affliction.<br>There are many cases in Scripture where verses must be transposed if they are to be interpreted properly. Thus: <i>There came unto me the Hebrew servant, who thou hast brought unto us, to mock me;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">281</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 39:17. The meaning being: “There came unto me to mock me the Hebrew servant.…”</i> <i>And all countries came into Egypt to buy corn to Joseph;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">282</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 41:57. The meaning being: “And all countries came into Egypt to Joseph.…”</i> <i>For whosoever eateth leavened bread, that soul shall be cut off from Israel, from the first day until the seventh day;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">283</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 12:15. The meaning being: “For whosoever eateth leavened bread, from the first day until the seventh day, that soul.…”</i> <i>In that day a man shall cast away his idols of silver, and his idols of gold, which they made for themselves to worship, to the moles and to the bats;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">284</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 2:20. The meaning being: “In that day a man shall cast away to the moles and to the bats his idols.…”</i> <i>Come, and hearken, and I will declare, all ye that fear G-d, what He hath done for my soul;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">285</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 66:16. The meaning being: “All ye that fear G-d, come.…”</i> <i>They cry unto Me, My G-d we Israel know Thee;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">286</sup><i class="footnote">Hosea 8:2. The meaning being: “Unto Me crieth Israel, ‘My G-d, we know Thee.’”</i> <i>And they shall be Mine, saith the Eternal of hosts, in the day that I do make, even Mine own treasure, and I will spare them</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">287</sup><i class="footnote">Malachi 3:17. The meaning being: “And they shall be Mine treasure, saith the Eternal.…”</i> There are many other such verses.<br>The sense of the verse is: “Even though I tell you that I have given this land to your children, you should surely know that before I give it to them they shall be strangers for four hundred years in a land not belonging to them, and they shall also enslave them and afflict them.”<br>Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra said [that the verse should be interpreted as follows]: “You should surely know that your children shall be strangers in servitude and affliction until the end of a four hundred year period commencing from this day of the covenant.” If so, G-d informed Abraham of the time of the redemption, but He did not inform him of the exact length of the exile. This too is correct.

Verse 14

‘VEGAM’ (AND ALSO) THAT NATION THAT MADE SLAVES OF THEM WILL I JUDGE. The words, <i>And also</i>, include the kingdoms of the four exiles which will be judged for having enslaved Israel. Thus the language of Rashi.<br>By way of the simple meaning of Scripture, the verse is stating: “Just as I decreed exile and affliction for your children on account of sin,<sup class="footnote-marker">288</sup><i class="footnote">See Ramban above, 12:10.</i> so will I bring judgment upon the nation that will enslave them for the violence they will do to them.”<br>The correct meaning of the word <i>vegam</i> appears to me to be as follows: Even though I have decreed that your children be strangers in a land not their own, and they shall enslave them and afflict them, I will nevertheless judge the nation that will enslave them for what they will do to them, and they will not be exonerated for having done My decree.” The reason for this is as Scripture states: <i>I am jealous for Jerusalem and for Zion with a great jealousy; and I am very sore displeased with the nations that are at ease; for I was but a little displeased, and they helped for evil</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">289</sup><i class="footnote">Zechariah 1:14-15.</i> And it says again, <i>I was wroth with My people, I profaned Mine inheritance, and gave them into thy hand; thou didst show them no mercy; upon the aged hast thou very heavily laid the yoke</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">290</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 47:6.</i> Such was the case with the Egyptians who increased the evil. They threw the children of the Israelites into the river, embittered their lives,<sup class="footnote-marker">291</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 1:14.</i> and they intended to eradicate their name from memory. This is the meaning of the expression <i>will I judge</i>, i.e., “I will bring them to judgment to determine whether they did as was decreed upon them or if they increased the evil inflicted upon them.” It is this principle which Jethro stated: <i>For it is the thing wherein they acted presumptuously</i> [that caused the punishment to come] <i>upon them</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">292</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 18:11.</i> It was their presumptuousness that brought upon the Egyptians the great punishment which utterly destroyed them. And this principle is also expressed in the verse: <i>for thou knewest that they dealt proudly against them</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">293</sup><i class="footnote">Nehemiah 9:10.</i><br>Now the Rabbi<sup class="footnote-marker">294</sup><i class="footnote">Rabbi Moshe ben Maimon (Rambam). See <i>Seder Bereshith</i>, Note 139.</i> stated the reason [for the punishment of the Egyptians — a punishment meted out even though it had been decreed that they were to enslave the Israelites] — in the Book of Knowledge:<sup class="footnote-marker">295</sup><i class="footnote">Mishneh Torah, Mada, Hilchoth Teshuvah, end of Chapter 6.</i> “It had not been decreed on any particular [Egyptian that <i>he</i> was to afflict the Israelites], and if any one of all those who perpetrated evil against Israel had not wanted to do it, he had the liberty to do so since the decree was not directed at any specific person.”<sup class="footnote-marker">296</sup><i class="footnote">Hence the individual Egyptian was properly punished since each one could, by exercise of his free choice, have not been a party to the suffering caused to the Israelites. Ramban’s position as explained in the text is shared by Rabbi Abraham ben David (Rabad), Rambam’s chief critic. (<i>Ibid.</i>)</i><br>But to me the Rabbi’s words are not reconciled with the facts. Even if the Holy One, blessed be He, were to decree that any individual among all the nations should do them [the Israelites] evil in such-and-such a manner, and this specific individual fulfilled His decree with alacrity, he has the merit of fulfilling a Divine commandment. What sense is there in the Rabbi’s words? If a king were to command that the inhabitants of a certain country do a particular deed, he who is slack and throws the matter upon others offends and sins against himself, while he who does it wins the king’s favor. And this is all the more since Scripture states, <i>And also that nation that made slaves of them</i>, which clearly implies that the entire Egyptian nation was to enslave them, and they came to Egypt of their own free will! Instead, the reason [for the punishment of the Egyptians] is as I have written above.<br>Our Rabbis already mentioned this matter when they said in Shmoth Rabbah:<sup class="footnote-marker">297</sup><i class="footnote">30:15.</i> “This may be likened to a lord who told his son that he should work for a certain person who should not cause him any suffering. So he went and worked for him. Now even though he worked for him without recompense, the master did not cease causing him suffering. When the lord finally was reconciled with his son, he decreed death to those who caused his son suffering. Similarly, the Holy One, blessed be He, decreed that Israel be in servitude in Egypt. But the Egyptians overwhelmed them and enslaved them by force. “Said the Holy One, blessed be He: ‘You should have used them as servants who would do your needs. <i>I was but a little displeased, and they helped for evil</i>.’”<sup class="footnote-marker">298</sup><i class="footnote">Zechariah 1:15.</i> Thus far [is the quote from the Midrash Shmoth Rabbah].<br>Now it is clear that throwing Hebrew children into the river was not included in the decree, <i>And they shall enslave them, and afflict them</i>, for this would result in their complete destruction. Similarly, that which the Egyptians said at first, <i>Come, let us deal wisely with them lest they multiply</i><sup class="footnote-marker">299</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 1:10.</i> is not part of servitude or affliction. Besides, they themselves increased the degree of affliction, as Scripture testifies, <i>And they made their lives bitter with hard service</i>, etc.<sup class="footnote-marker">300</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 14.</i> It is this which Scripture states in the following verse: <i>And he saw our affliction, and our toil, and our oppression</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">301</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 26:7.</i><br>Know and understand that a person who, on the New Year, has been inscribed and sealed for a violent death,<sup class="footnote-marker">302</sup><i class="footnote">During the coming year. The significance of the words “and sealed” is as follows: According to the Talmud (Rosh Hashanah 16 b), only the completely wicked people are inscribed “and sealed” immediately on Rosh Hashanah for death. The fate of the average person is not “sealed” until the Day of Atonement. Yet, continues Ramban, no one has a right to kill that person even though death was already decreed for him on the New Year, which would indicate that he was a completely wicked person.</i> the bandits who kill him will not be guiltless because they fulfilled that which had been decreed against him. <i>That wicked man shall die in his iniquity</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">303</sup><i class="footnote">Ezekiel 3:18.</i> but his blood will be sought from the murderer. However, when a decree issues from the mouth of a prophet, there are different laws concerning one who fulfills it. If he heard it and he wishes to fulfill the Will of his Creator as decreed, there is no sin upon him for doing so. On the contrary, it is accounted to him as a merit, just as it is said concerning King Jehu: <i>Because thou hast done well in executing that which is right in Mine eyes, and hast done unto the house of Ahab according to all that was in My heart, thy sons of the fourth generation shall sit on the throne of Israel</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">304</sup><i class="footnote">II Kings 10:30.</i> However, if he heard the command and killed him out of his personal hatred or in order to take his wealth, he is subject to punishment for his intention was to sin, and it is accounted to him as a transgression. Scripture so states with respect to Sennacherib, [king of Assyria]: <i>O Asshur the rod of Mine anger… I do send him against an ungodly nation, and against the people of My wrath do I give him a charge</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">305</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 10:5-6.</i> And Scripture continues: <i>but not so doth he mean, neither doth his heart think so, but it is in his heart to destroy</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">306</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 7.</i> This is why he was punished in the end, just as it is said, <i>Wherefore it shall come to pass, that when the Eternal hath performed his whole work… I will punish the fruit of the arrogant heart of the king of Assyria, and the glory of his haughty looks, etc</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">307</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 12.</i> Again it says concerning Sennacherib: <i>Israel is a scattered sheep, the lions have driven him away; first the king of Assyria hath devoured him, and last this Nebuchadrezzar king of Babylon. …Therefore thus said the Eternal… Behold, I will punish the king of Babylon and his land, as I have punished the king of Assyria</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">308</sup><i class="footnote">Jeremiah 50:17-18.</i> This is proof that the king of Assyria was punished because of the evil he did to Israel. Now Nebuchadrezzar heard that the prophets unanimously called upon him to destroy Jerusalem, and he and all his people were commanded to do this by word of the prophet, as it is written, <i>Behold, I will send and take all the families of the north, saith the Eternal, and I will send unto Nebuchadrezzar the king of Babylon, My servant, and will bring them against this land, and against the inhabitants thereof… and I will utterly destroy them</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">309</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 25:9.</i> And it is further written, <i>Behold I will give this city into the hand of the Chaldeans, and into the hand of Nebuchadrezzar king of Babylon… and they shall set the city on fire</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">310</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 32:28-29.</i> Concerning the Sanctuary itself, the prophet said, <i>I will make this house like Shiloh</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">311</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 26:6. Shiloh was destroyed by the Philistines. (I Samuel 4.)</i> The Chaldeans knew that it was the command of G-d, as Nebuzaradan [captain of the guard of the King of Babylon] said to Jeremiah, <i>The Eternal thy G-d pronounced this evil upon this place; and the Eternal hath brought it, and done according as He spoke, because ye have sinned against the Eternal</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">312</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 40:2-3.</i> Yet despite this, the Chaldeans were all punished in the end. This was because of two reasons. First, Nebuchadrezzar also intended to destroy the entire land in order to increase his authority, as it is written concerning him: <i>And I will cause the arrogancy of the proud to cease, and will lay low the haughtiness of the tyrants;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">313</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 13:11.</i> and again it is written: <i>And thou hast said in thy heart, I will ascend into heaven… I will ascend above the heights of the clouds; I will be like the Most High</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">314</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 14:13-14.</i> Concerning his nation it is written, <i>Thou sayest in thy heart: I am, and there is none else beside me</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">315</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 47:8.</i> Habakkuk the prophet said concerning him, <i>Woe to him that gaineth evil gains for his house, that he may set his nest on high</i>, etc.<sup class="footnote-marker">316</sup><i class="footnote">Habakkuk 2:9.</i> Thus Nebuchadrezzar’s punishment is as that of Sennacherib. It is for this reason that Scripture says, <i>Therefore thus saith the Eternal… Behold, I will punish the king of Babylon and his land, as I have punished the king of Assyria</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">317</sup><i class="footnote">Jeremiah 50:18.</i> And there was yet another reason for punishment in the case of the king of Babylon, i.e., for his having added to the decree and having exceedingly perpetrated evil against Israel, as it is said concerning him, <i>I was wroth with My people, I profaned Mine inheritance, and gave them into thy hand; thou didst show no mercy, upon the aged hast thou very heavily laid thy yoke</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">318</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 47:6.</i> Therefore did a twofold punishment come upon him: his people were utterly destroyed, there remaining of Babylon no <i>name and remnant, offshoot and offspring</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">319</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 14:22.</i> and his city was destroyed forever, as it is said, <i>And Babylon, the glory of kingdoms, the beauty of the Chaldeans’ pride, shall be as when G-d overthrew Sodom and Gomorrah. It shall never be inhabited, neither shall it be dwelled in from generation to generation… But wild-cats shall lie there… and satyrs shall dance there</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">320</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 13:19-21.</i> Scripture further states concerning him, <i>For it is the vengeance of the Eternal, the vengeance of His temple</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">321</sup><i class="footnote">Jeremiah 51:11.</i> and it is written, <i>‘The violence done to me and to my flesh be upon Babylon,’ shall the inhabitants of Zion say; and ‘My blood be upon the inhabitants of Chaldaea,’ shall Jerusalem say. Therefore thus saith the Eternal: Behold, I will plead thy cause, and take vengeance for thee</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">322</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 51:35-6.</i> There are many verses like these.

Verse 15

AND THOU SHALT COME TO THY FATHERS IN PEACE. And thou shalt not behold at this. Thus the language of Rashi.<br>This is not correct according to Rashi’s own interpretation, namely, that the decree, <i>thy seed shall be a stranger in a land not their own</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">323</sup><i class="footnote">Above, Verse 13.</i> took effect as soon as Abraham had a child. Thus, soon after Isaac was born it states, <i>And Abraham sojourned (‘vayagar’) in the land of the Philistines;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">324</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 21:34. The word <i>vayagar</i> has the same root letters as <i>geir</i> (stranger), thus suggesting that Abraham lived as a “stranger” in a land which was not his own.</i> <i>And Isaac sojourned in Gerar</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">325</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 26:6. The verse however states, <i>vayeshev</i> (and he “dwelled”), and not <i>vayagar</i>. In Rashi a different verse is quoted: <i>Sojourn (‘gur’) in this land</i>. (<i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 3.) Now <i>gur</i> has the same root as <i>vayagar</i>. (See preceding note.)</i> Now if so, Abraham was also included in the decree! But the meaning of the verse, <i>And thou shalt come to thy fathers in peace</i>, is that “no punishment will come to you from Me even though I decree on your children punishments of servitude and affliction.”

Verse 16

AND IN THE FOURTH GENERATION THEY SHALL COME BACK HITHER. After they are exiled into Egypt, they will be there for three generations. And thus it happened; Jacob was exiled into Egypt. Go and reckon his generations: Judah, Peretz, Chetzron, and Caleb the son of Chetzron was amongst those who entered the Land. Thus the language of Rashi. But this is not correct at all.<sup class="footnote-marker">326</sup><i class="footnote">Since Chetzron was among those who went down to Egypt (further, 46:12), they were in Egypt for only two generations. And if “the dwelling in a strange land” is to be reckoned as beginning with Abraham, there are seven generations from Abraham to Caleb: Abraham, Isaac, Jacob, Judah, Peretz, Chetzron and Caleb. (Tur.)</i><br>The correct interpretation appears to be that <i>the fourth generation</i> refers to the Amorite whose sin will then become full,<sup class="footnote-marker">327</sup><i class="footnote">Thus enabling Israel to return and take the land from him. (Tur.)</i> for from the day of the decree He prolonged the time of the Amorite, as He visits iniquity upon the third and fourth generation. Had the Amorites repented of their iniquities He would not have utterly destroyed them. Rather, they would have been a levy of bondservants, or they might have gone elsewhere.
THE INIQUITY OF THE AMORITE. He mentioned the strongest among them,<sup class="footnote-marker">328</sup><i class="footnote">Or else He should have mentioned “the Canaanites,” whose name the land carried. The Amorites are specifically singled out for their height by the prophet Amos, mentioned further on.</i> <i>Whose height was like the height of the cedars</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">329</sup><i class="footnote">Amos 2:9. The verse begins: <i>Yet I destroyed the Amorite, whose height.…</i></i> The Israelites would not be able to overpower him until his measure of sin was full and his own iniquities will ensnare him.<sup class="footnote-marker">330</sup><i class="footnote">See Proverbs 5:22.</i> Moreover the Amorite was the first one to be captured by them, and it was his land which they inherited first.<sup class="footnote-marker">331</sup><i class="footnote">The land of Sichon, king of the Amorites, was later the first to be captured by the Israelites. Hence his name is singled out here in the verse.</i>

Verse 17

AND BEHOLD, A SMOKING FURNACE, AND A FLAMING TORCH. It appeared to Abraham as if the furnace was all smoke and in its midst a flaming torch was burning, similar to <i>a great smoke, with a fire flashing up</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">332</sup><i class="footnote">Seen by the prophet Ezekiel (1:4). In the actual verse the word “cloud” appears instead of the word “smoke.”</i> The “smoke” mentioned here is <i>the cloud, and thick darkness</i> mentioned at the giving of the Torah,<sup class="footnote-marker">333</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 4:11.</i> and “the flaming torch” in its midst is “the fire” mentioned there: <i>And thou didst hear His words out of the midst of the fire;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">334</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 36.</i> and it is further written: <i>And the appearance of the glory of the Eternal was like devouring fire</i>, etc.<sup class="footnote-marker">335</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 24:17.</i> Thus the Divine Glory passed between the parts of the sacrifices, and this is the covenant which He made with Abraham forever. This is the meaning of the verse, <i>the Eternal made a covenant with Abraham</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">336</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 18.</i> as the Holy One, blessed be He, Himself carried through “the covenant of between the parts.” The student versed in the mysteries of the Torah will understand.

Verse 18

IN THAT DAY THE ETERNAL MADE A COVENANT WITH ABRAM, SAYING. Now the Holy One, blessed be He, promised Abraham the gift of the land many times, and all of the promises served a purpose. When he originally arrived in the land, He said to him, <i>Unto thy seed will I give this land</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">337</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 12:7.</i> but He did not clarify the extent of His gift, for included in this promise is only the land where he walked, <i>unto the place of Shechem unto the oak of Moreh</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">338</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 6.</i> Afterwards, when his merits increased while in the Land, He bestowed upon him the additional promise: <i>Lift up now thine eyes, and look from the place where thou art, northward and southward, and eastward and westward</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">339</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 13:14.</i> meaning that He will give him all those lands in their totality, for the meaning of the expression, <i>which thou seest</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">340</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 15.</i> is not literally “with your eyes” for the sight of a person does not extend far. Rather, it means that He will give him [land which lies in] every direction in which he looks.
