It may be that He miraculously showed him all the land of Israel, as was the case with Moshe Rabbeinu.<sup class="footnote-marker">341</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 34:1-3.</i> He further added in this second blessing: <i>and to thy seed forever</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">340</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 15.</i> and that his seed will increase <i>as the dust of the earth</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">342</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 13:16.</i> At the third time, He clarified to him the boundaries of the land, mentioning all the ten nations [who presently inhabited it],<sup class="footnote-marker">343</sup><i class="footnote">Here, Verses 19-21.</i> and in addition He made a covenant with him that sin would not cause [the annulment of the gift]. When He commanded him concerning circumcision, He told him, <i>for a possession forever</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">344</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 17:8.</i> that is to say, if they will be exiled from it they will again return and inherit it.<sup class="footnote-marker">345</sup><i class="footnote">The promise, <i>And to thy seed forever</i> (13:15), does not imply that if they will be exiled from the land they will return and re-inherit it. It assures legal title but not necessarily actual possession. However, the expression, <i>for ‘a possession’ forever</i>, does indicate that it is to be their land forever. Hence even if they are exiled they will return and possess it.</i> He also added at that time, <i>And I will be their G-d</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">346</sup><i class="footnote">See Ramban to Leviticus 18:25.</i> meaning that He in His Glory will lead them, and they shall not be under the rule of a star or constellation or any power of the powers above, as will yet be explained in the Torah.<sup class="footnote-marker">346</sup><i class="footnote">See Ramban to Leviticus 18:25.</i><br>Now at the time of the first gift, Scripture states, <i>Unto thy seed will I give</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">337</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 12:7.</i> the verb being in a future tense, and similarly in the second time,<sup class="footnote-marker">347</sup><i class="footnote"><i>To thee will I give it</i>. (Above, 13:15).</i> because until then He had not given him the entire land, and therefore, He said to him, <i>will I give it</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">337</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 12:7.</i> But at the third time, during the covenant, He said, <i>Unto thy seed have I given</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">348</sup><i class="footnote">In Verse 18 here.</i> meaning that He will make the covenant for the gift that He had already given him. Similarly, at the time of the circumcision, when He said, <i>for a possession forever</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">344</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 17:8.</i> He said to him, <i>And I will give unto thee</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">344</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 17:8.</i> in the future tense.<sup class="footnote-marker">349</sup><i class="footnote">Since, as explained above, this promises that if they will be exiled from the land, they will return and inherit it, the future tense refers to this future return to and repossession of the land.</i><br>Rashi wrote: <i>Unto thy seed have I given</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">348</sup><i class="footnote">In Verse 18 here.</i> The word of the Supreme One is as if it were already accomplished. — But there is no need for this explanation in this passage.<sup class="footnote-marker">350</sup><i class="footnote">Instead, the explanation is as set forth above.</i>

Chapter 16



Verse 1



Verse 2

AND ABRAM HEARKENED TO THE VOICE OF SARAI. Scripture does not state, “And he did so.” Rather it says that he hearkened to the voice of Sarai, thus indicating that even though Abram was very desirous of having children, he did not do so without permission of Sarai. Even now it was not his intention to build up a family from Hagar, and that his children be from her. His intent was merely to do Sarai’s will so that she may build a family from Hagar for she will find satisfaction in her handmaid’s children, or that by the merit of this act she will become worthy to have children, as our Rabbis have said.<sup class="footnote-marker">351</sup><i class="footnote">Bereshith Rabbah 71:7.</i><br>Scripture further says, <i>And Sarai took</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">352</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 3 here.</i> to inform us that Abram did not hurry the matter until Sarai took Hagar and gave her to him. Again, Scripture mentions <i>Sarai Abram’s wife… to Abram her husband</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">352</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 3 here.</i> to allude that Sarah did not despair of Abraham and that she did not render herself distant from him as she was his wife and he her husband, but she wanted that Hagar also be his wife. This is why the verse states, <i>And she gave her to Abram her husband to be his wife</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">352</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 3 here.</i> meaning that she was not to be as a concubine but as a woman married to him. All this reflects the ethical conduct of Sarah and her respect towards her husband.

Verse 3

AT THE END OF TEN YEARS. This is the established period for a woman who has lived with her husband for ten years without having given birth to children, after which he is bound to take another.
AFTER ABRAM DWELLED IN THE LAND OF CANAAN. This tells us that the period he dwelled outside of the Land is not to be included in the count of those ten years since he was not told <i>And I will make of thee a great nation</i><sup class="footnote-marker">353</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 12:2.</i> until after he had come to the land of Israel. Thus the language of Rashi.<br>This reason is not proper since it is a clear-cut halachic decision that the time spent living outside the Land is not to be included in the ten year period for any person in the world.<sup class="footnote-marker">354</sup><i class="footnote">Why then did Rashi add, “since the promise, <i>And I will make of thee a great nation</i>, was made to Abraham after he had come to the Land of Israel?” This language would make it appear that only in Abraham’s case was the time spent living outside the Land excluded from the ten year period, when it really applies to everyone.</i> The Mishnah<sup class="footnote-marker">355</sup><i class="footnote">Yebamoth 64a. The Mishnah is the collection of teachings by the Tannaim, compiled by Rabbi Yehuda Hanasi.</i> containing this principle applies to all men. And if it were as Rashi stated it, i.e., on account of this promise made to Abram, then for other people [the years they dwelled outside the land of Israel] should be included in the ten years period!<sup class="footnote-marker">356</sup><i class="footnote">But the law is not so. The years that husband and wife have lived together outside the Land of Israel are not included in the ten years total for anyone, and they begin to count the years after they arrive in the Land.</i> Some Talmudic commentators<sup class="footnote-marker">357</sup><i class="footnote">The forthcoming opinion which Ramban refutes is mentioned in Rabbeinu Asher, Yebamoth, Chapter 6, par. 12, in the name of “some scholars who wish to say.” Rabbeinu Asher also refutes their opinion.</i> have already made another mistake concerning this rule, stating that the law does not require a person who dwells outside the Land to divorce a woman with whom he has lived for ten years without her giving birth, nor does the law require him to marry another woman.<sup class="footnote-marker">358</sup><i class="footnote">Their reasoning being that childlessness may be a form of punishment for living outside the Land. Therefore he need not divorce her. This opinion, however, is refuted, for the law applies everywhere. Only in a case where, after having lived together outside the Land of Israel, husband and wife then move to the Land, the years they lived outside the Land are not included in the ten year period.</i> But the matter is not so. Rather, the intent [of the law which excludes the period one dwells outside the land of Israel from the ten year total] is that if a man lived with his wife for five or ten years outside the Land and then they came to the land of Israel, we give them a period of ten years from the time they came to the Land, for perhaps due to the merit of the Land they will build up a family. And thus did Abraham and Sarah our mother do from the time they came there.

Verse 4



Verse 5



Verse 6

AND SARAI DEALT HARSHLY WITH HER, AND SHE FLED FROM BEFORE HER FACE. Our mother did transgress by this affliction, and Abraham also by his permitting her to do so. And so, G-d heard her [Hagar’s] affliction and gave her a son who would be <i>a wild-ass of a man</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">359</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 12 here.</i> to afflict the seed of Abraham and Sarah with all kinds of affliction.

Verse 7



Verse 8



Verse 9

RETURN TO THY MISTRESS, AND SUBMIT THYSELF UNDER HER HANDS. The angel commanded her to return and accept upon herself the authority of her mistress. This implies that she will not go out free from her, as Sarah’s children will ever rule over her children.

Verse 10



Verse 11

AND THOU SHALT CALL HIS NAME ISHMAEL. The angel informed Hagar that his name will be Ishmael — just as in the verse, <i>Behold, a son shall be born unto the house of David Josiah by name</i><sup class="footnote-marker">360</sup><i class="footnote">I Kings 13:2.</i> — and he told her that she should so call him, and thus remember that G-d heard her affliction.<sup class="footnote-marker">361</sup><i class="footnote">The name <i>Ishmael</i> (G-d heareth) is, as the angel explained to Hagar, “because the Eternal hath heard thy affliction.” (Verse 11.)</i> Now Abraham either called him by this name on his own,<sup class="footnote-marker">362</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 15: <i>And Abraham called the name of his son, whom Hagar bore, Ishmael</i>.</i> with the intent that G-d hear him and answer him, or the Holy Spirit rested upon him, as Rashi has it, and he called him Ishmael because G-d had heard his mother’s affliction, as the angel had said.<br>The correct interpretation appears to me to be that the angel commanded Hagar that she call him so, but she, being a concubine,<sup class="footnote-marker">363</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 3 above is no proof to the contrary, as it may express only Sarai’s desire.</i> was afraid to give a name to her master’s son, so she revealed the matter to him, and Abram fulfilled the word of G-d. Scripture, however, did not need to delve at length into this matter.

Verse 12

‘PERE ADAM.’ Rashi comments: “One who loves the deserts<sup class="footnote-marker">364</sup><i class="footnote">The word <i>pere</i> is thus, according to Rashi, synonymous with “desert,” as it says <i>peraim bamidbar</i> (Job 24:5). <i>Pere adam</i> is thus: “a man who loves the desert.” (Mizrachi.)</i> [and] to hunt wild animals, as it is written, <i>And he dwelt in the wilderness and became an archer</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">365</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 21:20.</i> <i>His hand shall be against every man</i>. This means that he will be a highway man. <i>And every man’s hand against him</i>. Everyone will hate him and attack him.”<br>The correct interpretation is that <i>pere adam</i> is a construct form, meaning that he will be a wild-ass man accustomed to the wilderness, going forth to his work, seeking for food, devouring all and being devoured by all. The subject pertains to his children who will increase, and they will have wars with all the nations.<br>Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra said: “<i>His hand shall be against every man</i> in that he will be victorious at first over all nations, and afterwards, <i>every man’s hand shall be against him</i>, meaning that he will be vanquished in the end. <i>And in the face of all his brethren</i>, who are the sons of Keturah,<sup class="footnote-marker">366</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 25:1-4.</i> <i>he should dwell</i>, meaning that Ishmael’s children will outnumber those of Keturah.”

Chapter 17



Verse 1

‘E-IL SHA-DAI.’ These are two distinct Divine names, each one descriptive in itself.<sup class="footnote-marker">367</sup><i class="footnote">And not as Abraham ibn Ezra has it, i.e., that they both constitute one descriptive noun: “a G-d who is almighty” and “an almighty G-d.”</i> Now the meaning of the word <i>eil</i> is “mighty”, derived from the expression, <i>Eilei Moab</i> (the mighty ones of Moab).<sup class="footnote-marker">368</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 15:15.</i> The meaning of <i>Sha—dai</i>, according to Rashi, is “He whose G-dship suffices for every creature.” In the book Moreh Nebuchim<sup class="footnote-marker">369</sup><i class="footnote">I, 63 (toward the end).</i> the Rabbi<sup class="footnote-marker">294</sup><i class="footnote">Rabbi Moshe ben Maimon (Rambam). See <i>Seder Bereshith</i>, Note 139.</i> explained that the name <i>Sha—dai</i> signifies “he who is sufficient.” That is to say, He does not require the existence of what He created or the conservation of any other being; rather, His existence is self-sufficient. Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra explained in the name of the Nagid<sup class="footnote-marker">370</sup><i class="footnote">Shmuel Hanagid. In our text of Ibn Ezra, it appears anonymously as “And many explain.”</i> that the name is from the root <i>shodeid</i>, meaning “victor and prevailer over the hosts of heaven.” This is the correct interpretation, for the name <i>Sha—dai</i> represents the attribute of power which conducts the world, concerning which the Sages have said that it is “the attribute of Justice of the world below.”<sup class="footnote-marker">371</sup><i class="footnote">Bereshith Rabbah 35:4.</i><br>The reason for mentioning this Divine Name now is that with it are done the hidden miracles<sup class="footnote-marker">372</sup><i class="footnote">All miracles which a man can deny, saying that they are part of the natural order, are called “hidden,” while those that cannot be denied but are clearly the intervention of the power of G-d are called “open.” (Ma’or Veshamesh.) This concept is a major foundation in Ramban’s thinking. It will appear in many other places in a more developed manner. See e.g., further, 46:15; Exodus 6:2; Leviticus 26:11.</i> for the righteous, <i>to deliver their soul from death, and to keep them alive in famine</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">373</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 33:19.</i> as well as to redeem them in war from the power of the sword,<sup class="footnote-marker">374</sup><i class="footnote">See Job 5:20.</i> just as all the miracles done to Abraham and to the other patriarchs, and as all the blessings and curses mentioned in the Torah in the section <i>Im Bechukothai</i><sup class="footnote-marker">375</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 26:3-46.</i> and in the section <i>Vehaya Ki Thavo</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">376</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 28:1-69.</i> These blessings and curses are all miracles for it is not in nature that the rains should come in their due season<sup class="footnote-marker">377</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 26:4.</i> when we worship G-d, nor are the skies to be like iron<sup class="footnote-marker">378</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 19.</i> if we plant our fields in the seventh year, and similarly all promises in the Torah. Rather, they are all miracles by which the disposition of natural law is overpowered, except that no change from the natural order of the world is noticeable, as was the case with the miracles done through Mosheh Rabbeinu with the ten plagues, the dividing of the Sea, the Manna, the well, and their like, for these are miracles which openly changed nature, and they were done with the Tetragrammaton which He told to him. It is for this reason that He now told Abraham our father that He is the Almighty, the Victor Who will prevail over his constellation of birth so that he will have a son, and thus there will be a covenant between Him and his seed forever, meaning <i>that the portion of the Eternal is His people</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">379</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 32:9.</i> and that He will lead them at His own will, as they will not be under the rule of a star or constellation.<br>Know and consider that our father Abraham did not mention the Tetragrammaton [Eternal] in any of his utterances except in combination with the Divine Name written [G-d],<sup class="footnote-marker">380</sup><i class="footnote">Such as in 15:2 above.</i> or in combination with <i>E-il Elyon</i> [G-d Most High],<sup class="footnote-marker">381</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 14:22.</i> but he did mention in his affairs the name <i>Elokim</i> [G-d]. Thus he will say, <i>The Eternal, the G-d of heaven</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">382</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 24:3.</i> He said, however, <i>the Eternal seeth</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">383</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 22:14. In this case Abraham used the Tetragrammaton (Eternal) by itself. This would contradict the principle stated by Ramban above that Abraham never used this Divine Name except in some combination with another Name. Ramban answers that since the reference there is to the Sanctuary which was destined to be built on that mountain in the future and where the sacrifices were to be brought, the Tetragrammaton is the proper name to be used, as will be explained in the beginning of the book of Leviticus when sacrifices are discussed.</i> because it refers to the place of the future Sanctuary. Jacob, on the other hand, always mentioned <i>E-il Sha-dai</i> [G-d Almighty],<sup class="footnote-marker">384</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 43:14; 48:3.</i> which Moses our teacher never mentions. If you will be worthy you will understand this entire matter from that which the Rabbis said in Tractate Yebamoth:<sup class="footnote-marker">385</sup><i class="footnote">49b.</i> “All prophets contemplated Deity through an unlucid speculum,” which is why Isaiah said, <i>And I saw G-d</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">386</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 6:1.</i> [i.e., the Divine Name written <i>Aleph Dalet</i>]. “But Moses contemplated Deity through a lucid speculum.” This is why He said, <i>For a man shall not see Me and live</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">387</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 33:20.</i> whereas Isaiah’s verse, <i>and I saw G-d</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">386</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 6:1.</i> is written with the <i>Aleph Dalet</i>. I will mention this theme again in <i>Parshath Va’eira</i><sup class="footnote-marker">388</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 6:2.</i> if G-d will look upon my grief.<sup class="footnote-marker">389</sup><i class="footnote">A personal reference of Ramban to the difficult times in his life when he was engaged in the writing of this work.</i>
WALK BEFORE ME. i.e., by following the path which I will show you. [This command is similar in] meaning to the verse, <i>After the Eternal G-d shall ye walk, and Him shall ye fear</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">390</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 13:5.</i> except that with respect to a general command to follow His way which precedes His specific instructions, He says, <i>Walk before Me</i>, while with respect to a command which follows the specific command, He says, <i>After the Eternal ye shall walk</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">391</sup><i class="footnote">Here Abraham had not yet specifically been commanded what to do, for the command concerning circumcision was later revealed to him. Hence G-d says to him, <i>Walk ‘before’ Me</i>, meaning “follow the commandment which I will give to you.” But in the verse from Deuteronomy, where the commandments have already been annunciated, the verse properly says, <i>‘After’ the Eternal ye shall walk</i>.</i> The purport of both commands is to walk after G-d, fear Him alone and do whatever He commands.
AND BE THOU WHOLE-HEARTED. This is an additional commandment in this matter, similar in meaning to the verse, <i>Thou shalt be whole-hearted with the Eternal thy G-d</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">392</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 18:13.</i> which follows G-d’s admonition: <i>There shall not be found among you any one that … useth divination, a soothsayer, or an enchanter, or sorcerer</i>, etc.<sup class="footnote-marker">393</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 10.</i> The purport of both verses is that one should believe in his heart that the Holy One, blessed be He, alone is the Omnipotent from beginning to end. It is He who has the power to do and to undo, and therefore he should not listen to the soothsayers and diviners or to the enchanters and the sorcerers. He shall in no way believe that their words shall be fulfilled, but he should decree in his heart that everything is in the hand of the Supreme One, who is G-d, G-d Almighty, Who doeth a person good, which was not predestined by his constellation, and bringeth evil upon him despite a constellation that was good and auspicious. In accordance with the manner in which a man walks before Him, <i>He frustrateth the tokens of the impostors, and maketh diviners mad</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">394</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 44:25.</i> It is this which the Sages had in mind when they said: “[G-d said to Abraham], ‘Go forth from your astrological speculations, etc.’”<sup class="footnote-marker">395</sup><i class="footnote">See above, 15:5.</i><br>Now Rashi explained: “<i>And be thou whole-hearted</i>. Be whole-hearted in all the trials I impose upon you.” And Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra said that the verse means that he should not seek the reason for the commandment of circumcision, it being similar in meaning to the verse: <i>Let my heart be undivided in Thy statutes, in order that I may not be put to shame</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">396</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 119:80.</i> The correct interpretation is as I have explained.

Verse 2



Verse 3

AND ABRAM FELL ON HIS FACE. The purpose of this expression was to direct his mind towards the prophecy. When the prophecy concerning the commandment of circumcision was completed, Abraham rose and stood. When the word from heaven came to him a second time, saying to him, <i>As for Sarai thy wife</i>, etc.,<sup class="footnote-marker">397</sup><i class="footnote">Further, Verse 15.</i> he once again fell on his face to direct his mind towards the prophecy, and he also prayed concerning Ishmael.<sup class="footnote-marker">398</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 18 here.</i> in line with the verses: <i>And they fell upon their faces, and said, O G-d, the G-d of the spirits</i>, etc.;<sup class="footnote-marker">399</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 16:22.</i> <i>That I may consume them in a moment. And they fell upon their faces</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">400</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verses 21-22.</i>

Verse 4

BEHOLD, MY COVENANT IS WITH THEE, AND THOU SHALT BE THE FATHER OF A MULTITUDE OF NATIONS. This refers to the covenant of the circumcision, as He will explain, “This is the sign of the Covenant,<sup class="footnote-marker">401</sup><i class="footnote">In Verse 10: <i>This is my covenant</i>.</i> and after the covenant you will be the father of a multitude of nations.”<br>Blessed be the Lord! By Him alone are actions weighed, for He preceded and commanded Abraham to enter into His covenant to be circumcised before Sarah became pregnant so that his seed would be holy.

Verse 5



Verse 6

AND I WILL MAKE NATIONS OF THEE. The language of Rashi: “Israel and Edom are referred to here, for Ishmael was already born to him, and He could not therefore have been making any announcement concerning him.”<br>But in my opinion it is not correct that He should inform him of Esau at the time of the covenant of circumcision since Esau does not observe circumcision and has not been commanded thereon, as the Sages expounded in Tractate Sanhedrin:<sup class="footnote-marker">402</sup><i class="footnote">59b.</i> “<i>For in Isaac shall seed be called to thee</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">403</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 21:12.</i> but not all of Isaac.”<sup class="footnote-marker">404</sup><i class="footnote">Not <i>all</i> of the children of Isaac, namely Jacob and Esau, but only “in” Isaac, meaning only one, Jacob.</i> Instead, [the proper interpretation is that] Israel alone is called “nations” and “peoples,” as in the verses: <i>Yea, He loveth the peoples;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">405</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 33:3.</i> <i>They shall call peoples unto the mountains;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">406</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 19.</i> <i>After thee, Benjamin, among the peoples</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">407</sup><i class="footnote">Judges 5:14.</i> Even after the birth of all the tribes, He said: <i>A nation and a company of nations shall be of thee;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">408</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 35:11.</i> <i>And I will make of thee a company of peoples</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">409</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 48:4.</i>

Verse 7



Verse 8



Verse 9

‘VE’ATAH’ (AND AS FOR THEE), THOU SHALT KEEP MY COVENANT. Rashi commented, “The <i>vav</i> of <i>ve’atah</i> connects the verse with the preceding matter [in Verse 4]: ‘<i>As for Me behold My covenant is with thee</i>, and as for thee, thou shalt be careful to keep it.’ And what constitutes this ‘keeping’ of it? <i>This is My covenant, which you shall keep, between Me and you</i> — this applies to those who were then alive; <i>and thy seed after thee</i><sup class="footnote-marker">410</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 10 here.</i> — this applies to those who are yet to be born.” The Rabbi is correct in his interpretation of the plain meaning of the verse.<br>Now they<sup class="footnote-marker">411</sup><i class="footnote">This reason is found in the Commentary of R’dak. See also Moreh Nebuchim (III, 49), where other reasons are given.</i> have said concerning the reason for the commandment of circumcision that He has thereby placed a reminder in the organ of lust, which is the source of much trouble and sin, in order that it should not be used excepting where it is commandatory and permissible.<br>By way of truth,<sup class="footnote-marker">412</sup><i class="footnote">A reference to the mystic teachings of the Torah. See <i>Seder Bereshith</i>, Note 63.</i> the meaning of the verse, <i>Behold, My covenant is with thee</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">413</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 4 here.</i> is similar in meaning to the verses: <i>Behold, I am with thee;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">414</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 28:15.</i> <i>And He said, Certainly, I will be with thee;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">415</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 3:12.</i> <i>The Eternal our G-d be with us</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">416</sup><i class="footnote">I Kings 8:57.</i> He is thus saying that the covenant will be with him, and therefore he will be fruitful and multiply. After that He commanded that Abraham keep this covenant, and the circumcision will be as a sign of the covenant. Thus it is that this “sign” is as “the sign” of the Sabbath,<sup class="footnote-marker">417</sup><i class="footnote">Concerning the Sabbath, it is also written: <i>It is a sign forever</i>. (Exodus 31:17.)</i> and therefore circumcision sets aside the Sabbath. Understand this.

Verse 10



Verse 11



Verse 12



Verse 13



Verse 14

AND THE UNCIRCUMCISED MALE. Here Scripture teaches you that this circumcision must be at the location where the distinction between male and female is evident. Thus the words of Rashi. Our Rabbis have likewise mentioned other reasons.<sup class="footnote-marker">418</sup><i class="footnote">Shabbath 108a.</i><br>Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra said:<sup class="footnote-marker">419</sup><i class="footnote">In his commentary to Leviticus 12:3.</i> “<i>his foreskin</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">420</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 12:3.</i> which is known, for it is in the genital organ. But not so are the expressions: <i>uncircumcised in the heart;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">421</sup><i class="footnote">Jeremiah 9:25.</i> <i>uncircumcised lips;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">422</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 6:12.</i> <i>their ear is uncircumcised</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">423</sup><i class="footnote">Jeremiah 6:10.</i> All of these latter are in a construct state.<sup class="footnote-marker">424</sup><i class="footnote">But when the word <i>orlah</i> is not used in the construct state (as in Leviticus 12:3) it refers to the genital organ.</i><br>In my opinion the matter is clearly explained in Scripture. It does not say, “And ye shall circumcise your foreskin,” thus leaving the meaning in doubt, nor does it say, “the foreskin of your flesh,” just as it says <i>the foreskin of your heart</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">425</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 10:16.</i> and “the foreskin of your lips.”<sup class="footnote-marker">426</sup><i class="footnote">I did not find this exact quote. Perhaps reference is to Exodus 6:12, mentioned above.</i> But instead it says, <i>And ye shall circumcise the flesh of your foreskin</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">427</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 11 here.</i> meaning that you are to cut off the flesh which is your foreskin, namely, your flesh which obstructs, and there is no flesh in the body which obstructs and covers a limb [as is the case with the genital organ], where one can cut the flesh and remain without the foreskin, other than the “flesh that covers the corona,” which the Sages mentioned.<sup class="footnote-marker">428</sup><i class="footnote">Shabbath 137a. In our text of the Mishnah there: “flesh that covers ‘the greater part’ of the corona.” Ramban’s version is similar to that of the Talmud Munich Ms. (See Dikduke Sofrim, <i>ibid</i>.)</i> The word “flesh” in the expression, <i>uncircumcised in flesh</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">429</sup><i class="footnote">Ezekiel 44:9.</i> is a euphemism for the genital organ, just as in the verses <i>great of flesh</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">430</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 16:26.</i> and <i>an issue of his flesh</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">431</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 14:2. The word “flesh” in these two verses refers to the genital organ.</i>

Verse 15



Verse 16



Verse 17

‘VAYITZCHAK’ (AND HE LAUGHED). Onkelos translated: “and he rejoiced.” This is correct since the word <i>tzachak</i> can be used intermittently for sporting or rejoicing, just as in the verses: <i>‘Mesacheketh’ (Sporting) in His habitable earth</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">432</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 8:31.</i> <i>‘mesachkim’ (rejoiced) before the Eternal</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">433</sup><i class="footnote">II Samuel 6:5.</i><br>In my opinion the intent of this expression is to convey the thought that whoever sees a favorable unusual event in one’s life rejoices to the point where “his mouth is filled with laughter.”<sup class="footnote-marker">434</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 126:2.</i> It is this thought which Sarah expressed: <i>G-d hath made laughter for me; everyone that heareth will laugh on account of me</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">435</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 21:6.</i> just as in the verse, <i>Then was our mouth filled with laughter, and our tongue with singing</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">434</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 126:2.</i> And this is what Abraham did. When this good tiding was related to him, he rejoiced and his mouth was filled with laughter, <i>and he said in his heart</i> that this is an occasion for rejoicing as it is a very wonderful matter. <i>Shall a child be born unto him that is a hundred years old? and shall Sarah, that is ninety years old, bear?</i> And will this matter not give cause for rejoicing and happiness? Only, Scripture speaks summarily of his wonderment, as it is connected with the word <i>vayitzchak</i>. A similar case is the expression, <i>Have I even here seen</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">436</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 16:13.</i> which is connected with the beginning of the verse: <i>for she</i> [Hagar] <i>said</i>, “<i>Have I even here seen</i> G-d, revealing to me that He saw in my affliction, and shall I not call Him <i>E-il-ro’i</i> [the G-d who seeth me]?” Another such example is the expression, <i>Did I reveal Myself unto the house of thy father</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">437</sup><i class="footnote">I Samuel 2:27.</i> which is connected with the following verse, <i>Why do you kick at My sacrifice and at Mine offering</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">438</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 29.</i> thus stating, “Have I chosen you so that you kick at My sacrifice and Mine offering? Why then do you do so?”<br>It may be that the question, <i>Shall a child be born to him that is a hundred years old?</i> is an expression of amazement, not one of impossibility, just as in the verse, <i>Wilt thou judge the bloody city</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">439</sup><i class="footnote">Ezekiel 22:2.</i> which means, “Do you want to judge her and cause her to know all her abominations?” A similar case is the verse, <i>Wilt thou set thine eyes upon it? it is gone</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">440</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 23:5.</i> Likewise is the verse, <i>Hast thou eaten of the tree, whereof I commanded thee that thou shouldst not eat?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">441</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 3:11.</i> That is to say, “Has the thought occurred to you to eat of the tree?” This verse likewise is saying, “Has the thought occurred to anyone that a child be born to him that is a hundred years old, and that Sarah, who is ninety years, shall bear?” After that Abraham said to Him that he wishes this miracle be with the life of Ishmael.<sup class="footnote-marker">442</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 18 here.</i>
SHALL A CHILD BE BORN TO HIM THAT IS A HUNDRED YEARS OLD? There is no wonder that a person who is a hundred years old should beget children, for men beget as long as they have vigor even if they be ninety years old or a hundred years old, even in these generations. All the more in the days of Abraham, who had not yet lived two thirds of his life.<sup class="footnote-marker">443</sup><i class="footnote">Since Abraham lived 175 years (25:7) and was now only 100, he had not yet passed two-thirds of his life-span. So it is no wonder that he was yet in his vigor.</i> Moreover, forty years after this, he begot many children from Keturah.<sup class="footnote-marker">444</sup><i class="footnote">Further 25:1-2. “Forty years later.” Isaac was wed at the age of forty (25:20), and Abraham married Keturah after Isaac’s marriage (25:1). There was thus an interval of at least forty years between the time Abraham begot Isaac and when he begot children from Keturah.</i> But Abraham’s saying, <i>Shall a child be born to him that is a hundred years old</i>, expressed this thought: Since he did not beget a child from this woman while he was young, how could he beget from her after he was a hundred and she ninety? He knew that her womanly periods had ceased. Therefore Abraham did not say so originally when he was told, <i>And I will make nations of thee</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">445</sup><i class="footnote">Above, Verse 6.</i> but only when he was told that he would beget a child from Sarah.<br>Now He commanded him, <i>And thou shalt call his name Isaac</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">446</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 19 here.</i> on account of the rejoicing done by Abraham, which is proof that it was out of faith and joy [that Abraham said, <i>Shall a child be born</i>, etc.]<sup class="footnote-marker">447</sup><i class="footnote">As explained above. Had it been said out of a sense of derision, G-d would not have told him to call his son by a name which would commemorate his lack of faith. (Bachya.)</i> And after Abraham called him so, as G-d had commanded him, Sarah said, “Is he not rightly named Isaac? For <i>G-d hath made laughter</i> for me.”<sup class="footnote-marker">448</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 21:6.</i>

Verse 18

‘LU’ (O) THAT ISHMAEL MIGHT LIVE BEFORE THEE. The meaning of this word <i>lu</i> everywhere is as the word <i>im</i> (if), and it is also found combined in the word <i>lulei</i>, which means “if not.” [The Hebrew word <i>lulei</i>, ordinarily written with a <i>yud</i> at the end] is sometimes written with an <i>aleph</i> at the end.<sup class="footnote-marker">449</sup><i class="footnote">See Hebrew text of Scripture, <i>ibid.</i>, 43:10.</i> It is also combined into the form of <i>ilu</i>, as in the verses: <i>‘Ve’ilu’ (But if) we had been sold for bondmen and bondwomen;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">450</sup><i class="footnote">Esther 7:4.</i> <i>‘Ve’ilu’ (And if) a thousand years twice told</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">451</sup><i class="footnote">Ecclesiastes 6:6.</i> The purport of this word <i>ilu</i> is “even if,” and its meaning is as if it said, “if if,” the double use of the word being for the purpose of emphasis, as in the expressions: <i>Is it only through Moses alone;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">452</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 12:2. The words “only” and “alone” (<i>harak; ach</i>) are redundant and used for emphasis.</i> <i>Was it because there were no graves;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">453</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 14:11. The Hebrew words <i>hamibli ein</i> are both negatives. Again the redundancy is for special emphasis.</i> and other similar cases. Abraham thus said: “If Ishmael live before Thee, I will be pleased with this blessing with which Thou hast blessed me, namely, with seed from Sarah.” For since He promised him at first, <i>One born of your own body is to be your heir</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">454</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 15:4.</i> and the heir was to be one person, he [Abraham] had thought that this referred to Ishmael. But now that he was told that he will beget a child from Sarah and he understood that this child was to be the heir, he feared lest Ishmael die. Therefore, he said this: [<i>O that Ishmael might live before Thee</i>].<br><i>Live before Thee</i>. Rashi explained: “Live in reverence of Thee, similar in meaning to <i>Walk before Me</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">455</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 1 here.</i> which Onkelos renders, ‘Worship Me.’” But this is not correct, since He said, <i>And as for Ishmael, I have heard thee</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">456</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 20 here. If the sense of Abraham’s prayer is, as Rashi explained, that Ishmael live in reverence of G-d, how could G-d assure him of that, since, as the Sages express it, “Everything is by hand of Heaven except the fear of Heaven,” (Berachoth 33 b) which is in the hands of man to be determined by his free choice. (Mizrachi.)</i> Instead, its meaning is that he live and his seed will always exist.

Verse 19

‘AVAL’ SARAH THY WIFE. This is like the verse, <i>“Aval” she has no son</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">457</sup><i class="footnote">II Kings 4:14.</i> the word <i>aval</i> meaning “only.” He thus said: “Only the son of whom I informed you, your wife Sarah will give birth to, and with him will I establish My covenant forever and with his seed after him; and Ishmael I will bless by making his children numerous, but this will not be because of My covenant with him.”

Verse 20



Verse 21



Verse 22

AND G-D WENT UP FROM ABRAHAM. This is an expression of respect towards G-d,<sup class="footnote-marker">458</sup><i class="footnote">Since the <i>Shechinah</i> was standing <i>beside</i> Abraham, why then is it written, <i>And He went up</i>, suggesting that G-d had been <i>above</i> him? It is out of respect to G-d that this is so written. (Gur Aryeh.)</i> and we learn from it that the righteous are the Chariot of the Holy One, blessed be He. Thus the language of Rashi. But the saying of the Sages in the Bereshith Rabbah<sup class="footnote-marker">459</sup><i class="footnote">47:8.</i> is: “It is the patriarchs<sup class="footnote-marker">460</sup><i class="footnote">But not the other righteous.</i> that constitute the Chariot.” This is an allusion to that which is written: <i>Thou wilt give truth to Jacob, kindness to Abraham;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">461</sup><i class="footnote">Micah 7:20.</i> <i>And the Fear of Isaac had been on my side</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">462</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 31:42.</i> The student learned [in the mysteries of the Torah] will understand.

Verse 23



Verse 24



Verse 25



Verse 26

IN THE SELFSAME DAY WAS ABRAHAM CIRCUMCISED. Rashi wrote: “<i>In the selfsame day</i> when Abraham completed his ninety-ninth year and Ishmael his thirteenth, they were circumcised.”<br>But what reason is there to mention this? Moreover, there is already general agreement with the words of Rabbi Eliezer<sup class="footnote-marker">463</sup><i class="footnote">Rosh Hashanah 12 a; also <i>ibid.</i>, 27a. See also <i>Seder Noach</i>, Note 148, for fuller discussion of this point.</i> who said that in the month of Tishri the world was created, and in Tishri the patriarchs were born, with the exception of Isaac who was born on Passover. Now Scripture says that the birth of Isaac will be <i>at this time in the next year</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">464</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 21 here.</i> and Rashi himself wrote further on in <i>Seder Vayeira</i><sup class="footnote-marker">465</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 18:10.</i> that the tidings were given on Passover. Consequently, Isaac was born on the next Passover!<sup class="footnote-marker">466</sup><i class="footnote">How then could Rashi say that on this selfsame day Abraham completed his ninety-ninth year, thus making Passover his birthday, when the consensus of opinion is, as Rabbi Eliezer says, that the patriarchs were born in Tishri?</i><br>Instead, the expression, <i>In the selfsame day</i>, means that on the very day he was charged with this commandment, he and the men of his house — three hundred and eighteen<sup class="footnote-marker">467</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 14:14.</i> — and all those purchased with his money were circumcised. Scripture thus tells of Abraham’s distinction with respect to the fear of G-d, as well as that of all the men of his house, i.e., that they were all zealous, fulfilling their religious duty as promptly as possible.<br>Now the meaning of the phrase, <i>was Abraham circumcised and Ishmael his son</i>, is not that Abraham was circumcised first. Instead, it was Ishmael who was circumcised first, and then all the men of Abraham’s house, for it is so written: <i>And Abraham took Ishmael his son, and all that were born in his house</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">468</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 23 here.</i> and after that it says, <i>And Abraham was ninety years and nine when he was circumcised</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">469</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 24 here.</i> The reason for this was that Abraham was zealous concerning the commandment to circumcise them first, either doing it himself or perhaps inviting many circumcisers whom he supervised, and then he circumcised himself. Had he performed his circumcision first, he would have been sick or in danger on account of his advanced age, and he would then not have been in a position to concern himself with their circumcision.<br>Vayeira

Chapter 18



Verse 1

AND HE APPEARED TO HIM. Rashi comments: “To visit the sick man. Said Rabbi Chama the son of Chanina, ‘It was the third day after his circumcision, and the Holy One, blessed be He, came and inquired after him.’<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">“After him.” In our text of Rashi: “after the state of his health.”</i> <i>And, lo, three men:</i><sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 2 here.</i> angels who came to him in the form of men. <i>Three:</i> one to announce to Sarah that she would bear a son, one to heal Abraham, and one to overthrow Sodom. Raphael who healed Abraham went from there to rescue Lot” for these do not constitute two commissions.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">“One angel does not carry out two commissions.” (Bereshith Rabbah 50:2 and mentioned in Rashi here.) But, continues Ramban, these two missions given to the angel Raphael—healing Abraham and rescuing Lot from Sodom—do not violate the principle. See text.</i> This is because the second mission was in another place, and he was commanded thereon after [he had completed his first mission].<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">It is as if he was sent on a new mission in another place after he had completed his mission in a different place. For it is clear that the principle of one angel not carrying out two commissions applies only to two simultaneous commissions, as explained in Mizrachi’s commentary on Rashi.</i> Perhaps it is because the two missions had rescue as their common goal.<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">Since healing and rescue are missions with a common purpose, one angel could be charged with both missions.</i> “<i>And they did eat:</i><sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 8 here.</i> they appeared to be eating.”<br>In the book Moreh Nebuchim<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">Ibn Tibbon’s translation, II, 42: in Al Charizi, Chapter 43.</i> it is said that this portion of Scripture consists of a general statement followed by a detailed description. Thus Scripture first says that the Eternal appeared to Abraham in the form of prophetic visions, and then explains in what manner this vision took place, namely, that he [Abraham] lifted up his eyes in the vision, <i>and lo, three men stood by him</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 2 here.</i> <i>and he said, if now I have found favor in thy eyes</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 3 here.</i> This is the account of what he said in the prophetic vision to one of them, namely, their chief.<br>Now if in the vision there appeared to Abraham only men partaking of food, how then does Scripture say, <i>And the Eternal appeared to him</i>, as G-d did not appear to him in vision or in thought?<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">In other words, why does Scripture begin the chapter with the statement, <i>And the Eternal appeared to him</i>, when in the detailed account of the vision it is explained that he saw only angels?</i> Such is not found with respect to all the prophecies. And according to his<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">The author of the Moreh Nebuchim.</i> words, Sarah did not knead cakes, nor did Abraham prepare a bullock, and also, Sarah did not laugh. It was all a vision! If so, this dream came <i>through a multitude of business</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">See Ecclesiastes 5:2.</i> like dreams of falsehood, for what is the purpose of showing him all this!<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">Since the vision concerning the preparation and the eating of the meal were not relevant to the prophecy of the birth of Isaac.</i> Similarly did the author of the Moreh Nebuchim say<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">Ibn Tibbon’s translation, II, 42: in Al Charizi, Chapter 43.</i> in the case of the verse, <i>And a man wrestled with him</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 32:25. The reference deals with Jacob wrestling with the angel.</i> that it was all a prophetic vision. But if this be the case, I do not know why Jacob limped on his thigh when he awoke! And why did Jacob say, <i>For I have seen an angel face to face, and my life is preserved?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 31.</i> The prophets did not fear that they might die on account of having experienced prophetic visions. Jacob, moreover, had already seen a greater and more distinguished vision than this since many times, in prophetic visions, he had also seen the Revered Divinity.<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 28:13.</i> Now according to this author’s opinion, he will find it necessary for the sake of consistency to say similarly in the affair of Lot that the angels did not come to his house, nor did he bake for them <i>unleavened bread and they did eat</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 19:3.</i> Rather, it was all a vision! But if Lot could ascend to the height of a prophetic vision, how did the wicked and sinful people of Sodom become prophets? Who told them that men had come into Lot’s house? And if all these [i.e., the actions of the inhabitants of Sodom], were part of prophetic visions, then it follows that the account related in the verses, <i>And the angels hastened Lot, saying: Arise take thy wife. …And he said, Escape for thy life… See, I have accepted thee</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verses 17-21.</i> as well as the entire chapter is but a vision, and if so, Lot could have remained in Sodom! But the author of the Moreh Nebuchim thinks that the events took place of themselves, but the conversations relating to all matters were in a vision! But such words contradict Scripture. It is forbidden to listen to them, all the more to believe in them!<br>In truth,<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">Ramban partially agrees with Rambam’s position. He says that wherever seeing or hearing an angel is mentioned in Scripture, it refers to a vision since the human senses can not perceive an angel. However, wherever Scripture ascribes human appearances to the angels, as in the case of Abraham, then their presence is sensually perceived. Other differences of opinion between Ramban and Rambam regarding prophecy are mentioned further on in the text.</i> wherever Scripture mentions an angel being seen or heard speaking it is in a vision or in a dream for the human senses cannot perceive the angels. But these are not visions of prophecy since he who attains the vision of an angel or the hearing of his speech is not yet a prophet. For the matter is not as the Rabbi<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">Rabbi Moshe ben Maimon (Maimonides). See <i>Seder Bereshith</i>, Note 139.</i> pronounced,<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">Moreh Nebuchim, II, 41.</i> i.e., that every prophet, Moses our teacher excepted, received his prophecy through the medium of an angel. The Sages have already said<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">Megillah 3a.</i> concerning Daniel: “They<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">Haggai, Zechariah and Malachi—three prophets who lived at the beginning of the second Temple.</i> were greater than he for they were prophets and he was not a prophet.” His book, likewise, was not grouped together<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">The Men of the Great Assembly redacted the books of the Bible. See Baba Bathra 15a. They placed the book of Daniel in the section of the Writings. (<i>Ibid.</i>, 14 b).</i> with the books of the prophets since his affair was with the angel Gabriel, even though he appeared to him and spoke with him when he was awake, as it is said in the vision concerning the second Temple: <i>Yea, while I was speaking in prayer, the man Gabriel</i>,etc.<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">Daniel 9:1.</i> The vision concerning the ultimate redemption<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">From the beginning of Chapter 10 there.</i> also occurred when Daniel was awake as he walked with his friends beside the Tigris River.<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 10:4. As for his friends, see <i>ibid.</i>, Verse 7. Tradition specifies that these were Haggai, Zechariah and Malachi. (Megillah 3a.)</i> Hagar the Egyptian<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote">She was not a prophetess even though angels appeared to her. (Above, 16: 7.) Ramban thus differs with Rambam, who had said that all prophets received the prophecy through the medium of an angel. Rambam’s position is defended as follows: Rambam’s intent was not that whenever an angel is seen it is an instance of prophecy. Rather his intent was that whenever prophecy comes to any of the prophets it comes through an angel. However, it is possible that an angel may appear for the purpose of conveying information to one who is not a prophet. This was the case with Daniel and Hagar.</i> is not included in the group of prophetesses.<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">In Megillah 14 a, the Rabbis list seven prophetesses who arose in Israel: Sarah, Miriam, Deborah, Hannah, Abigail, Huldah and Esther. Hagar however was not listed among them. See Note 103 further.</i> It is also clear that hers was not a case of the <i>bath kol</i> (prophetic echo),<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote">Guide of the Perplexed, II, 42. See Friedlander’s note on <i>bath kol</i>, p. 199, n.2.</i> as the Rabbi<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">Rabbi Moshe ben Maimon (Maimonides). See <i>Seder Bereshith</i>, Note 139.</i> would have it. Scripture, furthermore, sets apart the prophecy of Moses our teacher from that of the patriarchs, as it is said, <i>And I appeared unto Abraham, unto Isaac, and unto Jacob, by</i> [the name of] <i>G-d Almighty</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 6:3.</i> this name being one of the sacred names for the Creator, and not a designation for an angel. Our Rabbis also taught concerning the difference in the degree of prophecy between Moses and the other prophets, and they said:<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">Vayikra Rabbah 1:14.</i> “What is the difference between Moses and all the prophets? The Rabbis say that all prophets saw through unclear vision. It is to this matter that Scripture refers in saying, <i>And I have multiplied visions, and by the ministry of the prophets have I used similitudes</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote">Hosea 12:11.</i> Moses saw through a clear vision. It is to this matter that Scripture refers in saying, <i>And the similitudes of the Eternal doth he behold</i>,”<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 12:8.</i> as is explained in Vayikra Rabbah<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">Vayikra Rabbah 1:14.</i> and other places. But in no place did the Sages attribute the prophecy of the prophets to an angel.<br>Do not expose yourself to argument by quoting the verse, <i>I also am a prophet as thou art; and an angel spoke unto me by the word of the Eternal, saying</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote">I Kings 13:18. From this you might argue that the prophets themselves attributed their prophecy to an angel. This is not correct, as is explained in the text.</i> since its meaning is as follows: “I also am a prophet as thou art, and I know that the angel who spoke to me was by word of G-d, this being one of the degrees of prophecy, as the man of G-d said, <i>For so was it charged me by the word of the Eternal</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 9.</i> and he further said, <i>For it was said to me by the word of the Eternal</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 17.</i><br>Our Rabbis have further stated<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote">Bamidbar Rabbah 20:13.</i> in the matter of Balaam, who said, <i>Now, therefore, if it displease thee, I will get me back</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 22:34.</i> [that is as if Balaam commented]: “I did not go [with the messengers of Balak] until the Holy One, blessed be He, told me, <i>Rise up, go with them</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 22:20.</i> and you [i.e., an angel], tell me that I should return. Such is His conduct! Did He not tell Abraham to sacrifice his son, after which the angel of the Eternal called to Abraham, <i>And he said, Lay not thy hand upon the lad</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 22:12.</i> He is accustomed to saying something and to have an angel revoke it, etc.” Thus the Sages were prompted to say that the prophecy comprising the first charge where G-d is mentioned is not like the second charge of which it is said that it was through an angel, only this was not unusual, for it is customary with the prophets that He would command by a prophecy and revoke the command through an angel since the prophet knew that the revocation was the word of G-d.<br>In the beginning of Vayikra Rabbah<sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote">1:9.</i> the Sages have said: “<i>And He called to Moses</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">42</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 1:1.</i> unlike Abraham. Concerning Abraham it is written, <i>And the angel of the Eternal called unto Abraham a second time out of heaven</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 22:15.</i> The angel called, and G-d spoke the word, but here with respect to Moses, the Holy One, blessed be He, said, ‘It is I Who called, and it is I Who spoke the word.’” That is to say, Abraham did not attain prophecy until he prepared his soul first to perceive an angel, and from that degree he ascended to attain the word of prophecy, but Moses was prepared for prophecy at all times.<br>Thus the Sages were prompted to inform us everywhere that seeing an angel is not prophecy, and those who see angels and speak with them are not included among the prophets, as I have mentioned concerning Daniel. Rather, this is only a vision called “opening of eyes,” as in the verse: <i>And the Eternal opened the eyes of Balaam, and he saw the angel of the Eternal;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 22:31.</i> similarly: <i>And Elisha prayed, and said, O Eternal, I pray thee, open his eyes, that he may see</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">45</sup><i class="footnote">II Kings 6:17.</i> But where Scripture mentions the angels as men, as is the case in this portion, and the portion concerning Lot — likewise, <i>And a man wrestled with him</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 32:25. The reference deals with Jacob wrestling with the angel.</i> <i>And a certain man found him</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">46</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 37:15.</i> in the opinion of our Rabbis<sup class="footnote-marker">47</sup><i class="footnote">According to the Sages the man who wrestled with Jacob was the angel of Esau (Bereshith Rabbah 77:2), and the man who found Joseph was the angel Gabriel (Tanchuma Vayeshev 2).</i> — in all these cases there was a special glory created in the angels, called among those who know the mysteries of the Torah “a garment,” perceptible to the human vision of such pure persons as the pious and the disciples of the prophets, and I cannot explain any further. And in those places in Scripture where you find the sight of G-d and the speech of an angel, or the sight of an angel and the speech of G-d, as is written concerning Moses at the outset of his prophecy,<sup class="footnote-marker">48</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 3:2.</i> and in the words of Zechariah,<sup class="footnote-marker">49</sup><i class="footnote">Zechariah 1:14, etc.</i> I will yet disclose words of the living G-d in allusions.<br>Concerning on the matter of the verse, <i>And they did eat</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 8 here.</i> the Usages have said:<sup class="footnote-marker">50</sup><i class="footnote">Bereshith Rabbah 48:16.</i> “One course after the other disappeared.”<sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote">That is, the angels really did not eat. Rather as soon as a dish of food was brought, it was consumed by fire.</i> The matter of “disappearance” you will understand from the account about Manoah,<sup class="footnote-marker">52</sup><i class="footnote">Judges 13:19.</i> if you will be worthy to attain it.<br>Now here is the interpretation of this portion of Scripture. After it says that <i>In the selfsame day was Abraham circumcised</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">53</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 17:26.</i> Scripture says that G-d appeared to him while he was sick from the circumcision as he was sitting and cooling himself in his tent door on account of the heat of the day which weakened him. Scripture mentions this in order to inform us that Abraham had no intention for prophecy. He had neither fallen on his face nor prayed, yet this vision did come to him.
IN THE OAKS OF MAMRE. This is to inform us of the place wherein he was circumcised.<br/>Now this revelation of the <i>Shechinah</i> (the Divine Presence) came to Abraham as a mark of distinction and honor, even as it is said in connection with the dedication of the Tabernacle, <i>And they</i> [Moses and Aaron] <i>came out, and blessed the people, and the glory of the Eternal appeared unto all the people</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">54</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 9:23.</i> as it was on account of their effort in fulfilling the commandment of building the Tabernacle that they merited seeing the <i>Shechinah</i>. Now the revelation of the <i>Shechinah</i> here and there was not at all for the purpose of charging them with some commandment or to impart some communication. Instead, it was a reward for the commandment which had already been performed, and it informed them that their deeds have G-d’s approval, even as it says, <i>As for me, I shall behold Thy face in righteousness; I shall be satisfied, when I awake, with Thy likeness</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">55</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 17:15.</i> Similarly, in connection with Jacob, Scripture says, <i>And the angels of G-d met him</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">56</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 32:2.</i> and yet we find no communication there, nor is any new matter conveyed. Instead, the verse only informs us that he merited seeing angels of the Supreme One, and thus he knew that his deeds had His approval. And so it was with Abraham: the seeing of the <i>Shechinah</i> (the Divine Presence) was both merit [for his having performed the commandment of circumcision] and assurance of G-d’s approval.<br/>Similarly did the Sages say<sup class="footnote-marker">57</sup><i class="footnote">Mechilta Shirah 3.</i> of those who passed through the Red Sea and said, <i>This is my G-d, and I will glorify Him:</i><sup class="footnote-marker">58</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 15:2.</i> “A handmaid saw at the sea what Ezekiel the prophet never saw.” This they merited at the time of the great miracle because <i>they believed in the Eternal, and in Moses his servant</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">59</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 14:31.</i><br/>At times the appearance of the <i>Shechinah</i> comes in a moment of anger, as mentioned in the verse: <i>And the whole congregation bade stone them with stones, when the glory of the Eternal appeared in the tent of meeting unto all the children of Israel</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">60</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 14:10.</i> That was for the protection of His righteous servants and their honor.<br/>Now do not be concerned about the interruption of the portion<sup class="footnote-marker">61</sup><i class="footnote">Since, as Ramban explains, the appearance of the Eternal to Abraham was in the merit of his having fulfilled the commandment of circumcision, one might ask: Why then are these two events presented in two different sections rather than in one consecutive chapter? It is to this point that Ramban now addresses himself. “Now do not be concerned, etc.,” for the events are after all connected.</i> since the subject is after all connected. It is for this reason that the verse says, <i>And He appeared to him</i>, and it does not say, “And the Eternal appeared to Abraham.” But in this present chapter Scripture wishes to give an account of the honor that was bestowed upon him [Abraham] at the time he performed the circumcision, and it tells that the <i>Shechinah</i> appeared to him and sent him His angels to inform his wife [that she would give birth to a son], and also to save his relative Lot on his account. Abraham had already been informed by the <i>Shechinah</i> concerning the birth of a son,<sup class="footnote-marker">62</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 17:19.</i> and Sarah was now informed by word of the angel who spoke with Abraham in order that Sarah should hear, even as it says, <i>And Sarah heard</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">63</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 10 here.</i><br/>This is the intent of the Sages’ saying,<sup class="footnote-marker">64</sup><i class="footnote">Baba Metziah 86b. Also quoted in Rashi above.</i> “G-d came to visit the sick man,” meaning that it was not for the purpose of some utterance but as a mark of honor to him.<br/>They have also said,<sup class="footnote-marker">65</sup><i class="footnote">Bereshith Rabbah 48:4.</i> “<i>An altar of earth thou shalt make unto Me</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">66</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 20:24.</i> Now if any person just built an altar to My name, he is assured that I will appear unto him and bless him.<sup class="footnote-marker">67</sup><i class="footnote">As Scripture concludes: <i>I will come unto thee and bless thee</i>. (Exodus 20:25.)</i> All the more is such assurance given to Abraham who circumcised himself for My name.”<br/>It is possible that the Sages may have further intended to say [by their remark, “He came to visit the sick man,”] that the vision of the <i>Shechinah</i> was a cure for his sickness on account of the circumcision, for so it should be, as it is written, <i>In the light of the King’s countenance is life</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">68</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 16:15.</i>

Verse 2

STOOD OVER HIM. The purport thereof is that they were standing opposite Abraham and looking at him, the expression being similar to: <i>that stood over the reapers;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">69</sup><i class="footnote">Ruth 2:6.</i> <i>the chief officers that stood over the work</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">70</sup><i class="footnote">I Kings 5:30.</i> And due to the fact that he [Abraham] was sitting and they were standing and looking at him, the verse says, “over him.” This is also the meaning of the expression, <i>And he saw, and ran to meet them</i>, for as he saw them standing opposite him and not continuing their journey, he ran to meet them in order to bring them to his house.<br/>The sense of the expression, <i>From the tent door</i>, is that Abraham was still sitting there after the vision of the <i>Shechinah</i> had departed from him.<br/>It is possible that the expression “over him” refers to the tent, i.e., that they were near it on the side which was not opposite the door, and there they stood and did not approach Abraham, just as in the verse, <i>encamping ‘al’ (on) the sea.</i><sup class="footnote-marker">71</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 14:9. Meaning “encamping alongside the sea.” Here too <i>alav</i> means “standing alongside him.”</i>

Verse 3

‘ADONAY,’ IF NOW I HAVE FOUND FAVOR IN THY EYES. We find the word <i>Adonay</i> here in the books marked with a <i>kamatz</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">72</sup><i class="footnote">A word whose end is voweled with a <i>kamatz</i> stands by itself and is not in construct form. This is not the case with a word whose end is voweled with a <i>patach</i>. Thus, <i>Ado-noy</i> voweled with a <i>kamatz</i>, must have reference only to G-d, but <i>Adonay</i> voweled with a <i>patach</i>, has a “profane” sense and does not refer to G-d. Ramban continues: Since we find the word in this verse written in the books with a <i>kamatz</i>, and Abraham was speaking to the angels, it must be because he referred to them by the name of their Master.</i> Thus it must be that he called them by the name of their Master, i.e., with the <i>Aleph Dalet</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">73</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ado-noy.</i></i> as he recognized them to be angels of the Supreme One, even as they are called <i>elohim</i> and <i>eilim</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">74</sup><i class="footnote">See Ramban, Exodus 20:3 and Leviticus 18:27.</i> For this reason he bowed down to the earth to them.
PASS NOT AWAY, I PRAY THEE, FROM THY SERVANT. Abraham spoke to each one of the angels, as is the way of the whole Torah: <i>Ye shall keep all My statutes… and do them;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">75</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 20:22. According to the author of Kesef Mezukak, the verse here should be [<i>ibid.</i> 18:5]: <i>Ye shall keep My statutes, and Mine ordinances, which if a man do….</i> Here, as in the succeeding examples, the verse begins with a plural and ends with a singular because the Torah speaks to each person.</i> <i>The nakedness of thy father, and the nakedness of thy mother, shalt thou not uncover;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">76</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 18:7.</i> <i>And when ye reap the harvest of your land, thou shalt not wholly reap the corner of thy field;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">77</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 19:9.</i> <i>And from thence ye will seek the Eternal thy G-d, and thou shalt find Him, if thou search after Him with all thy heart and with all thy soul</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">78</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 4:29.</i> The greater part of the <i>Mishneh Torah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">79</sup><i class="footnote">The book of Deuteronomy. See <i>ibid.</i>, 17:18, for origin of the expression.</i> is written in this manner. A counter-example to the above is the verse: <i>Behold, I set before you this day a blessing and a curse</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">80</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 11:26. Here He speaks to the whole congregation as a unit and not to each person individually.</i><br>Now our Rabbis have said,<sup class="footnote-marker">81</sup><i class="footnote">Bereshith Rabbah 48:9.</i> “Abraham spoke to the chief of the angels.”<sup class="footnote-marker">82</sup><i class="footnote">According to this opinion, the word <i>Adonay</i> does not refer to G-d.</i> It is also possible that he said to the chief, “<i>Pass not away, I pray thee</i>, [in the singular sense], and thou and thy companions who will remain with thee wash your feet,” [the verb “wash” being in the plural form].<br>The correct interpretation appears to me to be that he called them all “lords,” and he turned to each individual, saying to the first one: <i>If now I have found favor in thy eyes, pass not away</i>, and to the second one he said the same, and the same to the third one. He begged each one individually: <i>If now I have found favor in thy eyes, pass not away, and, let now a little water be fetched, and all of ye wash your feet</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">83</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 4 here.</i> This was by way of ethical conduct and respect out of his great desire to show kindness towards them. Now he recognized them as transients who did not have the desire to lodge there. This is why he asked of them only that a little water be fetched to wash their feet a little from the heat, to give <i>cold waters to a faint soul</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">84</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 25:25.</i> and that they recline under the tree in the cool of the day without coming into the tent and the tabernacle.

Verse 4



Verse 5

FORASMUCH AS YE PASSED BY. Since your path crossed near me, it is not proper that you should not rest a little with me.<br><i>So do, as thou hast said</i>. This is an ethical expression indicating that a morsel of bread will be sufficient.<sup class="footnote-marker">85</sup><i class="footnote">Since it should have stated, “<i>We</i> will do as thou hast said,” and instead it says, “So <i>thou</i> do, as thou hast said,” Abraham ibn Ezra takes it to mean “So do, as thou hast spoken: <i>And I will take a morsel of bread</i>, and do not trouble thyself for more.”</i> Thus the language of Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra.<br>It may be that the verse is stating, “So shalt thou do to us, that we recline under the tree and pass immediately as we are messengers, and therefore do not detain us by making us come into the tent or lodge with you.”

Verse 6

MEAL, FINE FLOUR. The fine flour for the cakes; the meal for the dough used by cooks to place over the pot to absorb the scum. Thus the words of Rashi. And so it is found in Bereshith Rabbah.<sup class="footnote-marker">86</sup><i class="footnote">48:13, with changes.</i> Now there the Sages explained that there were three measures of meal and three measures of fine flour for each one of the guests. But we do not know why he served so much bread for three men. Perhaps he was aware of how the food disappeared successively,<sup class="footnote-marker">87</sup><i class="footnote">See above, Note 51.</i> and it was as if he was offering more Burnt-offerings upon the altar, or perhaps because in their honor chiefs of his house dined with them.<br>By way of the simple meaning [of Scripture, the verse is to be interpreted as follows: <i>Make ready quickly three measures of meal</i> to make of them <i>fine flour</i>. Thus from the entire three measures of meal, they extracted a bit of fine flour.

Verse 7

AND ABRAHAM RAN UNTO THE HERD. The purport thereof is to tell us of his great desire to bestow kindness. This great man had three hundred and eighteen men<sup class="footnote-marker">88</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 14:14.</i> in his house, each one a swordsman, and he was very old and weakened by his circumcision, yet he went personally to Sarah’s tent to urge her in the making of the bread, and afterwards he ran to the place of the herd to chose <i>a calf, tender and good</i>, to prepare for his guests, and he did not have all these done by means of one of his servants who stood ready to serve him.

Verse 8



Verse 9



Verse 10

I WILL CERTAINLY RETURN UNTO THEE WHEN THE SEASON COMETH AROUND. Rashi comments, “The angel was not announcing that he would return to him, but he was speaking to him as G-d’s agent, [meaning that G-d would return]. This is similar to the verse: <i>And the angel of the Eternal said to her [Hagar], I will multiply thy seed exceedingly</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">89</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 16:10.</i> But he [the angel] has no power to multiply, and he was therefore speaking as G-d’s agent. So also here, he spoke as G-d’s agent.”<br>Now the Rabbi<sup class="footnote-marker">90</sup><i class="footnote">Rashi. See <i>Seder Bereshith</i>, Note 139.</i> found it necessary to say so because the Holy One, blessed be He, told Abraham here, <i>At the set time I will return unto thee</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">91</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 14 here. The words of the angel, in Verse 10 here, <i>I will certainly return unto thee</i>.</i> However, whether it be a reference to the angel or to the Holy One, blessed be He, we do not find it recorded that at the set time He returned. Perhaps a reference to this return is included in the expression, <i>And the Eternal remember-ed Sarah, as He had said, and the Eternal did unto Sarah as He had spoken</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">92</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 21:1.</i><br>Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra said that the verse beginning, <i>And the Eternal said to Abraham</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">93</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 14 here. It ends with the promise: <i>At the same time I will return unto thee</i>.</i> means that the angel said it in the name of Him Who sent him, and he did return at the set time which he had told him, even though it is not written in Scripture.<br>The correct interpretation appears to me to be that [the expression, <i>shov ashuv (I will certainly return)</i>], is akin to the phrase, <i>liteshuvath hashanah (at the return of the year)</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">94</sup><i class="footnote">II Samuel 11:1.</i> The verse is thus stating: “I will surely bring back to thee a time as this time, that you will be alive and Sarah your wife will have a son.” This is similar to what was said to Abraham, <i>At this set time in the next year</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">95</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 17:21.</i> The word <i>ashuv</i> will then be like, <i>‘Veshav’ (And) the Eternal your G-d (will bring back) thy captivity and have compassion upon thee and will return and gather thee</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">96</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 30:3. Ramban’s intent is as follows: The word <i>ve’shov</i> there means “and He will bring back.” Here too the word <i>ashuv</i> means “I will bring back a time, like the present, in which you will be alive, and in which time, in addition to your being alive, Sarah will have a son.”</i>

Verse 11

‘BA’IM BAYAMIM’ (ADVANCED IN DAYS). In his youthful days a man is called “standing in days,” and they are referred to as “his days” because they belong to him, just as in verse <i>The number of thy days will I fulfill</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">97</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 23:26.</i> But when he gets old and has lived longer than most people of his generation, it is said of him that he is <i>ba bayamim</i>, [literally, “came into days”], because it is as if he came into another land, travelling from and arriving in a city each and every day.
IT HAD CEASED TO BE WITH SARAH AFTER THE MANNER OF WOMEN. This is the time of pregnancy, for after menstruation has ceased due to old age, a woman will not become pregnant.

Verse 12



Verse 13

I BEING OLD. This is the explanation of Sarah’s words, <i>after I am waxed old</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">98</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 12 here.</i> And G-d’s words [that Sarah had said, “I being <i>old</i>“], were true, but for the sake of peace He did not reveal what she also said, namely, <i>My lord being old also</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">98</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 12 here.</i> for [if He were quoting Sarah], He should have said, “I and my lord are old,” as Sarah had laughed concerning both of them.

Verse 14

IS ANYTHING TOO HARD (‘HAYIPALEI’) FOR THE ETERNAL? Is anything too hard and improbable for G-d to cause to happen? This expression is similar to the verse, <i>For all things come of Thee, and of Thine own have we given Thee</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">99</sup><i class="footnote">I Chronicles 29:14. Here the word “come” is not found in the Hebrew but is added to complete the thought.
