Likewise, Ramban suggests, in our own verse here, the expression “to cause to happen” is to be added: “Is anything too hard for G-d to cause to happen?”</i> Likewise, <i>Out of Asher his fat bread</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">100</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 49:20.</i> meaning “Out of Asher will come fat bread.”<br>Onkelos translated: “Is anything hidden?” He interpreted it as similar to the expression, <i>If there arise a matter hidden (‘yipalei’) for thee in judgment</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">101</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 17:8.</i> If so, there is a hidden secret here.<br>Rashi’s language: “<i>Hayipalei</i>, is anything apart and hidden from Me that I cannot do as I would wish?” Rashi has thus grafted together in [the word <i>hayipalei</i>] two separate concepts.<sup class="footnote-marker">102</sup><i class="footnote">Hidden and apart.</i>

Verse 15

AND SARAH DENIED, SAYING. I wonder about the righteous prophetess:<sup class="footnote-marker">103</sup><i class="footnote">See above, Note 28, that Sarah was regarded as a prophetess.</i> How did she deny that which G-d had said to the prophet,<sup class="footnote-marker">104</sup><i class="footnote">Abraham. In Megillah 14 a, Rashi quotes the Hilchoth Gedoloth listing the forty-eight prophets who arose in Israel, and the three patriarchs are listed among them.</i> and also, why did she not believe in the words of G-d’s angels?<br>The answer appears to me to be that these angels who appeared as men came to Abraham, and he, in his wisdom, recognized them. They announced to him, “<i>I will certainly return unto thee</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">105</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 10 here.</i> and Sarah shall have a son.” <i>And Sarah heard it</i>, but she did not know that they were angels of the Supreme One, as was the case with the wife of Manoah.<sup class="footnote-marker">106</sup><i class="footnote">Judges 13:6.</i> It is even possible that she did not see them at all. Therefore she laughed within herself in derision, just [as the word “laugh” is used in the verse]: <i>He that sitteth in heaven laugheth, the Eternal hath them in derision</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">107</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 2:4.</i> For joyous laughter is [expressed in Hebrew as originating] in the mouth — <i>Then was our mouth filled with laughter</i><sup class="footnote-marker">108</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 126:2.</i> — but laughter originating in the heart is not spoken of as joyous. Now the Holy One, blessed be He, accused her before Abraham as to why the matter appeared to her to be impossible. It was fitting for her to believe, or she should have said, “Amen, G-d do so!” Now Abraham said to her, “Why did you laugh? Is anything too hard for the Eternal?” He did not explain to her that G-d had revealed her secret to him. And she, because of Abraham’s fear of G-d, denied it for she thought that Abraham had said so through recognition of the expressions on her face or because she had kept quiet and gave no expression of praise and thanksgiving or joy. And he said to her, <i>Nay, but thou didst laugh</i>. Then she understood that it was told to him in a prophecy, and so she remained quiet and did not answer a word.<br>It is proper that we also say that Abraham had not revealed to her what had originally been told to him: <i>Indeed, Sarah, thy wife shall bear thee a son</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">109</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 17:19.</i> Perhaps he waited until G-d would send her the announcement on the following day for he knew <i>that the Eternal G-d will do nothing, but He revealed His counsel unto His servants the prophets</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">110</sup><i class="footnote">Amos 3:7.</i> It may be that due to his great diligence in fulfilling commandments, he was occupied with his circumcision and the circumcision of the many people in his house. Afterward, on account of his weakness, he sat at the doorway of the tent, and the angels came before he had told her anything.

Verse 16



Verse 17

AND THE ETERNAL SAID. I.e., to the host of heaven standing by Him,<sup class="footnote-marker">111</sup><i class="footnote">See I Kings 22:19.</i> or to the angel messengers.<br>It is possible that the word <i>amar</i> (He said) refers to thought, meaning that He thought He should not keep it hidden from Abraham on account of these reasons. Similarly: <i>I ‘said,’ in the noontide of my days I shall go;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">112</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 38:10. The word “said” here means “thought.”</i> <i>And he ‘said’ to slay David</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">113</sup><i class="footnote">II Samuel 21:16. Here too the word “said” means “thought.”</i> Likewise all expressions of speaking within the heart refer to thought.<sup class="footnote-marker">114</sup><i class="footnote">E.g., <i>And Esau said in his heart</i>, further, 27:41. See Ramban there.</i>

Verse 18

AND ABRAHAM SHALL SURELY BECOME. A Midrash Agadah comments: <i>The memory of the righteous shall be for a blessing</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">115</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 10:7.</i> Since He mentioned Abraham, He blessed him. The simple meaning of the verse though is, “Shall I conceal it from him since he is so beloved by Me to become a mighty nation?” Thus the language of Rashi.<br>The correct interpretation is that G-d, blessed be He, spoke of the honor of Abraham, saying: “Behold, he is destined to become a great and mighty nation, and his memory will be a blessing among his seed and all nations of the earth. Therefore, I shall not conceal it from him for the future generations will say, “How could He hide it from him?’ or, ‘How could the righteous one<sup class="footnote-marker">116</sup><i class="footnote">Abraham.</i> be so callous about his close neighbors and have no mercy on them, not praying at all in their behalf, and that which was known to him, [i.e., that the cities will be destroyed], was good and pleasing!’ For I know that he recognizes and is cognizant that I the Eternal <i>loveth righteousness and justice</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">117</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 33:5.</i> that is to say, that I do justice only with righteousness, and therefore <i>he will command his children and his household after him</i><sup class="footnote-marker">118</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 19 here.</i> to follow in his path. Now if it is possible in keeping with righteousness and justice to free the cities from destruction, he will pray before Me to let them go, and it will be well and good. And if they are completely guilty, he too will want their judgment. Therefore, it is proper that he enter <i>in the council of G-d</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">119</sup><i class="footnote">Jeremiah 23:18.</i>

Verse 19

FOR I HAVE KNOWN HIM (‘YEDATIV’), TO THE END (‘LEMA’AN’) THAT HE MAY COMMAND HIS CHILDREN. Rashi comments: “<i>For I have known him</i>, as the Targum takes it, is an expression denoting affection, just as <i>A kinsman (‘moda’) of her husband’s;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">120</sup><i class="footnote">Ruth 2:1.</i> <i>And I know thee</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">121</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 33:17.</i> Still the main connotation of all these expressions is that of knowing, for he who holds a person in affection and draws him to himself knows him well and is familiar with him. But if you explain it as the Targum does — i.e., “I know that he will command his children” — then the word <i>lema’an</i> (to the end) does not fit into the sense.”<sup class="footnote-marker">122</sup><i class="footnote">Our Rashi has a different text. See notes in my Hebrew commentary, p. 110. See also Note 125 further.</i><br>It is possible that the word <i>yedativ</i> means “I have raised him and elevated him so that he shall command his children after him to do that which is right before Me, and therefore I will make him a great and mighty nation so that he should serve Me. In a similar sense are the verses: <i>I know thee (‘yedaticha’) by name;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">123</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 33:12. The sense would thus be: “I have made thee great in name.”</i> <i>What is man, that Thou knowest htm?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">124</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 144:3. The sense here then would be: “What is man before Thee that Thou hast given him greatness?”</i> Or the verse may be stating, I know that he will command,<sup class="footnote-marker">125</sup><i class="footnote">Ramban thus differs with Rashi, who said that if you take the sense of the verse to be, “I know of him that he will command,” then the word <i>lema’an</i> does not fit the context. Ramban proceeds to show from Exodus 23:12 that the words <i>lema’an yanuach</i> mean <i>she’yanuach</i> (that he may rest); here likewise, <i>lema’an asher yetzaveh</i> means <i>she’yetzaveh</i> (that he will command). Thus, the word <i>lema’an</i> is seen to fit into the context.</i> and in a similar sense is the verse, <i>So that thine ox and thine ass may have rest (lema’an yanuach)</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">126</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 23:12. See Note above.</i> meaning that he may have rest.<br>The correct interpretation appears to me to be that the word <i>yedativ</i> literally means “knowing.” He is thus alluding that G-d’s knowledge, which is synonymous with His Providence in the lower world, is to guard the species, and even the children of men are subject despite it to the circumstantial evil occurrences until the time of their visitation comes. But as regards His pious, He directs His Providence to know each one individually so that His watch constantly attaches to him, His knowledge and remembrance of him never departs, as it says: <i>He withdraweth not His eyes from the righteous</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">127</sup><i class="footnote">Job 36:7.</i> There are many verses on this theme, as it is written, <i>Behold, the eye of the Eternal is toward them that fear Him</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">128</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 33:18. See Moreh Nebuchim III, 51, where Rambam’s theory on Divine Providence is seen to be similar to that which Ramban expresses here.</i> and other verses besides.

Verse 20

AND THE ETERNAL SAID, THE CRY OF SODOM AND GOMORRAH. Rashi comments: “<i>And the Eternal said</i> to Abraham, thus doing what He had said, i.e., that He would not conceal the matter from him,”<br>And Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra said that the verse, <i>And the men turned from there</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">129</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 22 here.</i> was inserted in the middle of the account<sup class="footnote-marker">130</sup><i class="footnote">According to Ibn Ezra, Verse 22, which states, <i>And the men turned from there and went toward Sodom, and Abraham stood yet before the Eternal</i>, actually took place before our present verse for it was after the angels had walked toward Sodom that G-d said to Abraham, <i>The cry of Sodom and Gomorrah…</i> However, Verse 22 was entered later in the account in order to let us know the time of G-d’s word to Abraham — <i>the cry of Sodom and Gomorrah</i>, etc. — was when they came to Sodom.</i> in order to let us know that at the time the angels arrived in Sodom, then G-d said to Abraham: <i>The cry of Sodom and Gomorrah is great</i>.<br>The opinion of all commentators is likewise that G-d was speaking with Abraham. Now according to this, the correct interpretation of the verse, <i>And the men turned from there</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">129</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 22 here.</i> is that when G-d said to Abraham after the men journeyed from him, <i>The cry of Sodom and Gomorrah is great</i>, Abraham stood in prayer and supplication before Him to forgive them and to give him permission to speak. And he prolonged his prayer until the men came to Sodom, and then Abraham drew near and said, <i>Wilt Thou also sweep away the righteous with the wicked?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">131</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 23 here.</i> Or the explanation may be that Scripture itself returns to clarify the expression, <i>Abraham stood yet before the Eternal</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">132</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 22 here. According to this interpretation, Abraham did not pray before he began saying, <i>Wilt Thou also sweep away</i>.</i> as meaning that Abraham drew near and said, <i>Wilt Thou also sweep away the righteous with the wicked?</i> Thus he prolonged his supplication before Him, saying each time, “Let not the anger of the Eternal blaze,”<sup class="footnote-marker">133</sup><i class="footnote">See Exodus 32:22.</i> and directing the intent of his mind each time towards prophecy until he heard an answer to his words direct from the Holy One, blessed be He. They continued in this manner the entire day [until, as the verse says], <i>the Eternal finished speaking with Abraham</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">134</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 33 here.</i> and the two angels came to Sodom.
THE CRY OF SODOM AND GOMORRAH. This is the cry of the oppressed, crying out and begging for help from the arm of their wickedness. It would have been proper for Scripture to say, “<i>The cry of Sodom and Gomorrah</i> I heard <i>because it is great</i>” or “The cry of Sodom and Gomorrah is great and their sin is very heavy.” But the purport of the verse is to state that “I will go down and see the cry of Sodom and Gomorrah and their sin which have become very great. If they have all sinned, I will bring the law to bear down on them, and if not, I will know who are the sinners.”<br>Concerning the matter of “going down and seeing,” Rashi said by way of <i>derash:</i><sup class="footnote-marker">135</sup><i class="footnote">The homiletical interpretation of Scripture.</i> “This teaches that judges are not to give decisions in cases involving capital punishment except after having carefully looked into the matter.”<br>According to the simple meaning of Scripture, the explanation is as follows: Since the Holy One, blessed be He, wished to reveal to Abraham the matter of Sodom and to inform him that there was none among them who did good, He said to him “Because it is great, the cry of Sodom and Gomorrah will I go down to see, meaning I have come to judge. If they have sinned, I will make an end of them, and if not, I shall know what I shall do to them: <i>Then will I visit their transgression with the rod, and their iniquity with strokes</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">136</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 89:33.</i> He thus informed him that their judgment was not yet complete for now He will visit their sin and judge them. This is like the verse: <i>The Eternal looketh from heaven upon the children of men, to see if there were any man of understanding, that did seek after G-d. They are all corrupt; they are together become impure</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">137</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 14:2-3.</i><br>Now Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra said concerning this<sup class="footnote-marker">138</sup><i class="footnote">Ibn Ezra’s comment is found in Verse 21 here.</i> [“going down and seeing”] a mystery [i.e., a mysterious explanation], pleasing himself with foreign offspring.<sup class="footnote-marker">139</sup><i class="footnote">See Isaiah 2:6. Ramban says that “the mystery” suggested here by Ibn Ezra as an explanation of the verse comes to him from the philosophers who please themselves with theories which are “the offspring of aliens.” Ibn Ezra’s “mystery” explanation is that G-d’s knowledge of earthly matters is general, rather than detailed. Ramban rejects this concept as “foreign” to the Torah.</i> I shall now intimate to you the opinion of those who received the truth. Our Rabbis have exposited<sup class="footnote-marker">140</sup><i class="footnote">Yerushalmi Ta’anith II, 1.</i> from the verse, <i>For behold, the Eternal cometh forth out of His place, and will come down, and tread upon the high places of the earth:</i><sup class="footnote-marker">141</sup><i class="footnote">Micah 1:3.</i> “He cometh forth and goeth from attribute to attribute; He cometh forth from the attribute of mercy, and goeth to the attribute of justice.” We interpret this matter similarly. <i>And the Eternal said</i> in His heart, “<i>The cry of Sodom and Gomorrah, because it is great, I will go down</i> from the attribute of mercy to the attribute of justice, <i>and I will see</i> in mercy <i>if they have done according to the cry of it which is come unto Me</i> through the attribute of justice, and if so, <i>punishment; and if not, I will know</i> and I will show mercy,” just as in the verse, <i>And G-d knew</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">142</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 2:25. He knew of the suffering of the children of Israel and directed His mercy upon them. Here, likewise, Ramban teaches that the word <i>eida’ah</i> (I will know) bespeaks Divine mercy.</i> Now after Scripture tells of the knowledge of the Most High, it returns to the first matter and relates the story of how the men who glanced towards Sodom with the intention of going there and whom Abraham sent away arrived there. And Abraham, from the moment they left him until they arrived there, still stood before the Eternal for He called him and told him that the angels were those messengers who would destroy the place, as He had said. It was not necessary for Scripture to explain when Abraham stood before Him for from the moment He said, <i>Shall I conceal it from Abraham</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">143</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 17 here.</i> it is known that He told him.

Verse 21



Verse 22



Verse 23

AND ABRAHAM DREW NEAR AND SAID, WILT THOU ALSO SWEEP AWAY THE RIGHTEOUS WITH THE WICKED? The anger<sup class="footnote-marker">144</sup><i class="footnote">Ramban understood the verse as Onkelos rendered it, namely, that the word <i>ha’aph</i> does not mean “shall also”, but it means “the anger.” The verse reads: “shall the anger of G-d sweep away.” See Rashi.</i> of the Holy One, blessed be He, is His attribute of justice. Now Abraham thought that this would sweep away the righteous with the wicked, not knowing of G-d’s thoughts in which He thought of them with His mercies, as I have explained.<sup class="footnote-marker">145</sup><i class="footnote">At the end of Verse 20 here.</i> Therefore, Abraham said that it is proper and good that He should forgive the entire place because of the fifty righteous inhabitants, but it is inconceivable even according to the Divine attribute of Justice <i>to slay the righteous with the wicked</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">146</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 25 here.</i> for if so <i>the righteous will be as the wicked</i>, and they will say, <i>It is vain to serve G-d</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">147</sup><i class="footnote">Malachi 3:14.</i> And all the more is this inconceivable according to the Divine attribute of Mercy since He is <i>the Judge of all the earth</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">144</sup><i class="footnote">Ramban understood the verse as Onkelos rendered it, namely, that the word <i>ha’aph</i> does not mean “shall also”, but it means “the anger.” The verse reads: “shall the anger of G-d sweep away.” See Rashi.</i> and He does justice,<sup class="footnote-marker">148</sup><i class="footnote">With righteousness. (Tur quoting and interpreting Ramban.)</i> even as it is said, <i>And the Eternal of hosts is exalted through justice</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">149</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 5:16.</i> and we say in our prayers, “The King of judgment.”<sup class="footnote-marker">150</sup><i class="footnote">Literally, “the king, the Justice,” implying that the King is Justice. (See my Hebrew commentary, p. 112.) This prayer is said on the ten days from Rosh Hashanah to Yom Kippur. (Berachoth 12b.)</i> This is the significance of the double use of the expression, <i>It is unworthy of Thee</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">151</sup><i class="footnote">In Verse 24 here. One for the attribute of justice, and one for mercy, as explained above.</i> And the Holy One, blessed be He, conceded that He would forgive the entire place for the sake of the fifty righteous, for He will conduct Himself towards them with the attribute of Mercy.<br>What informs you of all this<sup class="footnote-marker">152</sup><i class="footnote">That Abraham thought that they would be judged only by Divine justice, and G-d told him that they would be judged with Divine mercy.</i> is the fact <i>vayomer hashem</i> (And the Eternal said)<sup class="footnote-marker">153</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 26 here.</i> is written with the Tetragrammaton, and all references by Abraham to the Divine Name are written <i>Ado-noy</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">154</sup><i class="footnote">The Tetragrammaton signifies Divine mercy, while the Name beginning with <i>Aleph Dalet</i> signifies Divine justice.</i> This has now been clarified.

Verse 24

FIFTY RIGHTEOUS. Rashi wrote: “Ten righteous men for each city. <i>Wilt thou destroy on account of the five</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">155</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 28 here.</i> Nine for each city, and You, the All-Righteous One of the Universe, will be counted with them [to make up the original number of ten]. <i>Perhaps there shall be found there forty</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">156</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 29 here.</i> Then let four cities be saved. So, too, thirty will save three of them, twenty will save two of them, and ten will save one of them. And he did not plead for less than ten since in the generation of the flood there were eight righteous people,<sup class="footnote-marker">157</sup><i class="footnote">Noah, his three sons, and their wives. (Rashi.)</i> and they could not save their generation. For nine, in association with G-d, he had already pleaded but found no acceptance.” All these are the words of the Rabbi, of blessed memory.<br>But I wonder: If so, what is this prayer and supplication which he pleads each and every time, saying, <i>oh let not the Lord be angry;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">158</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 30 here.</i> <i>Behold, now, I have taken upon me to speak?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">159</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 31 here.</i> It is proper that forty should save four cities, and thirty and twenty should save in proportion, just as fifty would save five! Similarly, concerning that which Rashi said, “for nine in association with G-d he had already pleaded but found no acceptance,” it may be asked: When he pleaded about forty-five, [i.e., to save all five cities by having nine righteous men for each city] in association [with G-d to make up ten], and he did not find forty-five, but perhaps he might have found there nine!<sup class="footnote-marker">160</sup><i class="footnote">Why then did Abraham not plead for nine men who, in association with G-d, would be ten, and thus save one city, for the principle of using G-d as a tenth was not declared invalid; rather, it was previously inapplicable since there were not forty-five righteous inhabitants.</i> Now it would seem that the intention of the Rabbi<sup class="footnote-marker">161</sup><i class="footnote">Rashi.</i> is that many righteous people can effect a proportionately greater salvation than a few righteous people can, just as the Sages have said:<sup class="footnote-marker">162</sup><i class="footnote">Sifra, Leviticus 26:8. The wording of the quotations used here is that of Rashi in his commentary to the Torah. (<i>Ibid.</i>)</i> “A few who fulfill the commandments of the Torah cannot compare with the many who fulfill the commandments of the Torah.” And thus,<sup class="footnote-marker">163</sup><i class="footnote">“And thus.” The Tur quoting Ramban writes, “Perhaps.”</i> the Holy One, blessed be He, having conceded that forty-five righteous men in association with the All-Righteous One of the Universe would save all the five cities just as if there were the entire fifty, it follows that if forty could save four cities — in association with the Righteous One, praised be He — they would also save with even thirty and twenty, since He already conceded this association. [Thus, thirty-six would save four, twenty-seven three, eighteen two, and nine one]. And in case you say that He conceded only the case of forty-five because they are many, and perhaps He might not concede the principle of association with the few, as we have said, the refutation is that it is proper for the righteousness of G-d to associate even with the few and save [as many of the cities as possible] since He had conceded the principle of association, for He would not distinguish between the many and the few.<sup class="footnote-marker">164</sup><i class="footnote">In other words, having admitted the principle of association in the case of forty-five, there could not be any difference between a larger and smaller group of righteous men with respect to the principle of association. Hence Abraham did not have to ask for nine, for in association with G-d there would be ten, and one city would be saved. But without the principle of association there might be a difference between a larger and smaller group. Hence Abraham had to ask for forty, thirty, twenty and ten. All this is to satisfactorily explain the interpretation of Rashi. Ramban’s own position is made clear further in the text.</i> This is the opinion of the Rabbi.<sup class="footnote-marker">161</sup><i class="footnote">Rashi.</i><br>But the way of the simple meaning of the verses is smooth.<sup class="footnote-marker">165</sup><i class="footnote">See Proverbs 15:19.</i> First Abraham said fifty in order to give a perfect number of ten for each city, and then he decreased the number as much as possible, and each time he thought to save all five cities. And I do not know who brought the Rabbi<sup class="footnote-marker">161</sup><i class="footnote">Rashi.</i> to that which he said.

Verse 25



Verse 26

WITHIN THE CITY. Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra explained that [these men for whose sake the cities were to be saved] fear G-d publicly. In a similar sense is the verse: <i>Run ye to and fro through the streets of Jerusalem</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">166</sup><i class="footnote">Jeremiah 5:1. <i>If ye can find a man, if there be any that doeth justly</i>.</i><br>The correct interpretation appears to me to be that Abraham said, <i>within the city</i>, meaning that even if they are strangers therein, it is fitting that they save it. He said this on account of Lot, and he thought that perhaps there are others there.

Verse 27



Verse 28

I WILL NOT DESTROY IT IF I FIND THERE. He assured him that He would not destroy it if that number of righteous men will be found there. And He did not tell him, “Know that there is not such a number there as you said,” since their trial had not been completed, just as He said, <i>I will go down now, and see</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">167</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 21 here.</i><br>Now Abraham did not know what would be done to them. Therefore, he rose early in the morning and looked towards Sodom,<sup class="footnote-marker">168</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 19:27-28.</i> and upon seeing that they were destroyed, he knew that the required number of righteous men had not been there.

Chapter 19



Verse 1



Verse 2

BEHOLD NOW, MY LORDS. Rashi comments: “Behold now you are my lords since you have passed by me” The correct interpretation is that it is an expression of pleadings: “My lords, behold now your servant’s house; turn aside, I pray you, to me” The word <i>suru</i> (turn aside) is as in the expressions: <i>Turn aside (‘surah’), sit down here;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">169</sup><i class="footnote">Ruth 4:1.</i> <i>Turn in (‘surah’), my lord, turn in to me; fear not</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">170</sup><i class="footnote">Judges 4:18.</i>
AND YE SHALL RISE UP EARLY, AND GO ON YOUR WAY. The purport of that was to tell them that they should not tarry in the city after the morning for Lot knew the nature of the men of the city and of their wickedness, but he thought, <i>In the morning light they do it</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">171</sup><i class="footnote">Micah 2:1. But at night they would not know of them. (Tur.)</i> It may be that he saw them as transients who would not tarry in the city, and so he said, <i>And ye shall rise up early and go on your way</i> if you desire.

Verse 3

AND HE URGED THEM GREATLY. His urging them was meritorious on the part of Lot, and he indeed had a sincere desire to welcome wayfarers. They, however, at first refused in order to increase his merit, and therefore they finally listened to him; but originally they did not want to come into his house as he was not a perfectly righteous man. But our Rabbis have said [in order to explain their original refusal]:<sup class="footnote-marker">172</sup><i class="footnote">Baba Metzia 87a.</i> “One may decline an offer from an inferior person, but not from a superior person.”<sup class="footnote-marker">173</sup><i class="footnote">Hence, to Abraham the angels immediately said, <i>So do, as thou hast said</i>, (above, 18:5), but with Lot, they at first declined.</i> If so, their declining his offer at first was merely an act of ethical conduct.

Verse 4



Verse 5

AND WE SHALL KNOW THEM. Their intention was to stop people from coming among them, as our Rabbis have said,<sup class="footnote-marker">174</sup><i class="footnote">Sanhedrin 109a.</i> for they thought that because of the excellence of their land, which was <i>as the garden of the Eternal</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">175</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 13:10.</i> many will come there, and they despised charity. Lot, however, came to them with his riches and wealth [and was given permission to live in Sodom because] he either asked permission of them, or that they accepted him in honor of Abraham.<br>Now Scripture testifies that this was the intent of the people of Sodom, as it is said, <i>Behold, this was the iniquity of thy sister Sodom: pride, fullness of bread, and careless ease was in her and in her daughters; neither did she strengthen the hand of the poor and needy</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">176</sup><i class="footnote">Ezekiel 16:49.</i> The verse stating, <i>And the men of Sodom were wicked and sinners against the Eternal exceedingly</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">177</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 13:13. This would seem to indicate that they sinned only against G-d but not against their fellow man.</i> really means that they continued provoking and rebelling against Him with their ease and the oppression of the poor. It is this thought which Scripture expresses by saying, <i>And they were haughty, and committed abomination before Me; therefore I removed them when I saw it</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">178</sup><i class="footnote">Ezekiel 16:50.</i><br>In the opinion of our Rabbis,<sup class="footnote-marker">179</sup><i class="footnote">Sanhedrin 109a.</i> all evil practices<sup class="footnote-marker">180</sup><i class="footnote">Such as blasphemy, bloodshed, etc. (<i>Ibid.</i>)</i> were rampant among them. Yet their fate was sealed because of this sin — i.e., they did not strengthen the hand of the poor and needy — since this sin represented their usual behavior more than any other. Besides, since all peoples act righteously towards their friends and their poor, there was none among all the nations who matched Sodom in cruelty.<br>Know that the judgment of Sodom was due to the superiority of the Land of Israel since Sodom is part of <i>the inheritance of the Eternal</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">181</sup><i class="footnote">II Samuel 20:19.</i> and it does not suffer men of abominations. And just as it later vomited out a whole nation on account of their abominations,<sup class="footnote-marker">182</sup><i class="footnote">See Leviticus 18:25.</i> so it now anticipated and saw that this entire people behaved worse than all nations towards Heaven and mankind. It thus laid waste heaven and earth for them, and the land was destroyed forever, never to be restored, since they became haughty on account of the goodness that was bestowed on them. The Holy One, blessed be He, thus made Sodom <i>a token against the rebellious children</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">183</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 17:25.</i> that is, against the children of Israel who were destined to inherit it, even as He warned them: <i>The whole land thereof is brimstone, and salt, and a burning… like the overthrow of Sodom and Gomorrah, Admah and Zeboiim, which the Eternal overthrew in His anger, and in His wrath</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">184</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 29:22.</i> For there have been among nations those who were evil and exceedingly sinful, and yet He did not do to them as He did to Sodom. However it was all on account of the superiority of this land for there is the <i>temple of the Eternal</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">185</sup><i class="footnote">Jeremiah 7:4.</i> I plan to explain this in <i>Seder Achrei Moth</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">186</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 18:24.</i> if He Who taketh life and giveth life will sustain me in life.

Verse 6



Verse 7



Verse 8

LET ME, I PRAY YOU, BRING THEM OUT UNTO YOU. From the praise of this man Lot we have come to his disgrace: he made every effort on behalf of his guests in order to save them because they came under the shadow of his roof, but he is ready to appease the men of the city by abandoning his daughters to prostitution! This bespeaks nothing but an evil heart for it shows that the matter of prostitution of women was not repugnant to him, and that in his opinion he would not be doing such great injustice to his daughters. It is for this reason that our Rabbis have said,<sup class="footnote-marker">187</sup><i class="footnote">Tanchuma Vayeira 12.</i> “It is the custom of the world that a man fights to the death for the honor of his daughters and his wife, to slay or to be slain, but this man hands over his daughters for dishonor. Said the Holy One, blessed be He, to him, ‘It is for yourself that you keep them.’”<sup class="footnote-marker">188</sup><i class="footnote">See further, Verses 30-36.</i><br>Now Lot was fearful [for the welfare of the angels] as he thought that they were men, but when they smote the men of the city with blindness and they said to him, <i>For we will destroy this place… and the Eternal hath sent us</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">189</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 13 here.</i> then he recognized them and believed in doing whatever they commanded him.<br>Know and understand that the matter of the concubine of Gibeah,<sup class="footnote-marker">190</sup><i class="footnote">Judges, Chapter 19. Ramban digresses here to explain the crime of Gibeah, which bears a certain resemblance to that of Sodom, and consequently explains also the civil war between the tribe of Benjamin and the rest of Israel. Thus Chapters 19 and 20 in the book of Judges are here explained by Ramban.</i> even though it resembles this affair, does not attain the degree of evil of the inhabitants of Sodom. Those wicked ones of Gibeah had no intention of stopping people from coming among them. Rather, they were steeped in immorality and desired sexual relations with the wayfarer, and when he brought his concubine out to them, they were satisfied with her.<sup class="footnote-marker">191</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 25.</i> The old man [who had invited the wayfarer to his house] and who said to the men of Gibeah, <i>Behold, here is my daughter, a virgin, and his concubine; I will bring them out now… and do with them what seemeth good unto you</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">192</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 24.</i> knew that they would not want his daughter and that they would not harm her. This was why they refused to listen to him. And when he finally turned his concubine alone outdoors to them, they ceased molesting him. Now the master of the house, as well as the guest, both wanted to save the man through his concubine, as a concubine does not have the status of a man’s wife. Besides, she had already played the harlot against him.<sup class="footnote-marker">193</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 2.</i> In that breach, too, not all of the men of the city were involved as they were in Sodom, concerning which it is said, <i>Both young and old, all the people from every quarter</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">194</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 4 here.</i> while of Gibeah it is said, <i>Behold, the men of the city, certain base fellows</i><sup class="footnote-marker">195</sup><i class="footnote">Judges 19:22.</i> — only some of them, those who were the rulers and strong men of the city, even as the man said in relating the incident, <i>And the masters of Gibeah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">196</sup><i class="footnote">“Masters of Gibeah.” This is obviously the way Ramban understood the verse since the Hebrew had “<i>ba’alei</i> [rather than <i>anshei</i>] Gibeah.” The J.P.S. translation, however, renders it: <i>And the men of Gibeah rose against me</i>.</i> <i>rose against me</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">197</sup><i class="footnote">Judges 20:5.</i> This was why the others did not protest against them. <i>Now the chiefs of all the people, of all the tribes of Israel</i><sup class="footnote-marker">198</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 2.</i> wanted to erect a great guard in the matter of immorality by slaying them, as it is said, <i>Now therefore deliver up the men, the base fellows that are in Gibeah, that we may put them to death</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">199</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 13.</i> It is clear that according to the law of the Torah they were not guilty of the death-penalty as they had done no deed exclusive of the torture of the concubine — harlot. They did not intend her death, nor did she die at their hands for <i>they let her go at the approach of dawn</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">200</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 19:25.</i> and she walked from them to her master’s house and after that she died,<sup class="footnote-marker">201</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 26.</i> weakened perhaps by her numerous violations, and chilled while lying at the door until it was light, and there she died. But because the men of Gibeah had wanted to do a shameful deed just as the men of Sodom, the tribes saw fit “to make a fence unto the Torah” so that this should never again happen or be contemplated in Israel, even as they said, <i>And that we may put away evil from Israel</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">202</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 20:13.</i> This judgment has its origin in the principle which our Rabbis have stated:<sup class="footnote-marker">203</sup><i class="footnote">Yebamoth 90b.</i> “The Court may administer stripes and the death penalty which are not authorized by the Torah. However, they may not do this [with the intent of instituting a law which] transgresses the words of the Torah but only for the purpose of erecting a fence around the Torah.”<sup class="footnote-marker">204</sup><i class="footnote">That is, as a temporary measure which the times require, they may act accordingly. See Rashi Sanhedrin 46 a, that this is its meaning.</i> The tribe of Benjamin, however, did not consent to this<sup class="footnote-marker">205</sup><i class="footnote">That the men of Gibeah, involved in the affair, should be put to death.</i> as they were not guilty of the death-penalty for violating the concubine. Perhaps the Benjamites were also provoked by the fact that the tribes did not communicate with them first and reached a consensus without asking for their opinion.<br>In my opinion, this [failure to consult Benjamin] caused Israel’s punishment which resulted in their being routed at first since the war was done not in accordance with the law. The obligation of making “the fence”<sup class="footnote-marker">206</sup><i class="footnote">To punish the men of Gibeah as an extraordinary measure.</i> lay upon the tribe of Benjamin, and not upon them, as it is the tribe itself that is obligated to judge its constituents.<sup class="footnote-marker">207</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 16:18. Sanhedrin 16 b: “It is commandatory upon the tribe to judge the people of the tribe.”</i><br>Thus both parties were deserving of punishment. Benjamin sinned by not bothering to punish the wicked ones or even rebuke them. Israel sinned by making war not in accordance with the law, <i>and they asked not counsel at the mouth of the Eternal</i><sup class="footnote-marker">208</sup><i class="footnote">Joshua 9:14.</i> on this matter. Instead they questioned G-d and said, <i>Who shall go up for us first to battle against the children of Benjamin?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">209</sup><i class="footnote">Judges 20:18.</i> They themselves had decided to do battle in any case. Similarly, they did not inquire concerning the outcome of the battle, “If Thou wilt give them into my hand,” since they relied on their man-power which was exceedingly great as they were now more than ten times [as numerous as the Benjamites].<sup class="footnote-marker">210</sup><i class="footnote">The Israelites mustered four hundred thousand (<i>ibid.</i>, Verse 17) while the Benjamites numbered twenty-six thousand (<i>ibid.</i>, Verse 15).</i> All they asked was, <i>Who shall go up for us first</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">209</sup><i class="footnote">Judges 20:18.</i> this being like casting lots among them. Perhaps each tribe was saying, “I will not go up first,” or each tribe was saying, “I will be first.”<sup class="footnote-marker">211</sup><i class="footnote">A similar case occurred when the Israelites stood before the Red Sea. There is a difference of opinion among the Rabbis as to their attitude. According to one authority each tribe said, “I will not go into the sea first [to escape the Egyptians],” while another authority maintains that each tribe was saying, “I will go first.”</i> And the Holy One, blessed be He, answered in accordance with their question: <i>Judah first</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">209</sup><i class="footnote">Judges 20:18.</i> meaning Judah is always first, <i>For He hath chosen Judah to be prince</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">212</sup><i class="footnote">I Chronicles 28:4.</i> This was why He did not say, “Judah shall go up,” as in other places,<sup class="footnote-marker">213</sup><i class="footnote">As in Judges 1:2.</i> for He did not give them permission. However, He did not stop them, and neither did he tell them, <i>Go not up, neither fight</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">214</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 1:42.</i> because of the merited punishment of the Benjamites. Thus did G-d walk with both of them by chance, leaving them to natural circumstances. Accordingly, the Benjamites, who were valiant men and whose cities were well fortified, destroyed the Israelites who had “made flesh their arm of strength.”<sup class="footnote-marker">215</sup><i class="footnote">See Jeremiah 17:5.</i> But now the Benjamites compounded their merited punishment. It would have been sufficient for them to drive the Israelites away from Gibeah. Instead, they killed them, <i>seeking to destroy them by a perpetual hatred</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">216</sup><i class="footnote">Ezekiel 25:15.</i> and they slew the mighty number of twenty-two thousand of their people.<sup class="footnote-marker">217</sup><i class="footnote">Judges 20:21.</i> Now when the Israelites suffered such a great defeat they became aware of their error, namely, that they did battle with their brethren without receiving Divine permission and engaged in a battle which was not in accordance with the law of the Torah. Therefore, on the second day they asked, <i>shall I again draw nigh to battle against the children of Benjamin my brother?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">218</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 23.</i> Now they mentioned the brotherhood among them, asking whether He forbids them to do battle. But now on the second day, G-d permitted them, saying, <i>Go up against him</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">218</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 23.</i> as it was now permissible for them to avenge the spilled blood of their brethren.<sup class="footnote-marker">219</sup><i class="footnote">Spilled needlessly. All the Benjamites had to do on the first day of battle was to drive the Israelites from Gibeah, as explained above. Instead, they killed twenty-two thousand of them. Hence, on the second day, it became “permissible” for the Israelites to attempt to avenge their death.</i> However, they did not ask whether they will be victorious because they were still relying upon their superior numbers to bring victory under all circumstances. But since G-d had explained to them only that the battle was permissible to them, and since their first sin had not yet been atoned for, there fell among them also on the second day eighteen thousand.<sup class="footnote-marker">220</sup><i class="footnote">Judges 20:25.</i> On the third day they decreed a fast, and they fasted <i>and they wept… before the Eternal</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">221</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 26.</i> and they offered burnt-offerings to atone for their sinful thoughts<sup class="footnote-marker">222</sup><i class="footnote"><i>A Burnt-offering is brought only for sinful thought</i>. (Vayikra Rabbah 7:3.)</i> through which they relied upon the strength of their arm. They also offered peace-offerings,<sup class="footnote-marker">221</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 26.</i> which were Thanksgiving peace-offerings, since they considered themselves as if they had all escaped from the sword of Benjamin. This indeed is the law of all who are delivered from danger: they are to bring a thanks-offering, just as it is said, <i>And let them offer the sacrifices of thanksgiving, and declare His works with singing</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">223</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 107:22.</i> and it is further written, <i>And now shall my head be lifted up above mine enemies round about me; and I will offer in His tabernacle sacrifices with trumpet-sound; I will sing, yea, I will sing praises unto the Eternal</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">224</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 27:6.</i><br>Now the number of dead among the Israelites during the two days was forty thousand, and in the end twenty-five thousand<sup class="footnote-marker">225</sup><i class="footnote">Judges 20:35.</i> of Benjamin’s warriors fell, besides those that were put to the sword <i>from the whole city and all that they found</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">226</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 48.</i> It is possible that among the men, women and children they totalled fifteen thousand additional casualties, thus making the punishment of the two groups equal.<br>And how significant are the words of our Rabbis<sup class="footnote-marker">227</sup><i class="footnote">Sanhedrin 103b.</i> who said that the anger of G-d at that time was due to the idol of Micah!<sup class="footnote-marker">228</sup><i class="footnote">See Judges, Chapter 17.</i> “Said the Holy One, blessed be He, ‘Concerning My honor, which was violated by those guilty of death and those who raised their hand against the principle of religion, namely, the unity of G-d, you did not protest; but for the honor of a mortal you did protest, to an extent which exceeded the limits of justice!”<br>Therefore He confounded the counsel of the two groups and made their hearts stubborn, <i>and they remembered not the brotherly covenant</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">229</sup><i class="footnote">Amos 1:9.</i> But after the affair they had regrets, just as it is said, <i>And the people came to Beth-eland sat there till evening before G-d, and lifted up their voice, and wept bitterly. And they said: O Eternal, G-d of Israel, why is this come to pass in Israel, that there should be today one tribe missing from Israel?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">230</sup><i class="footnote">Judges 21:2-3.</i> For now they realized their mistakes and punishment.<br>We have thus incidentally explained a concealed matter which is not clear [with a cursory reading of the text], and we have mentioned the cause thereof.

Verse 9

AND THEY PRESSED HARD (‘VAYIFTZERU’) UPON THE MAN, EVEN LOT. I have found this word <i>vayiftzeru</i> only in connection with words of pleading. If so, we will explain its usage here as follows: the men of Sodom begged him [Lot] exceedingly to open the door for them, and when he refused to do so, they approached in order to break it. It may be that he stood in front of the door, not letting them come near him, and they begged him to turn aside as they did not want to harm him. This is the meaning of their saying, <i>Stand back</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">231</sup><i class="footnote">In the beginning of this verse.</i> meaning “stand in another place.”

Verse 10



Verse 11



Verse 12

SON-IN-LAW, AND THY SONS, AND THY DAUGHTERS. Rashi comments: “Whom else of your family have you in the city besides your wife and daughters who are at home with you? If you have additionally a son-in-law, or sons and daughters, take them out from this place.” Now if so, they [the angels] spoke in the manner of ordinary people for Lot had no sons, only daughters.<br>Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra explained: “<i>Son-in-law, and thy sons</i> — sons-in-law who are [as dear to you] as your sons.”<br>It is possible that Lot had grown sons who were married, and he spoke with his sons-in-law first as he thought that his own sons would listen to him [and leave the place]. But as his sons-in-law laughed at him and their conversation continued, dawn appeared, and the angels only permitted him to take those who were at hand. Thus the merit of Lot could have saved his sons and daughters and sons-in-law, not as Abraham had thought that He would make the righteous perish with the wicked.<sup class="footnote-marker">232</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 18:25.</i> It is clear that the angels were acquainted with the knowledge of the Most High on this matter since the city of Zoar was also saved by his prayer.<sup class="footnote-marker">233</sup><i class="footnote">This is unlike the opinion of R’dak, who maintains that an angel who carries out a Divine mission also has the right to add or detract somewhat from the charge given to him. His proof is the fact that the angel here granted the sudden request of Lot to save the city of Zoar, (Verses 20-21). Ramban, however, is of the opinion that the angels were acquainted with the knowledge of the Most High and knew that He granted Lot’s request; they could thus assure Lot that the city of Zoar would be saved.</i><br>It is possible that [the salvation of Lot’s family was not on account of his merit but] was in honor of his hospitality for it is the ethical way of messengers to save their host and all that belong to him, just as the messengers of Joshua also saved all the families of their hostess.<sup class="footnote-marker">234</sup><i class="footnote">Joshua 6:23.</i> And in Bereshith Rabbah<sup class="footnote-marker">235</sup><i class="footnote">50:21.</i> it is said, “Because Lot honored the angel by offering him hospitality, he in turn befriended Lot.”<sup class="footnote-marker">236</sup><i class="footnote">And granted his request to save Zoar.</i>

Verse 13



Verse 14



Verse 15



Verse 16

AND THE MEN LAID HOLD UPON HIS HAND. Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra said that the word <i>vayachziku (and they laid hold upon)</i> clearly shows that Lot was afraid and had no strength to flee. The correct interpretation of the word is that it is like the verse, <i>‘Vatechezak’ (And) the Egyptians (were urgent) upon the people, to send them out of the land in haste</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">237</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 12:33.</i> Here likewise they were pulling them with strength to send them out in haste.
THE ETERNAL HAVING PITY UPON HIM. Not for Lot’s merit but only because of G-d’s pity and His abundant mercies. It may be that the verse is saying that they seized him to take them out while G-d’s pity was still upon him, lest the wrath go forth from G-d<sup class="footnote-marker">238</sup><i class="footnote">See Numbers 17:11.</i> and he perish.

Verse 17

LOOK NOT BEHIND THEE, NEITHER STAY IN ALL THE PLAIN. The purport of the verse is to state: “Do not stay in all the Plain and do not look behind you after you have been saved.” For as long as Lot had not reached the mountain, disaster would not overtake the inhabitants of Sodom. It is for this reason that Lot said, “<i>And I cannot escape to the mountain, lest the evil overtake me</i><sup class="footnote-marker">239</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 19 here.</i> when I am in the Plain since you will not extend the time for me more than a little, as you have said, <i>Haste thee, escape thither</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">240</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 22 here.</i><br>Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra said, “<i>Look not behind thee</i>, i.e., ‘thou and all who belong to thee.’ And similarly is the verse, <i>Thou shalt not eat of it</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">241</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 2:17. This command, given to Adam, must have included Eve as well, for otherwise she would not have been punished. Similarly, the command given to Lot must have included his wife and all who belonged to him.</i><br>But what need is there for this interpretation? The punishment here was not because they would violate the warning of the angel by looking at them. Instead, the angel merely warned them on his own that punishment would overtake them for such a glance, and he warned Lot because of his merit, and all who listened and took warning saved their lives.<br>Now as to the significance of the prohibition of looking, Rashi said: “You sinned with them but art saved through the merit of Abraham. You are not permitted<sup class="footnote-marker">242</sup><i class="footnote">“You are not permitted.” In our Rashi the text reads, “It is not fitting that.…”</i> to see their doom.”<br>There is yet another matter. Looking upon the atmosphere of a plague and all contagious diseases is very harmful, and they may cleave to him. Even the thought of them is harmful. Therefore, the leper is isolated and dwells alone.<sup class="footnote-marker">243</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 13:40.</i> Similarly, those who have been bitten by mad animals such as a mad dog and other animals besides, when they look into the water or any mirror, they behold in them the likeness of the offender, and as a result of this, they did just as the Rabbis have said in Tractate Yoma,<sup class="footnote-marker">244</sup><i class="footnote">Yoma 84a. See also Ramban, Numbers 21:9.</i> and as the students of nature have mentioned. It was for this reason that Lot’s wife turned into a pillar of salt<sup class="footnote-marker">245</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 26 here.</i> for the plague entered her mind when she saw the brimstone and salt<sup class="footnote-marker">246</sup><i class="footnote">Brimstone and salt. Here in the chapter, brimstone and <i>fire</i> are mentioned (Verse 24). Salt however is mentioned in Deuteronomy 29:22, in connection with the overthrow of Sodom.</i> which descended upon them from heaven, and it cleaved to her.<br>I am inclined to say that when G-d destroyed these cities the destroying angel <i>stood between the earth and heaven</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">247</sup><i class="footnote">I Chronicles 21:16.</i> appearing in a flame of fire, as did the destroying angel whom David saw.<sup class="footnote-marker">247</sup><i class="footnote">I Chronicles 21:16.</i> Therefore, he prohibited them from looking.<br>In Pirkei d’Rabbi Eliezer<sup class="footnote-marker">248</sup><i class="footnote">Chapter 25.</i> there is a similar text: “The angels said to them, ‘Do not look behind you since the Divine Presence of the Holy One, blessed be He, has descended to rain brimstone and fire upon Sodom and Gomorrah.’ The compassion of Edis, Lot’s wife, welled up for her married daughters who were in Sodom,<sup class="footnote-marker">249</sup><i class="footnote">Lot, according to Pirkei d’Rabbi Eliezer, had two married daughters in Sodom in addition to the two betrothed daughters who were yet in his house. See Verse 15.</i> and she looked behind her to see if they were following her. She thereupon saw the back of the Divine Presence, and she became a pillar of salt.”

Verse 18



Verse 19



Verse 20



Verse 21



Verse 22



Verse 23



Verse 24

AND THE ETERNAL CAUSED TO RAIN UPON SODOM (AND UPON GOMORRAH BRIMSTONE AND FIRE FROM THE ETERNAL OF HEAVEN). Rashi wrote: “Wherever it is said, <i>And the Eternal</i> it means Him and His Celestial Court. <i>From the Eternal</i>. It is not written ‘from Him,’ [with the pronoun ‘Him’ replacing the noun ‘Eternal’ in the second part of the verse, for] this is the Scriptural way of speaking. For example, <i>Ye wives of Lamech</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">250</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 4:23.</i> and he did not say ‘my wives.’ And David also said, <i>Take you the servants of your lord</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">251</sup><i class="footnote">I Kings 1:33.</i> and he did not say, ‘my servants.’ Ahaseurus also said, <i>Write ye… in the name of the king</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">252</sup><i class="footnote">Esther 8:8.</i> and he did not say, ‘in my name.’”<br>Now I wonder about the Rabbi<sup class="footnote-marker">253</sup><i class="footnote">Rashi. See <i>Seder Bereshith</i>, Note 139.</i> who wrote down conflicting opinions and made them alike for there is a division of opinion on this matter in Bereshith Rabbah.<sup class="footnote-marker">254</sup><i class="footnote">51:50.</i> And there is yet a third opinion: “Aba Chilfi, the son of Rabbi Simki, said in the name of Rabbi Yehudah the son of Rabbi Simon: <i>‘And the Eternal caused to rain upon Sodom</i> — this refers to the angel Gabriel. <i>From the Eternal out of heaven</i> — this refers to the Holy One, blessed be He.’ Rabbi Eleazar said, ‘Wherever it says, <i>And the Eternal</i>, it means Him and His Celestial Court.’ Rabbi Yitzchak said, ‘We find in the Torah, Prophets, and Writings, that a person mentions his name twice. In the Torah, <i>And Lamech said to his wives</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">250</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 4:23.</i> etc.’” Thus there are three conflicting opinions here. Rabbi Yehudah the son of Rabbi Simon ascribes the first Divine Name mentioned in the verse as referring to Gabriel as he was the messenger sent to destroy the city, it being a case of the deputy being referred to by the name of Him Who sent him. And Rabbi Eleazar said that He and His Celestial Court agreed on the judgment, and it was from Him that the brimstone and fire came. And Rabbi Yitzchak said that it is the Scriptural way of speaking.<br>Now if you will understand what I have written above,<sup class="footnote-marker">255</sup><i class="footnote">11:2, at the end.</i> you will know the intent of the Sages’ expression, “He and His Celestial Court,” and then the plain meaning of the verse will be clear to you. In a similar manner is the verse, <i>That they may keep the way of the Eternal… to the end that the Eternal may bring…</i><sup class="footnote-marker">256</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 18:19.</i> He did not say, “that they may keep My way… to the end that I may bring.” Likewise: <i>Because the cry concerning them is great before the face of the Eternal, and the Eternal hath sent us</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">257</sup><i class="footnote">Above, Verse 13.</i> And similarly: <i>And it came to pass, when G-d destroyed… that G-d remembered</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">258</sup><i class="footnote">Further, Verse 29.</i>

Verse 25



Verse 26

AND HIS WIFE LOOKED BACK FROM BEHIND HIM. From behind Lot, who was following them, acting as the rearguard for all his household, who were hurrying to be saved.

Verse 27



Verse 28



Verse 29

AND G-D REMEMBERED ABRAHAM, AND SENT LOT OUT FROM THE CATASTROPHE. The purport of this verse is that Lot had shown kindness towards the righteous one<sup class="footnote-marker">259</sup><i class="footnote">Abraham.</i> by going with him and roaming here and there, following him wherever he went. This is the intent of the verse, <i>And Lot went with him</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">260</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 12:4.</i> meaning that he went at Abraham’s command. Therefore he had the merit to be saved on account of Abraham’s meritoriousness as it was on account of him that he lived in Sodom, and were it not for Abraham he would have still been in Haran with his family. Now it is inconceivable that some evil should overtake him [Lot] because of Abraham who had left his country at his Creator’s command. This was also the reason why Abraham endangered himself by pursuing the kings on account of him.<sup class="footnote-marker">261</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 14:14.</i>

Verse 30

FOR HE FEARED TO DWELL IN ZOAR. Rashi wrote, “Because it was near to Sodom.”<br>This is not so.<sup class="footnote-marker">262</sup><i class="footnote">For since the angel had assured Lot, <i>See, I have accepted thee concerning this thing also, that I will not overthrow the city</i> [Zoar], (Verse 21), Zoar would no longer be in danger of destruction even though it was near Sodom. (Mizrachi.)</i> Rather, since it was one of the places upon which destruction had originally been decreed and it was only by Lot’s supplication that the angel exempted it because Lot could not make his escape to the mountain on that day,<sup class="footnote-marker">263</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 19 here.</i> Lot now thought that the angel would no longer extend his request, for he now had sufficient time to make the escape to the mountain.<sup class="footnote-marker">264</sup><i class="footnote">This was why he <i>feared to dwell in Zoar</i>.</i> This was why his daughter said, <i>And there is not a man in the earth</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">265</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 31 here.</i> for she thought that with her father’s departure from Zoar the city was destroyed.

Verse 31

AND THE FIRST-BORN SAID. Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra said, “It is possible that Lot had another wife<sup class="footnote-marker">266</sup><i class="footnote">Since Scripture mentions that Lot had married daughters (Verse 14), these two mentioned here must surely have been younger ones as it was customary for the older ones to marry before the younger ones. (See further, 29:26.) If so, how does Scripture call one of the single daughters <i>the first-born?</i> It must therefore be, concluded Ibn Ezra, that the ones mentioned above were from another wife who had died. Ramban, however, differs with this suggestion, as explained below in the text.</i> who died before.”<br>But there is no need for this; <i>the first-born</i> is just in contrast to <i>the younger</i>. In fraternal relations the one who is older is called “first-born,” and all those younger than he are called “the younger ones.”<br>Thus the first fruits of the year are called <i>bikurim;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">267</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Bikurim</i> has as its root the word <i>b’chor</i> (the first born). Here also the first fruits are relative to this year’s crop.</i> likewise, <i>the first-born of the poor</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">268</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 14:30.</i> meaning the most destitute, the poor of the poor. Likewise, <i>With the loss of his first-born shall he lay the foundation thereof, and with the loss of his younger shall he set up the gates of it</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">269</sup><i class="footnote">Joshua 6:26.</i> Onkelos also here translated, <i>rabtha</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">270</sup><i class="footnote">“The older.” And he did not translate, as elsewhere, <i>buchra</i> (the first-born).</i>

Verse 32

THAT WE MAY KEEP ALIVE SEED FROM OUR FATHER. The intent is perhaps that they said: “Let us do what we can, so that G-d should have mercy, and we shall give birth to a boy and a girl from whom the world shall be sustained, for <i>the world will be built with kindness</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">271</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 89:3.</i> and it is not in vain that G-d has saved us.” Now they were modest and did not want to tell their father to marry them, as a Noachide<sup class="footnote-marker">272</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Seder Bereshith</i>, Note 288.</i> is permitted to take his daughter.<sup class="footnote-marker">273</sup><i class="footnote">Sanhedrin 58b.</i> It may be that the matter was extremely repulsive in the eyes of the people of those generations and was never done. Our Rabbis,<sup class="footnote-marker">274</sup><i class="footnote">Bereshith Rabbah 51:11-12.</i> in Agadic expositions, likewise discredit Lot very much.

Chapter 20



Verse 1



Verse 2

AND ABRAHAM SAID OF SARAH HIS WIFE, SHE IS MY SISTER. This was not like what happened in Egypt. There, when they entered the land, it is said that the Egyptians saw that the woman was beautiful, and they praised her to the lords and to Pharaoh,<sup class="footnote-marker">275</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 12:14-15.</i> as they were an immoral people but this king was perfect and upright, and his people were likewise good. However Abraham suspected them, and he told everyone that she was his sister.
AND ABIMELECH, KING OF GERAR, SENT AND TOOK SARAH. It is wondrous that Sarah, after being worn with age, was extremely beautiful, fit to be taken by kings. When she was taken to Pharaoh, though she was sixty-five<sup class="footnote-marker">276</sup><i class="footnote">According to the Seder Olam, the famine occurred in Egypt in the year in which Abraham left Haran, and that is when Abraham went there (Chapter 1). Now Scripture states that when he left Haran, Abraham was seventy-five years old (12:4); Sarah who was ten years younger (17:17) was thus sixty-five.</i> years old, it is possible that she still had her beautiful appearance, but after being worn with age and the manner of women had ceased with her, that is a wonder! Perhaps her youthfulness returned to her when the angel brought her the tidings, as our Rabbis have said.<sup class="footnote-marker">277</sup><i class="footnote">Baba Metzia 87 a: “Her skin became smooth, and the wrinkles straightened, and beauty returned to its form.”</i>

Verse 3



Verse 4



Verse 5



Verse 6



Verse 7



Verse 8



Verse 9



Verse 10



Verse 11



Verse 12

AND YET SHE IS MY SISTER, THE DAUGHTER OF MY FATHER. I know not the sense of this apology. Even if it were true that she was his sister and his wife, nevertheless when they wanted to take her as a wife and he told them, <i>She is my sister</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">278</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 2 here.</i> in order to lead them astray, he already committed a sin towards them by bringing upon them a <i>great sin</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">279</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 9 here.</i> and it no longer mattered at all whether the thing was true or false!<br>Perhaps it was because Abimelech said, <i>What sawest thou, that thou hast done this thing?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">280</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 10 here.</i> meaning “What sin or wickedness have you seen in me that caused you to do this out of fear? I have never attempted to take women away from their husbands.” Then Abraham answered: “I did not know you, but I thought, perhaps <i>the fear of G-d is not in this place</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">281</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 11 here.</i> for in most places in the world there is no fear of G-d. Therefore, from the time I left my country and aimlessly wandered among the nations not knowing to which place we would come, I made this condition with her that she say thus in all places. For the matter is true, and I thought that by doing this, human life would be saved. I did not begin this practice upon entering your country for I did not see that you had committed any sin.” <i>And yet she is my sister, the daughter of my father</i>. This expression represents a different argument. Abraham said: “According to my custom, I said so for it is true, and I further thought that in case they will want her they will ask me if she is also my wife. Since your servants took her and they did not ask me any questions, I said, ‘The fear of G-d is also not in this place’ and I remained quiet.”<br>It is possible that he established this condition with her when they came to Egypt even though he said that he did it <i>when G-d caused me to wander from my father’s house</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">282</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 13 here.</i> It may be that he again warned her there in Egypt at the time of the event, as I have explained.<sup class="footnote-marker">283</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 12:11.</i><br>Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra’s opinion is that all these words were to put off Abimelech.

Verse 13



Verse 14



Verse 15



Verse 16

BEHOLD, I HAVE GIVEN THY BROTHER A THOUSAND PIECES OF SILVER. The sheep, the cattle and the servants which he gave him were worth a thousand pieces of silver. He thus said to Sarah: “Behold, I have given much money to your brother. Now the money will serve you as a cause for the covering of the eyes of all those who look at your beauty,<sup class="footnote-marker">284</sup><i class="footnote">“Had I given the money to you, people might say it was a harlot’s hire. But now that I have given it to your brother, people will say that I had to redeem myself against my will, and this will thus enable you to speak freely in your defense.” (Bachya.)</i> closing their eyes, and those of their leaders, the seers,<sup class="footnote-marker">285</sup><i class="footnote">See Isaiah 29:10, <i>And your heads, the seers hath He covered</i>.</i> to prevent them looking at you and at all that belongs to you, even your manservants and maidservants. Thus your being taken forcibly to my house was for your benefit as they will fear you and cover their eyes to avoid looking at you, saying: ‘The king had to redeem himself for having stretched forth his hand to the prophet’s wife.’”<br>The verse thus tells that Abimelech mollified Abraham with money, and Sarah with words, so that he should not be punished on account of either of them. The verse states in conclusion, <i>venochachath</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">286</sup><i class="footnote">According to Ramban, as is clear from the text further on, the translation of this word is, “and she continued to protest.”</i> as Sarah did not accept his apology, <i>for with all this</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">287</sup><i class="footnote">The money he gave to Abraham and the words of apology he offered her.</i> she yet continued arguing with him, saying that she would not forgive him. The verse thus speaks in her praise. Abraham, however, was appeased, and he prayed for the king. The word <i>venochachath</i> is similar in usage to these verses: <i>And with Israel ‘yithvakach’ (He has an argument);</i><sup class="footnote-marker">288</sup><i class="footnote">Micah 6:2.</i> <i>But my ways ‘ochiach’ (will I argue) before Him;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">289</sup><i class="footnote">Job 13:15.</i> <i>There the upright ‘nochach’ (might reason) with Him</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">290</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 23:7.</i><br>It is possible that the expression, <i>a thousand pieces of silver to thy brother</i>, means thousands of pieces of silver, much wealth, <i>according to the bounty of the king</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">291</sup><i class="footnote">Esther 1:7.</i> Similarly, <i>The smallest shall become a thousand</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">292</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 60:22.</i> [means that the smallest will become] a great people. Similarly: <i>Restore, I pray you, to them even this day, their fields, their vineyards, their oliveyards, and their houses, also the hundred pieces of silver, and the corn, the wine, and oil, that ye exact of them</i><sup class="footnote-marker">293</sup><i class="footnote">Nehemiah 5:11.</i> — [here too <i>the hundred pieces of silver</i> refer to] many hundreds, a great deal of money.

Verse 17

‘VAYEILEIDU’ (AND THEY BORE CHILDREN). If this is understood literally as referring to <i>his wife, and his maidservants</i> and stating that the Eternal had restrained their wombs, it is astonishing! For it appears that on the first night that Sarah was taken to Abimelech’s house, and he had not even approached her,<sup class="footnote-marker">294</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 4 here.</i> G-d immediately came to him in the dream, and in the morning he rose early and called his servants and also Abraham.<sup class="footnote-marker">295</sup><i class="footnote">Verses 8-9 here.</i> When then did they experience this restraining of the womb? Perhaps it so happened that they were in their due time, experiencing the pangs of childbirth, unable to be relieved by giving birth. Perhaps, also, Abraham delayed his prayer for many days. But according to this interpretation, the nature of Abimelech’s healing as well as his sickness have not been explained in Scripture.<br>Now Rashi comments: “<i>Vayeileidu</i> — and they were relieved,<sup class="footnote-marker">296</sup><i class="footnote">In our Rashi: “Explain it as the Targum does, ‘and they were relieved.’”</i> their channels were opened, and they brought forth their wastes. This was the <i>leidah</i> (bringing forth) as it referred to them. <i>All the wombs</i> means every opening of the body.”<br>But this is not correct. Even if we were to say concerning the word <i>vayeileidu</i> that it means “bringing forth” — as we do indeed find the word <i>leidah</i> used in many contexts, such as: <i>Yea, he conceiveth mischief ‘veyolad’ (and bringeth forth) falsehood;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">297</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 7:15.</i> <i>Before the decree ‘ledeth’ (bring forth);</i><sup class="footnote-marker">298</sup><i class="footnote">Zephaniah 2:2.</i> <i>for thou knowest not what a day ‘yolad’ (may bring forth)</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">299</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 27:1.</i> meaning what the days will bring forth and originate — but the word <i>rechem</i> (womb) never refers to any other openings. This is not contradicted by the verse, <i>Or, who shut up the sea with doors, when it broke forth, and issued out of the womb</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">300</sup><i class="footnote">Job 38:8.</i> for this is merely a figure of speech,<sup class="footnote-marker">301</sup><i class="footnote">Meaning when the sea broke from the abyss, where it was formed as a child in his mother’s womb. (Ramban in his commentary to Job, <i>ibid.</i>,)</i> similar to “the belly of the earth.”<sup class="footnote-marker">302</sup><i class="footnote">See Jonah 2:3, <i>the belly of the netherworld</i>.</i><br>Now Onkelos’ opinion is not like that of the Rabbi<sup class="footnote-marker">303</sup><i class="footnote">Rashi.</i> for even if he translated, “and they were relieved,” yet the word <i>rechem</i> (womb) he renders literally as “the opening for giving birth to a child.” However, [the reason why Onkelos translated it, “and they were relieved,” and not “and they gave birth,” is that] he wanted to include Abimelech also in the word <i>vayeileidu</i>.<br>In Bereshith Rabbah<sup class="footnote-marker">304</sup><i class="footnote">52:14.</i> it is said: “<i>For the Eternal had fast closed up (‘atzor atzar’)</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">305</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 18 here.</i> i.e., closed up the mouth, closed up the neck, closed up the eye, closed up the ear, closed up above,<sup class="footnote-marker">306</sup><i class="footnote">“Above… below,” a reference to urination, the minor function of the body, and defecation, the major function.</i> and closed up below.” Now the Rabbis derived this exposition from the double usage of the expression, <i>atzor atzar</i>, but they did not explain the expression, <i>every</i> womb, as meaning every opening of the body.<br>The correct interpretation appears to me to be that from the day Sarah was taken to Abimelech’s house, Abimelech was stricken in his limbs and was unable to fulfill his needs. This is [what the verse alludes to when it says], <i>Therefore I did not suffer thee to touch her</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">307</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 6 here.</i> as “touching” or “approaching” women are euphemisms for sexual intercourse, as in the verse, <i>Draw not near a woman;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">308</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 19:15.</i> <i>And I came unto the prophetess</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">309</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 8:3.</i> And He restrained the wombs of his wife and his maidservants who were pregnant so they could not give birth. “Restraining a womb” means that the woman could not conceive, even as it says, <i>And the Eternal had closed up her womb</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">310</sup><i class="footnote">I Samuel 1:5.</i> But “restraining the womb” denotes inability to give birth, similar in usage to the verse, <i>He hath hedged me about, that I cannot go forth</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">311</sup><i class="footnote">Lamentations 3:7.</i><br>Sarah stayed in Abimelech’s house many days, and Abimelech did not repent his way as he did not understand his transgression until G-d came to him in a dream and informed him of it. Now Scripture does not explain Abimelech’s sickness explicitly but mentions it only by hint in an ethical manner and out of respect for Sarah. After Abraham’s prayer, Abimelech and his wife and his maidservants were healed, and the women gave birth.

Chapter 21



Verse 1

AND THE ETERNAL ‘PAKAD’ (VISITED) SARAH AS HE HAD SAID. That is, by granting her pregnancy. <i>And the Eternal did unto Sarah as He had spoken</i> by granting her the birth of a son..Thus the words of Rashi.<br>But the word <i>pekidah</i> is only an expression of remembrance and attention to the one who is remembered, such as: <i>G-d will surely remember (‘pakod yiphkod’) you;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">312</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 50:25.</i> <i>I have surely remembered you;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">313</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 3:16.</i> <i>And Samson remembered his wife by</i> [bringing her] <i>a kid</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">314</sup><i class="footnote">Judges 15:1.</i> Here, too, the sense of the verse is that the Eternal remembered Sarah, and He did to her as He had spoken. This expression is also found in connection with all barren women who later give birth.
