Thus, in the case of Rachel: <i>And G-d remembered Rachel;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">315</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 30:22.</i> and in the case of Hannah: <i>And G-d remembered her</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">316</sup><i class="footnote">I Samuel 1:19.</i> Similarly, the Rabb is said,<sup class="footnote-marker">317</sup><i class="footnote">Rosh Hashanah 32b.</i> “Biblical verses which mention <i>pikdonoth</i> are equivalent to verses which mention Divine remembrances.”<sup class="footnote-marker">318</sup><i class="footnote">In the Additional Service of the New Year day, ten Biblical verses which speak of Divine remembrance are recited. A verse mentioning <i>pikadon</i> is treated as one mentioning remembrance. Thus, Ramban proves that the word <i>pakad</i> in the verse here can mean “remembered,” and not as Rashi explained it as meaning “granting pregnancy.”</i>

Verse 2



Verse 3



Verse 4



Verse 5



Verse 6



Verse 7

‘MI’ (WHO) WOULD HAVE SAID UNTO ABRAHAM. The word <i>mi</i> is used as an exclamation of praise and distinction. The sense of the verse is thus: “See Whom it is and to what extent He keeps His promise. He promises and performs!” Thus the language of Rashi.<br>But we do not find the word <i>mi</i> used in this way in expressions of distinction and honor. Instead, we find it used only in a derogatory sense: <i>‘Mi’ (Who is) Abimelech, and ‘mi’ (who is)</i> Shechem?<sup class="footnote-marker">319</sup><i class="footnote">Judges 9:28.</i> <i>‘Mi’ (Who is) the son of Jesse?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">320</sup><i class="footnote">I Samuel 25:10.</i><br>The correct interpretation appears to me to be that Sarah said, “<i>G-d hath made laughter for me; and every one that heareth will laugh on account of me</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">321</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 6 here.</i> filling his mouth with song and laughter for the wonder that has been done to me, for who among the hearers would have previously said to Abraham that Sarah will suckle children? There is not a person in the world who would have told him this, even merely to console him, for the possibility would never have occurred to anyone.” Onkelos’ rendition is close to this interpretation: “How faithful is He who spoke to Abraham! He has fulfilled His word that Sarah will suckle children.” That is to say, “Everyone that heareth will laugh on account of me” for there is no person who would have maintained his credulity even in the eyes of Abraham if he were to have told him this wonder.

Verse 8



Verse 9

‘METZACHEIK’ (MAKING SPORT). This refers to worshipping idols, murder and sexual immorality. He [Ishmael] quarrelled with Isaac about inheritance, saying, “I am the first-born and will take a double portion.”<sup class="footnote-marker">322</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 21:17.</i> They then went into the field, and Ishmael took his bow and shot arrows at Isaac, just as you say, <i>As a madman who casteth firebrands, arrows and death, so is the man who deceiveth his neighbor, and saith, Am I not in sport?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">323</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 26:18-19.</i> It is from Sarah’s complaint to Abraham — <i>for the son of this bondwoman shall not be heir</i>, etc.<sup class="footnote-marker">324</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 10 here.</i> — that you learn [that they were quarrelling about the inheritance]. All this is Rashi’s language.<br>Here too,<sup class="footnote-marker">325</sup><i class="footnote">See above, 19:24, where Ramban criticizes Rashi in a similar manner. Hence the word “too.”</i> the Rabbi<sup class="footnote-marker">303</sup><i class="footnote">Rashi.</i> writes all the different opinions, [mentioned in the following]: “We have been taught:<sup class="footnote-marker">326</sup><i class="footnote">Tosefta Sotah 6:6. A part thereof is mentioned in Rosh Hashanah 18b.</i> Rabbi Shimon the son of Eleazar said, ‘There are four interpretations of Rabbi Akiba which I interpret differently, and my interpretation seems more acceptable than his. Rabbi Akiba interpreted: “<i>And Sarah saw the son of Hagar the Egyptian, whom she had borne unto Abraham, making sport. Making sport</i> is but a designation for idolatry, etc.” But I say Heaven forbid that such be in the house of the righteous one! Is it possible that he, of whom it was written, <i>For I have known him, to the end that he may command his children and his household</i>, etc.,<sup class="footnote-marker">327</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 18:19.</i> will have in his household idolatry, sexual immorality, and murder? <i>Making sport</i> mentioned here is but a designation for the inheritance. When Isaac was born and everyone rejoiced, Ishmael said to them, “Fools, I am the first-born, and I take a double portion.” From the complaint of our mother Sarah to Abraham you learn [that <i>making sport</i> refers to the inheritance]. And my interpretation seems more acceptable than that of Rabbi Akiba.’”<br>The expression of the Rabbi,<sup class="footnote-marker">303</sup><i class="footnote">Rashi.</i> “that Ishmael quarrelled with Isaac about the inheritance,” also does not appear correct for if so, this must have happened much later when Isaac was grown up, and Ishmael would then have been too big for his mother to carry him on her shoulder.<sup class="footnote-marker">328</sup><i class="footnote">See Verse 14 here.</i> Our Rabbis have also said<sup class="footnote-marker">329</sup><i class="footnote">Yalkut Shimoni Genesis, 95: “Ishmael was seventeen years old when he left his father’s house.” Isaac was then three years of age (see Note 330). See also the note in my Hebrew commentary, p. 123.</i> that Ishmael was seventeen years old [at the time he left his father’s house]. If so, this happened at the time when Isaac was weaned,<sup class="footnote-marker">330</sup><i class="footnote">At the time of Isaac’s birth, Ishmael was fourteen years old. (He was thirteen at his circumcision (17:25), and a year later Isaac was born.) Now since Ishmael was seventeen when he left his father’s house, Isaac was three years old at the time, at which age he was weaned (Verse 8).</i> [and Isaac was thus too young for Ishmael to quarrel with him about the inheritance].<br>Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra said in line with the literal interpretation of Scripture that <i>metzachek</i> means “playing,” as is normal for every boy, and she was jealous of him because he was bigger than her son.<br>The correct interpretation appears to me to be that this event took place <i>on the day that Isaac was weaned</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">331</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 8 here.</i> and Sarah saw Ishmael mocking Isaac or the great feast. It is for this reason that the verse says, <i>And Sarah saw the son of Hagar the Egyptian</i> — rather than Ishmael — <i>making sport</i>. Similarly, she said, <i>Cast out this bondwoman and her son</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">324</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 10 here.</i> for she said: “The slave who mocks his master is deserving of death or stripes, but I want only that you cast him out from before me, and that he should in no way inherit your belongings together with my son, who is the son of the mistress.” She also told Abraham to cast out his mother, as the boy was unable to leave her for he would die if he were to leave his mother.<sup class="footnote-marker">332</sup><i class="footnote">See further, 44:22.</i>

Verse 10



Verse 11

AND THE THING WAS VERY GRIEVOUS IN ABRAHAM’s SIGHT ON ACCOUNT OF HIS SON. That is, for he had taken to degenerate ways. The plain meaning, however, is that he was grieved because she had told him to send him away. Thus the language of Rashi.<br>The correct interpretation appears to me to be that Scripture is speaking in honor of Abraham, saying that the reason why the matter was very displeasing to him was not due to a craving for his concubine and his desire for her. Therefore, if she had told him to cast out only the maidservant, he would have done her will. But it was on account of his son that he was very much incensed and did not want to listen to her. But the Holy One, blessed be He, told him that he should not resent it at all, neither for the son nor for the maidservant, and that he should listen to Sarah’s bidding for it is through Isaac alone that his name will be carried on, while Ishmael will not be referred to as his offspring. Now because Abraham feared lest an accident happen to Ishmael upon his sending him away, He told him that He will make a nation of him and He will bless him since he is indeed his son.

Verse 12



Verse 13



Verse 14

AND THE CHILD, AND HE SENT HER AWAY. This is to be understood in connection with the above: <i>And he gave to Hagar</i> [the bread and bottle of water]… <i>and the child</i>, for he gave her the child also to go with her wherever she will go.

Verse 15

AND SHE CAST THE CHILD. Thirst overtook him and he was unable to walk, and so his mother laid him under the tree, cast away and abandoned. It may be that the word <i>vatashleich (and she cast)</i> is similar in sense to the verses: <i>And He cast them into another land;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">333</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 29:27.</i> <i>Cast me not away from Thy presence</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">334</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 51:13.</i> meaning “sending away.”<br>Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra said: “<i>And she cast</i> for she had taken him onto her lap when he was weakened by thirst, [and seeing that he was expiring from thirst, she cast him from her].”<br>Our Rabbis have said<sup class="footnote-marker">335</sup><i class="footnote">Bereshith Rabbah 53:17.</i> that he was sick at the time he sent him away, and therefore he put the child on her shoulder. This is the sense of the word <i>vatashleich (and she cast)</i> him: [until that point she had carried him].<br>All this occurred to Abraham because he had been commanded to do whatever Sarah said, and she commanded that he send him away immediately, and it was at her command that he did not give them silver and gold, servants, and camels to bear them.

Verse 16



Verse 17

WHERE HE IS. He shall be judged according to his present deeds, and not according to those actions which he may do in the future. This was because the ministering angels laid charges, etc. Thus the words of Rashi quoting from the teachings of our Rabbis.<sup class="footnote-marker">336</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 19.</i><br>The correct interpretation, in line with the simple meaning of Scripture, appears to me to be that the verse is stating that G-d heard the voice of the lad in the place in which he was. He informed her that she will not need to go from there to a fountain or well for in that very place he will quench his thirst immediately. He thus said to her, “<i>Arise, lift up the lad</i><sup class="footnote-marker">337</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 18 here.</i> after you will have given him to drink, <i>for I will make him a great nation</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">337</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 18 here.</i> Similarly, the word <i>sham (there)</i> in verses, <i>Where he sunk, there he fell down dead;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">338</sup><i class="footnote">Judges 5:27. Meaning, “‘in the place’ where he fell.”</i> <i>And where the slain are, there is she</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">339</sup><i class="footnote">Job 39:30. Meaning “And ‘in the place’ where the slain are.”</i> alludes to the place.

Verse 18



Verse 19



Verse 20

ROVEH KASHOTH (AN ARCHER). Since <i>kashoth</i> is an adjective, they<sup class="footnote-marker">340</sup><i class="footnote">Ibn Ezra and R’dak. Their point is as follows: Since <i>kashoth</i> is an adjective, or more precisely, a <i>shem hatoar</i>, (a noun-adjective), as is also <i>roveh</i>, how could two adjectives appear without a noun? Therefore they said that the two words, <i>roveh kashoth</i>, are not in construct with one another, but they are interpreted as <i>roveh vekashoth</i> (a shooter of arrows and maker of bows) with the companion noun of each adjective being tacitly understood. Ramban’s opinion, however, is that since <i>roveh</i> may mean either “a shooter of arrows” or “a thrower of stones,” the word <i>kashoth</i> is used in order to explain that he was a shooter with the bow, meaning, a shooter of arrows and not a thrower of stones.</i> have said that <i>roveh</i> is one who shoots arrows, the word being derived from the expressions: <i>His archers compass me round about;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">341</sup><i class="footnote">Job 16:13.</i> <i>The archers have dealt bitterly with him</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">342</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 49:23.</i> — and <i>kashoth</i> is one who makes arrows.<br>A more correct interpretation is that <i>roveh</i> is a shooter, and it can refer to one who shoots arrows or throws stones or other objects, even as it is said, <i>Behold this heap… which I have thrown up between me and thee</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">343</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 31:51.</i> Therefore, the verse describes him further by saying that he was a shooter with the bow. In a similar sense is the verse, <i>And the shooters of arrows by the bow overtook him</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">344</sup><i class="footnote">I Samuel 31:3.</i>

Verse 21



Verse 22



Verse 23

NOW THEREFORE SWEAR UNTO ME HERE BY G-D ‘IM’ (IF) YOU WILL BE FALSE TO ME. The word <i>im</i> always expresses doubt — do not think of it in any other way<sup class="footnote-marker">345</sup><i class="footnote">Ramban’s intent is to differ with Rashi, who, in Leviticus 2:14, explains <i>im</i> to mean “that.” See Ramban there, where he explains it in a manner consistent with his teaching here.</i> — and it appears in most places in connection with an oath: <i>If you will be false to me;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">346</sup><i class="footnote">In the present verse.</i> <i>And therefore I have sworn unto the house of Eli ‘im’ (if) the iniquity of Eli’s house shall be expiated;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">347</sup><i class="footnote">I Samuel 3:14.</i> <i>Once I have sworn by My holiness ‘im’ (if) I will be false unto David;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">348</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 89:36.</i> <i>‘im’ (if) they should enter into My rest;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">349</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 95:11.</i> <i>And he was wroth, and swore, saying, ‘im’ (if) one of these men will see</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">350</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 1:34-35.</i><br>The purport of this is that since oaths are given with imprecation, Abimelech is stating, “Swear to me, saying, <i>G-d do so to me, and more also</i><sup class="footnote-marker">351</sup><i class="footnote">II Samuel 3:35.</i> if you will be false to me.” Likewise it is said, <i>Let there now be an oath between us</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">352</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 26:28.</i> And in the matter of a Divine oath: <i>I have sworn by My holiness if I will be false to David;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">348</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 89:36.</i> <i>if the iniquity of Eli’s house shall be expiated</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">347</sup><i class="footnote">I Samuel 3:14.</i> meaning “If that will be so, then My word is not true,” and in similar cases, since it does not want to expressly state the condition.<sup class="footnote-marker">353</sup><i class="footnote">Namely, that “if that be so, My word is not true.”</i> Scripture modifies and shortens these expressions. A similar case of a shortened condition is the verse, <i>And Jabez called on the G-d of Israel, saying: Oh that Thou wouldest bless me indeed, and enlarge my border</i>, etc., <i>and that Thou wouldest work deliverance from evil that it may not pain me. And G-d granted him that which he requested</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">354</sup><i class="footnote">I Chronicles 4:10.</i> Here the entire condition<sup class="footnote-marker">355</sup><i class="footnote">Namely, his vow of offering to G-d.</i> is missing. A similar example is the verse, <i>If they will see the land</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">356</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 14:23.</i> referring back to the first verse, <i>As I live, and all shall be filled with the glory of the Eternal</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">357</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 21.</i> and Scripture shortens the Divine oath.<br>The expression, <i>false to me</i>, is because Abimelech was a king, and Abraham dwelt in his land. [Thus, if Abraham were to do him evil, it would be an act of disloyalty towards him in his royal capacity], or it would be a betrayal of Abimelech’s love for him, as he [Abimelech] was his trustworthy friend, honoring him and doing his will. For you see that Abraham found no fault with him except <i>the well of water, which Abimelech’s servants had violently taken away</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">358</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 25 here.</i> and the king said to him, <i>According to the kindness that I have done unto thee</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">359</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 23 here.</i>

Verse 24



Verse 25



Verse 26



Verse 27



Verse 28



Verse 29



Verse 30



Verse 31



Verse 32

AND THEY RETURNED TO THE LAND OF THE PHILISTINES. The sense of the verse is that they returned to their city which was in the land of the Philistines for they lived in the land of the Philistines. However, they abode in Gerar,<sup class="footnote-marker">360</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 20:1.</i> which was the royal capital, while Abraham dwelled in Beer-sheba, which is in the land of the Philistines, in the valley of Gerar.<sup class="footnote-marker">361</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 26:17.</i>

Verse 33

AND HE CALLED THERE IN THE NAME OF THE ETERNAL, ‘E-IL OLAM’ (THE EVERLASTING G-D). Scripture explains that Abraham called by the name Eternal He Who in His might directs the time.<br>It may be that heaven and earth are here being called <i>olam</i> (world) [so that the sense of the verse is, “he called by the name Eternal the G-d of the world”], as is a customary expression in the words of our Rabbis. Thus Scripture informs us by this that Abraham called out and informed people of the secret of the leadership of the entire world, namely, that it is <i>in the name of the Eternal</i>, the Mighty One in strength, Supreme in power over all.<br>Now the Rabbi<sup class="footnote-marker">362</sup><i class="footnote">Rambam. See <i>Seder Bereshith</i>, Note 139.</i> said in the Moreh Nebuchim<sup class="footnote-marker">363</sup><i class="footnote">II, 13. See also III, 29.</i> that this alludes to the principle of the pre-existence of G-d since Abraham let it be known that G-d existed before the creation of time. Onkelos, however, said of the word <i>vayikra</i> (and he called), that it refers to prayer.

Chapter 22



Verse 1

AND G-D TRIED ABRAHAM. The matter of “trial,”<sup class="footnote-marker">364</sup><i class="footnote">See Rambam’s discussion of this problem, <i>ibid.</i>, III, 24.</i> in my opinion, is as follows: Since a man’s deeds are at his absolute free command, to perform them or not to perform them at his will, on the part of one who is tried it is called “a trial.” But on the part of the One, blessed be He, who tries the person, it is a command that the one being tested should bring forth the matter from the potential into actuality so that he may be rewarded for a good deed, not for a good thought alone.<br>Know further that <i>G-d trieth the righteous</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">365</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 11:5. See also Bereshith Rabbah 34:2. “The Holy One, blessed be He, trieth only the righteous.”</i> for knowing that the righteous will do His will, He desires to make him even more upright, and so He commands him to undertake a test, but He does not try the wicked, who would not obey. Thus all trials in the Torah are for the good of the one who is being tried.

Verse 2

TAKE NOW THY SON, THINE ONLY SON. Since Isaac was the son of the mistress and he alone was to be the one to carry his name, He called him Abraham’s only son. The description was for the purpose of magnifying the command, thus saying: “Take now thy only son, the beloved one, Isaac, and bring him up before Me as a burnt-offering.”
MORIAH. Rashi comments: “This is Jerusalem, and we find it in the book of Chronicles: <i>To build the house of the Eternal at Jerusalem on mount Moriah</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">366</sup><i class="footnote">II Chronicles 3:1.</i> Our Rabbis have explained that it is called <i>Moriah</i> (instruction) because from the Temple built there on that mountain, instruction came forth to Israel.<sup class="footnote-marker">367</sup><i class="footnote">The Chamber of Hewn Stone (<i>Lishchat hagazith</i>), the seat of the Great Sanhedrin, which was the highest court in Israel, was located in the Court of the Temple. See Deuteronomy 17:8-11.</i> Onkelos translated it as “the land of Worship.” This he derived on the basis of reference to the burning of incense, which contained <i>mor</i><sup class="footnote-marker">368</sup><i class="footnote">Hence the name <i>Moriah</i>: the mountain on which <i>mor</i> (myrrh), as part of the incense, was to be burnt. Thus according to Rashi’s understanding of Onkelos. Ramban will later differ with this interpretation in the meaning of Onkelos.</i> (myrrh) and other spices, [as part of the Divine Service].”<br>Now if so, [i.e., if this be the explanation of the name <i>Moriah</i>], the meaning of the verse will then be, “Go into the land which will be called <i>Moriah</i>.” Or it may be that it was always called so on account of the future. In Bereshith Rabbah,<sup class="footnote-marker">369</sup><i class="footnote">55:9.</i> the Sages have said thus: “The Rabbis say, <i>Go into the land of Moriah</i> means into the land where incense will be offered on the altar of G-d, even as it is said, <i>I will get me to the mountain ‘hamor’ (of myrrh)</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">370</sup><i class="footnote">Song of Songs 4:6.</i> But the opinion of Onkelos, who said “the land of worship,” does not appear to be based on the myrrh in the incense, as Rashi said, for the word “service” does not refer to one of the species used in one of the Divine Services. Besides, why did not Onkelos say, “to the land of the incense of spices?” Instead, Onkelos’ intent is to say, “in the land in which they will worhip G-d.”<br>Onkelos thus matched that which the Sages interpreted in Pirkei d’Rabbi Eliezer, where they said,<sup class="footnote-marker">371</sup><i class="footnote">Chapter 31.</i> “The Holy One, blessed be He, showed Abraham the altar with a finger. He said to him, ‘This is the altar on which the first man sacrificed. This is the altar on which Cain and Abel sacrificed. This is the altar on which Noah and his sons sacrificed.’ For it is said, <i>And Abraham built ‘hamizbei’ach’ (the altar) there</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">372</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 9 here.</i> <i>mizbei’ach</i> (an altar) is not written here, rather, <i>hamizbei’ach (the</i> altar). This is the altar on which the predecessors have sacrificed.” Thus far [is the interpretation of Pirkei d’Rabbi Eliezer]. And the name <i>Moriah</i> the Rabbis derived from the word <i>mora</i> (fear), for there the people feared G-d and worshipped Him.<br>The correct interpretation, in line with the plain meaning of Scripture, is that the name <i>Moriah</i> is like the expression, <i>To the mountain of myrrh, and to the hill of frankincense</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">370</sup><i class="footnote">Song of Songs 4:6.</i> for on that mountain [Moriah] are found <i>myrrh, aloes, and cinnamon</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">373</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 7:17.</i> even as the Rabbis have said:<sup class="footnote-marker">374</sup><i class="footnote">Yerushalmi Peah 7:3.</i> “Cinnamon grew in the Land of Israel, and goats and deers ate of it.” Or it may be that it was so called in praise of the Land of Israel.<sup class="footnote-marker">375</sup><i class="footnote">But myrrh, aloes and cinnamon actually do not grow on mount Moriah itself. It was, however, called by that name, in order to give praise to the land where these things grow.</i><br>Now here Scripture calls the name of the land, <i>the land of Moriah</i>, and there [in the book of Chronicles, mentioned above],<sup class="footnote-marker">366</sup><i class="footnote">II Chronicles 3:1.</i> it appears that only the Temple mount was called mount Moriah. Perhaps, the city<sup class="footnote-marker">376</sup><i class="footnote">“The City.” The Tur, quoting Ramban, has “the land.”</i> was called by the name of that mountain which it contains, [and the name “land of Moriah” means] the land which contains the <i>Moriah</i>, but it was the mountain alone that was called <i>Moriah</i>. Now Abraham knew the land but did not know the mountain. Hence G-d told him to go to the land of <i>Moriah</i>, and He will there show him one of the mountains which is called by that name. He commanded him to offer up his son in that place for that is <i>the mountain which G-d hath desired for His abode</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">377</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 68:17.</i> and He wanted the merit of the <i>Akeidah</i> (the Binding of Isaac) to be in the sacrifices forever, as Abraham said, <i>The Eternal seeth</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">378</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 14 here.</i> Moreover, <i>for His righteousness’ sake</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">379</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 42:21.</i> He increased the scope of the trial and wanted Abraham to do it after walking three days. Had Abraham been commanded to do so suddenly at his place, his deed would have been performed in haste and confusion, but since it was done after walking for days it was thus performed with reflection of mind and counsel. And so did the Rabbis say in Bereshith Rabbah:<sup class="footnote-marker">380</sup><i class="footnote">55:5.</i> “Rabbi Akiba said, ‘G-d surely tried [Abraham with a clear-cut situation] so that people should not say that He confounded him and confused him and he did not know what to do.’”

Verse 3

AND HE CLEAVED THE WOOD FOR THE BURNT-OFFERING. This illustrates Abraham’s zeal in performing a commandment for he thought that perhaps there would be no wood in that place, and so he carried it for three days. It may be that Abraham disqualified for use as an offering any wood in which a worm is found, as is the law of the Torah,<sup class="footnote-marker">381</sup><i class="footnote">Midoth 2:5.</i> and so he took from his house sound wood for the burnt-offering. Hence it says, <i>And he cleaved the wood for the burnt-offering</i>.

Verse 4

AND HE SAW THE PLACE AFAR OFF. He saw a cloud attached to the mountain,<sup class="footnote-marker">382</sup><i class="footnote">Bereshith Rabbah 56:2.</i> and through this was fulfilled the Divine assurance, <i>which I will tell thee of</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">383</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 2 here.</i><br>It is possible, in line with the simple meaning of Scripture, that the verse, <i>And he saw the place afar off</i>, means that he saw the land of <i>Moriah</i> for he knew that entire land [although he did not know the specific mountain].

Verse 5



Verse 6



Verse 7



Verse 8



Verse 9

AND THEY CAME TO THE PLACE WHICH G-D TOLD HIM OF — now,<sup class="footnote-marker">384</sup><i class="footnote">As explained above, Abraham recognized the land of <i>Moriah</i> from a distance as he was acquainted with that whole land, and when he came near the mountain, G-d told him, “This is the place which I had designated to you.” All this is in line with the plain meaning of Scripture, as Ramban mentioned above.</i> “This is mount Moriah,” for He told him, “Behold, this is the mountain of which I told you.”

Verse 10



Verse 11



Verse 12

FOR NOW I KNOW THAT THOU ART A G-D FEARING MAN. At the beginning Abraham’s fear of G-d was latent; it had not become actualized through such a great deed. But now it was known in actuality, and his merit was perfect, and his reward would be complete from the Eternal, the G-d of Israel.<sup class="footnote-marker">385</sup><i class="footnote">See Ruth 2:12.</i><br>The doctrine of this chapter which teaches that G-d is the One who tries Abraham and commands him about the binding of Isaac, and it is the angel of G-d who restrains and promises him, will be explained in the verse, <i>The angel who hath redeemed me</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">386</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 48:16.</i>

Verse 13



Verse 14



Verse 15



Verse 16

BECAUSE THOU HAST DONE THIS THING. In the beginning He promised him that he would increase his descendants as the stars of heaven<sup class="footnote-marker">387</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 15:5.</i> and the dust of the earth,<sup class="footnote-marker">388</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 13:16.</i> but now He gave him the additional assurance that <i>because thou hast done this</i> great deed, He swore by His Great Name [that He would increase his descendants <i>as the stars of heaven, and as the sand which is upon the seashore</i>],<sup class="footnote-marker">389</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 17 here.</i> and that his seed will possess the gate of its enemies.<sup class="footnote-marker">389</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 17 here.</i> Thus Abraham was assured that no sin whatever would cause the destruction of his descendants, nor would they fall into the hand of their enemies and not rise again. Thus this constitutes a perfect Divine assurance of the redemption which is destined to come to us.

Verse 17



Verse 18



Verse 19



Verse 20

BEHOLD, MILCAH, SHE ALSO HATH BORN CHILDREN. Since Milcah was the daughter of his brother Haran,<sup class="footnote-marker">390</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 11:29.</i> this was a tiding to Abraham that his older brother Nahor<sup class="footnote-marker">391</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 28.</i> had been visited with many children from the daughter of his dead brother Haran.<sup class="footnote-marker">392</sup><i class="footnote">Abraham was older than Nahor for Scripture says, <i>Abram, Nahor, and Haran, (ibid.</i>, Verse 27). Since Nahor was older than Haran, Ramban refers to him as “the older” brother.</i><br>Now from the text of Scripture it would appear that Abraham had no knowledge of any of them except on that day. If they were visited with children in their younger days, it would be impossible for them not to have been heard until this time for the distance between Mesopotamia and the land of Canaan is not great. Now when Abraham left Haran he was seventy-five years old,<sup class="footnote-marker">393</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 12:4.</i> and Nahor was also elderly and his wife too was not young.<sup class="footnote-marker">394</sup><i class="footnote">And if Nahor and his wife had had children many years ago, Abraham would have heard of it previously.</i> Indeed, we must say, G-d performed a miracle for them in that they were visited with children in their old age. This is the sense of the verse, <i>Milcah, she also</i>. In the words of our Rabbis, it is said<sup class="footnote-marker">395</sup><i class="footnote">Yalkut Shimoni Numbers, 746. See the complete quote in my Hebrew commentary, p. 127.</i> that Milcah was visited with children as was her sister Sarah.<sup class="footnote-marker">396</sup><i class="footnote">Iscah, Milcah’s sister (above, 11:29), is another name for Sarah. (Rashi, <i>ibid.</i>)</i>

Verse 21



Verse 22



Verse 23

AND BETHUEL BEGOT REBEKAH. The verse does not mention Laban, even though he was older than Rebekah, for its intent is only to mention the eight children which Milcah bore to Nahor.<sup class="footnote-marker">397</sup><i class="footnote">And Bethuel is already the eighth: Uz, Buz, Kemuel, Chesed, Hazo, Pildash, Jidlaph, Bethuel. Hence the verse does not intend to mention the children of Bethuel, namely, Laban. Rebekah, his daughter, however, was mentioned for the reason explained in the text.</i> However, Rebekah is mentioned since the entire chapter is written to make known her genealogy.<br><i>Kemuel the father of Aram</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">398</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 21 here.</i> Aram is mentioned only in order to make known the identity of Kemuel as Aram was a more important man than his father. Perhaps, also, there was another Kemuel in their generation. Hence [Scripture identifies Kemuel by saying that] he was the father of Aram.

Verse 24

AND HIS CONCUBINE, WHOSE NAME WAS REUMAH. Scripture tells the entire tiding which they related to Abraham concerning his brother’s children.<br>It is possible that this was written in order to make known the entire genealogy of Nahor, to establish that all of them were worthy to marry the children of Abraham, and it was with reference to all of them that Abraham said to Eliezer: <i>But thou shalt go unto my father’s house and to my family</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">399</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 24:38.</i><br>Chayei Sarah

Chapter 23



Verse 1

A HUNDRED AND TWENTY YEARS Rashi comments: “The reason the word ‘years’ is written at every term is that it informs you that each term must be interpreted by itself. At the age of one hundred she was as a woman of twenty as regards sin [for at the age of twenty she had not sinned since she had not reached the age when she was subject to punishment],<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">The Heavenly Court does not punish one for sin before the age of twenty. The verse thus indicates that at the age of a hundred, Sarah never sinned, just as at the age of twenty she had never sinned.</i> and at the age of twenty she was as beautiful as when she was seven.” Rashi wrote similarly on the verse, <i>the years of Abraham’s life</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 25:7.</i><br>However, this exegesis of his<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">Ramban does not disagree with Rashi’s interpretation as this is based on the Rabbis’ comment in Bereshith Rabbah. However, Ramban does dispute which words in the Torah-text are the basis for their interpretation. Thus according to Ramban a similar interpretation would not follow in the verses concerning Abraham and Ishmael.</i> is not correct. In the case of the verse, <i>the years of the life of Ishmael</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 25:17.</i> it is stated exactly as in the verse, <i>the years of Abraham’s life</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 25:7.</i> whereas these years of Ishmael were not all equally good since Ishmael was wicked in his early years, and only in the end did he repent of his evil ways.<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">See Ramban, <i>ibid.</i></i> Furthermore, the repetition of the word “year” at every term would seem to indicate an intent to distinguish between them and, thus, should not be interpreted to imply equality. Rather, the use of the word <i>shanah</i> (year) and <i>shanim</i> (years) in this instance is the customary usage of the Hebrew language, while that which the Rabbis have said in Bereshith Rabbah,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">Bereshith Rabbah 58:1.</i> “At the age of one hundred she was as a woman of twenty as regards sin,” is an interpretation which they derived only from the redundant expression, the <i>years of the life of Sarah</i>, which includes them all and equates them. The Rabbis would not make a similar interpretation of the verse concerning Abraham [since in his case Scripture does not conclude with a similar comprehensive expression].

Verse 2

AND ABRAHAM CAME. Rashi comments: “From Beer-sheba.” Now this does not mean to imply that Abraham remained in Beer-sheba — as is indicated in the verse, <i>And Abraham abode at Beer-sheba</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 22:19.</i> for how then would Sarah have been in Hebron? Rather, the intent is to state that Abraham had gone to Beer-sheba for the day for some purpose, and while there he heard of the death of Sarah and came from there to Hebron to mourn and weep for her. However, the expression of our Rabbis is,<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">Bereshith Rabbah 58:5.</i> “<i>And Abraham came</i> — from Mount Moriah.” This is in accord with the Midrash which the Rabbi [Rashi] previously cited<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">In his commentary to Verse 2.</i> which states that hearing of the Binding [in which her son had been made ready for sacrifice and had indeed almost been sacrificed] her soul flew from her and she died.<br>It would appear that the Divine command concerning the Binding was delivered to Abraham in Beer-sheba for there he dwelt and he returned thereto after the Binding, for so it is written at the outset: <i>And Abraham planted a tamarisk-tree in Beer-sheba and called there on the name of the Eternal, the Everlasting G-d</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 21:33.</i> It further states, <i>And Abraham sojourned in the land of the Philistines many days</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 34.</i> This refers to his dwelling in Beer-sheba, which is in the land of the Philistines, and it is there that he was commanded concerning the Binding. It is for this reason that he expended three days on the journey to Mount Moriah,<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 22:4.</i> for the land of the Philistines is distant from Jerusalem. On the other hand, Hebron is in the mountains of Judah, as Scripture testifies,<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">Joshua 20:7; 21:11.</i> and is therefore near to Jerusalem. Thus, when coming from the Binding, he returned to Beer-sheba, as it is said, <i>So Abraham returned to his lads and they rose and went together to Beer-sheba</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 22:19.</i> This teaches us that he tarried there and dwelled in Beer-sheba for a period of years. Now if this was the case, Sarah did not die during that period immediately following the Binding for it would not be that Abraham lived in Beer-sheba while Sarah dwelt in Hebron. And so it also appears since Isaac was born in Beer-sheba for it is previously written, <i>And Abraham journeyed from there towards the land of the south and abode between Kadesh and Shur and sojourned in Gerar</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 20:1.</i> and Abimelech said to him, <i>Behold, my land is before thee; abide where it is good in thine eyes</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 15.</i> There in that land Abraham settled in the city of Beer-sheba, for so it is written, <i>And it came to pass at that time that Abimelech and Phicol the captain of his host spoke unto Abraham, saying</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 21:22.</i> Though it is not written there that they came to him from Gerar, [as it is written in the case of Isaac],<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 26:26.</i> from which you might infer that Abraham lived in Gerar, this is not the case. Scripture clearly states that it was in Beer-sheba that they made the covenant.<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 21:32.</i> Similarly, you will see that when Hagar was sent away from the house of Abraham <i>on the day that Isaac was weaned</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 8.</i> she walked <i>in the desert of Beer-sheba</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 14.</i> for it was there that they lived. However, after many days, he [Abraham] journeyed from the land of the Philistines and came to Hebron, and there the righteous woman Sarah passed away.<br>However, according to the Midrash [which states that Sarah died at the time of the Binding], we must say that Abraham and Sarah lived in Hebron at the time of the Binding, and there Abraham was commanded concerning it. The verse which states that <i>On the third day Abraham lifted up his eyes</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 22:4.</i> poses this difficulty: Since Hebron is near Mount Moriah, which is in Jerusalem, why did he not arrive at the mountain until the third day? The answer is as follows: <i>The mountain which G-d had desired for His abode</i><sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 68:17. A reference to the fact that in the future the Temple of Jerusalem was to be built on that mountain. See Ramban, above, 22:2.</i> was not revealed to him until the third day. Thus for two days he wandered in the environs of Jerusalem, and it was not yet the Divine Will to indicate the mountain to him. After the Binding, Abraham did not return to his place in Hebron. Rather, he went first to Beer-sheba, the place of his tamarisk-tree, to give thanks for the miracle that befell him. It was there that he heard of the death of Sarah, and he came to Hebron. The two apparently divergent opinions — namely, that Abraham came from Mount Moriah and that he came from Beer-sheba — are thus one [since, as explained, on his way from Mount Moriah he went to the tamarisk-tree which was in Beer-sheba, there to give thanks for the miracle]. Accordingly, the verse which states, <i>And Abraham abode at Beer-sheba</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 22:19.</i> is intended to indicate that upon his return from the Binding he went to Beer-sheba, and from there he went to bury Sarah. After the internment he immediately returned to Beer-sheba and settled there for years. Scripture, however, concludes the subject of Beer-sheba all at once, and following that it tells of the burial, [which explains the lack of chronology in the verse, <i>And Abraham dwelt in Beer-sheba</i>]. It was there in Beer-sheba that Isaac married Rebekah, as it says, <i>For he dwelt in the land of the South</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 24:62.</i> the locus of Beer-sheba. It is thus the opinion of all the commentators that Abraham was in another place, and it was from there that he came to the burial.<br>In my opinion, Sarah had a tent for herself and her attendants. And so it is written elsewhere <i>into Jacob’s tent, and into Leah’s tent, and into the tent of the two maid servants</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 31:33.</i> Sarah thus died in her tent, and Abraham came into her tent with a group of his friends to bewail her. [This is a simple explanation of the expression, <i>and Abraham came</i>.] It may be that the word <i>vayavo (and he came)</i> indicates that Abraham was bestirred to make this eulogy, and he began to make it, for all who bestir themselves to begin doing a certain task are spoken of in Hebrew as “coming to it.” This usage is quite common in the language of Sages, as we learn in Tractate Tamid:<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">Tamid, IV, 3.</i> “He came to the neck and left with it two ribs on either side…. He came to the left flank…. He came to the rump.” And also (you have) their expression,<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">Bechoroth 20a.</i> “I have not come to this principle.” In Scripture, likewise, you find, <i>he came for his hire</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 22:14.</i> meaning that he came for the purpose of this work and did it for his hire. However, it does not appear to me feasible that Abraham came from another city to Hebron. If that were the case, Scripture would have mentioned that place and would have expressly written: “and Abraham heard, and he came from such and such a place.”

Verse 3



Verse 4

I AM A STRANGER AND SOJOURNER WITH YOU. It was customary for them to have separate burial grounds for each family and one burial ground for the internment of all strangers. Now Abraham said to the children of Heth: “I am a stranger from another land and have not inherited a burial ground in this land from my ancestors. Now I am a sojourner with you since I have desired to dwell in this land. Therefore give me a burying-place for an everlasting possession just as one of you.” However, since Abraham used the word “<i>t’nu</i> (give), [which has the same root as <i>matanah</i>,” (gift)], they suspected that he desired it from them as a gift. They therefore answered him: “You are not regarded by us as a stranger or sojourner. Rather, you are a king. G-d has made you king over us, and we and our land are subservient to you. Take any burial ground you desire, and bury your dead there. It shall be unto you a possession of a burial-place forever since no one of us shall withhold it from you.”

Verse 5



Verse 6



Verse 7



Verse 8

IF IT BE YOUR MIND TO BURY MY DEAD FROM BEFORE ME. The intent thereof is: “I will not bury my dead in another burial ground. However if it be your desire that I bury my dead, entreat for me to Ephron who has a cave at the end of his field, which is not used as his family burial-place but as a field.” The meaning of the word <i>milphanai</i>, (from before me), is that if you will not do so I will entomb her in a casket. It may be that it means “my dead wife who is before me, and as an obligation I must hurry to bury her.” The reason Abraham requested, <i>and entreat for me</i>, is that Ephron was a rich and distinguished person, as is indicated by his saying, <i>What is that between me and thee?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 15: <i>Land worth four hundred shekels of silver — what is that between me and thee?</i></i> It would therefore not be to his honor to sell his ancestral inheritance, as was the case with Naboth of Jezreel.<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote">I Kings, Chapter 28.</i> It was for this reason that Abraham did not go to Ephron to offer him an inflated price for the field, but instead he asked of the people of the city to entreat to him [Ephron] on his behalf in an honorable way.

Verse 9

THAT HE MAY GIVE ME. The intent of this is “that he may give it to me in such a way that I will consider it as a gift (even) if I will buy it from him for its full value.” It is for this reason that Abraham did not mention the word “selling.” A similar usage is found in the verse, <i>Thou shalt sell me food for money, that I may eat; and give me water for money, that I may drink</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 2:28.</i> meaning “for the water which is usually given as a gift I will give money.” It may be that such is the ordinary usage of the language to mention “giving” when describing sales transactions.
THE CAVE OF MACHPELAH. Rashi comments: “It had a lower and an upper cave. Another explanation [of why it was called Machpelah — the root of which is <i>keiphel</i> (double)] — is that it was ‘doubled’ on account of the four couples who were buried there: Adam and Eve, Abraham and Sarah, Isaac and Rebekah, Jacob and Leah”. But this is incorrect since Scripture states, <i>the field of Ephron which was in Machpelah.</i><sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 17 here.</i> Thus we see that it is the name of the place in which the field was located, and there is no need to search for a reason for the names of places.<br>In Bereshith Rabbah, the Sages have said:<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote">55:10.</i> “The Holy One, blessed be He, bent double the stature of the first man and He buried him there.” In their opinion, this entire place was always called Machpelah though the people did not know the reason for it for Ephron sold him everything for the price of the field unaware that there was a grave in it. Abraham, on the other hand, desired only that he should sell him the cave which was in the end of the field, and the field might be retained by Ephron. But Ephron by way of good conduct or trickery, [possibly hoping to receive a higher price for the larger transaction], said that he would give him the field and the cave which was in it since it would be unbecoming for such an honorable person to own the cave as a possession for a burial-place while the field belonged to another. Abraham rejoiced at this suggestion, and he purchased it in its entirety for the price that Ephron mentioned.

Verse 10



Verse 11

IN THE PRESENCE OF THE SONS OF MY PEOPLE. The intent thereof is to state: “Behold, all the people are present, and they are knowledgeable witnesses to the sale. Therefore do not fear denial or retraction, and so <i>bury thy dead</i> from now on, for it is yours and I cannot retract.” But Abraham did not do so for even after he paid its full value in silver he first took symbolic legal possession of the field and the cave. He established them as his possession in the presence of the people of the city, <i>and all those who came in at the gate of the city</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 18 here.</i> the merchants and the residents who happened to be there, and after that he buried her.

Verse 12



Verse 13

‘LU’ (IF) THOU WILT HEAR ME. This is equivalent to saying, “If you, if you will hear me,” and the purport thereof is like, “if you, if you would hear me,” the redundancy being for the purpose of emphasizing the matter. Similar cases are found in these verses: <i>Turn in, my lord, turn in to me;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote">Judges 4:18.</i> <i>Art thou any better, better than Balak?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 11:25.</i> <i>And to speak against him, saying;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote">II Chronicles 32:17.</i> <i>And as for me, whither shall I go?;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 37:30.</i> <i>And I turned myself;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote">Ecclesiastes 2:12.</i> <i>And I saw myself;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 13.</i> <i>Seeing all the congregation are all holy</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 16:3.</i> All these are examples of expressions of synonimity. In my opinion, this is also the case in the verse, <i>If from a thread even to a sandal tie, if I take (anything that is thine)</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 14:23. Here too, there is a redundant “if.”</i> which is equivalent to saying, “If, from a thread even to a sandal tie, I take anything that is yours.” It may be that [in the verse here before us the meaning is], “If you are as you have said.” that is, if you are speaking what is in your heart concerning the matter, and if you will listen to me and consummate the sale. A similar usage of a missing word is found in the verse, <i>And their brethren said unto them, What are ye?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">42</sup><i class="footnote">Judges 18:8.</i> [which means, “What are you saying?”] In my opinion, a similar case of such usage is the verse, <i>Wherefore am I?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 25:2. See also Ramban there.</i> [meaning, “Wherefore am I in the world?”] Perhaps this is the opinion of Onkelos who translated here, “if you will do me a favor,” meaning, “if you will do my will as you have said.”

Verse 14



Verse 15

LAND OF FOUR HUNDRED SHEKELS OF SILVER. According to Onkelos’ opinion, the intent of this is that the land was so worth, [since he translated, “land <i>worth</i> four hundred shekels of silver.”]<br>Perhaps it was Ephron’s intent to say that the price of the land was so fixed in that place for it was customary in most lands that the price of a field be fixed in accordance with its dimensions. In the words of our Rabbis,<sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote">Bereshith Rabbah 58:9.</i> however, Ephron set an exorbitant arbitrary price, and Abraham, out of the willingness of his heart, listened and <i>did according to his will, and magnified himself</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">45</sup><i class="footnote">Daniel 8:4. A reference to the Midrash (<i>ibid.</i>) which says that Abraham gave Ephron shekels of large size.</i> If we follow the simple interpretation of Scripture, <i>land of four hundred shekels of silver</i> means that either Ephron bought it for that price, or it was so purchased by his forefathers.

Verse 16



Verse 17



Verse 18



Verse 19

AND AFTER THIS, ABRAHAM BURIED SARAH HIS WIFE IN THE CAVE OF THE FIELD OF MACHPELAH BEFORE MAMRE — THE SAME IS HEBRON — IN THE LAND OF CANAAN. The reason why Scripture reverts to clarify the field, the place and the land is that the whole section mentioned the sons of Heth and Ephron the Hittite. Therefore Scripture mentions at the conclusion that the field was in the land of Canaan which is the land of Israel. And so it said at the beginning of the section: <i>in Kiryath arba — the same is Hebron — in the land of Canaan</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">46</sup><i class="footnote">Above, Verse 2.</i> All this is to explain that the righteous woman died in the land of Israel, and there she was interred, as the Hittites were of the families of Canaan.<sup class="footnote-marker">47</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 10:15.</i><br>In my opinion, the reason for the verses is only to mention that this was the land of Canaan, not the land of the Philistines. Having said, <i>And Abraham sojourned in the land of the Philistines many days</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">48</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 21:34.</i> and since all his habitats were in that land — in Gerar,<sup class="footnote-marker">49</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 20:1.</i> and the valley of Gerar,<sup class="footnote-marker">50</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 26:17-18.</i> and Beer-sheba,<sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 22:19.</i> and from there to Hebron and back — Scripture therefore mentioned that Hebron is in the land of <i>the Canaanite who dwelt in that hill country</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">52</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 14:45.</i> not in the land of the Philistines, which is mentioned in connection with Abraham. And in the end Scripture added a phrase to inform us that the cave was in <i>the field of Machpelah before Mamre</i>, for this was the name by which it was known.<br>This section was written to inform us of G-d’s kindnesses to Abraham, i.e., that in the land in which he came to live he was regarded as <i>a prince of G-d</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">53</sup><i class="footnote">Above, Verse 6.</i> and each individual as well as all the people called him “my lord” although he did not tell them that he was a prince and a great man. Also, in his lifetime G-d fulfilled His promise to him: <i>And I will make thy name great, and thou shalt be a blessing</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">54</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 12:2.</i> Moreover, his wife died and was buried <i>in the inheritance of the Eternal</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">55</sup><i class="footnote">I Samuel 26:19. A reference to the land of Israel.</i> Further, Scripture wanted to inform us of the place of the burial of the patriarchs since we are obligated to honor the burial place of our holy ancestors. Our Rabbis said<sup class="footnote-marker">56</sup><i class="footnote">Sanhedrin 111a.</i> that this also was one of the trials of Abraham: he desired a place to bury Sarah but did not find it until he purchased it, [despite G-d’s promise that the entire land would be given to him].<br>I do not know a reason for the words of Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra, who says that the purpose of this section is to let us know the superiority of the land of Israel as regards the living and the dead, and also to fulfill the word of G-d which promised him that the land would be an inheritance of his. But what superiority of the land was thus demonstrated? Abraham would not have carried her to another land to bury her, and the word of G-d to Abraham applied to the whole land, and that was fulfilled only with his seed.

Chapter 24



Verse 1

AND ABRAHAM WAS OLD, WELL STRICKEN IN AGE. Scripture reiterates [Abraham’s old age although it has already mentioned it]<sup class="footnote-marker">57</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 18:11.</i> in order to inform us of the reason that he adjured his servant. Thus Scripture says that because Abraham saw himself to be very old and he thought that if he will send the servant to the land of his origin, perhaps before the messenger would return, he will have gone <i>to his long home</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">58</sup><i class="footnote">Ecclesiastes 12:5.</i> he therefore adjured his servant — whose counsel Isaac would follow since <i>he ruled over all that he had</i><sup class="footnote-marker">59</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 2 here.</i> — that he should not take for him a wife from the daughters of Canaan.<br>In Bereshith Rabbah,<sup class="footnote-marker">60</sup><i class="footnote">48:19.</i> the Rabbis said: “Here<sup class="footnote-marker">61</sup><i class="footnote">That is, above, 18:11, where Scripture says, <i>Now Abraham and Sarah were old</i>.</i> it was old age combined with vitality; further on<sup class="footnote-marker">62</sup><i class="footnote">That is, in the verse before us.</i> it was old age without vitality.” By this the Rabbis wanted to explain that <i>ba’im</i> [literally: “coming” in days — mentioned above]<sup class="footnote-marker">57</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 18:11.</i> — means the beginning of the days of old age, as the word <i>ba’im</i> indicates the present, just as, <i>‘Haba’im’ (those that come) in at these gates</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">63</sup><i class="footnote">Jeremiah 7:2.</i> But here it says that he was very old for already he was <i>ba bayamim</i> [literally: “he had come in days” — past tense], just as: <i>Thy brother ‘ba’ (came) with subtlety</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">64</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 27:35.</i>
AND THE ETERNAL HAD BLESSED ABRAHAM IN ALL THINGS. I.e., with riches, possessions, honor, longevity and children, which are all the treasures of man. Scripture mentions this in order to say that Abraham was perfect in every detail, lacking in no respect save seeing his son have children who would inherit his superior position and his honor. This was why he desired it.<br>Now our Rabbis have a wonderful insight into this verse. They said:<sup class="footnote-marker">65</sup><i class="footnote">Baba Bathra 16b.</i> “<i>And the Eternal had blessed Abraham ‘bakol’ (in all things)</i>. Rabbi Meir said that Abraham was blessed in that he did not have a daughter. Rabbi Yehudah said that he did have a daughter. <i>Acheirim</i><sup class="footnote-marker">66</sup><i class="footnote">Literally “other ones,” other Rabbis besides those mentioned. Rabbi Meir is sometimes called by this name. Here, however, it could not refer to him since his opinion has already been stated. <i>Acheirim</i> here refers to anonymous authorities or to the opinion of Rabbi Meir’s master, Elisha ben Abuyah, who was also known as Acheir. See Chagigah 15a.</i> say that he did have a daughter and her name was <i>Bakol</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">67</sup><i class="footnote">The profounder meaning of this saying will be explained further in the text.</i> Rabbi Meir thus explained that Abraham did not have a daughter. This was a blessing for Abraham for he could not have married her except to the cursed sons of Canaan. If he were to send her to his country, she would also worship the idols as they did because a woman is subject to the authority of her husband. Indeed, Abraham did not want his worthy children from his wife Sarah to go outside the Land, and surely not that they worship the idols. Rabbi Yehudah, however, explained that Abraham did have a daughter since the Merciful One did not even cause him to lack a daughter, and that was the blessing implied by the expression, <i>in all things</i>, for he had everything that people desire, completely without exception. Then came <i>Acheirim</i> and mentioned the name of the daughter. Now truthfully, the intent of <i>Acheirim</i> and their controversy with Rabbi Yehudah were not merely to inform us of the name of this daughter. Far it be from them to expend the great and generalized blessing of Abraham on this matter, i.e., that Scripture is saying that G-d blessed him with one daughter with that name. However, <i>Acheirim</i> established a new interpretation on this verse, a very profound matter, and they explained with it one of the secrets of the Torah. Thus they said that the word <i>bakol</i> hints at a great matter, namely, that the Holy One, blessed be He, has an attribute called <i>Kol</i> (All), so called because it is the foundation of everything. It is with reference to this attribute that it says, <i>I am the Eternal that maketh ‘Kol’ (all)</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">68</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 44:24.</i> And this is also what Scripture says, <i>And the profit of the earth is ‘bakol’ (in all)</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">69</sup><i class="footnote">Ecclesiastes 5:8.</i> that is to say, the profit of the earth and the abundant goodness that is bestowed upon all that come into the world is on account of this attribute <i>Kol</i>. It is the eighth attribute of the thirteen attributes.<sup class="footnote-marker">70</sup><i class="footnote">See Ramban Exodus 34:6.</i> And there is another attribute called <i>bath</i> [literally “daughter”] that emanates from it, and with it He moves everything. This is “the Court of the Holy One, blessed be He,” that is hinted at in the word, <i>Vahashem (And the Eternal)</i>, in all places. It is called <i>kalah</i> (bride) in the book of The Song of Songs because it is comprised of <i>hakol</i> (the All), and it is this attribute which the Sages have surnamed <i>Knesseth Yisrael</i> (the assembly of Israel) in many places because it is the gathering of <i>hakol</i> (the All). It was this attribute which was to Abraham as a <i>bath</i> because he was the man of kindness, and he conducted himself in accordance with it. This was why <i>Acheirim</i> said that this blessing with which Abraham had been blessed in all things does not allude either to his having begotten a daughter from his wife Sarah, as Rabbi Yehudah said, or not, as Rabbi Meir claimed, but instead it hints at a great matter, i.e., that he was blessed with an attribute called <i>bath</i> which is contained in the attribute <i>Kol</i>, and is therefore also called <i>Kol</i>, being analogous to the expression, <i>For My name is in him</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">71</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 23:21.</i> Thus Abraham was blessed in heaven and on earth. This is why he said, <i>By the Eternal, the G-d of heaven and the G-d of the earth</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">72</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 3 here.</i><br>This matter is to be found hinted at in the traditions of our Rabbis in many places. Thus they said in the Midrash Chazita:<sup class="footnote-marker">73</sup><i class="footnote">Another name for the Midrash Rabbah on the Song of Songs. The name Chazita is derived from the first word in the verse with which this Midrash opens. <i>‘Chazita’ (Seest thou) a man diligent in his business? he shall stand before kings</i>. (Proverbs 22:29.) The Midrash quoted is found <i>ibid.</i>, 3:21.</i> “Rabbi Shimon ben Yochai asked Rabbi Eliezer the son of Rabbi Yosi, ‘Have you possibly heard from your father of the meaning of the verse, <i>The crown wherewith his mother hath crowned him?’</i><sup class="footnote-marker">74</sup><i class="footnote">Song of Songs 3:11.</i> He said to him, ‘Yes.’ He asked, ‘How?’ He replied, ‘It is like a king who had an only daughter whom he loved very much, and he would call her “my daughter.” This did not completely express his love for her until he called her “my sister.” Still he was not satisfied until he called her “my mother.” In the same way, the Holy One, blessed be He, loved Israel in the beginning and called them “My daughter.” It is this which Scripture says, <i>Hearken, O daughter, and consider</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">75</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 45:11.</i> This did not completely express His love for them until He called them “My sister,” as it is said, <i>Open to me, my sister, my love</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">76</sup><i class="footnote">Song of Songs 5:2.</i> Still He was not satisfied until He called them “My mother,” as it is said, <i>Attend unto Me, O My people, ‘ule’umi’ (O My nation)</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">77</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 51:4.</i> The word is written <i>le’imi</i> (O My mother).’ Then Rabbi Shimon ben Yochai arose and kissed him on his head, and he said to him, ‘Had I come to listen to this word of yours it would have been sufficient.’…”<br>Now, had the commentator who prides himself on his knowledge of the Torah’s secrets<sup class="footnote-marker">78</sup><i class="footnote">Reference here is to Ibn Ezra who often prides himself on knowing the secrets of the Torah but who, in the case of this Midrash concerning Abraham’s having a daughter by the name of <i>Bakol</i>, criticizes the interpretation by commenting that if that were the case, the word <i>bakol</i> should have had an additional letter <i>beth</i> preceding it and meaning “and G-d blessed Abraham ‘with’ <i>bakol</i>.”</i> known this, his lips would be dumb and not deride the words of our Rabbis. Therefore, I have written this in order to silence those who speak arrogantly against the righteous one.<sup class="footnote-marker">79</sup><i class="footnote">See Psalms 31:19.</i>

Verse 2



Verse 3

AND I WILL MAKE THEE SWEAR BY THE ETERNAL. It would have been proper for Abraham to command his son Isaac that he should not take a wife from the daughters of Canaan. But since it was his wish to dispatch someone during his lifetime to his country and his family, and he made the servant swear to do so whether in his lifetime or after his death, therefore Abraham found it necessary in any case to make the servant swear to go there. In addition he found it necessary to say to him, “I command you that you should not take a woman for my son of the daughters of Canaan. Instead you are to go to my country and take for him a wife from my father’s house.” Now having required the servant to swear to this, he no longer found it necessary to command Isaac at all for he knew that he would not transgress his father’s wish or the oath which he made his servant swear, as the matter was indeed known to Isaac.<br>It is also possible that the servant Eliezer was the administrator of his possessions, and Abraham commanded him to marry off Isaac in accordance with his will and cause him to inherit his estate on this condition, [namely, that he marry in accordance with his father’s wish]. This is the significance of the expression, <i>that ruled over all that he had</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">80</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 2 here.</i>
THE G-D OF THE HEAVEN, AND THE G-D OF THE LAND.<sup class="footnote-marker">81</sup><i class="footnote">“Of the land.” From Ramban’s commentary it becomes obvious that he understood the word <i>ha’aretz</i> (the land) to mean “the land of Israel.”</i> The Holy One, blessed be He, is called the G-d of the Land of Israel, as it is written, <i>They know not the manner of the G-d of the land</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">82</sup><i class="footnote">II Kings 17:26.</i> and it is further written, <i>And they spoke of the G-d of Jerusalem, as of the gods of the people of the earth</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">83</sup><i class="footnote">II Chronicles 32:19.</i> There is a secret in this matter which I will yet explain<sup class="footnote-marker">84</sup><i class="footnote">See further, 26:5, and Leviticus 18:25.</i> with the help of G-d. However [in Verse 7], further on where it says, <i>Who took me from my father’s house</i>, it does not say “the G-d of the land” because he [Abraham] was then in Haran or Ur of the Chaldees. So also the Rabbis have said:<sup class="footnote-marker">85</sup><i class="footnote">Ketuboth 110b.</i> “He who lives outside the land of Israel is as if he had no G-d, as it said, <i>For they have driven me out this day that I should not cleave unto the inheritance of the Eternal, saying, Go, serve other gods</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">86</sup><i class="footnote">I Samuel 26:19. But who said to David, <i>Go serve other gods?</i> However this verse teaches you that he who lives outside of the land of Israel is considered as if he worshipped idols. (Ibid.)</i>

Verse 4



Verse 5

PERADVENTURE THE WOMAN WILL NOT BE WILLING. The meaning [of the definite article in the word <i>ha’ishah</i>] is that it refers to “the woman to whom I will speak of all the women there”, or it may mean the woman who is fit for Isaac.

Verse 6



Verse 7

FROM MY FATHER’s HOUSE, ‘UMEI’ERETZ MOLAD’TI’ (AND FROM THE LAND OF MY NATIVITY). Rashi comments: “<i>From my father’s house</i> — from Haran. <i>And from the land of my nativity</i> — from Ur of the Chaldees.” If this is so, the expression, <i>Unto my country and to ‘molad’ti’ thou shalt go</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">87</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 4 here.</i> must also refer to Ur of the Chaldees. But Heaven forbid that the sacred seed should mix with the sons of Ham,<sup class="footnote-marker">88</sup><i class="footnote">The Chaldees and the entire land of Shinar belonged to the sons of Ham. See Ramban, above, 11:28.</i> the sinful one!<sup class="footnote-marker">89</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 9:22-24.</i> Even if one would say that Abraham had some family there from the seed of Shem, the fact is however that the servant went to Haran as his master said! Now perhaps the Rabbi [Rashi] thinks that <i>eretz molad’to</i><sup class="footnote-marker">87</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 4 here.</i>(the land of his birth) was Ur of the Chaldees, but <i>molad’ti</i><sup class="footnote-marker">87</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 4 here.</i> means “my family,” and <i>my country</i><sup class="footnote-marker">87</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 4 here.</i> means the land wherein he lived. But all these are futile words since here, in the verse before us, he said, <i>And thou shalt take a wife for my son from there</i>, [and according to Rashi, who explained <i>ume’eretz molad’ti</i>, mentioned in this verse, as meaning Ur of the Chaldees, it would follow that Abraham commanded Eliezer to go there to get a wife from the children of Ham]! Moreover, Abraham stayed in the land of Canaan for a longer period than he did in Haran, and so why should Haran be called his country simply because he lived there for some time? Instead, the meaning of the expression, <i>unto my country and to ‘molad’ti’</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">87</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 4 here.</i> is “unto my country in which I was born,” [namely, Haran in Mesopotamia], for there he stayed and from there his ancestors came, as was already explained.<sup class="footnote-marker">90</sup><i class="footnote">See Ramban above, 11:28 and 12:1.</i> In Bereshith Rabbah we find:<sup class="footnote-marker">91</sup><i class="footnote">59:13.</i> “<i>From my father’s house</i> — this is the house of his father. <i>And from the land of my birth</i> — this is the environs [of his father’s house].”<br>It is possible that <i>unto my country and unto ‘molad’ti’</i> means “Unto my country and unto my family,” for he did not want a wife to be taken for Isaac even from the people of his country but only from his family. Similarly in the verse, <i>And thou shalt take a wife for my son from there</i>, [the word <i>misham</i> (from there)] alludes to the expression, <i>from my father’s house</i>, mentioned at the beginning of the verse. And so did the servant say when quoting Abraham, <i>And thou shalt take a wife for my son of my family, and of my father’s house</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">92</sup><i class="footnote">Further, Verse 40.</i> and again he said, quoting his master. <i>Then shalt thou be clear from my oath when thou comest to my family</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">93</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 41.</i> These words were said by the servant to honor them so that they would listen to him.
AND WHO SPOKE ‘LI’ (UNTO ME). Rashi comments: “The word <i>li</i> means ‘in my interest,’ just as in the verse, <i>which He spoke ‘alai’ (concerning me)</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">94</sup><i class="footnote">I Kings 2:4.</i> In the same way, in every case where <i>li</i> and <i>lo</i> and <i>lahem</i> follow the word <i>dibur</i> (speaking), they are to be explained in the sense of <i>al</i> (concerning). For proper usage of the verb <i>dibur</i> [in the sense of speaking to a person, the pronouns <i>li</i> and <i>lo</i> and <i>lahem</i> are not appropriate, and] only <i>eilai</i> and <i>eilav</i> and <i>aleihem</i> are appropriate, and their renderings in the Targum are <i>imi</i> and <i>imei</i> and <i>imhon</i>. In the case of the word <i>amirah</i>, however, the expressions <i>li</i> and <i>lo</i> and <i>lahem</i> are appropriate.”<br>In the section of <i>Vayeitzei Yaakov</i>, Rashi brought [proof of his above mentioned principle which states that <i>li</i> or <i>lecha</i>, etc., following the word <i>dibur</i>, must be explained in the sense of <i>al</i> (concerning)] from that which is written there, <i>that which ‘dibarti’ (I have spoken) ‘lach,’</i><sup class="footnote-marker">95</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 28:15.</i> [which must be interpreted to mean “in thy interest and concerning thee”] since He had never spoken to Jacob before this occasion.<br>But this difference is not valid for we find: <i>And now go, lead the people unto the place of which ‘dibarti’ (I have spoken) ‘lach’;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">96</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 32:34. Here the word <i>dibur</i> is found in connection with <i>lach</i>, and yet it means “to you,” and not “concerning you,” as Rashi claimed.</i> <i>And the Chaldeans spoke to the king in Aramaic;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">97</sup><i class="footnote">Daniel 2:4. This too is a case similar to the above.</i> <i>And thou shalt drive them out, and make them to perish quickly, as the Eternal hath spoken unto thee</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">98</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 9:3. This too is similar to the above.</i> Similarly the verb <i>amirah</i> is used with both <i>li</i> and <i>eilai: And they shall say ‘li’ (to me), What is His name? What shall I say ‘aleihem’ (to them)?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">99</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 3:13.</i> And as for [the verse which Rashi mentioned as his proof], <i>that which ‘dibarti’ (I have spoken) ‘lach,’</i><sup class="footnote-marker">95</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 28:15.</i> [which must mean, as Rashi said, “concerning thee,” since He had never spoken to Jacob before this occasion], its interpretation is as follows: “that which I have said to you now that I will give the land to you and to your seed, and I will bless you.” [Thus the word <i>lach</i> (to you) follows the understood verb “give” and is not related to <i>dibarti</i>.]

Verse 8

THEN THOU SHALT BE CLEAR FROM THIS MY OATH. Abraham did not permit him to take a wife for Isaac from the daughters of Canaan, but he would be free [from the oath if Isaac were to do it on his own] <i>and the Eternal do that which is good in His sight</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">100</sup><i class="footnote">II Samuel 10:12.</i><br>But Rashi wrote, “And take a wife for him from the daughters of Aner, Eshkol or Mamre.” Now if they were Canaanites, far be it from him! And in truth they were of the seed of Canaan for Scripture says, <i>Mamre the Amorite, brother of Eshkol, and brother of Aner</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">101</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 14:13.</i> And in Bereshith Rabbah, the Rabbis have said:<sup class="footnote-marker">102</sup><i class="footnote">59:11.</i> “<i>That thou shalt not take a wife</i>, etc.<sup class="footnote-marker">103</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 3 here.</i> He warned him against the daughters of Canaan, Aner, Eshkol, and Mamre.” For it was with reference to Aner, Eshkol, and Mamre that Abraham said, <i>Among whom I dwell</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">103</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 3 here.</i> since he did not dwell among all the Canaanites as they were many nations. But he warned him against these his confederates, and all the more against the others. But the verse, <i>Then thou shalt be clear from this my oath</i>, means that the servant would be free from the oath if Isaac would want to do it on his own, and Abraham relied on his knowledge that his righteous son Isaac would listen to his father and that he would beware of them and go instead to Ishmael or to Lot and the other nations.<br>It is possible that <i>from this my oath</i> is a hint to that which he said, <i>And thou shalt take a wife unto my son from there</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">104</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 7 here.</i> since perhaps the oath was for everything, [meaning that the oath covered two points: a) that he should not take for him a wife from the daughters of Canaan, and b) that he should go to his family. In case they refused, he would be free from the second oath, while the first oath would always remain in effect]. Accordingly, <i>then thou shalt be clear from this my oath</i> does not allude to that which Abraham told him, <i>Thou shalt not take a wife unto my son of the daughters of the Canaanites</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">103</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 3 here.</i> [since he never freed him from this oath]. This explains the word <i>zoth (this) — [thou shalt be clear from ‘this’ my oath</i> — implying there was another oath from which he was not freed]. Therefore, the servant said, <i>That I may turn to the right hand, or to the left</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">105</sup><i class="footnote">Further, Verse 49.</i> and he did not say, “I would return [to the land of Canaan,” since he was not freed from the oath not to take a wife from the daughters of Canaan].

Verse 9



Verse 10

AND ALL THE GOODS OF HIS MASTER BEING IN HIS HAND.
