Rashi comments: “This refers to a deed of gift of all his possessions which he wrote in favor of Isaac so that they would be eager to send him their daughter.” And so it is also stated in Bereshith Rabbah,<sup class="footnote-marker">106</sup><i class="footnote">59:15.</i> “He carried with him a disposition of property.”<br>According to this opinion, the verse stating, <i>And Abraham gave all that he had unto Isaac</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">107</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 25:5.</i> means that he caused him to take possession of the belonging at the time of his death so that the other children would not contest his ownership, just as it is said, <i>And he sent them away from Isaac his son, while he yet lived</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">108</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 6.</i> If so, the word “taking” applies also to the first part of the verse, <i>And the servant ‘took’ ten camels, and departed, and all the goods of his master he took in his hand</i>. Perhaps [the words of the verse are to be transposed as follows]: “And the servant took ten camels and all the goods of his master in his hand, and departed.”<br>Others<sup class="footnote-marker">109</sup><i class="footnote">This interpretation is found in the commentary of Chizkuni.</i> explain the sense of the verse as meaning that immediately upon being sworn, the servant himself went and took many camels from his master’s camels because all his master’s goods were in his hand, he being the officer and captain over all and authorized to take from him whatever he desired, just as the verse says, <i>that ruled over all that he had</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">80</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 2 here.</i><br>The correct interpretation appears to me to be that the meaning of this verse is similar to that of the verse concerning Hazael, general of Aram, <i>And Hazael went to meet him</i> [Elisha the prophet], <i>and took a present with him, and every good thing of Damascus, forty camels’ burden</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">110</sup><i class="footnote">II Kings 8:9.</i> [which means “and ‘of’ every good thing of Damascus].” Here too Scripture states that he took in his hand of all his master’s goods ten camels’ burden. The sense of the verse concerning Hazael is that the camels carried all that was good and excellent among those species of fruits and precious things that were found in Damascus or in his master’s house, and in addition they carried a present with them. In a similar sense is the verse, <i>ten asses laden with the good of Egypt</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">111</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 45:23.</i> [which means laden with the good and excellent fruits of Egypt]. The verses, however, shorten expressions when the subjects are understood.

Verse 11



Verse 12



Verse 13



Verse 14

HER THOU HAST APPOINTED FOR THY SERVANT, EVEN FOR ISAAC. Rashi comments: “She is fit for him since she is charitable and worthy of admission into the house of Abraham. <i>And thereby shall I know</i> — this is a petition: ‘Let me know through her <i>that Thou hast shown kindness unto my master</i>.” If so, Eliezer is saying, “I know for certain that You have appointed her for Your servant Isaac.” But in that case [his petition, which still indicates a doubt as to whether she was the appointed one,] does not connect well.<br>Its interpretation however is as follows: “Make it happen to me this day that the girl to whom I will speak be the one that You have appointed for Your servant Isaac, and with this, show kindness to my master Abraham for with this I will know that You have shown kindness to him if she be of his family and of good mind and of beautiful appearance.” And so he said [when recounting the events of the day]: <i>And let it come to pass, that the maiden</i>, etc., <i>let the same be the woman whom the Eternal hath appointed</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">112</sup><i class="footnote">Further, Verses 43-44.</i>

Verse 15

WHO WAS BORN TO BETHUEL THE SON OF MILCAH THE WIFE OF NAHOR, ABRAHAM’s BROTHER. Because Nahor also had children from his concubine Reumah,<sup class="footnote-marker">113</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 22:24.</i> they always described the lineage of Bethuel by saying that he was the son of Milcah who was the mistress of the household. And because the girl mentioned her father’s mother first, as it says, <i>I am the daughter of Bethuel the son of Milcah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">114</sup><i class="footnote">Further, Verse 25.</i> — for such was customary among the girls, analogous to the verse, <i>And she told her mother’s house</i><sup class="footnote-marker">115</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 28 here.</i> — therefore Scripture mentions in the verse before us that he [Bethuel] was <i>the son of Milcah, the wife of Nahor</i>. But the servant later said, <i>And she said, The daughter of Bethuel Nahor’s son</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">116</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 47 here.</i> for he corrected the matter as is ethically proper. However, he did say, <i>whom Milcah bore unto him</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">116</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 47 here.</i> in order to state that Bethuel was the son of the mistress and not the concubine.

Verse 16



Verse 17

AND THE SERVANT RAN TO MEET HER. Rashi comments: “Because he saw that the waters rose in the well when she approached it.” In Bereshith Rabbah the Rabbis said,<sup class="footnote-marker">117</sup><i class="footnote">60:6.</i> “<i>And she filled her pitcher, and came up</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">118</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 16 here.</i> All the women went down and filled their pitchers from the well. But this one, as the waters saw her they immediately rose. The Holy One, blessed be He, said to her, ‘You are a sign of blessing to your children.’”<sup class="footnote-marker">119</sup><i class="footnote">When Israel wandered in the desert, the waters in the well would rise as soon as they approached it. See Numbers 21:17 and Midrash Rabbah, <i>ibid.</i></i><br>It would appear that the Rabbis derived this interpretation upon observing the language, <i>And she filled her pitcher, and came up</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">118</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 16 here.</i> for it does not say, “and she drew water and filled [the pitcher].” Now this miracle happened to her only the first time for afterwards it is written, <i>and she drew</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">120</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 20 here.</i> The servant, when recounting the day’s events to them, said: <i>And she went down unto the well, and drew water</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">121</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 45 here.</i> That was because he thought that perhaps they would not believe in the miracle.

Verse 18



Verse 19



Verse 20



Verse 21



Verse 22

AND THE MAN TOOK A GOLDEN RING… AND TWO BRACELETS UPON HER HANDS. This verse omits the deed for it should have said: “And the man took a golden ring and put it upon her nose<sup class="footnote-marker">122</sup><i class="footnote">So it says in Verse 47 here.</i> and two bracelets upon her hands.” Therefore I say that the interpretation of the verse is as follows: And the man took a golden ring and two bracelets which would be upon her hands, and he said to her, <i>Whose daughter art thou?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">123</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 23 here.</i> And after she had told him, <i>I am the daughter of Bethuel</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">124</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 24 here.</i> he put the ring upon her nose and the bracelets upon her hands, as he told them.<sup class="footnote-marker">125</sup><i class="footnote">In Verse 47 here. He first asked her who she was, and then he gave her the presents. This interpretation differs from Rashi (in Verse 23) who says that after he had given her the presents, he asked her whose daughter she was, for he was confident that, on account of Abraham’s merit, G-d would make his journey successful. Later, however, in Verse 47, when he recounted the story, he changed the sequence of the two events so that they should not sense the inconsistency and say, “How could you give her anything when you did not know who she was?”</i> Here, however, Scripture omits the actual giving, and similarly in many places.

Verse 23



Verse 24



Verse 25



Verse 26



Verse 27



Verse 28



Verse 29



Verse 30



Verse 31



Verse 32

AND THE MAN CAME INTO THE HOUSE. Eliezer is the man who entered the house. <i>And he ungirded the camels</i> — this refers to Laban who acted ethically towards his guests, unharnessed their camels and gave them straw and fodder, and he also gave water to wash the feet of Eliezer <i>and the feet of the men that were with him</i>. It must refer to Laban for it would be unlikely that it was Eliezer who gave water to wash his own feet and those of his men. A similar case is the verse, <i>And there passed by Midianites, merchantmen, and they drew and lifted up Joseph out of the pit</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">126</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 37:28.</i> The words, <i>and they drew</i>, refer back to the brothers of Joseph mentioned in the preceding verse, and not to the Midianites. And so in the verse, <i>Then said Ziba unto the king</i> [David]: <i>According to all that my lord the king commandeth his servant, so shall thy servant do; but Mephibosheth eateth at my table as one of the king’s sons</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">127</sup><i class="footnote">II Samuel 9:11.</i> [The concluding words, <i>but Mephibosheth eateth</i>], are the words of David and not Ziba. There are many such verses.<br>Now the purport of the expression, <i>and he ungirded the camels</i>, is that he unloosened the bands on their necks, as it was customary to lead them knotted, or perhaps they travelled with saddles girded upon them, just as is expressed in the verses: <i>Let not him that girdeth on his armor boast himself as he that putteth it off</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">128</sup><i class="footnote">I Kings 20:11.</i> <i>Loose thyself from the band of thy neck</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">129</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 52:2.</i><br>Now Rashi wrote, “He removed their muzzles for he had closed their mouths so that they might not graze in other peoples’ fields.” And in the words of Bereshith Rabbah,<sup class="footnote-marker">130</sup><i class="footnote">60:1.</i> “He removed their muzzles. Rabbi Huna and Rabbi Yirmiyah asked Rabbi Chiya the son of Rabbi Aba, ‘Were not the camels of our father Abraham like the ass of Rabbi Pinchas ben Ya’ir,<sup class="footnote-marker">131</sup><i class="footnote">A Sage of the Tannaitic period. He was a son-in-law of Rabbi Shimon ben Yochai. He was celebrated for his great piety; even his ass refused to eat untithed corn.</i> etc.?’” This question is intended to contradict [the interpretation which maintains that the ungirding refers to] the removing of the muzzles for it is impossible that the piety in the house of Rabbi Pinchas been Ya’ir should have been greater than that in the house of our father Abraham, and just as the ass of Rabbi Pinchas ben Ya’ir did not have to be guarded against eating things which its master was forbidden to feed it, all the more so were the camels of our father Abraham. There was thus no need to muzzle them for <i>no injustice befalleth the righteous</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">132</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 12:21.</i>

Verse 33



Verse 34



Verse 35



Verse 36



Verse 37



Verse 38



Verse 39



Verse 40



Verse 41



Verse 42



Verse 43



Verse 44



Verse 45

BEHOLD, REBEKAH CAME FORTH WITH HER PITCHER ON HER SHOULDER. This indicates that while he was in her house he heard her name, or perhaps she told him her name at the beginning even though it is not mentioned in Scripture.

Verse 46



Verse 47



Verse 48



Verse 49



Verse 50



Verse 51



Verse 52



Verse 53



Verse 54



Verse 55



Verse 56



Verse 57



Verse 58



Verse 59



Verse 60



Verse 61

AND REBEKAH AROSE, AND HER MAIDS. Scripture relates that after they gave permission for Rebekah and her nurse to go, as well as for Abraham’s servant and his men, Rebekah rose and called her maids. <i>And they rode upon the camels, and followed the man</i> because he led them on the way.
AND THE SERVANT TOOK REBEKAH, AND WENT HIS WAY. The purpose of this is to tell of his zealousness for after having left the city with all the women following him, the servant took Rebekah to him and did not part from her in order to guard her against any mishap along the way. And Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra said that it means that he walked with Rebekah and never felt the weariness of the journey until Isaac came and met him.

Verse 62

AND ISAAC ‘BA MIBO’ (HAD JUST COME) FROM THE WELL LAHAI-ROI. Scripture states that Isaac had just now come from the well Lahai-roi, having returned from the well of Lahai-roi to which he had previously come. Had the verse stated, “<i>Ba</i> (he came) from the well of Lahai,” it would have appeared as if he lived there. Therefore, it was necessary to explain <i>ba mibo</i> as meaning that he returned to his city from the temporary visit that he had made to the well of Lahai-roi, for <i>he abode in the south country</i> and he was returning to his city.<br>It is possible that since the word <i>mibo</i> is an infinitive, it indicates that Isaac constantly went to that place since it was a place of prayer for him because of the revelation of the angel there,<sup class="footnote-marker">133</sup><i class="footnote">See above, 16:14.</i> and he <i>abode in the south country</i> near there. And so did Onkelos translate it, “He came from his coming,” [thus indicating that he was in the habit of so doing].<br>In Onkelos’ opinion this was Beer-sheba for he translated both <i>between Kadesh and Shur</i><sup class="footnote-marker">134</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 20:1.</i> and <i>between Kadesh and Bered</i><sup class="footnote-marker">135</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 16:14.</i> as “Rekem and Chagra.”<sup class="footnote-marker">136</sup><i class="footnote">Thus it is obvious that Shur and Bered are synonymous. Now Shur is in Gerar (above, 20:1), and Beer-sheba is in the land of the Philistines near Gerar (see Ramban, above, 21:32). The well of Lahai-roi, which is between Kadesh and Bered (above, 16:14), is thus near Beer-sheba.</i> If so, that place — the place of the tamarisk-tree of Abraham<sup class="footnote-marker">137</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 21:33.</i> — was suitable for prayer. Now Isaac came from that well while he was on his way to another city which was on the same road as his city, and he went out towards eventide to converse in the field with his companions and friends who were there. He met the servant and Rebekah, whereupon they all walked together to the city, <i>and Isaac brought her into his mother Sarah’s tent</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">138</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 67 here.</i>

Verse 63



Verse 64

AND SHE SAW ISAAC. Rashi comments: “She saw his lordly appearance and felt abashed<sup class="footnote-marker">139</sup><i class="footnote">“Abashed.” In our Rashi: “and she gazed at him in astonishment.”</i> of him.” And Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra explained that the latter verse, [namely, Verse 65, <i>And she said unto the servant, What man is this</i>], preceded Verse 64. Thus the expression, <i>And she said unto the servant</i>, means “And she had already said to the servant.” In Ibn Ezra’s opinion there are many such verses in the Torah.<br>This is truly so, but here it is not correct, for in this case you would have to mix the verses and transpose their parts as follows: <i>And Rebekah lifted up her eyes, and she saw Isaac</i> [Verse 64] — <i>and she said unto the servant: What man is this that walketh in the field to meet us? And the servant said: It is my master</i> [Verse 65] — <i>and she alighted from the camel</i> [Verse 64] — <i>and she took her veil, and covered herself</i> [Verse 65].<br>In my opinion [we need not mix the verses, but the sense thereof is as follows]: When Rebekah saw a man walking in the field towards her, hastening on the road and walking in the field towards them, she knew that he had come to see them and greet them or to bring them into his house for lodging, and so she did as was ethically proper for women, and she stood modestly.
AND SHE ALIGHTED (‘VATIPOL’) FROM THE CAMEL. Rashi comments: “She let herself slide towards the ground, as the Targum renders it, ‘She inclined herself [towards the earth but did not actually reach the ground]. Similarly, <i>Let down thy pitcher</i><sup class="footnote-marker">140</sup><i class="footnote">Above, Verse 14.</i> was translated by Onkelos to mean ‘incline.’ <i>And He bowed down the heavens</i><sup class="footnote-marker">141</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 18:10.</i> — the Targum translates: ‘and He bent.’ A similar case is the verse, <i>Though he fall, he shall not be utterly cast down</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">142</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 37:24.</i> which means though he bends himself towards the earth, yet he shall not touch the ground.”<br>But Onkelos’ opinion is not that she let herself slide off the camel to the earth, for if so, she actually fell off the camel and did not just incline herself. Similarly, all expressions of “inclining” merely mean a bending towards one side. Onkelos’ opinion, however, is that on the camel upon which she was riding she bent herself towards one side in order to turn her face away from him. A similar case, in my opinion, is the verse: <i>And when Naaman saw one running after him, ‘vayipol’ from upon the chariot to meet him, and said, Is all well?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">143</sup><i class="footnote">II Kings 5:21.</i> The word <i>vayipol</i> here only means that he bent himself in the chariot towards the runner who was on the ground to ask of him whether all is well. And so indeed it is said there, <i>When the man turned back from his chariot to meet thee</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">144</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 26.</i> It is possible that as far as Onkelos is concerned, the expression, <i>from on the camel</i>, is like “on the camel,” [the letter <i>mem</i> in the word <i>mei’al</i> (<i>from</i> on) being redundant]. A similar case is the verse, <i>For great ‘mei’al’ the heavens is Thy mercy</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">145</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 108:5.</i> [which means “for great on the heavens is Thy mercy,” and not “from on the heavens”]. A redundant letter <i>mem</i> like this is also found in these verses: <i>There shall be no more ‘misham’ an infant of days, nor an old man</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">146</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 65:20.</i> [which means “there shall be no more <i>there</i>,” and not “from there”]; <i>Ye waters that are ‘mei’al’ the heavens</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">147</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 148:4.</i> [which means “ye waters that are on the heavens,” and not “from on the heavens”].<br>In line with the plain meaning [of Scripture, however, the letter <i>mem</i> in the word <i>mei’al</i> is not redundant, but instead] it is like the <i>mem</i> in the verse, <i>And, behold, there came many people ‘miderech’ (from a way) round-about</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">148</sup><i class="footnote">II Samuel 13:34.</i> [And thus in the verse before us, <i>mei’al hagamal</i> would mean that she alighted “from on the camel.”] There are many similar verses.

Verse 65



Verse 66



Verse 67

AND ISAAC BROUGHT HER INTO HIS MOTHER SARAH’s TENT. The construct is missing here [for the noun <i>ohel</i> (tent) appears with the definite article, and in this form it cannot be used in construct with “his mother Sarah.” The verse then should be understood as if it were written, “and Isaac brought her into the tent which was the tent of his mother Sarah.”] There are many cases like this.<br>The purport of the verse is to tell of the honor that Isaac bestowed upon his mother for from the time that Sarah died they did not take down her tent because they said, “Let not another woman come into the tent of the honorable mistress.” But when he saw Rebekah he brought her into that tent in her honor and there he took her as his wife. This is the meaning of the words, <i>and he loved her, and he was comforted</i>, indicating that he was deeply grieved for his mother, finding no comforter until he was comforted by his wife through his love for her. Otherwise, what reason is there for Scripture to mention a man’s love for his wife?<br>But Onkelos explained: <i>And Isaac brought her into the tent</i> and, behold, she was like <i>Sarah his mother</i>. It is for this reason that Scripture mentions the love he had for her because it was on account of her righteousness and the aptness of her deeds that he loved her and was comforted by her. And so the Rabbis mentioned in Bereshith Rabbah,<sup class="footnote-marker">149</sup><i class="footnote">60:15.</i> “Before Sarah died there was a blessing of miraculous increase in the dough. [After her death it stopped, and when Rebekah came the blessing reappeared.”]

Chapter 25



Verse 1



Verse 2



Verse 3

ASSHURIM, AND LETUSHIM, AND LEUMMIM. Rashi comments: “These were the names of clan chieftains. But I cannot reconcile Onkelos’ translation with the language of the text.”<sup class="footnote-marker">150</sup><i class="footnote">Onkelos translates <i>Asshurim</i> as meaning “camps,” <i>Letushim</i> as “owners of tents who spread about in all directions,” and <i>Leumim</i> as “islands” or “sea-districts.” Upon this Rashi comments that he cannot make Onkelos’ translation fit in exactly with the words of the text. Ramban now proceeds to explain Onkelos’ understanding on the verse and also the reason why he was forced to make this translation.</i><br>It appears to me that Onkelos was of the opinion that <i>Asshurim</i> means camps, companies that travel the roads from city to city, just as it says, <i>a company of Ishmaelites</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">151</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 37:25.</i> Onkelos thus considered <i>Asshurim</i> as being derived from the expressions, <i>To His steps (‘ba’ashuro’) hath my foot held fast;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">152</sup><i class="footnote">Job 23:11.</i> <i>His steps (‘ashurav’) do not slide</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">153</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 37:31.</i> And Onkelos’ opinion of <i>Letushim</i> is that they are the ones who dwell in tents that are scattered over the face of the earth, resting today in one place and tomorrow in another, for the letter <i>lamed</i> and <i>nun</i> interchange in many places, [thus <i>Letushim</i> would be like <i>Netushim</i> (scattered ones)] just like <i>lishchah</i> and <i>nishchah</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">154</sup><i class="footnote">Nehemiah 13:7.</i> [both of which mean “chamber”]; <i>And on that day men were appointed over ‘haneshachoth’ (the chambers)</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">155</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 12:44.</i> From this root is derived the expression, <i>a sword ‘netushah,’</i><sup class="footnote-marker">156</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 21:15.</i> which is the same as <i>letushah</i> (sharpened). And of the word <i>Le’ummim</i> Onkelos said <i>ulenagvon</i>, [which is Aramaic for the Hebrew word] <i>iyim</i> (islands).<sup class="footnote-marker">157</sup><i class="footnote">See Isaiah 41:1 and Targum.</i><br>Onkelos was stirred to this translation by the word <i>hayu</i> [<i>and the children of Dedan ‘hayu’ (were) Asshurim, and Letushim, and Leummim</i>], when it would have been proper to express it similarly to the verse, <i>And Mitzraim begot Ludim, and Ananim, and Lehabim, and Naphtihim</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">158</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 10:13.</i><br>And in Bereshith Rabbah we find:<sup class="footnote-marker">159</sup><i class="footnote">61:4.</i> “Rabbi Shmuel the son of Rav Nachman said that even though we translate these names and say, ‘Merchants, flaming ones, and heads of peoples,’ all of them were heads of peoples.” The matter is as I have explained. The translators rendered <i>Asshurim</i> as “merchants, those who walk the road.” From the word <i>Letushim</i> (sharp, shiny) they derived “men of wickedness,” <i>their faces are faces of flame</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">160</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 13:8.</i> burning as torches, from the roots: to <i>sharpen ( liltosh ) his plowshare, and his coulter;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">161</sup><i class="footnote">I Samuel 13:20.</i> <i>He sharpened ( yiltosh ) his eyes upon me</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">162</sup><i class="footnote">Job 16:9.</i> But Rabbi Shmuel the son of Rav Nachman said that even though they are accustomed to thus translate these names, they are still only the proper names of the heads of people, there being no descriptive name among them at all. And such is the case.

Verse 4



Verse 5



Verse 6

BUT UNTO THE SONS OF THE CONCUBINES, THAT ABRAHAM HAD. By way of the plain meaning of Scripture, since it was said to Abraham, <i>For in Isaac shall seed be called to thee</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">163</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 21:12.</i> and in no other seed, all his consorts were concubines to him, not as wives since their children would not be among his heirs. Thus, Hagar, Sarah’s handmaid, was his concubine. However, Keturah he took unto himself as a wife for if she whom he took as a concubine had been a handmaid in his house, Scripture would not have said, <i>And Abraham took a wife, and her name was Keturah</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">164</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 1 here.</i> She is called “concubine” in Scripture — it is written in Chronicles, <i>And the sons of Keturah, Abraham’s concubine</i><sup class="footnote-marker">165</sup><i class="footnote">I Chronicles 1:32.</i> — only for the reason that I have explained, [namely, that it had been said to Abraham, <i>For in Isaac shall seed be called to thee</i>]. Thus we note that Abraham took unto himself a wife from the daughters of Canaan! And should you say that she was an Egyptian or from the land of the Philistines, we may yet question why he did not send to his country and to his kindred as he did in the case of his son. But the answer is that he guarded only the seed of Isaac since it was concerning him that the Covenant was made. Furthermore, Scripture does not say, “And Abraham took a wife by the name of Keturah, the daughter of a certain Hivite or Philistine or Egyptian from a certain land,” as it says concerning Esau’s wives<sup class="footnote-marker">166</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 26:34 and 28:9.</i> and similar cases. Rather, Scripture mentions only Keturah’s name because she was a Canaanite, and therefore it cut short her genealogy. Scripture does so in many places where it is not concerned with the genealogy.<br>Perhaps Keturah was called “concubine” because she was a handmaid who was descended from a family of slaves. And if she was a handmaid in his [Abraham’s] household and he had connection with her, Scripture would not mention her genealogy since even among the matriarchs, such as Zilpah and Bilhah, it mentions only their names.<br>Now Rashi wrote, “Wives are those whom a man marries with a marriage-contract; concubines have no marriage-contract, as it says in reference to the wives and concubines of David, in Tractate Sanhedrin.”<sup class="footnote-marker">167</sup><i class="footnote">21a.</i> But the matter is not so. A woman is called a concubine only when there is no betrothal, for a marriage-contract is only a Rabbinic ordinance. And the correct text in Tractate Sanhedrin is: “A concubine has no marriage-contract or betrothal.” However, it is possible that the sons of Noah<sup class="footnote-marker">168</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Seder Bereshith</i>, Note 222.</i> too when they married wives, as is their law, by intercourse, were accustomed to write them a marriage-contract which granted <i>dowry and gift</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">169</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 34:12.</i> However, for one who wished to be a concubine to them, whom he could send away when he pleased and whose children would not be among his heirs, he would not write anything. But according to the opinion of our Rabbis that Keturah is Hagar,<sup class="footnote-marker">170</sup><i class="footnote">Bereshith Rabbah 61:4.</i> she was certainly a concubine [since it clearly says that Hagar was Sarah’s handmaid].<sup class="footnote-marker">171</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 16:1.</i>

Verse 7



Verse 8

OLD AND FULL OF YEARS. He witnessed the fulfillment of all the desires of his heart and was sated with all good things. In a similar sense is [the verse written in connection with Isaac’s life], <i>and full of days</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">172</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 35:29.</i> which means that his soul was sated with days, and he had no desire that the future days should bring something new. This is as it is said of David: <i>And he died in a good old age, full of days, riches and honor</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">173</sup><i class="footnote">I Chronicles 29:28.</i> This is a story of <i>the mercies of the Eternal</i><sup class="footnote-marker">174</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 63:7.</i> towards the righteous ones, and of their attribute of goodness by virtue of which they do not desire luxuries, just as it is said of them, <i>Thou hast given him his heart’s desire</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">175</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 21:3.</i> and not as it is said of other people, <i>He that loveth money shall not be satisfied with money</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">176</sup><i class="footnote">Ecclesiastes 5:9.</i> and as the Rabbis have commented thereon:<sup class="footnote-marker">177</sup><i class="footnote">Koheleth Rabbah 1:34.</i> “No man leaves the world having amassed half of his desires. If he has a hundred, he desires two hundred. If he succeeds in acquiring two hundred, he desires to make of it four hundred, as it is said, <i>He that loveth money shall not be satisfied with money</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">176</sup><i class="footnote">Ecclesiastes 5:9.</i> In Bereshith Rabbah the Rabbis have said:<sup class="footnote-marker">178</sup><i class="footnote">62:3.</i> “The Holy One, blessed be He, shows the righteous in this world the reward He is destined to give them in the Coming World, and their souls become full and they fall asleep.”<sup class="footnote-marker">179</sup><i class="footnote">I.e., they die without pain.</i> The Sages were stirred by this and they explained the verse which says, <i>and full of years</i>, with this vision [of the reward that G-d shows the righteous before they die].

Verse 9

AND HIS SONS ISAAC AND ISHMAEL BURIED HIM. In the language of Bereshith Rabbah,<sup class="footnote-marker">180</sup><i class="footnote">62:6.</i> “Here the son of the handmaid bestowed respect upon the son of the mistress” [since he yielded precedence to Isaac].

Verse 10



Verse 11

AND ISAAC DWELLED BY THE WELL LAHAI-ROI. I.e., near that place, or perhaps because it was not a city,<sup class="footnote-marker">181</sup><i class="footnote">See above, 16:14, for the origin of the name “the well of Lahai-roi,” and there it expressly says that it was <i>by a fountain of water in the wilderness</i>. It was thus not a city.</i> Scripture says that he pitched his tent near the well.

Verse 12



Verse 13



Verse 14



Verse 15



Verse 16



Verse 17

AND THESE ARE THE YEARS OF THE LIFE OF ISHMAEL. It appears plausible in line with the simple explanation that Scripture relates, in the case of the sons of the righteous, their generations and the number of their years in order to inform us that the seed of the righteous shall be blessed.<sup class="footnote-marker">182</sup><i class="footnote">See Psalms 112:2.</i> However, it did not relate the number of Esau’s years for he outlived Jacob,<sup class="footnote-marker">183</sup><i class="footnote">See my Hebrew commentary, p. 42, Note 90.</i> and the narrative was concluded with the death of Jacob. Hence, Scripture did not want to return to the life of Esau since it had already mentioned his generations in their appropriate place.<sup class="footnote-marker">184</sup><i class="footnote">Further, Chapter 36.</i><br>In the Midrash of our Rabbis<sup class="footnote-marker">185</sup><i class="footnote">Megillah 17 a; Bereshith Rabbah 62:8.</i> there are many reasons for the Scriptural account of Ishmael’s years. The correct one among them is that he was righteous, a man of repentance, and Scripture tells of him as it does with all righteous people.
AND HE EXPIRED (‘VAYIGVA’). Rashi comments: “This expression — ‘expiring’ — is only mentioned in the case of righteous people.” But in the Gemara<sup class="footnote-marker">186</sup><i class="footnote">Baba Bathra 16b. The <i>Gemara</i> (teaching) constitutes the collected discussions of the <i>Amoraim</i>, centering around the <i>Mishnah</i>. The Mishnah and Gemara combined are known as the Talmud.</i> the Rabbis objected, “But it says ‘expiring’ with reference to the generation of the flood: <i>And all flesh expired that moved upon the earth</i>, etc., <i>and every man;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">187</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 7:21.</i> <i>Every thing that is in the earth shall expire</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">188</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 6:17.</i> And the Gemara answers: “We were referring to [those places where it mentions both] ‘expiring’ and ‘gathering,’” [as it says in the case of Abraham and in the present verse concerning Ishmael].<br>The intent of the Rabbis is that the expression “expiring” indicates death without prolonged sickness and without pains. This death is merited only by the righteous people, [and concerning their death both “expiring” and “gathering” are mentioned]. But the men of the generation of the flood, who were <i>overthrown as in a moment, and no hands fell upon</i> them,<sup class="footnote-marker">189</sup><i class="footnote">Lamentations 4:6.</i> as also those who died in the desert — with them Scripture therefore mentions only “expiring”: <i>when our brethren expired</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">190</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 20:3.</i> And so is the sense of the verse, <i>And that man expired not alone in his iniquity</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">191</sup><i class="footnote">Joshua 22:20.</i> meaning that his iniquity did not cause him instant death. But when Scripture so mentions the term “expiring” in reference to death together with the word <i>vayei’aseph</i> (and he was gathered [unto his people]) or <i>vayamoth</i> (and he died), it hints to the death of the righteous ones.<br>In the words of Bereshith Rabbah,<sup class="footnote-marker">192</sup><i class="footnote">62:2.</i> “<i>And Abraham expired, and died</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">193</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 8 here.</i> Rabbi Yehudah the son of Rabbi Ilai said, ‘The early pious men used to suffer with intestinal disease for about ten or twenty days before death, thus establishing the principle that illness cleanses from sin.’ Rabbi Yehudah said, ‘All who are said to have expired died of intestinal disease.’” There in Bereshith Rabbah the Rabbis also said,<sup class="footnote-marker">194</sup><i class="footnote">31:15.</i> “<i>Everything that is in the earth ‘yigva’</i><sup class="footnote-marker">188</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 6:17.</i> — will shrivel.”<br>It would appear that to the Rabbis, the word <i>gviyah</i> (expiring) was analogous to <i>Their flesh shall consume while they stand upon their feet</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">195</sup><i class="footnote">Zechariah 14:12.</i> So also is the opinion of Onkelos who translated here <i>ve’isnagid</i>, meaning “fainting,” similar to the expressions: “<i>isnagid</i> (he became faint) and sighed”;<sup class="footnote-marker">196</sup><i class="footnote">Sanhedrin 39a.</i> “You might think he may pay as a fine five <i>negidim</i> (emaciated) oxen.”<sup class="footnote-marker">197</sup><i class="footnote">Baba Kamma 67b. In case of a thief who makes restitution for stolen oxen. See Exodus 21:37. Now “you might think that if he stole an ox worth one hundred (weights in gold or silver) he may pay as a fine five oxen emaciated (‘and in near-dying condition’ - Rashi). It is for this reason that Scripture says (<i>he shall pay five oxen</i>) <i>‘tachtav’</i> “ — in its place. In other words each one of the five oxen must be equal in value to the stolen ox, “for otherwise he might pay him back five emaciated oxen which together will not equal even the value of the one stolen” (Meiri, Baba Kamma <i>ibid.</i>).</i> It is so said in the case of the flood, as Scripture states, <i>And He blotted out every being</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">198</sup><i class="footnote">Above 7:23. Ramban’s intent here is to be understood in the light of what he has written above on that verse: “<i>And He blotted out every living substance…”</i> After having said, <i>And all flesh perished (‘vayigva’)</i>, and having said, <i>whatever was in the dry land, died</i>, Scripture continues to say, “<i>And He blotted out</i>, meaning etc.”(see above p. 112). Here in discussing the meaning of the word <i>gviyah</i>. Ramban brings proof to his theory that <i>gviyah</i> in itself does not mean death but fainting, emaciation, etc. For it is on this basis that we can understand why after having said <i>‘vayigva’ all flesh</i> Scripture continued to inform us further that it died and was blotted out, since these facts are not included in the term of <i>gviyah</i>.</i> And in the case of Ishmael it is stated in the verse before us: <i>And he expired and died</i>, as a man who is powerless and dies, and this is the measure<sup class="footnote-marker">199</sup><i class="footnote">“A measure.” In the Lisbon edition of Ramban: “the death.”</i> meted out to righteous people.<sup class="footnote-marker">200</sup><i class="footnote">For since in the present verse concerning Ishmael it says both “expired” and “died” the reference must be to the death of a righteous person, as explained in the text above. “It is based upon this (double expression) that the Sages of blessed memory have said that Ishmael repented of his evil ways” (Bachya, p. 219 in my edition).</i><br>Toldoth

Verse 18



Verse 19

AND THESE ARE THE GENERATIONS OF ISAAC, ABRAHAM’s SON. Scripture says this of Esau and Jacob,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">Ramban’s intent is to teach us that the word <i>toldoth</i> is not to be understood in the broad sense of “generations” but in the more specific sense of “children.” Thus the verse reads, <i>And these are the children of Isaac</i>, namely, Esau and Jacob mentioned further on. Compare Ramban at beginning of <i>Seder Noach</i>.</i> Isaac’s sons who are mentioned further on. Scripture further mentions the circumstances of their birth.<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">Thus, in order to explain fully the story of Jacob and Esau, Scripture begins with an account of their genealogy.</i>
ABRAHAM BEGOT ISAAC. Rashi comments: “Since it was written, <i>Isaac, Abraham’s son</i>, it became necessary for Scripture to say, <i>Abraham begot Isaac</i>, since the scoffers of the generation<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">Those who did not believe in the Divine Providence that guided Abraham’s destiny.</i> were saying, ‘It was from Abimelech that Sarah became pregnant.’ Therefore the Holy One, blessed be He, formed Isaac’s facial features similar to those of Abraham so that all should say,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">“Say.” In our text of Rashi: “testify.”</i> <i>Abraham begot Isaac</i>.”<br>Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra further says that the meaning of the word <i>holid</i> (begot) is “bring up and raise,” as is the expression, <i>‘Yuldu’ (were raised) upon Joseph’s knees</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 50:23. The word <i>yuldu</i> there could not mean “were born,” for it would then mean that Joseph’s great grandchildren were actually born upon his knees. It must mean “raised.” Similarly, it means here, “Abraham <i>raised</i> Isaac.”</i> even as it says, <i>And he sent them away from Isaac his son</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 25:6, referring to the other children that Abraham sent away. Thus it is clear that only Isaac was raised by Abraham.</i><br>In my opinion the correct reason [that Scripture states here, <i>Abraham begot Isaac</i>], is that it now reverts and begins the genealogy with the founding father, in consonance with Scriptural custom, which is to revert to the head of the ancestry when dealing with people of distinction.<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">The Hebrew <i>anshei hama’alah</i>, which literally means “men of elevation,” refers to spiritual or political distinction.</i> Similarly, it is written in the book of Chronicles, <i>The sons of Shem: Elam and Asshur, and Arpachshad, and Lud, and Aram, and Uz, and Hul, and Gether, and Meshech. And Arpachshad begot Shelah, and Shelah begot Eber</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">I Chronicles 1:17-18.</i> After Scripture concluded this listing, it began again by saying, <i>Shem, Arpachshad, Shelah</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 24. This is explained by the fact that Shem is the head of Abraham’s ancestry. Hence Scripture reverts to him in tracing the generations.</i> until, <i>Abram, the same is Abraham</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 27.</i> So also in the genealogy of Benjamin in the book of Chronicles, Scripture reverts to previous generations and begins, <i>And Ner begot Kish, and Kish begot Saul</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 9:39. Saul was king of Israel. Hence Scripture reverts to his founding ancestor.</i> Here also [the Torah reverts to the founding father and says], <i>Abraham begot Isaac</i>, and Isaac begot Jacob, as Scripture will soon mention.<br>It is necessary that Scripture return to relate this<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">“This” refers to the statement, <i>Abraham begot Isaac</i>. For the purpose of indicating Jacob’s distinction it would have been sufficient to mention, <i>And these are the generations of Isaac, Abraham’s son</i>. Merely mentioning Abraham in this connection would have satisfied the Scriptural principle of reverting to the founding father in the case of “people of distinction.” Why then did the Torah continue, <i>Abraham begot Isaac?</i> Ramban proceeds to resolve this difficulty in accordance with Scriptural textual principles as opposed to Rashi, quoted above, who resorted to an Aggadic explanation: “Since the scoffers of the generation were saying etc.”</i> since it said, <i>And these are the generations of Ishmael, Abraham’s son</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 25:12.</i> Now, had it only said, <i>And these are the generations of Isaac, Abraham’s son</i>, it would appear that Scripture equated Ishmael and Isaac with respect to genealogy and distinction, all the more so since it mentioned the firstborn first.<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">Thus, Ishmael, the firstborn son of Abraham, would seem to be more significant than Isaac since he was referred to in exactly the same manner as Isaac and additionally he was mentioned first. Hence it became necessary to augment Isaac’s distinction by saying, <i>Abraham begot Isaac</i>.</i> Furthermore it would have been fitting that it begin with Abraham<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">In other words, instead of saying, <i>And these are the generations of Isaac</i>, it would have been proper that Scripture begin with Abraham, but Scripture had to avoid this for reasons explained further on in the text.</i> and say, “These are the generations of Abraham.” But Scripture did not wish to do this in order to avoid listing Ishmael and the children of Keturah.<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 25:1-4.</i> It is for this reason that Scripture returns and completes the verse by stating, <i>Abraham begot Isaac</i>, as if to say that it is he [Isaac] alone who is Abraham’s offspring. It is considered as if he [Abraham] did not beget anyone else, just as it says, <i>For in Isaac shall seed be called to thee</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 21:12.</i> It is for this reason that it also says above, <i>And these are the generations of Ishmael, Abraham’s son, whom Hagar the Egyptian, Sarah’s handmaid, bore unto Abraham:</i><sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 25:12.</i> the phrase, <i>whom Hagar</i>, etc., is for the honor of Isaac, as if to say that the genealogy of these generations is not traceable to Abraham, rather they are the children of the handmaid, even as it says, <i>And also of the son of the bondwoman will I make a nation</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 13.</i> Scripture does also similarly in the book of Chronicles. At first it states: <i>The sons of Abraham; Isaac and Ishmael. These are their generations: the first born of Ishmael, Nebaioth</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">I Chronicles 1:28-29.</i> Then it mentions, <i>And the sons of Keturah, Abraham’s concubine: she bore Zimran</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 32.</i> Now it would have been logical to follow this by saying, “the sons of Isaac,” but instead it reverts and begins: <i>And Abraham begot Isaac. The sons of Isaac: Esau, and Israel</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 32. The repetition, <i>And Abraham begot Isaac</i>, is necessary lest we equate “the sons of Ishmael” with “the sons of Isaac.”</i>

Verse 20



Verse 21



Verse 22

AND SHE SAID: IF IT BE SO, ‘LAMAH ZEH ANOCHI?’”If the pain of pregnancy is so great, <i>lamah zeh anochi</i> (why did I) pray for and aspire to pregnancy?” Thus Rashi. But it is not correct.<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">For the word <i>anochi</i> (I), according to Rashi, implies “I prayed for pregnancy.” And this, comments Ramban, is not correct. (Gur Aryeh.)</i> Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra says that she asked the women if they had experienced such pains, and they said, “No,” whereupon she said, “If the matter and custom of pregnancy be as they said, <i>lamah zeh anochi</i>, why am I beset with an unusual pregnancy?” Now according to this exposition, the verse is missing and not complete.<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">Her inquiring of other women as to their experiences with pregnancy is not even mentioned explicitly although it is central to the thought expressed in the verse, according to Ibn Ezra.</i><br>The correct interpretation in my opinion is that she said, “If it shall be so with me, <i>lamah zeh anochi</i>, [why am I in the world]? Would that I did not exist, that I should die or never have come into existence.”<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">The J. P. S. translation, <i>If it be so, wherefore do I live?</i>, follows Ramban’s interpretation.</i> This is similar to the verse, <i>I should have been as though I had not been</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">Job 10:19.</i>
AND SHE WENT ‘LIDROSH’ (TO INQUIRE) OF THE ETERNAL. Rashi comments: “To tell<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">“To tell.” Our text of Rashi reads: “that He should tell her.”</i> what her outcome will be.” Now I have not discovered the word <i>drishah</i> [<i>lidrosh</i>, to inquire] in relation to G-d except in the context of prayer, as in the verses: <i>I sought (‘darashti’) the Eternal and He answered me;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 34:5.</i> <i>seek ye Me, (‘dirshuni’) and live;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">Amos 5:4.</i> <i>As I live, saith G-d the Eternal, I will not be inquired of (‘edareish’) by you</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote">Ezekiel 20:3. See Ramban on Exodus 18:15.</i>

Verse 23

TWO NATIONS ARE IN THY WOMB. The intent of this is that He informed her that she should not fear, for the reason that the struggle in her womb is that she is pregnant with twins, this being the customary way among women who are pregnant with twins.<br>It is possible that He is also saying that since they are destined to be two peoples, hating and warring with each other, at the very beginning of their creation they initiated a quarrel, thus intimating at the situation which will ultimately exist between them. But He assured her that now they will rest, and she will find rest and quiet for herself.

Verse 24



Verse 25



Verse 26



Verse 27



Verse 28

BECAUSE THERE WAS VENISON IN HIS MOUTH. The commentators<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">Ibn Ezra and R’dak.</i> explained it as meaning either that he [Esau] gave venison into Isaac’s mouth, or that he brought Isaac venison. The act of giving or bringing is thus missing from the verse. Similarly: <i>The set time which Samuel;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">I Samuel 13:5. Here the word “appointed” is missing, the meaning of the verse being “at the set time which Samuel had appointed.”</i> <i>But the Lord</i> — presented or made — <i>me as a mighty warrior</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote">Jeremiah 20:11.</i><br>It is possible to explain that <i>Isaac loved Esau</i> because there was always venison in the mouth of Isaac. All day he would desire to eat the venison, and it was always in his mouth. He would not eat anything else, and Esau was the one who brought it to him, as Scripture said, <i>A cunning hunter</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote">Above, Verse 27.</i><br>In my opinion the correct interpretation is that it is a metaphor which tells us that Esau, in the mouth of his father, was a hunter,<sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote">Instead of calling him by his name, Isaac would call him “hunter.”</i> as a person is surnamed by his constant occupation. Similarly, <i>Thy habitation is in the midst of deceit;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote">Jeremiah 9:5. Meaning “in the midst <i>of people</i> of deceit.” But the verse refers to the people by their constant practice.</i> likewise, <i>But I am all prayer</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 109:40. Meaning, “But I am <i>a man</i> of constant prayer.”</i> And so they said in Bereshith Rabbah,<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote">Bereshith Rabbah 63:15.</i> “Good meat for his mouth, good drink for his mouth.”<sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote">If he would find good meat or drink, he would bring it to his father. This Midrash thus indicates that Esau was constantly engaged in bringing food and drink to his father. Hence Isaac came to call him “hunter” because of his steady preoccupation with bringing him food.</i>

Verse 29



Verse 30

OF THIS RED, RED POTTAGE. The dish was either reddened by the lentils which were red, or it had been compounded with some red substance, and Esau, not knowing what it was, called it <i>edom</i> (red). <i>Therefore was his name called Edom</i> since they mocked at him for having sold an honorable birthright for a small dish. <i>For the drunkard and the glutton shall come to poverty</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 23:21. Esau was thus mocked that because of his gluttony he would be reduced to poverty.</i>

Verse 31

SELL ME THIS DAY (‘KAYOM’) THY BIRTHRIGHT. “I.e., as this day.<sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote">“As this day.” Our text of Rashi reads: “<i>Ketargumo</i> (Explain it as the Targum rendered it), ‘as this day.’” Rashi now proceeds to interpret the Targum to mean, “just as this day is certain, etc.”</i> Just as this day is certain, so make me a binding sale.” This is Rashi’s language.<br>The literal meaning of the word <i>kayom</i> is “at this time,” just as: <i>But stand thou still at this time (‘kayom’), that I may cause thee to hear the word of G-d;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote">I Samuel 9:27.</i> <i>At this time (‘kayom’) you shall find him;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">42</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 13.</i> <i>Let the fat be made to smoke at this time (‘kayom’);</i><sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 2:16.</i> <i>But unto us belongeth confusion of face, as at this day (‘kayom’)</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote">Daniel 9:7.</i><br>It would appear from the opinion of Onkelos<sup class="footnote-marker">45</sup><i class="footnote">Since Onkelos, the author of the Targum, added the word <i>dilhein</i>, it would appear from this, etc.</i> that because the sale of the birthright was to take effect after the death of his father Isaac, he [Jacob] said, “Sell me the birthright, with the sale to take effect on whatever day [our father’s death] may occur.”<sup class="footnote-marker">46</sup><i class="footnote">Ramban’s intent is as follows: Since Esau would not possess the birthright until after Isaac’s death —(see Ramban further, Verse 34, that the birthright carried with it no distinction except after the passing of the father)— if he were to attempt to sell it effective immediately, the sale would not be valid. But in this way, having stipulated “whenever that may be,” even though the death of Isaac and the subsequent acquisition of the birthright by Esau have not yet occurred, the sale by Esau is nevertheless valid since Jacob stipulated “whenever that may be.” See my Hebrew commentary, p. 145.</i> This is a typical usage of <i>lahein</i> in the Aramaic language: “Wherever (<i>lahein</i>) are you going?”<sup class="footnote-marker">47</sup><i class="footnote">Yerushalmi Berachoth II, 8: <i>lahein yeizil lei</i>.</i> This means, “To what place are you going?” This is derived from the expression, “Whatever (<i>hein</i>) you let me know.”<sup class="footnote-marker">48</sup><i class="footnote">Yalkut Shimoni Ezra 10:3.</i> Similarly in Bereshith Rabbah, <i>Parshath Vayishlach</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">49</sup><i class="footnote">Bereshith Rabbah 78:1.</i> “Wherever (<i>velahein</i>) are they going?”<sup class="footnote-marker">50</sup><i class="footnote">Our Bereshith Rabbah reads: <i>ule’an atun azlin</i>. See, however, Theodore’s edition of this Midrash, p. 906, where he quotes from manuscript, <i>velahein</i>, as Ramban has it.</i> is derived from the expression, “Whatever (<i>hein</i>) is broken.”<sup class="footnote-marker">49</sup><i class="footnote">Bereshith Rabbah 78:1.</i> This is their<sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote">Those conversing or writing in the Aramaic language.</i> customary usage of language in many places. And in the book of Daniel this form appears with a <i>patach</i><sup class="footnote-marker">52</sup><i class="footnote">That is our <i>kametz</i>.</i> under the letter <i>lamed</i>, similar in meaning to the word <i>ilahin</i> (which): <i>Which ‘lohin’ the angels whose dwelling is not with flesh;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">53</sup><i class="footnote">Daniel 2:11.</i> <i>whatever</i><sup class="footnote-marker">54</sup><i class="footnote">“Whatever, you do, O king….”</i> <i>(‘lohin’), O king, let my counsel be acceptable unto thee</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">55</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 4:24.</i> Now Onkelos translated the Hebrew word <i>zulathi</i> as <i>ilahin</i><sup class="footnote-marker">56</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 1:36. <i>Zulathi Caleb</i> (excepting Caleb) is translated by Onkelos as <i>elahin Caleb</i>. To the Aramaic root <i>lahin</i> which appears in the book of Daniel — (see my Hebrew text, p. 145 line 2 from bottom, covering Notes 53 and 55 here) — Onkelos added the letters <i>aleph</i> and <i>yod</i>, thus making it <i>elahin</i>. The intent of Ramban is to indicate that it should not surprise us that Onkelos added a <i>dalet</i> in the text before us, thus making it <i>dilhein</i>, for just as the original word <i>hen</i> was augmented to become <i>lahein</i> so he further expanded it to read <i>dilhein</i>. (Aboab.)</i> its meaning being as the two words, <i>ila hin</i>.<br>Now in carefully edited texts of Onkelos I found the reading, <i>kayom dilhei</i>. This conforms with my interpretation, for <i>hei</i> in their language<sup class="footnote-marker">57</sup><i class="footnote">Aramaic.</i> means “which,” as it is said in the Talmud: “Which (<i>hei</i>) Rabbi Meir?”<sup class="footnote-marker">58</sup><i class="footnote">Baba Kamma 99b.</i> “Which (<i>hei</i>) Rabbi Yehudah?”<sup class="footnote-marker">59</sup><i class="footnote">Baba Bathra 141a.</i> and others.<br>It is possible that Onkelos understood the word <i>kayom</i> (as the day) as if it were <i>bayom</i> (on the day). The verse would then be stating, “Sell the birthright to me on the day it will come into your possession.” We find such usage of the letter <i>kaf</i> elsewhere: <i>As (‘Ka’asher’) they go, I will spread My net upon them</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">60</sup><i class="footnote">Hosea 7:12.</i> meaning <i>ba’asher</i> (wherever they go) rather than “whenever they go.” Similarly, <i>And for the blood (‘kidmei’) of thy children that thou didst give unto them;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">61</sup><i class="footnote">Ezekiel 16:36. <i>Ve’kidmei</i> is to be interpreted as <i>ubidmei</i> (and <i>in</i> the blood).</i> <i>For I have spread you abroad as the four (‘ke’arba’) winds of the heavens</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">62</sup><i class="footnote">Zechariah 2:10. <i>Ke’arba</i> is here to be interpreted as <i>be’arba</i> (<i>in</i> the four).</i><br>And some scholars say<sup class="footnote-marker">63</sup><i class="footnote">Quoted by R’dak in his commentary in the name of his father. It is mentioned in Pesikta Zutrata, and a reference to it is also found in Bamidbar Rabbah 6:2.</i> that the price for the birthright was not the pottage at all. Rather, Scripture tells that when Esau, being faint, desired to eat, Jacob said to him, “Sell me your birthright for money and then eat,” and Esau, in his haste for food, answered him, “What is this birthright to me? It is sold to you.” He then swore to him upon it, and they sat down to eat and drink. Scripture however did not reveal the price. I do not agree with this interpretation.

Verse 32



Verse 33

SWEAR TO ME THIS DAY. When Esau said, “What is this birthright to me? I do not desire it,” Jacob said to him, “Swear to me that you will not desire it, nor will you inherit it forever.” Thereupon he swore to him, and following that he sold it to him, and Jacob gave him the purchase price<sup class="footnote-marker">64</sup><i class="footnote">That is, the money. This is in accordance with the opinion stated above. Although Ramban does not agree with it, he nevertheless mentions it as an alternate interpretation of the verse.</i> or the pottage he desired.<br>It is possible that Esau said, “What is this birthright to me? It is sold to you,” and Jacob said, “Swear to me that you will never complain about the sale.” And when Scripture says that first he swore to him and then he sold it to him, its intent is as if it said that he sold it to him first and then swore to him.

Verse 34

SO ESAU DESPISED HIS BIRTHRIGHT. <i>Who so despiseth the word shall suffer thereby</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">65</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 13:13. Ramban’s intent in quoting this verse is to explain why it was necessary for the verse before us to say, <i>So Esau ‘despised,’</i> since, as is clearly indicated in Scripture later on, Esau regretted his action and complained that <i>he</i> [Jacob] <i>took my birthright</i>. (Further, 28:36.) Scripture therefore justifies what befell Esau later on by saying here, <i>So Esau ‘despised’ the birthright</i>, and he who despises the word shall suffer thereby.</i> But, indeed, Scripture has already explained the reason that Esau consented to the sale. This was because he was in mortal danger from his hunting animals, and it was likely that he would die while his father was alive, and the birthright carried with it no distinction except after the passing of the father. So of what benefit was the birthright to him? This then is what Scripture says: <i>And he did eat and drink, and he rose and went, and he despised</i>, for, after having eaten and drunk, he returned to his hunt in the field which was the cause of the despising of the birthright. <i>For there is no desire in fools</i><sup class="footnote-marker">66</sup><i class="footnote">Ecclesiastes 5:3.</i> except to eat and drink and to fulfill their momentary desire, not giving a care for tomorrow.<br>Now Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra has erred here exceedingly by saying that Esau despised the birthright because he saw his father destitute of wealth. Now, [continues Ibn Ezra,] many wonder about Isaac’s poverty since Abraham left him with great wealth. But have they never seen a person who was wealthy in his younger years and became poor in his old age? An indication that Isaac was indeed poor is the fact that Isaac loved Esau because of his venison. Furthermore, had there been abundant food in his father’s house and he [Esau] “the honorable one in his sight,”<sup class="footnote-marker">67</sup><i class="footnote">See Isaiah 43:4.</i> he would not have sold his birthright for pottage. Also, if his father ate savory meat every day, what reason was there for him to say to Esau, “Bring me some venison?”<sup class="footnote-marker">68</sup><i class="footnote">See further, 27:3-4.</i> Why did Jacob not have costly garments as Esau had?<sup class="footnote-marker">69</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>ibid.</i>, Verse 15.</i> Why did his mother not give Jacob some silver and gold for his journey when he fled to Haran so that he had to say, <i>And He will give me bread to eat, and a garment to put on?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">70</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 28:20.</i> Why did she not send him some money — since she loved him — so that he was required to tend Laban’s flock?<sup class="footnote-marker">71</sup><i class="footnote">All these questions indicate that Isaac was indeed poor.</i> The verse which states, <i>Thus the man grew</i><sup class="footnote-marker">72</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 26:13.</i> [in wealth], must refer to the period before he became old. Now ignorant people think that wealth is a great distinction for the righteous. Let Elijah prove the contrary.<sup class="footnote-marker">73</sup><i class="footnote">See I Kings 17:6, where Elijah’s poverty is depicted.</i> These ignorant people further ask, “Why did G-d cause Isaac to lack wealth?” Perhaps they could also inform us why He caused Isaac’s vision to be diminished? And let them not dismiss me with a reply based upon a <i>d’rash</i><sup class="footnote-marker">74</sup><i class="footnote">The <i>D’rash</i> (Aggadic) answer is that Isaac’s eyes became dim as a result of Esau’s wives offering incense to the idols. See Rashi further, 27:1, where this is one of several reasons mentioned.</i> for there is indeed a secret<sup class="footnote-marker">75</sup><i class="footnote">Interpreters of Ibn Ezra suggest that “the secret” referred to here is the fact that Isaac was a son of Abraham’s old age, and it was for this reason that his eyesight was weak.</i> in the matter, and we must not probe since the thoughts of G-d are deep and no man has the power to understand them. All these are Abraham ibn Ezra’s words.<br>Now I wonder who has blinded Abraham ibn Ezra’s reasoning in this matter, causing him to say that Abraham left Isaac great wealth, and he lost it just prior to this event, [that is, the sale of the birthright], and for this reason, Esau despised the birthright, for this matter of the sale of the birthright took place when Jacob and Esau were still young, before Esau married, as Scripture tells,<sup class="footnote-marker">76</sup><i class="footnote"><i>And Esau was forty years old when he took to wife</i>. (26:34).</i> and after the sale of the birthright, Isaac again became wealthy in the land of the Philistines <i>until he became very great… and the Philistines were jealous of him</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">77</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 26:13-14.</i> Following that, [according to Ibn Ezra, we must say that Isaac] again became poor, and he desired the venison of his son Esau and the savory meats. All this is laughable. Furthermore, the verse says, <i>And it came to pass after the death of Abraham, that G-d blessed his son Isaac</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">78</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 25:11.</i> Now the blessing refers to increase of wealth, possessions and honor, but where was His blessing if he lost the wealth of his father and became impoverished? Afterwards it says, <i>And I will be with Thee, and I will bless thee</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">79</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 26:3.</i> [but according to Ibn Ezra you will have to say that Isaac] became rich and then poor! And if it be true that in matters of wealth, <i>There are righteous men unto whom it happeneth according to the work of the wicked</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">80</sup><i class="footnote">Ecclesiastes 8:14.</i> this does not apply to those righteous men who have been expressly blessed by the Holy One, blessed be He, since <i>the blessing of the Eternal maketh rich, and no sorrow is added thereto</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">81</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 10:22.</i> Rather, the patriarchs all were as kings before whom kings of the nations came and with whom they made covenants. Now it is written concerning Isaac and Abimelech, <i>And they swore one to another</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">82</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 26:31.</i> But if Isaac had suffered bad fortune and lost his father’s wealth, how did [Abimelech, King of the Philistines, and Phichol, the head of his army], say, <i>we saw plainly that the Eternal was with thee</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">83</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 28.</i> when he was already in financial difficulty? Rather, Esau’s disdain of the birthright was due to his brutal nature.<br>It is possible that the law of double portion to which the firstborn is entitled according to the statutes of the Torah<sup class="footnote-marker">84</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 21:17.</i> was not in effect in ancient times.<sup class="footnote-marker">85</sup><i class="footnote">That is, in the time of the patriarchs.</i> [At that time the birthright] was only a matter of inheriting the pre-eminence of the father and his authority so that he [the firstborn] would receive honor and distinction in relation to his younger brother. It is for this reason that Esau said to Isaac, <i>I am thy son, thy firstborn</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">86</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 27:32.</i> meaning to say that he is the firstborn who deserves to be blessed. Similarly, [Joseph said to his father, Jacob], <i>For this is the firstborn; put thy hand upon his head</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">87</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 48:18.</i> thereby meaning that Jacob should give him precedence in the blessing. Perhaps the firstborn also took slightly more of the inheritance since the law of double portion is an innovation of the statutes of the Torah.<sup class="footnote-marker">88</sup><i class="footnote">Thus even in ancient times it was customary that the firstborn inherit more than one share. However, the Torah established his portion to be two shares. This interpretation differs from Ramban’s original thesis that the firstborn originally had no preference whatever in inheritance, and that the Torah instituted this law.</i> And as for the venison in his mouth which Isaac desired so strongly, this is in keeping with the custom of princes and kings. They prefer venison above all food, and out of fear, all nations bring them gifts of venison. Esau flattered his father by bringing him all the venison so that he may always eat of it to his heart’s content,<sup class="footnote-marker">89</sup><i class="footnote">Ramban thus explains Isaac’s desire for venison without postulating Isaac’s poverty as Ibn Ezra did.</i> and the love of a father for his firstborn is easily understood.<br>As for Isaac’s saying that he would bless Esau after he had prepared the savory meats for him, that was not a reward or a recompense for the food. Instead, he wanted to derive some benefit from him so that his very soul would be bound up in his at the time that he brought him the food so that he would then bless him with a complete desire and a perfect will. Perhaps Isaac discerned in himself that following the meal his soul would be delighted and joyous, and then the <i>Ruach Hakodesh</i><sup class="footnote-marker">90</sup><i class="footnote">“The holy spirit.” The expression refers to a degree of prophecy. See Moreh Nebuchim, II, 45 (2).</i> would come upon him, [as was the case with Elisha the prophet, who said], ‘<i>But now bring me a minstrel. And it came to pass, when the minstrel played, that the hand of the Eternal came upon him</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">91</sup><i class="footnote">II Kings 3:15.</i><br>And as for not giving wealth to Jacob, that was [not due to Isaac’s poverty but rather] because Jacob was fleeing for his life. He left the country alone without his brother’s knowledge, and had he been given along wealth, servants and camels, they would have increased his enemies’ jealousy and resulted in their ambushing him and killing him. Our Rabbis do indeed say that Jacob was robbed [at the outset of his journey<sup class="footnote-marker">92</sup><i class="footnote">Bereshith Rabbah 68:2. Thus another difficulty tending <i>to</i> favor Ibn Ezra’s thesis that Isaac was poverty stricken is resolved.</i> of whatever possessions he had].<br>And who has told Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra that Jacob had no costly garments, <i>fine linen and silk and embroidered robes?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">93</sup><i class="footnote">Ezekiel 16:13.</i> Rather, Scripture states that when going to the field to hunt, Esau would change his garments for his hunting clothes, and due to the fact that [because of his dim eyesight], Isaac always touched his son and his clothes with his hands, Rebekah clothed Jacob with them lest he recognize him by his clothes. You see that this is precisely what Isaac did: <i>And he smelled the odor of his garments</i><sup class="footnote-marker">94</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 27:27.</i> because he had put them among calamus and cinnamon, even as it is written, <i>Myrrh and aloes, and cassia are all thy garments</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">95</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 45:9.</i> The spices grew in the Land of Israel, and it is for this reason that Isaac said, <i>The odor of my son is as the odor of a field</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">94</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 27:27.</i> Because he was a man of the field<sup class="footnote-marker">96</sup><i class="footnote">See above, Verse 27.</i> his garments had the odor of the field or that of the blossoms of the trees, just as our Rabbis explained it: <i>As the odor of a field</i><sup class="footnote-marker">94</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 27:27.</i> of apples.<sup class="footnote-marker">97</sup><i class="footnote">Taanith 29b.</i><br>And as for the question raised above concerning the quality of Isaac’s lack of vision, it is a question raised by the ignorant, for if<sup class="footnote-marker">98</sup><i class="footnote">Further in the text Ramban suggests that Isaac’s dim vision was a natural result of his old age. Hence he writes here: “<i>If</i> it was brought about.”</i> it was brought about especially by G-d, it was in order that Isaac bless Jacob, this being the purport of the verse, <i>And it came to pass, that when Isaac was old, and his eyes were dim, he called Esau</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">99</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 27:1.</i> And in line with the natural meaning of Scripture, this was but a manifestation of old age, the explanation of the verse being as follows: <i>And it came to pass, that when Isaac was old, and his eyes were dim</i> in his old age, <i>he called Esau</i>. Now of Jacob himself it is said later on, <i>Now the eyes of Israel were dim for age, so that he could not see</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">100</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 48:10.</i> Of Achiyah the Shilonite it is also written, <i>Now Achiyah could not see; for his eyes were set by reason of his age</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">101</sup><i class="footnote">I Kings 14:4.</i> and concerning Moses our teacher it is related with wonder that <i>his eye was not dim</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">102</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 34:7.</i>

Chapter 26



Verse 1

BESIDE THE FIRST FAMINE THAT WAS IN THE DAYS OF ABRAHAM. Perhaps<sup class="footnote-marker">103</sup><i class="footnote">“Perhaps.” Since in Bereshith Rabbah 25:3, it is stated that there were ten famines in the world, the first one having been in the days of Adam, Ramban writes, “Perhaps,” meaning that a famine of such magnitude had never occurred before the days of Abraham, and this explains why Scripture uses it as a reference point.</i> there was no famine in the world until the days of Abraham. This is why Scripture counts from it, for otherwise, what need is there to mention it? In my opinion the correct reason why Scripture mentions it is to tell us that people remembered the first famine, mentioning that on account of it Abraham went down to Egypt and there G-d did him great honor. It was for this reason that Isaac wanted to go in his father’s footsteps by descending into Egypt until it was said to him, <i>Go not down into Egypt</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">104</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 2 here.</i> The reason for the prohibition has been stated by our Rabbis: “You [Isaac] are a perfect burnt-offering and residence outside of the Land of Israel does not befit you.”<sup class="footnote-marker">105</sup><i class="footnote">Quoted by Rashi in this form. The source is in Bereshith Rabbah.</i><br>In my opinion, there is also included in this subject a reference to the future. Abraham’s exile into Egypt on account of the famine is an allusion to the exile of his children there.<sup class="footnote-marker">106</sup><i class="footnote">See Ramban above, 12:10, for complete exposition of this subject.</i> His going to Abimelech<sup class="footnote-marker">107</sup><i class="footnote">Chapter 20.</i> however was not an exile for he resided there of his own volition. But Isaac’s going [to the land of Abimelech, as recorded here in this verse, <i>And Isaac went unto Abimelech</i>] on account of the famine, does allude to an exile since he left his place against his will and went to another land. Now Isaac’s exile was from his own place to the land of the Philistines, which was the land in which his father had resided. This alludes to the Babylonian Exile, which took place in the land in which their ancestors had resided, namely, Ur of the Chaldees.<sup class="footnote-marker">108</sup><i class="footnote">In view of the fact that Ramban, at the end of <i>Seder Noach</i> (11:28), states his opinion at length that Abraham’s birthplace was not Ur of the Chaldees, it is necessary to say that the author’s reference here is to the time when Terah, his father, took him there, and while being there his life was saved by a miracle. See Ramban there at the end of Verse 28.</i><br>Know further that this Babylonian Exile mentioned is mirrored in the events which befell Isaac in that they did not take his wife<sup class="footnote-marker">109</sup><i class="footnote">As they did to Abraham in Egypt. (12:15).</i> in the land of the Philistines. Rather, his lot there was only exile and fear. At the beginning Abimelech said, <i>He that toucheth this man or his wife shall surely be put to death</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">110</sup><i class="footnote">Further, Verse 11.</i> Later he regretted it and said, <i>Go from us</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">111</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 16 here.</i> Afterwards, he returned and made a covenant with Isaac<sup class="footnote-marker">112</sup><i class="footnote">Verses 25-31 here.</i> Similarly, in the Babylonian Exile, they were exiled there <i>because of the burning heat of famine</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">113</sup><i class="footnote">Lamentations 5:10.</i> and while there, they were neither subjugated, nor were they treated harshly. On the contrary, their leaders were princes in the government. Later on, they said, <i>Whosoever there is among you of all His people — his G-d be with him — let him go up</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">114</sup><i class="footnote">Ezra 1:3.</i> even alerting the princes and governors beyond the River<sup class="footnote-marker">115</sup><i class="footnote">Euphrates. The term “beyond the River” here applies to the region beyond the River westward from the standpoint of those in Babylonia or Persia.</i> to help them. Later on, they ceased work [on the House of G-d in Jerusalem] , and it ceased “for a season and a time.”<sup class="footnote-marker">116</sup><i class="footnote">See Ezra 4:24 and Daniel 7:12.</i> Later, they again changed their policy and gave permission for the construction of the House of G-d, saying, <i>That they may offer sacrifices of sweet savor unto the G-d of heaven, and pray for the life of the king and his sons</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">117</sup><i class="footnote">Ezra 6:10.</i>
TO ABIMELECH, KING OF THE PHILISTINES. It is not known whether this is the same Abimelech who lived in the days of Abraham<sup class="footnote-marker">107</sup><i class="footnote">Chapter 20.</i> or whether every Philistine king was so called, for in the time of David he was also called Abimelech.<sup class="footnote-marker">118</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 34:1.</i> Onkelos, however, is of the opinion that the Abimelech with whom Isaac dealt was a son [of the one mentioned in the account of Abraham].<sup class="footnote-marker">119</sup><i class="footnote">Ramban refers to Onkelos’ translation of Verse 28, <i>Let there be now an oath between us, and thee</i>, which Onkelos translates as follows: “Let there be now an oath <i>which was between our fathers</i> between us and thee.” Thus Onkelos states that the present Abimelech was a son of the one who lived in the days of Isaac’s father.</i><br>The reason that Isaac went to Abimelech was that he intended to go down to Egypt, so he went to Abimelech, his father’s confederate, in the hope that perhaps he would deal kindly with him in the days of the famine, thus making it unnecessary for him to go down to Egypt.
