Now Abimelech, on account of his covenant with Abraham, did not harm him or his family at all. However, <i>the men of the place</i><sup class="footnote-marker">120</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 7 here.</i> asked Isaac, in mere quest, concerning his wife, and he said, <i>She is my sister</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">120</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 7 here.</i> Even so, neither the king nor any of his men touched her for they remembered the affair of Abraham.<sup class="footnote-marker">107</sup><i class="footnote">Chapter 20.</i> Hence Abimelech said, <i>One of the people might lightly have lain</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">121</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 10 here.</i> meaning to say, “I Abimelech did not touch her, and I was careful concerning her, but one of the men of the land might easily have stumbled, and then you would have made us incur guilt, as we sinned in the matter of your father.”

Verse 2

DWELL IN THE LAND WHICH I SHALL TELL THEE OF. It is incomprehensible that G-d should tell Isaac at one time, <i>Dwell in the land which I shall tell thee of</i>, [and in the following verse continue], <i>Sojourn in this land</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">122</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 3 here.</i> [and in both cases be referring to the same land]. Instead, its explanation is as follows: “<i>Go not down into Egypt</i>, and dwell all your days in the land which I shall tell you from time to time. At the bidding of G-d you should move, and at the bidding of G-d you should encamp,<sup class="footnote-marker">123</sup><i class="footnote">See Numbers 9:18.</i> and right now, <i>sojourn in this land</i>, the land of the Philistines, <i>for unto thee and unto thy seed I will give it</i>, even as it is written, <i>Counted to the Canaanites are the five lords of the Philistines</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">124</sup><i class="footnote">Joshua 13:3.</i><br>It is possible that [the event referred to in the beginning of the verse], <i>And the Lord appeared unto him, and said … dwell in the land which I shall tell thee of</i>, happened earlier so that before Isaac left his place it was said to him, “<i>Go not down into Egypt; dwell in the land which I shall tell thee of</i> when you will be there. Now dwell in this land, the land of Canaan, which will comprise many peoples and many lands, for I now command that you should not leave it forever for all these lands will I give to thy seed.” Following this command, Isaac journeyed from his place because of the famine to go into all the lands of Canaan, to dwell in the land which He would tell him. And when he came to Gerar, He said to him, “Dwell here.” It was not necessary however for Scripture to detail this for it is known that Isaac would not transgress the command of G-d.<sup class="footnote-marker">125</sup><i class="footnote">Therefore, when Scripture wrote that Isaac was given the charge, <i>Dwell in the land which I shall tell thee of</i>, he left his place and went searching within the land of Canaan for a new home. When he finally reached Gerar he was told, <i>Sojourn in this land</i>. Thus Ramban explains that there was a lapse of [[illegible]] Verses 2 and 3. The original difficulty which Ramban mentions at the beginning of his comments on this verse is thus removed.</i> A similar case of interpretation appears in the verse, <i>Upon one of the mountains which I will tell thee of</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">126</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 22:2.</i> as I mentioned there.

Verse 3

AND I WILL FULFILL THE OATH WHICH I SWORE UNTO ABRAHAM THY FATHER. There is no need for the Holy One, blessed be He, to assure Isaac that He will not violate the oath which He swore to his father, <i>for He is not a man, that He should repent</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">127</sup><i class="footnote">I Samuel 15:29.</i> Abraham had no other seed upon whom a covenant had been established with G-d except Isaac. The oath, moreover, was not given on condition. In the case of Jacob,<sup class="footnote-marker">128</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 35:12. <i>And [[illegible]] land which I gave to Abraham and Isaac, to thee will I give it</i>.</i> it was necessary that he be given such assurance on account of his brother Esau. He was thus saying that in him [Jacob] and his seed will the covenant be fulfilled, not in Esau. [But in the case of Isaac, why was it necessary that he be given such a promise?]<br>It would appear then that this expression, <i>Vehakimothi eth hashevuah</i>, is itself an oath.<sup class="footnote-marker">129</sup><i class="footnote">It is thus to be translated, <i>And I will ‘establish’ the oath</i>. This is now found in most English translations.</i> It is for this reason that the Torah always says, <i>The land which I swore unto Abraham, unto Isaac, and unto Jacob;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">130</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 34:4.</i> <i>Remember Abraham, Isaac, and Israel, Thy servants, to whom Thou didst swear by Thine own self</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">131</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 32:13.</i> For we find no source for an oath having been given to Isaac except this verse.<br>Now it was the desire of the Holy One, blessed be He, to swear to each one of the patriarchs to let it be known that each one was worthy of the covenant being made with him alone, and that the merit of each one stands before Him together with their seed. Even though the previous one suffices, it is an additional merit and honor to them.<sup class="footnote-marker">132</sup><i class="footnote">That is, their descendants.</i> It is for this reason He said, <i>Then will I remember My covenant with Jacob, and also My covenant with Isaac, and also My covenant with Abraham will I remember; and I will remember the land</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">133</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 26:42.</i> since all of them had the distinction of G-d having made a covenant with them.<br>It is possible that He promised something additional to Isaac through this oath, namely, that He will fulfill in him himself, the oath He had sworn to Abraham his father, i.e., that he [Isaac] will be a blessing among the nations, even as He said to Abraham his father, <i>And all the nations of the earth shall bless themselves with thy seed</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">134</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 22:18.</i> The explanation of the verse before us will thus be: “<i>And I will fulfill</i> in thee <i>the oath which I swore unto Abraham thy father</i> since you will be a blessing among the nations.” Similarly, He also says in the case of Jacob, <i>And in thee and in thy seed shall all of the families of the earth be blessed</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">135</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 28:14.</i>

Verse 4



Verse 5

AND HE KEPT MY CHARGE. Rashi comments: “<i>As a reward that Abraham hearkened to My voice</i> when I tested him. <i>And he kept My charge</i> — these are the precautionary decrees instituted by the Sages, which are intended to make us avoid the violation of Biblical laws, such as Second Degrees of forbidden marriages and certain prohibited acts on the Sabbath. My <i>commandments</i> — these are precepts which, had they not been written in the Torah, were requisite to have been written, such as robbery and murder. <i>My statutes</i> — these are matters against which the evil inclination and the heathen nations argue, such as the prohibitions against eating the swine and the wearing of garments woven of wool and linen, there being no apparent rationale for them except that they are decrees of the King imposed on His subjects. <i>And My laws</i> — the plural is intended to include, [besides the Written Law], the Oral Law as well as those rules given to Moses from Sinai.” [Thus far the words of Rashi.]<br>Now if so, all this interpretation is posited on the opinion that Abraham fulfilled and observed the Torah before it was given on Sinai. This is indeed what the Sages of the Midrash said in connection with the verse, <i>And Joseph gave them ‘agaloth’ (wagons)</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">136</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 45:21. The word <i>agaloth</i> (wagons) may also mean “heifers,” thus suggesting that as a mark of identification to his father, Joseph gave his brothers a reference to the law of the Heifer (Deuteronomy 21:6) which he studied with his father just before he became separated from him. The Midrash referred to is in Bereshith Rabbah 95:2.</i> thereby indicating to his father that when he left him they were studying the section dealing with <i>Eglah Arufah</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">137</sup><i class="footnote">See Deuteronomy 21:1-9.</i> Thus Joseph occupied himself with Torah just as his fathers did. Though the Torah had not yet been given, it is still written of Abraham, <i>And he kept My charge, My commandments, My statutes, and My laws</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">138</sup><i class="footnote">Thus far the Midrash in Bereshith Rabbah, 95:2.</i> There the Sages also said<sup class="footnote-marker">139</sup><i class="footnote">Bereshith Rabbah, <i>ibid.</i></i> that Abraham observed the details of the Torah, which he taught to his children, etc.<sup class="footnote-marker">140</sup><i class="footnote">To his children, as it is said, <i>For I know him that he will command his children and his household after him</i>, etc. (Above, 18:19.) Bereshith Rabbah, <i>ibid.</i></i><br>The question presents itself: If it be the case [that the laws of the Torah were observed by our ancestors before the Torah was given on Sinai], how did Jacob erect a pillar<sup class="footnote-marker">141</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 28:18. This is forbidden in Deuteronomy 16:22.</i> and marry two sisters in their lifetime,<sup class="footnote-marker">142</sup><i class="footnote">Forbidden in Leviticus 18:18.</i> and, in the opinion of our Rabbis, four sisters.<sup class="footnote-marker">143</sup><i class="footnote">According to Bereshith Rabbah 74:11, Bilhah and Zilpah were also daughters of Laban. Thus Jacob married four sisters: Leah, Rachel, Bilhah and Zilpah.</i> Also, Amram [Moses’ father] married his aunt,<sup class="footnote-marker">144</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 6:20.</i> and Moses our teacher erected twelve pillars.<sup class="footnote-marker">145</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 24:4.</i> How then was it possible that they should be permissive in matters of Torah which Abraham their ancestor had prohibited on himself, and for which G-d appointed him reward, when he [Abraham] was wont <i>to command his children and his household after him</i><sup class="footnote-marker">146</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 18:19.</i> to walk in His ways? In the case of Jacob the Sages taught that he observed the Sabbath and established borders for Sabbath distances.<sup class="footnote-marker">147</sup><i class="footnote">Bereshith Rabbah 79:7.</i> In this matter of the Sabbath it is possible though that Jacob observed it because it is equal in importance to the entire Torah since it testifies to the act of Creation.<br>Perhaps then we should say that <i>My charge</i> refers to the Second Degree of marriages which were forbidden to the Sons of Noah;<sup class="footnote-marker">148</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Seder Bereshith</i>, Note 222, and <i>Seder Vayishlach</i>, Note 148.</i> <i>My commandments</i> applies to robbery and murder; <i>My statutes</i> refers to the laws against eating a limb torn off from a live animal, as well as breeding mixed kinds of cattle or grafting together different species of trees; and <i>My laws</i> refer to civil statutes and the prohibitions against idol worship. The Sons of Noah were commanded concerning all of these matters, and Abraham observed and fulfilled the Will of his Creator, observing even the details and the strictures of their commandments, even as the Sages mentioned: “The tractate of idolatry of our father Abraham contained four hundred chapters.”<sup class="footnote-marker">149</sup><i class="footnote">Abodah Zarah 14b.</i> They further expounded [on the verse referring to Isaac, which says], <i>And he found in that year a hundredfold</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">150</sup><i class="footnote">Further, Verse 12.</i> that he measured the produce for the purpose of tithing,<sup class="footnote-marker">151</sup><i class="footnote">Bereshith Rabbah 64:6.</i> since the patriarchs were <i>the generous ones of the peoples</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">152</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 47:10.</i> giving tithes to the poor or the priests of G-d, such as Shem and Eber and their disciples, just as it is said, <i>And he was a priest of the most high G-d</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">153</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 14:18. Reference is to Melchizedek, whom tradition identifies as Shem, the son of Noah. See Ramban, <i>ibid.</i></i><br>Now it appears to me from a study of the opinions of our Rabbis that Abraham our father learned the entire Torah by <i>Ruach Hakodesh</i><sup class="footnote-marker">154</sup><i class="footnote">See Note 90.</i> and occupied himself with its study and the reason for its commandments and its secrets, and he observed it in its entirety as “one who is not commanded but nevertheless observes it.”<sup class="footnote-marker">155</sup><i class="footnote">The concept of “one who is not commanded but observes” is found in the Talmud (Kiddushin 31 a). His reward is less than that of “one who is commanded and observes.” (<i>Ibid.</i>) The reason for it, as explained in Tosafoth, is that he who is commanded to do a certain <i>mitzvah</i> (commandment) is under tension lest he might not properly fulfill it, while he who is not commanded therein has no responsibility in the matter and may leave it at his will. Consequently, his reward is less.</i> Furthermore, his observance of the Torah applied only in the Land of Israel, whereas Jacob married two sisters only when outside the Land,<sup class="footnote-marker">156</sup><i class="footnote">See Leviticus 18:25 where Ramban extends the explanation further by saying that the reason Rachel died as they entered the Land of Israel (35:16-19) was that she was the sister whom Jacob married last.</i> and similarly with Amram who married his aunt. For the Commandments are <i>the ordinance of the G-d of the land</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">157</sup><i class="footnote">II Kings 17:26.</i> even though we have been charged with personal duties in all places. Our Rabbis have already alluded to this secret, and I will yet call your attention to it with the help of G-d.<sup class="footnote-marker">158</sup><i class="footnote">See Ramban on Leviticus 18:25.</i> And the matter of the erection of the pillar [by Jacob and Moses referred to above] was a commandment that was innovated at a certain time, as the Sages expounded from the verse, “<i>Neither shalt thou set up a pillar which the Eternal thy G-d hateth</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">159</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 16:22.</i> He hated it although it was pleasing to Him in the days of the ancestors.”<sup class="footnote-marker">160</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Sifre. The reason for the change being that the Canaanites afterward had made it an ordinance of idol worship.</i> And with respect to Joseph concerning whom the Sages expounded that he observed the Sabbath even in Egypt,<sup class="footnote-marker">161</sup><i class="footnote">Bereshith Rabbah 92:4.</i> it was because it is equal in importance to all the commandments, constituting, as it does, a testimony to <i>Creatio ex nihilo</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">162</sup><i class="footnote">In Hebrew, <i>chiddush</i> (new), thus implying that G-d created a new world out of an absolute void.</i> Therefore Joseph would do so in order to teach his children faith in the Creation of the world, to remove from their hearts the false doctrine of idolatry and the opinion of the Egyptians. This then is the intent [of the Sages when speaking of the patriarchs and their children observing the Torah].<br>In accordance with the literal meaning of Scripture, you may say that <i>My charge</i> means faith in the Deity, implying that Abraham believed in the unique Divine Name and kept vigilant guard over it in his heart, differing thereby with the worshippers of idols, and calling by the name of the Eternal to bring many to His worship. <i>My commandments</i> refers to all that G-d commanded Abraham: <i>Go out of thy land</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">163</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 12:1.</i> the bringing of his son as a burnt-offering, and the expulsion of the maid-servant and her son.<sup class="footnote-marker">164</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 21:12.</i> <i>My statutes</i> refers to walking in the paths of G-d by being gracious and merciful, doing righteousness and judgment,<sup class="footnote-marker">165</sup><i class="footnote">See Maimonides, “The Commandments,” Vol. I, pp. 11-12 Soncino edit. Positive Commandment 8.</i> and commanding his children and his household concerning them.<sup class="footnote-marker">166</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 18:19.</i> <i>And My Laws</i> refers to the circumcision of Abraham himself and his sons and his servants, as well as all Commandments of the Sons of Noah<sup class="footnote-marker">148</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Seder Bereshith</i>, Note 222, and <i>Seder Vayishlach</i>, Note 148.</i> which constitute their Law.

Verse 6



Verse 7

AND HE SAID: SHE IS MY SISTER. They did not ask concerning the children for he would say, “They are my children from another woman.”

Verse 8



Verse 9



Verse 10



Verse 11



Verse 12



Verse 13



Verse 14

AND HE HAD POSSESSIONS OF FLOCKS, AND POSSESSIONS OF HERDS, AND A GREAT HOUSEHOLD, meaning she-asses and camels, he-asses, and men-servants and handmaids. Now Scripture mentions these but not silver and gold, as it says concerning Abraham,<sup class="footnote-marker">167</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 13:2.</i> because the wealth which he amassed in the land of the Philistines consisted of flocks and a great household.<sup class="footnote-marker">168</sup><i class="footnote">Since these possessions which Isaac accumulated in the land of the Philistines were visible to all, the Philistines became jealous of him. Ramban thus explains the beginning and end of this verse as cause and effect.</i> <i>And the Philistines were jealous of him</i> in this matter. This is the meaning of that which Abimelech says to Isaac, <i>For thou art become much mightier than we</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">169</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 16 here.</i> The king said to him, “I, too, who am the king do not have in my home such flocks and domestics as you, and it is a disgrace to us that your household is greater than that of the king.”

Verse 15



Verse 16



Verse 17

IN THE VALLEY OF GERAR, far away from the city. <i>And</i> [Isaac] <i>digged again the wells of water, which they had digged in the days of Abraham his father</i>, and which the Philistines had stopped up before Isaac left Gerar, he once again dug. Thus the words of Rashi.<br>It would appear from Rashi’s words, then, that the wells mentioned here [in Verse 18] are the same as those mentioned [above in Verse 15]: <i>For all the wells which his father’s servants had digged in the days of Abraham his father the Philistines had stopped them, and filled them with earth</i>. But this is not so, for how would the Philistines give him permission when they had said, “These wells are a source of danger to us because of invaders.”<sup class="footnote-marker">170</sup><i class="footnote">Quoted in Rashi, Verse 15 here.</i> Rather, the wells [mentioned in Verse 18] are different ones in another location since <i>the valley of Gerar</i> is the name of a place, or perhaps the valley extended from Gerar to another land, and when the Philistines, namely, the lords of Gerar — the principality of the king — became jealous of Isaac, they stopped the wells which were his by inheritance from his father in the boundary of the city of Gerar. The king then sent him away from his throne-city, and he went to another city. Possibly, this new place was not part of his kingdom even though it was in the land of the Philistines. There were other wells there which Abraham had dug when he lived there for many days<sup class="footnote-marker">171</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 21:34.</i> but which the Philistines stopped upon his death since Isaac did not dwell there. They did not do this out of hatred. But in the days of Abraham, [even after he had moved from there], they did not want to stop them out of respect to him, saying, “Perhaps he will return to dwell there.” This was why Isaac returned and dug them in the valley. But the herdsmen of the valley quarrelled with him <i>saying, The water is ours</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">172</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 20 here.</i> meaning, “The well is in the valley, and the waters ooze forth from that valley while those in the valley are diminished. Hence they are ours.” It is for this reason that Scripture mentions, <i>And they found there a well of living water</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">173</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 19 here.</i> stating that it was a source gushing forth living water which did not come from the valley as those who quarrelled with Isaac had previously claimed.

Verse 18



Verse 19



Verse 20

AND HE CALLED THE NAME OF THE WELL ESEK. Scripture gives a lengthy account of the matter of the wells when in the literal interpretation of the story there would seem to be no benefit nor any great honor to Isaac in that he and his father did the identical thing.<sup class="footnote-marker">174</sup><i class="footnote">Both Isaac and Abraham dug wells in the land of the Philistines. They did not quarrel with Abraham, but they did quarrel with Isaac. Thus, in the literal meaning of the story, there “is no great honor to Isaac.”</i> However, there is a hidden matter involved here since Scripture’s purpose is to make known a future matter. <i>A well of living water</i> alludes to the House of G-d which the children of Isaac will build. This is why Scripture mentions <i>a well of living waters</i>, even as it says, <i>A fountain of living waters, the Eternal</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">175</sup><i class="footnote">Jeremiah 17:13. From the context of Ramban’s language it would appear that he interprets the verse as if it said, <i>A fountain of living waters</i>, which is the house of <i>the Eternal</i>.</i> He called the first well <i>Esek</i> (Contention), which is an allusion to the First House,<sup class="footnote-marker">176</sup><i class="footnote">The First Sanctuary, which was built by Solomon and destroyed by the Babylonians.</i> concerning which the nations contended with us and instigated quarrels and wars with us until they destroyed it. The second well he called <i>Sitnah</i> (Enmity),<sup class="footnote-marker">177</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 21 here.</i> a name harsher than the first. This alludes to the Second House,<sup class="footnote-marker">178</sup><i class="footnote">The Second Sanctuary, which was built by the Jews who returned from the Babylonian Captivity and which was destroyed by the Romans.</i> which has indeed been referred to by this very name, <i>in the beginning of his reign, they wrote ‘sitnah’</i><sup class="footnote-marker">179</sup><i class="footnote">Hatred, accusation. Thus the same word <i>sitnah</i> appears in connection with the Second Sanctuary.</i> <i>against the inhabitants of Judah and Jerusalem</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">180</sup><i class="footnote">Ezra 4:6.</i> And during its entire existence they<sup class="footnote-marker">181</sup><i class="footnote">Our historic enemies during the period of the Second Temple, signified in the chapter here by the Philistines.</i> were a source of enmity unto us until they destroyed it and drove us from it into bitter exile. The third well he called <i>Rechovoth</i> (Spacious). This is a reference to the Future House, which will be speedily built in our days, and it will be done without quarrel and feud, and G-d will enlarge our borders, even as it says, <i>And if the Eternal thy G-d enlarge thy border, as He hath sworn</i>, etc.,<sup class="footnote-marker">182</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 19:8.</i> which refers to the future. And concerning the Third House of the future it is written, <i>Broader</i><sup class="footnote-marker">183</sup><i class="footnote">In Hebrew <i>verachavah</i>, from the same root as the name of the third well, <i>Rechovoth</i>. The connection between the third well and the Third Temple of the future, concerning which Ezekiel prophesied, is thus established.</i> <i>and winding about higher and higher</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">184</sup><i class="footnote">Ezekiel 41:7.</i> [The concluding statement in the present narrative, concerning the naming of the third well], <i>And we shall be fruitful in the land</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">185</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 22 here.</i> signifies that all peoples will come to worship G-d <i>with one consent</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">186</sup><i class="footnote">Zephaniah 3:9.</i>

Verse 21



Verse 22



Verse 23



Verse 24

FEAR NOT, FOR I AM WITH THEE. Since Abimelech drove him away because of the Philistines’ jealousy of him, and since the herdsmen of Gerar quarrelled with him, Isaac feared lest they gather against him and smite him and his family. Therefore the Holy One, blessed be He, assured him that he should not fear them, and He blessed him. Then He prompted them so that the king went to Isaac with greater honor than that which he did to his father since he came with Phichol, the chief of his host, and also brought with him many of his friends.

Verse 25



Verse 26



Verse 27



Verse 28



Verse 29

IF THOU WILT DO US HURT, AS WE HAVE NOT TOUCHED THEE. The king is saying: “If you will do us hurt [and we could do nothing against you], just as we have not touched you because <i>thou art now the blessed of the Eternal</i> and we do not have it in our power to harm you, the time will yet change on account of the violence you will do against us and you will need to return to our land. Then we will requite you accordingly.”<br>The meaning of the phrase, <i>We have not touched thee</i>, is: “We did not persuade our hearts concerning your wife, causing her to be touched by one of them.” This is similar in expression to the verse, <i>He that toucheth this man or his wife</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">187</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 11 here.</i><br>“<i>We have done thee nothing but good</i>, guarding whatever you had, by our commanding the people to beware of you. <i>And we have sent thee away in peace</i> for even when we were jealous of you we took nothing of all the wealth you amassed with us, and we sent you away in peace with all you had.” The reason for their being fearful of him could hardly have been the apprehension of the king of the Philistines lest Isaac come to war against him. Instead, it was because Abraham had promised them a covenant, “to him, to his son, and his son’s son,”<sup class="footnote-marker">188</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 21:23.</i> and now they thought, “Since we annulled our covenant with Isaac and sent him away from us, he too will annul his covenant with us, and his children will drive our children from the land.” This was why they made a new covenant with him, excusing themselves by telling him that they did not annul the first covenant, since they have done him nothing but good. And this is the meaning of their saying, <i>Let there now be an oath between us:</i><sup class="footnote-marker">189</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 28 here.</i> “We will now come with you in oath to express a ban upon whoever will transgress the covenant.” This is similar in meaning to the verse, <i>That thou shouldst enter into the covenant of the Lord thy G-d, and into His oath</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">190</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 29:11.</i><br>It is possible that Abraham was very great and mighty in power, having in his household three hundred men<sup class="footnote-marker">191</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 14:14.</i> that drew sword, and also many confederates; <i>and he also that is valiant, whose heart is as the heart of a lion</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">192</sup><i class="footnote">II Samuel 17:10. The verse refers to David, but Ramban uses it also in connection with Abraham, since as pointed out he was also mighty in battle.</i> and he chased after four powerful kings and subdued them.<sup class="footnote-marker">193</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 14:14-15.</i> When they saw Abraham’s success which clearly was from G-d, the king of the Philistines was then fearful of him lest he conquer his kingdom, since this would be easier than the war against the four kings. Perhaps the king of the Philistines had also heard the matter of G-d having given the land to Abraham. Hence he made a covenant with him, making him swear <i>that thou wilt not deal falsely with me, nor with my son, nor with my son’s son</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">188</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 21:23.</i> it being considered an act of falsehood if Abraham were to rebel against the king, and considering it possible that Abraham might live until his grandson will rule, [he also mentioned <i>my sons’s son</i>]. And as the fathers are, so are the sons. Isaac was as great as his father, and the king therefore feared lest Isaac war against him because he had driven him from his land.

Verse 30



Verse 31



Verse 32

AND ISAAC’s SERVANTS CAME AND TOLD HIM CONCERNING THE WELL WHICH THEY HAD DIGGED. This is the same well mentioned above in the verse, <i>And there Isaac’s servants digged a well</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">194</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 25 here.</i> They had begun to dig it, and Abimelech came to him during that period, and on the day of the making of the covenant, when Abimelech and his retinue had left, Isaac’s servants brought him the tidings that they had found water.<br>It appears feasible to me that this is the same well which Abraham dug, in connection with which he gave Abimelech seven lambs as a witness [to his ownership of the well].<sup class="footnote-marker">195</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 21:30.</i> The Philistines, however, stopped it together with the other wells, whereupon Isaac dug it again and called it by the same name which his father had called it. It is for this reason that the name of the city is Beer-sheba: on account of the well (<i>be’er</i>) which both the father and the son called by that name <i>because there they swore both of them</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">196</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 31. The verse there refers to Abraham and Abimelech. Ramban uses it here only as an expression to indicate that both Abraham and Isaac called the same well by the same name and both had occasion to swear over it. The name of the city “Beer-sheba” thus derives its historical significance from both the first patriarch and his son.</i><br>This well of theirs alludes to the Tabernacle at Shiloh, which the Philistines stopped when the Ark of G-d was taken captive by them.<sup class="footnote-marker">197</sup><i class="footnote">I Samuel 4:11.</i> And they redug it, indicating that the Philistines indeed returned the Ark together with the honorary gift to G-d.<sup class="footnote-marker">198</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 6:11.</i>

Chapter 27



Verse 1



Verse 2



Verse 3



Verse 4

THAT MY SOUL MAY BLESS THEE. It was Isaac’s intent to bless Esau that he merit the blessing of Abraham to inherit the land and to become the one with whom G-d would make the covenant since he was the firstborn.<br>It would appear that Rebekah never told Isaac of the prophecy which G-d had related to her, i.e., <i>And the elder shall serve the younger</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">199</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 25:23.</i> else how would Isaac <i>transgress the commandment of the Eternal, seeing that it shall not prosper</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">200</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 14:41.</i> Now at first she did not tell it to him due to ethical modesty, for the verse, <i>And she went to inquire of the Eternal</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">201</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 25:22.</i> suggests that she went without Isaac’s permission.<sup class="footnote-marker">202</sup><i class="footnote">Hence due to ethical modesty she did not tell him of the prophecy for it would indicate a breach of wifely modesty for her to have gone without permission.</i> [Perhaps she did not tell him because] she said, “I need not relate a prophecy to a prophet for Isaac is greater than the one who told it to me.”<sup class="footnote-marker">203</sup><i class="footnote">This is a reference to the tradition mentioned by Rashi (25:23), which says that the prophecy was told to Shem the son of Noah and he told it to Rebekah. Therefore Rebekah said: “There is no reason for me to tell Isaac since he is greater in prophecy than the one who told it to me.”</i> And now she did not want to tell him, “So was it said to me in the name of G-d before I gave birth,” for she reasoned that because of his love for Esau he will not bless Jacob, but he will leave everything in the hands of Heaven. And she further knew that by this arrangement of hers, Jacob will be blessed from Isaac’s mouth by an undivided heart and a willing mind. Perhaps these are causes induced by G-d so that Jacob would be blessed, and Esau as well with the blessing of the sword, <i>And by Him</i> alone <i>actions are weighed</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">204</sup><i class="footnote">I Samuel 2:3.</i>

Verse 5



Verse 6



Verse 7

AND I WILL BLESS THEE BEFORE THE ETERNAL BEFORE MY DEATH. In this entire section, the expression, <i>before the Eternal</i>, is not mentioned except in this place. This is because his mother said to Jacob, “The blessing will be <i>before the Eternal</i> with the <i>Ruach Hakodesh</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">205</sup><i class="footnote">See above, Note 90.</i> and if Esau your brother be blessed with it, it will remain with his children forever, and you will have no standing before him.”

Verse 8



Verse 9



Verse 10



Verse 11



Verse 12

PERHAPS MY FATHER WILL FEEL ME. The reason that Isaac will feel him is not for the purpose of recognition. Instead, Jacob said, “Perhaps he will bring me near him to kiss me or to put his hand on my face in the manner of a father demonstrating affection for his son, and in feeling me he will discover that I am smooth.”<br>Now I wonder why Jacob was not afraid of vocal recognition for all people are recognizable by their voice as our Rabbis have said, “How is a blind man permitted to live with his wife? And how are people permitted to live with their wives at nighttime? Only by vocal recognition.”<sup class="footnote-marker">206</sup><i class="footnote">Chullin 96a.</i> Now if ordinary people have such power of recognition, what of Isaac, who was wise and expert in distinguishing between his sons?<sup class="footnote-marker">207</sup><i class="footnote">As Scripture testifies (25:28), his love was centered on one.</i> He should truly have the power of recognition by voice. Perhaps the brothers had similar voices, and therefore the Sages said that the verse, <i>The voice is the voice of Jacob</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">208</sup><i class="footnote">Further, Verse 22.</i> refers not to Jacob’s voice but to his words, i.e., that he speaks gentle language and mentions the Name of Heaven.<sup class="footnote-marker">209</sup><i class="footnote">Bereshith Rabbah 65:16. Due to the fact that the voices of the brothers were alike, it was necessary for the Sages to interpret the verse, <i>The voice is the voice of Jacob</i>, as referring to the kind of language Jacob used.</i> It may be that he altered his voice in order to speak as his brother did, for there are people who know how to do this.

Verse 13



Verse 14



Verse 15

ESAU HER ELDER SON, JACOB HER YOUNGER SON. The reason why Scripture mentions this is to accentuate the unusual action of the righteous one,<sup class="footnote-marker">210</sup><i class="footnote">Rebekah.</i> for parents customarily give recognition to the firstborn in blessing, honor, and gift,<sup class="footnote-marker">211</sup><i class="footnote">See Ramban above, 25:34.</i> but she, knowing of the righteousness of the younger and the wickedness of the elder, went to all this trouble to transfer the blessing and the honor from the elder to the younger. Similarly, it says further on, <i>And the words of Esau her elder son were told to Rebekah, and she sent and called Jacob her younger son</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">212</sup><i class="footnote">Further, Verse 42.</i>

Verse 16



Verse 17



Verse 18



Verse 19



Verse 20



Verse 21

COME NEAR, I PRAY THEE, THAT I MAY FEEL THEE. Rashi comments: “Isaac said to himself, ‘It is not Esau’s way to have the Name of Heaven so readily in his mouth.’” This interpretation is found in Bereshith Rabbah.<sup class="footnote-marker">209</sup><i class="footnote">Bereshith Rabbah 65:16. Due to the fact that the voices of the brothers were alike, it was necessary for the Sages to interpret the verse, <i>The voice is the voice of Jacob</i>, as referring to the kind of language Jacob used.</i><br>But I wonder about this for Esau was not wicked in his father’s eyes!<sup class="footnote-marker">213</sup><i class="footnote">This being so, how could the mention of G-d be a distinguishing mark for Jacob?</i> Perhaps Isaac thought that since Esau is a man of the field and his heart is set on the hunt, he is not wont to mention the Name of Heaven for fear that he might mention it in some unclean place and without proper concentration. In the eyes of his father, this was considered a manifestation of his fear of Heaven. In line with the simple meaning of Scripture, this was because of vocal recognition.<sup class="footnote-marker">214</sup><i class="footnote">Since the voice instilled doubt as to his identity, Isaac desired to feel him.</i>

Verse 22



Verse 23



Verse 24



Verse 25



Verse 26



Verse 27



Verse 28

OF THE DEW OF HEAVEN. The blessing is not that G-d give him of the dew of heaven for the dew descends in all places. Now had he said that G-d give him an abundance of dew, or that it come in its season, even as it says, <i>Then I will give your rains in their season</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">215</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 26:4.</i> that would have constituted a blessing. Instead, its meaning is as follows: Since above he mentioned G-d’s blessing, <i>As the odor of a field which the Eternal hath blessed</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">216</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 27 here.</i> meaning “which G-d had blessed for my son”<sup class="footnote-marker">217</sup><i class="footnote">Ramban interprets the phrase, <i>which the Eternal hath blessed</i>, as referring back to the word <i>b’ni</i> (my son), thus making it “the field which G-d had blessed for my son.” Isaac thus continues his blessing by saying, “Just as He has blessed the field for you, my son, may He also give you another blessing, namely, of the dew of the heavens.”</i> — that is, since G-d blessed him in the field by giving him success there in his hunt and by guarding him from death or any mishap — he now says, <i>So G-d give thee</i>, [as an additional blessing], <i>of the dew of heaven, and of the fat places of the earth</i>. It is thus a blessing of addition and abundance. It may be that the expression, <i>And plenty (‘verov’) of corn and wine</i>, is written in the Torah with an extra <i>vav</i>, [which should not affect the meaning], with the sense of the verse being: “So G-d give thee of the dew of heaven and of the places of the earth, i.e., plenty of corn and wine.”<br>In my opinion the correct interpretation is that G-d’s gift is steady and there is never any interruption in it. Therefore he says, “<i>So G-d give thee</i> for the extent of your days upon your land <i>of the dew of heaven</i>, and give thee <i>of the fat places of the earth</i>,” meaning the fattest of all lands, even as it is written, <i>The beauty of all lands</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">218</sup><i class="footnote">Ezekiel 20:6.</i><br>Now Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra says that the prefix <i>mem</i> in the word <i>mital</i>, (of the dew) applies to itself and yet to another word, [namely, <i>mishmanei</i> (the fat places of the earth), which is then to be understood as] <i>umimishmanei ha’aretz</i> and from the fat places of the earth.<sup class="footnote-marker">219</sup><i class="footnote">According to Ibn Ezra, reference is thus to the fruits from the fat places of the earth.</i><br>To Esau, on the other hand, he gave a blessing which mentions neither through a gift of G-d nor with abundance. Rather he said, “For you too I have reserved a blessing after him: of the fat places of the earth and of the dew of heaven shall your dwelling be.”<sup class="footnote-marker">220</sup><i class="footnote">Based on Verse 39 here.</i> That is “as long as you will dwell there,” thereby alluding that he will ultimately be destroyed and lost, for only as long as he will live will his lot be good.

Verse 29

CURSED BE EVERY ONE THAT CURSETH THEE, AND BLESSED BE EVERY ONE THAT BLESSETH THEE. But in the case of Balaam it says, <i>Blessed be every one that blesseth thee, and cursed be every one that curseth thee</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">221</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 24:9. The question thus arises: Why did Isaac mention first the curse and then the blessing while Balaam did the opposite?</i> [The reason for this change in order is that] the righteous begin with affliction and ultimately attain tranquility, so that those who curse them precede those who bless them.<sup class="footnote-marker">222</sup><i class="footnote">Therefore, Isaac, himself a righteous man, speaks first of those who afflict the righteous, and then mentions those who bless them. The opposite is true in the case of Balaam.</i> But the wicked experience tranquility first and their end is affliction. Hence Balaam mentioned the blessing before the curse. This is Rashi’s language quoting Bereshith Rabbah.<sup class="footnote-marker">223</sup><i class="footnote">Bereshith Rabbah 66:5.</i><br>But if this be so, why did the Holy One, blessed be He, say to Abraham, <i>And I will bless them that bless thee, and curse him that curseth thee?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">224</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 12:3. Now here in the case of the righteous, it still mentions the blessing first!</i> This however is no difficulty since He concludes there, <i>And in thee shall all families of the earth be blessed</i>. Thus there is a blessing at the beginning and at the end. It may be, as we have explained it there, that He speaks in terms of both an individual and many,<sup class="footnote-marker">225</sup><i class="footnote">The blessing is expressed in plural form — <i>And I will bless ‘those’ who bless thee</i> — while the curse is expressed in singular form — <i>and curse ‘him’ that curseth thee</i>.</i> suggesting that Abraham will be universally blessed, and the single person who will curse him will be cursed.<sup class="footnote-marker">226</sup><i class="footnote">Hence He mentions the blessing first as there will be many who will bless Abraham.</i>

Verse 30



Verse 31



Verse 32

WHO ART THOU? When Esau said to him, <i>Let my father arise</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">227</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 31 here.</i> Isaac thought that it was Jacob, i.e., that because Jacob knew that he had eaten of Esau’s venison and blessed Esau, he too prepared savory meats so that he should bless him also. Therefore he asked, <i>Who art thou?</i>, in order to know the truth.<sup class="footnote-marker">228</sup><i class="footnote">If Isaac did not think him to be Jacob, why should he ask, “Who art thou?” He himself had told Esau to make him savory food, and now he came and said, “Let my father arise.” However, since Ramban explains that Isaac thought him to be Jacob, the question is understandable.</i>

Verse 33

AND ISAAC TREMBLED VERY EXCEEDINGLY, AND SAID, WHO THEN IS HE THAT HATH TAKEN VENISON AND BROUGHT IT TO ME, AND I HAVE EATEN OF ALL BEFORE THOU COMEST AND HAVE BLESSED HIM? YEA, AND HE SHALL BE BLESSED. It is not natural for a person who just trembled violently and complained, “Who was it that subtly made me bless him?” to conclude his complaint by immediately saying, <i>Yea, and he shall be blessed</i>! Rather, it would have been proper that he curse him! Moreover, Esau would then complain to his father, saying, “But why do you bless him now, my father?” And how would Esau believe his father that it was originally done through subtlety<sup class="footnote-marker">229</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 35 here.</i> when he saw that he was now blessing him willingly!<br>The correct interpretation appears to me to be that it is in the present tense.<sup class="footnote-marker">230</sup><i class="footnote">The word <i>yihyeh</i>, generally understood as a future tense — <i>and he shall be blessed</i> — is here to be understood as a present tense, as explained below in the text.</i> Isaac is saying, “<i>Who then is he that hath hunted venison</i>, who could have beguiled me so that I should bless him and that he should remain blessed under all circumstances for I knew that he is a blessed one?” Or it may be that the expression, <i>Yea, and he shall be blessed</i>, means “against my will, since it is impossible for me to transfer the blessing from him.” From the moment he blessed him, Isaac knew by <i>Ruach Hakodesh</i><sup class="footnote-marker">231</sup><i class="footnote">See above, Note 90.</i> that his blessings indeed rested upon Jacob. This then is the reason for his violent trembling for he knew that his beloved son Esau had lost his blessing forever. This also is the explanation for his saying, <i>Thy brother came with subtlety</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">229</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 35 here.</i> meaning that after he said, <i>Who then is he</i> etc. he realized that Jacob had been the one who came before him to receive the blessing for it would have been impossible for the blessing to rest on any but his offspring, [and, as mentioned above, Isaac knew by <i>Ruach Hakodesh</i> that the blessing had taken effect. Hence he was sure that it was Jacob who had come before him.]

Verse 34



Verse 35



Verse 36



Verse 37

AND ALL HIS BRETHREN HAVE I GIVEN HIM AS SERVANTS. This is not the blessing, <i>Be lord over thy brethren</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">232</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 29 here.</i> for Isaac had already said, <i>Behold, I have made him thy lord</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">233</sup><i class="footnote">In the beginning of the present verse.</i> However, it is possible that Jacob be the lord and they not be his servants, just as the verse says, <i>For Judah ‘gavar’ above his brethren</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">234</sup><i class="footnote">I Chronicles 5:2. There the word <i>gavar</i> does not indicate a master and servant relationship. Similarly, the word <i>gvir</i> (lord) does not indicate such a relationship.</i> But the source for his saying, <i>I have given to him as servants</i>, comes from his expression, <i>And let thy mother’s sons bow down to thee</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">232</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 29 here.</i> for this refers to the bowing of the servant to his masters, just as he says, <i>Let people serve thee</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">232</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 29 here.</i> and then repeats, <i>And nations bow down to thee</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">232</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 29 here.</i><br>The meaning of the expression, <i>And all his brothers</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">235</sup><i class="footnote">Jacob had only one brother. Why then does Isaac use the plural form, “his brothers?”</i> is the same as that of <i>thy brothers</i> and <i>thy mother’s sons</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">232</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 29 here.</i> These he mentions in the plural in order to allude to all of Esau’s offspring. And Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra says that it refers to the children of Abraham’s concubines.<sup class="footnote-marker">236</sup><i class="footnote">See above, 25:6.</i>

Verse 38



Verse 39

BEHOLD (‘HINEI’), OF THE FAT PLACES OF THE EARTH SHALL BE THY DWELLING. The intent of the word <i>hinei</i> (behold) is: “Now I could give you of the fat places of the earth and of the dew of heaven, for of these there is sufficient [abundance] for both of you to have of the fat places of the earth and of the dew of heaven, but in the matter of lordship, that will be his, and you shall serve him.” Isaac also did not give him <i>plenty of corn and wine</i> as he gave to his brother since he wanted to honor the one who had been blessed first above him. Later he said to Jacob, <i>And G-d Almighty give thee the blessing of Abraham… that thou mayest inherit the land of thy sojournings</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">237</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 28:4.</i> meaning that he should have the plentifulness of the corn and wine in the land of Canaan, which was Abraham’s gift, while Esau would have the dew and the fat places of the earth in another land.

Verse 40

AND ON THY SWORD (‘VE’AL CHARBECHA’) YOU SHALL LIVE. The meaning of <i>ve’al charbecha</i> is as if it were written, <i>becharbecha</i> (<i>by</i> thy sword). A similar case is the verse, <i>For man does not live ‘al halechem’ (on bread) alone</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">238</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 8:3.</i> which means <i>belechem</i> (by bread). Now the blessing is not that he live on the booty he takes from his enemies by the sword, for he has already given him of the fat places of the earth and of the dew of heaven by which he shall live. Instead, the purport of the blessing is that he survive his battles and be victorious, and not fall by the sword of an enemy. It is for this reason that immediately following this he said, <i>And thou shall serve thy brother</i>, meaning, “but you will not prevail over him. Instead, he will prevail over you.”
AND IT SHALL COME TO PASS WHEN THOU SHALL BREAK LOOSE in thy suffering on account of Jacob’s transgression,<sup class="footnote-marker">239</sup><i class="footnote">Specifically, the transgression of the command, <i>Contend not with them</i>, as is explained further on.</i> THEN THOU SHALT SHAKE HIS YOKE FROM OFF THY NECK. This is an indication to Israel that they should not contend with the children of Esau too much in order to do them evil. This is what Scripture commanded: <i>Take ye good heed, contend not with them</i>, etc.<sup class="footnote-marker">240</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 2:4-5. referring to the children of Esau in the land of Se’ir.</i> And so did our Rabbis<sup class="footnote-marker">241</sup><i class="footnote">Yerushalmi Rosh Hashanah, I, 1.</i> say: “<i>For Joab and all Israel remained there six months, until he had cut off every male in Edom</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">242</sup><i class="footnote">I Kings 11:16.</i> The Holy One, blessed be He, said to David, ‘I said, <i>Contend not with them</i>, and you did contend. By your life, these six months will not accrue to you and your reign.’ We know this was fulfilled since it is written, <i>And the days that David reigned over Israel were forty years</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">243</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 2:11.</i> but in truth he reigned six more months, as it is written, <i>In Hebron he reigned over Judah seven years and six months</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">244</sup><i class="footnote">II Samuel 5:5. <i>And in Jerusalem he reigned thirty and three years</i> for a total of forty years and six months. Yet he is credited with only forty years.</i> The Rabbis also said,<sup class="footnote-marker">245</sup><i class="footnote">Devarim Rabbah 1:15.</i> “The Holy One, blessed be He, said to David, ‘Thy hands are sharp and pointed, and I seek to rule my world with them, etc’”<sup class="footnote-marker">246</sup><i class="footnote">The Midrash concludes: “Moses your teacher has already desired to confront them, and I told him, ‘It is sufficient for you.’” (Deuteronomy 2:3).</i>

Verse 41

AND ESAU SAID IN HIS HEART. Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra said, “It is possible that he revealed his secret to one of his friends.”<sup class="footnote-marker">247</sup><i class="footnote">If not, how did Rebekah become aware of the fact that Esau was planning to kill Jacob? (Verse 42 here).</i><br>But this is not necessarily so for any decision which a person reaches after deliberation is referred to in Hebrew as “speaking with the heart,” even when it also includes speech with the lips. A similar case is found in the verse, <i>And with a double heart do they speak</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">248</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 12:3.</i> for the will is synonymous with the heart. <i>And all Israel were of one heart to make David king</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">249</sup><i class="footnote">I Chronicles 12:39.</i> meaning that they had all arrived at the same decision and were talking of it. Similarly, <i>And Jeroboam said in his heart</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">250</sup><i class="footnote">I Kings 12:26. Further on it says, <i>And the king took counsel</i>, (Verse 28). Here also there was speech which Scripture had referred to as being said in his heart.</i> Similarly did Eliezer say, <i>And before I had finished speaking in my heart</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">251</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 24:25.</i> whereas the prayer there was with his lips, as Scripture states, <i>And he said, O Eternal G-d of my lord Abraham</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">252</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 12.</i> However it is possible that the expression, <i>before I had finished speaking in my heart</i>, means “before I had concluded the thought in my mind.”<br>Now here the verse states that when the great hatred of Jacob permeated Esau’s soul because of the blessing, he conceived the idea of murdering his brother, and with this he comforted himself from his depressed state. This explains the verse, <i>And the words of Esau were told to Rebekah</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">253</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 42 here. As Ramban explained, a decision in one’s heart, even though coupled with speech, is still referred to in Hebrew as “the speech of heart.” Therefore, the verse means that Esau decided upon a course of action, and he himself informed his mother of his decision.</i> This is why she said to Jacob, <i>Thy brother Esau comforts himself to slay thee</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">254</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 42 here.</i><br>Now Rashi comments, “She was told, through <i>Ruach Hakodesh</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">231</sup><i class="footnote">See above, Note 90.</i> what Esau was thinking in his heart.” And so it is found in Bereshith Rabbah.<sup class="footnote-marker">255</sup><i class="footnote">Bereshith Rabbah 67:9.</i> If so, Esau’s words and thoughts were only in his heart, just as in the verse, <i>I spoke with my own heart</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">256</sup><i class="footnote">Ecclesiastes 1:16.</i><br>The reason that Esau said, <i>Let the days of mourning for my father be at hand then will I slay my brother</i> is because he would not bring grief to his father during his lifetime. Perhaps it was due to his fear lest his father curse him, and his blessing would then turn into a curse. Rebekah, [who nevertheless advised Jacob to flee], feared that perhaps the elderly one would die suddenly, and Esau would then kill Jacob, or perhaps he might find occasion to kill him even during Isaac’s lifetime.

Verse 42

AND SHE SENT AND CALLED JACOB. The meaning thereof is that Jacob was in another place, not in the tent of his father and mother, since he was hiding from his brother Esau who was complaining about him, and he was ashamed or afraid of him.
HE DOTH COMFORT HIMSELF (‘LECHA’) TO SLAY THEE. “He comforts himself for the loss of the blessings by killing you.” Thus the language of Rashi.<br>But the simple interpretation is that “he comforts himself with you.”<sup class="footnote-marker">257</sup><i class="footnote">According to Rashi, the comfort is for the blessings Esau lost. Thus the verse states that “his comfort for the loss he suffered is to slay thee.” But according to Ramban the comfort is for his own personal sake, and the meaning of the word <i>lecha</i> (to you) is as if it were written <i>becha</i> (with you), and the thought of the verse is that “his comfort with you is to kill you.”</i> Similar cases [of the letter <i>lamed</i> having the meaning of a <i>beth</i>] are found in the verses, <i>Thou hast chosen the son of Jesse</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">258</sup><i class="footnote">I Samuel 20:7. The Hebrew: <i>l’ben Yishai</i> (to the son of Jesse). The verse thus means that “your choice lies with the son of Jesse.”</i> <i>And he took hold of him</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">259</sup><i class="footnote">II Samuel 15:5. The Hebrew <i>vehechezik lo</i> here means <i>vehechezik bo</i>.</i> and many similar cases.<br>Perhaps the interpretation is that “he is comforting himself concerning you,” just as in the verses: <i>And the men of the place asked him of his wife;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">260</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 26:7. The Hebrew word <i>le’ishto</i> in this verse does not mean “to his wife,” but “concerning his wife.”</i> <i>And he fell on his face;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">261</sup><i class="footnote">I Samuel 20:41. The Hebrew word <i>le’apav</i> in this verse does not mean “to his face,” but “on his face.”</i> <i>For the king had so commanded concerning him</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">262</sup><i class="footnote">Esther 3:2. The word <i>lo</i> (to him) here means <i>alav</i> (concerning him).</i> Onkelos, however, translates it as <i>kemin lecha</i>, meaning, “he lies in wait for you.” It would appear from his opinion that the meaning of the Hebrew expression, <i>mithnachem lecha</i>, is that “Esau effects the appearance of having been consoled about the matter of the blessings as if he no longer cares for them, but in truth he lies in wait for you and acts this way so that you should not be on guard.” Now Onkelos translated according to the intent of the verse but not according to the language.

Chapter 28



Verse 1



Verse 2



Verse 3



Verse 4



Verse 5

THE BROTHER OF REBEKAH, JACOB’s AND ESAU’s MOTHER. Because it stated<sup class="footnote-marker">263</sup><i class="footnote">It is obvious that Ramban has in mind the words of Rashi, whose comment upon the expression, <i>Jacob’s and Esau’s mother</i>, was, “I do not know what this intends to tell us.” Ramban then proceeds to offer an explanation.</i> that Isaac commanded Jacob to get a wife from the daughters of Laban, his mother’s brother, Scripture mentions that he was also the brother of Esau’s mother. It would have been proper for Isaac to have commanded Esau likewise, but since he knew that the blessing of Abraham would apply only to Jacob and his seed, he did so only to Jacob. Now Scripture further mentions that Esau heard that his father had commanded Jacob not to take a wife from among the daughters of Canaan<sup class="footnote-marker">264</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 1 here.</i> and that he should go to his mother’s brother Laban. He [Esau] heeded his father’s will that one not take a wife from among the daughters of Canaan, but he did not act properly and take a wife from the daughters of Laban, despite his [Laban’s] being his mother’s brother. Scripture further mentions that he took her<sup class="footnote-marker">265</sup><i class="footnote">Mahalath, the daughter of Ishmael. (Verse 9 here.)</i> <i>besides his former wives</i>, and he did not divorce the evil wives since he followed his heart’s desire more than he followed the will of his father.<br>Vayeitzei

Verse 6



Verse 7



Verse 8



Verse 9



Verse 10



Verse 11



Verse 12

AND BEHOLD A LADDER SET UP ON THE EARTH AND THE TOP OF IT REACHED TO HEAVEN; AND BEHOLD THE ANGELS OF G-D ASCENDING AND DESCENDING ON IT. In a prophetic dream, He showed Jacob that whatever is done on earth is effected by means of the angels, and everything is by decree given to them by the Supreme One. The angels of G-d, <i>whom the Eternal hath sent to walk to and fro through the earth</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">Zechariah 1:10.</i> would not do anything minor or major until they return to present themselves before the Master of the whole earth, saying before Him, “We have traversed the earth,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>ibid.</i>, Verse 11.</i> and behold it dwells in peace, or is steeped in war and blood,” and He commands them to return, to descend to the earth and fulfill His charge. And He further showed him [Jacob] that He, blessed be He, stands above the ladder, and promises Jacob with supreme assurance to inform him that he will not be under the power of the angels, but he will be <i>G-d’s portion</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 32:9.</i> and that He will be with him always, as He said, <i>And, behold, I am with thee, and will keep thee wherever thou goest</i><sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 15 here.</i> for his [Jacob’s] excellence is superior to that of the other righteous ones of whom it is said, <i>For He will give His angels charge over thee, to keep thee in all thy ways</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 91:11.</i><br>And in the opinion of Rabbi Eliezer the Great<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">Pirkei d’Rabbi Eliezer, 35.</i> this vision was akin to the one seen by Abram at the time of the covenant “between the parts”<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 15:9-18.</i> for He also showed Jacob the dominion of the Four Kingdoms,<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">See Ramban above, 14:1 and 15:12. The Four Kingdoms represent the great world powers seen in a vision by Daniel (Chapter 7), who in succession will subject Israel until such time when Israel’s final and complete deliverance will be effected by the Messiah. The power of the fourth kingdom, that of Rome, is still in sway. See Ramban further at the beginning of <i>Seder Vayechi</i>. Jacob, like Abraham, was thus shown the events that will happen to his descendants during all the generations of their exiles.</i> their ascent and descent. This is the meaning of <i>angels of G-d</i> (mentioned here), just as it is said in the visions of Daniel: the prince of the kingdom of Greece,<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">Daniel 10:20.</i> and the prince of the kingdom of Persia.<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 13. Similarly, the angels mentioned in the verse before us are to be understood as the representatives of the various nations.</i> And He promised him that He, exalted be He, will be with him wherever he will go among the nations, and He will guard him and rescue him from them. Thus the Rabbis have said:<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">Pirkei d’Rabbi Eliezer, 35.</i> “The Holy One, blessed be He, showed him the Four Kingdoms, their dominion and their destruction. He showed him the prince of the kingdom of Babylon ascending seventy rungs<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">Symbolic of the seventy years of the Babylonian exile.</i> and then descending the ladder. Then He showed him the prince of the kingdom of Media ascending one hundred and eighty rungs<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">See my Hebrew commentary, (p. 158, n.12), which asserts that the correct reading is: “He showed him the prince of the kingdom of Media going up fifty-two rungs and then descending. And He showed him the prince of the kingdom of Greece going up one hundred-eighty rungs and then descending.” The number of rungs represent the amount of years that these kingdoms held sway over Israel.</i> and then descending. And then He showed him the prince of the kingdom of Edom ascending and not coming down. Jacob then said to the prince of Edom, <i>Yet thou shalt be brought down to the nether-world</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 14:15.</i> The Holy One, blessed be He, said to [the prince of Edom], <i>Though thou make thy nest as high as the eagle</i>, etc.”<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">Obadiah 1:4. <i>And though thou set it among the stars, I will bring thee down from thence, saith the Eternal</i>.</i>

Verse 13



Verse 14



Verse 15



Verse 16



Verse 17

THIS IS NONE OTHER THAN THE HOUSE OF G-D, AND THIS IS THE GATE OF HEAVEN. This refers to the Sanctuary which is the gate through which the prayers and sacrifices ascend to heaven.<br>Rashi comments, Rabbi Elazar the son of Rabbi Yosei the son of Zimra said, ‘This ladder stood in Beer-sheba and its slope<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">“Its slope.” In our text of Rashi: “the middle of its slope.” Ramban will explain later that the reference is to “the end” of the slope, which is the head of the ladder.</i> reached unto the Sanctuary in Jerusalem. Beer-sheba is situated in the southern part of Judah, and Jerusalem is to its north on the boundary between Judah and Benjamin, and Beth-el was in the northern portion of Benjamin’s territory, on the boundary between Benjamin’s territory and that of the children of Joseph. It follows, therefore, that a ladder whose base is in Beer-sheba and whose top is in Beth-el has its slope<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">“Its slope.” In our text of Rashi: “the middle of its slope.” Ramban will explain later that the reference is to “the end” of the slope, which is the head of the ladder.</i> reaching opposite Jerusalem. Now regarding the statement of our Rabbis that the Holy One, blessed be He, said, ‘This righteous man has come to the place where I dwell, [namely, the Sanctuary in Jerusalem, and shall he depart without spending the night?’],<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">Chullin 91b.</i> and with regard to what they also said, ‘Jacob gave the name Beth-el to Jerusalem’<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">Pesachim 88b.</i> this place which he called Beth-el was Luz and not Jerusalem! And whence did they learn to say so, [implying that Luz is identical with Jerusalem]? I therefore say that Mount Moriah [the Temple site in Jerusalem] was forcibly removed from its place and came here to Luz, and this movement of the Temple site is ‘the springing of the earth’ which is mentioned in Tractate Shechitath Chullin.<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">“The slaughtering of unconsecrated beasts.” This tractate is now generally called Chullin (Unconsecrated Beasts). 91b.</i> It means that the site on which the Sanctuary was later to stand came towards Jacob to Beth-el. And this too is what is meant by <i>vayiphga bamakom (and he met the place)</i>:<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 11 here.</i> [as two people meet, who are moving towards each other]. If you should ask, ‘When our father Jacob passed the site of the Sanctuary [on his way from Beer-sheba to Haran] why did He not detain him there?’ The answer is: If it never entered his mind to pray at the place where his fathers had prayed, should Heaven make him stop there? He had journeyed as far as Haran, as we say in the chapter of <i>Gid Hanasheh</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">“The sinew of the hip.” It is the seventh chapter of Tractate Chullin (see Note 18) 91b.</i> and Scripture itself helps us clarify this point by saying, <i>And he went to Haran</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 10 here.</i> When he arrived at Haran he said, ‘Is it possible that I have passed the place where my fathers prayed without praying there myself?’ He decided to return and had returned as far as Beth-el, whereupon the ground of the Temple site sprang for him until Beth-el.”<br>All these are the words of the Rabbi.<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">Rashi. See also Note 139, <i>Seder Bereshith</i>.</i> But I do not agree with them at all for ‘the springing of the earth’ which the Rabbis mention in connection with Jacob is like that which they have said happened to Eliezer, the servant of Abraham, namely, that he reached Haran in one day. As they have said in Tractate Sanhedrin,<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">95a.</i> “The earth sprang for three persons: Eliezer, the servant of Abraham, our father Jacob, and Abishai the son of Zeruiah.”<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">II Samuel 21:17. In coming to the rescue of David, a miracle occurred, and he reached him at once though he was far away from him.</i> And the Rabbis explained: “Eliezer, the servant of Abraham — for it is written, <i>And I came this day unto the fountain</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 24:42.</i> which teaches that on that very day he embarked on his journey. Jacob — for it is written, <i>And he met the place</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 11 here.</i> When he arrived at Haran he said, ‘Is it possible that I have passed the place where my fathers prayed without praying there myself?’ As soon as the thought of returning occurred to him, the earth sprang for him, and immediately <i>he met the place</i>.” Thus the Rabbis explicitly say that as soon as the thought to return occurred to him in Haran, the earth sprang for him and he met the place where his fathers prayed, but not that he returned to Beth-el, nor that Mount Moriah sprang and came there to Beth-el. In Bereshith Rabbah<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">59:15.</i> the Rabbis further equated them both [Eliezer and Jacob] with respect to “the springing of the earth.” Thus they said: “<i>And he arose, and went to Aram-naharaim</i><sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 24:10.</i> — on the very same day. <i>And I came this day unto the fountain</i><sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 24:42.</i> — this day I embarked on the journey, and this day I arrived.” With respect to Jacob the Rabbis interpreted in a similar vein: “<i>And he went to Haran</i><sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 10 here.</i> — the Rabbis say on the very same day.” And furthermore, what reason is there for Mount Moriah to “spring” and come to Beth-el, as Rashi claims, after Jacob had troubled himself to return from Haran to Beth-el, a journey of many days?<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">If such a miracle was to be performed, why did not Mount Moriah spring all the way to Haran?</i> Moreover, Beth-el does not lie on the border of the Land of Israel which faces towards Haran for Haran is a land which lies to the east [of the Land of Israel while Beth-el lies in its western part].<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 12:8.</i> Additionally, the middle part of a ladder is not referred to as its “slope.”<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">Thus Rabbi Elazar who said that “its slope” reached to the Sanctuary did not refer to its middle, as Rashi has it.</i> And, finally, what reason is there for the middle of the ladder to be opposite Beth-el, [where, according to Rashi, the side of the Sanctuary had been transported], when the middle part of an object does not possess significance beyond that of its whole?<br>There is, however, another intent to these Midrashim. The Rabbis have said in Bereshith Rabbah,<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">68:6.</i> “Rabbi Hoshayah said, ‘It has already been stated, <i>And Jacob hearkened to his father and his mother, and was gone to Paddan-aram</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 28:7.</i> What then does Scripture teach by repeating, <i>And Jacob went out from Beer-sheba?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 10 here.</i> Rather, the redundancy teaches us that Jacob said, “When my father desired to leave the Land of Israel, at what location did he seek permission for it? Was it not in Beer-sheba? I, too, shall go to Beer-sheba to seek this permission. If He grants me permission, I shall leave, and if not, I shall not go.” Therefore Scripture found it necessary to state, <i>And Jacob went out from Beer-sheba</i>.’”<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 10 here.</i><br>The intent of this Midrash is that the Rabbis were of the opinion that Jacob was blessed by his father in Hebron, the land of his father’s sojournings, and it was to Hebron that he came when he returned to his father from Paddan-aram, as it is said, <i>And Jacob came unto Isaac his father to Mamre, to Kiriath-arba — the same is Hebron — where Abraham and Isaac sojourned</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 35:27.</i> Now if so, the verse stating, <i>And Jacob went out from Beer-sheba</i><sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 10 here.</i> teaches that when his father commanded him to go to Laban<sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 28:5.</i> he went to Beer-sheba to receive Divine permission, and that is the place wherein he spent the night and saw visions of G-d, and it was there that He gave him permission to exit from the Land of Israel, even as He said, <i>And I will keep thee wherever thou goest and will bring thee back unto this land</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 15 here.</i> And the ladder which he saw, in the opinion of Rabbi Yosei the son of Zimra, he saw with its feet in Beer-sheba, in the very place where he lay, and with the end of its slope which is the top of the ladder reaching to a point opposite the Sanctuary. It was supported by heaven at the gate through which the angels enter and exit. The revered G-d stood over him, and therefore he knew that Beer-sheba was the gate of heaven, suitable for prayer, and the Sanctuary was the house of G-d. And in the morning Jacob continued his journey from Beer-sheba and arrived at Haran on the same day, and this was “the springing of the earth” mentioned with respect to Jacob.<br>This is the opinion of Rabbi Yosei the son of Zimra who said in Bereshith Rabbah,<sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote">69:5.</i> “This ladder stood in Beer-sheba and its slope reached to the Sanctuary, as it is said, <i>And Jacob went out from Beer-sheba;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 11 here.</i> <i>And he was afraid and said, How fearful is this place</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 17 here.</i> And the stone which he erected as a pillar<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 18 here.</i> he did not erect in the place where he slept, for Beer-sheba is not Beth-el and it was in Beth-el that he erected it, and there he went upon his return from Paddan-aram, as it is said, <i>Arise, go up to Beth-el … and make there an altar unto G-d who appeared unto thee</i>, etc.<sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 35:1.</i> But he erected it [after carrying the stone from Beth-el to Jerusalem]<sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote">Thus comments Rabbi David Luria (R’dal) in explanation of Ramban’s words. See my Hebrew commentary, p. 160.</i> opposite the slope, at the place where the head of the ladder stood, which he had called the house of G-d, and this is the city which had previously been called Luz.<sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 19 here.</i><br>Thus in the opinion of Rabbi Yosei the son of Zimra, Luz was Jerusalem which Jacob called Beth-el.<sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 19 here.</i> Possibly this may be so, according to the verses in the book of Joshua.<sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote">The source intended is not clear to me. See my Hebrew commentary, p. 160, for further discussion of this matter.</i> It is certainly true that it is not the Beth-el near Ai<sup class="footnote-marker">42</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 12:8. Whereas the Beth-el referred to here had previously been called Luz.</i> for that Beth-el was originally so named in the days of Abraham<sup class="footnote-marker">42</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 12:8. Whereas the Beth-el referred to here had previously been called Luz.</i> and prior to that.<br>But Rabbi Yehudah the son of Rabbi Shimon differs there<sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote">Bereshith Rabbah 69:8.</i> with Rabbi Yosei the son of Zimra, and he says: “This ladder stood upon the Sanctuary site and its slope reached to Beth-el. What is his reason? <i>And he was afraid, and said</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 17 here.</i> etc. <i>And he called the name of that place Beth-el</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 19 here.</i> Thus in the opinion of Rabbi Yehudah the son of Rabbi Shimon the verse stating, <i>And he lighted upon the place</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 11 here.</i> means Mount Moriah. <i>And he tarried there all night, because the sun was set</i> for him not at its proper time [so that he should spend the night there], for as our Rabbis have stated:<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">Chullin 91b.</i> “[The Holy One, blessed be He, said], ‘This righteous man has come to the place where I dwell. Shall he then depart without staying there over night?’” And so Jacob saw the ladder with its feet standing in that place, and its slope, which is its top, reached to a point which was opposite that particular Beth-el [which was mentioned in connection with Ai during Abraham’s era],<sup class="footnote-marker">42</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 12:8. Whereas the Beth-el referred to here had previously been called Luz.</i> and that was the city of Luz. And Jacob said that the very place where he spent the night was the house of G-d, and the slope of the ladder was the gate of heaven, thus Mount Moriah is excellent for prayer, and Beth-el also is a suitable place for the worship of G-d.
