And he erected the pillar in Beth-el, for in the opinion of all Rabbis he erected it opposite the slope of the ladder.<br>The opinion of Rabbi Yehudah the son of Rabbi Shimon, [i.e., that Jacob slept on Mount Moriah, and he erected the pillar in Beth-el], is in agreement with the Midrash in the <i>Gemara</i> of the chapter concerning <i>Gid Hanasheh</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">“The sinew of the hip.” It is the seventh chapter of Tractate Chullin (see Note 18) 91b.</i> and that of Chapter <i>Cheleck</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote">“Portion,” i.e., in the World to Come. This is the tenth chapter of Tractate Sanhedrin, 95b.</i> which states that Jacob left Beer-sheba and came to Haran, and when he reconsidered and decided to return and pray at Mount Moriah, the place where his fathers had prayed, then the earth “sprang” for him and he lighted immediately upon Mount Moriah. Perhaps it is the Rabbis’ opinion that the earth “sprang” for him both when going from Haran to Mount Moriah and when returning from Mount Moriah to Haran. This would be in agreement with the opinion of the Rabbi who says:<sup class="footnote-marker">45</sup><i class="footnote">Bereshith Rabbah 68:9.</i> “<i>And he went to Haran</i><sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 10 here.</i> — on the same day. <i>And he lighted upon the place</i><sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 11 here.</i> — at once, very suddenly.”<br>I found it more explicitly in Pirkei Rabbi Eliezer Hagadol:<sup class="footnote-marker">46</sup><i class="footnote">Chapter 35.</i> “Jacob was seventy-seven years of age when he left his father’s house,<sup class="footnote-marker">47</sup><i class="footnote">He was sixty-three when he was blessed by his father (Megillah 16 a), and for the following fourteen years he was secluded in the house of Shem and Eber for the purpose of studying Torah. This makes Jacob seventy-seven years old when he left Haran. The Pirkei d’Rabbi Eliezer refers to it as “when he left his father’s house,” but the intent is as explained. (Rabbi David Luria.)</i> and he followed the well that travelled before him from Beer-sheba to Mount Moriah, a two-day journey, and he arrived there at midday, etc. The Holy One, blessed be He, said to him, ‘Jacob, you have bread in your travelling-bag, the well is before you, enabling you to eat and drink and lie down in this place.’ Jacob replied, ‘Master of all worlds, the sun has yet to descend fifty stages, and shall I lie down to sleep in this place?’ Prematurely, the sun then set in the west. Jacob looked and saw that the sun had set in the west, so <i>he tarried there all night, because the sun was set</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 11 here.</i> Jacob took twelve stones from the stones of the altar upon which his father Isaac had lain bound as a sacrifice<sup class="footnote-marker">48</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 22:9.</i> and put them under his head. By the fact that his resting-place contained twelve stones, G-d informed him that twelve tribes were destined to be established from him. But then all twelve stones were transformed into one stone to inform him that all twelve tribes were destined to become one nation in the earth, as it is said, <i>And who is like Thy people, like Israel, a nation one in the earth?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">49</sup><i class="footnote">II Samuel 7:23.</i> In the morning Jacob awoke with great fright, and said, ‘The house of the Holy One, blessed be He, is in this place,’ as it is said, <i>And he was afraid, and said: How fearful is this place!</i><sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 17 here.</i> From here you learn that whosoever prays in Jerusalem is considered as if he prayed before the Throne of Glory, for the gate of heaven is open there to receive the prayer of Israel, as it is said, <i>And this is the gate of heaven</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 17 here.</i> Jacob then wanted to collect the stones [which he had used as a resting-place for his head in order to build an altar], but he found them all to be one stone, and so he set it up as a pillar in that place. Thereupon oil flowed down for him from heaven, and he poured it on top of the stone, as it is said, <i>And he poured oil upon the top of it</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 18 here.</i> What did the Holy One, blessed be He, do? With His right foot He sank the anointed stone unto the depths of the abyss to serve as the key-stone of the earth, just as one inserts a key-stone in an arch. It is for this reason that it is called <i>Even Hashethiyah</i> (The Foundation Stone),<sup class="footnote-marker">50</sup><i class="footnote">On this stone, the Ark of G-d, which contained the two Tablets of the Law, rested in the Holy of Holies in the Sanctuary in Jerusalem. (Yoma 53b.)</i> for there is the center of the earth, and from there the earth unfolded, and upon it stands the Temple of G-d, as it is said, <i>And this stone, which I have set up for a pillar, shall be G-d’s house</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 22 here. The use of the present tense in the Pirkei d’Rabbi Eliezer — “and upon it <i>stands</i> the Temple of G-d” — may either be a reference to the remains of the ancient Sanctuary and its environs, which were still visible in the days when the Pirkei d’Rabbi Eliezer was composed, or it may preferably indicate that although the Temple is now in ruins the place thereof is still deemed sacred as in the days when the House of G-d was firmly established on the sacred mountain.</i> From there he [Jacob] went on his journey, and in the twinkling of an eye he arrived in Haran.” Thus far [extends the quotation from the Pirkei Rabbi Eliezer Hagadol].<br>Thus, all Midrashim — despite some minor differences among them — acknowledge that “the springing of the earth” occurred to Jacob through which he travelled a journey of many days in the twinkling of an eye. It is possible that all Midrashim concede to one another, and that on all these journeys of his — when going from Beer-sheba to Haran, when he desired to return to Mount Moriah, and when he left there to go to Haran — the earth “sprang” for him. But there is not one of all these Midrashim which says, as Rashi said, [that Mount Moriah was forcibly removed from its location and was transported to meet him in Beth-el].

Verse 18

AND HE SET IT UP FOR A PILLAR. Our Rabbis have explained<sup class="footnote-marker">52</sup><i class="footnote">Yerushalmi Abodah Zarah IV, 5.</i> the difference between a pillar and an altar by saying that a pillar consists of one stone while an altar is composed of many stones. It further appears that a pillar is made for pouring libations of wine upon it and for the pouring of oil upon it, but not for sacrifices and not for offerings, whereas an altar is for bringing Burnt-offerings and Peace-offerings thereon. When Israel entered the Land, the pillar was prohibited to them<sup class="footnote-marker">53</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteromony 16:22.</i> because the Canaanites had established it as an ordinance of an idolatrous character to a greater extent than the altars. Even though it is written concerning the altars, <i>Ye shall break down their altars</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">54</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 34:13.</i> [since the altars were not as prevalent as pillars among the Canaanites, He did not prohibit the Israelites from making their own altars]. It may be that He did not want to prohibit all sacrifices, and so He retained the altar as fit for libations and sacrifices.

Verse 19



Verse 20

IF (‘IM’) G-D WILL BE WITH ME. Rashi comments: “If He will keep for me these promises which He made to me.” The reason for the condition is lest the sin cause the abrogation of the promises. And so the Rabbis said in Bereshith Rabbah,<sup class="footnote-marker">55</sup><i class="footnote">76:2.</i> “Rabbi Huna said in the name of Rabbi Acha, ‘<i>And behold, I am with thee</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">56</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 15 here.</i> and yet it is written, <i>If G-d will be with me</i>! However, from here you infer that there is no assurance to the righteous in this world.’”<br>In line with the simple meaning of Scripture it is further possible that the word <i>im</i> does not indicate a doubt in the matter, but such is the way of Scripture when referring to future events, such as: <i>until ‘im asithi’ (I have done)</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">56</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 15 here.</i> And so also: <i>‘Ve’im’ there shall be the jubilee of the children of Israel</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">57</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 36:4.</i> In all these cases it means if there will come a time when the condition is satisfied, then the deed will be fulfilled, that is to say, <i>ve’im</i> does not mean “<i>if</i> it occurs,” but rather “<i>when</i> it occurs.”

Verse 21

THEN THE ETERNAL SHALL BE MY G-D. This is not a condition, as Rashi would have it. It is rather a vow, and its purport is as follows: “If I will return to my father’s house, I will worship the proper Name of the Eternal in the Chosen Land at the location of this stone which will be for me a house of G-d, and there I will set aside the tithe.” There is in this matter a secret relating to that which the Rabbis have said:<sup class="footnote-marker">58</sup><i class="footnote">Kethuboth 110b.</i> “He who dwells outside the Land of Israel is like one who has no G-d.” [Thus, according to the meaning of the above quotation, the Eternal will be Jacob’s G-d only when he returns to the Land of Israel.]

Chapter 29



Verse 1



Verse 2

AND HE LOOKED, AND BEHOLD A WELL IN THE FIELD, AND LO THREE FLOCKS OF SHEEP LYING THERE BY IT. Scripture tells this story at length in order to let us know that <i>they that wait for the Eternal shall renew their strength</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">59</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 40:31.</i> and the fear of Him gives strength. For here our father Jacob is coming from the journey and he is tired, yet he alone rolls away the stone, a task which required all the shepherds. The many shepherds and all the watchmen of the three flocks of sheep could not shift the rock.<br>With respect to this chapter, our Rabbis in Bereshith Rabbah<sup class="footnote-marker">60</sup><i class="footnote">70:8.</i> also have a secret which alludes to the future. For it happened to him that he came to Haran by way of the well, and only three of all the flocks were gathered. He arrived at the time when the stone was yet upon the mouth of the well, and the flocks waited for the water thereof. Likewise, the matter which is narrated here is all for the purpose of letting it be known that Jacob will succeed in this venture and will have children worthy of the fulfillment of this allusion. For the well alludes to the Sanctuary, and the three flocks of sheep are symbolic of the pilgrims ascending to the Sanctuary during the three festivals.<sup class="footnote-marker">61</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Pesach, Shevuoth</i>, and <i>Succoth</i>. See Deuteronomy 16:16.</i> The expression, <i>For out of that well they watered the flocks</i>, alludes to the fact that they drew holy inspiration from the pilgrimages to the Sanctuary. It may be that it alludes to the verse, <i>For out of Zion shall go forth Torah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">62</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 2:3. Thus both prophecy and law emanated from the Sanctuary.</i> — which has been likened to water,<sup class="footnote-marker">63</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 55:1, Baba Kamma 17a.</i> <i>and the word of the Eternal from Jerusalem</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">62</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 2:3. Thus both prophecy and law emanated from the Sanctuary.</i> — <i>And thither were all the flocks gathered</i><sup class="footnote-marker">64</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 3 here.</i> — <i>from the entrance of Hamath unto the Brook of Egypt</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">65</sup><i class="footnote">I Kings 8:65. The verse refers to the gathering of pilgrims for the festival of <i>Succoth</i>.</i> — <i>And they rolled the stone from the well’s mouth and watered</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">64</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 3 here.</i> for they drew holy inspiration therefrom. <i>And they put the stone back</i><sup class="footnote-marker">64</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 3 here.</i> to lie dormant until the next festival.

Verse 3



Verse 4



Verse 5

KNOW YE LABAN THE SON OF NAHOR? Laban was recognized and known by the name of his father’s father Nahor since Nahor was more important than Laban’s father [Bethuel], and he was the head of their family, as it is written, <i>the G-d of Abraham and the G-d of Nahor</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">66</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 31:53.</i> [Thus, Laban being the son of Bethuel,<sup class="footnote-marker">67</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 28:5.</i> was nevertheless known by his father’s father’s name, Nahor.]<sup class="footnote-marker">68</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 22:22.</i> It is possible that Bethuel was a dishonorable person, and Laban wanted people to ascribe his lineage only to his father’s father, for so we find, <i>And Laban and Bethuel answered</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">69</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 24:50.</i> [Laban is thus mentioned before his father, which indicates that Bethuel was not regarded as the head of the family.] Perhaps all this is in honor of Abraham for [by virtue of Laban’s being known by Nahor’s name], the whole family traced its lineage to <i>Nahor the brother of Abraham</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">70</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 22:23.</i> [and thus demonstrated its connection with its illustrious relative Abraham].

Verse 6



Verse 7



Verse 8



Verse 9

FOR SHE WAS A SHEPHERDESS. The intent of this is to relate that Laban’s sheep had no shepherd other than Rachel, since her father turned over the flock to her alone. She alone tended them all the days, and Leah did not go with the flock at all. The matter was thus unlike that of the daughters of Jethro, where all seven daughters tended the flock simultaneously, as it is said, <i>And they came and drew water</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">71</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 2:16.</i> Perhaps due to Leah’s eyes being tender,<sup class="footnote-marker">72</sup><i class="footnote">Further, Verse 17.</i> the rays of the sun would have hurt her, or because Leah was older and of marriageable age, her father was more concerned about her. Jethro however was honored in his community and he was the priest of the country, and he was confident that people would be afraid of approaching his daughters. It may be that Laban was more modest than Jethro for Abraham’s family was proper and modest, but Rachel was yet young and there was no concern for her. This is the sense of the verse, <i>And Jacob kissed Rachel</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">73</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 11 here.</i> It may be as Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra said that where the Hebrew word for “kissing” is followed by the letter <i>lamed</i> — [as here: <i>Vayishak Yaakov l’Rachel</i>, instead of the word <i>eth</i>] — it means not on the mouth, but that he kissed her on her head or on her shoulder.

Verse 10



Verse 11



Verse 12

AND SHE TOLD HER FATHER. Rashi comments: “Her mother was dead.” And so it is stated in Bereshith Rabbah.<sup class="footnote-marker">74</sup><i class="footnote">70:12.</i> But according to the plain meaning of Scripture, Rachel related it to her father in order to inform him of the arrival of his relative and so that he should go forth to meet him and honor him. For, as regards her mother, what was Jacob to her and what could she do for him? However, Rebekah did show her mother the jewels which Eliezer gave her,<sup class="footnote-marker">75</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 24:28.</i> as is the custom of maidens.

Verse 13



Verse 14



Verse 15

IS IT BECAUSE THOU ART MY BROTHER, THAT THOU SHOULDEST SERVE ME FOR NOUGHT? Scripture did not relate that Jacob served Laban. It is possible that from the time Scripture stated, <i>And he watered the flock of Laban his mother’s brother</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">76</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 10 here.</i> the flock never left his care, for when he saw that Rachel was a shepherdess, Jacob had compassion for her and desired that she no longer tend the sheep. So, out of his love for her, he tended them.<br>It is also possible to say that Laban spoke with cunning. First he said to him that he is his bone and his flesh,<sup class="footnote-marker">77</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 14 here.</i> and that he will have compassion for him as a man has compassion for his own bone and flesh, but when he saw that Jacob tarried there, supporting himself from Laban’s belongings, he said to him, “<i>Is it because thou art my brother, that thou shouldest serve me for nought?</i> For I know that you will henceforth serve me for you are an ethical man, and you will not support yourself from the property of others. Nor do I desire that the labor you perform for me be free without full compensation. Therefore tell me what you want for your hire, and I will give it.” Jacob then discerned Laban’s mind, and he told him that he would serve him for seven years for Rachel. Undefined, “serving” here means tending the sheep, for this is what was needed and this was the subject of their conversation.

Verse 16



Verse 17



Verse 18



Verse 19



Verse 20



Verse 21

FOR MY DAYS ARE FULFILLED. This means “the time which my mother told me to remain away from home.” Another explanation is: <i>For my days are fulfilled</i> — “I am now eighty-four years old and when shall I beget twelve tribes?” These are the words of Rashi.

Verse 22



Verse 23



Verse 24



Verse 25



Verse 26



Verse 27

FULFILL ‘SHVUA’ (THE WEEK OF) THIS ONE. The word <i>shvua</i> is in the construct state for it is punctuated with a <i>sheva</i>. It thus means the seven days of this wife, referring to the seven days of the wedding feast. These too are the words of Rashi.<br>But if so, [i.e., if Rashi interprets <i>shvua</i> as referring to the seven days of the wedding feast rather than, more simply, the seven years of labor, thus implying that the seven years of work had been completed], why did not the Rabbi [Rashi] explain the verse above, <i>my days are fulfilled</i>, as referring to the years of work and the condition which were completed, as Onkelos has it,<sup class="footnote-marker">78</sup><i class="footnote">The days of my work are fulfilled. (Onkelos, Verse 27.)</i> and which is the true sense of the verse, [instead of explaining it as referring to the length of time his mother told him to remain there or to his advanced age]? For merely because the days his mother told him to remain with him were completed or because of his advanced age, Laban would not give him his daughter before the mutually agreed time, and it is enough to expect of Laban that he fulfill his condition. It is according to Onkelos, [who says that Jacob’s seven years of work had been completed], that we are bound to explain, <i>fulfill ‘shvua’ this one</i>, as referring to the seven days of the wedding feast for as Jacob had told him, the days of work had already been completed. So also did Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra explain it. And I do not know [how the reference here could be to “the seven days of the marriage feast,” as Rashi claims], for “the seven days of the wedding feast” is an ordinance established for Israel by our teacher Moses.<sup class="footnote-marker">79</sup><i class="footnote">Yerushalmi Kethuboth I, 1.</i><br>Perhaps we may say that the dignitaries of the nations had already practiced this custom of old, just as was the case with mourning, as it is written, <i>And he made a mourning for his father seven days</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">80</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 50:10. Thus the seven-day period of mourning was already an established practice in the days of the patriarchs.</i> And that which the Rabbis have deduced from here in the Yerushalmi<sup class="footnote-marker">81</sup><i class="footnote">Moed Katan I, 7.</i> and in Bereshith Rabbah,<sup class="footnote-marker">82</sup><i class="footnote">70:18.</i> “One must not mix one rejoicing with another,” that is merely a Scriptural intimation based upon the customary practices of the ancient ones prior to the giving of the Torah. But in our <i>Gemara</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">83</sup><i class="footnote">Moed Katan 9a.</i> the Rabbis did not derive it from here, [i.e., from Laban’s statement], but instead they deduced it from the verse, <i>And Solomon held the feast</i> etc.<sup class="footnote-marker">84</sup><i class="footnote">I Kings 8:65. The verse reads: <i>And Solomon held the feast at that time … seven days and seven days, even fourteen days</i>. The Rabbis explain that the first seven days were a feast of dedication of the new Temple, and the second seven days were the feast of Tabernacles, and he did not combine the two festivities into one because “we must not mix one rejoicing with another.” — The explanation for this principle is stated by Tosafoth Moed Katan 8b. “For just as we must not perform religious duties bundle-wise, but pay exclusive attention to each singly, so must we turn our heart completely toward one rejoicing only, without interference from another.”</i><br>Now it is possible to say that this was part of “the changing of the hire ten times”<sup class="footnote-marker">85</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 31:41.</i> of which Jacob accused Laban. For Jacob told Laban originally that the days were fulfilled, and Laban kept quiet and gave him Leah. Later, Laban told him, “<i>Fulfill ‘shvua’ this one</i>, for the work period for Leah has not been fulfilled, and I gave her to you before the time I had agreed upon.” And Jacob listened to Laban and completed the days as defined by Laban, for he desired Rachel, and what could he do? Therefore, Scripture does not say at first, “And it came to pass when the days were fulfilled, and Jacob said, etc.,” [for this would have indicated mutual agreement concerning the completion of the work period, whereas Laban, as explained, claimed that that time had not yet arrived].<br>It is also possible to say that when the seventh year arrived, Jacob said to Laban, <i>Give me my wife, for my days are fulfilled</i>, meaning that this is the year in which the days will be fulfilled. Similarly, <i>The aged with him that is full of days</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">86</sup><i class="footnote">Jeremiah 6:11.</i> which means, “he who is attaining his final year.” Similarly, <i>Until the day of your consecration be fulfilled</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">87</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 8:33.</i> which means, “until the seventh day in which the days of your consecration will be fulfilled.” It is possible that Jacob said, <i>My days are fulfilled</i>, because they were about to be fulfilled and are considered as if fulfilled. There are many similar examples in Scripture. Likewise, in the next <i>Seder</i> (portion of the Torah), <i>As her soul was departing, for she died</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">88</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 35:18.</i> which means, “when she was near death, and was considered as if she had already died.” And this is the meaning of the expression, <i>that I may come unto her</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">89</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 21 here.</i> that is to say, Jacob said, “My request is not that you give her to me and I will then leave, but rather that I marry her and complete the few days which are still obligatory upon me for now that the period is almost over, you will not be afraid that I might leave you.” Our Rabbis have given a Midrashic interpretation to the words, <i>that I may come unto her</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">90</sup><i class="footnote">Bereshith Rabbah 70:17; also mentioned in Rashi, Verse 21: his mind was intent upon having children and rearing them in the religious traditions of his fathers.</i> because it is not the ethical way to mention it in this manner, the more so with righteous people, but the intent is as I have said.<br>Laban then told Jacob, “Fulfill the seven years of this one, Leah, for perhaps since I transgressed your will by giving you Leah instead of Rachel you will not fulfill them.” Perhaps he mentioned it in order that it be known when the days of work for Rachel begin, and then he told him, “I will give you the other daughter, Rachel, <i>for the service which thou shalt serve with me</i> after the wedding.”
‘VENITNAH’ (AND WE WILL GIVE) THEE. The verb is plural, as in, <i>Let us go down, and let us confound there;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">91</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 11:7.</i> And let us <i>burn</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">92</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 3.</i> Here too it is a form of <i>venitein</i> (and we will give). This is Rashi’s comment, but he did not say why an individual person [Laban] would use the plural form. Perhaps Rashi thought that this is the manner in which dignitaries speak in the Sacred Language, i.e., as if others are speaking. And Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra said here that <i>nitnah</i> is in the (<i>niphal</i>) passive tense and the prefix <i>vav</i> converts it from the past to the future, thus meaning, “and it shall be given to you.”<br>The correct interpretation appears to me to be that Laban’s words were spoken with cunning. He said to Jacob, “<i>It is not so done in our place</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">93</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 26 here.</i> for the people of the place will not let me do so, [i.e., to marry off the younger before the firstborn], for this would be a shameful act in their eyes. But you <i>fulfill the week of this one</i>, and we — I and all the people of the place — will give you also this one, for we will all consent to the matter, and we will give you honor and a feast as we have done with the first one.”

Verse 28



Verse 29



Verse 30

AND HE LOVED RACHEL MORE THAN LEAH. The reason why Scripture mentions that he also loved Rachel more than Leah is that it is natural for a man to have more love for the woman with whom he first had relations, just as the Sages have mentioned with reference to women:<sup class="footnote-marker">94</sup><i class="footnote">Sanhedrin 22b.</i> “And she makes a firm commitment only to he who marries her first.” Thus Jacob’s loving Rachel more than Leah was unnatural. This is the sense of the word <i>gam</i>: [<i>and he loved ‘gam’ Rachel than Leah</i>].

Verse 31

AND THE ETERNAL SAW THAT LEAH WAS HATED. Now Leah had deceived her sister and also Jacob. For even if we were to say that she showed respect for her father, who took her and brought her in to him and she was not rebellious against him, she should have by word or sign indicated that she was Leah. All the more is this so since she feigned herself all night to be another, which was the reason why Jacob did not recognize her until he saw her in the morning. It was for this reason that Jacob hated her. But G-d, knowing that she did so in order to be married to the righteous one, had compassion upon her. And so the Rabbis said in Bereshith Rabbah:<sup class="footnote-marker">95</sup><i class="footnote">71:2.</i> “When Jacob saw the deeds by which Leah had deceived her sister, he decided to divorce her. But when the Holy One, blessed be He, remembered her by giving her children, Jacob said, ‘Shall I divorce the mother of these children?’” This is the meaning of the expression, <i>And the Eternal saw</i>: He had compassion upon her so that Jacob should not leave her. But there are some scholars<sup class="footnote-marker">96</sup><i class="footnote">R’dak in his Commentary on the Torah.</i> who say that in the case of two wives, one of whom is loved exceedingly, the second one, who is the less beloved, is called “hated” relative to the first, just as Scripture said, <i>And he loved Rachel more than Leah</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">97</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 30 here.</i> but not that he hated her. Leah however was ashamed of the matter and so G-d saw her affliction.

Chapter 30



Verse 1

GIVE ME CHILDREN. The commentators<sup class="footnote-marker">98</sup><i class="footnote">Rashi and Ibn Ezra.</i> said that this means that Rachel asked Jacob to pray on her behalf. <i>Or else I die</i> — Rashi comments: “For one who is childless may be considered as dead.” This is a Midrash of our Rabbis.<sup class="footnote-marker">99</sup><i class="footnote">Bereshith Rabbah 71:19.</i><br>But I wonder. If so, why was Jacob angry with her? And why did he say, <i>Am I in G-d’s stead?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">100</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 2 here.</i> for G-d hearkens to the righteous.<sup class="footnote-marker">101</sup><i class="footnote">See Psalms 69:34.</i> [I wonder concerning] that which Jacob said [to Rachel, as quoted in Rashi:<sup class="footnote-marker">100</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 2 here.</i> “You say that I should do as did my father, who prayed on behalf of Rebekah, but I am not circumstanced as my father was. My] father had no children at all. I, however, have children. It is from you that He had withheld children and not from me.” Do not the righteous pray on behalf of others? There were Elijah<sup class="footnote-marker">102</sup><i class="footnote">I Kings 18:21.</i> and Elisha<sup class="footnote-marker">103</sup><i class="footnote">II Kings 4:33.</i> who prayed on behalf of strange women.<br>It would appear that on account of Jacob’s answer, our Rabbis took him to task, saying in Bereshith Rabbah:<sup class="footnote-marker">104</sup><i class="footnote">71:10.</i> “The Holy One, blessed be He, said to Jacob, ‘Is this the way to answer a woman who is oppressed by her barrenness? By your life! Your children are destined to stand before her son Joseph!’”<br>In line with the plain meaning of Scripture, Rachel asked of Jacob that he give her children, but her intent was truly to say that he should pray on her behalf and continue indeed to pray until G-d would, in any case, grant her children, and if not, she would mortify herself because of grief. In her envy she spoke improperly, thinking that because Jacob loved her he would fast, put on <i>sackcloth with ashes</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">105</sup><i class="footnote">Esther 4:1.</i> and pray until she would have children, so that she should not die of her grief.

Verse 2

AND JACOB’s ANGER WAS KINDLED. It is not in the power of the righteous that their prayer be heard and answered in any case, and because she spoke in the manner of yearning women who are loved, thus attempting to frighten him with her death, his anger was kindled. Therefore, he said to her that he is not in G-d’s stead that he should remember the barren ones by giving them children in any case, and he does not care about it since it is from her that children were withheld and not from him. He said this in order to admonish her and shame her. Now the righteous woman Rachel, seeing that she could not rely upon Jacob’s prayer, then went to pray on her own behalf to Him Who hears the cry of those in trouble. This is the sense of the verse, <i>And G-d hearkened to her</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">106</sup><i class="footnote">Further, Verse 22.</i><br>Perhaps we can rectify Jacob’s retort in consonance with the opinion of our Rabbis [who related that Jacob said to Rachel, “It is from you that he has withheld children and not from me,”] for it is impossible to think that Jacob did not pray on behalf of his beloved wife who was barren, however his prayer was not accepted.<br>Now Rachel came to him with a pretext saying that he should, in any case, give her children through his prayer for he is not of less stature than his father who did so. At this, his anger was kindled and he said to her that the matter is up to G-d and not to him, and that his father’s prayer was heard because he was a righteous man and was destined to have children, but here it is from her that He has withheld children. This is a correct interpretation.

Verse 3



Verse 4



Verse 5

AND SHE BORE ‘L’YAAKOV’ (TO JACOB) A SON. In the case of all the handmaids Scripture mentions the phrase, <i>to Jacob</i> [in connection with the birth of their children], in order to relate that Jacob desired and acknowledged them and that they were not called by him “sons of the handmaids,” but “sons of Jacob,” just like the sons of the mistresses who traced their lineage to him. In the case of the fifth and sixth sons of Leah it also says, <i>to Jacob</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">107</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verses 17 and 19.</i> since due to her abundance of sons, Scripture deems it necessary to say that Jacob desired and befriended all of them. This is not mentioned in connection with the birth of the first [four sons of Leah because it is obvious that Jacob desired them].

Verse 6



Verse 7



Verse 8



Verse 9

WHEN LEAH SAW THAT SHE HAD LEFT OFF BEARING SHE TOOK ZILPAH HER HANDMAID, etc. I do not know what motivated this deed of Leah and why she gave her handmaid to her husband for she was not barren that she should hope to have children through Zilpah, and it is not natural for women to increase the number of their husbands’ wives. We must, however, say that the matriarchs were prophetesses,<sup class="footnote-marker">108</sup><i class="footnote">Bereshith Rabbah, end of Chapter 72.</i> who knew that Jacob was destined to establish twelve tribes, and Leah desired that the majority of his sons be from her or from her handmaid, who was in her power, so that her sister Rachel would not prevail over her with respect to the number of her sons. Therefore, she said, <i>G-d hath given me my share, because I have given my handmaid to my husband</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">109</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 18 here.</i> Jacob also came unto her on account of this, i.e., that he raise many sons for he knew it to be so, as our Rabbis have said.<sup class="footnote-marker">110</sup><i class="footnote">Bereshith Rabbah 70:17. Jacob was also aware that he was destined to establish twelve tribes.</i><br>It is possible that knowing that the Land had been given to their children, and realizing that Abraham and Isaac had not had many children, Jacob wanted to have many wives in order to increase his progeny so as to inherit the Land, for <i>a fourth generation shall come hither again</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">111</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 15:16.</i> and so Leah wanted to give him her handmaid so that he would not wed a stranger.

Verse 10



Verse 11



Verse 12



Verse 13



Verse 14

‘DUDA’IM.’ These are <i>‘sigli’</i> (violets). In Arabic it is called <i>jasmin</i>. So I found in Rashi’s commentary. But this is not so for the Arabic jasmin bears the same name in the words of our Rabbis, as they say in the chapter <i>Bameh Tomnin:</i><sup class="footnote-marker">112</sup><i class="footnote">“With What May They Cover Up” hot food, the fourth chapter in Tractate Shabbath. 50b.</i> “Poppy pomace flavored with jasmin may be used [as a lotion on the Sabbath],” while they say <i>sigli</i> is an odorous herb concerning which they have said<sup class="footnote-marker">113</sup><i class="footnote">Berachoth 43b.</i> that on smelling it, one recites the blessing: “Blessed art Thou… who createst odorous plants.” However, their season is not <i>in the days of the wheat</i>, but perhaps Reuben found them there by chance. It is best to accept Onkelos’ opinion concerning the translation of <i>duda’im</i>, which he rendered as <i>yavruchin</i> (mandrakes). In Bereshith Rabbah<sup class="footnote-marker">114</sup><i class="footnote">72:2.</i> it is also explained similarly: “Rabbi Chiya the son of Rabbi Abba said, ‘<i>Yavruchin</i>,’” and these are <i>yavruach</i> in Arabic.<br>Now Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra wrote: “Onkelos translated <i>duda’im</i> as ‘mandrakes,’ and so they are called in Arabic. They have a good odor. And it is so written: <i>The mandrakes give forth fragrance</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">115</sup><i class="footnote">Song of Songs 7:14.</i> They resemble the human form as they have the shape of the human head and hands. Now some say that they are an aid to pregnancy, but I do not know it since their effect is to produce the cold fluid in the body.” These are Ibn Ezra’s words.<br>The correct interpretation is that Rachel wanted the <i>duda’im</i> for delight and pleasure, for Rachel was visited with children through prayer, not by medicinal methods. And Reuben brought the branches of <i>duda’im</i> or the fruit, which resemble apples and have a good odor. The stem, however, which is shaped in the form of the human head and hands, he did not bring, and it is the stem which people say is an aid to pregnancy. And if the matter be true, it is by some peculiar effect, not by its natural quality. But I have not seen it thus in any of the medicinal books discussing mandrakes.

Verse 15

IS IT A SMALL MATTER THAT THOU HAST TAKEN AWAY MY HUSBAND? The intent thereof is as follows: “Is it a small matter that you take my husband unto yourself as if you are his wife and I am the handmaid? Will you now also make yourself the mistress to take the mandrakes in whose odor I delight?”<br>It is possible that Rachel wanted the mandrakes in honor of Jacob to perfume his couch. Leah had done in the customary way of women, just as it is written, <i>I have perfumed my bed with myrrh, aloes and cinnamon</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">116</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 7:17.</i> Therefore, Leah said, <i>Is it a small matter that thou hast taken away my husband</i> from me that you now also take my son’s mandrakes to win him over with them?<br>And some scholars say<sup class="footnote-marker">117</sup><i class="footnote">I have not been able to identify them. However, see R’dak.</i> that <i>duda’im</i> are herbs, which act as a male aphrodisiac, the word being derived from the expression, <i>the time of ‘dodim’ (love)</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">118</sup><i class="footnote">Ezekiel 16:8.</i> Therefore Leah said, <i>Is it a small matter that thou hast taken away my husband?</i> as I have mentioned.

Verse 16



Verse 17



Verse 18



Verse 19



Verse 20

G-D HATH ‘Z’VADANI’ (ENDOWED) ME WITH A GOOD ‘ZEVED’ (DOWRY). The commentators have not found the source of this word in the Sacred Language.<br>We could perhaps say that <i>zeved</i> is a composite word formed from <i>zeh bad</i>, just as is the word <i>madua</i>, [which is composed of the two words, <i>mah dua</i>, meaning “what is the opinion of this matter” or simply “why”] or the word <i>bagad</i><sup class="footnote-marker">119</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 11 here.</i> in its written form. [It is read, however, as two words: <i>ba gad</i> (good luck cometh.)] Since the vowel signs <i>segol</i> and <i>patach</i> interchange in many places, particularly in composite words, [the second <i>segol</i> in <i>zeved</i> could have come from the <i>patach</i> of <i>bad: zeh bad</i>]. So also in the word <i>tzalmaveth</i>, [which consists of the two words: <i>tzeil maveth</i> (the shade of death)], and the word <i>biladai</i>, [composed of <i>bal ad</i> (except unto, except unto me, or except me)]. And the second part (<i>bad</i>) of the word <i>zeved</i> comes from the word <i>badim</i> (branches), as in, <i>‘badei’ (staves) of accacia-wood;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">120</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 25:13.</i> <i>And it brought forth ‘badim’ (branches), and shot forth sprigs</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">121</sup><i class="footnote">Ezekiel 17:6.</i> The thick branches of a tree are called <i>badim</i>, and then the word was appropriated to mean “children,” as in, <i>The first-born of death shall devour ‘badav’ (his sons);</i><sup class="footnote-marker">122</sup><i class="footnote">Job 18:13.</i> <i>His ill-founded ‘badav’ (sons)</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">123</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 16:6. See Rashi there, who explains the verse as follows: <i>for most of Moab’s sons are illegitimate</i>, etc.</i> Therefore Leah said that this son whom G-d had given her would be a good son for he will cause her husband to reside in her shadow, as “he will now <i>‘yizbleini’ (dwell with me)</i> in my shadow.” Similarly, <i>I have surely built Thee a house ‘z’vul’ (of habitation)</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">124</sup><i class="footnote">I Kings 8:13.</i> meaning “in order to abide in His shadow.” This was said in this fashion out of respect for the Supreme One, just as Solomon said, <i>Behold, heaven and the heaven of heavens cannot contain Thee, how much less this house that I have builded!</i><sup class="footnote-marker">125</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 27.</i> Likewise, <i>The sun and moon stand still ‘z’vulah’ (in their habitation)</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">126</sup><i class="footnote">Habakkuk 3:11.</i> meaning “stand still in the place where they abide,” as it is said, <i>In them</i> [the heavens] <i>hath He set a tent for the sun</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">127</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 19:5.</i><br>Now Onkelos translated <i>zeved tov</i> as a good portion. I did not understand his reasoning until I saw in the Jerusalem Targum:<sup class="footnote-marker">128</sup><i class="footnote">Found in our Targum Yonathan. The traditional <i>Targumim</i> (translations) of the Pentateuch are <i>Onkelos, Yonathan</i>, and <i>Yerushalmi</i>. The latter has not reached us in its entirety.</i> “The word of G-d has outfitted me (<i>zavad</i>) with good provision.” [<i>Zavad</i> is written here with two <i>vavim</i> instead of the <i>beth</i> with which the word <i>zeved</i> is written in the Torah.] From this I learned that both Onkelos and the Jerusalem Targum considered the word <i>zeved</i> of the Torah, which is spelled with the letter <i>beth</i>, as if it were written with the letter <i>vav</i>, and they connected it to the Aramaic language which translates the Hebrew word <i>tzeidah</i> (provision) as <i>zvadim</i> (provisions). Leah thus said that G-d had made this son a good provision and a good portion for her because her husband, due to her many children, will now live mainly with her, and thus she will be supported together with him when it is well with him. The <i>vav</i> and the <i>beth</i> are used interchangeably in our language in many places, such as: <i>ta’avah</i> (desire) written with a <i>vav</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">129</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 3:6.</i> and <i>ta’avah</i>, written with a <i>beth;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">130</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 119:20.</i> <i>geivi (My back)</i> — [written with a <i>vav</i>] — <i>I have given to the smiters</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">131</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 50:6.</i> and, <i>Upon ‘gabi’ (my back)</i> — [written with a <i>beth</i>] — <i>the plowers plowed</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">132</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 129:3.</i> So also, <i>‘Lekitzvei’ (To the bottoms)</i> — [written with a <i>beth</i>] — <i>of the mountains I went down</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">133</sup><i class="footnote">Jonah 2:7.</i> is as if it were written, <i>lekitzvei</i> with a <i>vav</i>. Also, <i>‘Laparbor’ (For the precinct)</i> — [written with a <i>beth</i>] — <i>westward, four at the causeway</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">134</sup><i class="footnote">I Chronicles 26:18.</i> serves as the basis of the word <i>parvor</i>, written with a <i>vav</i>, as it is written, <i>By the chamber of Nethan-melech the officer, which was ‘baparvorim’ (in the precincts)</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">135</sup><i class="footnote">II Kings 23:11.</i> written with a <i>vav</i>, and the meaning of both forms, [whether written with a <i>beth</i> or <i>vav</i>] is the Court which is outside the wall. <i>‘Umigrash’ (And open land) round about the cities</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">136</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 35:2.</i> is rendered by the Jerusalem Targum as, <i>uparvor</i>. And so did the Jonathan Targum translate <i>migrashoth</i> (open lands) as <i>parvoraya</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">137</sup><i class="footnote">Ezekiel 27:28.</i> In the Mishnah we also find the <i>vav</i> and the <i>beth</i> interchange: “A <i>tarvad</i> (spoon)-full,” written with a <i>vav</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">138</sup><i class="footnote">Nazir VII, 2.</i> and in some editions it is written, <i>tarbad</i>, with a <i>beth</i>; “A board which has no <i>levazbiz</i> (edges),” written with a <i>beth</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">139</sup><i class="footnote">Pesachim 48b.</i> and in certain places they use the word <i>lazbiz</i>, written with a <i>beth</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">140</sup><i class="footnote">Kelim II, 3.</i> while in other places they use <i>lazviz</i> written with a <i>vav</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">141</sup><i class="footnote">Source is unknown to me.</i> Also, <i>itztaba</i> (a balcony), written with a <i>beth</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">142</sup><i class="footnote">Shabbath 7a.</i> and <i>itztava</i>, written with a <i>vav</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">143</sup><i class="footnote">Eirubin 77b.</i> and many other similar words. In the Jerusalem Talmud they also write <i>avir</i> (space)<sup class="footnote-marker">141</sup><i class="footnote">Source is unknown to me.</i> with a <i>beth</i> in place of the usual <i>vav</i>, as they were not particular about that.

Verse 21



Verse 22



Verse 23

G-D ‘OSAPH’ (HATH TAKEN AWAY) MY DISGRACE. I.e., “He has laid it up somewhere where it cannot be seen.” Similar examples are: <i>And it shall not ‘yei’aseph’ (have been taken away) into the house;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">144</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 9:19.</i> <i>And the stars ‘asphu’ (withdraw) their shining;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">145</sup><i class="footnote">Joel 2:10.</i> <i>Neither shall thy moon ‘yei’aseph’ (withdraw itself)</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">146</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 60:20.</i> meaning it shall not hide itself. This is the language of Rashi. But Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra said that <i>asaph</i> has the same meaning as “vanish,” as in, <i>‘Vene’esaph’ (And vanish) will joy and gladness</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">147</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 16:10.</i><br>The correct opinion is that of Onkelos, who made them all expressions of gathering and assembling, as is their plain sense, derived from the verses: <i>‘Vaya’asphu’ (And they gathered) the quails;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">148</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 11:32.</i> <i>But ‘me’asphav’ (they who have garnered it) shall eat it</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">149</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 62:9.</i> Death is called <i>asiphah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">150</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 25:8.</i> because the dying person is gathered to his dead ancestors. <i>And it shall not ‘yei’aseph’ into the house</i><sup class="footnote-marker">144</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 9:19.</i> means to be gathered to his household. <i>And the stars ‘asphu’ their shining</i><sup class="footnote-marker">145</sup><i class="footnote">Joel 2:10.</i> means that they will gather the light within them and not give forth their light outside, or that they will be gathered into their tent, which is in the firmament of the heaven.<sup class="footnote-marker">151</sup><i class="footnote">See Psalms 19:5, mentioned above, Note 127</i> The word <i>asiphah</i> is used in connection with disgrace, meaning that the disgraced person should be gathered and not spread among people, i.e., to be discussed further in the streets.

Verse 24



Verse 25



Verse 26



Verse 27

‘NICHASHTI’ I HAVE OBSERVED THE SIGNS AND THE ETERNAL HATH BLESSED ME FOR THY SAKE. That is, “on account of you and your merit for you are a righteous man.” The word <i>nichashti</i> means “I have tested,” and every form of <i>nichesh</i> connotes testing. And some say<sup class="footnote-marker">152</sup><i class="footnote">Ibn Ezra.</i> that Laban was a diviner with teraphim.<sup class="footnote-marker">153</sup><i class="footnote">See Ramban further, 31:19.</i><br>Jacob, however, said, <i>And the Eternal hath blessed thee ‘leragli’ (since my coming)</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">154</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 30 here.</i> but, in a humble manner, he did not want to say “for my sake.” Thus, he said <i>leragli</i>, meaning that “from the time I set my foot in your house, you have been blessed.”

Verse 28



Verse 29

AND HOW THY CATTLE HAVE FARED WITH ME. “You know the number of your few cattle that were entrusted to me at first.” These are Rashi’s words. That is to say, “You know how few your cattle were when they were entrusted to me.” But according to Rashi’s interpretation, it would have been more proper had he said, “and your cattle which were with me:” you know <i>for it was little which thou hadst</i> before I came, <i>and it hath increased abundantly</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">154</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 30 here.</i> Or, we shall explain: “<i>Thou knowest how I have served thee</i> since I have done it with all my strength, and thou knowest <i>how thy cattle have fared with me</i>, for a long time has passed since then, and thou knowest <i>for it was little which thou hadst before I came, and it hath increased abundantly</i>, in an unnatural way. It is only <i>The blessing of the Eternal</i> [that] <i>maketh rich</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">155</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 10:22.</i> which came from the time I set foot in your house.” This is the correct interpretation.

Verse 30

WHEN SHALL I PROVIDE ‘GAM’ (ALSO) FOR MINE OWN HOUSE? “At present, my sons alone provide for my needs, but I also ought to work together with them and assist them.” This is the force of the word <i>gam</i> (also). These are Rashi’s words. But we do not find that Jacob had his own sheep, nor do we find mentioned anywhere that his young children — the oldest of whom was six years or less — tended them. It was possible that before Jacob came, Laban had children younger than Rachel<sup class="footnote-marker">156</sup><i class="footnote">This is a reference to what Rashi explained in Verse 27 that since Jacob’s arrival, a blessing came upon Laban and he begot sons, “for is it possible that if he previously had sons, he would have let his daughter Rachel go among the shepherds?” Yet he had sons, as it is said, <i>And he</i> [Jacob] <i>heard the words of Laban’s sons</i>, (further, 31:1). We must say that these sons were born to him after Jacob came.</i> and now they were fit to tend the flock. [However, Jacob’s children were still very young.] Perhaps Jacob referred to his wives and servants, who he said did his work for him. But all this is not correct. The meaning of, <i>When shall I provide also for mine house?</i> is: “When shall I provide for my house just as I have also done for your house.” Similarly, <i>And he loved also Rachel from Leah</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">157</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 29:30.</i> means “And he loved Rachel also more than he loved Leah.” And similarly, <i>Also thee I would have slain</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">158</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 22:33.</i> means “Also I would have slain thee.” And there are many other such verses.

Verse 31



Verse 32

SPECKLED AND SPOTTED. This means speckled <i>or</i> spotted. <i>And every ‘chum’ among the sheep</i> — commentators have explained<sup class="footnote-marker">159</sup><i class="footnote">Ibn Ezra and R’dak.</i> <i>chum</i> as meaning “black,” since blackness comes from heat (<i>cham</i>). But this does not appear to me to be correct since most sheep are black, particularly in the eastern countries where it is warm, and if so, all sheep would then belong to Jacob.<br>The correct interpretation is the rendition of Onkelos, namely, that <i>chum</i> is reddish or brownish, called <i>rouge</i> in Old French, and so did Rashi explain it. <i>Chum</i> would then be from the root; <i>the light of ‘hachamah’ (the sun)</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">160</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 30:26.</i> since it is like the sun which is somewhat red.
AND OF SUCH SHALL BE MY HIRE. Rashi comments: “Those which from now on will be born speckled and spotted among the goats, and the brownish ones amongst the sheep shall belong to me.” And so also is the opinion of Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra. The meaning of the expression, <i>every one among the flock speckled and spotted</i>, is that it refers to the he-goats; <i>and the spotted and speckled among the goats</i> refers to the she-goats, just as Scripture said, <i>And he removed that day the he-goats … and all the she-goats</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">161</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 35 here.</i> And the meaning of the expression, <i>every one that had white in it</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">161</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 35 here.</i> is that it refers to those mentioned, [namely, the spotted and the speckled among the he-goats and the she-goats], <i>and all the brownish among the sheep</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">161</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 35 here.</i> [Thus, according to Rashi and Ibn Ezra, Jacob’s hire was to be all spotted and speckled he-goats and she-goats that will henceforth be born, and also the reddish ones among the sheep, but not the spotted and speckled among the sheep.]<br>In my opinion, all the spotted and speckled among the sheep, as well as all brownish ones, were to be Jacob’s hire since he did not make among his sticks any with a brownish color, in which case he caused himself the loss of his hire from among the sheep, which are the best of the flock. Similarly, in his dream, he was shown <i>the rams which went up on the flocks were ringstraked, speckled</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">162</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 31:10.</i> there being no brownish ones among them. And the meaning of the verse before us is: removing from there every one of the flock speckled and spotted and all brownish ones among the sheep, and removing the spotted and the speckled among the goats, <i>and they shall be my hire</i>, namely, the three colors among the sheep — speckled, spotted, and brownish — and two among the goats — spotted and speckled. And he further said, <i>So shall my righteousness answer for me in time to come</i>, that <i>everyone that is not speckled and spotted among the goats, and</i> all <i>brownish among the sheep, that shall be accounted stolen with me</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">163</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 33 here.</i>

Verse 33



Verse 34



Verse 35

AND HE REMOVED THAT DAY THE HE-GOATS. The meaning thereof is that Scripture relates that Jacob had said in a general way, <i>removing from there … the spotted and the speckled among the goats</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">164</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 32 here.</i> [which, according to Ramban’s opinion explained above, refers only to the she-goats], but Laban was afraid of the influence of the male seed, and so he removed the he-goats that were even ringstraked, having a little white on their feet at the spot where they are bound, and he removed from the sheep <i>every one that had white in it</i> together with <i>all the brownish ones</i>. Now if <i>every one that had white in it</i> means that he removed from among the he-goats and she-goats all that had any white color in them, whether ringstraked or grizzled, in that case, <i>and all brownish among the sheep</i> is in addition to the colors mentioned [for, as we have seen, Ramban is of the opinion that Jacob’s hire from the sheep was from all three colors]. The reason why they added the brownish color to the hire from the sheep is that it is not in their nature to be born with the same colors as he-goats and she-goats, and it is not in the nature of goats to be brownish.

Verse 36



Verse 37

AND JACOB TOOK HIM STICKS OF POPLAR. As soon as they agreed that his hire would be these colors it was permissible for Jacob to do whatever he could to cause them to give birth in this manner. Perhaps Jacob had made a condition that he may do with them whatever he wants since Laban did not know of the ramifications of this measure, nor did Laban’s shepherds sense anything when they saw the sticks in the gutters once a year during the days of Nisan. For <i>When the flocks were feeble</i><sup class="footnote-marker">165</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 42 here.</i> in the days of Tishri, <i>he did not put them in</i>, otherwise not a hoof would have remained for Laban.<br>Now some commentators<sup class="footnote-marker">166</sup><i class="footnote">R’dak.</i> say that the first year [Jacob did not make use of these sticks, but] there were born to him many speckled and spotted ones by virtue of G-d’s blessing which the angel showed him.<sup class="footnote-marker">167</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 31:12.</i> And then he put the sticks in front of those which were his so that they should give birth in their form. This would prevent Laban from saying that their offspring was stolen by Jacob, [as he would have claimed had they given birth to other colored offspring].<br>This is the meaning of <i>whensoever the stronger flocks became heated</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">168</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 41 here.</i> referring to those that had been born to Jacob by way of G-d’s blessing; <i>but when the flocks</i> of Laban <i>were feeble, he put them not in; so that the feebler were Laban’s</i>, for they did not give birth to speckled ones, <i>and the stronger</i> were all <i>Jacob’s</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">165</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 42 here.</i> including their offspring, for they gave birth to speckled ones.

Verse 38



Verse 39



Verse 40

AND JACOB SEPARATED THE LAMBS. Rashi comments: “Those sheep that were thus born spotted on the ankles and speckled, he separated and set apart by themselves, thus forming them into a separate flock. The spotted flock he led in front of the ordinary sheep so that the faces of the sheep that followed behind them were gazing at them. This is what Scripture means in saying, <i>And he set the faces of the flocks towards the spotted;</i> the faces of the sheep were directed towards the spotted animals and towards all that were brownish which were found amongst Laban’s sheep. <i>And he put his own droves by themselves, and set them not with Laban’s flocks</i>, as I have already explained.” This is the Rabbi’s [Rashi’s] language. But his words here are not correct. For why did Jacob separate the spotted lambs so that there did not remain in Laban’s flock any speckled or brownish ones, neither in the sheep nor in the goats? And if those that he separated were the ringstraked, speckled and spotted which the sheep had given birth to and which belonged to him, and it was from them that he made this spotted flock, why did he separate only the lambs and did not take also the he-goats and she-goats which were born spotted and make from all of them this spotted flock which he led before the sheep? Moreover, Scripture makes no mention of the fact that brownish ones were born. And again, according to the opinion of the Rabbi [Rashi], there were no ringstraked and spotted among the lambs for these were not his hire. Only the brownish were, and for the brownish he had made no sticks.<br>But the explanation of the verse is that Jacob separated the lambs from the goats and made from them a separate flock. Now he had a flock of brownish lambs and a flock of spotted and speckled goats. He then had the faces of all the flocks — of the lambs and of the goats — directed towards the ringstraked and towards all the brownish which were in the flock of Laban, since he put the ringstraked before the goats and all the brownish before the lambs, this being in accordance with the opinion of the earlier Rabbis, [Rashi and Ibn Ezra, as explained above], or, according to [Ramban’s] opinion, the ringstraked and all the brownish before the lamb. For the purpose of the separation of the lambs from the goats was on account of the brownish which were his hire from the lambs alone.<br>The correct interpretation appears to me to be that Scripture is saying, <i>Jacob separated</i> [only] <i>the lambs and set the faces of the flocks</i>, which refer to the above mentioned lambs, <i>to the ringstraked and all the brownish in the flock of Laban, and he put his own droves</i> of the ringstraked and the brownish <i>by themselves, and he set them not with Laban’s flocks</i>, for these, [the ringstraked and the brownish], were his hire. And the meaning of the expression, <i>in the flock of Laban</i>, is that he did so with all of Laban’s flocks but not that they belonged to Laban since the ringstraked among the lambs were Jacob’s.<br>Now do not ask why Scripture at first says “lambs” and then says “the faces of the flocks” rather than “the faces of the lambs”, for it is normal for Scripture to express itself this way. In this section there is a similar case in connection with the mountain of Gilead.<sup class="footnote-marker">169</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 31:25. <i>Now Jacob had pitched his tent in the mountain, and Laban with his brethren pitched in the mountain of Gilead</i>. “The mountain” mentioned at the beginning of the verse is the “mountain of Gilead” mentioned at the end.</i> And the reason Jacob did this with the lambs more than with the goats is that there were no brownish ones among the sticks he put up. It is possible that he knew that because of their heaviness, it is natural for lambs to require many signs to arouse them — more than the light-weight he-goats require.

Verse 41

THE FLOCKS ‘HAMEKUSHAROTH.’ The correct interpretation of this expression appears to me to be that they are the flocks in which the males follow the females at all times, never leaving them due to their abundant desire, as in the expression, <i>Seeing that his soul is ‘keshurah’ (bound up) with the lad’s soul</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">170</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 44:30.</i> This is also found in the language of our Sages: “a swine <i>karuch</i> (clinging) to a ewe;”<sup class="footnote-marker">171</sup><i class="footnote">Bechoroth 24a.</i> “clinging to her.”<sup class="footnote-marker">172</sup><i class="footnote">Kiddushin 79b.</i> And the offspring born at that time are called <i>hakeshurim</i> after the name of their father.<br>But many authorities say<sup class="footnote-marker">173</sup><i class="footnote">P’sikta Zutrata on this verse.</i> that <i>keshurim</i> are “the strong ones” whose limbs are firmly attached to each other with a strong tie, as this is the basis of health, while <i>atuphim</i><sup class="footnote-marker">165</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 42 here.</i> are “the weak ones” whose <i>soul ‘tithataph’ (fainted) in them</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">174</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 107:5.</i> and who have no desire, as in the expression, <i>‘ha’atuphim’ (that faint) for hunger</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">175</sup><i class="footnote">Lamentations 2:19.</i> Onkelos translated <i>hamekusharoth</i> as the early-bearing sheep, and <i>atuphim</i> as the late-bearing ones, for such is the fact: [the early-bearing sheep are the stronger ones, and the late-bearing ones are weaker].

Chapter 31



Verse 1



Verse 2



Verse 3



Verse 4



Verse 5



Verse 6

THAT WITH ALL MY POWER I HAVE SERVED YOUR FATHER. That is, “from the outset, and he has been blessed since my coming.” It is possible that Laban’s flocks had been many, but that even the feebler ones were blessed since Jacob came, for Laban’s sons complained only out of jealousy of Jacob that <i>he had gotten all this wealth</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">176</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 1 here.</i>

Verse 7

AND YOUR FATHER HATH MOCKED ME, AND CHANGED MY WAGES TEN TIMES. This was true, even though Scripture did not previously relate it. And so too did Jacob tell Laban: <i>And thou hast changed my wages ten times</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">177</sup><i class="footnote">Further, Verse 41.</i> There are many similar places in the Torah. For example, in this earlier section, Scripture did not relate that Leah gave the mandrakes to Rachel [although the event is referred to later in Verse 16: <i>for I have hired thee with my son’s mandrakes</i>].

Verse 8

IF HE SAID THUS: THE SPECKLED SHALL BE THY WAGES. The meaning thereof is that at first Laban agreed to give Jacob the two appearances the speckled and the spotted — also the brownish lambs. Then he retracted and agreed to give him another color, and thus he changed it every year. The flocks, however, gave birth accordingly. This was not due to the power of the sticks, for he was telling them of the deed of the Great G-d who treated him wondrously each and every year, just as he said, <i>But G-d suffered him not to do me evil</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">178</sup><i class="footnote">Above, Verse 7.</i><br>It is also possible that Laban changed his wages after the flocks became pregnant and gave birth in accordance with Jacob’s will, it pleasing the Creator to do so. [In this case, it clearly was not due to the power of the sticks.] And so we find in Bereshith Rabbah:<sup class="footnote-marker">179</sup><i class="footnote">74:2.</i> “The Holy One, blessed be He, foresaw what Laban was destined to do to our father Jacob, and He created the form of the sheep to conform to the colors Laban was to stipulate. Thus, it is not written here, ‘If he said (<i>amar</i>) thus,’ but it is written, ‘If he will say (<i>yomar</i>) thus,’” [indicating that G-d foresaw what Laban was destined to stipulate to Jacob].

Verse 9



Verse 10

AND IT CAME TO PASS AT THE TIME THAT THE FLOCK CONCEIVED. This was after Laban changed his wages, and therefore the angel said to Jacob, <i>For I have seen all that Laban does unto thee</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">180</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 12 here.</i>
AND, BEHOLD THE HE-GOATS WHICH WENT UP ON THE FLOCKS [WERE RINGSTRAKED, SPECKLED, AND GRIZZLED]. The meaning thereof is that it was shown to Jacob in a dream that the he-goats which mounted the flocks were all ringstraked, and afterwards they were all speckled, and still later they were all grizzled. And the angel told him that in view of the injustice which Laban does him by changing his wages, the future offspring will have the appearance which Jacob will need, and that henceforth Jacob should not make the sticks, for <i>Whoso putteth his trust in the Eternal shall be set up on high</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">181</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 29:25.</i>
AND, BEHOLD, ‘HA’ATUDIM’ WHICH WENT UP ON THE FLOCKS. He-goats and rams are called <i>atudim</i> for all the adults in the flocks are so called. This applies also to the mighty ones among men, as in: <i>‘atudei’ (the chief ones) of the earth</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">182</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 14:9.</i><br>And Rashi comments: “Although Laban had separated all these so that the sheep should not give birth to young marked similarly to them, angels brought them from the flock which had been placed in charge of Laban’s sons to the flock in Jacob’s charge.”<br>In line with the simple meaning of Scripture this was a vision assuring Jacob that the flocks would give birth to young similar to the marked rams and he-goats, and the proof of it is the word <i>vehinei</i> (and behold), for this expression is used with respect to all dreams, indicating that it is as if the action is in the presence of the dreamer. In Bereshith Rabbah,<sup class="footnote-marker">183</sup><i class="footnote">73:7.</i> the Sages did not mention the angels [bringing the marked ones from the flocks of Laban], but it may be inferred by exegesis. Thus they said: “It is not written here <i>olim</i> (went up) but <i>ha’olim</i> (those that mounted),” [meaning those which actually mounted. Thus the dream only indicated the action of the <i>atudim</i> which came from Laban’s flocks and that they were ringstraked, speckled, etc. However, the fact that they came was not part of the dream. This really occurred since the angels brought them]. But the plain sense of the verse is as we have said.

Verse 11



Verse 12



Verse 13

I AM THE G-D OF BETH-EL. Jacob related to his wives all that G-d’s angel had told him in the dream, all this serving to persuade them to go with him. However, what he told did not consist of one dream. The statement, <i>Lift up now thine eyes, and see, all the he-goats</i><sup class="footnote-marker">180</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 12 here.</i> was made to him when he served Laban for his flock, <i>at the time the flock conceived</i><sup class="footnote-marker">184</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 10 here.</i> in one of the first years.<sup class="footnote-marker">185</sup><i class="footnote">One of the first of the six years he served for the sheep. See further, 31:41.</i> The statement, <i>I am the G-d of Beth-el</i> was made to him after that, at the time of the journey, for after He said to him, <i>Now arise, get thee out from this land</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">186</sup><i class="footnote">In Verse 13 here.</i> he no longer remained in Haran to further tend Laban’s flocks so that the he-goats would mount the flocks and the flocks would give birth to speckled and spotted. But on the morrow of the dream, he sent for Rachel and Leah and told them his dream, and they left Haran.<br><i>I am ‘ha’e-il’ (the G-d) of Beth-el</i>. The meaning thereof is, as Rashi explained it, that the letter <i>hei</i> in <i>ha’e-il</i> is redundant and is the same as if it were written: “I am <i>e-il</i> Beth-el (the G-d of Beth-el).” Similarly, <i>To ‘ha’aretz’ (the land) of Canaan;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">187</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 34:2.</i> [the <i>hei</i> is redundant and is the same as if it were written: “to <i>eretz</i> Canaan (the land of Canaan).”] Grammarians<sup class="footnote-marker">188</sup><i class="footnote">Ibn Ezra and R’dak.</i> adjusted it by saying that it is as if it were written, “I am the G-d, who is the G-d of Beth-el.” Similarly, <i>And the tree of the knowledge of good and evil</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">189</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 2:9.</i> [which is as if it said: “and the tree of the knowledge, namely the knowledge of good and evil”]; <i>the cords of gold</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">190</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 39:17.</i> [which is as if it said, “the cords, which are cords of gold]. And the angel here speaks in the name of He Who sent him, [therefore, he speaks in the first person and says, “I am, etc.”] ….
WHERE THOU DIDST ANOINT A PILLAR, WHERE THOU DIDST VOW A VOW UNTO ME. The meaning thereof is that “you have vowed to worship the Proper Name of the Eternal in the Chosen Land, and that this stone should be to you a house of G-d in which to set aside your tithes,<sup class="footnote-marker">191</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 28:22.</i> and if you further delay the fulfillment of your vows, G-d might yet be angry at your voice.”<sup class="footnote-marker">192</sup><i class="footnote">See Ecclesiastes 5:5.</i>

Verse 14



Verse 15



Verse 16



Verse 17



Verse 18



Verse 19

AND RACHEL STOLE THE TERAPHIM. Her intention was to wean her father from idol-worship. This is the language of Rashi.<br>Now it is possible that Laban used the teraphim for idol worship, as he himself said, <i>Why hast thou stolen my gods?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">193</sup><i class="footnote">Further, Verse 30.</i> But not all teraphim were for the purpose of worship, for how could one find idolatry in the house of our lord David.<sup class="footnote-marker">194</sup><i class="footnote">See I Samuel 19:13, where it states that there were teraphim in David’s house.</i> That which the commentators<sup class="footnote-marker">195</sup><i class="footnote">R’dak, in his Commentary on the verse here.</i> say seems reasonable, namely, that these are vessels to receive<sup class="footnote-marker">196</sup><i class="footnote">“Receive.” According to the Tur, “determine.”</i> a knowledge of the hours, and they divine with them in order to gain knowledge of future events. The word <i>teraphim</i> is derived from the expressions: <i>‘rephai’ (weak) handed;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">197</sup><i class="footnote">II Samuel 17:2.</i> <i>‘nirpim’ (idle) ye are, idle</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">198</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 5:17.</i> They are called “teraphim” in order to hint by their name that their words are like a weak prophecy, usually occurring as a prophecy <i>for many days hence</i><sup class="footnote-marker">199</sup><i class="footnote">Ezekiel 12:27.</i> and turning out to be false, just as the prophets have said, <i>For the teraphim have spoken vanity</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">200</sup><i class="footnote">Zechariah 10:2.</i> People of little faith set them up for themselves as gods. They do not seek to know by the glorious name of the Eternal, nor do they offer their prayers to Him. Rather, their deeds are guided by divination revealed to them by the teraphim. Thus it is written, <i>And the man Micah had a house of G-d, and he made an ephod, and teraphim</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">201</sup><i class="footnote">Judges 17:5.</i> and it is further written there, <i>Ask counsel, we pray thee, of G-d that we may know whether our way which we are going shall be prosperous</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">202</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 18:5.</i> for they used to ask of the teraphim. Such also was the case in Israel with the ephod, for, having been accustomed to the sacred ephod<sup class="footnote-marker">203</sup><i class="footnote">See Exodus 25:6-12.</i> they made something similar in form, and they would seek guidance of it, believe in its words, and blunder after it. Even in sickness they sought not G-d but only them.<sup class="footnote-marker">204</sup><i class="footnote">See II Chronicles 16:12.</i> This is the meaning of the verse, <i>And Gideon made an ephod thereof, and put it in his city, even in Ophrah; and all Israel went astray after it there; and it became a snare unto Gideon, and to his house</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">205</sup><i class="footnote">Judges 8:27.</i> for they turned aside from following the Eternal. Now Laban was a diviner and an enchanter, just as he said, <i>I have divined</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">206</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 30:27.</i> His country, too, was ever a land of diviners, as it is written, <i>For they are replenished from the east, and with soothsayers like the Philistines</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">207</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 2:6. Laban’s city Haran was in the land of the children of the east (above, 29:1).</i> and Balaam the son of Beor the diviner was from his city.<sup class="footnote-marker">208</sup><i class="footnote">See Numbers 23:7.</i> And this is the meaning of, <i>Why hast thou stolen my gods?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">193</sup><i class="footnote">Further, Verse 30.</i>

Verse 20



Verse 21



Verse 22

ON THE THIRD DAY. For there was a journey of three days between them. <i>Seven days’ journey</i>—<sup class="footnote-marker">209</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 23 here.</i> throughout these three days during which the messenger had travelled to tell Laban that Jacob had proceeded on his journey, Jacob was consequently a six days’ journey distance from Laban. On the seventh day, [that is, on the day during which Jacob covered the stretch of ground which made him seven days’ journey distance from Laban’s starting point, Laban] overtook him. We may thus infer that the entire distance which Jacob covered in six<sup class="footnote-marker">210</sup><i class="footnote">“Six.” In our Rashi we have “seven,” which seems to fit the calculation better.</i> days, Laban covered in one day. These are the words of Rashi quoting Bereshith Rabbah.<sup class="footnote-marker">211</sup><i class="footnote">74:4.</i> It is correct that Laban should proceed <i>as a strong man to run his course</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">212</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 19:6.</i> for such is the way of pursuers. However, Laban <i>had set a three days’ journey</i><sup class="footnote-marker">213</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 30:36.</i> between his flock and the flock which was in Jacob’s care, not between the city and his flock. Thus if Laban tended his flocks to the east of the city, Jacob did so to the west, and between them there was <i>a three days’ journey</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">213</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 30:36.</i> Now Jacob began his journey from the city, in which were his wives, sons and daughters, and all his belongings with the exception of the flocks. The fact of his flight was told to Laban on the third day since they were not aware of it on the first day, and then Laban returned to his nearby city and took his brethren<sup class="footnote-marker">209</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 23 here.</i> from there, and starting from his city he pursued him for seven days. [Hence, it should have been said that what Jacob covered in ten days Laban covered in seven days!] We must say then, according to the opinion of Bereshith Rabbah, that it was from the field where the flocks were that Jacob left for the journey, and that Laban took his brethren with him from the shearers of his flocks. [Since there was a three days’ journey between them at the outset and Jacob had already travelled for three days, they were thus six travel days apart. On that day Laban was informed, and the following day he pursued him and overtook him. Jacob meanwhile had covered an additional day’s distance, with the result that the distance Jacob travelled in seven days, Laban covered in one day].<br>In Pirkei d’Rabbi Eliezer<sup class="footnote-marker">214</sup><i class="footnote">Chapter 36.</i> it appears that Laban returned to his city, and from there he took all mighty men and all valiant ones, and he pursued Jacob from there.

Verse 23

AND HE OVERTOOK HIM IN THE MOUNTAIN OF GILEAD. For on the eve of the seventh day Laban reached the base of the mountain, and he saw Jacob encamped at a distance. That night he slept below Jacob’s camp and the dream came to him.

Verse 24

LABAN THE ARAMEAN. The intent of this is to relate that even though he was an Aramean, and the people of his place used teraphim <i>and were soothsayers like the Philistines</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">215</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 2:6.</i> yet the prophetic dream came to him in honor of the righteous one [Jacob]. Similarly, <i>And Jacob outwitted Laban the Aramean:</i><sup class="footnote-marker">216</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 20 here.</i> [the epithet “Aramean” is mentioned in order to indicate that] even though Laban was the Aramean, the diviner and owner of teraphim, [he was still outwitted by Jacob].
EITHER GOOD OR BAD. [Why should he not speak good?] Because all the good that the wicked do is looked upon by the righteous as bad. This is Rashi’s language.
