But the plain meaning thereof is as follow: “Take heed that you speak not to Jacob and promise to treat him well if he will return with you from his journey, or lest you threaten to do him evil if he will not come with you, for it is I Who commanded him to return to his land.”

Verse 25



Verse 26



Verse 27



Verse 28



Verse 29



Verse 30



Verse 31



Verse 32



Verse 33

IN THE TENT OF JACOB AND IN THE TENT OF LEAH. Rashi comments: “<i>In the tent of Jacob</i> — this was Rachel’s tent, for he was constantly with her. And so also Scripture says, <i>The sons of Rachel Jacob’s wife</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">217</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 46:19.</i> while in the case of the other wives it does not say ‘Jacob’s wife.’ <i>And he entered into Rachel’s tent</i>. When Laban left Leah’s tent he returned again to Rachel’s tent before he searched the tent of the two maid-servants. And why did he feel compelled to do all this? Because he knew her to be inclined to touch everything.” But in line with the plain meaning of Scripture, it is not correct for the same tent to be called by two names, [i.e., “the tent of Jacob” and “the tent of Rachel”] in one verse.<br>And Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra said that Laban entered into the tent of Jacob, the tent of Leah, and the tent of the two maid-servants [the singular form “tent” being used] since one tent served both. Afterwards he came back a second time to Leah’s tent, and after that he entered into Rachel’s tent. But this too is incorrect.<br>Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra further wrote: “The feasible interpretation appears to me to be that Scripture followed here a way of brevity and delayed mentioning the tent of Rachel in order to state concerning all of the others, <i>but he found them not</i>, as they were not there. Scripture then returns and explains that when he went out of Leah’s tent he came into Rachel’s tent where the teraphim were.” That is the correct interpretation.<br>It is true that there were separate tents for all of the wives for this was due to the righteous man’s regard for modesty. Thus each one of the wives<sup class="footnote-marker">218</sup><i class="footnote">The above mentioned opinion that one tent served the two maid-servants was that of Ibn Ezra; Ramban however differs.</i> had a separate tent so that one should not know when he came to the other. It is also a matter forbidden by Torah law, as the Sages have mentioned in Tractate Niddah.<sup class="footnote-marker">219</sup><i class="footnote">17a.</i> And Jacob had a special tent, in which he would eat at his table with his children and people of the household. And the reason why Scripture mentions <i>Jacob’s wife</i><sup class="footnote-marker">217</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 46:19.</i> in connection with Rachel in my opinion, according to its simple sense, is that she is mentioned in that chapter among the concubines. For this reason Scripture does not say so in the <i>Seder Vayishlach Yaakov</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">220</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 35:23-26.</i> for there it mentions Leah and Rachel and then the maid-servants.

Verse 34



Verse 35

LET NOT MY LORD BE ANGRY THAT I CANNOT RISE UP BEFORE THEE. I do not understand what kind of an apology this is. Do women in that condition not rise or stand? Perhaps she said that her head and limbs feel heavy, and she was sick on account of the menstruation, for such is the customary way among them, and all the more among those such as Rachel, whose birth-giving powers are diminished since they have little blood,<sup class="footnote-marker">221</sup><i class="footnote">See Kethuboth 10b.</i> and menstruation presses very heavily upon them.<br>The correct interpretation appears to me to be that in ancient days menstruants kept very isolated for they were ever referred to as <i>niddoth</i> on account of their isolation since they did not approach people and did not speak with them. For the ancients in their wisdom knew that their breath is harmful, their gaze is detrimental and makes a bad impression, as the philosophers have explained. I will yet mention<sup class="footnote-marker">222</sup><i class="footnote">See Ramban Leviticus 18:19.</i> their experiences in this matter. And the menstruants dwelled isolated in tents where no one entered, just as our Rabbis have mentioned in the <i>Beraitha</i><sup class="footnote-marker">223</sup><i class="footnote">“Exterior,” a teaching of the <i>Tannaim</i> that for some reason had not been included in the Mishnah by Rabbi Yehudah Hanasi. The collection of <i>Beraithoth</i> was compiled by Rabbi Chiyah and Rabbi Oshayah. They are generally found in the <i>Tosephta</i>. which follows the order of the Mishnah.</i> of Tractate Niddah:<sup class="footnote-marker">224</sup><i class="footnote">There are differences of opinion among scholars concerning this <i>Beraitha</i>. See my Hebrew commentary, p. 177, and commencing with the second edition also on p. 548, column 2, top of page.</i> “A learned man<sup class="footnote-marker">225</sup><i class="footnote">The meaning of the word <i>talmid</i> or <i>talmud</i> here is not clear.</i> is forbidden to greet a menstruant. Rabbi Nechemyah says, ‘Even the utterance of her mouth is unclean.’ Said Rabbi Yochanan: ‘One is forbidden to walk after a menstruant and tread upon her footsteps, which are as unclean as a corpse; so is the dust upon which the menstruant stepped unclean, and it is forbidden to derive any benefit from her work.’” Therefore Rachel said, “It would be proper for me to rise before my lord to kiss his hands, but <i>the way of women is upon me</i>, and I cannot come near you nor walk at all in the tent so that you should not tread upon the dust of my feet.” And Laban kept silent and did not answer her, as it was customary not to converse with them at all because the speech of a menstruant was unclean.

Verse 36

AND JACOB WAS WROTH, AND QUARRELLED WITH LABAN. Jacob had originally given him permission to search the tents, for he said, <i>With whomsoever thou findest thy gods</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">226</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 26 here.</i> and he further said, <i>before our brethren recognize what is thine with me</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">226</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 26 here.</i> and how could Laban find it if not by searching and handling? At first, however, Jacob feared lest one of the wives or servants had stolen Laban’s gods, and now that he saw that they were not with them his anger was aroused, for he said, “He did not lose his gods, only <i>he is seeking a quarrel with me</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">227</sup><i class="footnote">Judges 14:4.</i> So he said, “<i>Why have you hotly pursued after me</i> as one pursues a thief? You have not found in my possession anything <i>of all thy household stuff</i><sup class="footnote-marker">228</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 37 here.</i> though I was entitled to take from you all I could for you have <i>changed my hire ten times</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">229</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 41 here.</i> and you demanded of me recompense for the animals that were torn by beasts,<sup class="footnote-marker">230</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 39 here.</i> and I paid you, though not legally by law required to do so.”

Verse 37



Verse 38



Verse 39



Verse 40



Verse 41



Verse 42

AND THE FEAR OF ISAAC HAD BEEN ON MY SIDE. “He did not want to say “G-d of Isaac” because G-d does not associate His name with the righteous during their lifetime. Although G-d said to Jacob when he was departing from the Land of Israel, <i>I am the Eternal, the G-d of Abraham thy father and the G-d of Isaac</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">231</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 28:13.</i> this was because Isaac’s eyes were dim, and he might therefore be regarded as dead. Jacob, however, feared to say so, [and instead said, ‘the Fear of Isaac’].” Thus the words of Rashi. It is also the opinion of Onkelos that <i>pachad Yitzchak</i> means “his G-d,” for he translated it as: “He Whom Isaac fears.”<br>And Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra said: “Isaac’s fear of G-d helped me, for the merit of the father helps the son. <i>And Jacob swore ‘bepachad’ of his father Isaac</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">232</sup><i class="footnote">Further, Verse 53.</i> — by Him Whom Isaac fears.” Ibn Ezra’s explanations of the same expression are thus not alike. Ibn Ezra further wrote,<sup class="footnote-marker">232</sup><i class="footnote">Further, Verse 53.</i> “And there are some who say<sup class="footnote-marker">233</sup><i class="footnote">Found in R’dak.</i> that this ‘fear’ is an allusion to the day of Isaac’s Binding.” This is not far fetched.<br>By way of the Truth [namely, the mystic lore of the Cabala] the language fits its plain meaning and intent, that is, it refers to the attribute of Justice on high.<sup class="footnote-marker">234</sup><i class="footnote">See Ramban above, 9:12.</i> Based on this, Scripture says: <i>Afterward shall the children of Israel return, and seek the Eternal their G-d, and David their king; and shall come trembling unto the Eternal and to His goodness in the end of days</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">235</sup><i class="footnote">Hosea 3:5.</i> The verse is stating that they will seek the Merciful One and the attribute of Justice on earth, and bring the Fear of Isaac to G-d and His goodness mentioned.
‘VAYOCHACH’ YESTERNIGHT. “The word here has the meaning of ‘reproof’ [<i>and he reproved</i>] and not of ‘clarification.’” These are the words of Rashi. But is is more correct to say that it is an expression meaning “clarification.” Since Jacob said above, <i>‘veyochichu’ (that they may judge) between us both</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">228</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 37 here.</i> he now said that it is G-d, Who knows the hidden secrets, Who should clarify the dispute between the two of them. This is why Jacob did not say, <i>vayochach othcha emesh</i>, [which would mean, “and He reproved ‘thee’ yesternight,” for the meaning of the word is not “rebuke” but “clarify”].

Verse 43

AND TO MY DAUGHTERS, WHAT CAN I DO TO THESE TODAY? Commentators have said<sup class="footnote-marker">236</sup><i class="footnote">Ibn Ezra and R’dak.</i> that it is as if it were written, “And to my daughters, what could I do to <i>them</i> today?” and the word “them” constitutes additional clarification. Likewise, <i>As we both of us have sworn</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">237</sup><i class="footnote">I Samuel 20:42.</i> [the word “we” serving as additional clarification]; <i>We, our sons and our daughters</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">238</sup><i class="footnote">Nehemiah 5:2.</i> [the word “we” is here too mentioned for the greater clarity].<br>But it appears to be more correct that this is said in a compassionate way: “<i>And to my daughters, what can I do to these</i> who are before me, for I am deeply stirred for them, <i>or unto their children</i>, who have been born in my house, and they are to me as my children?” This is also the meaning of <i>whom they have borne</i>. Laban thus said this as if defending himself against Jacob’s words by claiming: “I have come after you to see my daughters, and to determine what favor I can do for them or their children. Now I can do them this good by seeing that you make me a covenant that you will not afflict them and will take no other wives in addition to them.”<sup class="footnote-marker">239</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 50 here.</i>

Verse 44

‘VEHAYAH’ FOR A WITNESS. This means, “And let the Holy One, blessed be He, serve as a witness.” These are the words of Rashi. But this is not the usual sense of the expression. Rather, Laban is saying, “And let the covenant be for a witness between us, for he who violates it should be cursed with all <i>the curses of the covenant</i>,”<sup class="footnote-marker">240</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 29:20.</i> similar in meaning to the verse, <i>And they shall be upon thee for a sign and for a wonder</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">241</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 28:46.</i> The meaning of the verse here may be: “Let us establish a covenant by a permanent thing which will serve as a witness between us.” For this reason, Jacob set up a stone as a pillar, and this is the meaning of that which he said, <i>This stone-heap be witness, and this pillar be witness</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">242</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 52 here.</i> A similar meaning is found in the verse, <i>And Joshua said unto all the people: Behold, this stone shall be a witness against us</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">243</sup><i class="footnote">Joshua 24:27.</i>

Verse 45



Verse 46

AND JACOB SAID UNTO HIS BRETHREN. I.e., to Laban’s brothers mentioned above,<sup class="footnote-marker">244</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 23 here.</i> who had accompanied him, as Jacob did not want to say it to his father-in-law whom he treated with respect. Likewise, the verse, <i>And he</i> [Jacob] <i>called his brethren to eat bread</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">245</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 54 here.</i> also refers to Laban’s brothers, and he did not invite Laban to eat bread as an act of respect, as if everything is under his authority and is all his. A similar case is the verse, <i>And Pharaoh said unto his brethren: What is your occupation?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">246</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 47:3.</i> [which means he said it to Joseph’s brethren]. But Rashi explained: “<i>And Jacob said unto his brethren</i> — to Jacob’s brothers, [meaning, his sons, who were like brothers to him since they stood by him in trouble and in battle].” However, those that came with Laban, whom Scripture calls “his brethren”, were really his friends and companions.<br>It is possible that that which is said concerning Laban, <i>And he took his brethren with him</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">244</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 23 here.</i> refers to his kinsmen, members of his family from the seed of Nahor the brother of Abraham. He did this because he did not want to bring against Jacob strangers lest they fight with him intensely, or covet, rob and steal his belongings. Thus these men were kinsmen to Jacob just as to Laban, and therefore they are called “brethren” of both.<br>And some say<sup class="footnote-marker">247</sup><i class="footnote">P’sikta Zutrata above on Chapter 29, Verse 4.</i> that Jacob ethically referred to them as “my brothers,” just as he said to the shepherds, <i>My brethren, whence are ye?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">248</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 29:4.</i> And in Bereshith Rabbah, the Sages have said:<sup class="footnote-marker">249</sup><i class="footnote">74:11.</i> “<i>And Jacob said unto his brethren</i> — these are his sons, whom, in a respectful manner, he called his brothers.” However, with respect to the verse, <i>And he called his brethren to eat bread</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">245</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 54 here.</i> the Midrash did not explain [that “his brethren” refers to his sons]! The correct interpretation is the one I wrote at the outset.
AND THEY DID EAT THERE UPON THE STONE-HEAP. They ate a little there as a remembrance. Perhaps it was customary for both of those who made a covenant to eat from one bread as a sign of love and companionship. After having entered into an oath and a covenant, they offered sacrifices and made a great feast. It is possible that the verse stating, <i>and they did eat there upon the stone-heap</i>, refers to the offerings mentioned below,<sup class="footnote-marker">250</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 54 here.</i> for he said to them, “<i>Gather stones</i><sup class="footnote-marker">251</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 46 here.</i> and we will make a heap to eat thereon, and it will also serve as a witness when we make the covenant,” and afterwards they ate the offerings upon it. And the meaning of the verse, <i>And they did eat bread</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">250</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 54 here.</i> is that Jacob made them a great feast, and not just a party, in order that they should tarry with him all night.

Verse 47



Verse 48

AND LABAN SAID, THIS STONE-HEAP IS A WITNESS. After Jacob had called it Galed,<sup class="footnote-marker">252</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 47 here.</i> Laban spoke in Jacob’s language, <i>This stone-heap is a witness</i>, and therefore its name was called Galed, for they mutually agreed upon this name. It may be that Laban’s words are translated into the Sacred Language, [but he himself did not use the term Galed].

Verse 49

AND MITZPAH. Rashi comments that the meaning of the verse is: “And the Mitzpah which is on Mount Gilead, as it is written, <i>And he passed over Mitzpah of Gilead</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">253</sup><i class="footnote">Judges 11:29.</i> Why was it called Mitzpah? Because each of them said to the other, <i>The Eternal ‘yitzeph’ (watch)</i>.” And if so, Mitzpah is the name of a high place on top of the mountain. In my opinion, however, Mitzpah is the stone which Jacob set up for a pillar<sup class="footnote-marker">254</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 45 here.</i> and is connected with the above verse: <i>Therefore was the name of it called Galed</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">255</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 48 here.</i> <i>and he</i> also <i>called it the Mitzpah because he said, The Eternal watch between me and thee</i>. It is possible that this stone is Mitzpah of Gilead,<sup class="footnote-marker">253</sup><i class="footnote">Judges 11:29.</i> for the place was always called by the name of this stone.

Chapter 32



Verse 1



Verse 2

AND THE ANGELS OF G-D MET HIM. Rashi comments: “The angels who minister in the Land of Israel came to meet him. <i>And he called the name of that place Mahanaim</i>: the plural form implies two camps, one consisting of the angels ministering outside of the Land of Israel who had accompanied him thus far, the other consisting of those ministering in the Land of Israel who had come forth to meet him.”<br>But I wonder at this, for Jacob had not yet reached the Land of Israel and was still distant from there for he sent messengers to Esau from afar. And then it says there, <i>And he passed over the ford of the Jabbok</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">256</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 32:23.</i> which is <i>the river Jabbok which is the border of the children of Ammon</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">257</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 3:16.</i> This is to the southeast of the Land of Israel, and he still had to pass the boundary of the children of Ammon and Moab, and then the land of Edom, and his first entry into the Land was at Shechem, as it is said, <i>And Jacob came in peace to the city of Shechem, which is in the land of Canaan</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">258</sup><i class="footnote">Further 33:18. This poses a difficulty to Rashi’s interpretation of “Mahanaim.”</i> Instead, we must say this vision came to Jacob as he arrived in enemy territory in order to inform him that “they that are with him are more than they that are with them.”<sup class="footnote-marker">259</sup><i class="footnote">See II Kings 6:16.</i> And the name of the place was called “Mahanaim” in the plural, for such is the way of Scripture with names.<sup class="footnote-marker">260</sup><i class="footnote">For a single event or person, a plural name is given, as for example, “Mitzraim”.</i> It may be that “Mahanaim” refers to His camp and the camp of the higher beings,<sup class="footnote-marker">261</sup><i class="footnote">In that case the plural in the word Mahanaim is naturally justified.</i> that is to say that His camp on earth is as the camp of the angels, all of them being camps of G-d, blessing Him and confessing His Unity, may His name be blessed forever.

Verse 3



Verse 4

This section was written in order to inform us that the Holy One, blessed be He, delivered His servant, <i>and He redeemed him from the hand of him that is stronger than he</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">Jeremiah 31:11.</i> <i>and he sent an angel</i><sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 20:16.</i> and saved him, and in order to further teach us that Jacob did not place his trust in his righteousness and that he strove for delivery with all his might. There is yet in this section a hint for future generations, for everything that happened to our father with his brother Esau will constantly occur to us with Esau’s children, and it is proper for us to adhere to the way of the righteous<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">See Job 17:9.</i> by preparing ourselves in the three things for which he prepared himself: for prayer, for giving him a present, and for rescue by methods of warfare, to flee and to be saved. Our Rabbis have already derived this hint from this section, as I shall mention.
TO ESAU HIS BROTHER UNTO THE LAND SE’IR. Since the southern part of the Land of Israel adjoins Edom, and Jacob’s father <i>dwelt in the land of the South</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 24:62.</i> he had to pass through Edom or near there. Therefore, he feared lest Esau hear of it, and he took the initiative by sending messengers to him in his country. But the Sages have already taken him to task for this, saying in Bereshith Rabbah:<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">75:2.</i> “<i>Like one that taketh a dog by the ears is he that passeth by, and meddleth with a strife not his own</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 26:17.</i> The Holy One, blessed be He, said to Jacob, ‘Esau was going his way, and you send him messengers, and say to him, <i>Thus saith thy servant Jacob!</i>“<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 5 here.</i><br>In my opinion this too hints at the fact that we instigated our falling into the hand of Edom [Rome] for the Hasmonean kings during the period of the Second Temple entered into a covenant with the Romans,<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">In Maccabees, I, 8, it is related how Judah Maccabee sent a delegation to Rome to establish a political alliance with the Romans.</i> and some of them even went to Rome to seek an alliance. This was the cause of their falling into the hands of the Romans. This is mentioned in the words of our Rabbis,<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">Abodah Zarah 8b.</i> and is well publicized in books.<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">Ramban is undoubtedly referring to the history book of Josippon, or Joseph ben Gorion, a medieval work regarded as the Hebrew version of Josephus Flavius. It was a popular work with the people of the Middle Ages. See also Ramban on Leviticus 26:16.</i>

Verse 5

THUS SHALL YE SAY UNTO MY LORD ESAU: THUS SAITH THY SERVANT JACOB. He commanded them that they should say “to my lord Esau we belong,” or “we were sent to him,”<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">The intent of Ramban is to state that Jacob, speaking to his servants, did not refer to Esau as “my lord Esau,” but rather he commanded them to use the expression in Esau’s presence.</i> and to say to him, <i>Thus saith thy servant Jacob: I have sojourned with Laban</i>. A similar example in this section is the verse: <i>When Esau my brother meeteth thee, and asketh thee, saying, Whose art thou?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">Further, Verse 18. The verse concludes that they are to tell him that it is a gift “to my lord Esau.” Again Jacob is telling them what to say.</i> It may be that in their presence Jacob called Esau “my lord Esau” in order to caution them not to mention Esau in any other but a respectful way even when not in his presence, inasmuch as their lord calls him “my lord.”<br>Know that this respect which Jacob showed for his brother by fearfully saying “my lord” and “thy servant” was due to it being the custom of the younger brother to give recognition and respect to the firstborn as if he were his father, just as the Torah also hints to us on this matter:<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">Kethuboth 103a. Commenting on the letter <i>vav</i> in the expression, <i>ve’eth imecha</i> (“honor thy father <i>‘and’ thy mother</i>“), our Rabbis said: “This includes your oldest brother!”</i> “This includes your oldest brother.” Now Jacob had taken his birthright and his blessing, for which Esau hated him, and now he is acting towards Esau as if the effect of that sale was nil as far as he was concerned, and he is conducting himself towards him as to a firstborn and father in order to remove the hatred from his heart.

Verse 6

AND I HAVE SENT TO TELL MY LORD. I.e., “to announce that I am coming to you. <i>That I may find favour in thy sight</i> for I am at peace with you and seek your friendship.” These are Rashi’s words. Rashi’s intent is that the verse; <i>I have sent to tell my lord</i>, does not refer to the previous verse, <i>I have sojourned with Laban</i>, etc. but, instead, it says, “<i>And I have sent to tell my lord</i> that I have come <i>to find favour in thy sight</i> and to do whatever my lord will command.”<br>But it is more correct to say that it refers to the verse above: “<i>And I have sent to tell my lord</i> that I have wealth, belongings, and precious things, to do with them according to your desire and will.” He thus hinted to him that he would send him a present from them, or that Esau may take from him whatever he desires. And so, when Esau asked Jacob, <i>What meanest thou by all this camp which I met? he</i> [Jacob] <i>said: To find favour in the sight of my lord</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 33:8.</i>

Verse 7

AND THE MESSENGERS RETURNED TO JACOB, SAYING. These messengers had fulfilled their mission, but Scripture did not relate this for it would serve no purpose. The meaning of the expression, <i>And moreover he cometh to meet thee</i>, is that “even as you go to meet him, so he goes to meet you, and you will quickly encounter one another.”

Verse 8

THEN JACOB WAS GREATLY AFRAID. This was because they told him that Esau had gone forth from his city and was coming to meet Jacob, and moreover, that he took along many men — four hundred. He thus greatly feared for his life, for he said, “He has not taken all these men except for the purpose of waging war against me.”<br>It appears to me in this matter that Esau did not receive the messengers properly and paid them no heed. Perhaps they did not even come before him for he did not at all give permission for them to come before him and speak to him for otherwise, Scripture would have related that Esau questioned them concerning his brother’s welfare and about his circumstances and those of his household and children. [Scripture further would have told how Esau requested] that they convey greetings to Jacob and tell him that he is proceeding towards him to see him, and they would have told it thus to Jacob. Scripture, however, does not narrate that the messengers transmitted a word in Esau’s name. Instead, he [Esau] kept his wrath in his heart,<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">See Amos 1:11.</i> and he came with his army for the purpose of doing Jacob evil. Now the messengers had investigated the matter in the camp, and they knew that he was going to meet Jacob. This is the meaning of the word <i>vegam</i> (and moreover) [in the verse, <i>and moreover he goeth to meet thee</i>], for they said, “<i>We came to thy brother Esau</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 7 here.</i> but he did not answer us a word, and he sent you no greeting, <i>and moreover, he goeth to meet thee</i> with might and an army.” This was why he added fear to his fear, as Scripture says, <i>And Jacob was greatly afraid, and was distressed</i>. And so our Rabbis said that the messengers recognized hatred in him[Esau]. Thus they said:<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">Bereshith Rabbah 75:7.</i> “<i>We came to thy brother Esau</i>. You behave towards him like a brother, but he behaves towards you like Esau the villain.” However, in the end, when Esau saw the great honor that Jacob bestowed upon him and how he prostrated himself before him, bowing to the ground seven times<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 33:3.</i> from the distance until he approached him, his mercy was aroused, and he thought that Jacob is recognizing his birthright and his pre-eminence, as I have explained.<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">Above, Verse 5.</i> And with this he was comforted, for the hearts belong to G-d, Who turns them whither He will.<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">See Proverbs 21:1.</i>

Verse 9

THEN THE CAMP WHICH IS LEFT SHALL ESCAPE. In line with the simple meaning of Scripture, Jacob stated this as a possibility. He said that perhaps one camp shall escape, for during the time he [Esau] smites one, the other will flee, or perhaps his anger will subside or deliverance will come to them from G-d. And so the Rabbis said in Bereshith Rabbah,<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">76:2.</i> “The Torah teaches you proper conduct: a man should not leave all his money in one corner.” And Rashi wrote: “‘<i>Then the camp which is left shall escape</i> in spite of him for I will fight against him.’ He prepared himself for three things: for prayer, for giving Esau a gift, and for war.” And I have seen in the Midrash:<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">Tanchuma, Buber, Vayishlach 6.</i> “What did Jacob do? He armed his people underneath, and clothed them in white from outside, and he prepared himself for three things.” And this is the most correct [interpretation, in line with Rashi and the Midrash, who say that he prepared himself also for war, as opposed to the simple meaning first mentioned].<br>The intent of this is that Jacob knew that all his seed would not fall into Esau’s hands. Therefore, in any case, one camp would be saved. This also implies that the children of Esau will not formulate a decree against us designed to obliterate our name entirely, but they will do evil to some of us in some of their countries. One of their kings will formulate a decree in his country against our wealth or our persons while simultaneously another king will show compassion in his place and save the refugees.<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">A clear echo of Ramban’s times is hereby heard. While waves of persecution, expulsions and massacres were a steady feature of Jewish life in most European countries, refuge was always found in some country. At the time of Ramban, Spain was a place of relative relief for Jews from France and Germany.</i> And so the Rabbis said in Bereshith Rabbah,<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">76:3.</i> “<i>If Esau come to the one camp, and smite it</i> — these are our brethren in the south. <i>Then the camp which is left shall escape</i> — these are our brethren in the Diaspora.” Our Rabbis thus saw that this chapter alludes also to the future generations.

Verse 10



Verse 11

‘KATONTI’ OF ALL THE MERCIES, AND OF ALL THE TRUTH. “My merits have diminished as a consequence of all the kindness and truth which You have already shown me. For this reason I am afraid lest I have become depraved by sin since the time You made these promises to me, and this may cause me to be delivered into the hand of Esau.” This is Rashi’s language. But it is not a correct interpretation because it does not fit into the language of the verse, [for <i>katan</i> refers to size, not quantity]. Furthermore, Jacob said afterwards, <i>And Thou saidst: I will surely do thee good and make thy seed as the sand of the sea</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 13 here.</i> but of what efficacy would this promise be if subsequent sin caused him to be deprived of it? Moreover, Jacob mentioned two promises which the Holy One, blessed be He, had made him — one in Beth-el,<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 28:15.</i> and one in Haran<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 31:3.</i> — and he first stated the promise given to him in Haran, <i>O Eternal, who saidst unto me: Return unto thy country, and to thy kindred, and I will do to thee good</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 10 here.</i> this being what was said to him when he was about to leave the house of Laban: <i>Return unto the land of thy fathers, and to thy kindred, and I will be with thee</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 31:3.</i> Now following this promise, G-d did not bestow good upon Jacob to account for all these mercies and truths of which Jacob mentioned that his merits should be diminished on account of them.<br>The word <i>katonti</i> rather means that he is too small to have been worthy of all the mercies which He had done for him. Likewise, <i>How shall Jacob stand? for he is small</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote">Amos 7:2.</i> that is, too small to be able to bear all that was decreed against him. And so the Rabbis said in Bereshith Rabbah,<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">76:4.</i> “<i>Katonti</i>. Rabbi Abba said that it means ‘I am not worthy.’” Now <i>hachasadim</i> (the mercies) are the kindnesses which G-d did for him without having vowed to do them, and <i>ha’emeth</i> (the truth) is the kindness which He promised him and fulfilled. Jacob thus said that he was unworthy of G-d’s promising him and performing those kindnesses which He promised him, nor was he worthy of those other many kindnesses which He did for him without having promised to do them.<br>But I have not understood the opinion of Onkelos who translated, “from all the mercies and all the good,” when he is accustomed to translate <i>chesed ve’emeth</i> as “mercy and truth.” Perhaps Onkelos is rendering <i>chasadim</i> here as referring to Jacob’s rescue, that is, the many times He had saved him from his troubles. Onkelos rendered <i>emeth</i> as referring to all this good which Jacob possessed, for G-d had given him sons and daughters, wealth and belongings, and honor.<br>The correct interpretation appears to me to be that long-lasting kindnesses such as children and wealth are called <i>emeth</i>, which is from the root of <i>emunah</i> (faith), just as: ‘<i>Vene’eman</i>’ <i>(and confirmed shall be) thy house and thy kingdom forever</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">II Samuel 7:16. This was said to David, whose kingdom was assured of existence.</i> which connotes assured existence; <i>His bread shall be given, his waters ‘ne’emanim’ (shall be sure)</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 33:16.</i> just as the prophet said, <i>Wilt thou indeed be unto me as a deceitful brook as waters that are not ‘ne’emanu’ (sure)?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote">Jeremiah 15:18.</i>

Verse 12

AND HE SMITE ME, THE MOTHER WITH THE CHILDREN. Commentators<sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote">Mentioned in Ibn Ezra. The verb “smite” thus applies to the beginning and end of the sentence.</i> have explained it as meaning. “And he smite me and smite the mother with the children.” There are many similar verses.

Verse 13

AND THOU SAIDST: I WILL SURELY DO THEE GOOD. Even though he was afraid lest the sin cause him to lose that which he was promised, Jacob said: “You have done great kindnesses for me even though I was unworthy of them. Certainly You will do for me this undeserved kindness which You have promised me, namely, that You will bestow good upon me and increase my seed. My sin should not withhold from me the good You have promised me, for in the beginning I was also unworthy of it had You marked against me mine iniquities.<sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote">See Psalms 130:3.</i> And You did not promise it to me on account of my deeds, but only out of Your abundant mercies.”<br>And some commentators say<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote">Ibn Ezra. Thus Jacob’s fear was not lest his sin cause him to lose that which he was promised, but because he did not know, etc., as explained in the text.</i> that Jacob had compassion for his children and household lest Esau smite them, because he did not know whether the promise, <i>And thy seed shall be as the dust of the earth</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 28:14.</i> applied to these or to others, it being possible that he himself would escape and have additional children. But in my opinion this is not correct, for if this was his thought, how did he say in his prayer, <i>And Thou saidst: I will surely do thee good and make thy seed as the sand of the sea?</i> Moreover, it was told to him in Beth-el, <i>And behold, I am with thee, and will keep thee whithersoever thou goest, and I will bring thee back into this land</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 28:15.</i> If his children were to fall before his brother’s sword, this promise would not be fulfilled, and it is to this promise that Jacob alluded when he said, <i>And Thou saidst: I will surely do thee good</i>. Similarly with the promise, <i>And I will do thee good:</i><sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 10 here.</i> all this Jacob said on the basis of it having been said to him, <i>And I will be with thee</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 31:3.</i> But all his misgivings were on account of the fear of sin, for it is the way of the righteous to be always fearful. Thus Jacob was fearful that perhaps even after he left Haran, he sinned by entering into a covenant with Laban, who was an idol-worshipper, or in some other matter, and <i>Who can discern errors?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 19:13.</i>

Verse 14

OF THAT WHICH HE HAD WITH HIM A PRESENT. Scripture states that he composed a gift out of that which he had since his wealth consisted of flocks and herds, and it was from them that Jacob sent a gift, for he was en-route and he had no opportunity to send him <i>vessels of silver, and vessels of gold… and precious things</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 24:53.</i>

Verse 15



Verse 16



Verse 17

AND PUT A SPACE BETWEEN DROVE AND DROVE. I.e., in order to satisfy the covetous eye of that wicked man and to amaze him by the size of the gift. In Bereshith Rabbah<sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote">75:13.</i> the Rabbis express the opinion that there is an allusion to the future in this matter: “Jacob said before the Holy One, blessed be He, ‘O Master of the universe! If troubles will come upon my children, do not bring them one after another, but allow them intervals from their troubles.’” On the basis of this verse, the Rabbis thus hinted that the tributes and taxes which the children of Esau will collect from Jacob’s seed will have intervals and cessations between one another.

Verse 18



Verse 19



Verse 20



Verse 21

‘ACHAPRAH’ (I WILL APPEASE) HIM WITH THE PRESENT. I.e., “I will dissipate his anger.” Similarly: <i>‘Vechupar’ (and annulled shall be) your covenant with death;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 28:18.</i> <i>Thou shalt not be able ‘kaprah’ (to put it away)</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">42</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 47:11.</i> I am of the opinion that whenever the word <i>kaparah</i> is used in association with iniquity and sin and in association with the word <i>panim</i> (anger), it always signifies erasing and removing. It is an Aramaic expression occurring frequently in the Talmud: “He wished to wipe his hands on that man.”<sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote">Gittin 56a.</i> In Biblical Hebrew, also, the bowls in the Sanctuary are called <i>‘Kipurei’ of gold</i><sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote">Ezra 1:10.</i> because the priest wiped his hand on them, that is, on the rims of the bowl. These are the words of our Rabbi Shlomo [Rashi]. And so also did Onkelos translate: “I will calm his anger.” If so, the explanation of the verse will [not] be that Jacob said these words, but that Jacob thought to himself, “I will appease him.” It is Scripture that tells us this [but it is not part of Jacob’s instructions to his messengers], for it would have been improper for the messengers to do so and thereby remind Esau of his antagonism towards Jacob. And so did Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra explain it.<br>But it does not appear to me to be correct that Scripture should find it necessary to tell us Jacob’s thought at this time when it is a well known matter pertaining to all who send presents. Besides, if it were so, Scripture should have mentioned this originally [in connection with the first drove, in Verse 19] , <i>And, behold, he is also behind us</i>, for he thought, “I will appease him with the present,” for now [when commanding the leaders of the second and third droves] he did not add to that instruction [which he gave the leader of the first drove].<br>However, the correct interpretation is that now Jacob additionally explained to them that they should say in a respectful manner, <i>Behold, he is also behind us</i>, that is to say, “Behold, your servant Jacob is also behind us, and he has sent us before him in order to give <i>a ransom for his life</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">45</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 30:12.</i> using this present as a means of seeing your honor’s face, just as servants present their ransom when they are given permission to see the king’s face. <i>And afterward I will see his face</i>, for <i>perhaps he will accept me</i> and honor me by permitting me to be among those <i>who see the king’s face</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">46</sup><i class="footnote">Esther 1:14.</i> This was a way of expressing Esau’s exalted status and was due to Jacob’s fear of him. The expression <i>achaprah panav</i> is then being used as it is used in the verse, <i>The wrath of a king is as messengers of death; but a wise man ‘yechaprenah,’</i><sup class="footnote-marker">47</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 16:14. </i> meaning he will give ransom to allay the wrath. And the connotation of “wiping away” attached to forgiveness is not valid in the Sacred Language but rather in the Aramaic tongue. Similarly, <i>‘kipurei’ of gold</i><sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote">Ezra 1:10.</i> is the Babylonian name for bowls, for the word <i>kaparah</i> is never used in association with “sin,” meaning “wipe away,” but instead Scripture says: <i>‘lechapeir’ (to make atonement) for your souls;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">48</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 30:15.</i> <i>‘lechapeir’ (to make atonement) for him, and he shall be forgiven</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">49</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 15:28.</i> i.e., for his soul. And Scripture also says: <i>‘achaprah’ (I shall make atonement) for your sin</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">50</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 32:30.</i> All of these are related to the expression, <i>Then shall they give every man ‘kopher’ for his soul</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">45</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 30:12.</i> which means a ransom.

Verse 22

AND HE HIMSELF LODGED THAT NIGHT IN THE CAMP. Scripture states that he did not enter his tent that night but lodged in the camp together with his servants and the shepherds of the flocks, <i>set in array, as a man for war</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote">Jeremiah 6:23.</i> lest his brother come at night and attack him.

Verse 23

AND HE TOOK HIS TWO WIVES, AND HIS TWO HANDMAIDS. There is no significance to being mentioned earlier or later in this verse with respect to rescue work. [Hence even though his wives are mentioned here first, from which you might infer that they appeared before Esau first, Scripture later states — 33:6 — that the handmaids came first.] Instead, Scripture states that he gathered his wives and handmaids and children at the edge of the brook, and he alone traversed the ford of the Jabbok to see if the waters were high, and then he returned and took them all with him at one time <i>and made them pass the brook</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">52</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 24 here.</i> and after that <i>he made pass that which was his</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">52</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 24 here.</i> namely, his camp and his belongings.

Verse 24



Verse 25

AND JACOB WAS LEFT ALONE. That is, for he had forgotten some small jars, and he returned for them. These are the words of Rashi. But in line with the plain meaning of Scripture, the verse, <i>And he took them, and made them pass the brook</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">52</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 24 here.</i> means that he made them [his family] pass together with him, <i>and he made pass that which was his</i><sup class="footnote-marker">52</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 24 here.</i> — [i.e., his camp and his belongings] — by commanding others to do it. He returned [to his camp after ferrying his family across], and he commanded that all others pass over the brook before him, and so he remained behind them.
‘VAYEI’AVEIK’ A MAN WITH HIM, A man covered himself with dust. So Menachem ben Saruk explained it, being derived from the word <i>avak</i> (dust); by their movements, they were raising dust with their feet. I, however, am of the opinion that it means “and he attached himself to,” and that it is an Aramaic word, as in, “After they have joined (<i>aviku</i>) it;”<sup class="footnote-marker">53</sup><i class="footnote">Sanhedrin 63b.</i> “And they twined the Fringes with loops.”<sup class="footnote-marker">54</sup><i class="footnote">Menachoth 42a.</i> This is all the language of Rashi.<br/>In the language of the Sages, <i>avikah</i> is often used to convey the sense of <i>chavikah</i> (loop), as in: “There are <i>avkso</i> (loops) in the punishing scourge;”<sup class="footnote-marker">55</sup><i class="footnote">Makkoth 23a.</i>, “A couch is called <i>dargesh</i> when it is set up and taken apart by means of loops, through which the cords are fastened.”<sup class="footnote-marker">56</sup><i class="footnote">Nedarim 56b.</i> Similarly the word <i>avukah</i> (a torch) is so called in the language of the Sages because it is made up of small pieces of wood which are tied and bound together. This is because the letter <i>cheth</i> is difficult to pronounce in their language and so they used the easier <i>aleph</i>. Many times the <i>cheth</i> disappears completely as in <i>tuteich</i><sup class="footnote-marker">57</sup><i class="footnote">Chullin 7 b: <i>metutei</i> (from beneath her feet).</i> (underneath) in place of <i>techuteich; mesuta</i><sup class="footnote-marker">58</sup><i class="footnote">Kiddushin 33a.</i> (a bath) in place of <i>maschuta; asita</i><sup class="footnote-marker">59</sup><i class="footnote">Shabbath 77b.</i> (a mortar) in place of <i>chasita</i>. And it is possible that the word <i>vayei’aveik</i> is actually <i>vayeichaveik</i>, as <i>vayechabkeihu (and he embraced him)</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">60</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 33:4.</i> for perhaps it is the way of the Hebrew language to interchange the <i>aleph</i> and <i>cheth</i>. Thus we find: <i>And in the fourth chariot grizzled ‘amutzim’ horses</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">61</sup><i class="footnote">Zechariah 6:3.</i> which is the same as <i>chamitzim</i>, derived from the expression, <i>‘chamutz’ (crimsoned) garments</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">62</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 63:1.</i> Commentators<sup class="footnote-marker">63</sup><i class="footnote">R’dak in his Book of Roots, under the root <i>erez</i>.</i> have said that <i>‘va’aruzim’ for thy merchandise</i><sup class="footnote-marker">64</sup><i class="footnote">Ezekiel 27:24.</i> is like <i>vecharuzim</i>, derived from the expression, <i>thy neck ‘bacharuzim’ (with beads)</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">65</sup><i class="footnote">Song of Songs 1:10.</i> So too did they say concerning the word <i>vate’altzeihu</i><sup class="footnote-marker">66</sup><i class="footnote">Judges 16:16.</i> that it is like <i>vatechaltzeihu (and she pressed him)</i>, this being an inverted form of <i>vatilchatzeihu</i>, [the root of which is <i>lachatz</i> (oppression)]. Perhaps this is the opinion of Onkelos who said, in translation of the word <i>vayei’aveik, ve’ishtadeil</i>, and so also he translated the expression, <i>And if a man ‘yephateh’</i><sup class="footnote-marker">67</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 22:15.</i> “as if <i>yeshadeil</i>,” if he embraces and kisses which is the manner of seduction. It may be that Onkelos found no word comparable to <i>vayei’aveik</i>, and so he considered it a matter of cunning, for all effort implies cunning and a clarification of circumstances. In Bereshith Rabbah<sup class="footnote-marker">68</sup><i class="footnote">77:3.</i> the Sages said: “Who became filled with dust? The man that was with him.” This agrees with the words of Menachem [ben Saruk, who said that <i>vayei’aveik</i> means “he covered himself with dust] “, and this is the correct interpretation.

Verse 26

AND HE SAW THAT HE PREVAILED NOT AGAINST HIM. <i>Ye angels of His, ye mighty in strength, that fulfill His word</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">69</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 103:20.</i> Because of this<sup class="footnote-marker">70</sup><i class="footnote">Although the angel’s strength was superior to Jacob’s, he was restrained by G-d from harming him.</i> the angel could not prevail against him to harm him for it was not permitted to him to do other than that which he did to him, namely, to disjoint the hollow of his thigh. Now the Rabbis have said in Bereshith Rabbah:<sup class="footnote-marker">71</sup><i class="footnote">77:4.</i> “He touched all the righteous people who were destined to come from Jacob. This refers to the generation of religious persecution.”<sup class="footnote-marker">72</sup><i class="footnote">This refers to the religious persecution during the reign of Emperor Hadrian, 117-138 Common Era.</i> The purport of this Midrash is that this entire event constitutes a hint to his generations, indicating that there will be a generation from the seed of Jacob against whom Esau [Rome] will prevail to the extent of almost uprooting his seed. This occurred in one generation during the period of the Sages of the Mishnah, which was the generation of Rabbi Yehudah ben Baba<sup class="footnote-marker">73</sup><i class="footnote">In Sanhedrin, 13 b, it is recounted how this Sage suffered martyrdom for the sake of ordaining his disciples, an act which the Romans had forbidden.</i> and his companions.<sup class="footnote-marker">74</sup><i class="footnote">Possibly a reference to the <i>Assarah harugei malchuth</i>, the Ten great Rabbis who endured martyrdom rather than abide by the Hadrianic regulations.</i> As they said:<sup class="footnote-marker">75</sup><i class="footnote">Shir Hashirim Rabbah 2:18.</i> “Rabbi Chiya bar Abba said, ‘If a person were to tell me, “Give your life for the sanctification of the Name of the Holy One, blessed be He,” I would give it, providing only that they slay me immediately. But in the generation of religious persecution I could not endure!’ And what did the Romans do in that generation? They would bring iron balls and heat them in fire and then place them under their arm-pits and cause their death.” And there are other generations in which they have done to us such things as these and even worse, but we have endured and it has passed over us, just as it is hinted in the verse, <i>And Jacob came in peace</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">76</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 33:18.</i>

Verse 27



Verse 28



Verse 29



Verse 30

WHY IS IT THAT THOU DOST ASK AFTER MY NAME? The angel said: “There is no advantage to you in knowing my name for no one possesses the power and the capability other than G-d alone. If you will call upon me I will not answer you, nor will I save you from your trouble. However, I will now bless you, <i>for so I am commanded</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">77</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 8:35.</i> But Scripture does not explain the contents of the blessing. That which our Rabbis have said<sup class="footnote-marker">78</sup><i class="footnote">Mentioned in Rashi, Verse 27. See also the explanatory note on this verse in my Hebrew commentary, p. 186.</i> is most probable, namely that the angel, despite himself, conceded to him at that place the legitimacy of his father’s blessings, as Jacob did not wish to wait for him until he arrived at Beth-el.

Chapter 33



Verse 1



Verse 2



Verse 3



Verse 4



Verse 5

WHO ARE THESE WITH THEE? Esau inquired about the women and children, and Jacob modestly answered, <i>The children whom G-d hath graciously given thy servant</i>, as he did not want to say that they were his wives. Esau thereby understood that they were the mothers of the children.

Verse 6



Verse 7



Verse 8

WHAT MEANEST THOU BY ALL THIS CAMP WHICH I MET? Now Jacob’s servants did everything he had commanded them, but Esau refused to accept the explanation from them. Perhaps due to his haughtiness and his arrogance he did not speak to them and did not ask them, <i>Whose art thou ? and whither goest thou?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">79</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 32:18.</i> and they were afraid to approach him. And so he now said, <i>What meanest thou by all this camp?</i> for he thought that they belonged to Jacob on the basis of the words of the first messengers [whom Jacob had originally sent to inform Esau of his coming]. It may be that these messengers had so related in Esau’s camp, and it was then conveyed to Esau. Perhaps because there was no other individual on that road that had these things, [he assumed that they belonged to Jacob]. The intent of <i>What meanest thou by all this camp?</i> is: “Who is this person to you that you send him all these?” That is to say, “Who is this superior of yours that you send him all these?” And he answered him, “<i>To find favour in the sight of my lord</i>, for in my eyes, you are the superior and lord.”

Verse 9



Verse 10

FORASMUCH AS I HAVE SEEN THY FACE. Jacob said to him: “Take my present from me because I have seen your face, which to me is <i>as one seeth the sight of an angel, ‘vatirtzeini’ (and thou wast pleased with me)</i>, as you indicated by accepting the present,” just as <i>G-d ‘rotzeh’ (taketh pleasure) in them that fear Him</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">80</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 147:11.</i> by accepting their offerings and sacrifices. This is similar to the verses: <i>‘Venirtzah’ (And it shall be favourably accepted) for him;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">81</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 1:3.</i> <i>Their burnt-offerings and their sacrifices shall be ‘leratzon’ (acceptable) upon Mine altar</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">82</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 56:7.</i> this being associated with the expressions: <i>Let him be ‘retzui’ (the favoured) of his brethren</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">83</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 33:24.</i> <i>And the light of Thy countenance, for ‘ratzitham’ (Thou wast favourable to them)</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">84</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 44:4.</i> <i>For Thy servants ‘ratzu’ (take pleasure) in her stones</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">85</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 102:15.</i> All these forms of <i>ratzah</i> connote desire and pleasure in a matter. But Rashi wrote, “Because you have agreed to pardon my offense. <i>Vatirtzeini</i>, you are reconciled with me.” But I have already said<sup class="footnote-marker">86</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 32:21.</i> that it was not advisable for Jacob to bring iniquity to remembrance.<sup class="footnote-marker">87</sup><i class="footnote">See Ezekiel 21:28.</i>

Verse 11

TAKE, I PRAY THEE, MY BLESSING. I.e., the gift. Likewise, <i>Make your blessing with me</i><sup class="footnote-marker">88</sup><i class="footnote">II Kings 18:31.</i> means “bring me a gift” or “make your peace with me.” So also, <i>Take a blessing of thy servant</i><sup class="footnote-marker">89</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 5:15.</i> means “take a present from thy servant.” They called a gift which a man sends of his own free will “a blessing” because he sends it from that with which G-d had blessed him, just as the verse states, <i>Wherewith the Eternal thy G-d hath blessed thee thou shalt give unto him</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">90</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 15:14.</i> and just as Scripture said above, <i>And he took of that which he had with him</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">91</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 32:14.</i> However, a specific gift of that which has been agreed upon as due the king is called <i>mas</i> (tribute).

Verse 12



Verse 13

AND ALL THE FLOCKS WILL DIE. Jacob said this in a compassionate manner for he should have said, “And they will all die,” but he would not express himself this way about the children. Neither did he wish to say, “and they will die,” with reference to the herds and the flocks, because he had compassion on the children lest they be included by implication. He also did not want to be verbose and say, “and all the flocks and herds will die.” It may be that the explanation of the verse is that “<i>the children are tender — even the youths shall faint and be weary</i><sup class="footnote-marker">92</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 40:30.</i> — and they will not want to go, <i>and that the flocks and herds giving suck are a care to me</i>, and if they will be overdriven the flocks will die, as they are small cattle, but the herds [signifying larger cattle] will not die although they will be harmed.”

Verse 14

UNTIL I COME UNTO MY LORD UNTO SE’IR. In returning to his land Jacob could have gone by way of the land of Se’ir. Now Esau told him, <i>And I will go before thee</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">93</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 12 here.</i> meaning that he will not be separated from him until Jacob returns to his father in order to honor him when he comes into his land. But Jacob said, “I will proceed slowly and let my lord return to the city of his rule, and if I will return by way of his city, he will honor me and go with me as he desires.” This was not a vow on the part of Jacob that he will come to him, for Esau did not need him. Our Rabbis have further said<sup class="footnote-marker">94</sup><i class="footnote">Abodah Zarah 25 b, and mentioned here by Rashi.</i> that Jacob had no intention of returning by way of Se’ir, and his desire was to remove himself from him as much as possible, but he mentioned <i>until I come … unto Se’ir</i> in order to extend the length of his journey [so that if Esau meant to do him harm he would wait until Jacob reached his abode at Se’ir]. This also was wise counsel. The Rabbis have yet another Midrash,<sup class="footnote-marker">95</sup><i class="footnote">Bereshith Rabbah 78:18.</i> which states that Jacob will fulfill his word in the days of the Messiah, as it is said, <i>And saviours shall come up on mount Zion to judge the mount of Esau</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">96</sup><i class="footnote">Obadiah 1:21.</i> Scripture is saying that the saviors [i.e., the judges of Israel]<sup class="footnote-marker">97</sup><i class="footnote">See Judges 2:16.</i> who are on Mount Zion shall come up to judge the mount of Esau.

Verse 15

WHY THIS? LET ME FIND FAVOUR IN THE EYES OF MY LORD. <i>Why this</i>, that you should do me a favor which I do not need? <i>Let me find favour</i> in your eyes, and do not give me any recompense at present [for the gift which I have presented to you]. This is the language of Rashi. Now Jacob’s meaning was that he did not want them and their company at all, the more so since he intended to go another way.<br>Our Rabbis have further seen an advisory aspect in this entire chapter. Thus they have said:<sup class="footnote-marker">95</sup><i class="footnote">Bereshith Rabbah 78:18.</i> “Before embarking on a journey to the Roman ruler, Rabbi Yanai would peruse this section of the Torah, and he never took Romans with him as an escort on the return journey. One time he did not peruse this section and he took Romans with him, and he had not yet reached Acco when he was compelled to sell his travelling cloak for bribery money.” [The significance attached to this chapter] was because of the Rabbinical tradition that this was the section of the exile. Therefore when Rabbi Yanai entered Rome, in the court of the kings of Edom, [on a mission] concerning public matters, he would peruse this section of the Torah in order to follow the advice of the wise patriarch, for it is he that the generations are to see and emulate. Thus he would not accept the company of the Romans as an escort for they draw no man near to them except for their own interest<sup class="footnote-marker">98</sup><i class="footnote">Aboth 2:3.</i> and take liberties with people’s belongings.

Verse 16



Verse 17

AND HE BUILT FOR HIMSELF A HOUSE. It is possible that the place was a location which had no city, and he therefore found it necessary to build for himself a house and make booths for his cattle. Or it may be that the expression, <i>and he built for himself a house</i>, means that he built for himself a large house with a strong tower to fortify himself against Esau.

Verse 18

AND JACOB CAME IN PEACE … FROM PADDAN-ARAM. [This is stated here in the same manner] as a person says to his friend, “That man there has come from between the teeth of the lions and has arrived unhurt.” Similarly here, <i>And Jacob came in peace</i>, i.e., from Laban and from Esau. This is the language of Rashi. But Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra explained that the sense of the verse is that Jacob arrived in peace from his lengthy journey and nothing happened to him, as Scripture now begins to narrate the event of Dinah.<br>In my opinion Scripture speaks thus since for the length of his sojourn in Succoth<sup class="footnote-marker">99</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 17 here.</i> he was fearful of Esau. Succoth — if it be the one mentioned in the book of Joshua<sup class="footnote-marker">100</sup><i class="footnote">Joshua 13:27.</i> — was east of the Jordan, in the kingdom of Sihon, and if it be another city by that name, it was nearer to Se’ir. Thus until he entered the land of Canaan Jacob did not feel safe, for only then did he know that Esau would not touch him for his father was nearby, or because the people of the land would help him as his father was a prince of G-d in their midst, or because the merit of having entered the land would save him. And therefore, Scripture now said that he came in peace into the land of his father’s sojourning<sup class="footnote-marker">101</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 37:1. </i> since G-d delivered him in his travels <i>out of the hand of all his enemies</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">102</sup><i class="footnote">II Samuel 22:1.</i> And the Rabbis have said in Bereshith Rabbah<sup class="footnote-marker">103</sup><i class="footnote">78:20.</i> that during all these months that our father Jacob stayed in Succoth he honored Esau with that present enumerated above<sup class="footnote-marker">104</sup><i class="footnote">32:14-15.</i> by Scripture for he was afraid of him there, and monthly or annually he would send him a comparable present.
AND HE ENCAMPED BEFORE THE CITY. He did not wish to be a transient lodger in the city, but rather he wished that his inaugural entrance into the land should be into his own property. Therefore he encamped in the field and bought a place for the purpose of taking possession of the land. This action constituted a hint that this place will be conquered by him first<sup class="footnote-marker">105</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 34:28.</i> before the dwellers of the land would be driven from before his seed, just as I have explained in the case of Abraham.<sup class="footnote-marker">106</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 12:6.</i> And our Rabbis have said:<sup class="footnote-marker">107</sup><i class="footnote">Bereshith Rabbah 79:7.</i> “He arrived on Friday close to sundown [and was therefore compelled to encamp <i>before the city</i> as there was no time left to enter the city], and he set Sabbath limits [while it was yet day.” The verse thus teaches us that Jacob observed the Sabbath before it was declared on Sinai]. Now according to this opinion of the Rabbis the act of Jacob encamping there first was unintentional. However, in any case, the event hinted to the future as we have said. Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra however said that Scripture mentions this in order to inform us that there is great excellence to the Land of Israel, and he who owns a part thereof has it considered as a portion in the World to Come.

Verse 19



Verse 20

AND HE CALLED ‘LO’ (IT) E-IL-ELOKEI-ISRAEL. It does not mean that the altar was called “The G-d of Israel,” but because the Holy One, blessed be He, had been with him to deliver him, he named the altar in honor of the miracle so that the praise of the Holy One, blessed be He, would be recalled when people referred to the altar. Thus it would mean, “He Who is <i>E-il</i> is the G-d of me whose name is Israel.” Similarly we find in the case of Moses: <i>And he called its</i> [the altar’s] <i>name Adonai-nissi</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">108</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 17:15.</i> It is not that the altar was called by the Divine Name <i>Adonai</i> but rather that he named the altar in honor of the miracle so that the praise of the Holy One, blessed be He, might be mentioned: “G-d — He is my banner.” Our Rabbis expounded that the Holy One, blessed be He, called Jacob <i>eil</i> (a great and mighty man). [According to this, the verse should be interpreted as follows: “And the G-d of Israel called Jacob <i>eil</i>].” The words of the Torah are thus as a hammer splitting the rock into many different pieces, admitting many different explanations. I, however, make it my aim to render the plain sense of Scripture. All of this is the language of Rashi.<br>Now the words of the Rabbi [Rashi] are correct as regards the plain sense of Scripture. And the meaning of the word <i>lo</i> will then be [not “it,” which would refer to the altar, but “him,” which refers to Jacob], just as is the meaning of the same word in the verses: <i>And his father called ‘lo’ (him) Benjamin;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">109</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis, 35:18.</i> <i>‘Vekarei lecha’ (and thou shalt be called) The repairer of the breach</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">110</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 58:12.</i><br>Know that it was the custom in Israel that names be called which are indicative of the praises of G-d, such as <i>Zuriel</i><sup class="footnote-marker">111</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 3:35.</i> (G-d is my rock), <i>Zurishaddai</i><sup class="footnote-marker">112</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 7:36.</i> (The Almighty is my rock), for the one who calls that name declares that G-d is his rock and the Almighty is his rock. Likewise, <i>Immanuel</i><sup class="footnote-marker">113</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 7:14.</i> (G-d is with us). And so also the name of the Messiah, who will be called, <i>The Eternal is our righteousness</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">114</sup><i class="footnote">Jeremiah 23:6.</i> and the name of Jerusalem will be, <i>The Eternal is there</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">115</sup><i class="footnote">Ezekiel 48:35.</i> And so did they do with the names of the angels: <i>Gabriel</i><sup class="footnote-marker">116</sup><i class="footnote">Daniel 8:16.</i> (G-d is my strength), <i>Michael</i><sup class="footnote-marker">117</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 10:13.</i> (Who is like unto G-d?), for because of their great power they proclaim with their very name that the strength belongs to G-d and who is like unto Him!<br>Onkelos however said: “And he worshipped on it before G-d, the G-d of Israel.” In that case the meaning of the word <i>lo</i> will be as <i>bo</i> (“in it” or “on it”), in the same manner as: <i>That thou hast chosen ‘l’ben’ (the son) of Jesse;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">118</sup><i class="footnote">I Samuel 20:30.</i> <i>And he took hold ‘lo’ (of him);</i><sup class="footnote-marker">119</sup><i class="footnote">II Samuel 15:5.</i> <i>‘L’mei’ (In the waters) of Meribah</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">120</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 20:24.</i> It may be that Scripture is saying, “And he called Him G-d, the G-d of Israel,” and the meaning of the word <i>lo</i> is similar to the usage in these verses: <i>I will get me unto the great men;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">121</sup><i class="footnote">Jeremiah 5:5.</i> <i>Get thee out of thy country</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">122</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 12:1.</i><br>And by way of the Truth, [that is, the mystic lore of the Cabala, the verse is to be understood] as being in accord with the Midrash which the Rabbis have expounded in Tractate Megillah:<sup class="footnote-marker">123</sup><i class="footnote">18a.</i> “Whence do we know that the Holy One, blessed be He, called Jacob <i>eil</i>? It is said, <i>And He — the G-d of Israel — called him ‘eil.’</i> “ There is in this matter a great secret, which the Sages have additionally mentioned in Bereshith Rabbah<sup class="footnote-marker">124</sup><i class="footnote">79:10.</i> in another way: “Jacob said to G-d, ‘Thou art the G-d of those on high, and I am the master of those down below.’” The Sages thereby alluded to that which they constantly say: the likeness of Jacob is engraved in the Heavenly Throne.<sup class="footnote-marker">125</sup><i class="footnote">Tanchuma Numbers 19.</i> The intent [of Jacob’s statement quoted in the Midrash — “I am the master of those down below”] — is that the Divine Glory rests in the Land of Israel. The student learned in the mystic lore of the Cabala will understand.

Chapter 34



Verse 1

THE DAUGHTER OF LEAH, WHOM SHE HAD BORNE UNTO JACOB. The reason [Scripture specifies <i>the daughter of Leah</i>] is to state that she was the sister of Simeon and Levi, who were envious for her sake and avenged her cause. And Scripture mentions further, <i>whom she had borne unto Jacob</i>, in order to allude to the fact that all the brothers were envious for her.

Verse 2

AND HE LAY WITH HER, AND HE AFFLICTED HER. <i>He lay with her</i> in natural gratification; <i>and he afflicted her</i> unnaturally. This is Rashi’s language. But Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra said: <i>And he afflicted her</i> naturally because she was a maiden.” But there is no need for this for all forced sexual connection is called “affliction.” Likewise, <i>Thou shalt not deal with her as a slave, because thou hast afflicted her</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">126</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 21:14.</i> And so also: <i>And my concubine they afflicted, and she is dead</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">127</sup><i class="footnote">Judges 20:5.</i> Scripture thus tells — in Dinah’s praise — that she was forced, and she did not consent to the prince of the country.

Verse 3



Verse 4



Verse 5



Verse 6



Verse 7

AND THUS IT OUGHT NOT TO BE DONE. I.e., to do violence to maidens, for the nations “had fenced themselves round” against unchastity as a result of the Flood. This is Rashi’s language. But I do not know this, for the Canaanites were immersed in unchastity with women, beasts and males, as it is written, <i>For all these abominations have the men of the land done, that were before you</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">128</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 18:27.</i> and they did not begin such practices in that generation [but rather it was their traditional behavior], and even in the days of Abraham and Isaac, the patriarchs feared lest they kill them in order to take their wives. Instead, the expression, <i>and thus it ought not to be done</i>, refers back to the word <i>beyisrael</i> (in Israel): <i>because he had wrought a vile deed in Israel… and thus it ought not to be done</i> among them. This is why Scripture said <i>in Israel</i> for it was not a base deed among the Canaanites. And Onkelos translated: “It is not proper that it be done,” meaning that it is forbidden, and that is why it was a base deed in Israel.

Verse 8



Verse 9



Verse 10



Verse 11



Verse 12

‘MOHAR’ (DOWRY) ‘UMATAN’ (AND GIFT). <i>Mohar</i> [refers to the bridal gifts given at the time of] the marriage-contract which is given to maidens, as it is written, <i>according to the dowry of virgins</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">129</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 22:16.</i> these being the presents which the young men send to the maidens whom they marry. <i>Umatan</i> are garments or silver and gold which the groom sends to her father and her brothers. In Bereshith Rabbah the Rabbis said:<sup class="footnote-marker">130</sup><i class="footnote">80:7.</i> “<i>Mohar</i> is <i>parnon</i> (the wife’s settlement); <i>matan</i> is <i>parapurnon</i> (the additional settlement above the usual dowry),” these being in the language of the Jerusalem Talmud<sup class="footnote-marker">131</sup><i class="footnote">Yerushalmi Kethuboth 5:8.</i> “the regular dowry” and “the usufruct estate,” that is to say, that which he gives her of his properties to be accounted as if she had brought them from her father’s house, the produce of which belongs to him.<br>The reason for this conciliatory gesture is in order that they willingly give her to him as a wife, as the maiden did not consent to him and she steadily protested and cried. This is the sense of the verse, <i>And he spoke comfortingly unto the damsel</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">132</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 3 here.</i> Therefore Shechem said, <i>Take me this young maiden to wife</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">133</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 4 here.</i> as she was already in his house and in his power, and he feared not her brothers because he was the prince of the country and how could they take her by force out of his house? Now Shechem’s great desire was because the maiden was very beautiful. However, Scripture did not narrate her beauty as it did in the case of Sarah, Rebekah and Rachel because it did not want to mention that which was to her <i>a stumbling-block of iniquity</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">134</sup><i class="footnote">Ezekiel 18:30.</i> while Scripture speaks only in praise of the righteous women but not of this one. Similarly, Scripture does not mention what happened to her after her rescue from Shechem’s house. In line with the simple meaning of Scripture she stayed with her brothers, “shut up, living as widows,”<sup class="footnote-marker">135</sup><i class="footnote">See II Samuel 20:3.</i> as she was considered defiled in their sight, as it is written, <i>Because he had defiled Dinah their sister</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">136</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 13 here.</i> Our Rabbis have differed on this matter.<sup class="footnote-marker">137</sup><i class="footnote">Bereshith Rabbah 80:10.</i> The most feasible opinion is that of he who says<sup class="footnote-marker">137</sup><i class="footnote">Bereshith Rabbah 80:10.</i> that Simeon took her, and upon her death, he buried her in the land of Canaan, this being in agreement with what we have said, i.e., that she was with him in his house as a widow, and she went down with them to Egypt, and there she died but was buried in the Land of Israel. Her grave is known by tradition to this day as being in the city of Arbel with the grave of Nitai the Arbelite.<sup class="footnote-marker">138</sup><i class="footnote">Aboth 1:7. He was a leader of the Sanhedrin in the early days of the Hasmoneans. As for Dinah’s grave being near that of Nitai the Arbelite, see my Hebrew commentary, p. 190, for data from other medieval itinerants. Ramban’s testimony though is that of an eye-witness when he travelled through the land.</i> It is possible that Simeon brought up her remains from Egypt out of pity for her while the Israelites were still in Egypt or that the children of Israel brought them up together with the bones of her brothers — all the tribes — just as our Rabbis have mentioned.<sup class="footnote-marker">139</sup><i class="footnote">Mechilta, Exodus 13:19.</i>

Verse 13

AND THE SONS OF JACOB ANSWERED SHECHEM AND HAMOR HIS FATHER WITH SUBTLETY. Now Hamor and Shechem spoke to her father and her brothers,<sup class="footnote-marker">140</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 11 here.</i> but the patriarch did not answer them at all as his sons spoke in his place on this matter out of respect for him for since the affair was a source of shame to them, they did not want him to speak about it at all.<br>There is a question which may be raised here. It would appear that they answered with the concurrence of her father and his advice for they were in his presence, and it was he who understood the answer which they spoke with subtlety, and, if so, why was he angry afterwards?<sup class="footnote-marker">141</sup><i class="footnote">Further, Verse 30. See also Ramban further, 49:5.</i> Moreover, it is inconceivable that Jacob would have consented to give his daughter in marriage to a Canaanite who had defiled her. Now surely all the brothers gave that answer with subtlety, while Simeon and Levi alone executed the deed, and the father cursed only their wrath.<sup class="footnote-marker">142</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 49:7.</i> [But if all the brothers shared responsibility for the answer and the plan, why did Jacob single out only Simeon and Levi for chastisement?] The answer is that the craftiness lay in their saying that every male of theirs be circumcised,<sup class="footnote-marker">143</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 15 here.</i> as they thought that the people of the city will not consent to it. Even if perchance they will listen to their prince and they will all become circumcised, they will come <i>on the third day, when they were in pain</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">144</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 25 here.</i> and will take their daughter<sup class="footnote-marker">145</sup><i class="footnote">“Daughter.” in Tur: “sister.”</i> from the house of Shechem. Now this was the advice of all the brothers and with the permission of their father, but Simeon and Levi wanted to take revenge of them and so they killed all the men of the city.<br>It is possible that Jacob’s anger in cursing their wrath<sup class="footnote-marker">142</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 49:7.</i> was because they killed the men of the city who had committed no sin against him; they should have killed Shechem alone.
