The meaning of the verse is that since Scripture had said that the chiefs of Esau dwelt <i>in the land of their possessions</i><sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 36:43, the concluding verse in the previous <i>Sedra</i>.</i> — that is to say, the land which they took to themselves as a possession forever — it now says that Jacob, however, dwelt as his father had, as a stranger in a land which was not their own but which belonged to the Canaanites. The purport is to relate that they<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">Isaac and Jacob.</i> elected to dwell in the Chosen Land,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">A term denoting the Land of Israel. See Ramban above, 19:5.</i> and that G-d’s words to Abraham, <i>That thy seed shall be a stranger in a land that is not theirs</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 15:13.</i> were fulfilled in them but not in Esau, for Jacob alone shall be called their progeny.<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">“Their”: Abraham and Isaac.</i>

Verse 2

THESE ARE THE ‘TOLDOTH’ (GENERATIONS) OF JACOB. And this is an account of the generations of Jacob. These are their settlements and the events which occurred to them until they attained settlement status. The first cause was <i>Joseph, being seventeen years old</i>, etc. It was through this incident that it happened that they descended to Egypt. This is the literal explanation of the text, which permits each detail to fall into its place. These are the words of Rashi. But the word <i>toldoth</i> cannot apply to a settlement.<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">Ramban thus understood the above text of Rashi as interpreting the word <i>toldoth</i> as having reference to Jacob’s settlement. Mizrachi, however, points out that Rashi’s intent is that the word <i>Eileh</i> (these are) refers to the settlements, while the word <i>toldoth</i> is to be understood in its usual sense as meaning “children.” The sense of the verse thus becomes: “These are the settlements of the children of Jacob.”</i><br>And Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra said [that the verse should be interpreted thus]: “These are the events which happened to him, and the occurrences which befell him. This is similar in meaning to the usage in the verse, <i>For thou knowest not what a day may bring forth</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 27:1. The Hebrew is <i>yolad yom</i> (a day may bring forth). Similarly, according to Ibn Ezra, the word <i>toldoth</i>, which has the same roots as <i>yolad</i>, here means the events which evolved.</i> But a person is not said to bring forth his events; it is only to days that events can be ascribed.<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">Ramban makes the point that <i>toldoth</i> can mean events when it modifies a period of time. However, when referring to a person, as in the present verse, it cannot have this meaning. Ramban thus takes issue with Ibn Ezra’s interpretation.</i> Now perhaps the verse, according to Ibn Ezra, is saying, “These are the events which the days of Jacob brought forth.”<br>The correct interpretation in my opinion is as follows: “These are the generations of Jacob: Joseph and his brothers, whom Scripture will mention further on.” Scripture here adopts a concise approach to their names since it already mentioned them above.<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 35:23-26.</i> But the intent of the verse is to say that these are the generations of Joseph and his brothers to whom the following happened. It is also possible that the word <i>Eileh</i> (these are) alludes to all those mentioned in this book: <i>Thy fathers went down into Egypt with threescore and ten persons</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 10:22. The listing of the names of sixty-nine of these seventy people is found further on “in this book,” 46:8-27. Jochebed, who was born as they entered Egypt, is the seventieth.</i> Just as in the chapter, <i>These are the generations of Esau</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">Above, Chapter 36.</i> Scripture mentioned sons and sons’ sons, kings and chiefs, including all that there had been among them up to the time the Torah was given,<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">See Ramban above, 36:40.</i> so will Scripture count the generations of Jacob, his sons and grandsons, and all his seed, mentioning only the outstanding details in their generations.
AND THE LAD WAS WITH THE SONS OF BILHAH. His actions were those of youth: he would touch up his eyes and dress his hair. <i>With the sons of Bilhah</i>, that is to say, he associated with the sons of Bilhah because his brothers slighted them as being the sons of handmaids, and he therefore befriended them. <i>Their evil report</i> — he told his father about every wrong which he discerned in his brothers, the sons of Leah. This is the language of Rashi.<br>But if this be so, why did the children of the handmaids not save him later on, inasmuch as he loved and befriended them, and told his father about his brothers’ slighting them. And if we say that they feared their brothers, they were four,<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">Dan, Naphtali, Gad, and Asher.</i> and Reuben was with them,<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">As expressly stated further on in Verses 21-22.</i> and, with Joseph himself, [they made a total of six]. Surely they would have prevailed against them especially when considering that the remaining five sons of Leah would not wage war against them. Moreover, it appears from Scripture that all<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">“All,” except Reuben, the eldest, and Benjamin, the youngest, (Rabbeinu Bachya, p. 306, in my edition.)</i> of the brothers concurred in the sale of Joseph. However, according to our Rabbis in Bereshith Rabbah,<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">84:7.</i> he uttered slander against all of them.<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">And not, as Rashi has it, that the evil report concerned only the sons of Leah.</i><br>In my opinion the correct interpretation is that this verse returns to explain that which it mentioned above, and its purport [is as if the phrases in the verse were transposed as follows]: Joseph being a lad of seventeen years, was feeding the flock together with his brothers, the sons of Bilhah and the sons of Zilpah, his father’s wives. A similar case requiring transposition of phrases is found in this <i>Seder:</i><sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Sedrah</i> or <i>Parsha</i> (section).</i> <i>And they dreamed a dream both of them in one night, each man according to the interpretation of his dream, the butler and the baker of the king of Egypt, who were bound in the prison</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">40:5.</i> The verse returns to explain the word <i>shneihem</i> (both of them) which it had mentioned at the outset. Its purport, [after the phrases have been suitably transposed, is as follows]: And both of them dreamed a dream, the butler and the baker of the king of Egypt, who were bound in the prison, each man according to the interpretation of his dream. There are many similar verses. It may be that the word <i>v’hu</i> (and he was) requires another similar word, as if it were written: “and he was a lad, and he was with the sons of Bilhah and with the sons of Zilpah, who were his father’s wives.” The verse thus states that because he was a lad he was constantly with the sons of Bilhah and the sons of Zilpah, his father’s wives, never being separated from them on account of his youth, for their father had commanded them to watch over him and serve him, not the sons of the mistresses, and he brought an evil report concerning them<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">The sons of Bilhah and Zilpah.</i> to their father. It was for this reason that these four brothers<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">Dan, Naphtali, Gad, and Asher.</i> hated Joseph. Following that, the verse says that his father loved him. Now when the other brothers<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">The sons of Leah.</i> saw that their father loved him more than all, they became jealous of him and they hated him. Thus Joseph is found to be hated by all: the sons of the mistresses were jealous of him because Jacob loved him more than them although they were also sons of a mistress as he was, and the sons of the handmaids, who would otherwise not have been jealous of his superior position over them, hated him because he brought their evil report to their father.<br>The purpose of the redundant expression, <i>dibatham ra’ah</i> (their evil report), is to magnify,<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">I.e., to indicate that the report was of an exceedingly evil nature.</i> for <i>dibah</i> itself connotes evil.<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">Otherwise, why does Scripture add the word <i>ra’ah</i> (evil)? It does so in order to magnify the evil nature of the report.</i> Now according to the opinion of Rashi it is possible for <i>dibah</i> to be a good report. Thus when Scripture uses the expression, “he brings <i>dibah</i>“, it means that he tells what he sees,<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">He reports the truth.</i> but when it uses the term, <i>he bringeth forth ‘dibah,’</i> it refers to the fool who speaks falsehood.<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">This opinion that <i>dibah</i> connotes evil only when used in conjunction with the word <i>motzi</i> (bring forth) is borne out by Numbers 13:32.</i><br>In line with the literal meaning of Scripture, the fact that it calls one a <i>na’ar</i> (lad) when he was seventeen years of age<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">Ramban’s intent is to disagree with Rashi’s interpretation of <i>na’ar</i>, which is that his actions were those of a youth.</i> presents no difficulty for since he was the youngest among them, it calls him by that name, indicating that he was not as sturdy as his brothers and therefore needed to be with the sons of Bilhah and Zilpah on account of his youth. Now of Rehoboam, Solomon’s son, it is written, <i>And Rehoboam was young and faint-hearted and could not withstand them</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote">II Chronicles 13:7.</i> yet he was <i>forty-one years old when he began to reign</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 12:13.</i> Similarly the verse: <i>Is it well with the lad Absalom?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote">II Samuel 18:32. Now although Scripture does not state how old Absalom was at the time of his death, it would appear certain that he was about thirty years old since he was born to David in Hebron (<i>ibid.</i>, 3:3-5), and David ruled thirty-three years in Jerusalem. The rebellion of Absalom occurred three years before David’s death (see Seder Hadoroth, year 2921). Hence Absalom, at his death, was at least thirty years old, yet David calls him <i>na’ar</i>.</i> And Benjamin, upon going down to Egypt, was older than Joseph was now,<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">For Joseph was separated from his father for twenty-two years. Therefore Benjamin must have been at least thirty years old at the time he went down to Egypt.</i> and yet Scripture frequently refers to him as <i>na’ar</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 44:31 and 33.</i><br>Now Onkelos translated <i>v’hu na’ar</i> as “<i>he grew up</i> with the sons of Bilhah.” Thus the verse states that from the time he was a lad he was in their company. They raised him as a father would, and they served him. This interpretation is also correct according to the literal interpretation of Scripture, which I offered as an explanation, namely that Scripture relates that he brought evil report concerning [the sons of the handmaids, who, according to Onkelos, raised him. This is why they hated him, whereas] the sons of the mistresses hated him because of their jealousy, as explained above.<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote">Ramban thus indicates that the authoritative interpretation of Onkelos is here consistent with his own.</i><br>The meaning of the expression, <i>His father’s wives</i>, is that they were his “wives” for he took them as such. Scripture calls them “handmaids” only when they are mentioned together with Rachel and Leah, who were their mistresses. Similarly, <i>And he put the handmaids and their children foremost</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 33:2.</i> as if to say that because they were handmaids of Rachel and Leah, Jacob placed them before them in a more exposed position. Similarly, <i>And he lay with Bilhah, his father’s concubine</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 35:22.</i> [The word “concubine” is used to indicate] that if she were a mistress it would not have occurred. It is possible that during the lifetime of Rachel and Leah, Scripture calls them “handmaids” and “concubines,” but now that they had died [Jacob] took them as wives.

Verse 3

BECAUSE HE WAS THE SON OF HIS OLD AGE. That is, he was born to him during his old age. Onkelos translated: “he was a wise son to him,” for all that he had learned from Shem and Eber<sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote">The traditional masters who taught Torah to Jacob during the fourteen years he hid from Esau (Megillah 17 a). This source, however, mentions only Eber. See Bereshith Rabbah 84:8, where Shem is also mentioned.</i> he transmitted to him. Another interpretation is that the facial features of Joseph were similar to those of Jacob. This is Rashi’s language. Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra also explains it in this way: “<i>Because he was the son of old age</i> — for he begot him in his old age when he was ninety-one<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote">For when Jacob stood before Pharaoh at the end of two of the lean years he was one hundred and thirty years old (47:9). Now when Joseph stood before Pharaoh he was thirty years old. Therefore after the seven years of plenty, and the two lean years he was thirty-nine. Subtract his age from Jacob’s age and there remain ninety-one years. This was Jacob’s age when Joseph was born. (Ohel Yoseph.)</i> years old. They likewise called his brother Benjamin <i>a little child of his old age</i>. “<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 44:20.</i><br>But in my opinion this is not correct for the verse states that Jacob loved Joseph more than all his children because he was the son of his old age, whereas all his children were born to him during his old age! Issachar and Zebulun were not more than a year or two<sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote">See Seder Olam Rabbah, 2.</i> older than Joseph.<br>The correct interpretation appears to me to be that it was the custom of the elders to take one of their younger sons to be with them to attend them. He would constantly lean on his arm, never being separated from him, and he would be called <i>ben z’kunav</i> because he attended him in his old age. Now Jacob took Joseph for this purpose, and he was with him constantly. He therefore did not accompany the flock when they went to pasture in distant places. And Onkelos who translated, “he was a wise son,” intended to say that in his father’s eyes, Joseph was a knowledgeable and wise son, and his understanding was as that of elders.<sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote">See the interpretation of Ramban on Leviticus 19:32.</i> However in the case of Benjamin, who is called <i>yeled z’kunim (a little child of his old age)</i>, Onkelos translated: <i>bar savtin</i><sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote">Rather than <i>bar chakim</i>, as in the case of Joseph.</i> (a son of old age). [The explanation of Onkelos in the case of Joseph becomes clear] because the verse here does not state, “Joseph <i>hayah</i> (was) a son of old age;” instead, it says, <i>hu lo</i> (he was unto him), meaning that in his eyes he appeared to be [a <i>ben z’kunim</i>, and consequently it must mean <i>bar chakim</i>, a wise son].<sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote">For if the sense of the verse is to be understood literally as meaning that “he was a son of his old age,” why specify “to Jacob?” Hence Onkelos correctly translated it as <i>bar chakim</i>, which means that Joseph was a wise son in his father’s estimate.</i> This is the intent of the Sages when they said:<sup class="footnote-marker">42</sup><i class="footnote">In the Rashi quoted above. The original source is Bereshith Rabbah 84:8.</i> “Whatever Jacob had learned from Shem and Eber<sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote">The traditional masters who taught Torah to Jacob during the fourteen years he hid from Esau (Megillah 17 a). This source, however, mentions only Eber. See Bereshith Rabbah 84:8, where Shem is also mentioned.</i> he transmitted to him,” meaning that he passed on to him wisdoms and the secrets of the Torah, and that the father found the son to be intelligent and profound in these areas as if he were an elder and a man of many years.

Verse 4



Verse 5



Verse 6



Verse 7

MY SHEAF AROSE, AND ALSO PLACED ITSELF UPRIGHT, AND, BEHOLD, YOUR SHEAVES SURROUNDED. The purport of the dream concerning the sheaves is that Joseph was shown that through the sheaves and the produce they will prostrate themselves to him. The matter of “surrounding” — [<i>your sheaves surrounded</i>] — is to indicate that they will surround him as they do a king arrayed for battle, around whom his subjects encamp.

Verse 8

SHALT THOU INDEED REIGN OVER US? OR SHALT THOU INDEED HAVE DOMINION OVER US? Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra explained: “Shall we voluntarily make you king over us, or will you rule over us by force?” The opinion of Onkelos appears to be more correct.<sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote">Since the authority of a king is essentially the same whether he rules by consent or force, Scripture should not change the expression from <i>malach</i> (reign) to <i>mashal</i> (dominion) if the explanation of Ibn Ezra is correct. Hence Ramban prefers Onkelos’ explanation which follows.</i> He rendered it: “Shall you be king over us or some authority ruling us?” For people prostrate themselves before both. The verse thus means, “You will never be king or any kind of authority over us.”<br>The meaning of the expression, <i>And they continued to hate him still more for his dreams, and for his words</i>, is that they hated him for the dreams and for relating the dreams to them in a boastful manner, even as it says, <i>Hear, I pray you, this dream which I have dreamed</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 6 here.</i>

Verse 9



Verse 10

AND HE RELATED IT TO HIS FATHER. He told his father of this dream concerning the sun, moon and stars, but not of the first one concerning the sheaves because he himself recognized its interpretation and knew that the sun alluded to his father, and his father rebuked him.<sup class="footnote-marker">45</sup><i class="footnote">Ramban’s intent is to say that the father’s rebuke is proof that he knew that Joseph understood the meaning of the dream.</i><br>The meaning of the expression, <i>And he related it to his father and to his brothers</i>, is that he related it to them a second time,<sup class="footnote-marker">46</sup><i class="footnote">Since it is already stated in Verse 9 that he related this dream concerning the sun, moon and stars to his brothers, it must mean here in Verse 10 that he related it to them a second time.</i> as he told it to his father in their presence, and his father rebuked him in order to dissipate their anger towards him.<br>The meaning of the expression, <i>What is this dream that thou hast dreamed?</i> is the same as, <i>What is man that Thou shouldst take cognizance of him?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">47</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 144:3.</i> That is to say, “What is this dream? It is nothing that you should relate for it is nothing but idle talk.” Alternatively, the meaning of the rebuke may be: “How dare you dream such a dream? It is but your conceit and youth that bring up such matters in your heart,” just as it says concerning dreams, <i>Thy thoughts came upon thy bed;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">48</sup><i class="footnote">Daniel 2:29. Here understood literally: “The thoughts you entertained during the day came with you to bed, and you dreamed about them.”</i> <i>And imaginings upon my bed</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">49</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 4:2. Understood in the same sense as above.</i>
SHALL I AND THY MOTHER AND THY BRETHREN INDEED COME TO PROSTRATE OURSELVES TO THEE TO THE EARTH? “Is not your mother long since dead?” Jacob, however, was not aware that the matter alluded to Bilhah who had raised him as if she were his mother. From here, our Rabbis derived the principle that there is no dream that does not contain invalid matters. Jacob’s intention in pointing out the invalidity of the dream was to cause his sons to forget the matter so that they should not be envious of him because of it. Jacob said to Joseph: “Just as it is impossible for the dream to be fulfilled with respect to your mother, so is the remainder invalid.” Thus the language of Rashi.<br>In my opinion, at the time when Jacob went down to Egypt, Bilhah and Zilpah had already died<sup class="footnote-marker">50</sup><i class="footnote">See Ramban 46:15.</i> since, in enumerating the seventy souls that went down to Egypt, Scripture states, <i>Besides Jacob’s sons’ wives</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 46:26.</i> and it does not say “besides Jacob’s wives and his sons’ wives.”<sup class="footnote-marker">52</sup><i class="footnote">Thus, there is proof that Bilhah had already died at the time Jacob went down to Egypt. So how then could Rashi say that the mother in the dream, symbolized by the moon, who was to bow before Joseph in Egypt, referred to Bilhah?</i> And if you say that because they were concubines Scripture does not want to say “besides Jacob’s sons’ wives and his concubines,” yet we find that they are referred to as <i>his father’s wives</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">53</sup><i class="footnote">Above, Verse 2. Why then does Scripture not say “besides Jacob’s wives and his sons’ wives?” Thus it is clear that they had already died.</i> Besides, it is unlikely that “the moon” in the dream alludes to his concubine. Instead, my opinion concerning the matter of the dream is that the sun is an allusion to Jacob, and the moon alludes to the children of his household and all his wives, which comprised Jacob’s seed. Thus, the moon alludes to the fact that all his seed will prostrate themselves to Joseph, these being all the seventy souls that issued from his loins, since they all prostrated themselves when they came before him. The eleven stars represent the brothers who bowed down before him separately,<sup class="footnote-marker">54</sup><i class="footnote">This explains why the brothers are singled out from all of Jacob’s seed, alluded to by the moon.</i> before their father arrived, as it is written, <i>And when Joseph came into the house, they brought him the present which was in their hand into the house, and prostrated themselves to him to the earth</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">55</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 43:26.</i>

Verse 11



Verse 12



Verse 13



Verse 14

AND HE SENT HIM OUT OF THE VALLEY OF HEBRON. Scripture mentions the place from which Joseph was sent, in order to indicate that there was a great distance between father and son, and that this was the reason why the brothers did him evil: they were distant far from their father. It also serves to relate that Joseph, out of respect for his father, strengthened himself to go after them to a distant place, and he did not say, “How shall I go when they hate me?”. Our Rabbis yet have a Midrash concerning this matter, in which they say, “It was to fulfill the profound thought of the ‘seemly companion’<sup class="footnote-marker">56</sup><i class="footnote">Abraham. The Midrash thus explains the word <i>Chevron</i> (Hebron) as if it consisted of the two words: <i>chever na’eh</i> (seemly companion). Thus it refers to Abraham who walked before G-d (above 17:1). The Midrash is in Bereshith Rabbah 84:13.</i> who was buried in Hebron.”<sup class="footnote-marker">57</sup><i class="footnote">Reference is to the covenant — which G-d made with Abraham — that his seed will be a stranger in a land that is not their own (above, 15:13). The idea expressed is that Jacob’s act of sending Joseph to his brethren was thus the beginning of a cycle of events which would fulfill the covenant made with Abraham.</i>

Verse 15

AND A MAN FOUND HIM, AND BEHOLD, HE WAS STRAYING IN THE FIELD. The verse is stating that Joseph was straying from the road, not knowing where to go, and he entered a field since he was looking for them in a place of pasture. Scripture mentions this at length in order to relate that many events befell him which could properly have caused him to return, but he endured everything patiently for the honor of his father. It also informs us that the Divine decree is true and man’s industry is worthless. The Holy One, blessed be He, sent him a guide without his knowledge in order to bring him into their hands. It is this that our Rabbis intended when they said<sup class="footnote-marker">58</sup><i class="footnote">Bereshith Rabbah 84:13.</i> that these men<sup class="footnote-marker">59</sup><i class="footnote"><i>And ‘a man’ found him … and ‘the man’ asked him</i> … <i>And ‘the man’ said</i> … (Verses 15, 17).</i> were angels, for these events did not occur without purpose, but rather to inform us that <i>It is the counsel of the Eternal that shall stand</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">60</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 19:21.</i>

Verse 16



Verse 17

THEY HAVE JOURNEYED HENCE. “They have departed from any feeling of brotherhood. ‘<i>Let us go to Dothan</i>, that is, let us go to seek pretexts of <i>dathoth</i> (laws) with which to put you to death.’ According to the literal sense, however, <i>Dothan</i> is the name of a place, and Scripture never sheds its literal sense.” This is Rabbi Shlomo’s [Rashi’s] language.<br>Now it was not the intent of our Rabbis to say that the man expressly told him, “They have departed hence from any feeling of brotherhood, and they have gone to stir up charges and pretexts against you,” for if so, he would have avoided going there and would not have endangered himself. Instead, their intent is to say that “the man” — Gabriel<sup class="footnote-marker">61</sup><i class="footnote">So identified in Rashi (Verse 15), and the source thereof is Pirkei d’Rabbi Eliezer, Chapter 38.</i> — who told it to him told the truth, but he spoke words having a double meaning, both of them true. Joseph, however, did not grasp the hidden meaning therein, and he followed the obvious. He thus followed his brothers and found them in Dothan, as he had told him. The Rabbis expounded this on the basis of the fact that the “man” referred to was an angel, and if so, he knew where the brothers were. Why then did he not say, “They are in Dothan,” instead of speaking as if he was in doubt, i.e., that he heard from them that they were going to Dothan but he does not know where they are at present. It is for this reason that they expounded the above Midrash concerning his words.
FOR I HEARD THEY ARE SAYING. “I heard that they were saying.”<sup class="footnote-marker">62</sup><i class="footnote">Ramban’s intent is to explain that the Hebrew <i>shamati omrim</i>, literally, “I heard they are saying,” is as if it were written, <i>shamati shehayu omrim</i>, “I heard that they were saying,” thus referring to a past event.</i> Similarly the expression, <i>Rebekah hears</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">63</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 27:5.</i> means that she heard. It is possible that he is saying: “The shepherds have gone from here for I heard people saying,<sup class="footnote-marker">64</sup><i class="footnote">According to this interpretation, Gabriel spoke concerning people in general as if he did not recognize that these shepherds were his brothers.</i> ‘Let us go to Dothan.’ Perhaps they were your brothers.” The man thus spoke with him as if he were avoiding the subject.

Verse 18

AND THEY CONSPIRED AGAINST HIM TO SLAY HIM. They thought to kill him with their subtle intrigues by which they had conspired against him before he drew near to them<sup class="footnote-marker">65</sup><i class="footnote">According to Tur this refers to attempting to kill him with arrows.</i> so that they would not have to spill his blood with their own hands. Thus did the Rabbis say in Bereshith Rabbah:<sup class="footnote-marker">66</sup><i class="footnote">84:13.</i> “Let us set the dogs against him.” And perhaps they did so but did not succeed. Now, when they saw that he was approaching them and they could not kill him with their intrigues, they said to each other, “Behold, he has come to us, so let us kill him ourselves.”

Verse 19



Verse 20

AND WE SHALL SEE WHAT WILL BECOME OF HIS DREAMS. This is a derisive metaphor: “We shall see after his death if we shall prostrate ourselves before him.”<br>The correct interpretation appears to me to be that they said, “Now we shall see <i>what will become of his dreams</i>, for if he shall be rescued from our hands he will surely reign over us.” But our Rabbis said:<sup class="footnote-marker">66</sup><i class="footnote">84:13.</i> “It is the <i>Ruach Hakodesh</i><sup class="footnote-marker">67</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Seder Toldoth</i>, Note 90.</i> that says, <i>We shall see what will become of his dreams</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">68</sup><i class="footnote">The intent is to say that it is the <i>Ruach Hakodesh</i> which completes the sentence, and not Joseph’s brothers.</i> as if to say; ‘We shall see <i>whose words shall stand, Mine or theirs</i>.’”<sup class="footnote-marker">69</sup><i class="footnote">Jeremiah 44:28.</i>

Verse 21



Verse 22

SHED NO BLOOD. Reuben said to them: “I would have been tolerant of you when you thought to kill him by your subtle intrigues, for I too hated him and desired that he be killed by others. But do not spill blood with your hands. Far it be from you!” And Reuben’s intent in all this was to rescue him and restore him to his father. Now Scripture relates that which Reuben told them when they paid heed to him. However, originally he told them other things which they did not accept, as he said to them afterwards, <i>Spoke I not unto you, saying: Do not sin against the child and you would not hear?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">70</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 42:22.</i> Now when he saw that they would not listen to the extent of releasing him, he said to them, “If so, <i>shed no blood</i> with your own hands.”<br>Now Reuben did not say, “Shed not <i>his</i> blood,” [but instead, he said, “<i>Shed no blood</i>,”] in order to make it appear that he is not saying it because he loves him, but in order that they should not spill blood. Thus he taught them that the punishment of he who indirectly causes death is not as great as that of he who personally spills blood.<br>The meaning of the expression, <i>This pit that is in the wilderness</i>, is that this pit is deep and he will not be able to get out of it, and it is in the desert, and if he cries for help there is no one to rescue him as no one passes by there.<br>Now Scripture relates that the pit was empty and did not contain water.<sup class="footnote-marker">71</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 24 here.</i> Had there been water in it they would not have drowned him as they had already avoided spilling his blood. Now Rashi writes: “Since it states that <i>the pit was empty</i>, do I not know that there was no water in it? Why then does it say that <i>there was no water in it?</i> It means to state that water indeed was not in it, however it did contain serpents and scorpions.” This is Rashi’s language quoting from the words of our Rabbis.<sup class="footnote-marker">72</sup><i class="footnote">Shabbath 27a.</i> If so, the serpents and scorpions must have been in the cracks of the pit, or it was deep and they did not know about them. Had they seen them and known that they did not harm Joseph, it would have become clear to them that a great miracle had been done to him, and that he was indeed a perfectly righteous man. They would then have known that his merits would save him from all evil, and how would they touch the anointed one of G-d in whom He delights and whom He saves, even as it says, <i>My G-d hath sent His angel, and hath shut the lions’ mouths, and they have not hurt me; for as much as before Him innocency was found in me</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">73</sup><i class="footnote">Daniel 6:23.</i> But, we must therefore conclude, they did not know anything about it.<br>In line with the simple meaning of the verse, it states that the pit was empty and completely devoid of water, for even if there were a little water in it, it would still be called “empty.”<sup class="footnote-marker">74</sup><i class="footnote">Therefore, the verse specifies that <i>there was no water in it</i> to indicate that there was no water at all in it.</i> Similarly, <i>For thou shalt die and not live</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">75</sup><i class="footnote">II Kings 20:1.</i> which means “not live at all, under any circumstances.” Such redundancies are all for the purpose of clarification and emphasis.

Verse 23



Verse 24



Verse 25

AND, BEHOLD, A CARAVAN OF ISHMAELITES CAME FROM GILEAD. When they looked up and saw at a distance men approaching from the direction of Gilead,<sup class="footnote-marker">76</sup><i class="footnote">Ramban’s intent is to explain why Scripture refers to these men first as Ishmaelites, then as Midianites (Verse 28), and again as Ishmaelites (<i>ibid.</i>), and finally as Midianites (Verse 36).</i> they recognized them as a camel caravan of Ishmaelites on their way to Egypt, for it was from Gilead that balms and spices came, and it was their custom to bring it to Egypt. This was why Judah said to them, “Behold these men come from afar and are travelling to a distant country. Let us sell him to them so that the matter should not become known.” And when they came near they discovered them to be merchants of spices and balms — <i>Midianites, merchantmen</i><sup class="footnote-marker">77</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 28 here.</i> — who had hired the camels from the Ishmaelites. They sold Joseph to the Midianites who purchased him for profit, but the company of Ishmaelites, the lessors of the camels, would not purchase him for their own investment purposes. The verse which states, <i>And they sold Joseph to the Ishmaelites</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">77</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 28 here.</i> means that it was to them that the Midianites who bought him turned him over, for they were the ones who transported the merchandise to Egypt. This is also the meaning of the verse, <i>From the hand of the Ishmaelites, that had brought him down thither</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">78</sup><i class="footnote">39:1.</i> for he was in their care. But the Midianites were his masters, and they made trade with him. This is the sense of the verse, <i>And the Midianites sold him to Egypt</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">79</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 36 here.</i><br>All stories in Scripture are written in this manner: sometimes it is told in the name of the authority who commands that it be done, and other times in the name of the agent who performs the act. Such a case is the verse, <i>All the great work of the Eternal which He did</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">80</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 11:7.</i> while elsewhere it states, <i>Which Moses did in the sight of all Israel</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">81</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 34:12.</i> Similarly it says, <i>Thus all the work that king Solomon did in the house of the Eternal was finished</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">82</sup><i class="footnote">I Kings 7:51.</i> but it was Hiram that did it, as it is written, <i>And he came to king Solomon, and wrought all his work</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">83</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 14.</i> In the case of Joseph himself, the verse says, <i>And whatsoever they did there, he was the doer of it</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">84</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 39:22.</i> thus ascribing the action both to he who commanded it and the one who did it.<br>Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra says that the Midianites are called Ishmaelites, just as Scripture, in speaking of Midianite kings, says, <i>Because they were Ishmaelites</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">85</sup><i class="footnote">Judges 8:24.</i> But the matter is not as Ibn Ezra considered it to be since the verse which states, <i>For they had golden ear-rings, because they were Ishmaelites</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">85</sup><i class="footnote">Judges 8:24.</i> alludes to “the children of the east” whose war it was, as it is written, <i>Now all the Midianites and Amalekites and the children of the east assembled themselves together</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">86</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 6:33.</i> and “the children of the east” are Ishmaelites, for concerning all the sons of the concubines that Abraham had, it is said, <i>And he sent them away from Isaac his son, while he yet lived, eastward, unto the east country</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">87</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 25:6.</i> It is also possible that the kings were Ishmaelites who ruled over Midian. Otherwise, why should “kings of Midian”<sup class="footnote-marker">88</sup><i class="footnote">Judges 8:26.</i> be called by the name of Ishmael their brother?<br>In line with the literal sense of Scripture the correct interpretation concerning the sale of Joseph is as we have said. But our Rabbis have said<sup class="footnote-marker">89</sup><i class="footnote">Bereshith Rabbah 84:2.</i> that he was sold several times [and have thereby explained why his captors are alternately referred to as Midianites and Ishmaelites].

Verse 26

AND WE SHALL CONCEAL HIS BLOOD. “We shall hide the fact of his death.” This is Rashi’s language. And Onkelos similarly says, “and we shall cover up his blood.”<br>The correct interpretation is as its literal sense indicates. It is the custom of those who kill in secret to slay the victim, bury him, and conceal his blood in the earth, even as it says, <i>And he hid him in the sand</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">90</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 2:12.</i> This was why Judah said to them, “By casting him into the pit we shall kill our brother and cover his blood with dust, for it will so be accounted to us.”<sup class="footnote-marker">91</sup><i class="footnote">Judah was arguing against throwing him into the pit, for this act would also be accounted to them as murder. This explanation is developed further on in the text.</i><br>Now Reuben had instructed them not to spill blood with their hands. Rather, they should throw him into the pit and let him perish there, since the punishment of he who causes bloodshed is not the same as the punishment of one who actually commits the murder. Judah now came and said, “This too will be accounted to us as murder, as if we had killed him.” Such indeed is the truth, as the verse says, <i>And him</i> [Uriah] <i>thou hast slain with the sword of the children of Ammon</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">92</sup><i class="footnote">II Samuel 12:9.</i> The difference between actual murder and causing death is that there is a greater punishment for a murderer and a lesser punishment for the one who indirectly causes death. Thus, the two of them [Reuben and Judah] spoke the truth.

Verse 27



Verse 28



Verse 29



Verse 30



Verse 31



Verse 32

AND THEY SENT THE COAT OF MANY COLORS, AND THEY BROUGHT IT TO THEIR FATHER. I.e., by command.<sup class="footnote-marker">93</sup><i class="footnote">Ramban’s intent is to resolve the following difficulty: The verse, <i>And they sent the coat of many colors</i>, clearly indicates that they did not bring it themselves. Ramban answers that the second half of the verse means that they commanded others to bring the coat to their father.</i> Perhaps the word <i>vayavi’u</i> (and they brought) refers to the messengers who brought the coat, for the brothers dispatched it when they were still in Dothan, and it was the messengers who said, <i>This we have found; recognize now</i>. It may be that they sent the coat to Hebron, to one of their homes, and when they arrived they brought it before their father, and said to him, <i>This we have found</i>. They did all of this in order to feign ignorance of the matter, for had they remained quiet, he would have suspected them, saying; “You killed him,” for he knew that they were jealous of him.<br>And some scholars<sup class="footnote-marker">94</sup><i class="footnote">Mentioned in R’dak in the name of “some” scholars.</i> explain the word <i>vayeshalchu</i> — ordinarily translated as “and they sent” — to mean that they pierced the coat with a sword in order to tear it in many places, to give the appearance of having been torn by the teeth of animals. The word <i>vayeshalchu</i> would thus be derived from the verse, <i>By the sword (‘b’shelach’) they shall perish</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">95</sup><i class="footnote">Job 36:12.</i> The significance of the word <i>hapasim</i> (many colors) is that they sent him the coat so that he might recognize it by the colors which he had made for him.

Verse 33



Verse 34



Verse 35

AND ALL HIS DAUGHTERS. This refers to his daughter and his son’s daughter.<sup class="footnote-marker">96</sup><i class="footnote">Since Jacob had. only one daughter, Dinah, the expression “and his daughters” in the plural must include some other person. Ramban first suggests that the term includes his granddaughter, Serach the daughter of Asher. See also my Hebrew commentary, pp. 211-2.</i> Now it is possible that his daughters-in-law are also included in this category, for in Scripture they too are called “daughters,” or as the saying of the Sages has it:<sup class="footnote-marker">97</sup><i class="footnote">Bereshith Rabbah 84:19.</i> “A person does not refrain from calling his daughters-in-law ‘daughters.’” So did Naomi say to her daughters-in-law: <i>Go, turn back, my daughters;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">98</sup><i class="footnote">Ruth 1:8; 1:12.</i> <i>Nay, my daughters;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">99</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 13.</i> <i>Go, my daughter</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">100</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 2:2.</i> It is nothing but an expression of love, just as, <i>Hearest thou not, my daughter?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">101</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 8. This was said by Boaz to Ruth and can certainly not indicate the relationship of daughter or daughter-in-law.</i>

Verse 36

OFFICER OF ‘HATABACHIM.’ This means the slaughterers of the king’s animals. This is the language of Rashi. Similarly, it says, <i>And the ‘tabach’ (cook) took up the thigh;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">102</sup><i class="footnote">I Samuel 9:24.</i> <i>For perfumers and for cooks ‘tabachoth’</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">103</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 8:13.</i><br>Closer to the meaning of the word <i>hatabachim</i> is the opinion of Onkelos who says that since the prison house was under his charge, [he was called the officer of the <i>tabachim</i>, since] we find the word <i>t’vichah</i> in connection with the killing of people. <i>Prepare ye the slaughter (‘matbiach’) for his children;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">104</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 14:21.</i> <i>Thou hast slaughtered (‘tavachta’) unsparingly</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">105</sup><i class="footnote">Lamentations 2:21.</i> The verse in the book of Daniel is proof of the validity of Onkelos’ interpretation: <i>To Arioch the captain of ‘tabachaya’ of the king, who was gone forth to slay the wise men of Babylon</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">106</sup><i class="footnote">Daniel 2:14. The word <i>tabachaya</i> or <i>tabachim</i> is thus clearly associated with the slaying of people. See my Hebrew commentary, Note 77, pp. 211-212.</i>

Chapter 38



Verse 1



Verse 2

A DAUGHTER OF A CERTAIN CANAANITE. [In translating “Canaanite,” Onkelos said “merchant.” That is to say, a merchantman who came to dwell in the land of Canaan for business reasons. His intent is to say that Jacob’s sons guarded themselves from marrying Canaanitish women, as Isaac and Abraham, their fathers, had commanded.<sup class="footnote-marker">107</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 28:1. 24:3.</i> And thus did the Sages mention in the <i>Gemara</i> of Tractate Pesachim.<sup class="footnote-marker">108</sup><i class="footnote">Pesachim 50a.</i> They took as wives women from Egypt, Ammon, Moab, and from the noble families of the children of Ishmael and the sons of Keturah. It is for this reason that Scripture singles out Shaul, the son of Simeon, as the son of a Canaanitish woman,<sup class="footnote-marker">109</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 46:10. </i> as he was the only one among them. And even there the Rabbis expounded<sup class="footnote-marker">110</sup><i class="footnote">Bereshith Rabbah 80:10. </i> that the reference is to Dinah who had relations with a Canaanite [Shechem].<br>Our Rabbis, however, have differed in this matter. Thus they have said:<sup class="footnote-marker">111</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 84:19.</i> “Rabbi Yehudah says, ‘Twin sisters were born with each of Jacob’s sons, and they took them as wives.’ Rabbi Nechemyah says, ‘Their wives were Canaanitish women.’” It is possible that Rabbi Nechemyah was not particular about [ the term “Canaanitish” and did not mean it to indicate] their genealogy. He meant to say only that they took women from the land of Canaan as wives. However, they were from among the strangers and the sojourners who had come there from all lands, either Ammonite or Moabite women, and other peoples. His purpose<sup class="footnote-marker">112</sup><i class="footnote">Ramban is pointing out that Rabbi Nechemyah agrees with the Talmudic sages who said that Jacob’s sons did not marry Canaanitish women. See Note 108.</i> was only to differ with Rabbi Yehudah and say that they did not marry their sisters, since a maternal sister is forbidden to the sons of Noah. But according to Rabbi Yehudah it will be necessary to say that the sons of Leah married the twin sisters of the six other brothers,<sup class="footnote-marker">113</sup><i class="footnote">This is because “the sons of Noah” were forbidden to marry a maternal sister. Prior to the giving of the Torah on Sinai, our ancestors had the status of <i>b’nei Noach</i> (sons of Noah). Consequently they could marry a paternal sister but not a maternal sister. See Sanhedrin 58 a; Rambam, Hilchoth Melachim 9:5.</i> and they in turn wed the twin sisters of the sons of Leah. It may be that Rabbi Nechemyah does not at all admit the existence of these twins, with Jacob not having any daughter other than Dinah, as the literal interpretation of Scripture would indicate.<br>It is not logically correct to say that they all married Canaanitish women since there would then have been descendants of Canaan, the accursed servant, among those who inherited the land, just as there were representatives of the seed of Abraham, and Scripture has commanded that he be destroyed until neither remnant nor survivor remain.<br>In any case,<sup class="footnote-marker">114</sup><i class="footnote">I.e., whatever the correct opinion be in the matter discussed above.</i> this man [the Canaanite referred to here] was a merchant, for why should Scripture find it necessary to state that he was a Canaanite by descent when all people of the land were Canaanites, of the Perizzites and Jebusites and their brothers, as all of these traced their genealogy to Canaan? Adullam, [from where this man came] furthermore, was in the land of Canaan.<sup class="footnote-marker">115</sup><i class="footnote">In Joshua 12:15, the king of Adullam is mentioned among the kings of Canaan. Thus if the word “Canaanite” is to be understood literally, why should Scripture have even mentioned it?</i> It would then have been proper for the verse to say: “And Judah took there a wife with such-and-such a name,” just as it mentions the names of the women in the case of Tamar, and Esau’s wives,<sup class="footnote-marker">116</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 26:34.</i> and others. But the true explanation is that he was a merchant, not of the land of Canaan, which belonged to the Hivite or the Amorite. This then is the meaning of the verse: <i>And Judah saw there a daughter of a certain Canaanite</i>, implying that he married her on account of her father.<sup class="footnote-marker">117</sup><i class="footnote">This is implied in the expression, <i>And he saw there</i>, meaning that he saw a man there who was not of the regular community. The word “Canaanite” must therefore mean merchant, for they were all Canaanites, and if “Canaanite” were to refer to his genealogy it would not be significant enough to be mentioned.</i> And concerning the verse which states, <i>The sons of Judah: Er, and Onan, and Shelah; which three were born unto him of Bath-shua the Canaanitess</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">118</sup><i class="footnote">I Chronicles 2:3. This would seem to indicate that she was indeed a Canaanitess.</i> this is due to the fact that being the daughter of the man called “the Canaanite,” she was also so called, since this man was called “the merchant” by them as he was known for, and expert in, his trade, on account of which he settled there.<br>Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra says<sup class="footnote-marker">119</sup><i class="footnote">In his commentary on Genesis 46:10.</i> that because this woman was a Canaanitess, and Judah had transgressed the opinion of his fathers, her children were evil and they died. And this is why concerning Shaul,<sup class="footnote-marker">109</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 46:10. </i> Scripture mentions only that he was the son of a Canaanitish woman, but with respect to Shelah the son of Judah it was not necessary for Scripture to mention it<sup class="footnote-marker">120</sup><i class="footnote">Since it is so stated in this present chapter. Shaul, on the other hand, was not mentioned above. Hence in mentioning the seventy souls, it states that he was of a Canaanitish woman (46:10). These are the words of Ibn Ezra, and Ramban now proceeds to comment upon them.</i> [when enumerating the descendants of Jacob who entered Egypt].<br>If so,<sup class="footnote-marker">121</sup><i class="footnote">If Judah, according to Ibn Ezra, went against the command of Abraham and Isaac.</i> the expression, <i>And Judah saw there a daughter</i>, would mean that he saw her and desired her, even as it says of Samson, <i>And he saw a woman in Timnah</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">122</sup><i class="footnote">Judges 14:1.</i> And in the <i>Parshah</i> of <i>Vayechi Yaakov</i>, Rashi wrote: “<i>And his sons bore him</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">123</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 50:13.</i> but not his sons’ sons. For thus indeed did Jacob command them; ‘My bier shall not be borne by any of your sons since they are children of Canaanitish women.’”<sup class="footnote-marker">124</sup><i class="footnote">Now this text of Rashi would apparently contradict the opinion of Ibn Ezra who states that only Shaul the son of Simeon, and Shelah the son of Judah, were born of Canaanitish women. Ramban, however, proceeds to reconcile the position of Rashi with that of Ibn Ezra.</i><br>It may be that, according to Rashi, Jacob said this of Shaul the son of Simeon, and Shelah the son of Judah, who were of the daughters of Canaan, and therefore Jacob excluded all the other [grandsons although their mothers were not Canaanitish]. However, in all of our texts of Bereshith Rabbah<sup class="footnote-marker">125</sup><i class="footnote">Mentioned in Yalkut Shimoni 161.</i> we find this version: “My bier shall not be borne by any of your sons’ sons, as there is among them of the daughters of Canaan.”<sup class="footnote-marker">126</sup><i class="footnote">The Midrash there concludes: “For it is said, <i>And Shaul the son of a Canaanitish woman</i> (46:10).” Thus it is clear from this Midrash that only Shaul was born of a Canaanitish woman, but not Shelah the son of Judah.</i> Tamar likewise was the daughter of one of the strangers living in the land, not the daughter of a man who was a Canaanite by descent. Far be it that our lord David<sup class="footnote-marker">127</sup><i class="footnote">He was a descendant of Tamar and Judah through Peretz, who was the ancestor of David. See Ruth 4:15-22.</i> and the Messiah our just one, who will speedily reveal himself to us, be of the seed of Canaan, the accursed servant. Our Rabbis have also said<sup class="footnote-marker">128</sup><i class="footnote">Bereshith Rabbah 85:11.</i> concerning Tamar that she was the daughter of Shem, of whom it is said, <i>And he was a priest of the most high G-d</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">129</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 14:18.</i>

Verse 3

AND HE CALLED HIS NAME ER. Judah called his son Er, said name being derived from the expression, <i>Stir up (‘Or’rah’) Thy might</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">130</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 80:3.</i> His wife called the name of the second son Onan,<sup class="footnote-marker">131</sup><i class="footnote">A word which suggests grief and mourning. Ramban makes the point that the name Judah chose for his son can easily be surmised, as it suggests strength. But why his wife should choose a name like “Onan” is not indicated.</i> but Scripture does not relate the reason for this name. Now it is possible that she experienced difficult labor, for it is customary for women to name their children after such an experience, as did the mother of Jabez who so named him, <i>saying: Because I bore him with pain</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">132</sup><i class="footnote">I Chronicles 4:9. The name “Yavetz” contains the Hebrew letters of <i>atzev</i> (pain).</i> And so did Atarah, the mother of Onam,<sup class="footnote-marker">133</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 2:26.</i> [call him by the name Onam on account of her difficult labor], the name being derived from the expression, <i>And the people were ‘k’mithon’nim’ (as murmurers);</i><sup class="footnote-marker">134</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 11:1.</i> <i>Wherefore doth a living man ‘yithonen’ (complain)?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">135</sup><i class="footnote">Lamentations 3:39.</i> This is similar in expression to <i>ben oni</i> (the son of my sorrow)<sup class="footnote-marker">136</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 35:18.</i> mentioned in the case of Rachel. Judah was not particular about changing Onan’s name as his father Jacob had done.<sup class="footnote-marker">136</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 35:18.</i><br>In Bereshith Rabbah<sup class="footnote-marker">137</sup><i class="footnote">85:5.</i> our Rabbis said, by way of explaining the name Er, that he was destined to be thrown off (<i>she’hu’ar</i>) from the world.<sup class="footnote-marker">138</sup><i class="footnote">Since, as Scripture relates, he died on account of his sin. (Verse 7, and see Ramban there.)</i> Now this is not to say that such was Judah’s intent. However, the Rabbis made their exposition since the names indicate the future.

Verse 4



Verse 5

AND SHE CALLED HIS NAME SHELAH, AND HE [Judah] WAS AT CHEZIB, WHEN SHE BORE HIM. Rashi wrote: “I am of the opinion that because it was there that she ceased bearing children, the place was called <i>Chezib</i> (deceit). It is similar in expression to the verse, <i>Wilt thou indeed be unto me as a deceitful (‘achzav’) brook</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">139</sup><i class="footnote">Jeremiah 15:18.</i> If this be not so, what is the verse teaching us by mentioning that Judah was in Chezib?”<br>Now I do not know why a place should be named for that reason, [i.e., because there she ceased bearing children], there being nothing outstanding in such an event as three sons were sufficient for her.<sup class="footnote-marker">140</sup><i class="footnote">Had she been barren that would be a tragedy of some significance.</i> Moreover, at the time she gave birth to the third son it was not yet known whether she had ceased bearing or would give birth afterwards. Only at the time of her demise did it become established [that she had ceased bearing with the third son].<sup class="footnote-marker">141</sup><i class="footnote">Why then would the place have been called Chezib at the time she gave birth to the third son?</i><br>Now some scholars<sup class="footnote-marker">142</sup><i class="footnote">R’dak in his commentary. Also in Da’ath Z’keinim ba’alei Tosafoth.</i> say that it was their custom for the father to name the firstborn, and the mother the second one. It is for this reason that Scripture states concerning the first son, <i>And he called his name</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">143</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 3 here.</i> and concerning the second one, <i>And she called</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">144</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 4 here.</i> Now concerning the third son, [the naming of whom was the father’s prerogative, Scripture nevertheless] says, <i>And she called</i>, explaining that this was because Judah was in Chezib when she gave birth to him, and he was not there to name him. This interpretation lacks rhyme or reason.<br>In the opinion of Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra Scripture relates where they were born; the statement, <i>when she bore ‘him,’</i> is as if it had said ‘them,’ as all three sons were born in one place.<br>In my opinion, the name Shelah is an expression meaning a thing which stops and deceives. Thus, <i>do not ‘thashleh’ (deceive) me</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">145</sup><i class="footnote">II Kings 4:28.</i> which the Targum there renders as, “Let not your word deceive your handmaid.” Perhaps it is related to the concept of error, for he who commits an error deceives his thinking. Thus Scripture is saying that she called him Shelah, [a word which is traceable to the root of the Hebrew word meaning ‘error,’] because of the name of the place, as <i>he was in Chezib</i> — [a word which means ‘deceive’] — <i>when she bore him</i>. And [the word <i>v’hayah</i> (and he was), although it should really be saying, <i>v’haytha</i>, (and <i>she</i> was), is identical with the expression <i>‘V’hayah hana’arah’</i> (And the damsel shall be).<sup class="footnote-marker">146</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 24:14. There, too, it should be saying, <i>v’haytha hana’arah</i> in the feminine, except that the word <i>v’haya</i> does not refer to <i>na’arah</i> but to the event itself and is therefore to be understood as: “And it shall come to pass that the damsel, etc.” Here, likewise, it is to be so understood.</i> This is the intent of the saying of the Rabbis in Bereshith Rabbah:<sup class="footnote-marker">137</sup><i class="footnote">85:5.</i> “Paskath was the name of the place.”<sup class="footnote-marker">147</sup><i class="footnote">This contradicts the opinion of Rashi, who maintains that it was the mother who named the place Chezib because she ceased bearing children.</i>

Verse 6



Verse 7

AND ER, JUDAH’s FIRSTBORN, WAS WICKED IN THE SIGHT OF THE ETERNAL. Scripture does not specify the nature of his wickedness as it did in the case of his brother.<sup class="footnote-marker">148</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 9 here.</i> Instead, it simply states that he died for his own sin. It informs us that this was not by way of punishment of Judah for his role in the sale of Joseph, since the saving of Joseph’s life by Judah compensated for his role in the sale. There was no case of death of a child in the house of the patriarchs except this one who <i>was wicked in the sight of the Eternal</i>, since the race of the righteous is blessed. This is why Jacob mourned many days for his son Joseph, <i>and he refused to comfort himself</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">149</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 37:34-35.</i> for he considered this to be a great punishment to himself, quite apart from his love for him.

Verse 8

AND MARRY HER AS BROTHER-IN-LAW, AND RAISE SEED TO THY BROTHER. The son will be called by the name of the deceased. This is Rashi’s language.<br>But this is not true, for in the same commandment of the Torah it likewise says, <i>And it shall be, that the firstborn that she beareth shall succeed in the name of his brother that is dead, that his name be not blotted out of Israel</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">150</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 25:6.</i> and yet the brother-in-law is not commanded to call his son by the name of his dead brother.<sup class="footnote-marker">151</sup><i class="footnote">Yebamoth 24a.</i> In the case of Boaz it says, <i>Moreover Ruth the Moabitess, the wife of Machlon, have I acquired to be my wife, to raise up the name of the dead upon his inheritance, that the name of the dead be not cut off from among his brethren, and from the gate of his place</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">152</sup><i class="footnote">Ruth 4:10.</i> and yet she called him Obed,<sup class="footnote-marker">153</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 21.</i> not Machlon. Moreover, it says here, <i>And Onan knew that the seed would not be his</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">154</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 9 here.</i> Now what misfortune would have befallen him — to the point that he wasted his seed from before her — if his son was to be called by the name of his dead brother? Most people even desire to do so. Again, Scripture does not say, “And Onan said,” but instead it says, <i>And Onan ‘knew’ that the seed would not be his</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">154</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 9 here.</i> This would indicate that Onan had some definite kind of knowledge in this matter which made him certain <i>that the seed would not be his</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">154</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 9 here.</i><br>The subject is indeed one of the great secrets of the Torah,<sup class="footnote-marker">155</sup><i class="footnote">Ramban here hints to the mystic doctrine of the transmigration of souls. Onan “knew” that when he married his brother’s wife his brother’s soul would become incarnate in his son. Therefore Onan did not consider the child to be his own. See my Hebrew commentary, pp. 214-5.</i> concerning human reproduction, and it is evident to those observers who <i>have eyes to see, and ears to hear</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">156</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 29:3.</i> The ancient wise men who were prior to the Torah knew of the great benefit in marrying a childless dead brother’s wife, and that it was proper for the brother to take precedence in the matter, and upon his failure to do so, his next of kin would come after him, for any kinsman who was related to him, who would inherit his legacy, would derive a benefit from such a marriage. And it was customary for the dead man’s wife to be wed by the brother or father or the next of kin in the family. We do not know whether this was an ancient custom preceding Judah’s era. In Bereshith Rabbah<sup class="footnote-marker">157</sup><i class="footnote">85:6.</i> they say that Judah was the one who inaugurated the commandment of marrying a childless person’s widow, for since he had received the secret<sup class="footnote-marker">155</sup><i class="footnote">Ramban here hints to the mystic doctrine of the transmigration of souls. Onan “knew” that when he married his brother’s wife his brother’s soul would become incarnate in his son. Therefore Onan did not consider the child to be his own. See my Hebrew commentary, pp. 214-5.</i> from his ancestors he was quick to fulfill it. Now when the Torah came and prohibited marrying former wives of certain relatives, it was the will of the Holy One, blessed be He, to abrogate the prohibition against marrying a brother’s wife in case he dies childless, but it was not His will that the prohibition against marrying a father’s brother’s wife or a son’s wife or similar wives of relatives be set aside. It was only in the case of a brother that the custom had established itself,<sup class="footnote-marker">158</sup><i class="footnote">Prior to the giving of the Torah.</i> and the benefit is likely with him and not with the others,<sup class="footnote-marker">159</sup><i class="footnote">Ramban’s intent is that when two brothers come from one father, the soul of the dead one finds closer identification with the child that his brother will beget rather than with that of any of the other relatives. (Abarbanel; see my Hebrew commentary, p. 215).</i> as I have mentioned. Now it was considered a matter of great cruelty when a brother did not want to marry his dead brother’s wife, and they would call it <i>the house of him that had his shoe loosed</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">160</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 25:10.</i> for [after his dead brother’s wife had performed <i>Chalitzah</i> (the loosening of the shoe) of the brother-in-law], he<sup class="footnote-marker">161</sup><i class="footnote">The soul of the dead brother. The Cabala has considered the subject of Chalitzah, as one of profound mystery.</i> was now removed from them, and it is fitting that this commandment be fulfilled through the loosening of the shoe. Now the ancient wise men of Israel, having knowledge of this important matter, established it as a custom to be practised among all those inheriting the legacy, providing there is no prohibition against the marriage, and they called it <i>Ge’ulah</i> (Redemption).<sup class="footnote-marker">162</sup><i class="footnote">Ruth 4:7.</i> This was the matter concerning Boaz, and the meaning of the words of Naomi and the women neighbors.<sup class="footnote-marker">163</sup><i class="footnote">Reference is to what the neighbors said; <i>There is a son born to Naomi</i> (Ruth 4:17), meaning that she was thereby given back the son Machlon whom she had lost. This explains why the women did not say, “There is a son born to Ruth or Boaz.”</i> The man of insight<sup class="footnote-marker">164</sup><i class="footnote">A term denoting the student of the Cabala, the mystic doctrine of the Torah.</i> will understand.

Verse 9



Verse 10



Verse 11

ABIDE A WIDOW AT THY FATHER’s HOUSE. The meaning thereof is that “you should conduct yourself there as a widow until Shelah be grown up.” He suggested to her: “Place yourself in mourning, put on mourning garments, do not anoint yourself with oil, as a woman <i>girded with sack-cloth for the bridegroom of her youth</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">165</sup><i class="footnote">Joel 1:8.</i> until Shelah be grown up and he will marry you.” Such was the custom of a widow waiting to be married: she who desires to be married to a stranger wears mourning garments only for a short period as is the custom, and then feigning comfort arrays herself in scarlet. <i>And she covered herself with a veil</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">166</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 14 here. Ramban thus interprets the verse; <i>And she removed the garments of her widowhood, and covered herself with a veil</i>, as an indication that she was no longer mourning. See Ramban further, Verse 16.</i> until she be married to a man.
FOR HE SAID, LEST HE ALSO DIE, LIKE HIS BRETHREN. That is to say, he dismissed her with a paltry reply because he never intended to give her to him in marriage. <i>For he said, Lest he also die, like his brethren</i>, for she has established herself as one whose husbands die young. This is Rashi’s Language.<br>Now I do not know why Judah, a ruler of his generation, should be shy towards this woman and not tell her, “Go in peace from my house,” and why should he mislead her when she is even forbidden to Shelah, just as the Rabbis have said concerning a married woman:<sup class="footnote-marker">167</sup><i class="footnote">Kethuboth 43:2.</i> “Twice establishes a presumption [that the woman is a <i>katlanith</i> — a woman whose husbands die].” However since Judah was angered by her harlotry to the extent of condemning her to be burned, it would appear that he originally did wish her to remain in his family. It is also unreasonable to say that Judah did not hear about how his children sinned against G-d, thus causing Him to deliver them into the hands of their fate, while Tamar was guiltless in their death.<sup class="footnote-marker">168</sup><i class="footnote">Ramban thus raises two questions against Rashi’s interpretation. It is obvious that Judah did care to have Tamar in the family, and as for her part in the death of Er and Onan, did not Judah hear how his sons had sinned against G-d, and that Tamar was guiltless?</i><br>The correct view appears to me to be that Shelah was fit for the marriage, but his father did not want him to marry Tamar while he was still a youth, lest he commit some sin with her as had his brothers who died young, for they were boys, none of them having attained twelve years<sup class="footnote-marker">169</sup><i class="footnote">Seder Olam 2. See my Hebrew commentary, p. 216.</i> of age. His intention was that when he would mature and would listen to the instruction of his father, he would then give her <i>to</i> him as a wife. But when she had waited a long time and it appeared to her that Shelah had grown up — although in the eyes of his father he was still a boy as he was not yet ten years old and therefore his father was bent on waiting longer — then Tamar, in her craving to give birth from the sacred race, hastened and did this deed.

Verse 12

AND JUDAH, WENT UP UNTO HIS SHEEP-SHEARERS. He would go there continually to console himself after his wife’s death so that he may turn his attention to the sheep <i>and forget his poverty</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">170</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 31:7. [and remember his trouble no more.]</i> Now when it was told to Tamar that he goes up there daily without fail, she waited for him on one of those days. It may be that since Judah was prominent in the land, people would assemble there to make a feast at the time of the shearing, similar to a royal feast, and the poor would go there, and it was told to her before he went up there.

Verse 13



Verse 14



Verse 15

AND HE THOUGHT HER TO BE A HARLOT. This was because she was sitting at the cross-roads. <i>For she had covered her face</i>, and he could not see her. A Midrash of our Rabbis explains: <i>For she had covered her face</i>, i.e., that when she stayed in Judah’s house, she had acted modestly, always covering her face, and therefore he did not suspect her. This is Rashi’s language.<br>Now the Rabbi’s [Rashi’s]<sup class="footnote-marker">171</sup><i class="footnote">See Note 139, <i>Seder Bereshith</i>.</i> literal interpretation is feasible since it was the way of the harlot to sit at the cross-roads, just as it is written, <i>And she sitteth at the door of her house, on a seat in the high places of the city, to call to them that pass by</i>, etc.<sup class="footnote-marker">172</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 9:14-15.</i> Accordingly, the verse states that because her face was veiled he did not recognize her. But according to the Midrasn of our Rabbis which states that she covered her face in her father-in-law’s house, meaning that she hid herself from him while being in his house and that he never saw her face, how would he recognize her even if she were not veiled?<br>It further appears to me to be correct, in line with the literal sense of Scripture, that the verse is stating that he thought her to be a harlot because her face was veiled, since afterwards it states, <i>For he knew not that she was his daughter-in-law</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">173</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 16 here. This indicates that if her face were not veiled, he would have recognized her to be his daughter-in-law. This again is at odds with the Midrash which states that he never saw her face.</i> The reason for the covering of the face is that it was the way of the harlot to sit at the cross-roads wrapped up in a veil, with part of the face and hair uncovered, gesticulating with the eyes and lips, and baring the front of the throat and neck. Now since she would speak to the by-passer in an impudent manner, catching him and kissing him,<sup class="footnote-marker">174</sup><i class="footnote">See Proverbs 7:13.</i> she therefore veiled part of the face. Furthermore, harlots sitting by the roadside veil their faces because they commit harlotry even with relatives. Sodomites still do it to this day in our countries, and when they return to the city they remain anonymous.<br>Thus we have learned in a Mishnah:<sup class="footnote-marker">175</sup><i class="footnote">Keilim 24,16.</i> “There are three kinds of head-nets: that of a girl, which is susceptible to <i>midras</i><sup class="footnote-marker">176</sup><i class="footnote">A term applied to the uncleanness conveyed by a <i>Zav</i> or <i>Zavah</i> — (see Leviticus 15:2-6; 25-26) — to an object which is used as a seat. An object not so used, but which serves as a garment or a container, is susceptible only to corpse-uncleanness (see Numbers 19:14-17). If it serves none of these purposes, it is not susceptible to any uncleanness.</i> uncleanness; that of an old woman, which is susceptible to the uncleanness of a corpse, while that of a <i>yotza’ath chutz</i>, [literally, ‘she who goes outside’], is not susceptible to any uncleanness.” Now a <i>yotzath chutz</i> refers to the harlot, the <i>nafkat bro</i> of Onkelos<sup class="footnote-marker">177</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 15 here. This is the Aramaic form of the Hebrew term, <i>yotza’ath chutz</i> (she who goes outside).</i>, who places the head-net on part of the head. It does not serve her the purpose of lying on it, for in that case it would be susceptible to <i>midras</i>-uncleanness.<sup class="footnote-marker">176</sup><i class="footnote">A term applied to the uncleanness conveyed by a <i>Zav</i> or <i>Zavah</i> — (see Leviticus 15:2-6; 25-26) — to an object which is used as a seat. An object not so used, but which serves as a garment or a container, is susceptible only to corpse-uncleanness (see Numbers 19:14-17). If it serves none of these purposes, it is not susceptible to any uncleanness.</i> Nor does she cover her head with it, for in that case it would be susceptible to corpse-uncleanness. Instead, she uses it to dress up the ends of her hair, in order that it be partly visible from beneath the net, and this is why it is not susceptible to any uncleanness.

Verse 16



Verse 17



Verse 18

THY SIGNET ‘UP’THILECHA.’ Onkelos renders it as “thy signet and thy cloak,” meaning “the ring which you use as a seal, and the cloak with which you cover yourself.” This is Rashi’s language.<br>But it is not correct to say that he would give his cloak, and go away from her unclothed. And how is it that a cloak is called <i>p’thil</i> in the Hebrew language? And how can it be referred to later on as <i>p’thilim</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">178</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 25 here.</i> in the plural? Now should you say that on account of its fringed strings (<i>p’thilim</i>), the garment was called <i>p’thil</i>, far be it that Judah should fulfill the Commandment of <i>Tzitzith</i> (Fringes),<sup class="footnote-marker">179</sup><i class="footnote">See Numbers 15:38.</i> yet treat it so lightly as to give it away in unchastity! Perhaps, he had with him a small scarf which he occasionally wound around part of the head, and which was called <i>p’thil</i> because it was short as a <i>p’thil</i> (fringe), and it is this which the Targum [Onkelos] rendered as <i>shashifa</i>, [which Rashi incorrectly took to mean “a cloak”]. Now you will not find that Onkelos will translate <i>simlah</i> (a garment) as <i>shashifa</i> wherever it is found in the Torah. Instead, he translates it throughout by a term denoting “cover” or “garment,” excepting the verse, <i>And they shall spread the ‘simlah’</i> (garment),<sup class="footnote-marker">180</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 22:17.</i> concerning which he says, “And they shall spread the <i>shashifa</i>,” because this is the <i>sudar</i> referred to in the Talmud<sup class="footnote-marker">181</sup><i class="footnote">Kethuboth 10 a: “Bring me the <i>sudar</i>.” See also Ramban to Deuteronomy 22:17.</i> through which virginity is established. So did Jonathan ben Uziel translate <i>hama’ataphoth</i><sup class="footnote-marker">182</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 3:22.</i> (the mantlets) as <i>shashifa</i>, these being small scarfs which they wound around the head, and distinguished persons spread them over their bonnets and headbands. This custom still prevails in eastern countries.<br>It is further possible that Judah possessed a seal impressed with the form of a lion or some other known figure, as rulers do, and he also had fringes in his hand, woven in the same design, with which to stroll about, as well as a rod in his hand, as becomes a ruler or lord, even as it is written, <i>A strong rod, to be a sceptre to rule</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">183</sup><i class="footnote">Ezekiel 19:14.</i> and it is further written, <i>The sceptre shall not depart from Judah</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">184</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 49:10.</i> It was these that he gave into Tamar’s hand.

Verse 19



Verse 20



Verse 21



Verse 22



Verse 23



Verse 24

AND JUDAH SAID: BRING HER FORTH, AND LET HER BE BURNT! Ephraim Makshoah,<sup class="footnote-marker">185</sup><i class="footnote">There are two interpretations for the name ‘Makshoah’: (a) he was a watchman in a cucumber field (<i>kishuim</i>); (b) he was a scholar famous for his great ability in debate (<i>kasheh</i>). See Commentaries to Bereshith Rabbah 84:11.</i> a disciple of Rabbi Meir, said in the name of Rabbi Meir: “Tamar was the daughter of Shem who was a priest.<sup class="footnote-marker">186</sup><i class="footnote">See Ramban above, 14:18.</i> They therefore sentenced her to be burnt.”<sup class="footnote-marker">187</sup><i class="footnote">See Leviticus 21:9.</i> Rashi quoted this Midrash but did not explain it.
