And I do not know this law, for a priest’s daughter is not liable to be burned except for harlotry in conjunction with a binding relation to a husband, either espoused or married, as is explained in the <i>Gemara</i> in Tractate Sanhedrin.<sup class="footnote-marker">188</sup><i class="footnote">Sanhedrin 51b.</i> However, a priest’s daughter who is waiting to be married by a brother-in-law is not at all liable to death for harlotry. Whether she is an Israelite’s daughter or a priest’s daughter, her punishment is only that of having violated a simple negative precept.<sup class="footnote-marker">189</sup><i class="footnote">This would be stripes, but not the death penalty.</i> And should you say that marrying a childless brother’s wife was customary among the Sons of Noah, and that she was regarded by them as having the status of a married woman, and that their prohibitions were punishable by death, it would not be correct. The Rabbis say in Bereshith Rabbah<sup class="footnote-marker">157</sup><i class="footnote">85:6.</i> that Judah was the one who first inaugurated the observance of the commandment that a brother marry a childless brother’s widow. And again, in the <i>Gemara</i> in Tractate Sanhedrin,<sup class="footnote-marker">190</sup><i class="footnote">Sanhedrin 58a.</i> it is made clear that a childless brother’s widow of the Sons of Noah is not at all liable to any punishment for harlotry.<br>It appears to me that since Judah was a chief, an officer, and a ruler of the land, his daughter-in-law who committed harlotry against him was not judged by the same law as other people, but as one who degraded royalty. It is for this reason that it is written, <i>And Judah said: Bring her forth, and let her be burnt</i>, for the people came before him to do unto her in accordance with his command, and he declared her guilty of a capital crime because of the superior rank of royalty. Thus he judged her as if she had profaned her father in respect of his priesthood, but this was not the judgment meted out to commoners.<br>In line with the literal interpretation of Scripture, it is possible that their law was similar to that which is presently customary in some of the countries of Spain, i.e., that a married woman who commits a faithless act is turned over to her husband who decrees death or life for her, as he wishes. Now Tamar was designated for his son Shelah, and in the eyes of their laws she was considered as a married woman.

Verse 25



Verse 26

SHE IS RIGHTEOUS FROM ME. “<i>She is righteous</i> in her words. <i>From me</i> is she with child. Our Rabbis expounded that a <i>bath kol</i> (a Divine voice) came forth and said the word <i>mimeni</i>, i.e., ‘From Me and from My authority did these events unfold.’” This is Rashi’s language.<br>The correct interpretation is that it is similar to the verses: <i>Men more righteous and better than he;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">191</sup><i class="footnote">I Kings 2:32.</i> <i>And he</i> [Saul] <i>said to David, Thou art more righteous than I; for thou hast rendered unto me good, whereas I have rendered unto thee evil</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">192</sup><i class="footnote">I Samuel 24:18.</i> Here too the meaning is: “She is more righteous than I, for she acted righteously and I am the one who sinned against her by not giving her my son Shelah.” The purport of the statement is that Shelah was the brother-in-law, [hence he was the first designated to marry her], and if he did not wish to take her as his wife, his father is next in line to act as the redeemer, as I have explained above<sup class="footnote-marker">193</sup><i class="footnote">In Verse 8 here.</i> when I discussed the law of marrying a childless brother’s widow.
AND HE KNEW HER AGAIN NO MORE (<i>‘v’lo yasaph’</i>). After having established progeny for his children, he did not wish to be with her again even though this was dependent upon his wish as she was not forbidden to him, being, in fact, considered as his wife, as is the law when the widow of a childless man has relations with a relative. This is the reason for the explanation given by a certain Sage,<sup class="footnote-marker">194</sup><i class="footnote">Shmuel the Elder (Sotah 10 b).</i> who explains the verse as saying, “And he did not <i>cease</i> to know her,”<sup class="footnote-marker">195</sup><i class="footnote">Since Tamar did in fact become his legitimate wife, as explained above, he did not cease living with her.</i> since here the expression used is, <i>v’lo yasaph</i>, and elsewhere it is written, <i>A great voice ‘v’lo yasaph’</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">196</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 5:19. Reference there is to the Divine Voice that came forth from Mount Sinai, concerning which Scripture says, <i>v’lo yasaph</i> [with a <i>kamatz</i>], meaning “and it did not cease,” or “it did not diminish in strength,” unlike the human voice which decreases and eventually stops completely. Here also the identical expression, <i>v’lo yasaph</i> [with a <i>patach</i>], means “and he did not cease.”</i>

Verse 27



Verse 28



Verse 29

HOW HAST THOU BURST FORTH? THIS BURSTING UPON THYSELF (‘PARATZTA ALECHA’). “What a strong effort you have made!” thus the language of Rashi.<br>But the word <i>paretz</i>, wherever used, signifies the breaching of a fence and passing through, just as: <i>I will break down (‘p’rotz’) the fence thereof;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">197</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 5:5.</i> <i>Why hast Thou broken down (‘paratzta’) her fences?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">198</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 80:13.</i> And in the language of the Rabbis: “<i>Pirtzah</i> (a breach in a wall) calleth forth to the thief.”<sup class="footnote-marker">199</sup><i class="footnote">Sotah 26a.</i> Indeed, the Sacred Language<sup class="footnote-marker">200</sup><i class="footnote">Hebrew. See Ramban on Exodus 30:13, as to why Hebrew is called “a sacred” language.</i> uses the term <i>p’rotz</i> when referring to anything that oversteps its boundary: <i>And thou shalt break forth (‘upharatzta’) to the west, and to the east;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">201</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 28:14. Here referring to the conquest of land.</i> <i>And the man broke forth (‘vayiphrotz’) exceedingly</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">202</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 30:43. Here referring to an unusual increase in wealth. It is thus clear that the word <i>p’rotz</i> is used to refer to anything which breaks forth from its normal boundary.</i> It is for this reason that the verse here is saying, at the time that the first child drew back his hand, and this one hurriedly came out, “What great breach hast thou made in the fence in order to hurry out before him?” The verse says, <i>alecha</i> (upon thee), to indicate that ‘the fence’ was upon him, and he was imprisoned in it. The sense of the verse is thus: “What great breach did you take upon yourself to make in the fence, with the result that you came out of it?”<br>Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra said in explanation of the verse: “<i>Mah paratzta</i>? What have you broken, in the manner of a man who makes a breach in a fence and exits through it, and now the responsibility for this breach is upon you.”<sup class="footnote-marker">203</sup><i class="footnote">That is, “if in the process of your hurried exit you would have caused harm or death to your brother, you would have been held responsible.”</i><br>There is no point to this interpretation. In the Midrash of Rabbi Nechunya ben Hakaneh<sup class="footnote-marker">204</sup><i class="footnote">Sefer Habahir, 196. See Note 42, <i>Seder Bereshith</i>.</i> there is mentioned a mystic principle in connection with the name of these children, Peretz and Zerach. Thus they said: “He was called <i>Zerach</i> (shining) on account of the sun which always shines, and <i>Peretz</i> (breaking) on account of the moon which is sometimes dismantled<sup class="footnote-marker">205</sup><i class="footnote">Referring to the days when the moonlight decreases, and to the end of the month when its light completely disapppears.</i> and sometimes whole. Now was not Peretz the firstborn, and yet the sun is greater than the moon?<sup class="footnote-marker">206</sup><i class="footnote">In which case Zerach, whose name is symbolic of the sun, should have been the first born.</i> This presents no difficulty, for it does indeed say, <i>And he</i> [Zerach] <i>put out his hand</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">207</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 28 here. Thus Zerach was indeed the firstborn.</i> and it is further written, <i>And afterwards came out his brother</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">208</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 30 here, referring to Zerach. And the verse concludes; <i>that had the shining red thread upon his hand</i>, thus indicating the importance of his having put out his hand first.</i> Now according to their opinion, the moon is associated with the name Peretz on account of the kingdom of the House of David.<sup class="footnote-marker">209</sup><i class="footnote">Having gone through various periods of ascendancy and decline in its history, the kingdom of the House of David resembles the light of the moon which is constantly changing.</i> Peretz and Zerach were born twins since the moon functions by means of the sun. Thus Peretz is the twin of Zerach who gives forth the hand, while he<sup class="footnote-marker">210</sup><i class="footnote">That is, Peretz. In other words, by putting forth his hand, Zerach indicated that the birthright was to have been his, but Peretz, by coming out first, indicated the consent of the Supreme One to his being appointed the firstborn.</i> is the firstborn by virtue of the power of the Supreme One, as is said, <i>I also appoint him first-born</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">211</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 89:28.</i> This is the purport of the saying of the Sages with respect to the Sanctification of the Moon: “David King of Israel lives and exists.”<sup class="footnote-marker">212</sup><i class="footnote">Rosh Hashanah 25a. Ramban’s meaning is that since the kingdom of David evolved from Peretz, and Peretz is symbolized by the moon, the Sages of the Talmud, when wishing to inform the Jews in other countries that the New Moon had appeared and been sanctified by the Great Court, would use this message: “David, king….” This they did in order to circumvent a prohibition by the Romans against transmitting news regarding the times set for the festivals. See Ramban above, 32:26.</i> The man learned [in the mystic teachings of the Cabala] will understand.

Chapter 39



Verse 1



Verse 2



Verse 3

THAT THE ETERNAL WAS WITH HIM. The name of G-d was a familiar word in his mouth. This is Rashi’s language. But it does not appear to be correct.<sup class="footnote-marker">213</sup><i class="footnote">For, according to Rashi, the text should have read: “that the name of the Eternal was familiar in his mouth”</i> Instead, <i>And his lord saw that the Eternal was with him</i>, means that he saw that his endeavors were always more successful than that of anyone else, so he knew that success came to him from G-d. In a similar sense is the verse, <i>We have surely seen that the Eternal was with thee</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">214</sup><i class="footnote">Above 26:28.</i> Thus Joseph found favor in his lord’s eyes, and he appointed him as his personal attendant and overseer of his house.

Verse 4

AND ALL THAT HE HAD HE GAVE INTO HIS HAND. I.e., to be overseer and officer in charge of all that he had in the house and in the field. Our Rabbis have a Midrash on this verse. Thus they say:<sup class="footnote-marker">215</sup><i class="footnote">Bereshith Rabbah 86:6.</i> “He would whisper<sup class="footnote-marker">216</sup><i class="footnote">His father’s instructions. (<i>Ibid.</i>, Commentaries.)</i> whenever he entered and whenever he left. If his master said to him, ‘Mix a hot drink,’ it was hot immediately in Joseph’s hands and if he said, ‘Mix it lukewarm,’ it was lukewarm. [Because he suspected Joseph of witchcraft, his master said to him,] ‘What is this, Joseph? Bringing witchcraft to Egypt is like importing straw to Ofraim!’<sup class="footnote-marker">217</sup><i class="footnote">“Straw to Ofraim” is the Midrashic equivalent of the present day expression, “coals to Newcastle.”</i> How long did his master suspect him of practicing witchcraft? It was until he saw the Divine Presence standing over him. This is the meaning of the words, <i>And his lord saw that the Eternal was with him</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">218</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 3 here.</i><br/>The point of this Midrash is that because his lord was an Egyptian who did not know the Eternal, the Sages in the Midrash said that when he saw Joseph’s great success he suspected that it was done by witchcraft, as was the case with his countrymen, until he saw in a vision which was shown to him in a dream, or, when awake, in the form of a cloud of glory or the like, that his success came from the Supreme One. This was done in honor of the righteous Joseph.

Verse 5



Verse 6

SAVE THE BREAD WHICH HE DID EAT. In the words of our Rabbis, this is a refined expression which refers to his wife.<sup class="footnote-marker">219</sup><i class="footnote">Bereshith Rabbah 86:7.</i><br>Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra said in interpretation of the verse that whatever Potiphar possessed was left in the hands of Joseph excepting the bread which he ate. This he did not even permit him to touch since he was a Hebrew. It was the customary behavior of the Egyptians towards the Hebrews that they not permit the Hebrews to touch their food, <i>because that is abhorrent to the Egyptians</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">220</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 43:32.</i><br>Possibly this is so. Perhaps the interpretation of the verse is that his lord did not know of Joseph taking anything from him save only the bread which Joseph ate, but no other pleasures as young people are wont to do. Nor did he gather wealth and property, just as it is said of David, <i>And I have found no fault in him since he fell unto me unto this day</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">221</sup><i class="footnote">I Samuel 29:3.</i> Now the verse, <i>Having me, he knoweth not what is in the house</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">222</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 8 here. Joseph speaking to Potiphar’s wife.</i> expresses another matter, namely, that he [Joseph’s lord] did not trouble himself to know about anything inside the house. But the present verse, <i>Having him, he knew not aught</i>, is an expression of negation; he knew that nothing in the house is [taken by Joseph except the bread which he eats].<sup class="footnote-marker">223</sup><i class="footnote">See my Hebrew commentary, pp. 219-220.</i>
AND JOSEPH WAS HANDSOME AND GOOD-LOOKING. The verse mentions this here in order to indicate that it was on <i>account</i> of his good looks that his master’s wife cast her eyes upon him. And Rashi wrote that because he saw that he was ruler of the house, he began to eat and drink, and curl his hair, etc.<sup class="footnote-marker">224</sup><i class="footnote">“The Holy One, blessed be He, said to Joseph: ‘Your father is mourning for you, and you curl your hair. I will incite a bear against you.’” (Rashi.) That is, “I shall let temptation loose against you.”</i>

Verse 7



Verse 8

BUT HE REFUSED, AND SAID UNTO HIS MASTER’s WIFE. Scripture relates that he refused to do her will even though she was his mistress, i.e., his master’s wife, and he feared her, for he feared G-d more. This is the meaning of the expression, <i>unto his master’s wife</i>.

Verse 9

AND I SHALL SIN AGAINST G-D. The Sons of Noah<sup class="footnote-marker">225</sup><i class="footnote">See Note 113 above.</i> were commanded concerning forbidden relations. This is Rashi’s language.<br>This is correct. It is only due to the feminine lack of knowledge that he first told her that the act would constitute a betrayal of his master who trusted him, and following that he added that it also involves a sin against G-d.<br>It is possible to further explain the verse, <i>And I shall sin against G-d</i>, by this betrayal, since “it would be a matter of great evil consequence which would be accounted to me as a sin against G-d since His eyes are <i>upon the faithful of the land</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">226</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 101:6.</i> and no traitor dare come before Him.” Joseph spoke the truth. However he did not mention the prohibition of the illicit relation<sup class="footnote-marker">227</sup><i class="footnote">According to this interpretation.</i> because he spoke in language suitable to women.

Verse 10

TO LIE ‘ETZLA’ (BY HER). The meaning of this expression is as Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra interpreted it: “even to lie near her, each in their garment, or to be with her for general conversation.” This interpretation is correct since we do not find the word <i>etzla</i> (near her) in Scripture in connection with sexual intercourse, only the word <i>ima</i> (with her) or <i>othah</i> (with her), as for example: <i>Lie ‘imi’ (with me);</i><sup class="footnote-marker">228</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 12 here.</i> <i>And if any man lie ‘othah’ (with her);</i><sup class="footnote-marker">229</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 15:24.</i> <i>And the women ravished (‘tishachavnah’)</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">230</sup><i class="footnote">Zechariah 14:2. In <i>tishachavnah</i>, the plural form of <i>othah</i> is implicit.</i>

Verse 11



Verse 12

AND HE LEFT HIS GARMENT IN HER HAND. Out of respect for his mistress he did not wish to take the garment from her hand with his superior strength, and he removed it from upon himself, as it was a garment which one wears as a robe and headdress. But when she saw that he left his garment in her hands she feared lest he expose her to the people of the household or his master, and so she preceded him to them, saying that he had removed his garment to lie with her, but “when he saw that I screamed he fled in confusion.” This is the meaning of the verse, <i>And it came to pass, when she saw that he had left his garment in her hand</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">231</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 13 here.</i> This is also why she did not say, “And he left his garment in my hand,” but she instead told the men of her house and her husband, <i>And he left his garment ‘etzli’ (with me)</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">232</sup><i class="footnote">The word <i>etzli</i> (with me) indicates that he himself had removed his garment, as explained above.</i>

Verse 13



Verse 14

SEE, HE HATH BROUGHT IN A HEBREW UNTO US. The meaning thereof is that the Hebrews were hated by the Egyptians. They did not eat with them, this being a matter of abhorrence to them.<sup class="footnote-marker">233</sup><i class="footnote">See further, 43:32.</i> They did not purchase them as servants except as vinedressers and plowmen, but they would not permit them to come into their homes. This is why she said: “Behold, the master has done us evil by bringing a Hebrew into our home, and he has further appointed him as overseer and ruler, and now he has fittingly seen to mock us.” [The point of her statement] is similar to that which is said in the verse, <i>He that delicately bringeth up his servant from a child shall have him become a master at the last</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">234</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 29:21.</i> This is the meaning of her saying, <i>Whom thou hast brought unto us</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">235</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 17 here.</i> as his being brought into their house was in itself embarassing to them.<br>In the verse before us, the expression, <i>He has brought us</i>, refers to her husband. She does not mention him by name out of respect,<sup class="footnote-marker">236</sup><i class="footnote">In view of the fact that she blames him for what happened.</i> or perhaps because such is the ethical way for women to speak, or perhaps because it is known who brought Joseph into the house. Similarly, in many places in the book of Job it speaks of Almighty G-d anonymously because the conversants know that they are speaking of Him. Similarly, in the verse, <i>And he said to Abner, Why hast thou gone in unto my father’s concubine?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">237</sup><i class="footnote">II Samuel 3:7.</i> the name of the speaker is not mentioned, and no reference is made to him at all in the above verse because it is known that he was Ish-bosheth.<sup class="footnote-marker">238</sup><i class="footnote">Of “the house of Saul,” mentioned there in Verse 6. And it is already self-understood that the speaker in Verse 7 is Ish-bosheth, as he was the leader of the house of Saul. (R’dak.)</i>

Verse 15



Verse 16



Verse 17



Verse 18



Verse 19

AND IT CAME TO PASS, WHEN THE MASTER HEARD. She told him about it at the time of conjugal intimacy. <i>Matters such as these did your servant to me</i>, i.e., matters of intimacy such as these. So says Rashi.<br>So also did they say in Bereshith Rabbah:<sup class="footnote-marker">239</sup><i class="footnote">87:10.</i> “Rabbi Abahu said, ‘She said it to him at the time of conjugal relations.’”<br>Now I wonder. Joseph’s master was a castrate,<sup class="footnote-marker">240</sup><i class="footnote">Sotah 13b.</i> who had married his wife during his youth, and the Rabbis expounded, “ <i>‘Sris’ (a captain of) Pharaoh</i><sup class="footnote-marker">241</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 37:36.</i> — this teaches us that he bought Joseph for carnal purposes only, but the Holy One, blessed be He, caused Joseph’s master to become castrated.”<sup class="footnote-marker">242</sup><i class="footnote">The Hebrew word for castrate is <i>saris</i>, the same word mentioned in the verse above.</i> Moreover, how would she dare discredit herself and become loathsome in the eyes of her husband by telling him that she had committed adultery, whether by force or with acquiescence, which would have merited mortal punishment, for why did she not cry out at the outset, so that he should run away, as she did at the end? Now to the men of her house she said, <i>He came unto me to lie with me</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">243</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 14 here.</i> but not that he lay with her, only that he came to do so, but she cried out and he fled. And surely she would hide the matter from her husband. And should you say that she told him so in order that his anger be kindled against him and that he should kill him, [it would have been sufficient for this purpose that she say that he attempted to violate her, for] any servant that attempts to violate his master’s wife deserves the death penalty!<br>It is possible that they intended to explain the expression, <i>Matters such as these</i>, as meaning matters of intimacy, meaning, exposing and caressing but not actual intimacy, as his master had become physically castrate, having been visited by a disease which resulted in a lack of desire for conjugal relations, as is the case with a <i>shachuf</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">244</sup><i class="footnote">One whose genitals are atrophied.</i><br>In line with the literal interpretation of Scripture there is no need for all this, for the Hebrew letter <i>kaph</i>, in the word <i>kadvarim</i>, is not for the purpose of expressing comparison to other matters. Instead its meaning is “these things.”<sup class="footnote-marker">245</sup><i class="footnote">I.e., only to indicate approximation, and here meaning: “matters as these, more or less.”</i> A similar usage [of the letter <i>kaph</i> is found in these verses]: <i>And she told her mother’s house ‘kadvarim ha’eileh’ (according to these words);</i><sup class="footnote-marker">246</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 24:28. </i> <i>And when he had spoken unto me ‘kadvarim ha’eileh’ (according to these words) I set my face toward the ground</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">247</sup><i class="footnote">Daniel 10:15. </i> There are many similar verses. It may be that the verse is saying that when his master heard his wife’s words which she told him — “Your servant did unto me such matters as these which I had immediately related to the men of the house” — then his anger was kindled.<br>It is possible that the <i>kaph</i> is here used for exaggeration, similar to its use in the verses: <i>Why speaketh my lord ‘kadvarim ha’eileh’ (such words as these)?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">248</sup><i class="footnote">Further 44:7.</i> <i>And there have befallen me such things as these (‘ka’eileh’)?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">249</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 10:19.</i><br>Now due to his master’s love for Joseph he did not kill him, or it was a miracle of G-d, or knowing Joseph’s righteousness, he doubted her words. Similarly the Rabbis said in Bereshith Rabbah:<sup class="footnote-marker">250</sup><i class="footnote">Bereshith Rabbah 87:10.</i> “The master said to Joseph, ‘I know this charge against you is false, but lest a stigma fall on my children,<sup class="footnote-marker">251</sup><i class="footnote">Lest people say; “Just as she was free with you, so she was with others, and the children she had are not his.”</i> [I will put you in prison].’”

Verse 20

AND HE PUT HIM INTO PRISON, THE PLACE WHERE THE KING’s PRISONERS WERE BOUND. Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra says that the verse itself explains that a <i>beth haso’ar</i> (prison) is “a place where the king’s prisoners were bound.” The reason this is stated in the verse itself is that <i>beth haso’ar</i> is an Egyptian word, for it is the style of Scripture to explain foreign words just as, <i>they cast pur, that is the lot</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">252</sup><i class="footnote">Esther 3:7.</i><br>This interpretation is of no significance. Rather, <i>And he put him into the prison</i>, means that he put him into a certain prison recognized as the royal prison, which was the place where the king’s prisoners were bound. The sense of the verse is thus to state that this was the cause of the butler and the baker being imprisoned with him.<br>It is possible that the term, “the king’s prisoners,” means his servants and attendants who have sinned against him in matters of state, as other prisoners of the people sentenced by judges and officers were placed in another prison house. Scripture relates that they placed Joseph in the king’s prison because of his master’s love for Joseph, all of which was caused by G-d.<br>Linguists<sup class="footnote-marker">253</sup><i class="footnote">Here referring to R’dak, who so writes in his Book of Roots, under the term <i>sohar</i>.</i> explain <i>sohar</i> as an arched chamber, similar in expression to, <i>agan hasohar</i> (a round goblet).<sup class="footnote-marker">254</sup><i class="footnote">Song of Songs 7:3.</i> In my opinion it is an underground house having a small opening above ground, through which the prisoners are lowered and from which they have light. The word <i>sohar</i> is thus derived from the word <i>sihara</i> (light) in Aramaic, just as in Hebrew, Scripture says; <i>A transparency (‘tzohar’) shalt thou make to the ark</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">255</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 6:16.</i> the word <i>tzohar</i> being derived from <i>tzaharayim</i> (mid-day — when the light reaches its zenith). The difference between <i>tzohar</i> and <i>sohar</i> is that <i>tzohar</i> connotes an abundance of light, while <i>sohar</i> connotes minimal light.

Chapter 40



Verse 1



Verse 2

AGAINST TWO ‘SARISAV’ (OF HIS EUNUCHS). These two lords were both castrates, for as they also acted as the chiefs of the butlers and bakers in the women’s quarters in the royal apartments, the kings would customarily castrate them. Onkelos’ opinion though is that <i>sarisim</i> means lords and chiefs. Thus he says of Potiphar, who is called <i>sris par’oh</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">241</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 37:36.</i> “the officer of Pharaoh,” and in the present verse he similarly translates, “against his two officers.” And so did the Targum Yonathan translate: <i>And they shall be ‘sarisim’ in the palace of the king of Babylon</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">256</sup><i class="footnote">II Kings 20:18. Yonathan translated this as: “And they shall be officers.”</i>

Verse 3



Verse 4



Verse 5

EACH MAN ACCORDING TO THE INTERPRETATION OF HIS DREAM. The expression “interpreting dreams” means relating the events which will happen in the future, and he who foretells that future is called <i>potheir</i> (interpreter). In the opinion of many scholars the word <i>pithron</i> signifies “meaning.”<sup class="footnote-marker">257</sup><i class="footnote">But it does not signify the foretelling of future events.</i> And the interpretation of the verse, <i>Each man according to the interpretation of his dream</i>, is that each dreamed a dream consistent with the interpretation<sup class="footnote-marker">258</sup><i class="footnote">The butler dreamed of wine, the symbol of joy, while the baker dreamed of a bird snatching the food he was bringing to the king, an event which signifies grief. (Tur.)</i> which foretold the future that was to befall them. This is Rashi’s language.<br>Now what sense does it make for Pharaoh’s chief butler to say, “We have dreamed a dream consistent with the interpretation,” thereby minimizing the wisdom of the interpreter. Besides, Pharaoh’s dream [related later on] may not have been so, [that is, consistent with the interpretation], and Joseph would not know it.<sup class="footnote-marker">259</sup><i class="footnote">Why then did he recommend Joseph as being able to interpret the king’s dream? The king had not yet related his dream, and it could be that that dream might not be consistent with its interpretation, as was the case in his own dream. Why then did he not fear for his life in recommending Joseph to the king?</i><br>Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra says in explanation of the verse that each saw in his dream the truth concerning the future as the interpretation would indicate, meaning that it was a true dream, not the kind which comes from many worries, of which only a part is fulfilled. This is the correct interpretation.

Verse 6



Verse 7

AND HE ASKED PHARAOH’s OFFICERS THAT WERE WITH HIM IN THE WARD OF HIS MASTER’s HOUSE. It would be proper for Scripture to say; “And he asked them, saying.” Instead, Scripture speaks at length about it for its desire is to speak in praise of Joseph. Here is a servant lad who is enquiring of two great officers who are wards in the house of his master who hates him,<sup class="footnote-marker">260</sup><i class="footnote">“Who <i>hates</i> him.” Ramban is here writing from the standpoint of the butler and the baker, who must have thought that Joseph’s master imprisoned him because he hated him, not being aware, as explained above, that he did so to protect his family’s reputation.</i> and each of whom could command his hanging.<sup class="footnote-marker">261</sup><i class="footnote">If his interpretation of the dreams would turn out to be incorrect. Thus, as explained further on by Ramban, if the baker had been restored to his position, he would have seen to it that Joseph pay for his mistake with his life.</i> Yet he was not afraid of them, and asked them their dreams and told them his opinion with respect to the interpretation because he trusted in his wisdom. Had the lord of the bakers been saved and restored to his position by the king, he would have hung him for his false interpretation.

Verse 8

AND THERE IS NO INTERPRETER OF IT. The meaning thereof is that “there is no one to inform us concerning the future which can be derived from the dream.”<br>It is possible that they sent for some magicians in the morning, or that there were people with them in the prison, but no one could interpret it. It may be that they said; “There is no one in the world, in our opinion, who can interpret it, for it is very obscure.”
DO NOT (‘HALO’) INTERPRETATIONS BELONG TO G-D? Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra explained it as saying that “future events destined to come as indicated in dreams belong to G-d, for He alone brings on the dream and lets the future be known, and it is He <i>who makes peace, and creates evil</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">262</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 45:7.</i> but in my speaking to you there is neither benefit nor loss.” This he said so that they should not punish him if evil should befall them, or so that they should tell him the dreams and not scorn him.<sup class="footnote-marker">263</sup><i class="footnote">Thus far the comment of Rabbi ibn Ezra.</i><br>But if so, there is no sense for the word <i>halo</i> (do not) in this context.<sup class="footnote-marker">264</sup><i class="footnote">Since Joseph is stating it all in the affirmative; “dreams belong to G-d, etc.” the interrogative form of the word <i>halo</i> is out of place.</i> Perhaps its meaning is the same as that of the word <i>hinei</i> (behold). Thus Joseph is saying, “Behold, to G-d alone belong interpretations, but not to man the interpreter.”<br>In my opinion the correct interpretation is that Joseph is saying; “Do not interpretations of all dreams which are obscure and confined belong to G-d? He can make known the interpretation of your dreams. Now if it is obscure to you tell it to me; perhaps He will be pleased to reveal His secret to me.”

Verse 9



Verse 10

AND IT WAS AS THOUGH IT BUDDED AND ITS BLOSSOM WENT UP. “It seemed as though it budded. <i>And it was as though it budded</i>, i.e., it seemed to me in my dream as though it budded, and after the bud its blossom shot up, and after that it brought forth the clusters and then the ripe grapes. Onkelos translates: ‘And, when it buddeth, it brought forth sprouts.’ These words are the translation of the word <i>porachath</i> alone.”<sup class="footnote-marker">265</sup><i class="footnote">The Hebrew states: <i>V’hi keporachath althah nitzah</i>. Rashi’s intent, in quoting the Targum, is to say that Onkelos’ words, <i>apeikath lavlevin</i> (brought forth sprouts), is an expression which Onkelos appended to his translation of the Hebrew word <i>porachath</i>. Ramban will later differ with this opinion, holding that it constitutes Onkelos’ rendition of the Hebrew word <i>althah</i>, and signifies: “And it, when it budded, <i>immediately</i> brought forth sprouts.” See below, Note 271.</i> Thus far the words of Rashi.<br>This is not correct. If he is speaking in terms of appearances because they are matters of a dream, he should say, “Behold, <i>like</i> a vine was before me, and on the vine <i>like</i> three shoots.”<sup class="footnote-marker">266</sup><i class="footnote">Instead, Scripture states: “Behold, a vine was before me. And on the vine were three shoots.”(Verses 9-10.)</i> This <i>kaph</i> of comparison is found neither in the dream of the chief of the bakers nor in the dream of Pharaoh. Why then should the chief of butlers use the comparative form more than the others? Instead, in all three dreams it says <i>v’hinei</i> (and behold).<sup class="footnote-marker">267</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 9, in the dream of the butler; Verse 16, in the dream of the baker, and in Chapter 41, Verse 3, the word <i>v’hinei</i> is used in connection with Pharaoh’s dream.</i> It is this word which indicates comparison, for its meaning is “as if.”<br>But the explanation of the verse before us, <i>And it was ‘keporachath’ its blossoms shot up</i>, is that he saw that immediately as it budded, its blossoms shot up and its clusters ripened into grapes. This was to indicate that G-d was hastening to do it. This is how Joseph recognized that the “three shoots” indicated three days, and not months or years, and he himself deduced that on the same day the two will be summoned before the king. It may be [that this was also indicated by the dreams] because both of them dreamed in one night. Thus there is no need for the words of Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra, who says that Joseph knew of Pharaoh’s birthday.<br>This usage of a <i>kaph</i> to indicate immediacy is found in many places: <i>And it came to pass, ‘k’meishiv’ (as he drew back) his hand;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">268</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 38:29.</i> <i>‘k’vo Avram’ (as Abram came);</i><sup class="footnote-marker">269</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 12:14.</i> <i>‘uk’eith’ (and at the time) of her death the women that stood by her said</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">270</sup><i class="footnote">I Samuel 4:20.</i> and many others.<br>Onkelos’ rendition into Aramaic stating, “And when it budded, it brought forth sprouts,” [means to say that the expression “brought forth sprouts”] is a translation of the Hebrew word <i>althah</i>, meaning that it immediately brought forth sprouts of the vine. That is, as soon as it budded, it brought forth large sprouts, its blossoms shot up, and its clusters ripened into grapes.<sup class="footnote-marker">271</sup><i class="footnote">Rashi is of the opinion that Onkelos’ expression, <i>va’aneitzath neitz</i>, (not mentioned by Ramban, but appearing in the Targum, following <i>apeikath lavlevin</i>, mentioned above in Note 265), is the Aramaic equivalent of the Hebrew <i>althah nitzah</i>. Ramban however says that it is the translation only of the word <i>nitzah</i>, for <i>althah</i> (shoot up) could not refer to <i>nitzah</i> (sprouts). This is why, according to Ramban, Onkelos translated the word <i>althah</i> as <i>apeikath lavlevin</i> (it brought forth sprouts). In brief, according to Rashi’s understanding of the Targum, the Hebrew <i>v’hi keporachath</i> is rendered by the Targum as <i>kad aphrachath apeikath lavlevin</i>. The Hebrew <i>althah nitzah</i> is rendered <i>va’aneitzath neitz</i>. In the opinion of Ramban, <i>v’hi keporachath</i> is rendered by the Targum as <i>kad aphrachath;</i> the Hebrew <i>althah</i> is rendered <i>apeikath lavlevin</i>, and the Hebrew <i>nitzah</i> has its equivalent in Onkelos’ <i>va’aneitzath nitzah</i>.</i> Onkelos would not apply the word <i>althah</i> (shoot up) to <i>nitzah</i> (sprouts), as they do not “shoot up.”

Verse 11



Verse 12



Verse 13



Verse 14

BUT HAVE ME IN THY REMEMBRANCE. “If you will remember me when it will be well with you, I now pray for the kindness and truth you will do to me by making mention of me to Pharaoh.” And if the word <i>na</i><sup class="footnote-marker">272</sup><i class="footnote"><i>V’asitha ‘na’ imadi chesed</i>. In the explanation above the Hebrew word <i>na</i> was understood in the sense of ‘now’: “If you will remember me then… I <i>now</i> pray for the kindness and truth you would show me.” But according to the second interpretation, the word <i>na</i> is understood as supplication, as explained in the text.</i> is to be understood as expressing supplication, the sense of the verse is: “If you will remember me and would, in your mercy, do me a kindness, I beg that you remember me to Pharaoh.”<br>The sense of the word <i>itcha</i> (with thee) is that “you should remember to show me mercy in the very same way that it has been shown to you, i.e., that you went out from prison.” The interpretation may be that “you should remember me in your heart as if I am with you.”<br>The purport of mentioning him before Pharaoh is that he should praise him by saying, “Now in the house of the chief of the officers there is an excellent servant fit to enter the service of kings.”<br>It further appears to me correct that Joseph is saying: “If you will remember me to be with you when all goes well with you and you return to your high position, and you should want to do me this kindness, then make mention of me to Pharaoh, saying to him, ‘I remember a lad who served me in the prison; give him to me to be my servant.’ <i>And bring me out of this house</i> for it is a great sin to those who retain me here.”<br>It may be that the meaning of the expression, <i>And make mention of me to Pharaoh</i>, is that “Pharaoh saw me when I was a servant to his minister, in charge of all he had and performing my duties before him,<sup class="footnote-marker">273</sup><i class="footnote">Thus, the sense of the verse is to state that “all you need do is mention my name to Pharaoh, as he knows me already.”</i> and if you will remember me before him you will bring about my release from here. I have committed no sin, and it is befitting the king to release me and thereby save me from the hands of my oppressors, for <i>there is no matter hid from the king</i><sup class="footnote-marker">274</sup><i class="footnote">II Samuel 18:13.</i> if he desires.”

Verse 15

THE LAND OF THE HEBREWS. This means the land of Hebron, wherein dwelt Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob. Abraham, the head of the lineage, was called “Abraham the Hebrew”<sup class="footnote-marker">275</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 14:13.</i> since he came from across the River Euphrates, and he was honored among the nations for in him was fulfilled the blessing, <i>And I will make thy name great</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">276</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 12:1.</i> It is for this reason that all of his seed are called <i>Ivrim</i> (Hebrews). They hold on to this name in order not to intermingle with the various peoples in the Canaanite lands, and this name has been established as the name for all Israel’s seed forever. This is the meaning of the verse, <i>He hath brought in a Hebrew unto us</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">277</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 39:14.</i> since Joseph told them “I am a Hebrew,” and he did not want them to take him as a Canaanite. And the land where they resided was called “the land of the Hebrews,” that is to say, the land in which the Hebrews are.<sup class="footnote-marker">278</sup><i class="footnote">But not that it is theirs.</i> It may be that it was so called because they were its leaders and nobles, even as it says, <i>Thou art a prince of G-d in the midst of us</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">279</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 23:6.</i> and it is further written, <i>Touch not My anointed ones</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">280</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 105:15.</i>

Verse 16

THAT THE INTERPRETATION WAS GOOD. Onkelos rendered it that he interpreted it well. A similar use is found in the verses: <i>Teach me fair discernment and knowledge;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">281</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 119:66.</i> <i>That they were ‘tovoth’ (fair)</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">282</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 6:2.</i> which means “pretty.” The intent of the verse is to state that this man [the lord of the bakers] had scorned Joseph, thinking of him as not ever knowing how to interpret the dream, and he would never have told him the dream had he not seen that he interpreted for his friend in a fair and proper manner. It may be that the verse is saying: “And the lord of the bakers saw that he gave a favorable interpretation to the lord of the butlers and he rejoiced. He then told him his own dream which had caused him more anguish than that of his friend.”
BASKETS OF ‘CHORI.’”Baskets made of peeled willows, made so that they have many holes.” This is Rashi’s language.<br>Rav Saadia Gaon<sup class="footnote-marker">283</sup><i class="footnote">See the Commentary of Abraham ibn Ezra.</i> interpreted it as “baskets of white bread,” white as befits the king’s bread, with the word <i>chori</i> being derived from the Hebrew, <i>Neither shall his face now wax white (‘yechvaru’)</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">284</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 29:22.</i> as well as from the Aramaic where the word <i>chivar</i> means “white.” This is the correct interpretation, for all the baskets in the dream contained the king’s bread, and in the uppermost basket there were all manner of baked goods for Pharaoh.<br>You find it similarly in the language of our Rabbis in the Mishnah:<sup class="footnote-marker">285</sup><i class="footnote">Beitzah 2:6.</i> “Large loaves and white cakes (<i>v’chivri</i>) [may be baked on a Festival Day].” And in the Jerusalem Talmud on this Mishnah: “The Rabbis [in discussing the permissibleness of baking extra fine white breads on the Festival Day even though they require more work than ordinary bread] derived the meaning of <i>chori</i> from this verse: <i>And, behold, I had three baskets of ‘chori’ on my head</i>. “<sup class="footnote-marker">286</sup><i class="footnote">This establishes that the word <i>chori</i> in the verse and <i>chivri</i> in the Mishnah were considered by the Rabbis of the Talmud as identical. For just as in the case of the king’s bread it means “large and white,” as befits such bread, so does it have a similar meaning in the Mishnah. It is thus obvious that the Rabbis understood the word <i>chori</i>, as did Rav Saadia Gaon, to mean “white.”</i><br>Mikeitz

Chapter 41



Verse 1

BY THE ‘YE’OR’ (RIVER). With the exception of the Nile, none of the other rivers is called <i>ye’or</i>, a word signifying “canal,” because the entire country consists of artificially constructed canals, and the waters of the Nile<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">“Rain does not fall in Egypt, but the Nile rises and irrigates the land.” (Rashi, Exodus 7:17).</i> flow into them. This is the language of Rashi.<br>Onkelos however did translate the word <i>ye’or</i> here as “river,” but in the book of Exodus he translated <i>al ye’oreihem</i><sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 7:19.</i> as “on their canals,” as he had to distinguish between <i>nahar</i> and <i>ye’or</i> since they are both mentioned in the same verse: <i>‘al naharotham ve’al ye’oreihem’ (on their rivers and on their canals)</i>. Thus, according to Onkelos, all rivers are called <i>ye’orim</i>, with the large ones being called both <i>n’haroth</i> and <i>ye’orim</i> while those canals constructed by man are also called <i>ye’orim</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">Thus the word <i>nahar</i> applies only to a natural river, while the word <i>ye’or</i> applies to both a natural river and a man-made canal.</i> Thus we find that the Tigris, besides being called <i>nahar</i>, is also called <i>ye’or</i>, as it is written, <i>I was by the side of the great ‘nahar’ (river), which is Tigris… and behold a man clothed in linen</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">Daniel 10:4-5.</i> and it is further written there: <i>And, behold, there stood other two, the one on the bank of the ‘ye’or’ (river) on this side, and the other on the bank of the ‘ye’or’ on that side. And one said to the man clothed in linen, who was above the waters of the ‘ye’or’ (river)</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 12:5-6.</i> In my opinion the fact is as Onkelos said,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">When he said that <i>ye’or</i> and <i>nahar</i> are both terms for rivers.</i> as both <i>ye’or</i> and <i>nahar</i> convey the same concept, both being an expression for <i>orah</i> (light). The rain, likewise, is called <i>or</i> (light), as it is said: <i>He spreadeth ‘oro’ (His light) upon it;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">Job 36:30.</i> <i>He spreadeth abroad the cloud of ‘oro’ (His lighting);</i><sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 37:11.</i> and as Rabbi Yochanan said,<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">Bereshith Rabbah 26:18.</i> “All verses in Elihu’s speech in the book of Job containing the word <i>orah</i> refer to the coming down of rain.” Perhaps this is because the rains are influenced by the luminaries,<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">“Luminaries.” In his commentary to Job 36:30, Ibn Ezra writes: “For the rain is called <i>or</i> (light) on account of the small luminary (the moon), since its movements, by command of the Creator, cause the rain.” An identical explanation is also found in R’dak’s Sefer Hashorashim, under the root <i>or</i>.</i> and the rivers which are formed by the rains are thus related to their first cause,<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">This explains why rain is referred to in Elihu’s speech as <i>or</i> (light), since the rain is caused by the movement of the luminaries, as explained above.</i> the luminaries.

Verse 2

AND BEHOLD, THERE CAME UP OUT OF THE RIVER. Since the land of Egypt is irrigated by the river, and it is from the river that abundance or famine befalls them, the king saw the cows coming up out of the river. The cows symbolize plowing, and the ears of corn symbolize the harvest, just as Joseph said, <i>in which there shall be neither plowing nor harvest</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 45:6. Thus it is obvious that Joseph understood the characters in the dreams — i.e. the cows and the ears of corn — as symbolizing plowing and harvesting.</i> He saw that the river rose only slightly and there would thus be no plowing, and the little which will be planted in moist places, <i>a wind blowing from the east, a wind from the Eternal</i><sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">Hosea 13:15.</i> would burn them, even as he saw the ears of corn <i>parched with the east wind</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 6 here.</i><br>It would appear to be implied in the verses that the abundance was only in the land of Egypt, even as it said, <i>Seven years of great plenty throughout all the land of Egypt;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 29 here.</i> likewise the verse, <i>And he stored up all the food of the seven years which was in the land of Egypt</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 48 here.</i> But the famine, on the other hand, was in all the lands. And so did Joseph interpret it when he said, <i>And there shall arise after them seven years of famine</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 30 here.</i> and did not mention the land of Egypt. It was for this reason that in the other countries they were unable to store up food even if they had heard about it, as they undoubtedly did, for the matter was well known throughout their lands. Perhaps this was alluded to in the dream since with respect to the fat cows, it mentions, <i>And they fed in the reed-grass</i>, for it was there in Egypt that they fed and stood, but the lean ones, after they consumed the fat ones, <i>walked to and fro through the earth</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">Zechariah 6:7.</i> and Pharaoh did not know where they had gone.
BA’ACHU. Meaning “in the marshy land,” as in the verse, <i>Can ‘achu’ grow?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">Job 8:11.</i> This is the language of Rashi.<br>This is not correct, as <i>achu</i> is the name of the grass which grows, [and not the land upon which it grows, as Rashi explained it], just as in the verse, <i>Can the rush shoot up without mire, can the ‘achu’ (reed-grass) grow without water? It withereth before any other herb</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verses 11-12.</i> Thus it is obvious that the word <i>achu</i> is not the marsh land. Perhaps Rashi’s intent is that the grass which grows in the marsh-lands is called by the name of the land upon which it grows.<br>The correct interpretation is that <i>achu</i> is the generic name for all vegetation and grass which grow on the banks of the rivers and the marsh-lands. In that case, the letter <i>beth</i> in <i>ba’achu</i> would be as the <i>beth</i> in the verse, <i>Come, eat ‘b’lachmi’ (of my bread), and drink of the wine which I have mingled</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 9:5. Ramban’s intent is to say that if <i>achu</i> is the name of the grass, as he said in attempting to vindicate Rashi’s explanation, the verse before us should have said <i>achu</i>, rather than <i>ba’achu</i>. But if <i>achu</i> is a generic name, the term <i>ba’achu</i> is correct, and the verse would mean that they fed in the green foliage or vegetation which was upon the bank of the river.</i> for they were feeding on the bank of the river, just as it is said, <i>near the cows upon the bank of the river</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 3 here.</i> Now perhaps the word <i>achu</i> is a derivative of <i>achvah</i> (brotherhood), since many varieties of grass grow together.

Verse 3

AND THEY STOOD BESIDE THE COWS. I.e., by their side and near them. This was a sign that there would be no lapse of time between the years of plenty and the years of famine even though Pharaoh did not relate this to Joseph.<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">See Verse 19 here.</i> But perhaps the vision which Pharaoh saw and the relating of the dream to Joseph were really alike, except that Scripture did not concern itself [with mentioning all the details Pharaoh told Joseph], just as it added into the story [details not mentioned in the actual dream, as for example], <i>And it could not be known that they had eaten them up</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 21 here.</i> and also, <i>the ears of corn came up on one stalk</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 5 here.</i> which was a sign that the seven years will occur consecutively.

Verse 4

AND THE COWS ATE UP. In my opinion<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">Ramban’s interpretation differs from Rashi, who writes that the eating up of the fat by the lean indicates that all joy occasioned by the years of plenty would be forgotten in the days of the famine. His own opinion is presented in the text.</i> this is a sign that the years of famine shall consume the years of plenty. It is from this that Joseph inferred that he should tell Pharaoh, <i>And let them store up all the food of those good years</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 35 here.</i> <i>And the food shall serve as a reserve for the land against the seven years of famine</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 36 here.</i> as he saw that the healthy cows and ears of corn were absorbed by the lean ones.<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote">The fact that the fat ones were absorbed by the lean ones was a sign to Joseph that the food from the seven years of plenty should be kept as a reserve for the years of famine.</i> This was no mere counsel which Joseph proposed, for was he appointed to be a counselor of the king?<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">See II Chronicles 25:16.</i> It was only in connection with the interpretation of the dream that he said thus: <i>And the plenty shall be forgotten</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 30 here.</i> <i>And the plenty shall not be known</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 31 here.</i> These words of Joseph constitute the interpretation of: <i>It could not be known that they had eaten them up, their appearance being bad as previously</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 21 here.</i> for Joseph saw that by their consumption of the fat cows, the lean ones did not become fine and plump. They served them for subsistence only, for had they not eaten them they would have died in their lean state. This is unlike Rashi, who says that <i>the plenty shall be forgotten</i><sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 30 here.</i> is the interpretation of the eating itself.<sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote">But according to Ramban, Joseph’s words, <i>And the plenty shall be forgotten</i>, are the interpretation of the aspect of the dream expressed by: <i>It could not be known that they had eaten them up</i>.</i>

Verse 5



Verse 6

SPRUNG UP AFTER THEM. Not that he saw them springing up —[although the word <i>tzomchoth</i> is actually in the present tense] — for he saw ripe ears of corn. But the verse is to be interpreted as if it said “they sprang up,” [i.e., <i>tzamchu</i>, which is in the past tense], suggesting that no sooner did he see the full ears than he immediately saw the thin ones coming up after them, for he saw the sign of immediacy in all facets of the dream.

Verse 7

AND PHARAOH AWOKE, AND, BEHOLD, IT WAS A DREAM. The meaning thereof is that “there was a complete dream before him.” Thus the language of Rashi.<br>In my opinion<sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote">Ramban finds a difficulty in Rashi’s interpretation. If the sense of the verse is that Pharaoh felt that an entire dream had been presented to him, why was he not troubled until the following morning? Ramban therefore presents his own interpretation. (Aboab.)</i> the verse alludes to the fact that Pharaoh lay awake, thinking about his dream, wondering whether he will see yet a third manifestation, and when he arose in the morning and had not dreamed again, his spirit was disturbed. This is the meaning of the verse, <i>And it came to pass in the morning that his spirit was troubled</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 8 here.</i> In the case of Nebuchadnezzar, however, it says, <i>And his spirit was troubled, and his sleep broke from him</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote">Daniel 2:1.</i> for even the night brought no rest to his mind. The verse mentions, <i>And Pharaoh awoke</i>, in order to indicate a matter stated in the Book of Sleep,<sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote">Apparently this book by some unknown medieval author dealt with the art of interpreting dreams. But see Tractate Berachoth 56 a, in connection with a man called Bar Hadya, whose profession was interpreting dreams, where the Talmud relates: “As he went away, <i>his book</i> fell down,” thus indicating that books dealing with this topic were prevalent even in Talmudic times.</i> i.e., that a dream which is followed in the same sleep by another dream with different content is not fulfilled. Therefore the verse says that when he awoke it was a dream fit for fulfillment. Yet he thought about it till morning, that perhaps he will have his dream a third time in the manner in which it had been repeated. But Pharaoh himself realized that the two dreams had the same content. This is why the verse states, <i>And behold, it was a dream</i>. So, likewise, did Pharaoh state it: <i>I have dreamed ‘a dream,’ and none can interpret it</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 15 here.</i> and he did not refer to the plural form, “dreams.” This is also the sense of the verse, <i>And I saw in my dream</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 22 here.</i> Scripture however states, <i>But none could interpret ‘them’ to Pharaoh</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 8 here.</i> meaning that none could interpret even one of them.

Verse 8



Verse 9



Verse 10



Verse 11



Verse 12

TO EACH MAN ACCORDING TO HIS DREAM. He interpreted it in accordance with the dream and consistent with its contents. Thus the words of Rashi. A more correct interpretation would be for Rashi to say that “he interpreted it in accordance with the truth of the dream as it was destined to befall him, for as he interpreted it, so it befell us.” Similar in thought is the verse, <i>Every man according to his blessing he blessed them</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">42</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 49:28. In the case of Jacob’s blessing to his sons.</i> i.e., according to the blessing which was destined to come upon him.<br>But in my opinion there is no need for this. Instead, the verse is stating that “he interpreted his dream for each man, and as he interpreted it to each one, so it came upon us.” The chief of the butlers is thus saying that these were different dreams with different interpretations, as he would explain, so that Pharaoh should not think that the two [the butler and the baker] dreamed one dream having one interpretation. In my opinion, a similar thought is conveyed in the verse, <i>Every man according to his blessing he blessed them</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">42</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 49:28. In the case of Jacob’s blessing to his sons.</i> meaning that he did not bless them with one blessing common to all, but with a unique blessing for each one, as he explained to each son and spoke to him.

Verse 13



Verse 14



Verse 15



Verse 16



Verse 17



Verse 18



Verse 19



Verse 20



Verse 21



Verse 22



Verse 23

‘TZ’NUMOTH,’ THIN. <i>Tz’numa</i> is Aramaic for “a rock.” That is, they are like wood without sap and hard as rock. But Onkelos translated, <i>natzan lakyan</i> (their blossom is stricken), i.e., there is nothing in them but their withered blossom because they were empty of grain. Thus the language of Rashi.<br>But ears of corn when empty of grain have no blossoms! Pharaoh also did not see the ears of corn when they blossomed; he saw them full and good,<sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 22 here.</i> and thin, and parched with the east wind.<sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 23 here.</i> Likewise, Rashi’s interpretation deriving <i>tz’numoth</i> from <i>tz’numa</i> as signifying “rocky” is also not correct. Thin ears of corn are not as hard as rocks.<br>But the meaning of <i>tz’numoth</i> is “separated,” [fragmented] into many pieces. It is the Rabbinic word:<sup class="footnote-marker">45</sup><i class="footnote">Berachoth 39a.</i> “Bread <i>hatz’numa</i> in a bowl requires the blessing of <i>hamotzi</i>,”<sup class="footnote-marker">46</sup><i class="footnote">The standard blessing for bread.</i> the word <i>hatz’numa</i> meaning “cut bread,” or more exactly, pieces of bread<sup class="footnote-marker">47</sup><i class="footnote">Rashi, however, in his commentary to Berachoth, translates it as “hard pieces of bread.” This is consistent with his interpretation here.</i> in a bowl upon which he pours soup, and each part is eaten without any other bread. This likewise is the meaning of the Targum, who uses the word <i>natzan</i>, which signifies “cut and deficient.”<br>The usage of the word <i>natza</i> is similar to that in the saying of the Rabbis:<sup class="footnote-marker">48</sup><i class="footnote">Baba Bathra 54a.</i> “If one transfers dirt from a <i>malya</i> into <i>malya</i> or <i>natza</i> into <i>natza</i>, it does not constitute taking possession,<sup class="footnote-marker">49</sup><i class="footnote">In order to take legal possession of a field, the buyer must perform some constructive act indicating ownership, such as fixing a fence, etc. But this particular act, as explained further, contributes nothing to the field.</i> but if he takes <i>malya</i> and throws it into <i>natza</i>, it does constitute an act of taking possession.” Now a high place in a field solidly filled with earth is called <i>malya</i>, and one in which there is an appreciable shortage of earth is called <i>natza</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">50</sup><i class="footnote">Thus if the buyer took earth from one <i>malya</i> to another, or from one <i>natza</i> to another, he has not improved the land. Hence it does not constitute an act of taking possession. But if he took earth from a <i>malya</i> and filled in a <i>natza</i>, he has performed a constructive act, and it therefore constitutes an act of taking possession.</i> Here likewise the opposite of “full ones” is <i>tz’numoth</i>, and (the singular) <i>natzan</i> is the opposite of <i>malyan</i> (a full one).<br>The situation described here in the verse is that the ears were not full of grain but that there were empty spots without grain in them, and in other places, higher up on the stalk, the ears were wind-beaten and empty. This was why Joseph used the word <i>reikoth</i> (empty ones),<sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 27 here. Compare Verse 23.</i> instead of <i>tz’numoth</i> as there were there places on the ears which contained no grain whatever.

Verse 24



Verse 25



Verse 26



Verse 27

THEY SHALL BE SEVEN YEARS OF FAMINE. Since plentifulness in the land of Egypt is not a great novelty since the country is <i>as the garden of the Eternal</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">52</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 13:10.</i> Joseph first mentioned the interpretation concerning the bad events, for it was this that constituted the novelty and the purpose of the dream. G-d in His mercy showed the famine to Pharaoh to save life for a great deliverance.<sup class="footnote-marker">53</sup><i class="footnote">See further, 45:7.</i> This is the sense of the verse, <i>And the seven years of famine began to come, according as Joseph had said</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">54</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 54 here.</i> for the truth of Joseph’s words was not realized until the years of famine.

Verse 28



Verse 29



Verse 30



Verse 31



Verse 32

AND FOR THAT THE DREAM WAS REPEATED UNTO PHARAOH TWICE. The verse is explaining the reason for the repetition of the dream — i.e., that it occurred twice in one night<sup class="footnote-marker">55</sup><i class="footnote">Ramban’s intent is to point out that there are two aspects to the dreams. They depicted two subjects — the cows and the ears of corn — and they were shown in two separate dreams although they might have been shown to Pharaoh in one continuous dream. Ramban will explain that these double aspects indicated two things: the fulfillment of the dream and its speedy realization.</i> — although it would have been possible for both the cows and the ears of corn to be shown in one dream and make known that there shall neither be plowing nor harvest.<sup class="footnote-marker">56</sup><i class="footnote">As Ramban explained above, at the beginning of Verse 2, the cows symbolize the plowing, and the ears of corn the harvest.</i> Yet He showed them in two separate dreams, one after another, in one night — an unusual circumstance for dreamers in order to make known that the matter is prepared, <i>and G-d hasteneth to do it</i>. This is the meaning of the word <i>pa’amayim</i> (twice) as the dreams concerning the cows and the ears of corn were not presented at one time.<br>But Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra explains that the repetition of the theme of the dream — through the medium of the cows and the ears of corn — attested to the fact that the matter is set and established. And the fact that the dream occurred twice in one night attested that <i>G-d hasteneth to do it</i>. But if so,<sup class="footnote-marker">57</sup><i class="footnote">That is, if both the cows and the ears of corn symbolize, as is the opinion of Ibn Ezra, that the matter is set and established, and not as Ramban has it, i.e., that the cows symbolize that there will be no plowing, and the ears of corn that there will be no harvest, what was the necessity of the dream about the cows? The dream concerning the corn would have indicated the impending famine, and showing that <i>G-d hasteneth to do it</i> could have been accomplished by repeating the same dream.</i> we would say that the dream concerning the ears of corn would have been sufficient since that dream informed Pharaoh of the famine.

Verse 33

NOW THEREFORE LET PHARAOH FIND A MAN UNDERSTANDING AND WISE. Joseph told Pharaoh that he will need an understanding and wise man who will be appointed to administer the entire land, and he in turn will appoint overseers under him who will go through the land and gather all the food since the ruler cannot travel throughout the entire land. He told him that the man must be <i>understanding and wise</i>. <i>Understanding</i>, in order to know how to support the people of Egypt from his hand with bread, in accordance with their family requirements, to supply them with their sustenance, and sell the balance to other countries in order to accumulate wealth and money for Pharaoh. <i>Wise</i>, in order to know how to preserve the produce so that it should not rot, by mixing with each kind some natural preservative such as the salty substances used for the preservation of wheat, which our Rabbis have mentioned,<sup class="footnote-marker">58</sup><i class="footnote">Shabbath 31a.</i> and some raw silver dust, which prevents the grain from getting mothy,<sup class="footnote-marker">59</sup><i class="footnote">Machshirin VI, 1. Rashi, Shabbath 88b.</i> and similar things. Thus the Sages said in Bereshith Rabbah:<sup class="footnote-marker">60</sup><i class="footnote">90:50.</i> “He mixed the grain with earth and sawdust, things which preserve the grain.” Joseph mentioned all this so that they should choose him for this task, for <i>the wise man’s eyes are in his head</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">61</sup><i class="footnote">Ecclesiastes 2:14.</i>

Verse 34



Verse 35



Verse 36

AND THE FOOD SHALL SERVE AS A RESERVE FOR THE LAND. Joseph said that the food should be kept in reserve under the charge of Pharaoh’s officers for the needs of the land during the seven years of famine, and they should not be used for other purposes lest the land be consumed by the famine just as the cows in the dream did not die on account of their leanness.

Verse 37



Verse 38

CAN WE FIND SUCH A ONE AS THIS? Because he was a Hebrew, the members of which race were repugnant to the Egyptians, who would not eat of the things the Hebrews touched, or have any contacts with them as they considered them unclean, Pharaoh did not want to appoint Joseph viceroy without their permission. Therefore he said to them that they would find no Egyptian comparable to him, as <i>the Spirit of G-d is in him</i>. After they admitted it, he said to Joseph, <i>Since G-d has made all this known unto thee</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">62</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 39 here.</i> for since the interpretation met with the approval of Pharaoh and all his courtiers,<sup class="footnote-marker">63</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 37 here.</i> they regarded everything he had said as if it had already been fulfilled.<br>It is possible that the expression, <i>all this</i>, alludes also to that which the chief of the butlers told Pharaoh. A similar case is the verse, <i>And he</i> [Jacob] <i>related to Laban all these things</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">64</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 29:13.</i> meaning the blessings bestowed upon him by Isaac mentioned before. Pharaoh thus said: “Since G-d has imbued you with this great wisdom, thus enabling you to interpret all secret and hidden dreams, and not a word of yours has failed, there is none so understanding and wise in all matters as you are, and you are therefore fit to assume authority and rulership and to be second to me.”

Verse 39



Verse 40



Verse 41



Verse 42

AND PHARAOH TOOK OFF HIS RING FROM HIS HAND. The giving of the king’s ring is a sign that the person to whom he hands it is to be second to him in rank. Thus the language of Rashi.<br>The correct interpretation is that the king’s ring contains his seal, just as it is said, <i>And sealed with the king’s ring</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">65</sup><i class="footnote">Esther 8:8.</i> The king thus gave Joseph his seal so that he should be <i>a leader and commander</i><sup class="footnote-marker">66</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 55:4.</i> of the entire government, and seal with the king’s ring whatever he desires.

Verse 43

‘B’MIRKEVETH’ (IN THE CHARIOT) ‘HAMISHNEH.’ I.e., in the chariot second to his own chariot, which travelled next to his own. Thus the language of Rashi.<br>Now according to this interpretation, the word <i>hamishneh</i> refers to the noun, [“chariot,” meaning that this was the chariot of second rank]. The same applies in the verses: <i>the priests ‘hamishneh’ (of the second order);</i><sup class="footnote-marker">67</sup><i class="footnote">II Kings 23:4.</i> <i>‘eth mishnei’ (a copy) of this Torah</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">68</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 17:18.</i><br>The correct interpretation is that the word <i>mishneh</i> is adjectival,<sup class="footnote-marker">69</sup><i class="footnote">Meaning that this was the chariot of the <i>mishneh</i>, of he who was second in rank.</i> just as: <i>And I shall be to you ‘l’mishneh’ (as a second one);</i><sup class="footnote-marker">70</sup><i class="footnote">I Samuel 23:17.</i> <i>For Mordecai the Jew was ‘mishneh’ (the second) unto king Ahaseurus</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">71</sup><i class="footnote">Esther 10:3.</i> Similarly, the expression, <i>keseph mishneh</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">72</sup><i class="footnote">43:12.</i> (the money of the <i>mishneh</i>) is adjectival and is to be understood as “the money of the ‘second’ purchase.” Now the grammarians<sup class="footnote-marker">73</sup><i class="footnote">Reference is to R’dak who mentions this point in his Sefer Hashorashim (Book of Roots), under the root <i>shana</i>.</i> have already brought a proof to this thesis<sup class="footnote-marker">74</sup><i class="footnote">That the word <i>mishneh</i> here, and in the other three cases mentioned, (see Notes 70-72), all have the meaning ascribed to them by Ramban.</i> since in all these cases the letter <i>nun</i> in the word <i>mishneh</i> is vocalized with a <i>segol</i>, [which does not indicate the construct state as would <i>tzeirei</i>], while <i>mishnei hatorah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">68</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 17:18.</i> and all nouns are vocalized with a <i>tzeirei</i>, as is the rule in the construct state. The sense of the present verse is that the king had a chariot known to be his, even as it is said, <i>And the horse which the king rideth upon</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">75</sup><i class="footnote">Esther 6:8.</i> and there was another chariot known to be for his second in rank, and another one for the third in rank.

Verse 44



Verse 45

‘TZAPHNATH PA’NEI’ACH.’ Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra said, “If this is an Egyptian word, we do not know its meaning, and if it is a translated one [from Yoseiph, the Hebrew name for Joseph], then we do not know the meaning of the name Yoseiph, [that is, the aspect of the name which has this translation].<br>But according to the opinion of earlier scholars, who say that it means “explainer of secrets” and is a Hebrew expression, it is possible that Pharaoh called him by this honorable name in accordance with the language of Joseph’s country after he asked him,<sup class="footnote-marker">76</sup><i class="footnote">I.e., Pharaoh asked Joseph, “What is the expression, in the Canaanitish language, which means ‘one who reveals secrets?’” and Joseph told him, “It is <i>tzaphnath pa’nei’ach</i>.”</i> or the king may have known the language of Canaan, which was adjacent to Egypt, and its purport is that “he reveals concealed matters.” So also did Pharaoh’s daughter name Moses our teacher in the language of his people, <i>for out of the water ‘m’shithihu’ (I pulled him)</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">77</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 2:10.</i><br>Now do not wonder why Egyptian writers called Moses, “Munyos,” for they changed the names into the language they understood or used, as the Targum Onkelos does in some cases, as for example, <i>Between Kadesh and Shur</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">78</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 20:1.</i> which he translated as “between Rekem and Chigra,” and similarly with many names. And in some places Onkelos does not change them at all, just as in the case of Sichon king of Cheshbon and Og king of Bashan, and many others like them. This is because in his times they were called thus in Aramaic.<sup class="footnote-marker">79</sup><i class="footnote">And therefore Onkelos wrote down the equivalent Aramaic name by which they were known in his time, which coincided with the way they were referred to in Scripture.</i>
THE DAUGHTER OF POTI-PHERAH ‘KOHEIN’ (PRIEST OF) ON. He is indentical with Potiphar.<sup class="footnote-marker">80</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 37:36.</i> He was called Poti-phera<sup class="footnote-marker">81</sup><i class="footnote">The word <i>pera</i> connotes “uncover and pull down.” See Ramban above, 39:19.</i> because he had been emasculated on account of having purchased Joseph for sodomy. Thus the language of Rashi, and it is actually a Midrash of our Rabbis.<sup class="footnote-marker">82</sup><i class="footnote">Bereshith Rabbah 86:3.</i><br>On account of this Midrash, Rashi was forced to say in explanation of <i>kohein On</i><sup class="footnote-marker">83</sup><i class="footnote">Rashi’s explanation of <i>kohein On</i> is found further in his commentary on 47:22.</i> that “the term <i>kohein</i> always means one who ministers to Deity with the exception of this one, i.e., <i>kohein On</i>, which denotes one of high rank since he was the chief of the slaughterers of the king’s animals, and similarly, <i>kohein Midian</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">84</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 3:1. Meaning the chief of Midian. It could not mean “the priest” of Midian since Jethro had already abandoned idolatry.</i><br>But I say that according to the words of our Rabbis, [who said that Poti-phera is identical with Potiphar, and was called Poti-phera because of his emasculation, as explained above],<sup class="footnote-marker">85</sup><i class="footnote">Ramban’s intent is to state that even though Potiphar is identical with Poti-phera, and Potiphar was an officer to the king, he later became a priest, so that <i>kohein On</i> does not mean, as Rashi explained, “one of high rank,” or “the chief of On,” but rather “the priest of On.”</i> Potiphar was an officer of the king, and later when he became physically castrate, on account of which they called him “Poti-phera,” he was embarassed and retired from his office. He then entered a temple of idol-worship and became a priest therein, for such was the custom among the nobility, and it is possible that On was the name of his idol. Likewise, <i>kohein Midian</i><sup class="footnote-marker">86</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 3:1.</i> means “priest of Midian,” just as they said, concerning Jethro,<sup class="footnote-marker">87</sup><i class="footnote">Sanhedrin 82b.</i> that he used to fatten calves for the idols.<br>Now the truth of the matter is that the term <i>k’hunah</i> means ministry, but not to the Deity alone, for it is stated, <i>And David’s sons were ‘kohanim,’</i><sup class="footnote-marker">88</sup><i class="footnote">II Samuel 8:18.</i> and in the book of Chronicles,<sup class="footnote-marker">89</sup><i class="footnote">I Chronicles 18:17.</i> in the same connection it says, <i>And the sons of David were chiefs at the side of the king</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">90</sup><i class="footnote">It is thus clear that <i>kohanim</i> in the book of Samuel means “chief ministers.”</i> Similarly we find in the following verses: <i>He leadeth ‘kohanim’ barefoot</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">91</sup><i class="footnote">Job 12:19.</i> referring to ministers of the king; <i>‘y’chahein pe’eir,’</i><sup class="footnote-marker">92</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 61:10.
