Translated: “a priestly diadem.”</i> (he has clothed him in splendor as a ministering priest), meaning that they will make him garments unlike those of the rest of the people, for glory and for splendor. Also similar is the verse [II Kings 10:11], <i>And his familiar friends ‘v’kohanav’</i>, meaning his chief ministers.

Verse 46



Verse 47

‘LIKMATZIM’ (HANDFULS). They stored up the grain handful upon handful, fist by fist. This is the language of Rashi.<br>Onkelos translated it as, “into store houses,” since excavations made in the earth for storage or other purposes are called ‘<i>kmatzim</i>.’ <i>He is hid now in one of ‘hap’chothim’ (the pits)</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">93</sup><i class="footnote">II Samuel 17:9.</i> Jonathan translated, “in one of the <i>kumtza</i>.” Similarly, he always translated the term <i>pachath</i> as <i>kamtza</i>, which is related to the expression, <i>He that diggeth ‘gametz’ (a pit)</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">94</sup><i class="footnote">Ecclesiastes 10:8.</i> as the letter <i>gimmel</i> serves here as <i>kuph</i>, just as it serves as a <i>kaph</i> in the following verses: <i>Never lacking in ‘hamazeg’ (mingled wine)</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">95</sup><i class="footnote">Song of Songs 7:3.</i> the word <i>hamazeg</i> being derived from the term, <i>‘Mas’cha’ (She hath mingled) her wine;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">96</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 9:2.</i> <i>‘v’chano’ which Thy right hand hath planted</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">97</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 80:16. Translated: <i>‘And of the stock’ which Thy right hand hath planted</i>. But Ramban explains it as: “<i>And of the garden</i>, etc.”</i> which is like <i>ganoh</i> (garden); <i>‘vayisachru’ the fountains of the murmuring deep</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">98</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 8:2.</i> which is like <i>vayisagru</i> (and they were closed); <i>To their native land (‘m’churatham’);</i><sup class="footnote-marker">99</sup><i class="footnote">Ezekiel 29:14 <i>(m’churatham);</i> 16:3 (<i>m’chorotayich</i>).</i> <i>Thy origin (‘m’chorothayich’) and thy birth;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">99</sup><i class="footnote">Ezekiel 29:14 <i>(m’churatham);</i> 16:3 (<i>m’chorotayich</i>).</i> <i>And I will give over (‘v’sikarti’) Egypt</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">100</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 19:4.</i> In all of these cases the <i>kaph</i> and the <i>gimmel</i> are alike. The <i>kuph</i> and the <i>kaph</i> are often alike, as in <i>kova</i> and <i>chova</i>, (both meaning “hat”);<sup class="footnote-marker">101</sup><i class="footnote">I Samuel 17:38 <i>(kova)</i>; 17:5 <i>(chova)</i>.</i> <i>‘tikein’ (he set in order) many proverbs</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">102</sup><i class="footnote">Ecclesiastes 12:9.</i> the word <i>tikein</i> being like the term <i>sichein</i> in the verse, <i>Who has directed (‘sichein’) the spirit of the Eternal?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">103</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 40:13.</i> Our Rabbis have said in connection with the term jewelry: <i>tachshitim</i> and <i>takshit</i>. Similarly, it is said, <i>‘Vayatziku’ (And they set down) the ark of G-d — but Abiathar went up — until all the people hath passed out of the city</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">104</sup><i class="footnote">II Samuel 15:24.</i> and the Targum translates: “And they put down the ark,” thus making <i>vayatziku</i> as <i>vayatzig</i>, just as it is said concerning it, <i>And they brought in the ark of the Eternal, ‘vayatzigu’ (and set it) in its place</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">105</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 6:17.</i> the word being derived from the expressions, <i>‘atziga’ (let me place) with thee</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">106</sup><i class="footnote">Above 33:15.</i> and <i>‘v’hitzagtiv’ (And I will set him) before thee</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">107</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 43:9.</i>

Verse 48

AND HE STORED UP ALL THE FOOD. “He” refers to Joseph mentioned above.<sup class="footnote-marker">108</sup><i class="footnote">In Verse 46: <i>And Joseph was…</i></i> The same applies to the following verse: <i>And Joseph piled up grain… until he ceased numbering</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">109</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 49 here.</i> The pronoun “he” refers to Joseph, who was mentioned.<br>Now Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra said that the phrase, <i>all the food</i>, is not to be understood literally, for otherwise they would have died of famine immediately. A similar case is the verse, <i>And all the lands came into Egypt to Joseph to buy grain</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">110</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 57 here. This verse is also not to be understood in its literal sense since Jacob and Benjamin did not come to buy grain.</i> The meaning of <i>he stored up all the food</i> is only that Joseph stored up all the food which he could.<br>It appears to me to be correct that Joseph gathered all food under his control, and he gave enough of it every year for sustenance to the Egyptians, so that they should not squander it. This is the intent of his statement, <i>And let them store up all the food of those good years that come, and pile up corn under the hand of Pharaoh… and hold it there</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">111</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 35 here. Ramban thus makes a distinction between <i>ochel</i> (food) and <i>bar</i> (corn). At the end of the paragraph, he will mention that Onkelos makes no distinction between them.</i> Now in view of the fact that it says, <i>And let them store up all the food… and pile up corn</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">111</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 35 here. Ramban thus makes a distinction between <i>ochel</i> (food) and <i>ibur</i> (corn). At the end of the paragraph, he will mention that Onkelos makes no distinction between them.</i> and [here in the verses before us] it says, <i>And he stored up all the food… And Joseph piled up grain</i>, this would indicate that he gathered whatever is eaten by man; corn, bread, and all food essential to life, even figs, fresh and dried, and similar things. He piled the corn — meaning the produce which is brought under a winnowing shovel and fan for fanning and cleansing — under the hand of Pharaoh, and he laid up in the cities enough of all the fruits for sustenance. Thus all the food was held in need for the years of famine to be drawn upon to the degree essential for life, and the balance of the corn he preserved in the storehouses.<br>It is possible that Joseph paid them money from the royal treasures at a low market price. This was why the corn belonged to Pharaoh, and he sold it to them in the years of famine, just as it is written, <i>And Joseph collected all the money that was found in the land of Egypt</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">112</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 47:14.</i> It is possible that the king took it by force, saying: “I preserved it.”<sup class="footnote-marker">113</sup><i class="footnote">For were it not for the king’s dream, the food of the seven years of plenty would have been squandered.</i><br>Onkelos, however, translated both <i>ochel</i> (food) and <i>bar</i> (corn) alike.<sup class="footnote-marker">114</sup><i class="footnote">Calling them <i>ibur</i>. See Note 111.</i>

Verse 49



Verse 50



Verse 51



Verse 52



Verse 53



Verse 54

AND THE FAMINE WAS IN ALL LANDS. That is, which surrounded Egypt. Otherwise, what could the distant lands do if there was such a famine in them?<sup class="footnote-marker">115</sup><i class="footnote">They would not be able to come to Egypt to ease the famine and would have perished.</i> Thus did the Sages say in Bereshith Rabbah:<sup class="footnote-marker">116</sup><i class="footnote">90:6.</i> “The famine was in three lands: Phoenicia, Arabia and Palestine.”

Verse 55



Verse 56

AND HE SOLD GRAIN UNTO THE EGYPTIANS, AND THE FAMINE WAS SEVERE IN THE LAND OF EGYPT. The verse states that Joseph did not throw open the contents of the storehouses until the famine had become severe in the land, but not as soon as they cried to Pharaoh,<sup class="footnote-marker">117</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 55 here.</i> as people would cry even when they have a small amount of sustenance, and it was his desire that nothing remain to them before he opened the granaries. This is the meaning of the verse, <i>And the famine was over all the face of the earth</i>, meaning that before he had opened his storehouses the famine was over the entire face of the earth, and then the verse proceeds to explain that he did not sell them food until the famine had become severe upon them. Perhaps it is possible that the verse is magnifying the famine by stating that it was a “famine accompanied by panic.”<sup class="footnote-marker">118</sup><i class="footnote">See Aboth V, 8.</i>

Chapter 42



Verse 1

WHY ‘TITHRA’U’. (DO YOU LOOK TO YOURSELVES)? “Do not show yourselves before the children of Esau and Ishmael as having plenty to eat.” At that time they still had some grain. From others I have heard that the word <i>tithra’u</i> is an expression of leanness. Thus Jacob said to his sons, “Why should you become lean through hunger?” A similar [use of the word <i>tithra’u</i>, i.e., similar to the first explanation], is the verse: <i>And he that satisfies (‘umarveh’) abundantly shall be satisfied (‘yoreh’)</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">119</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 11:25. That is, he who is benevolent to others will himself be recompensed by the Divine bounty.</i> Thus the language of Rashi.<br>Now the comment of “others,” [namely, that the word <i>tithra’u</i> connotes leanness], has no validity whatsoever. And I did not understand that which Rashi says, “Do not show yourselves before the children of Ishmael and the children of Esau as having plenty to eat.” The children of Ishmael and of Esau were not then present in the land of Canaan, and why did Jacob not say that they should not show themselves before the children of <i>Canaan</i> as having plenty to eat? Perhaps the children of Ishmael and of Esau did come from their dwelling places to Joseph to buy food, and they came by way of the land of Canaan, thus passing by Jacob. He thus said to his children that they should not show themselves before them as having plenty to eat, for they would then suspect that Jacob has food, whereupon they would come to eat bread with him in his house. Accordingly, Jacob’s words, <i>That we may live, and not die</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">120</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 2 here.</i> constitute another reason for his command to them. He warned them to be careful with the little food yet left to them, and that they should go to buy food from Egypt so as not to die when all the bread in their possession is consumed.<br>The correct interpretation is: “Why do you show yourselves in this place, for you should have immediately journeyed from here when you heard that there is grain in Egypt,” since they were already in a state of danger if they would not make haste in the matter. This is the meaning of the words, <i>That we may live, and not die</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">120</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 2 here.</i>

Verse 2



Verse 3



Verse 4



Verse 5



Verse 6

HE IT WAS THAT SOLD GRAIN TO ALL THE PEOPLE OF THE LAND. Now it is not befitting a ruler of a land, second in rank to the king of Egypt, that he sell everyone a <i>se’ah</i> [a dry measure] or a half thereof of grain. It was for this reason that our Rabbis were impelled to say<sup class="footnote-marker">121</sup><i class="footnote">Bereshith Rabbah 91:6.</i> that Joseph had ordered at that time that all storehouses except one be closed so that he would be sure to meet his brothers.<br>In line with the literal interpretation of the verse it is possible that the people from all lands came before him, and he would question and investigate them, and then command the officers, “Sell so much food of this — and that — kind to the people of that city.” Thus it was necessary for the children of Jacob to come before him among those who came from the land of Canaan, that he could issue an order concerning them, specifying how much grain should be sold to their land, since they were the first to come from the land of Canaan<sup class="footnote-marker">122</sup><i class="footnote">See further, at the end of Verse 9, where Ramban establishes the fact that the brothers were the first to come from the land of Canaan to buy grains, thus offering Joseph the opportunity to charge them as spies.</i> and they came before him for the sake of all.

Verse 7

AND JOSEPH SAW HIS BRETHREN, AND HE RECOGNIZED THEM. Immediately as he saw them he recognized them, and he feared lest they recognize him. <i>And he made himself strange (‘vayithnakeir’) unto them</i> by putting a mitre upon his forehead and part of the face, thus disguising himself, just as it is said concerning the wife of Jeroboam, <i>Arise, I pray thee, and disguise thyself, that thou be not known to be the wife of Jeroboam</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">123</sup><i class="footnote">I Kings 14:1. Ramban explains the word <i>vayithnakeir</i> in a physical sense. Joseph disguised himself by placing his mitre over his face. Further on, Ramban mentions a second interpretation. See Note 126.</i> and it further says, <i>For it will be, when she cometh in, that she ‘mithnakeirah’ (will pretend to be another woman)</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">124</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 5.</i> It may be that the word <i>vayithnakeir</i> here means that he made himself strange by his words, speaking to them harshly and asking them in anger — as if it were not customary to come before him to purchase food — “From where do you come to appear before me?” <i>And they said, From the land of Canaan to buy food</i>. When they mentioned this to him, it then became clear to him that they were indeed his brothers. This is the meaning of the expression, <i>And Joseph recognized his brethren</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">125</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 8 here.</i> which is mentioned a second time to indicate an additional sense of recognition and knowledge of the truth with respect to them.<br>Now Rashi wrote in explanation of the word <i>vayithnakeir:</i> “He made himself like a <i>nochri</i> (stranger) in conversation by speaking harshly to them.” According to Rashi’s opinion, the word <i>vayithnakeir</i> signifies that he spoke to them as a man who is a <i>nochri</i> (stranger). But this is not correct.<sup class="footnote-marker">126</sup><i class="footnote">A stranger does not necessarily speak harshly. Hence Rashi’s interpretation is incorrect. Ramban’s second interpretation mentioned above, however, is based upon the word <i>vayithnakeir</i> having the same root as <i>heker</i> (recognition), except that the word here changes its meaning so as to indicate its opposite. See Rashi on Exodus 27:3, where he says that there are many such words in the Hebrew language. In the case before us, the word <i>vayithnakeir</i> would thus mean that Joseph made himself unrecognizable by speaking harshly to them. See my Hebrew commentary, p. 232.</i>

Verse 8

BUT THEY DID NOT RECOGNIZE HIM. I.e., at all. And so he no longer needed to make himself appear strange to them. Now in this matter of recognition, our Rabbis have said<sup class="footnote-marker">127</sup><i class="footnote">Kethuboth 27b.</i> that Joseph recognized his brothers because he had left them bearded, but they did not recognize him because when he left them he had no beard and now they found him with a beard.<br>Now Issachar and Zebulun were but a little older than Joseph,<sup class="footnote-marker">128</sup><i class="footnote">Thus they were also beardless when Joseph left, so how did he recognize them now that they were bearded?</i> but having recognized the older ones, he recognized them all. Moreover, he recognized them because he knew they were bound to come, but they did not recognize him because it did not occur to them that a slave sold to the Ishmaelites should be the ruler of a land.<br>Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra says: <i>And he recognized them</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">129</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 7 here.</i> That is, at first he recognized them to be his brothers, and following that, he looked at each one and recognized him individually.<sup class="footnote-marker">130</sup><i class="footnote">This explains the repetition in Verse 8, <i>And Joseph recognized his brethren</i>, since it refers to individual recognition.</i>

Verse 9

AND JOSEPH REMEMBERED THE DREAMS WHICH HE DREAMED OF THEM. [That is, he remembered the dreams which he dreamed] concerning them, and now knew that they had been fulfilled, for they had bowed down to him. This is the language of Rashi.<br>In my opinion, the matter is the reverse. Scripture states that when Joseph saw his brothers bowing down to him, he remembered all the dreams which he had dreamed concerning them and he knew that in this instance, not one of the dreams had been fulfilled. He knew that it was inherent in their interpretation that according to the first dream, at first all his brothers would bow down to him, as it says, <i>And, behold, we were binding sheaves</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">131</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 37:7.</i> for “we” refers to all eleven of his brothers. The second time, in accordance with the second dream, <i>the sun, the moon and eleven stars</i><sup class="footnote-marker">132</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 9.</i> would bow down to him. Now since he did not see Benjamin with them, he conceived of the strategy of devising a charge against them so that they would also bring his brother Benjamin to him, in order to first fulfill the first dream. It is for this reason that he did not wish to tell them at this time, <i>I am Joseph your brother</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">133</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 45:4.</i> and to say, <i>Hasten and go up to my father</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">134</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 45:9.</i> and send wagons, as he did to them the second time,<sup class="footnote-marker">135</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 19.</i> for in that case his father would undoubtedly have come at once. It was only after fulfillment of the first dream that he told them, <i>I am Joseph your brother</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">133</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 45:4.</i> etc., in order to fulfill the second dream. Were it not for this consideration, Joseph would indeed be regarded as having committed a great sin: bringing anguish to his father, leaving him for many days in the position of being bereft and mourning for Simeon and him. Even if it was his intention to cause his brothers minor anguish, how did he not have compassion for his elderly father? But <i>he assigned each to its proper time</i><sup class="footnote-marker">136</sup><i class="footnote">Ecclesiastes 3:11.</i> in order to fulfill the dreams, knowing that they would truly be fulfilled. Also, the second matter, which he effected against them in connection with the goblet,<sup class="footnote-marker">137</sup><i class="footnote">In which he accused Benjamin of stealing the goblet. (Further, 44:17).</i> is not to be interpreted as if his intention was to cause them anguish, but rather because he suspected that they might hate Benjamin as a result of their jealousy of him on account of his father’s love for him, just as they were jealous of Joseph. Perhaps Benjamin had sensed that they had harmed Joseph, thus causing a quarrel and hatred to erupt between him and his brothers. Therefore, Joseph did not wish Benjamin to travel with them until he had tested their love for him, lest they harm him.<br>It is to this matter that our Rabbis in Bereshith Rabbah<sup class="footnote-marker">138</sup><i class="footnote">93:9.</i> referred when they said: “Rabbi Chiya the son of Rabbi Abba said, ‘When you read the entire plea which Judah made in the presence of his brothers, until you reach the verse, <i>Then Joseph could not refrain himself</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">139</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 45:1.</i> [you can see that] there was in it an attempt to win the sympathy of Joseph, the sympathy of his brothers, and the sympathy of Benjamin. Joseph’s sympathy [would be gained since Joseph would think], ‘See how he is ready to give his life for Rachel’s children, etc.’”<br>Similarly I say that all these acts of Joseph are accounted for by his wisdom in the interpretation of the dreams. Otherwise, one should wonder: After Joseph stayed in Egypt for many years and became chief and overseer in the house of a great lord in Egypt, how was it possible that he did not send a single letter to his father to inform him of his whereabouts and comfort him, as Egypt is only about a six-day journey from Hebron? Even if it were a year’s journey, out of respect to his father, he should have notified him, in which case even if the ransom of his person would be ever so costly, he would have redeemed him. But it was because Joseph saw that the bowing down of his brothers, as well as his father and all his family, could not possibly be accomplished in their homeland, and he was hoping that it would be effected in Egypt when he saw his great success there. This was all the more so after he heard Pharaoh’s dream, from which it became clear to him that all of them were destined to come there, and all his dreams would be fulfilled.
AND HE SAID UNTO THEM, YE ARE SPIES. This accusation requires some reason or some plausible explanation, for what did they do that he should so accuse them? People from every country came to him to buy grain, and they were “among those who came,” just as it says, <i>To buy grain among those that came, for the famine was in the land of Canaan</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">140</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 5 here.</i> Perhaps [the reason for the accusation was that] they had the appearance of men of stature and prominence, <i>all of them clothed most gorgeously</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">141</sup><i class="footnote">Ezekiel 38:4.</i> whereupon he said to them, “It is not customary for prominent people as you to come to buy food, having as you do many servants.”<br>It is possible that they were the first ones to come from the land of Canaan. This is the meaning of the verse, <i>And the sons of Israel came to buy grain among those that came, for the famine was in the land of Canaan</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">140</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 5 here.</i> meaning that now they were the first who came from there. So Joseph said to them, “You are spies, since no one has come from the land of Canaan to buy food.” This is the intent of the question, <i>“Where have you come from?”</i><sup class="footnote-marker">142</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 7 here.</i> which he addressed to them at the outset.

Verse 10



Verse 11

WE ARE ALL ONE MAN’s SONS. It is possible to explain this plea as follows: They said that “since we are brothers, one man’s sons, who do not separate from each other for such is our father’s will, we all came to buy food, and we did not send one of us with his servants.” This indeed was the truth, for why should Jacob have sent them all, except that it was not their wish to be separated from one another. It is also possible that they did so because of the extreme famine, lest the grain brought by their servants be robbed from them on the way.<br>It is also possible that they said to him: “<i>We are all one man’s sons</i>. You can investigate him, for he is known in the gates by the vastness of his wealth and the multitude of his children. And if you will inquire and investigate, you will know that we are trustworthy, righteous men, sons of a righteous one, and not spies.”
THY SERVANTS HAVE NOT BEEN SPIES. The meaning of this expression is: “We have been trustworthy in all our affairs from our youth on. Your servants have not been spies from then till now.” Similarly, <i>We have not been spies</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">143</sup><i class="footnote">Further in Verse 31.</i> means: “We have never been spies.”<br>Now our Rabbis have been aroused by the matter we have discussed,<sup class="footnote-marker">144</sup><i class="footnote">Namely, what did the brothers do to justify Joseph’s accusation that they were spies?</i> and they have expounded<sup class="footnote-marker">145</sup><i class="footnote">Bereshith Rabbah 91:6.</i> that they entered the city by ten different gates in the manner of spies, and it was for this reason that he accused them. Now this is plausible; however, Scripture does not mention it! Moreover, at the very outset, the brothers said to him in defense of themselves, <i>We are all one man’s sons</i>, and [if, as the Midrash has it, the basis of his accusation was that they entered by ten different gates], this itself indicates their guilt.<sup class="footnote-marker">146</sup><i class="footnote">Since brothers as a rule stay together, the fact that they did not enter by the same gate indicates that they are spies.</i><br>Now it is possible to say in explanation of the Midrash that Joseph originally said to them, “you entered by ten gates, and now you are all gathering in one place and conspiring together. This is nothing other than the behavior of spies.” Thereupon they said to him, “It is because we are brothers that we are gathered together.” But he said, “<i>Not so, but you have come to find out the condition of the land</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">147</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 12 here.</i> If you were brothers you should have entered by one gate, just as you are now together.” Then they told him that <i>one of them is gone</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">148</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 13 here.</i> and that they had gone in search of him, [which was why they entered by different gates]. Scripture, however, does not care to prolong the discussion of the motivation of their arguments.

Verse 12



Verse 13



Verse 14



Verse 15



Verse 16



Verse 17

AND HE PUT THEM ALL TOGETHER INTO A WARD THREE DAYS. This he did in order to frighten them and to make them believe that it is G-d he fears,<sup class="footnote-marker">149</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 18 here.</i> meaning that it is because of his fear of G-d that he is releasing them lest the people of their households perish from hunger. This is the meaning of his words, <i>The rest of you, go and take grain home to your starving households</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">150</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 19 here.</i> Besides, they would not have consented to leave the one [Simeon]<sup class="footnote-marker">151</sup><i class="footnote">See Verse 24.</i> behind except for the purpose of saving all their families.

Verse 18



Verse 19



Verse 20



Verse 21

IN THAT WE SAW THE DISTRESS OF HIS SOUL, WHEN HE IMPLORED US. It is obvious that the brothers now considered their display of cruelty towards Joseph as deserving of a greater punishment than the sale itself since it was their blood-brother who was imploring and prostrating himself before them and they remained unmoved. Scripture, however, did not relate there [that Joseph implored them at the time of the sale], either because it is naturally understood that a person would implore his brothers when falling into their grip when their intention is to harm him, swearing by the life of his father, and doing all that is possible to save himself from death. It may be the desire of Scripture to speak only briefly of their sin, or it is possible that it is characteristic of Scripture to speak briefly about a matter in one place, and to elaborate on it in another place.<br>Now Reuben answered them by saying: “Now I already told you at the time that the event took place that you should not sin against him for he is only a lad, and only on account of his youth did he sin against you, and it is therefore fitting for you to gloss over the sins of his youth. And now, <i>his blood also</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">152</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 22 here.</i> together with the display of cruelty which you mention, <i>is required</i>.” Perhaps the explanation of the phrase, <i>his blood also</i>, may be: “Even though you have not killed him, G-d will require his blood of you, and it will be accounted to you as if you spilled his blood since he was sold as a permanent slave, for it is possible that being a <i>darling child</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">153</sup><i class="footnote">Jeremiah 31:19.</i> unused to work, he died.”<br>Our Rabbis have expounded<sup class="footnote-marker">154</sup><i class="footnote">Bereshith Rabbah 91:10.</i> “The expression, <i>‘Also’ his blood</i>, implies his blood and the blood of his aged father.”

Verse 22



Verse 23



Verse 24



Verse 25

AND TO GIVE THEM PROVISION FOR THE WAY. The reason for saying this is so that they should not consume the food which they bought in the course of the journey. He informed them of this for he gave them the provisions for the journey in a kindly fashion so that they should be able to bring the brother [Benjamin] to him, for he said, “I have no intention of harming you if your words are verified.”

Verse 26



Verse 27

AND AS ONE OF THEM OPENED HIS SACK. One of them opened his sack in the inn to give therefrom some fodder to his ass, while the others did not open their sacks until they were with their father, just as it says, <i>And it came to pass as they emptied their sacks</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">155</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 35 here.</i> for perhaps the others took straw for their asses, lest they consume their entire loads on the way. But the one who opened the sack on the way had a weak ass, which required fodder, and he thus found the money <i>in the mouth of his bag (‘amtachto’)</i>.<br>Now Rashi writes that <i>amtachath</i> is the sack, but Onkelos translated it as “load.” It appears from Onkelos’ opinion that each one in order to equalize his load, had large sacks and small sacks, and the total load of each one is called <i>amtachath</i>. Thus it happened that one of them found his money at the mouth of the particular sack he opened, while it did not happen to the others until they emptied all their sacks.<br>It seems plausible to me that <i>amtachath</i> is a large sack containing two sides, known in the language of the Talmud as <i>matrata</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">156</sup><i class="footnote">Kethuboth 110 a: <i>hafuchi matrata lamah li</i>, meaning that if a person is carrying two leather sacks of equal weight on his right and left shoulders, why should he change one sack for the other? (See Rashi there.)</i> and the money of each one was put at the mouth of one of the sides. Now it so happened that one of them opened the side where the money lay, but it did not happen to the others. This kind of sack is called <i>amtachath</i> because it stretches (<i>yimtach</i>) at the sides.

Verse 28



Verse 29



Verse 30



Verse 31



Verse 32



Verse 33



Verse 34

AND YOU SHALL BE FREE (‘TIS’CHARU’) TO TRADE IN THE LAND. They altered it for the sake of peace<sup class="footnote-marker">157</sup><i class="footnote">For we do not find that Joseph told this to his brothers.</i> so that Jacob would consent to send Benjamin along with them. It had been their desire to return immediately were it not that Jacob had said, <i>My son shall not go down with you</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">158</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 38 here.</i> Similarly, for the sake of peace, they told him Joseph’s words, <i>‘Leave’ one of your brothers with me</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">159</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 33 here.</i> and they did not tell their father of their imprisonment or of Simeon’s imprisonment.<br>It is possible that Joseph did tell them, <i>And you shall be free to trade in the land</i>, but Scripture does not relate it. If so, the intent of the statement is that “you will be able to bring merchandise at your will for the purpose of purchasing grain, and I will not take it, as compensation for your embarassment.”<sup class="footnote-marker">160</sup><i class="footnote">Thus he suggested that they will be able to keep their original merchandise for sale to others, and obtain grain free.</i><br>Similarly, their saying, <i>The man persisted in asking about ourselves, and our family</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">161</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 43:7.</i> constitutes a motivating plea to their father, [but the event never actually took place]. It may be that when they told Joseph, <i>We are all one man’s sons</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">162</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 11 here.</i> he said to them, “<i>Not so, but you have truly come to find out the condition of the land</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">163</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 12 here.</i> Now tell me if your father is alive, and if you have another brother, for I will investigate you and know what you are.” Then they said, “We are twelve brethren, the sons of one man who is presently in the land of Canaan, for he is still alive, and the youngest one is with him, and one is gone.” This was what Judah said to Joseph: <i>My lord asked his servants, saying, Have you a father, or a brother?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">164</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 44:19.</i> In a similar manner Scripture, in many places, is concise about an event or the recounting thereof, as I have mentioned.<sup class="footnote-marker">165</sup><i class="footnote">See Ramban above in Verse 21.</i><br>Now Rashi writes: “<i>Tis’charu</i>, you may travel round the land. All expressions of <i>s’chorah</i> (merchandise) and <i>socharim</i> (merchants) are derived from <i>sochar</i>, which means ‘going around,’ because the merchants go round looking for merchandise.”<br>It would seem that the Rabbi [Rashi]<sup class="footnote-marker">166</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Bereshith</i>, Note 139.</i> aimed by this interpretation to guard himself against this difficulty.<sup class="footnote-marker">167</sup><i class="footnote">Namely, that we do not find that Joseph mentioned to his brothers about being free to <i>trade</i> in the land. Therefore, Rashi explained the word <i>tis’charu</i> as giving them the right to travel around the land and buy grain always without hindrance.</i> He therefore explained their words as reporting only that Joseph had said that they would be permitted to travel around the land and always buy grain at their pleasure. But above, in the story of Shechem, Rashi did not so interpret the same expressions: <i>Settle down ‘us’charuah’ (and engage in trade);</i><sup class="footnote-marker">168</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 34:10. For there actual trade is referred to, while here only travelling around the land is meant. Therefore Rashi makes his comment here, and not there in the story of Schechem.</i> <i>‘v’yis’charu othah’ (and engage in trade in it).</i><sup class="footnote-marker">169</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 21.</i>

Verse 35



Verse 36



Verse 37

MY TWO SONS ‘TAMITH’ (THOU SHALT SLAY). Under penalty of a curse,<sup class="footnote-marker">170</sup><i class="footnote">Ramban’s intent is to explain that the word <i>tamith</i> is not to be understood literally as meaning that Reuben was ready to forfeit the lives of his two sons. Instead, the word is to be understood in a general sense, i.e., that Reuben is willing to be punished, but not that Jacob slay Reuben’s sons.</i> Reuben obligated himself to return Benjamin to his father, as he said to him, <i>My two sons ‘tamith,’</i> meaning, “May thy punishment be upon me if I do not bring him back to you.” This is similar in intent to that which Judah said: <i>Then I shall have sinned against thee all my days</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">171</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 43:9.</i><br>Now Reuben said, <i>My two sons</i>, although he actually had four.<sup class="footnote-marker">172</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 46:9.</i> His intent in saying “two” was to state that “in place of one of your sons, it should be visited doubly upon my sons.”<br>Now Jacob did not rely upon Reuben as he did upon Judah,<sup class="footnote-marker">173</sup><i class="footnote">For when Judah gave his promise to his father that he would bring back Benjamin, he finally consented to send him along (43: 9-13), but Reuben’s plea went unanswered.</i> <i>for Judah prevailed upon his brethren</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">174</sup><i class="footnote">I Chronicles 5:2. Thus suggesting that Judah’s great influence upon his brothers would assure their cooperation in bringing back Benjamin under all circumstances.</i> Moreover, Reuben had already sinned against his father,<sup class="footnote-marker">175</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 35:22.</i> and therefore he would no longer rely upon him. Generally, Judah’s counsel was sound: i.e., to leave the patriarch alone until there was no bread in the house, for then he would listen. This — [Judah’s reference to the complete absence of food] — is indicated by Judah’s words to his father: <i>That we may live, and not die, both we, and thou, and also our little ones</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">176</sup><i class="footnote">Further 43:8.</i>

Verse 13



Verse 14

THAT HE MAY SEND AWAY YOUR OTHER BROTHER, AND BENJAMIN. In line with the literal interpretation of Scripture, it would seem that Simeon was not a favorite of his father because of the Shechem affair.<sup class="footnote-marker">177</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 34:25-30.</i> This was why he did not say, “My son Simeon, and Benjamin,” as he would not mention him by name, and as he left him in Egypt for a long time. Indeed, had there been food in his house, he would not yet have sent Benjamin, and he would have left him [Simeon] in Egypt.<br>Now Rashi wrote, “<i>The other one:</i> the spirit of prophecy was enkindled within Jacob so as to include Joseph.” In Bereshith Rabbah<sup class="footnote-marker">178</sup><i class="footnote">92:3.</i> they also said: “<i>That he may send away your brother:</i> this refers to Joseph. <i>The other one:</i> this refers to Simeon.” This is correct, for at the moment of prayer, Jacob directed his heart to pray in a general manner for the other one [Joseph] also, for perhaps he is still alive.<br>There in Bereshith Rabbah,<sup class="footnote-marker">178</sup><i class="footnote">92:3.</i> the Rabbis expounded on the verse in yet another way, saying, “Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi interpreted the verse as alluding to the exiles: <i>And G-d Almighty give you compassion before the man</i> — this is a reference to the Holy One, blessed be He, as it is said, <i>The Eternal is a man of war</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">179</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 15:3.</i> and it is written, <i>And He gave them compassion before their captors</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">180</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 106:46.</i> <i>That he may send away your brother</i> — this alludes to the Ten Tribes exiled by the Assyrians.<sup class="footnote-marker">181</sup><i class="footnote">II Kings 17:6.</i> <i>The other one, and Benjamin</i> — this refers to the exile of Judah and Benjamin. <i>And as for me, bereaved</i> by the First Destruction [brought about by the Babylonians], <i>I am bereaved</i> by the Second Destruction [caused by the Romans], but no more will I be bereaved.”<sup class="footnote-marker">182</sup><i class="footnote">Following the redemption from the Roman exile, there will no longer be a destruction. See Ramban’s work, Sefer Hage’ulah (Book of Redemption) in my Kitvei Haramban, Vol. I, where he expounds this theme at great length.</i> This is the language of the Rabbis, may their memory be blessed.<br>The intent of this text is to suggest that Jacob’s going down to Egypt alludes to our present exile at the hand of Edom, as I will explain,<sup class="footnote-marker">183</sup><i class="footnote">See the beginning of <i>Seder Vayechi</i>.</i> and the prophet [Jacob] saw this matter at its very inception, and so he prayed about it in a general way, which was applicable to the moment as well as to the future.<sup class="footnote-marker">184</sup><i class="footnote">See Ramban above, 12:6.</i> This verse, according to their interpretation, contains a great mystic thought. Jacob was saying: “<i>And G-d Almighty</i>, by the Divine attribute of justice, <i>give you the compassion</i> that is before Him,” meaning that “He should direct you upward from the Divine attribute of justice to that of compassion.” The student versed in the mystic teachings of the Torah will understand.
AND AS FOR ME, AS I AM BEREAVED, I AM BEREAVED. “<i>And as for me</i>, until you return I shall be bereaved because of doubt. <i>As I am bereaved</i> of Joseph and Simeon, <i>I am bereaved</i> of Benjamin.” These are the words of Rashi.<br>The correct interpretation is that Jacob is saying that “you can no longer add to my bereavement as I am already bereaved.” He thus consoled himself about everything that came upon him by his great suffering for Joseph. In a similar sense is the verse, <i>And as I perish, I perish</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">185</sup><i class="footnote">Esther 4:16.</i> meaning “I have already perished,<sup class="footnote-marker">186</sup><i class="footnote">By being separated from my people. (Abraham ibn Ezra, <i>ibid</i>).</i> and if the king will slay me he will not add to my destruction.”

Verse 16



Verse 17



Verse 18

THAT HE MAY DEVISE SOME PRETEXT (‘L’HITHGOLEIL’) AGAINST US. The word <i>l’hithgoleil</i> is of the same root as: <i>And Amasa lay wallowing (‘mithgoleil’) in blood?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">187</sup><i class="footnote">II Samuel 20:12.</i> <i>And every cloak rolled (‘m’golalah’) in blood</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">188</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 9:4.</i> [Its meaning is] as a man who turns from side to side upon his fellow.
AND TO FALL UPON US. I.e., as a man who intentionally throws his full stature upon his fellow.<br>Now Onkelos translated <i>l’hithgoleil</i> as meaning “to play the lord over us,” meaning that he will elevate himself above us, as the sea raises its waves.<sup class="footnote-marker">189</sup><i class="footnote">See Ezekiel 26:3.</i> Onkelos rendered the expression, <i>and to fall upon us</i>, as <i>le’istakapha</i>, meaning “to accuse us of things which did not occur,” since things which did not occur are expressed by the Hebrew word <i>nopheil</i> (falling), just as it says, <i>Not one thing failed (‘naphal’)</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">190</sup><i class="footnote">Joshua 23:14.</i> Similarly did Onkelos translate <i>Wanton charges (‘aliloth d’varim’)</i><sup class="footnote-marker">191</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 22:14.</i> as <i>taskophei milin</i> (intrigues). Jonathan too translated <i>to’einah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">192</sup><i class="footnote">Judges 14:4.</i> (pretext) as <i>thuskapha</i>.
AND TO TAKE US FOR SERVANTS, AND OUR ASSES. The reason why they mention their asses in the verse is that they would feel apprehensive about them, saying, “Now they will also take our asses with their sacks, and we will not be able to send grain to our families, and thus they will all perish of famine.”

Verse 19



Verse 20

‘BI ADONI’ (O, MY LORD). The word <i>bi</i> is an expression of entreaty and supplication. In Aramaic, we have <i>bai bai</i>. Thus the language of Rashi.<br>Now it is a very strange thing to associate the Hebrew word <i>bi</i> with a word from the Tarsian<sup class="footnote-marker">193</sup><i class="footnote">A dialect of Aramaic. Ramban probably uses the word <i>Tarsi</i> here in a derogatory sense to emphasize the difficulty of associating a word of the sacred Hebrew language with a “Tarsian” root.</i> language, which is unlike it, for the word <i>bai</i> is all one root; it cannot be changed, nor can you obtain the form of the word <i>bi</i> from this Aramaic root.<br>Moreover, this word <i>bai</i> does not connote entreaty and supplication, as the Rabbi [Rashi] states. Rather it is an expression of distress and affliction over a tragedy and mishap, similar to the word <i>avoi</i> in the Sacred Language. This is well known in the Arabic language, where the poets customarily use it in their elegies, always with a <i>patach</i> under the <i>beth: bai</i>. In the Greek language the word is <i>bia</i> — the <i>beth</i> having a <i>shva</i> — and is used to express distress and grief. Thus you find in Bereshith Rabbah, <i>Seder Bereshith</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">194</sup><i class="footnote">12:10.</i> that the Sages say: “What is the meaning of the verse, <i>Extol Him that rideth upon the skies, the Eternal (‘bayah’) is His Name?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">195</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 68:5.</i> There is no place whatever that does not have an officer in charge of its grievances. Agricus<sup class="footnote-marker">196</sup><i class="footnote">A type of public official.</i> is in charge of grievances in his state; Agratus<sup class="footnote-marker">196</sup><i class="footnote">A type of public official.</i> is in charge of grievances in his state. In the same way, who is in charge of the grievances (<i>baya</i>) in His world? [It is] the Holy One, blessed be He.” That is to say, every place has someone in charge of hearing complaints of distress and injustice, and the Holy One, blessed be He, is in charge of the cries of the oppressed, who cry, <i>baya</i>.<br>Again, before us in the Midrash Bereshith Rabbah of the <i>Parshath</i> (section of) <i>Vayigash Eilav:</i><sup class="footnote-marker">197</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 44:18. Bereshith Rabbah 93:5.</i> “Judah said to Joseph, ‘You do <i>baya</i> (violence)<sup class="footnote-marker">198</sup><i class="footnote">You are treating us unjustly.</i> against us. You had said to us thus: <i>That I May set mine eyes upon him</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">199</sup><i class="footnote">Further 44:21.</i> Is this “casting an eye” upon him?’”<br>And in the <i>Parshath Vay’hi B’shalach</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">200</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 13:17.</i> you find in Shmoth Rabbah:<sup class="footnote-marker">201</sup><i class="footnote">2:8.</i> “Do I ever <i>baya</i> (wrong) any creature?” And in the <i>Parshath Vayishma Yithro</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">202</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 18:1.</i> we find in Shmoth Rabbah:<sup class="footnote-marker">203</sup><i class="footnote">27:8.</i> “Once a man has been appointed and he has put on the mantle of leadership, all communal burdens are upon him. If he sees a man doing <i>baya</i> against his fellow, or committing some transgression, and he fails to protest it, he is punished on account thereof.” And in the <i>Parshath Isha Ki Thazria</i><sup class="footnote-marker">204</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 12:2.</i> we find:<sup class="footnote-marker">205</sup><i class="footnote">This Midrash is quoted in Aruch Hashalem, under the root <i>baya</i>.</i> “I raise a cry of violence (<i>baya</i>) against you.” And so also in many places.<br>Now Onkelos, who translated <i>Bi Adoni</i> here as <i>b’va’u riboni</i> (O please, my lord), did not intend to suggest that the Hebrew word <i>bi</i> is a derivative of the Aramaic <i>ba’u</i>, but he merely translated it in accordance with its context, for the word <i>bi</i> is always found as an expression of supplication.<br>Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra says that <i>bi adoni</i> is a shortened form in the Sacred Language, and its meaning is as in the verse, <i>Upon me, my lord, upon me be the iniquity</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">206</sup><i class="footnote">I Samuel 25:24.</i> thus meaning, “do to me whatever you wish, but listen to me.” But if this interpretation of Ibn Ezra is correct, it should follow that a person should also be able to say in Hebrew, “‘<i>bi</i>’ my brother,” or “‘<i>bi</i>,’ listen to me.” And yet nowhere do we find the word <i>bi</i> except in conjunction with the word <i>adoni</i> (my lord), or with the Honored Name of G-d when it is written with the letters <i>aleph, daleth</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">207</sup><i class="footnote">Such as in Exodus 4:10.</i> which is also an expression of lordship. It is for this reason that I say that the meaning of the word <i>bi</i> is “by myself”: “By my life! you are lord and ruler.” The two pronouns<sup class="footnote-marker">208</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Bi</i> (by <i>my</i> self) and <i>adoni</i> (<i>my</i> lord). The use of the double first person pronoun when one would be sufficient is for the purpose of emphasis, and it is found in many places in Scripture, as Ramban proceeds to demonstrate.</i> serve for the purpose of emphasis, just as: <i>But me, even me thy servant;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">209</sup><i class="footnote">I Kings 1:26.</i> <i>Upon me, my lord, upon me</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">210</sup><i class="footnote">I Samuel 25:24.</i> Similar to this is the verse, <i>That thou art against Me, against thy help</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">211</sup><i class="footnote">Hosea 13:9. Here the letter <i>beth</i> appears twice: <i>bi be’ezracha</i>, when one would be sufficient: <i>bi ezracha</i> (in Me is thy help). The double <i>beth</i> is for emphasis.</i> meaning “I serve as your help.”

Verse 21



Verse 22



Verse 23

HE HATH GIVEN YOU A HIDDEN TREASURE (‘MATMON’) IN YOUR BAGS. Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra said that Joseph told them that “it is possible that some one had a hidden treasure in his house which he forgot,<sup class="footnote-marker">212</sup><i class="footnote">It was inadvertently placed in the grain which was collected during the years of plenty, and it happened to be hidden in the grain purchased by Joseph’s brothers.</i> and it fell to your lot for <i>your money came to me</i>.”<br>Now these are but words of consolation, for how did it happen that each one of the brothers received the precise amount of money<sup class="footnote-marker">213</sup><i class="footnote">Above, Verse 21.</i> which he paid for the grain! Rather, the correct interpretation is that all matter which is hidden is called <i>matmon</i> in Hebrew: <i>The lazy man hides (‘taman’) his hand in the dish;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">214</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 19:24.</i> <i>We have stores hidden (‘matmonim’) in the field</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">215</sup><i class="footnote">Jeremiah 41:8.</i> Thus Joseph told them that it is customary for ass-drivers who buy grain that each one put his money in his sack, and the attendant in charge of the sales took the sacks from those who came and filled ten sacks with grain, and the money remained hidden under the grain. Then the attendant’s master came and commanded him to pour these ten bags into the vessels of Jacob’s sons as he wanted to send them away in a hurry or because he was not in charge of taking money.<sup class="footnote-marker">216</sup><i class="footnote">The officer who commanded the sacks to be transferred to the brothers’ vessels in order to load them on the asses was not in charge of taking money from the buyers. Neither did he know that the attendant who was supposed to have received the money had not received it. Thus the mistake occurred.</i> Thus it happened that each one found his exact amount of money at the opening of the sack, as each one had brought the amount of money for a donkey’s load worth of bread. This constantly occurs in market-places and store-houses where sales take place in a great confusion of people.

Chapter 44



Verse 1

AS MUCH AS THEY CAN BEAR. I.e., more than they were entitled to for the money they had brought him.
AND PUT EVERY MAN’s MONEY IN HIS BAG’s MOUTH. That is, with their knowledge, for the house steward said to them, “My lord knows that he did you wrong, and he now wishes to make amends to you.” If he would do as he had done the first time, that is, [put the money in their bags] without their knowledge, they would have had a defense in the matter of the goblet, i.e., that the same thing happened to it as happened to the money. Instead, it was done with their knowledge, and they knew of the money just as they knew of the load, for they recognized that he had given them <i>as much as they can bear</i>. But if it were done without their knowledge, he might perhaps argue on their behalf that the money had come to them this time too on account of its having been hidden there,<sup class="footnote-marker">212</sup><i class="footnote">It was inadvertently placed in the grain which was collected during the years of plenty, and it happened to be hidden in the grain purchased by Joseph’s brothers.</i> but such was not possible with the goblet. But, then, who can argue with one more powerful than himself?<sup class="footnote-marker">217</sup><i class="footnote">See Ecclesiastes 6:10.</i><br>Know that on account of the very many buyers from all over Egypt, and the great confusion in the midst of it, those who came to buy would give their sacks and money to the seller, and he would measure grain for them according to the amount of money he found in the sacks. They in turn took the grain given to them, <i>forasmuch as the king’s word hath power</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">218</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 8:4.</i> and moreover, <i>for he did his work honestly</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">219</sup><i class="footnote">See II Kings 12:16.</i> It is for this reason that they took their closed sacks the first time, and even the second time they knew not what was in them.

Verse 2



Verse 3



Verse 4



Verse 5

IS NOT THIS THE ONE IN WHICH MY LORD DRINKETH? He did not mention “the goblet,” but instead he spoke with them as if it was known that they took the goblet. This was why he said, “Is not this, which you took, the one from which my master drinks?” They also answered him as if they do not know what he wants: <i>How then should we steal out of thy lord’s house silver or gold?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">220</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 8 here.</i> And they further said, <i>“With whomsoever of thy servants there be found</i> stolen silver or gold, <i>let him die.”</i><sup class="footnote-marker">221</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 9 here.</i>
IN WHICH MY LORD DRINKETH. This is intended as a pretext in order to magnify the accusation against them, for he who steals the royal cup from which the king drinks demonstrates disdain for royalty, and bribe and ransom will be of no avail.
WHICH INDEED HE USES FOR DIVINATION. That is, he does not wish that his cup be in the hands of others so that he should have to ask other diviners about it. This is the meaning of his words, <i>A man like me</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">222</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 15 here.</i> And his intent is to say that through diviners he knows that they stole it, and this was why he pursued them more than any other people who came into his house. All this he did in order to give the appearance that the matter is unfamiliar to him, just as he feigned unfamiliarity when he searched their bags, beginning with the eldest and concluding with the youngest.<sup class="footnote-marker">223</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 12 here.</i>

Verse 6



Verse 7



Verse 8



Verse 9



Verse 10

ALSO NOW IT WERE RIGHT TO BE ACCORDING TO YOUR WORDS. “Indeed, this is only right. Verily it should be according to your words since you are all guilty in this matter. When there are ten men and a stolen thing is found in the possession of one of them, all of them are arrested. I, however, will deal with you inside the bounds [of justice, that is, I will deal with you more leniently]. <i>He with whom it shall be found</i>, he alone <i>shall be my servant</i>.” Thus the language of Rashi.<br>But according to this interpretation, the words, <i>gam atah</i> (also now), do not fit in well.<sup class="footnote-marker">224</sup><i class="footnote">For since Rashi writes that this is a <i>din emeth</i> (a true decision), how can the words <i>gam atah</i> (also now) fit into the context since these words suggest that <i>now</i> a new law is established. (Aboab.) See also my Hebrew commentary, p. 238.</i> Perhaps Rashi is saying: “Also now, when according to your words, it is the law [that all be held guilty in the matter], <i>he with whom it shall be found shall be my servant</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">225</sup><i class="footnote">Thus, Joseph’s verdict is not at all related to the established law concerning theft, but is primarily designed to bespeak his kindness in keeping only Benjamin as a servant while the rest go completely free. Hence the words <i>gam atah</i> (also now) apply since this is a principle newly set forth.</i> But this can hardly be correct since Joseph said, <i>Far be it from me to do so</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">226</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 7 here.</i> This shows that it is <i>not</i> the law that they all be held responsible for the theft. It is for this reason that he said: “<i>Far be it from me</i>, for I am the judge of the whole land, and far be it from me to do you wrong,” for all ten men are not guilty if a stolen article is found in the possession of one of them unless they all planned the theft and were united in going to steal it. Then, if one of them took it with the knowledge of all, they are all liable.<br>The correct interpretation would seem to be that at first he accused them all: <i>Why have you repaid evil for good?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">227</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 4 here.</i> <i>You have done evil in so doing</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">228</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 5 here.</i> And they freed themselves of the accusation by saying, “<i>With whomsoever of thy servants it be found, let him die</i>, since he is the thief, and <i>we also</i>, who are guiltless of the theft, <i>will be my lord’s servants</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">229</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 9 here.</i> Thus their opinion was that the thief, in whose possession it might be found, was the only one with knowledge of the theft, for if they were all involved in the theft, why should that one alone be put to death while the rest remain alive. In that case, all of them should be put to death or all of them should become servants, for they all bear equal legal responsibility. Rather, they pleaded that the others had no knowledge of the theft. They agreed that they should become servants as a self-punishment only. This is why Joseph said to them, “<i>Gam atah</i> (also now) that you are assembled and are together,<sup class="footnote-marker">230</sup><i class="footnote">The fact that you are now all found together suggests that you all had a hand in the stealing.</i> <i>it were right to be according to your words; nevertheless, he with whom it is found</i>, he alone is the thief, and he alone is deserving of punishment, and he will be a servant to me for I desire his services more than his death. <i>But you shall be guiltless</i>, for perhaps you did not know about the theft, as you say.”<br>Perhaps the meaning of the words <i>kein hu</i> (it were right) is that “it shall be so,” meaning, “also now that the law is not so,<sup class="footnote-marker">231</sup><i class="footnote">For you said that only as an act of self-punishment you agree to be servants. That is not the law, for since there is a suspicion upon all of you, you should be arrested until the matter is clarified. Yet <i>so shall it be</i> according to your words, and ye shall be guiltless.</i> according to your words so shall it be.” A similar case is the verse, <i>And she said: According to your words, ‘kein hu,’ and she sent them away, and they departed</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">232</sup><i class="footnote">Joshua 2:21.</i> which means, “so shall it be.” This is the correct interpretation in my opinion. This conforms to the words of our Rabbis in Bereshith Rabbah,<sup class="footnote-marker">233</sup><i class="footnote">92:8.</i> who say, “If ten people are discovered with a stolen article, are they not all to be imprisoned? I will not do so, but <i>he with whom it is found shall be my servant</i>.” They thus intended to interpret the verse as I have explained it,<sup class="footnote-marker">234</sup><i class="footnote">That the brothers were denying that under the law they were all responsible. It was only as a form of self-punishment that they agreed to be servants. Joseph, however, argued that since suspicion does fall upon them they should be imprisoned until their innocence is established.</i> and not in accordance with the words of Rashi.<sup class="footnote-marker">235</sup><i class="footnote">That the brothers agreed that under the law they all could be held responsible.</i><br>We might correct the interpretation in accordance with the opinion of the Rabbi [Rashi] by stating that Joseph said: “Far be it from me to do this and deal more harshly with you than my house-steward, who freed you at the outset by saying to you, <i>but ye shall be guiltless</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">236</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 10 here.</i> for I will confirm the words of my servant, and the counsel of my messenger will I perform.”<sup class="footnote-marker">237</sup><i class="footnote">See Isaiah 44:26.</i><br>Vayigash
