Verse 15



Verse 16



Verse 17



Verse 18

LET THY SERVANT, I PRAY THEE, SPEAK A WORD. The intent thereof is to say that he [Judah] will speak but a few words which will not burden Joseph. In my opinion, the correct interpretation is that “a word” refers to the exchange concerning which he is to plead before him, namely, that Joseph exchange him for his brother Benjamin, for he will not ask any other thing of him, and all of the rest of his words are an appeasement and a plea for this exchange.
AND LET NOT THINE ANGER BURN AGAINST THY SERVANT. Judah is saying: “Do not be angry at me for speaking before you.”
FOR THOU ART EVEN AS PHARAOH, i.e., “it is with great fear that I speak before you, as if I was speaking before Pharaoh.”

Verse 19

MY LORD ASKED HIS SERVANTS. I know no reason for this lengthy speech of Judah in which he relates that which has already transpired between them. And that which the Rabbis, of blessed memory, have said in interpretation of Judah’s words:<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">Bereshith Rabbah 93:5, quoted here by Rashi.</i> “Is this the ‘setting your eyes upon him’ to which you referred when you said, <i>That I may set mine eyes upon him?</i>”<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 21 here.</i> — does not make it a valid argument, for a ruler who commands that a person be brought before him does not do so on condition that he be freed from the consequences of the evils he would commit, and the more so for a theft in which the goblet from which he drinks was stolen from the king’s house. And originally he had favorably cast his eyes upon Benjamin, greeting him by saying <i>G-d be gracious unto thee, my son</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 43:29.</i> and he made all a party before him in the palace in Benjamin’s honor, and he gave them presents<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 34.</i> and gave them corn <i>as much as they can bear</i><sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 44:1.</i> in excess of the money they had brought him, as I have explained, and what else was he to do for him!<br>It therefore appears to me, in line with the plain meaning of Scripture, that Judah’s words are nought but supplications to bestir Joseph’s compassion, for Judah thought that he was a man who fears G-d, as he had told him,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 42:18.</i> and since he had conducted himself mercifully towards them in the manner of one who fears sin, by consoling them for the trouble he had caused them.<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 43:23.</i> And this is the purport of the story. Judah said to him: “As a consequence of my lord’s inquiry, we were forced to tell you about this brother of ours, and we also did not consent to bring him down before you as you commanded at first, but we said that <i>the lad cannot leave his father</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 22 here.</i> However, at the peril of our lives, <i>because of the burning heat of famine</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">Lamentations 5:10.</i> we brought him, for you said, <i>Ye shall see my face no more</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 23 here.</i> But our father did not want to listen and permit us to return to buy a little food until we were all in danger, and then he consented with fear and worry. But now <i>when he seeth that the lad is not with us</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 31 here.</i> he will die <i>in bitterness of soul</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">Job 21:25.</i> Therefore, <i>let my supplication, I pray thee, be presented before thee</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">Jeremiah 37:20.</i> to have pity upon us and the aged father, and take me in place of the lad as a permanent servant, for I am better than he, <i>and it shall be righteousness unto thee</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 24:13.</i> This is the purport of the entire section.<br>It is possible that the expression, <i>and thy servants will bring down the gray hairs of thy servant our father</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 31 here.</i> is a euphemism out of respect [for Joseph, and Judah’s intent was to say], “and <i>you</i> will bring down the gray hairs of thy servant our father.” Similarly, <i>But this thing brings sin upon thy people</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 5:16.</i> [The officers meant to say, “This thing brings sin upon you.”]<br>It may further be said, in line with that which our Rabbis have said: “Is this the ‘setting your eyes upon him’ to which you referred?”—that Judah said, <i>For thou art even as Pharaoh</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 18 here.</i> meaning “it behooves you to stand by your word and your inquest, for it was on account of you that we have brought the lad under great duress,” as he [Judah] mentions, and he feared to be more explicit. But hidden in his words is the hint that the goblet affair was a scheme of his to have a pretext against them, for why should Joseph have wanted to see Benjamin to begin with, against their will. And so the Rabbis said in Bereshith Rabbah:<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">93:8.</i> “Judah said to him, ‘I will prove to you that you moved against us with a pretext. The people of how many countries have come down to buy food? Have you interrogated them as you have interrogated us? Were we perhaps asking for your daughter in marriage or were you seeking to marry our sister?’” The Rabbis are saying that this was hinted at in his words.

Verse 20



Verse 21

THAT I MAY SET MINE EYES UPON HIM. Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra said that the meaning thereof is “that I may see him.” But I have not found “setting of eyes” in Scripture in reference to just seeing. Thus: <i>And I will set Mine eyes upon them for good;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">Jeremiah 24:6.</i> <i>Take him, and put your eye upon him, and do him no harm</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 39:12.</i> for Nebuchadrezzar did not command Nebuzaradan to merely see Jeremiah after he took him into custody, but to watch him and treat him well. But the meaning here is that Joseph had vowed to them to have pity on the lad and to guard him, even though it is not mentioned explicitly [in the narrative of the original confrontation between Joseph and his brothers], just as Scripture is concise there about all these matters which Judah related in Joseph’s presence. Now Judah did not mention the imprisonment of Simeon and the pretext that <i>Ye are spies</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 42:9.</i> out of respect or out of the fear of majesty.

Verse 22

AND WE SAID UNTO MY LORD: THE LAD CANNOT LEAVE HIS FATHER; FOR IF HE SHOULD LEAVE HIS FATHER, HE WOULD DIE. Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra explained this to mean “and his father would die.” But if so, Judah would have said: “Our father cannot leave his son, for if he should leave his son, he [the father] would die.” Or he should have said, “We cannot bear that the lad leave the father,” for they would not make the plea for compassion for their father dependent upon the lad, [saying, as the verse has it. <i>‘The lad’ cannot leave his father for if he should leave his father, he would die]</i>, since they considered him as a child who did not know the difference between good and evil. [Therefore, if it be as Ibn Ezra says, i.e., that the concern in this verse is lest the father die, they would have said, “We cannot bear that the lad should leave his father,” or “Our father cannot leave his son.”] Rather, the meaning is: <i>The lad cannot leave his father</i> on account of his youth and his being the darling son in the lap of his father who loves him, and if he should leave him and come on the journey the lad would die.

Verse 23



Verse 24

WHEN WE CAME UP UNTO THY SERVANT MY FATHER, WE TOLD HIM THE WORDS OF MY LORD. Judah said that immediately upon coming to their father, they told him that they will not see the ruler’s face again without their younger brother, but he refused to send him, and would have left Simeon to him in his prison. This is the meaning of the verse, <i>And our father said: Go again, buy us a little food</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 25 here.</i> for he did not consent to send Benjamin in spite of all we said, until forced to by the famine.

Verse 25



Verse 26



Verse 27

YE KNOW THAT MY WIFE BORE ME TWO SONS. If we say [that Jacob’s intention was to point out] that Benjamin is the only one left to his mother, why is this a reason [for his saying that if some harm will befall him] it will bring down his <i>gray hairs with sorrow to the grave?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 29 here.</i> After all, he has many sons and grandchildren, and Benjamin’s mother has already died, and she would no longer weep over him in Jacob’s presence. The meaning of the verse, however, is that Jacob took only Rachel as a wife on his own initiative. This is the sense of the words, <i>my wife bore me</i>: “for from a woman that was my wife of my own will there have been only two sons born to me, and I have bestowed my love upon them as if they were my only ones, the rest being to me as if they were children of concubines. And with his brother Joseph dead, this one alone is my only son whom I have loved.” It is for this reason that Scripture mentions Rachel before Leah: <i>Like Rachel and like Leah, which two did build the house of Israel;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">Ruth 4:11.</i> <i>And he called Rachel and Leah to the field</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 31:4.</i> Rachel took precedence in his mind. The commentators<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">See Rashi further 46:19.</i> have said that the reason why Scripture in this <i>Seder</i> says, <i>The sons of Rachel Jacob’s wife</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 46:19.</i> is that she is called his wife in truth, without any deception. In my opinion, however, this is because Rachel is mentioned there among the handmaids, as I have already so mentioned.<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 31:33 and 37:2. Ramban agrees with the principle as he himself explains it in connection with the verse above, 31:4. However, he points out that in the verse further, 46:19, the term, <i>Jacob’s wife</i>, is independently justified.</i>

Verse 28



Verse 29

AND ‘ASON’ (HARM) BEFALL HIM, YE WILL BRING DOWN MY GRAY HAIRS. That is, “if harm befall him as it did to his brother Joseph, you will bring down <i>my gray hairs with sorrow to the grave</i>.” Perhaps the expression, <i>and ‘ason’ (harm) befall him</i>, means that it will so happen to him on account of his being young and tender and not accustomed to travel on the road, this being analogous to what Jacob said above, <i>Lest ‘ason’ (harm) should befall him</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 42:4.</i> for the meaning of the word <i>ason</i> is accidental death, such as those killed by a human or a wild beast or the change of air on the road.

Verse 30



Verse 31



Verse 32

FOR THY SERVANT BECAME SURETY FOR THE LAD. Judah is saying that his father will go down <i>with sorrow to the grave</i><sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 31 here.</i> on account of the lad, for “despite all that we have said to him, the aged father did not want to send him until I became surety for him, and he trusted me. Therefore, <i>let thy servant, I pray thee, abide</i><sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 33 here.</i> in his stead.” And if the explanation of the verse, <i>And thy servants will bring down the gray hairs of thy servant our father…to the grave</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 31 here.</i> is in line with the plain meaning thereof, [namely, that the responsibility will fall upon the brothers, as opposed to Ramban’s previous interpretation that “thy servants” is a euphemism for Joseph,<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">See Ramban above, Verse 19.</i> then Judah] is saying that “we will have caused the death of the aged father by sorrow, for I was surety for the lad.” 

Verse 33



Verse 34

He said, <i>For how shall I go up to my father</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 34 here.</i> in order to let him [Jacob] know that he [Judah] would choose to be a permanent servant rather than go up to his father without the lad for he could not bear to see his sorrow, as he would constantly weep and mourn for him all day. Judah mentioned this so that he should not suspect him of planning some deceit since he would know how to escape better than the lad.

Chapter 45



Verse 1

THEN JOSEPH COULD NOT ‘L’HITHAPEIK’ (REFRAIN HIMSELF) BEFORE ALL THEM THAT STOOD BY HIM. He could not bear that the Egyptians should stand by him witnessing how his brothers would be put to shame when he makes himself known to them. This is the language of Rashi. But Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra said that <i>l’hithapeik</i> means “to bear.” The expression <i>Before all them that stood by him</i>, means until all that stood by him would go out, and so it was necessary that he call out that they be removed. Onkelos, however, translated <i>l’hithapeik</i> as meaning “to strengthen himself.” Similarly: <i>‘Va’ethapak” (And I forced myself) and offered the burnt-offering</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote">I Samuel 13:12.</i> Every other form of <i>hithapkuth</i> in every place is likewise an expression of strengthening.<br>The correct interpretation in my opinion is that there were present many people of Pharaoh’s house and other Egyptians, pleading with Joseph to pardon Benjamin, for their compassions were deeply stirred by Judah’s pleas, and Joseph could not overcome them all. He then called forth to his servants, “<i>Let every</i> strange <i>man go out from me</i>, because I will speak to them.” And when they had gone out, <i>he wept aloud; and the Egyptians heard, and</i> the people of <i>the house of Pharaoh</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 2 here.</i> who had been expelled from his presence, for they were still in the outer court.<br>It is possible that the expression, <i>‘hanitzavim’ (them that stood) by him</i>, means his servants who stood before him, just as: <i>The servant ‘hanitzav’ (that was set) over the reapers;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote">Ruth 2:6.</i> <i>‘sarei hanitzavim’ (chief officers);</i><sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote">I Kings 5:30.</i> <i>‘L’hithyatzeiv’ (To present themselves) before the Eternal</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote">Job 1:6.</i> And the meaning of <i>Vayikra</i> (and he called) is that he raised his voice with anger and said to his servants, “<i>Cause every man to go out from before me</i>, except these men.” And the reason for the removal is that he expelled them from there so that they should not hear when he mentions the matter of the sale to his brothers because it would be a source of distress to them and also to himself, for the servants of Pharaoh and the Egyptians will say of them: “These are treacheous people who must not live in our land, nor tread in our palaces. They have acted treacherously against their brother, and also dealt treacherously with their father. What will they do to the king and his people?” They would also no longer believe in Joseph.

Verse 2



Verse 3



Verse 4



Verse 5



Verse 6

FOR THESE TWO YEARS HATH THE FAMINE BEEN IN THE LAND. The reason why he mentioned to them what had transpired, which they themselves also knew, was to state that a land which has gone through two years of famine, in which the people had consumed all which they possessed, resulting in exceedingly high prices, and which was destined to experience five more years of famine, could offer them no sustenance whatsoever — had G-d not dispatched me before you.

Verse 7



Verse 8



Verse 9



Verse 10

AND THOU SHALT DWELL IN THE LAND OF GOSHEN. Joseph knew that his father would not want to stay in that part of the land of Egypt where the royal palace was. Therefore he now informed him that he will settle him in the land of Goshen. The meaning of the expression, <i>Thou and thy children</i>, is that it is connected with the previous verse: <i>Come down unto me…</i><sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 9 here.</i> <i>thou and thy children, and thy children’s children, and thy flocks, and thy herds, and all that thou hast</i>.

Verse 11

LEST THOU COME TO POVERTY, THOU, AND THY HOUSEHOLD. Joseph said this by way of respect for his father. To his brothers he said, <i>For G-d did send me before you to preserve life</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 5 here.</i> and <i>to give you a remnant</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 7 here.</i> but to his father he did not want to say so. Instead, he said, “that if you will delay in the land of Canaan you will be impoverished for I could not send you much food from the royal storehouse as they will suspect me of selling it there in order to accumulate treasures of money and then return to my land and to my birthplace. But when you come here, and they will know that you are my father and brothers, the king will give me permission to sustain you.”

Verse 12

THAT IT IS MY MOUTH THAT SPEAKETH UNTO YOU. I.e., in the Holy Language. This is the opinion of the commentators,<sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote">Rashi, Ibn Ezra and R’dak.</i> and it is also the translation of Onkelos. It is possible that Joseph said so to them for plausibility and in order to be conciliatory, for the fact that a person in Egypt speaks the Holy Language is not proof that he is Joseph. It is my opinion that the Holy Language was the language of Canaan for Abraham did not bring it there from Ur of the Chaldees or Haran, as they spoke Aramaic there, as is attested to by “the heap.”<sup class="footnote-marker">42</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 31:47. In Aramaic, Laban named it <i>Yegar-sahaduth</i> (the heap of witness). Thus it is clear that Aramaic was the spoken language in Abraham’s birthplace.</i> Now it was not the language of one man alone; rather, it was the language of the entire land of Canaan, and many people in Egypt knew it, since Canaan was nearby. We would particularly expect knowledge of languages in the case of a ruler for it is usual for kings and rulers to be linguistic. It is just as you see in the case of Nebuchadnezzar who said in the Holy Language, <i>I have dreamed a dream, and my spirit is troubled to know the dream</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote">Daniel 2:3.</i> because there were <i>the magicians, and the enchanters, and the sorcerers, and Chaldeans</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 2.</i> people of many languages, as well as from Israel, and they all would understand him. They, however, answered him in Aramaic, as it says, <i>Then spoke the Chaldeans to the king in Aramaic</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">45</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 4.</i> as they were close to him, <i>and sat first in the kingdom</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">46</sup><i class="footnote">Esther 1:14.</i> and they had the permission to speak to the king. Moreover, just as Joseph came from Canaan to Egypt, many others also came. Besides, the brothers had greater proof that he was Joseph when he mentioned his name and the circumstance of the sale, saying, <i>I am Joseph your brother, whom ye sold into Egypt</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">47</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 4 here.</i><br>The correct interpretation in my opinion is that Joseph is saying: “<i>And, behold, your eyes see, and the eyes of my brother Benjamin</i>, that I, the ruler and lord of all Egypt, am the one telling you with my mouth that I am your brother, and command you to bring down my father to me in order to sustain him. This being so, you will tell my father of all the glory in Egypt, <i>and of all that you have seen</i><sup class="footnote-marker">48</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 13 here.</i> with your eyes, and you will hurry and bring him down to me for the words I have spoken are true, and I have the power to deliver him and to keep him alive in the famine.”<sup class="footnote-marker">49</sup><i class="footnote">See Psalms 33:19.</i> This is analogous to saying, “for I have spoken my word.” In the <i>Gemara</i> of Tractate Megillah,<sup class="footnote-marker">50</sup><i class="footnote">16b.</i> the Rabbis have said: “As my mouth, so is my heart,” [meaning: “Just as I indicate no hatred against you in my speech, so is my heart free of hatred against you].”

Verse 13



Verse 14



Verse 15



Verse 16

JOSEPH’s BRETHREN ARE COME. The intent thereof is that Joseph told the house of Pharaoh that he had honorable brothers in the land of the Hebrews, for he had been stolen away from there,<sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote">See above, 40:15.</i> and now the Egyptians heard that Joseph’s brothers had come as he said.
AND IT PLEASED PHARAOH WELL, AND HIS SERVANTS. For it was a disgrace to them to be ruled by a stranger, a servant [of whom it is said], <i>out of prison he came forth to be king</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">52</sup><i class="footnote">Ecclesiastes 4:14.</i> and now when his honorable brothers came to him, and it became known that Joseph was worthy to stand before kings,<sup class="footnote-marker">53</sup><i class="footnote">See Proverbs 22:29.</i> they all rejoiced in the matter.

Verse 17



Verse 18



Verse 19

NOW THOU ART COMMANDED, THIS DO YE. Pharaoh stated the matter in the form of a directive to him because his knowledge of Joseph’s integrity assured him that he would not stretch forth a hand to take from the king’s fortune, <i>and having him, he gave no concern to anything</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">54</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 39:6.</i> Therefore Pharaoh thought that perhaps Joseph would not want to send his father anything. Hence he said to him, “I command you that you do this in any case.”

Verse 20



Verse 21



Verse 22



Verse 23

AND TO HIS FATHER HE SENT ‘KAZOTH’ (IN LIKE MANNER). I.e., according to this amount. And what was the amount? <i>Ten asses</i>, etc. This is the language of Rashi. It is not correct that <i>kazoth</i> should refer to the amount [for if it refers to <i>cheshbon</i> (amount), it should have said <i>kazeh</i> in the masculine, and not <i>kazoth</i> in the feminine]. But it is possible that Scripture says, <i>in like manner</i>, meaning “according to this gift,” [with the word <i>minchah</i> matching the feminine gender of <i>kazoth</i>] The purport thereof is, “and to his father he sent this gift: ten asses, etc.,” [with the word <i>kazoth</i> being understood as if it were written <i>zoth</i>], and the letter <i>kaph</i> in the word <i>kazoth</i> is considered redundant. However, it is the way of the Sacred Language to express it in this way, just as, <i>And she spoke to him</i>, [saying]: <i>‘ka’dvarim ha’eileh’ (after the manner of these things) did thy servant do to me</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">55</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verses 17 and 19.</i> It may be that Scripture is saying: “and to his father he sent provision <i>(tzeidah)</i>, [which is also in the feminine gender], which was like this provision which he gave to his brothers.” But the intent of the expression is not to make them equal, but only to say that just as he gave them provision for the road when they went to Canaan, so did he send his father <i>corn and bread and sustenance</i> for his journey towards Egypt. And this is the correct interpretation. Scripture mentions asses and she-asses to inform us that he sent him both the provisions and the animals that carried them, and it was customary to send males and females, as his father had done.<sup class="footnote-marker">56</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 32:16.</i>

Verse 24

DO NOT ‘TIRG’ZU’ BY THE WAY. <i>Rogez</i> is an expression of trembling and movement, and is usually applied when the trembling is a result of fear, as for example, <i>a heart ‘ragaz’ (that is trembling);</i><sup class="footnote-marker">57</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 28:65.</i> <i>‘V’ragzu’ (and they shall tremble), and be in anguish;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">58</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 2:25.</i> <i>And where I stand ‘ergaz’ (I tremble);</i><sup class="footnote-marker">59</sup><i class="footnote">Habakkuk 3:16.</i> <i>And drink thy water ‘b’ragzah’ (with trembling) and with anxiety</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">60</sup><i class="footnote">Ezekiel 12:18.</i> Therefore, the correct interpretation of this verse is, in my opinion, that Joseph said to them, “Do not fear by the way,” and the purport thereof is that since they were carrying <i>corn and bread and sustenance</i><sup class="footnote-marker">61</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 23 here.</i> and the best of Egypt in the days of the famine, they might fear lest robbers attack them while they travelled on their journey to Canaan, and the moreso when they return to Egypt with all their possessions, and thus they will not hasten the matter.<sup class="footnote-marker">62</sup><i class="footnote">See II Chronicles 24:15.</i> Therefore he told them that they should go quickly and hurry to come there, as it is said, <i>Hasten ye, and go up to my father</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 9 here.</i> and they should have no fear at all on the way as his name is upon them. Since he is the ruler of the entire land of Egypt, and the lives of the peoples of those countries are in his hand, and all are fearful of his awe, they will travel and arrive in peace.

Verse 25



Verse 26

‘VAYAPHAG’ HIS HEART. His heart passed away and ceased to believe; his heart took no notice of their words. The word <i>vayaphag</i> has the same meaning as the Mishnaic expression: “The fragrance of all spices <i>m’phigin</i> (escape).”<sup class="footnote-marker">63</sup><i class="footnote">Beitza 14a.</i> Similar is the verse, <i>Without any ‘haphugoth’ (intermission)</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">64</sup><i class="footnote">Lamentations 3:49.</i> The verse, <i>And his scent is not ‘namar,’</i><sup class="footnote-marker">65</sup><i class="footnote">Jeremiah 48:11.</i> is rendered in the Targum: “and his scent is not <i>pag</i> (passing away).” This is the language of Rashi. But it is not correct, for <i>phugah</i> is an expression of cessation and abolition, just as : <i>give thyself no ‘phugath’ (respite)</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">66</sup><i class="footnote">Lamentations 2:18.</i> So also, <i>Mine eye is poured out, and ceaseth not, without any ‘haphugoth,’</i><sup class="footnote-marker">64</sup><i class="footnote">Lamentations 3:49.</i> meaning “mine eye pours out tears steadily without cessation or intermission.” And so likewise, “<i>m’phigin</i> (their fragrance)”<sup class="footnote-marker">63</sup><i class="footnote">Beitza 14a.</i> means that the spices scatter the fragrance and it is voided. So also, <i>Therefore the law is ‘taphug,’</i><sup class="footnote-marker">67</sup><i class="footnote">Habakkuk 1:4.</i> that is, voided and ceased. In this verse also, <i>‘vayaphag’ his heart</i> [thus means that the beat of] his heart was suspended and his breathing ceased, for the movement of the heart ceased and he was as dead. This condition is known when joy suddenly comes upon one, and it is mentioned in the books of medicines that old or feeble persons cannot withstand the shock, for many of them faint when joy comes to them very suddenly. The heart widens and opens suddenly, and its natural heat goes out and scatters throughout the outer parts of the body, and the heart thus ceases to function because of its coolness. Thus the patriarch fell as dead. Scripture says, <i>for he believed them not</i>, in order to relate that he remained in that condition a great part of the day, and he lay so without movement because he did not believe them.<br>Concerning such fainting it is known that people shout to the fainting person and accustom him to that joyful event gradually until he accepts it with a tranquil spirit. And this is the meaning of the verse, <i>And they told him all the words of Joseph, which he had said unto them, and when he saw the wagons</i> [<i>which Joseph had sent to carry him, the spirit of Jacob their father revived</i>],<sup class="footnote-marker">68</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 27 here.</i> for they shouted into his ears the words of Joseph and brought the wagons before him. Then did his spirit return to him, and his breathing began and he was revived. It is this which Scripture says, <i>And the spirit of Jacob their father revived</i>. Now Onkelos translated: “The Divine Presence, [which had departed from him when he was in mourning], again rested upon him.” Onkelos added this because the thing is true, and he expounded this interpretation from the word <i>ruach</i> (spirit), since Scripture does not say, “and Jacob their father revived,” [but rather, <i>and the spirit of Jacob their father revived</i>]. He thus explained the verse here as being analogous to these verses: <i>The spirit of the Eternal G-d is upon me;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">69</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 61:1.</i> <i>And now the Eternal G-d hath sent me and His spirit;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">70</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 48:16.</i> <i>A man in whom is spirit</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">71</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 27:18.</i>

Verse 27

AND THEY TOLD HIM ALL THE WORDS OF JOSEPH. It is my opinion, in line with the plain meaning of Scripture, that it was never told to Jacob throughout his entire lifetime that the brothers had sold Joseph. Rather he thought that Joseph had strayed in the field, and those who found him took him and sold him into Egypt. The brothers did not want to tell him of their sin, being afraid for their lives lest he be wroth and curse them as he did to Reuben, Simeon and Levi,<sup class="footnote-marker">72</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 49: 3-7.</i> while Joseph in his good ethical conduct did not want to tell him. It is for this reason that it is said, <i>And they sent a message unto Joseph, saying: Thy father did command before he died</i>, etc.<sup class="footnote-marker">73</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 50:16.</i> And had Jacob known of this matter, it would have been proper for them to plead before their father at the time of his death to command Joseph by word of his mouth, for he would have granted his father’s request and not rebelled against his word, and they would not have been in danger, nor would they need to feign words out of their own hearts.<sup class="footnote-marker">74</sup><i class="footnote">See Nehemiah 6:8.</i>

Chapter 46



Verse 1

AND HE OFFERED SACRIFICES UNTO THE G-D OF HIS FATHER ISAAC. The duty of honoring one’s father is more imperative than that of honoring one’s grandfather. Therefore the sacrifices are associated with the name of Isaac, and not with that of Abraham. Thus the language of Rashi. But this is not sufficient, for it would have been proper for Scripture to say, “and he offered sacrifices unto the G-d of his fathers,” without singling out any one person, just as Jacob said, <i>The G-d before whom my fathers Abraham and Isaac did walk;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">75</sup><i class="footnote">Further 48:15.</i> and in his prayer he said, <i>O G-d of my father Abraham, and G-d of my father Isaac</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">76</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 32:10.</i> Or Scripture should have said, “and he offered sacrifices to the Eternal,” just as it says in the case of Abraham, <i>And he built there an altar unto the Eternal</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">77</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 12:7.</i> And what need was there to explain it further?<br>However, this verse contains a secret, which the Rabbis revealed to us there in Bereshith Rabbah:<sup class="footnote-marker">78</sup><i class="footnote">94:5.</i> When Jacob was about to go down to Egypt he saw that the exile was beginning for him and his children, and he feared it, and so he offered many sacrifices to <i>the Fear of his father Isaac</i><sup class="footnote-marker">79</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 31:53.</i> in order that Divine judgment should not be aimed against him. This he did in Beer-sheba which was a place of prayer for his father, and from there he had taken permission when he went to Haran.<sup class="footnote-marker">80</sup><i class="footnote">See Ramban above, 28:17.</i><br>Now Scripture uses the word <i>z’vachim</i>, [a term connoting peace-offerings], to inform us that they were not burnt-offerings as were his fathers’, as Abraham offered burnt-offerings. Our Rabbis have said<sup class="footnote-marker">81</sup><i class="footnote">Zebachim 116a.</i> that Noachides<sup class="footnote-marker">82</sup><i class="footnote">See Note 148 in <i>Seder Vayishlach</i>, also Note 222 in <i>Seder Bereshith</i>.</i> did not offer peace-offerings; they offered burnt-offerings. And concerning Noah it is clearly written, <i>And he offered burnt-offerings on the altar</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">83</sup><i class="footnote">Above 8:20.</i> But on account of his fear of the Eternal, Jacob offered peace-offerings in order to bring all Divine attributes into accord towards him, even as the Rabbis have expounded:<sup class="footnote-marker">84</sup><i class="footnote">Torath Kohanim Vayikra 16:1.</i> “They are called <i>sh’lamim</i> (peace-offerings) because they bring <i>shalom</i> (peace) into the world.” Now his original intent was directed at the Divine attribute of power, this being nearest to Isaac. This is the explanation of that which the Rabbis mentioned in Bereshith Rabbah,<sup class="footnote-marker">78</sup><i class="footnote">94:5.</i> i.e., that the duty of honoring one’s father is more imperative than that of honoring one’s grandfather. This explanation applies to that which the Rabbis have said there in yet another form: “First you greet the pupil and afterward you greet the Rabbi.”<sup class="footnote-marker">85</sup><i class="footnote">The case refers to a procession of a Rabbi and his pupils on the road. Since the pupils travel in advance of the Rabbi, a person coming from the opposite direction would first meet the pupils and then the Rabbi. Similarly, Isaac is the pupil and Abraham is the Rabbi. Hence Jacob offered sacrifices to the G-d of his father Isaac.</i><br>I have seen this text in the Midrash of Rabbi Nechunya ben Hakanah:<sup class="footnote-marker">86</sup><i class="footnote">Sefer Habahir, 135. See Note 42 in <i>Seder Bereshith</i>.</i> “<i>And Jacob swore by the Fear of his father Isaac</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">79</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 31:53.</i> Is there any one who swears by the belief of the Fear of his father? However, it was because Jacob was not yet given strength, and so he swore by the power given to his father, as it is said, <i>And Jacob swore by the Fear of his father Isaac</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">79</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 31:53.</i> And what is this? It is this concerning which Scripture writes, <i>Then the fire of the Eternal fell, and consumed the burnt-offering</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">87</sup><i class="footnote">I Kings 18:38.</i> and it is further written, <i>For the Eternal thy G-d is a devouring fire</i>, etc.”<sup class="footnote-marker">88</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 4:24.</i> Thus far the Midrash. From the words of the Rabbis of this Midrash, we learn that it was for this reason that it does not say here, “and he offered sacrifices to the Eternal,” [but instead it says, “to the G-d of his father Isaac],” because now in Beer-sheba Jacob had already become privileged to possess his own portion [and needed only to bring all Divine attributes into accord towards him],<sup class="footnote-marker">89</sup><i class="footnote">The words in the brackets are from the Commentary of Lvush to the Rekanati on the Torah, who quotes these words of Ramban.</i> as it is said, <i>Thou wilt give truth to Jacob, mercy to Abraham, as Thou hast sworn unto our fathers from the days of old</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">90</sup><i class="footnote">Micah 7:20.</i> It was therefore necessary to explain it now. Thus by the merit of the sacrifices, the G-d of his father Isaac appeared to him <i>in the visions of the night</i><sup class="footnote-marker">91</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 2 here.</i> with an ameliorated Divine attribute of justice. It is this which Scripture says concerning them, <i>in the visions of the night</i>, complementing that which He said, <i>I am G-d, the G-d of thy father</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">92</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 3 here.</i> for He is the G-d of Beth-el Who said to him in Haran, <i>I am the G-d of Beth-el, where thou didst anoint a pillar;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">93</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 31:13.</i> it is He Who is <i>the G-d of thy father</i>. This is the Name and this is the attribute. And He assured him that he should have no fear in Egypt for he will be found righteous in Divine judgment, and he will be redeemed after the affliction. This is the meaning of the Divine promise, <i>And I will also surely bring thee up again</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">94</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 4 here.</i><br>Now the Rabbi [Moshe ben Maimon] has written in the twenty-seventh chapter of the first part of the Moreh Nebuchim (Guide of the Perplexed) concerning Onkelos’ translation of the verse, <i>I will go down with thee into Egypt, and I will also surely bring thee up again</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">94</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 4 here.</i> [which Onkelos rendered here literally]: “I will go down with thee…and I will bring thee up.” And the Rabbi was amazed at the opinion of Onkelos, [namely, that the literal translation should be used], saying that Onkelos had exerted all his effort to remove any implication of G-d’s corporeality from all narratives in the Torah. Accordingly, in the case of any expression found in the Torah implying any mode of motion that refers to G-d, Onkelos ascribed the action to a certain glory that had been created for the occasion, or a manifestation of Divine Providence. Thus he translated <i>And G-d came down</i><sup class="footnote-marker">95</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 19:20.</i> as “and G-d manifested Himself;” <i>I will go down now and see</i><sup class="footnote-marker">96</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 18:21.</i> as “I will manifest Myself now and see.” And if so, why did Onkelos here translate literally, “I will go down”? And so the Rabbi explained that since Scripture said at the outset of the matter, <i>And G-d spoke unto Israel in the visions of the night</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">91</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 2 here.</i> thus indicating that it is an account of what Jacob was told and not what actually took place, Onkelos therefore did not hesitate to literally translate the words as they were addressed to Jacob in the visions of the night, for the words in question represent an account of what Jacob was told, not what actually took place. There is thus a great difference between a communication transmitted in a dream or a vision of the night, or a communication designated as having been made in a vision or manifestation, and a communication given clearly, [not in a dream, such as communications introduced by phrases like these]: “And the word of the Eternal came unto me, saying,” or “And the Eternal spoke unto me, saying.” These are the words of Rabbi Moshe ben Maimon.<br>Similarly he said<sup class="footnote-marker">97</sup><i class="footnote">Moreh Nebuchim I, 48.</i> that Onkelos never translated expressions of “hearing” literally [when the Scriptural references were to G-d], but instead explained them as expressing that a certain matter reached the Creator, or that He accepted a prayer. Thus Onkelos translated <i>the Eternal heard</i><sup class="footnote-marker">98</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 29:33.</i> as “it was heard before the Eternal;” he translated the verse, <i>I will surely hear his crying</i><sup class="footnote-marker">99</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 22:22.</i> as “I will surely accept his complaint.”<br>But if the matter is as the Rabbi [Moshe ben Maimon] said, why does Onkelos shun literal translations of expressions of movement, and also avoid literal expressions of hearing due to his fear that they might indicate corporeality, but he does not in any place shy away from literally expressing “saying,” “speaking” or “calling,” whether the communication was in a dream or manifestation or overt speech, for in every case he translates: “and G-d said,” “G-d spoke,” “and G-d called unto Moses”? These expressions likewise signify corporeality, and Onkelos should have translated, “and it was said from before G-d,” or “and the glory of G-d said,” or “and G-d willed,” as is appropriate in each case, just as the Rabbi has explained<sup class="footnote-marker">100</sup><i class="footnote">Moreh Nebuchim I, 65.</i> with reference to the terms “speaking” and “saying” when they refer to G-d. And why did Onkelos avoid literal translation in the case of “hearing” and did not do so with respect to “seeing,” which he translated as: “and the Eternal saw”?<sup class="footnote-marker">101</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 6:5.</i> And that which the Rabbi has said<sup class="footnote-marker">102</sup><i class="footnote">Moreh Nebuchim I, 48.</i> that “seeing” indicates mental perception as well as the sensation of sight, this applies all the more to “hearing” for it is employed in many places to indicate mental perception and will, such as: <i>And Abram hearkened to the voice of Sarai;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">103</sup><i class="footnote">Above 16:2.</i> <i>Hear the voice of my supplications;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">104</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 28:2.</i> <i>Yea, when ye make many prayers, I will not hear;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">105</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 1:15.</i> <i>And it shall come to pass, if thou shalt hearken diligently unto the voice of the Eternal thy G-d</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">106</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 28:1.</i> And so also, <i>leiv shomei’ah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">107</sup><i class="footnote">I Kings 3:9.</i> (literally: a hearing heart, an understanding heart), and so also in the case of most of [the verses cited by Rabbi Moshe ben Maimon]. So Onkelos should not have been apprehensive of expressions of “hearing” as they only indicate acceptance of a matter by G-d and His being pleased with it, for he does not avoid literal translations of expressions of sight any place, but translates it literally in all cases even when seeing alone is involved. However, where a matter is not conceived by sight alone, but requires attention and discernment, Onkelos renders it as befits the subject. For example, when Scripture says, <i>Because the Eternal hath looked upon my affliction</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">108</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 29:32.</i> [Onkelos rendered it as, “because my affliction is manifested before the Eternal”]. The verse, <i>I have surely seen the affliction of My people</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">109</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 3:7.</i> [was rendered by Onkelos as, “the enslavement of my people is manifest before me,” and the verse], <i>And G-d saw the children of Israel</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">110</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 2:25.</i> [he rendered as, “and the enslavement of the children of Israel was manifest before G-d],” since His seeing them was not just as a matter of perceiving their bodies but of His attention to their situation and His knowledge thereof. This is Onkelos’ method throughout the Torah, and not as the Rabbi’s opinion would have it, as a consquence of which opinion he had to declare [our version of Targum Onkelos] erroneous<sup class="footnote-marker">111</sup><i class="footnote">Ramban refers here to Chapter 48 of the first part of the Moreh Nebuchim mentioned above, in which Rabbi Moshe ben Maimon (Rambam) sets forth the theory that Onkelos always renders “seeing” literally except where it is connected with wrong, injury or violence, in which cases he expresses it as “It was manifest before the Eternal.” Onkelos is thus consistent with the prophetic phrase, <i>Thou canst not look on iniquity</i> (Habakkuk 1:13). However, Rambam mentions that he found three passages which contradict his theory. One is the verse, <i>And the Eternal saw that the wickedness of man was great upon the earth</i>, (above, 6:5), and the other two are mentioned in the following note. In these three cases which are connected with wrong and violence, Onkelos should have expressed “seeing” in the form of “being manifest before the Eternal,” and yet he translated them literally! Rambam then concludes that our version of Onkelos is inaccurate in those three cases! It is this conclusion of Rambam with which Ramban takes issue in the text before us.</i> in [the following three places: the verse mentioned above, namely, <i>And the Eternal saw</i>],<sup class="footnote-marker">101</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 6:5.</i> and two other verses,<sup class="footnote-marker">112</sup><i class="footnote"><i>And G-d saw the earth, and behold it was corrupt</i>, (above, 6:12). <i>And the Eternal saw that Leah was hated</i>, (above, 29:31).</i> which Onkelos translated as, “and He saw,” since these translations do not fit his theory.<br>With reference to expressions of “passing” Onkelos paraphrased and thus translated the expression, <i>And the Eternal passed by before him</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">113</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 34:6.</i> as, “and He caused His Presence to pass before his [Moses’] face.” He did this so that the passing object would be, in accordance with Onkelos’ opinion, something created, as he would not ascribe any expression of motion to the Creator in accordance with what the Rabbi has mentioned.<sup class="footnote-marker">114</sup><i class="footnote">Moreh Nebuchim I, 21.</i> But if this is so, why did Onkelos literally translate the verse, <i>The Eternal thy G-d, He will go over before thee?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">115</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 31:3. In our version of Onkelos, the text reads, “His word will go over.” Ramban’s objection is thus removed.</i> This is a form of motion occurring in a narrative<sup class="footnote-marker">116</sup><i class="footnote">As opposed to “the visions of the night.” See the beginning of the section where Ramban explains this distinction which Rambam makes.</i> and yet Onkelos was not apprehensive about it! Similarly, Onkelos translated the verse, <i>And Israel saw the great hand</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">117</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 14:31.</i> as, “and Israel saw the power of the great hand.” He added the term “power” due to the subsequent expression, <i>that the Eternal did</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">117</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 14:31.</i> yet he left intact the expression, “the great hand” and was not apprehensive and fearful of the term “hand” being ascribed to G-d and did not paraphrase it at all! He did the same in literally translating, <i>written with the finger of G-d</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">118</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 31:18.</i> The Rabbi’s answer<sup class="footnote-marker">119</sup><i class="footnote">Moreh Nebuchim I, 66.</i> that Onkelos thought that “the finger” was a created instrument which, by the will of the Creator, engraved the writing on the tablets, is not the truth. There is the verse, <i>At His right hand was a fiery law unto them</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">120</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 33:2.</i> in translation of which Onkelos wrote, “His right hand,” and he was not apprehensive of “the right hand writing,” that is lest it indicate corporeality, and such is the case also with “the finger” as mentioned above. He furthermore literally translated: <i>Thou stretchest forth Thy right hand</i><sup class="footnote-marker">121</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 15:12.</i> as, “Thou raisest Thy right hand.” So also the verses: <i>Thy right hand, O Eternal, dasheth in pieces the enemy;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">122</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 6.</i> <i>Thy strong hand;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">123</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 3:24.</i> <i>By a mighty hand, and by an outstretched arm;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">124</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 4:34.</i> <i>And My hand take hold on judgment;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">125</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 32:41.</i> <i>The eyes of the Eternal thy G-d are always upon it</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">126</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 11:12.</i> [Onkelos literally translated all of these verses without fear that the terms “hand” and “eyes” might indicate corporeality.] Now in the case of Jacob, the Scriptural narrative begins, <i>And he dreamed, and behold a ladder set up on the earth</i>, etc., and yet Onkelos, fearing corporeality, translated [the verse, <i>And, behold, the Eternal stood beside him</i>],<sup class="footnote-marker">127</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 28:12-13.</i> as “and, behold, the Glory of G-d stood beside him,” and he did not translate literally, “and, behold, the Eternal” although it was in a dream.<sup class="footnote-marker">128</sup><i class="footnote">Rabbi Moshe ben Maimon’s thesis is that the reason Onkelos did not paraphrase the verse, <i>I will go down with thee into Egypt</i>, but translated it literally, is that the narrative begins with a statement that it was in a vision of the night. Ramban questions this thesis, for in the story of the ladder, which is also introduced as a dream, Onkelos avoided possible indications of corporeality, and accordingly he paraphrased the verses.</i> He further translated the expression, <i>And, behold, I am with thee</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">129</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 28:15.</i> as “and, behold, My word will be in thy help,” and did not say literally, “and, behold, I am with thee,” just as he literally translated, “I will go down with thee,” even though the story of the ladder is a statement of what Jacob was told, [not a narrative of what took place], and is completely analogous to the narrative of the dream here. Again, Onkelos literally translated the expression, <i>And I will be with thy mouth</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">130</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 4:12.</i> [even though the story there is not introduced as a vision of the night or a dream], and on the other hand he translated the verse, <i>And He said, Certainly I will be with thee, and this shall be the token unto thee</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">131</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 3:12.</i> as “behold, My word will be with thee.” Furthermore, Onkelos does not always translate literally in the case of dreams. Thus he rendered the verses, <i>And G-d came to Abimelech in a dream of the night</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">132</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 20:3.</i> <i>And G-d came to Laban in a dream</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">133</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 31:24.</i> as “and the word came from before G-d.” Should you say that Onkelos paraphrased it there because he was concerned lest one think that G-d came to them before the dream, and one might thus think that G-d’s appearance actually took place, [this would still not justify his using the expression, “and the word came,”] for in the case of Solomon it is written, <i>In Gibeon the Eternal appeared to Solomon in a dream</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">134</sup><i class="footnote">I Kings 3:5.</i> and yet Jonathan ben Uziel<sup class="footnote-marker">135</sup><i class="footnote">See Note 152 in <i>Seder Noach</i>.</i> translated it as, “G-d revealed Himself to Solomon,” even though, according to Rabbi Moshe ben Maimon, a narrative introduced as a dream is rendered by Onkelos and Jonathan as it was actually said. They find no difficulty in translating such a statement literally, even though the expression connotes corporeality, because since it occurs in a dream, they understand that it is inexact. Thus in the case of Solomon, since the Eternal appeared to him in a dream, it was proper for Jonathan to give a literal account of the occurrence, for since Scripture relates that it was <i>in a dream by night</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">134</sup><i class="footnote">I Kings 3:5.</i> one would himself infer that it was not real but only a dream in which the person dreaming imagined it to be so. [Now since Jonathan did not paraphrase the account of Solomon’s dream, although Onkelos did so in the case of the dreams of Abimelech and Laban, it thus helps to disprove the thesis of Rabbi Moshe ben Maimon that accounts of what occurred in man’s imagination are not paraphrased by the Targum.] Now do not think that Jonathan ben Uziel did this because the term “seeing” in reference to dreams is not found in Aramaic — for the verse, <i>And I saw in my dream</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">136</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 41:22.</i> is indeed translated [in Targum Onkelos] as “I saw,” and in the case of the dream of Nebuchadnezzar, it likewise says in Aramaic, <i>Thou O King, sawest</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">137</sup><i class="footnote">Daniel 2:31.</i><br>And so did Onkelos translate the verse, <i>Your murmurings are not against us, but against the Eternal</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">138</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 16:8.</i> as “but against the word of G-d.” Onkelos thus paraphrased here even though there is no fear or apprehension of corporeality connoted by literal translation. Likewise, he translated <i>And the people spoke against G-d, and against Moses</i><sup class="footnote-marker">139</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 21:5.</i> as, “and the people murmured against the word of G-d.” So also the verses, <i>Between Me and you</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">140</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 9:12.</i> and <i>Between G-d and every living creature</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">141</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 16.</i> were translated by Onkelos as: “between My word and you,” “between the word of G-d and every living creature.” There are many similar examples [of verses which he paraphrased in spite of the fact that there would have been no apprehension of intimating corporeality had he translated literally]. And so also he translated <i>The Eternal watch</i><sup class="footnote-marker">142</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 31:49.</i> as “the word of G-d watch;” <i>G-d is witness</i><sup class="footnote-marker">143</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 50.</i> as “the word of G-d is witness.” Yet there would be no apprehension of corporeality had those expressions been literally translated. Besides, what sense is conveyed here by the expression, “the word of G-d’ watch or witness”? Similarly the verse, <i>Swear unto me here by G-d</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">144</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 21:23.</i> is rendered by Onkelos as “swear unto me by the word of G-d,” although people who swear do not mention, “I swear by the word of G-d.” There are many other such cases in Onkelos, and their secret meaning is known to the learned students [of the mystic lore of the Torah].<br>Likewise, with respect to the term “standing” when applied to G-d, the Rabbi said<sup class="footnote-marker">145</sup><i class="footnote">Moreh Nebuchim I, 28.</i> that Jonathan ben Uziel’s intent was to explain it as meaning “to endure permanently,” and therefore he translated the expression, <i>And His feet shall stand</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">146</sup><i class="footnote">Zechariah 14:4.</i> as “and He will appear in His might.” So also all expressions denoting contact and motion were rendered by him as “the might of G-d.” Yet Onkelos had no apprehension of the term “standing.” and he translated it literally: <i>Behold, I will stand before thee there upon the rock</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">147</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 17:6.</i><br>And concerning that which the Rabbi has said<sup class="footnote-marker">148</sup><i class="footnote">Moreh Nebuchim I, 27.</i> that all expressions denoting any mode of motion are rendered by Onkelos as the revelation of the Divine Presence, or the manifestation of a certain Glory that had been created for the occasion, now Onkelos avoids even literal translation of verses which mention “seeing” the Glory [of G-d, and would certainly oppose using it to denote expressions of motion]. Thus he translates the verse, <i>And the glory of the Eternal appeared unto all the congregation</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">149</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 16:19.</i> as “and the glory of G-d was manifested,” just as he said in translation of the verse, <i>And the Eternal came down</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">150</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 19:20.</i> “and the Eternal manifested Himself,” and did not translate it literally as “and the glory of the Eternal appeared.” He also likewise translates “seeing,” when referring to angels, as “and he manifested himself.”<sup class="footnote-marker">151</sup><i class="footnote">Onkelos, <i>ibid.</i>, 3:2.</i> Now if it is as the Rabbi [Moshe ben Maimon] said<sup class="footnote-marker">148</sup><i class="footnote">Moreh Nebuchim I, 27.</i> that in the case of angels, or manifestation of a certain glory that had been created for the occasion, Onkelos does not hesitate to literally translate expressions denoting corporeality, it would have been proper for him not to avoid expressions of literal “seeing” of angels by man, and should there translate it as “and he appeared,” just as he has literally rendered the verse, <i>For I have seen ‘Elokim’ face to face</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">152</sup><i class="footnote">Above, Verse 31.</i> as “for I have seen an angel of G-d.” Heaven forbid that the Divine Presence or the Glory created for the occasion be anything except the glorious Divine Name, blessed be He, as the Rabbi has expressed himself here<sup class="footnote-marker">148</sup><i class="footnote">Moreh Nebuchim I, 27.</i> and in many chapters of his book. Thus Onkelos translated the expression, <i>If Thy face go not</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">153</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 33:15.</i> as “if Thy Divine Presence go not among us.” Now, other than the glorious Divine Name, blessed be He, Moses did not want a special Glory created to go with him, since the Holy One, blessed be He, had already told him, <i>Behold Mine angel shall go before thee</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">154</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 32:34.</i> and Moses was not pleased with it. He instead wanted that G-d in His own glory should go with him. Also, after G-d heard his plea and told him, <i>I will do this thing also that thou hast spoken</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">155</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 33:17.</i> Moses said, <i>Let the Lord, I pray thee, go in the midst of us</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">156</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 34:9.</i> and this Onkelos rendered as “let now G-d’s Divine Presence go among us.”<sup class="footnote-marker">157</sup><i class="footnote">We thus see that even here, where it is clear from the context that the verse refers to G-d and not an angel, Onkelos does not hesitate to translate “going” literally.</i> He similarly translated the expression, <i>Thou canst not see My face</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">158</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 33:20.</i> “thou cannot see the face of My Divine Presence, for man shall not see Me.” [In translating the verse in the book of Ezekiel, <i>Blessed be the glory of the Eternal from His place</i>,]<sup class="footnote-marker">159</sup><i class="footnote">Ezekiel 3:12.</i> Jonathan ben Uziel said, “Blessed be the glory of the Eternal from the region of His Divine abode.” Now if by this “Glory,” [which is mentioned in the book of Ezekiel] Scripture refers to the Creator in His true essence, analogous to the verse, <i>Show me, I pray Thee, Thy glory</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">160</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 33:18.</i> which the Rabbi has indeed so interpreted,<sup class="footnote-marker">161</sup><i class="footnote">Moreh Nebuchim I, 54 and 64.</i> then how did [Jonathan ben Uziel] in translating the verse mention “the region of His Divine abode” [when the terms “region,” “abode,” etc., indicate corporeality]? And if one would say that the verse in Ezekiel refers to a certain glory that had been created for the occasion, as is the opinion of the Rabbi with respect to the verse, <i>And the glory of the Eternal filled the tabernacle</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">162</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 40:35. Moreh Nebuchim I, 64.</i> and other similar verses, then how did the angels direct their words, “Blessed, etc.,” towards it when he who blesses and prays to a glory created for an occasion is as he who worshipped idols? The teachings of our Rabbis also contain many texts which indicate that the name <i>Shechinah</i> (Divine Presence) is identical with G-d, blessed be He. But all these subjects, [some of which are rendered literally and some of which are paraphrased, are not influenced by a fear of using terms denoting corporeality but rather by secrets] of the Cabala<sup class="footnote-marker">163</sup><i class="footnote">See Note 56 in Introduction to <i>Sefer Bereshith</i>.</i> known to Onkelos and Jonathan ben Uziel, and the secrets thereof are revealed to those who know the mystic lore of the Torah. Thus in the Revelation on Mount Sinai, wherever <i>Elokim</i> is mentioned in that section, Onkelos renders it as “the Glory” or “the Word of G-d,” but when Scripture mentions the Tetragrammaton he does not so render it. All this is done by Onkelos with extraordinary care and wisdom, and I will yet mention<sup class="footnote-marker">164</sup><i class="footnote">See Ramban on Exodus 20:19.</i> this with the help of G-d, blessed be He. Now the reason that Onkelos literally translated the verse, <i>And ‘Elokim’ spoke all these words, saying</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">165</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 20:1.</i> [rather than render it, “and the Glory of G-d spoke,” as he usually does wherever <i>Elokim</i> is mentioned], is that it is said, <i>Face to face the Eternal spoke</i><sup class="footnote-marker">166</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 5:4.</i> <i>unto your whole assembly</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">167</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 19.</i> The student learned [in the mystic lore of the Cabala] will understand.<br>However, the reason why Onkelos here literally translated, <i>I will go down with thee to Egypt</i>, [and did not paraphrase it as “My Glory will go down with thee],” is that he wanted to allude to that which the Rabbis have said:<sup class="footnote-marker">168</sup><i class="footnote">Mechilta Shirah 3. See also Megillah 29a.</i> “When they were exiled to Egypt, the Divine Presence went with them, as it is said, <i>I will go down with thee to Egypt</i>. When they were exiled to Elam, the Divine Presence went down with them, as it is said, <i>And I will set My throne in Elam</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">169</sup><i class="footnote">Jeremiah 49:38.</i> Thus both the verse which speaks of G-d “saying” [namely, <i>And He said, I am G-d, the G-d of thy father, etc</i>.],<sup class="footnote-marker">170</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 3 here.</i> and [the verse which speaks of G-d] “going down,” [namely, <i>I will go down with thee</i>], are alike [for they both refer to the Creator in His true essence], as I have explained above, and therefore he could not, under any circumstances, have translated in any other way, as I have hinted. But there in the case of Jacob’s dream, Onkelos could not have literally translated, “and behold I am with thee,” [and was forced to paraphrase it as, “and My word will be in thy help],”<sup class="footnote-marker">129</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 28:15.</i> because it is written there, <i>And, behold, the Eternal stood beside him</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">171</sup><i class="footnote">28:13. Since the Tetragrammaton (“the Eternal”) represents the attribute of mercy, had Onkelos literally translated Verse 15, “and, behold, I am with thee,” it would have indicated that this attribute would follow Jacob into exile since at the outset of this matter in Verse 13, Scripture uses the Tetragrammaton. Hence Onkelos translated Verse 15 as, ‘and My word will be in thy help,’ which is a reference to the attribute of judgment. (Bei’ur Ha’lvush to Rekanati on the Torah, who quotes the words of Ramban.)</i> The student learned [in the mystic lore of the Cabala] will understand. And due to the fact that Onkelos found the meaning of this verse not to be in line with its plain meaning, he therefore spurned [literally translating the rest of the verse, and rendered it as referring to assistance], and thus he said, “My word will be in thy help,” instead of saying “My word will be with you,” as he said in the case of Moses.<sup class="footnote-marker">131</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 3:12.</i> And may G-d show us wonders in His Torah.

Verse 2

AND HE SAID, JACOB, JACOB. After G-d had told him, <i>Thy name shall not be called any more Jacob, but Israel shall be thy name</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">172</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 35:10.</i> it would be proper that He call him by this glorious name, and so he is indeed mentioned three times in this section.<sup class="footnote-marker">173</sup><i class="footnote">In Verses 1, 2 and 5.</i> However, He called him Jacob in order to hint that now he will not contend with G-d and men and prevail, [as the name Israel indicates],<sup class="footnote-marker">174</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 32:29.</i> but he will be in a house of bondage until He will also bring him up again, since the exile now begins with him. This is the meaning of the verse, <i>And these are the names of the children of Israel who came into Egypt, Jacob and his sons</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">175</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 8 here.</i> for they would come there with the appellation, “children of Israel,” since the children would multiply and increase there and their name and glory would extend. However, he is “Jacob” when descending thereto.<br>The reason why Scripture mentions Er and Onan<sup class="footnote-marker">176</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 12 here.</i> together with <i>the children of Israel who came into Egypt</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">175</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 8 here.</i> [although they had already died, as clearly stated in Verse 12]; is due to a secret which can be known from the words we have already written.<sup class="footnote-marker">177</sup><i class="footnote">See Ramban above, 38:8.</i> The learned student [of the mystic lore of the Cabala] will understand this, as well as the meaning of the entire Verse [12]. Scripture likewise mentioned them among those numbered<sup class="footnote-marker">178</sup><i class="footnote">The intent of the Hebrew text may also be that Scripture likewise mentions them “in the book of Numbers,” thus giving this sentence the same format as Ramban’s next sentence, “And in the book of Chronicles….”</i> in the desert: <i>The sons of Judah: Er and Onan; and Er and Onan died in the land of Canaan. And the sons of Judah after their families were</i>, etc.<sup class="footnote-marker">179</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 26:19-20.</i> And there, in the book of Chronicles, Scripture enumerates them in another count: <i>The sons of Judah: Er, and Onan and Shelah; which were born unto him of Bath-shua the Canaanitess…And Tamar his daughter-in-law bore him Perez and Zerah. All the sons of Judah were five</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">180</sup><i class="footnote">I Chronicles 2:3-4. This is difficult to understand. Since two of his sons died prior to the birth of the youngest two, how does Scripture conclude that they totalled five? Thus there is here also an allusion to that which was referred to above.</i>

Verse 3



Verse 4



Verse 5



Verse 6



Verse 7

AND HIS SONS’ DAUGHTERS. These were Serah, the daughter of Asher, and Jochebed, the daughter of Levi. This is the language of Rashi. But what will Rashi include in the term, <i>his daughters</i>, [which is also plural, although Jacob only had one daughter, Dinah]? Rather, it is the way of Scripture, when mentioning the genealogy of many people, to refer to an individual in the plural form, as for example, <i>And the sons of Dan: Hushim;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">181</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 23 here.</i> <i>And the sons of Palu: Eliab</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">182</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 26:8.</i> The same is true here: “daughters” refer to Dinah. “His sons’ daughters” refers to Serah the daughter of Asher, but Jochebed [Moses’ mother] is not mentioned by Scripture [as being among the persons who went down to Egypt], as it is said, <i>All the souls were threescore and six</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">183</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 26 here.</i> She is, however, hinted at, according to the opinion of our Rabbis.<sup class="footnote-marker">184</sup><i class="footnote">Baba Bathra 123a. See also Ramban, on Verse 15.</i>

Verse 8



Verse 9

Verse 14



Verse 15

THIRTY AND THREE. But in the above enumeration you will find only thirty-two. However, the one whose name is omitted is Jochebed who was born as they entered the border city, as it is said, <i>Jochebed, the daughter of Levi, whom</i> [her mother] <i>bore to Levi in Egypt</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">185</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 26:59.</i> She was born in Egypt, but she was not conceived in Egypt. This is the principle of our Rabbis.<sup class="footnote-marker">184</sup><i class="footnote">Baba Bathra 123a. See also Ramban, next Verse.</i><br>But Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra replied, saying that “this is surprising. For if so, why did Scripture not mention the wonder that befell her, for she gave birth to Moses when she was one hundred and thirty years old?<sup class="footnote-marker">186</sup><i class="footnote">Israel stayed in Egypt two hundred and ten years. Since Moses was eighty years old when he stood before Pharaoh, he was thus born one hundred and thirty years after they entered Egypt.</i> And why did it mention the case of Sarah who gave birth when she was ninety years old? This distress was not yet sufficient for us so that the poets came and composed liturgic poems for the day of <i>Simchath Torah</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">187</sup><i class="footnote">Literally, “Rejoicing of the Law.” On this festival day, which marks the last day of the festival of Succoth, the concluding chapter of the life of Moses is read in the Synagogue. The joyous celebrations on this day are due to the annual completion of the reading of the Torah, as well as to the fact that it is commenced anew.</i> wherein they state, ‘Jochebed, my mother, will be comforted after me,’ [implying that Jochebed survived her son], and thus she was two hundred and fifty years old at the death of Moses!<sup class="footnote-marker">188</sup><i class="footnote">Her age when Moses was born added to Moses’ life span of one hundred and twenty totals two hundred and fifty.</i> Is the proof of the poets for this longevity of Jochebed because Ahijah the Shilonite<sup class="footnote-marker">189</sup><i class="footnote">I Kings 11:29.</i> lived a life of great duration?<sup class="footnote-marker">190</sup><i class="footnote">According to an Agadic tradition, Ahijah the Shilonite was among those who went out of Egypt, and lived to the days of Jeroboam I, king of Israel, a period of about four hundred and fifty years. (Baba Bathra 121b.) On the basis of this tradition, the poets claimed that since longevity was possible for Ahijah, it was possible also for Jochebed, Moses’ mother.</i> [If so, this is not a proof, for his longevity is but] an Agadic tradition or the opinion of a single authority.”<sup class="footnote-marker">191</sup><i class="footnote">The source for Ahijah’s longevity is the Seder Olam, Chapter 1. This book is a chronicle of Biblical times, composed by Rabbi Yosei ben Chalaphtah, a disciple of Rabbi Akiba.</i> These are the words of Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra.<br><i>Now lest he be wise in his own eyes</i><sup class="footnote-marker">192</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 26:5.</i> in contradicting the words of our Rabbis, I must answer him and say that in any case, there is in the matter of Jochebed a great wonder of the hidden miracles<sup class="footnote-marker">193</sup><i class="footnote">See Ramban, above, 17:1.</i> which constitute the foundation of the Torah. Jochebed was Levi’s actual daughter, and not merely his offspring, as it is written, <i>Jochebed, the daughter of Levi, whom</i> [her mother] <i>bore to Levi</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">185</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 26:59.</i> and it is furthermore written, <i>And Amram took himself Jochebed his father’s sister for a wife</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">194</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 6:20.</i> [Thus Amram, Levi’s grandson, married Jochebed, Levi’s daughter.] Now if we would say that Levi begot Jochebed in his younger years, just as he begot all his sons, this would place her birth soon after his descent into Egypt, and she would have been very old at the time of Moses’ birth,<sup class="footnote-marker">186</sup><i class="footnote">Israel stayed in Egypt two hundred and ten years. Since Moses was eighty years old when he stood before Pharaoh, he was thus born one hundred and thirty years after they entered Egypt.</i> at or near the age stated by our Rabbis.<sup class="footnote-marker">195</sup><i class="footnote">In that case the wonder would have been only on the part of Jochebed.</i> And if we would say that he begot her after he resided in Egypt for many years — say, for a period of fifty-seven years — then Levi would have been one hundred years old at Jochebed’s birth, for when he went down to Egypt he was forty-three years<sup class="footnote-marker">196</sup><i class="footnote">Jacob married Leah when he was eighty-four years old. (Bereshith Rabbah 68:5). When Levi, her third son, was born, Jacob was thus eighty-seven. When he stood before Pharaoh, Jacob said that he was one hundred and thirty years old (47:9). Thus Levi was forty-three at that time.</i> of age. In that case, there were two great wonders! [Levi, at the time he begot Jochebed], was as old as Abraham, concerning whom Scripture mentions, <i>Shall a child be born to him who is a hundred years old?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">197</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 17:17.</i> and it is further written, <i>And my lord is old also</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">198</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 18:12.</i> while Jochebed would still have been an elderly woman of seventy-three when Moses was born! And should we further postpone Jochebed’s birth to the end of Levi’s days, the wonder of his begetting a child will be greater than that of Abraham!<br>But I will tell you a true principle, clearly indicated in the Torah. Scripture mentions miracles performed through a prophet and which he previously prophesied, or performed by an angel who is revealed in the course of a Divine mission, but those effected naturally in order to help the righteous or destroy the wicked are not mentioned in the Torah or in the books of the prophets. May this be “hot gold poured into the mouth”<sup class="footnote-marker">199</sup><i class="footnote">Sanhedrin 92b.</i> of this wise man who refuted the words of our Rabbis in the matter of Phinehas<sup class="footnote-marker">200</sup><i class="footnote">In his Commentary to Numbers 25:12, Ibn Ezra brushes aside the tradition that Phinehas is identical with Elijah.</i> and similar matters in many places. Why should Scripture mention hidden miracles when all the foundations of the Torah are hidden miracles. In the entire scope of the Torah there are only miracles, and no nature or custom. All assurances of the Torah are in the form of signs and wonders, as it is not natural that he who has connection with one of the forbidden degrees of marriage or he who eats forbidden fat suffers excision or death.<sup class="footnote-marker">201</sup><i class="footnote">Ramban here refers to death by heavenly punishment. See, for example, Leviticus 20:17.</i> Nor is it by nature that the heavens become as iron<sup class="footnote-marker">202</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 26:19.</i> because we have sowed our fields in the Sabbatical year. Similarly, all the assurances of the Torah concerning those blessings [which will result from our observance of the law], and all the good fortune of the righteous ones because of their righteousness, as well as all the prayers of our king David [in the book of Psalms] and all our prayers, all are founded upon miracles and wonders, except that there is no heralded change in the nature of the world, as I have already mentioned,<sup class="footnote-marker">193</sup><i class="footnote">See Ramban, above, 17:1.</i> and I will yet explain it further,<sup class="footnote-marker">203</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 11.</i> with the help of G-d.<br>I will give you faithful testimony to that which I have said. We know that from the time Israel came into the Land until the birth of our lord David, about three hundred and seventy years elapsed.<sup class="footnote-marker">204</sup><i class="footnote">From the Exodus to the building of the Temple, four hundred and eighty years elapsed (I Kings 6:1). Deduct the forty years spent in the desert and the seventy years of David’s lifespan, and the remainder is three hundred and seventy.</i> These years are to be divided among four generations: Salmon, Boaz, Obed, and Jesse [David’s father],<sup class="footnote-marker">205</sup><i class="footnote">Ruth 4: 21-22.</i> each one being allotted ninety-three years. Thus when they begot children they were all approximately as old as Abraham was when he begot Isaac. Furthermore, each one begot his son in the year of his death, a most unusual thing, since in their era the general span of life was not a hundred years.
