And if one of them begot his son in his younger years, as is usual, the others would have had to be much older than Abraham, and thus the wonder concerning them would be exceedingly great since people in the generation of Abraham lived long, and in the days of David the average lifespan was reduced to a half. And perhaps these four generations lived longer than their contemporaries for it is possible that Salmon was already advanced in years when he entered the Land of Israel. It is for this reason that the masters of Tradition, who are the true Sages, have attributed longevity to Obed,<sup class="footnote-marker">206</sup><i class="footnote">Bereshith Rabbah 96:4: “The Sages have said, Obed lived more than four hundred years.”</i> this being a covert miracle which was done to the ancestor of the kingdom [of the house of David], the son of the righteous one [Ruth], who had come to take refuge under the wings of the Divine Presence.<sup class="footnote-marker">207</sup><i class="footnote">See Ruth 2:12.</i> The Sages similarly mention longevity in connection with Obed’s mother, Ruth.<sup class="footnote-marker">208</sup><i class="footnote">In Baba Bathra 91 b, it is stated that Ruth was still alive in the days of Solomon.</i> Now I have already explained<sup class="footnote-marker">197</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 17:17.</i> that the wonder in the case of Abraham was not as the above-mentioned Sage [Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra] and other masters of the Scriptures have thought.<sup class="footnote-marker">209</sup><i class="footnote">That the wonder was due to Abraham’s advanced age.</i> Abraham begot Isaac seventy-five years before his death, prior to the completion of two-thirds of his lifespan, and in all generations, old age does not affect people until three quarters of their lives have passed, just as the doctors have considered the divisions of life to be: childhood, youth, manhood, and old age. In these generations, when the lifespan is about seventy years, doctors do not consider a person aged until after sixty. Moreover, Abraham begot many children<sup class="footnote-marker">210</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 25: 1-2.</i> forty years after the birth of Isaac, and the wonder is thus manifoldly miraculous! And should we say that G-d caused Abraham to revert to his youthful days, it may be asked why Scripture does not mention this great wonder when it was an open and known miracle which is contrary to nature. Moreover, it is known that in this present generation some men beget children until they are full seventy or eighty years old and more, depending upon the extent to which they retain their natural vitality. Women also have no specific time [for ceasing to conceive], as long as they have their period they can give birth. However, the wonder in the case of Abraham and Sarah, as I explained there,<sup class="footnote-marker">197</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 17:17.</i> was due to the fact that they had not begotten children in their younger years, and now together they begot a child. In the case of Sarah there was an additional wonder, i.e., <i>that the manner of women</i><sup class="footnote-marker">211</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 18:11.</i> had ceased with her, and after this happens, women no longer give birth. Now if Jochebed lived as many years as her father Levi had,<sup class="footnote-marker">212</sup><i class="footnote">One hundred and thirty-seven years (Exodus 6:16).</i> and if her vitality remained with her until near her old age, as is the way of women, it would be no wonder if she gave birth at the time set forth by our Rabbis, [namely, at one hundred and thirty years of age]. It is because G-d wanted to redeem Israel though the brothers [Moses and Aaron], and since the time of the redemption had not yet come, He delayed their birth many years until their mother was old. Nothing is too difficult for the Eternal.<sup class="footnote-marker">213</sup><i class="footnote">See above, 18:14.</i><br>Rabbeinu Shlomo [Rashi] wrote:<sup class="footnote-marker">214</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 26 here.</i> “According to the view that a twin-sister was born with each of Jacob’s sons, we must say that they died before Jacob and his sons went down to Egypt because they are not enumerated here.” There is no necessity for this conclusion, for the Rabbis have said:<sup class="footnote-marker">215</sup><i class="footnote">Bereshith Rabbah 84:19. See also Ramban, above, 38:2.</i> “Rabbi Yehudah says that Jacob’s sons married their sisters.” These twin-sisters were thus the wives of Jacob’s sons, concerning whom Scripture says, <i>besides Jacob’s sons’ wives</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">214</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 26 here.</i> In fact, Rabbi Yehudah arrived at this opinion on the basis of this verse, since if it refers to Canaanitish women what reason is there for Scripture to say, <i>besides Jacob’s sons’ wives</i>, after it had already said, <i>that came out of his loins?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">214</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 26 here.</i> It is only because his sons’ wives were also of those “that came out of his loins” that Scripture refers to them. It does not, however, divulge them here, just as it did not mention them explicitly when they were born together with Jacob’s sons. Furthermore, Scripture mentions here only those who begot children and increased in Egypt, in order to make known the great miracle which was performed in the mighty increase which they effected in Egypt, for at this juncture, they numbered seventy souls. Thus their wives were not counted because a man and his wife are one.

Verse 16



Verse 17



Verse 18

THESE ARE THE SONS OF ZILPAH, etc. 19. THE SONS OF RACHEL JACOB’s WIFE, etc. It is customary for Scripture to first enumerate the sons of the mistresses together, just as it said in the <i>Seder Vayishlach Yaakov</i><sup class="footnote-marker">216</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 35: 23-26.</i> and in the <i>Seder V’eileh Shmoth bnei Yisrael</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">217</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 1: 2-4.</i> or else to enumerate them according to the order of their birth, <i>the firstborn according to his birthright and the youngest according to his youth</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">218</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 43:33.</i> as Scripture did when they were blessed by Jacob in the <i>Seder Vayechi Yaakov</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">219</sup><i class="footnote">See my Hebrew Commentary (p. 295) where the point is made that Ramban refers only to Joseph and Benjamin. Either Scripture mentions them at first together with the sons of Leah, as it did in <i>Seder Vayishlach</i> and in <i>Shmoth</i>, or according to their age, as it did in <i>Vayechi</i>. Ramban is attempting to explain why they are mentioned here after Zilpah’s children.</i> Here, however, because Scripture’s purpose was to enumerate their numbers and to state that with seventy souls they went down to Egypt, it gave precedence to those who were more numerous. This was why Scripture mentioned Rachel among the concubines, and hence it was necessary to mention her with respect, saying, <i>Jacob’s wife</i>, as I have mentioned above.<sup class="footnote-marker">220</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 37:2.</i>

Verse 19



Verse 20



Verse 21



Verse 22



Verse 23



Verse 24



Verse 25



Verse 26



Verse 27



Verse 28



Verse 29

AND HE APPEARED BEFORE HIM. Joseph appeared before his father. <i>And he wept on his neck a good while</i>. The phrase <i>vayeivk od</i> signifies “weeping copiously.” Jacob, however, did not fall upon the neck of his son Joseph, nor did he kiss him. Our Rabbis said that this was because he was reciting the <i>Shema</i>, (the affirmation of G-d’s Unity). This is the language of Rashi. But [according to this interpretation, which says that it was Joseph who fell on his father’s neck and wept], I know of no reason for the statement, <i>And he appeared before him</i>, since it is understood that Joseph appeared before Jacob since he fell upon his neck. Moreover, it is not respectful for Joseph to fall upon his father’s neck. He should rather bow before him or kiss his hands, as it is written, <i>And Joseph brought them out from between his knees, and he fell down on his face</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">221</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 48:12.</i> And at the present moment, it was more fitting that he bow to him [than at the time referred to in the aforementioned verse].<sup class="footnote-marker">221</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 48:12.</i> So also, every term <i>‘od’</i> in Scripture indicates an addition to the original but does not imply copiousness. Thus: <i>He doth not set a stated time ‘od’ for a man</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">222</sup><i class="footnote">Job 34:23.</i> which means, “He sets a stated time for a man in accordance with his transgression, and nothing is added.”<sup class="footnote-marker">223</sup><i class="footnote">We thus see that <i>od</i> can refer to a slight increase.</i><br>The correct interpretation appears to me to be that Israel’s eyes were already slightly dim from age,<sup class="footnote-marker">224</sup><i class="footnote">See further, 48:10.</i> and when Joseph arrived <i>in the carriage of the second in rank</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">225</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 41:43.</i> with a mitre on his head as was the custom of the Egyptian kings, his father did not recognize him. His brothers also had not recognized him.<sup class="footnote-marker">226</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 42:8.</i> Therefore Scripture mentioned that when he appeared before his father, who stared at him and finally recognized him, his father fell on his neck and cried again over him, even as he had continually cried over him to this day when he had not seen him after his disappearance, and then Jacob said, <i>Now let me die, since I have seen thy face</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">227</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 30 here.</i> It is a known matter as to whose tears are more constant: that of an old father who finds his son alive after having despaired of him and having mourned for him, or that of a grown-up son who reigns. Do not be concerned [lest this interpretation be open to question] because Scripture immediately says, <i>And Israel said</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">228</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 30 here.</i> [thus implying that the previous subject is not Israel but Joseph], whereas according to our interpretation Scripture is speaking of Jacob and then mentions his name once again in the following verse. A similar case is found in these verses: <i>And he gathered up all the foods of the seven years</i>, etc.,<sup class="footnote-marker">229</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 41:48.</i> [where Joseph is the subject of the verse, and yet Scripture mentions his name in the succeeding verse], <i>And unto Joseph were born two sons</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">230</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 50.</i> There are constantly many similar places in the Torah and in the other books of Scripture.

Verse 30



Verse 31



Verse 32

AND THE MEN ARE SHEPHERDS, FOR THEY HAVE BEEN KEEPERS OF CATTLE. Joseph told them that they are shepherds but that they do not tend to the cattle of others because even with respect to their own cattle, they have servants and attendants to pasture them. It is only that their wealth consists of cattle. This is the sense of the expression, <i>they have been keepers of cattle</i>, and had wealth, <i>and a very great household</i><sup class="footnote-marker">231</sup><i class="footnote">Job 1:3.</i> by virtue of the great multitude of cattle which they possessed. It was Joseph’s intention to mention them in an honorable way.

Chapter 47



Verse 1



Verse 2



Verse 3



Verse 4

TO SOJOURN IN THE LAND ARE WE COME; FOR THERE IS NO PASTURE FOR THY SERVANTS’ FLOCKS. I wonder about this reason which they told to Pharaoh, for there was also no pasture in Egypt; the famine was as severe in the land of Egypt as it was in the land of Canaan, or even more so, for it was against Egypt that the main decree was directed. Perhaps they said that in the land of Canaan, due to the severity of the famine, people were eating the grass of the field and were not leaving any sustenance for the cattle. However, in the land of Egypt where there is corn, people subsist on that, and thus in Egypt there is a little pasture left. It is possible that in the land of Egypt there was a little pasture in the reedgrass on account of the rivers and the ponds.

Verse 5

THY FATHER AND THY BRETHREN ARE COME UNTO THEE. This introduction is as if to say: “Now I have heard that your father and your brothers have come, and the land of Egypt is before you.” The correct interpretation appears to me to be that Pharaoh said to Joseph: “Your father and your brothers have come to you because they have heard of your glory, and it is upon you that they have cast their burden. See that you treat them well for it is your responsibility and it is within your power.”

Verse 6



Verse 7

AND JACOB BLESSED PHARAOH. This refers to a salutation, as is customary for all who are granted an occasional interview with kings. Thus the language of Rashi. But this does not appear to be so, for it is not royal protocol for a person to greet the king, and the Rabbis have similarly said:<sup class="footnote-marker">232</sup><i class="footnote">Shabbath 89a.</i> “May a servant greet the king?” Instead, it refers to a real blessing which Jacob bestowed upon Pharaoh, for it is customary for aged and pious people who come before kings to bless them with wealth, possessions, honor, and the advancement of their kingdom, even as Scripture says, <i>Let my lord king David live forever</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">233</sup><i class="footnote">I Kings 1:31.</i> Upon his taking leave of Pharaoh, Jacob again blessed him<sup class="footnote-marker">234</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 10 here.</i> in order to take permission to leave. Our Rabbis have said<sup class="footnote-marker">235</sup><i class="footnote">Tanchuma Naso 26, and mentioned here by Rashi.</i> that he blessed him that the Nile might rise at his approach.

Verse 8



Verse 9

FEW AND EVIL HAVE BEEN THE DAYS OF THE YEARS OF MY LIFE. I know no reason for this comment by our aged patriarch. Is it ethical for a person to complain to the king? And what sense is there in saying, <i>and they have not attained unto the days of the years of the life of my fathers?</i> He may yet possibly attain them and live even longer than they did!<br>It appears to me that our father Jacob had turned gray, and he appeared very old. Pharaoh wondered about his age, for most people of his time did not live very long as the lifespan of mankind had already been shortened.<sup class="footnote-marker">236</sup><i class="footnote">See Ramban, above, 5:4.</i> He therefore asked him, “<i>How many are the days of the years of thy life</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">237</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 8 here.</i> as I have not seen a man as aged as you in my entire kingdom?” Then Jacob answered that he was one hundred and thirty years of age, and that he should not wonder at the years he had lived for they are few when compared with the lifespans of his fathers who had lived longer. However, on account of their having been hard years of toil and groaning, he had turned gray and he appeared extremely old.

Verse 10



Verse 11

AND JOSEPH SETTLED HIS FATHER AND HIS BRETHREN AND GAVE THEM A POSSESSION, etc. The meaning thereof is that he settled them in the choicest land and with the possession which he gave them since he did not want them to be as strangers in the land. Thus he bought them houses and gave them <i>an inheritance of fields and vineyards</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">238</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 16:14.</i> This he did with the permission of Pharaoh because they had said, “<i>To sojourn in the land are we come</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">239</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 4 here.</i> not to live, and when the famine will pass we will return to our land.” But Pharaoh said to Joseph, <i>Settle thy father</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">240</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 6 here.</i> meaning that he settle them in the manner of citizens of the land who reside in the land of Goshen.

Verse 12



Verse 13



Verse 14

AND JOSEPH GATHERED UP ALL THE MONEY, etc. Scripture relates this and goes on to complete the subject in this entire section in order to make known Joseph’s excellence <i>in wisdom, in understanding, and in knowledge</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">241</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 31:3.</i> and that he was <i>a faithful man</i><sup class="footnote-marker">242</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 20:6.</i> in that he brought all money into Pharaoh’s house and did not accumulate for himself treasures of money and secret hiding places for wealth in the land of Egypt, or send it to the land of Canaan. Instead, he gave all money to the king who trusted him and purchased the land for him, and even the bodies of the Egyptians. Through this endeavor, he found grace even in the eyes of the people, for it is G-d Who causes those who fear Him to prosper.

Verse 15

AND WHEN THE MONEY WAS ALL SPENT IN THE LAND OF EGYPT, AND IN THE LAND OF CANAAN, ALL THE EGYPTIANS CAME UNTO JOSEPH, etc. Scripture mentions that the money in the land of Canaan had been exhausted because when the Egyptians came before Joseph they reminded him of this, for they said: “Since the money is also exhausted in the land of Canaan, and since they will no longer come to buy food, <i>why should we die in thy presence? For the money is at an end</i>, and you will cause our death in vain, for the food will remain in your hand, and no man shall buy it.”

Verse 16



Verse 17



Verse 18

THEY CAME UNTO HIM IN THE SECOND YEAR. I.e., the second year of the years of the famine. Now although Joseph had said, <i>And there are yet five years when there will be no plowing and sowing</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">243</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 45:6.</i> as soon as Jacob came to Egypt a blessing came with his arrival, and they began to sow and the famine came to an end. And thus we read in the Tosephta of Tractate Sotah.<sup class="footnote-marker">244</sup><i class="footnote">10:9. <i>Tosephta</i> means “addition.” This is a collection of Tannaitic teachings compiled by Rabbi Chiya and Rabbi Oshayah soon after the Mishnah was completed by Rabbi Yehudah Hanasi.</i> Thus the language of Rashi. And it is similarly mentioned in Bereshith Rabbah:<sup class="footnote-marker">245</sup><i class="footnote">89:11.</i> “Rabbi Yosei the son of Rabbi Chanina said that the famine lasted for two years, for when our father Jacob went down to Egypt the famine ceased. When did it return? In the days of Ezekiel, etc.” But if so, then Joseph’s words regarding his interpretation of [Pharaoh’s dream which predicted the seven years of famine] were not fulfilled, and would thus cause people to doubt his wisdom! Perhaps we shall say that the famine continued in the land of Canaan as Joseph had said, but in Egypt our father Jacob went down to the river in the presence of Pharaoh and all of Egypt, whereupon all his people saw that the waters in the Nile rose as he approached it, and thus they knew that G-d’s blessing was due to the prophet’s arrival. In that case, the verse stating, <i>And Joseph sustained his father, and his brethren, and all his father’s household, with bread, according to the want of their little children</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">246</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 12 here.</i> applies to the remainder of the seven years and for as long as his father lived,<sup class="footnote-marker">247</sup><i class="footnote">According to the Tur’s version of Ramban, this passage reads: “applies to the years of plenty of his father’s entire lifespan.”</i> for even after his father’s death, Joseph said, <i>I will sustain you and your little ones</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">248</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 50:21.</i><br>Yet, with all this, I wonder: for if so, then Pharaoh’s dream was not true since it only revealed the decree to him but not what would ultimately become of those seven years! Now I have seen there in the Tosephta of Tractate Sotah:<sup class="footnote-marker">244</sup><i class="footnote">10:9. <i>Tosephta</i> means “addition.” This is a collection of Tannaitic teachings compiled by Rabbi Chiya and Rabbi Oshayah soon after the Mishnah was completed by Rabbi Yehudah Hanasi.</i> “Rabbi Yosei said that as soon as our father Jacob died, the famine reverted to its former condition, etc.” We have further been taught in the Sifre:<sup class="footnote-marker">249</sup><i class="footnote">Sifre Eikev, 38.</i> “<i>And Jacob blessed Pharaoh</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">234</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 10 here.</i> How did he bless him? [His blessing was] that the years of famine should cease. Nevertheless they were completed after Jacob’s death, as it is said, <i>Now therefore fear ye not; I will sustain you</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">248</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 50:21.</i> Now just as ‘sustaining’ mentioned above<sup class="footnote-marker">250</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 45:11. <i>And there I will sustain thee, for there are yet five years of famine</i>.</i> by Scripture refers to years of famine, so also ‘sustaining’ mentioned here<sup class="footnote-marker">248</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 50:21.</i> refers to years of famine. Rabbi Shimon says, ‘It is not a sanctification of G-d’s Name for the words of the righteous to be effective as long as they live, and then to be removed after their death.’ Rabbi Eleazar the son of Rabbi Shimon said, ‘I accept the opinion of Rabbi Yosei rather than that of my father, for it is indeed a sanctification of G-d’s Name for there to be a blessing in the world for the period that the righteous are in the world, and for the blessing to remove from the world when they leave.’” Thus far the text of the Tosephta. Thus the remaining five years of the famine were completed.<br>The opinion of Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra is that these two years, [recounted in Verses 14-20, during which the Egyptians gave their money and cattle to Joseph in exchange for food], occurred after Jacob had come to Egypt, [and since there were two years of famine before he came to Egypt, this accounts for four of the seven years of famine]. And Ibn Ezra wrote as follows: “We find in homiletic texts of the Rabbis that the famine was removed by the merit of Jacob. It is also possible that there were three more years of famine, but that they were not as severe as the first four years which had passed.” But Ibn Ezra’s words are not at all correct. The account of the dream and its interpretation make all seven years alike, and, had it been as he said, Scripture would have mentioned the different nature of these three last years.<br>In line with the plain meaning of Scripture, Joseph gathered up all the money that was found in the land of Egypt and in the land of Canaan during a period of five years, and he brought it to Pharaoh, for how is it possible for the money and cattle to be exhausted in one year? Rather, the money sufficed them for the entire five years, as is the usual way of the world.<sup class="footnote-marker">251</sup><i class="footnote">In a time of famine, people conserve money and make it last for a long period of time.</i> Now since nothing was initiated, and no change of any kind occurred during all these years, Scripture relates nothing about them except, <i>And Joseph gathered up all the money</i>, etc.<sup class="footnote-marker">252</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 14 here.</i> When the money was exhausted, Scripture relates that they came to Joseph — this was in the sixth year of the famine — and he gave them bread in exchange for their cattle. He fed them with bread only to the extent of sustaining them, but not to satiety. <i>And when that year was ended</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">253</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 18 here.</i> in which he had vowed to them that he would feed them with bread in exchange for their cattle—which was the sixth year—<i>they came unto him the second year</i>, [i.e., the year following the sixth year of famine being discussed], and they told him that he should purchase them and their land for the bread which he will feed them during that seventh year, and since the land will then belong to Pharaoh, he should give them seed so that the land will not be desolate, for they knew that when the seven years of famine will be completed, they will have planting and reaping. The verse stating, <i>And Joseph sustained his father…with bread, according to the want of their little ones</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">246</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 12 here.</i> thus means that he furnished them with bread sufficient for their needs during the famine, as the expression, <i>according to the want of their little ones</i>, indicates.

Verse 19

BUY US AND OUR LAND. Now they said to him that he should also purchase their bodies as servants for Pharaoh, and thus did Joseph say, <i>Behold, I have bought you this day and your land</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">254</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 23 here.</i> However, Scripture records, <i>And Joseph bought all the land of Egypt for Pharaoh; for the Egyptians sold every man his field</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">255</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 20 here.</i> but it does not say that he bought their bodies, only the land. The reason for it is that the Egyptians told Joseph that he should purchase them as servants to perform the king’s business as he pleases. But Joseph wanted to buy only the land, and he made a condition with them that they work on it forever, thus becoming Pharaoh’s family tenants. Afterwards he said to them, “<i>Behold, I have bought you this day and your land for Pharaoh</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">254</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 23 here.</i> not as servants as you told me, but you will belong to him with the land. Now it is proper that the king, who is now lord of the land, take four parts of the harvest and that you take the remaining fifth, but I will deal kindly with you in that you will take the portion due to the owner of the land, and Pharaoh will take the portion due the tenant. However, you will be sold to him in that you will not be able to leave the fields.” This is the meaning of that which they vowed to him, <i>And the land will not be desolate</i><sup class="footnote-marker">256</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 19 here.</i> meaning that it will never be desolate. For this reason they said to Joseph, “<i>We have found favor in the sight of my lord</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">257</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 25 here.</i> for you have been lenient with us by permitting us to take four parts of the harvest so that we may use them to live, <i>and we will be Pharaoh’s servants</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">257</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 25 here.</i> as we have vowed, in that we will work the ground in accordance with his will.”<br>Vayechi

Verse 20



Verse 21



Verse 22



Verse 23



Verse 24



Verse 25



Verse 26



Verse 27



Verse 28

AND JACOB LIVED IN THE LAND OF EGYPT SEVENTEEN YEARS. I have already mentioned<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 43:14.</i> that Jacob’s descent into Egypt alludes to our present exile at the hand of the “fourth beast,”<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">In Daniel’s vision concerning the Four Kingdoms, the fourth beast symbolizes Rome. See Daniel 7:7, also Note 8 in <i>Seder Vayeitzei</i>.</i> which represents Rome. [There are many parallels,] for it was Jacob’s sons themselves who, by the sale of their brother Joseph, caused their going down there. Jacob, moreover, went there on account of the famine, thinking to find relief with his son in the house of his son’s friend, for Pharaoh loved Joseph and considered him as a son. It was their hope to ascend from there as soon as the famine would cease in the land of Canaan, just as they said, <i>To sojourn in the land we have come, for thy servants have no pasture for their flocks, for the famine is heavy in the land of Canaan</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 47:4.</i> But then they did not come up, but instead the exile prolonged itself upon Jacob and he died there, and his bones ascended from there accompanied by all the elders and courtiers of Pharaoh, who instituted severe lamentation for him. Our relationship with our brothers Rome and Edom is similar. We ourselves have caused our falling into their clutches, as they<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">The Hasmonean rulers during the Second Temple era. See Abodah Zarah 8b.</i> made a covenant with the Romans, and Agrippa, the last king during the Second Temple, fled to them for help. It was due to famine that Jerusalem was captured by the Romans, and the exile has exceedingly prolonged itself over us, with its end, unlike the other exiles,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">It was known that the Babylonian Exile would last for a period of seventy years, (Jeremiah 25:12; II Chronicles 36:21). There was also a terminus known for the Egyptian Exile, (above 16:13).</i> being unknown. We are in it as the dead, who say, “Our bones are dried up, we are completely cut off.”<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">See Ezekiel 37:11.</i> But in the end they will bring us from all the nations as <i>an offering to the Eternal</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 66:20.</i> and they will be in deep sorrow as they will behold our glory, and we will see the vengeance of the Eternal. <i>May He raise us, that we may live in His presence</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">Hosea 6:2.</i>

Verse 29

AND WHEN THE DAYS OF ISRAEL DREW NEAR TO DIE. This means when the time for Israel’s death approached, which was during the last year of his life,<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">Ramban’s intent is to say that the verse does not refer to Jacob’s day of death but to the general period in his life when he felt his powers beginning to ebb.</i> he called his son Joseph. The purport of it is that he felt exhaustion and undue weakness in himself, but he was not sick. Rather, he knew that he would not live much longer, and therefore he called his son Joseph. Now after Joseph returned to Egypt [from visiting with his father who lived in Goshen, Jacob] became ill, whereupon Joseph was informed, and he came before him with his two sons so that he [Jacob] would bless them.<br>In a similar sense is the verse, <i>Now the days of David drew near that he should die</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">I Kings 2:1. There too the sense of the verse is that this occurred some time before David’s death.</i> and there it says, <i>I go the way of all the earth</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 2.</i> [which clearly indicates that the meaning of the first verse is] that David knew in his heart that his end was approaching.

Verse 30



Verse 31

SWEAR UNTO ME. AND HE SWORE UNTO HIM. Jacob did not suspect that his righteous and beloved son would disobey his father’s command and renege on the matter which he had promised him by saying, <i>I will do according to thy words</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 30 here.</i> But Jacob did so in order to strengthen the matter in the eyes of Pharaoh, as perhaps he might not give Joseph permission to leave him, and he would instead say to him, “Send your brothers and your servants, and they will bring him up there.” It may be that Pharaoh would want the prophet<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">Jacob. — Rashi quotes Hilchoth Gedoloth in Megillah 14 a that Jacob was one of the forty-eight prophets that arose in Israel.</i> to be buried in his country as an honor and privilege to them. It was for this reason that he made him swear for it would not then be proper for him to force Joseph to violate his oath, and Joseph too would feel more obligated to fulfill his father’s wish on account of the oath. Such indeed was the case, as Pharaoh said, <i>Go up, and bury thy father, as he made you swear</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">50:6.</i>

Chapter 48



Verse 1



Verse 2



Verse 3



Verse 4



Verse 5



Verse 6

AND THE CHILDREN THAT WERE BORN TO YOU AFTER THEM. “If you beget any more children, they will not be numbered among my sons, but they will rather be included among the tribes of Ephraim and Menasheh. Nor shall they have a name amongst the tribes as far as inheritance in the Land of Israel is concerned.” Now even though the Land of Israel was divided according to the number of persons, as it is written, <i>To the more thou shalt give the more inheritance</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 26:54.</i> and each person received an equal share except for the first-born, who received a double share,<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 21:17.</i> nevertheless only these sons were designated as “tribes.” This is the language of Rashi.<br>Now this is not correct, for if so,<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">If, as Rashi says, Joseph’s designation as firstborn meant only that Joseph’s two sons shall be counted as separate tribes, but not that they shall receive a double share in the Land, then it follows that, etc.</i> then Jacob’s granting of the birthright to Joseph was just nominal, its only effect being that Joseph’s sons would be called “tribes,” whereas the verse states, <i>in their inheritance</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">At the end of the verse before us: <i>And the children that were born to you after shall be counted to you; they shall be called after the name of their brethren ‘in their inheritance.’</i> This indicates that the two sons of Joseph were to be given the extra right of the firstborn in the matter of inheritance.</i> In the <i>Gemara</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">Horayoth 6b.</i> the Sages have said: “I have likened Ephraim and Menasheh to Reuben and Simeon with respect to the matter of inheritance, but not with respect to other matters,”<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">As, for example, the case of a Sin-offering which is brought by the great Sanhedrin for an erroneous decision, followed by <i>most of the tribes</i> even though they did not constitute an actual majority of the entire population. In that case Ephraim and Menasheh are considered part of the tribe of Joseph.</i> as is stated in Tractate Horayoth.<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">Horayoth 6b.</i> Our Rabbis have mentioned in many places<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">Baba Bathra 123a.</i> that Joseph was the first-born as far as inheritance was concerned, and that he received a double share in the Land, as is the rule of every first-born,<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 21:17.</i> but not that his being first-born consisted merely of his sons being called “tribes,” as the Rabbi [Rashi] would have it.<br>From this we further learn that the Land was not divided among all the tribes of Israel according to their populations for if so, what was the significance of this primogeniture with respect to inheritance? If we would say it meant that each and every individual offspring of Joseph was given double that of each person of all other tribes, this is not mentioned at all in Scripture, and we do not find Jacob giving the birthright to Joseph except by what he said here, <i>As Reuben and Simeon shall they be to me,</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 5 here.</i> and based upon this, Scripture states, <i>His</i> [Reuben’s] <i>birthright was given to the sons of Joseph the son of Israel</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">I Chronicles 5:1.</i> If so, then Ephraim and Menasheh were fully considered as two tribes, and it was this which constituted Joseph’s birthright, and the words of the Sages indeed corroborate this everywhere.<br>Thus the matter is not at all as the Rabbi<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">Rashi. Rashi’s premise that the Land was divided according to population is disputed by Ramban. Since, according to Ramban, each tribe received an equal portion, he proceeds to differ with Rashi and says that Joseph received twice as much land as any other tribe since Ephraim and Menasheh were considered separate tribes.</i> stated it. Instead, the Land of Israel was divided according to tribes. They made twelve equal parts of it, with Simeon, the least populous of the tribes, taking a share equal to that of Judah, the most populous of the tribes, and thus, Ephraim and Menasheh took exactly the same amount of land as Reuben and Simeon. This is the conclusion of the <i>Gemara</i> in the chapter, <i>Yesh Nochalin</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">Baba Bathra 121b. <i>Yesh Nochalin</i> (“There are some that inherit,”) the eighth chapter of that tractate, deals with all problems of personal inheritance, as well as with the whole range of problems connected with the original division of the Land by Joshua.</i> Scripture also states, <i>Ye shall divide the land for inheritance according to the twelve tribes of Israel, Joseph receiving two portions</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">Ezekiel 47:13.</i> So too does Onkelos say,<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote">In translating the blessing bestowed upon Joseph by Jacob. Further, 49:22.</i> “Two tribes shall come forth from his sons. They shall receive <i>chulka ve’achsanta</i> (portion and inheritance),” which means that they shall be equal to the other tribes with respect to inheritance received. Now <i>chulka</i> (portion) refers to the extra share of the first-born, and <i>achsanta</i> (inheritance) refers to ordinary inheritance. In the verse stating, <i>To the more thou shalt give the more inheritance, and to the fewer thou shalt give the less inheritance</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 26:54. This verse, which seems to indicate that the Land was divided according to population, as Rashi taught, is explained by Ramban as referring to the internal division within each tribe.</i> Scripture refers to the paternal families mentioned there in the chapter.<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verses 8-50.</i> Scripture is stating that the tribe divides its share of the land among the paternal families that left Egypt by giving a larger portion to a more populous family and a smaller portion to a less populous family, with the dead becoming heirs of the living, as is explained in the Sifre<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">Sifre Pinchas 132. See also Ramban on Numbers 26:54.</i> and is mentioned by Rashi in the <i>Parshah</i> of <i>Pinchas</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">Rashi, <i>ibid.</i></i> Thus the general principle with respect to Joseph was that he was the first-born as regards inheritance, and if, as mentioned in the <i>Gemara</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">Baba Bathra 121b. <i>Yesh Nochalin</i> (“There are some that inherit,”) the eighth chapter of that tractate, deals with all problems of personal inheritance, as well as with the whole range of problems connected with the original division of the Land by Joshua.</i> the land was divided according to the number of tribes, they gave the children of Joseph portions equal to those of Reuben and Simeon.<br>And even if we were to say that the land was divided according to the number of persons, as is apparent from the verse,<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote"><i>To the more thou shalt give the more inheritance</i>, etc. (Numbers 26:54.)</i> then we would say that they gave them double portions commensurate with their numbers — an ordinary share as large as all the other people, and a second portion for the birthright. In that case, the meaning of Jacob’s words, <i>As Reuben and Simeon shall they be to me</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 5 here.</i> is that they should receive as many shares as twice their number of people. But that Joseph should be as the other tribes with respect to inheritance, with the birthright consisting of his two sons being called “tribes,” as the Rabbi<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote">Rashi. In his commentary to Numbers 26:54, Ramban further discusses this problem at great length.</i> stated, this is impossible under any circumstance.

Verse 7

AND I BURIED HER THERE. In Rashi’s commentary it is written, “And I did not transport her for burial even to Bethlehem to bring her into the Land.”<br>Now I do not know the meaning thereof. Was Rachel buried outside of the Land? Forbid it! She died within the Land, and she was buried there, just as it says here in the <i>parshah: Rachel died by me in the land of Canaan</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote">In the verse before us.</i> And there in the narrative of her death it is still more clearly written, <i>And Jacob came to Luz, which is in the land of Canaan — the same is Beth-el</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 35:6.</i> and it is further stated, <i>And they journeyed from Beth-el and there was still some way to come to Ephrath</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 16.</i> and Rachel died on the way between Beth-el and Bethlehem Ephratha in the Land of Israel.
AND I BURIED HER THERE. “Now I know that there is some resentment in your heart against me [for not having brought her into the city]. But you should know that I buried her there by the word of G-d, that she might help her children when Nebuzaradan<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote">Chief general of Nebuchadnezzar, king of Babylon, who destroyed the city of Jerusalem, burned the Temple, and led the people into captivity (II Kings 25:8-21).</i> would exile them,” for when they passed along that road, Rachel came forth from her grave and stood by her tomb beseeching mercy for them, as it is said, <i>A voice is heard in Ramah, lamentation and bitter weeping, Rachel weeping for her children</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote">Jeremiah 31:15.</i> and the Holy One, blessed by He, answered her, <i>Thy work shall be rewarded … and the children shall return to their own border</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verses 16-17.</i> This is the language of Rashi.<br>Now in any case there should be some allusion in Scripture to this interpretation which is stated in this Agadah. Perhaps this is alluded to in the expression of the verse, <i>She died by me … in the way … And I buried her in the way</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote">The second <i>baderech</i> (in the way) is unnecessary except as an allusion to “the way” which Rachel’s children were destined to use when they went into captivity. (Bachya. See my Hebrew commentary on Ramban, p. 261.)</i> that is to say, “She died on the road which her children would pass, and I buried her there for her advantage.” She did not die on the road, but in Ramah,<sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote">See Ramban, above, 35:16.</i> a city in the land of Benjamin, and there she was buried. [Thus, according to the Midrash, Scripture is implying that] she died on the road which her children were destined to pass in the future, as Scripture does not fully explain future events but only alludes to them in a general manner.<br>In line with the plain meaning of Scripture, it is likewise understood that Jacob spoke to Joseph in an apologetic vein so that when he discerned his father’s wish to be buried in the cave of Machpelah, Joseph should not be angered about his failure to bury his mother there just as he buried Leah there. It was for this reason that Jacob told him that she died in the land of Canaan, and she was not buried outside of the Land in the manner in which an Egyptian burial would befall Jacob. Furthermore, she died on the road suddenly, and he could not bury her in the cave of Machpelah for how could he leave his children and his flocks on the road and hurry with her body to the cave of Machpelah? And where could he find doctors and medicines to embalm her? This is the meaning of the word <i>alai</i> (by me) [in the verse, <i>Rachel died by me</i>]. Even though the cave of Machpelah is but a half-day’s distance from the place of her death, Jacob was heavily laden with much cattle and family, and he would not arrive there for many days. Thus he did indeed spend many days on that road until he came to his father. Our Sages have further taught:<sup class="footnote-marker">42</sup><i class="footnote">Moed Katan 27a.</i> “The bier of a woman may never be set down, out of respect.”<br>Now it is my opinion that these are but words of apology as Joseph already knew that Rachel died on the road and was buried in the Land, and that honor was paid to her when she died. But the reason Jacob did not transport Rachel to the cave of Machpelah was so that he should not bury two sisters there,<sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote">For being married concurrently to two sisters was later prohibited by the Torah (Leviticus 18:18). See also Ramban above, pp. 330-2.</i> for he would be embarassed before his ancestors. Now Leah was the one he married first, and thus her marriage was permissible, while he married Rachel out of his love for her and because of the vow he made to her.<sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote">Since he married her while already married to Leah, the wedding to Rachel would have been forbidden according to the Torah’s later prohibition. Hence her burial place could not be in the cave of Machpelah. See my Hebrew commentary, p. 262.</i>

Verse 8



Verse 9

WHOM G-D HATH GIVEN ME HERE. It was really not necessary for Joseph to inform his father that his two sons were born to him in Egypt since when Joseph left him he had no wife and children, and Jacob himself had previously said to him, <i>Thy two sons, who were born unto thee in the land of Egypt</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">45</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 5 here. Why then was it necessary for Joseph to tell his father, <i>They are my sons, whom G-d hath given me here?</i></i> It appears to me that the meaning of the word <i>bazeh</i> (here) is “in this matter concerning which you have spoken,” i.e., “G-d gave them to me before you came to Egypt to me, and they are the ones concerning whom you have said that they are yours.”<sup class="footnote-marker">46</sup><i class="footnote">See Verse 5 here.</i> A similar use of the word <i>bazeh</i> is found in the verse, <i>In this way (‘u’bazeh’) the maiden came to the king</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">47</sup><i class="footnote">Esther 2:13. Meaning that she came in this manner specified above. (<i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 12).</i> Now Joseph said, <i>G-d hath given me</i>, meaning that “G-d had performed miracles for me until the king gave me this wife, and I have these children from her.”

Verse 10



Verse 11



Verse 12



Verse 13



Verse 14



Verse 15

AND HE BLESSED JOSEPH, AND SAID. The meaning of this verse<sup class="footnote-marker">48</sup><i class="footnote">The verse begins by stating that Jacob blessed Joseph, and the blessing that follows refers only to his sons. Ramban is attempting to resolve this difficulty.</i> is that in order to bless Joseph, out of his love for him, he blessed his sons. Scripture is relating that Joseph had no other children and his entire blessing was inherent in the blessing of these boys. It may be that [the blessing here was directed at Joseph himself, stating that] the other children who will be born to him in the future<sup class="footnote-marker">49</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 6 here.</i> shall be called by the name of their brothers and be blessed with their blessing.<br>In my opinion this latter interpretation is correct since the prophet Jacob said, <i>And the children that were born (‘holad’to’)</i><sup class="footnote-marker">50</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Holad’to</i> is in the past tense and means “were born to you.” Ramban will explain that Jacob’s words are to be understood as if they were in the future tense: “And the children that <i>will be born to you</i> after them shall be thine.” Joseph thus had other children besides Ephraim and Menasheh, whom Scripture does not record, as they were counted among the tribes of his first sons.</i> <i>after them, shall be thine</i>, and his word would not be in vain.<sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote">As it would be if we interpret the verse literally as referring to the past for Joseph did not as yet have any children other than Ephraim and Menasheh.</i> However, Joseph did beget children after that, just as is the opinion of Onkelos, who translated: “And the children that you <i>will beget</i> after them.” And thus, <i>asher holad’to</i> is a past tense replacing a future, just as in the verse, <i>Which I took out of the hand of the Amorite</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">52</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 22 here. Here again, <i>lakachti</i> (I took) is to be understood as if it were in the future tense.</i> and many additional verses besides. Even in line with the literal interpretation of Scripture it would appear that Joseph had children that he had begotten after his father came to him in Egypt. This is obvious from the fact that Jacob found it necessary to elaborate rather than say, “And now thy sons, Ephraim and Menasheh, who were born to thee, shall be mine as Reuben and Simeon, and the children that will be born shall be thine.” This is the reason why Scripture states, <i>And unto Joseph were born two sons before the year of famine came</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">53</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 41:50.</i> since after the famine additional children were born to him, but Scripture does not mention them as there is no need for us to know of them [since they were absorbed into the tribes of Ephraim and Menasheh].
THE G-D, BEFORE WHOM MY FATHERS, ABRAHAM AND ISAAC, DID WALK, THE G-D WHO HATH BEEN MY SHEPHERD ALL MY LIFE LONG UNTO THIS DAY. The prophet<sup class="footnote-marker">54</sup><i class="footnote">Jacob. Ramban is here explaining the double use of <i>Elokim</i> (G-d) in this blessing: <i>The G-d before Whom … the G-d who hath been my shepherd</i>.</i> calls upon the G-d of his fathers Who [has] the greatness and the power and Who did great and tremendous things for them, and [after that he refers to Him in a synonymous way and] he calls upon the true G-d, Who had been his shepherd all his life.<br>It is possible that the word <i>haro’eh</i> (shepherd) — in the phrase, <i>Who hath been my shepherd</i> — is derived from the word <i>rei’ah</i> (friend), as in the verse, <i>Thine own friend (‘rei’acha’), and thy father’s friend, forsake not</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">55</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 27:10.</i> for in that attribute there is peace and friendship. Do not find difficulty with the expression, <i>all my life unto this day</i>, in connection with that which we have written on the verse, <i>And he offered sacrifices unto the G-d of his father Isaac</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">56</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 46:1. The difficulty is that the verse here indicates that the attribute of peace was forever directing Jacob’s life, while in the verse above (46:1) Ramban explained that this attribute did not come into his life until that time. (Tziyoni. See my Hebrew commentary, p. 263.)</i> for from his very inception He did indeed lead him in the true path, but His attribute of truth was not brought to bear upon him completely until he returned to the land of his ancestors as he was outside of the Land, and also because he was constrained to conduct himself in a crafty manner towards Laban, and that was not the path of truth.

Verse 16

AND LET MY NAME BE CALLED ON THEM. Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra said that it means that all Israel be called by the name Ephraim,<sup class="footnote-marker">57</sup><i class="footnote">As in the verse: <i>Is Ephraim a darling son unto me?</i> (Jeremiah 31:19), the reference there being to all Israel.</i> just as they are called “the children of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob.”<br>This is not correct for Scripture uses the word <i>bahem (on them)</i>, [thus referring to both Ephraim and Menasheh], and they were not called by the name of Menasheh. But perhaps this is because they were called <i>the house of Joseph</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">58</sup><i class="footnote">Zechariah 10:6. <i>And I will help the house of Joseph</i>.</i><br>The correct interpretation though is that their race and their name will exist forever, and the name of Abraham, Isaac and Jacob will forever be upon them.

Verse 17

IT DISPLEASED HIM. Perhaps Joseph loved Menasheh more on account of his being the first-born. Hence it displeased him. The correct interpretation in my opinion is that he thought that his father had made a mistake concerning them, and if his blessing will be without true knowledge it will never be fulfilled upon them as it will not have been done with the proper <i>Ruach Hakodesh</i> (holy spirit). But when his father told him, <i>I know it, my son, I know it</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">59</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 19 here.</i> he was reconciled.

Verse 18



Verse 19



Verse 20

AND HE BLESSED THEM THAT DAY. The meaning of <i>that day</i> is that since Joseph had urged him to give Menasheh precedence, the verse declares that Jacob did not wish to remove his right hand from Ephraim’s head to that of Menasheh. Moreover, he expressly reiterated on that occasion, in Joseph’s presence, when he blessed them by saying, <i>As Ephraim and Menasheh. And he put Ephraim before Menasheh</i> in all his blessings.
BY THEE SHALL ISRAEL BLESS. Jacob addressed this to Joseph. It means that the nation of Israel will bless with your children and say to those being blessed, <i>God make thee as Ephraim and Menasheh</i>.

Verse 21



Verse 22

MOREOVER I HAVE GIVEN TO THEE ONE PORTION ABOVE THY BRETHREN. After he had blessed Joseph’s children and made them two tribes, he returned to Joseph and said to him: “<i>Behold, I die; but G-d will be with you</i><sup class="footnote-marker">60</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 21 here.</i> in exile in order to save you from all trouble, and you will increase and multiply exceedingly, and He will bring you back to the land of your fathers to inherit it. I have already given you the one portion in my power to bestow — namely, the portion of the birthright — to be yours above that of your brothers, right from the day that <i>I took it out of the hand of the Amorite with my sword and with my bow</i>.” All this is a conciliation to Joseph and a manifestation of his love for him, for he informed him that he gave him the birthright, meaning that his sons will henceforth be blessed by becoming two tribes, also in the banners which were assigned in the desert,<sup class="footnote-marker">61</sup><i class="footnote">See Numbers, Chapter 2.</i> and in the dedication of the Tabernacle by the princes of the tribes.<sup class="footnote-marker">62</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Chapter 7.</i> He also gave him his portion in the inheritance which he would acquire when the children of Israel will conquer the Land by sword and bow and war. Jacob thus told him: “I have done for you all the good which I was able to do for you as long as it was in my power to do it.” Jacob’s right in the Land was but one portion for he had no right to divest any of his sons of his inheritance. Only the birthright was his to give to whomever he pleased, and it was to Joseph that he gave it.
OUT OF THE HAND OF THE AMORITE. The meaning of this is that Israel first took the Land from the hand of the Amorite. Sichon and Og were two Amorite kings, and the first great war in the conquest of the Land took place between the children of Joseph and the Amorites. This was the war of Joshua<sup class="footnote-marker">63</sup><i class="footnote">Joshua belonged to the tribe of Ephraim, Joseph’s son. See Numbers 13:8, and 16.</i> with the Amorites, and it was in the course of the war with them that the great miracle took place, as it is written, <i>Then spoke Joshua to the Eternal in the day when the Eternal delivered up the Amorites before the children of Israel</i>, etc.<sup class="footnote-marker">64</sup><i class="footnote">Joshua 10:12.</i> And it was out of the hand of the Amorites that the children of Joseph took their portion and inheritance in the Land, as it is written, <i>And the children of Machir the son of Menasheh went to Gilead, and took it, and dispossessed the Amorites that were there</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">65</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 32:39.</i> The children of Ephraim likewise inherited in the territory of the Amorites, as it is written, <i>But the Amorites were resolved to dwell in Har-cheres, in Ayalon, and in Shaalbin; yet the hand of the house of Joseph prevailed, so that they became tributary</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">66</sup><i class="footnote">Judges 1:35.</i>
WITH MY SWORD AND WITH MY BOW. The meaning thereof is that the Land was captured by them only through the sword and bow. This alludes to that which Scripture states, <i>There was not a city that made peace with the children of Israel, save the Hivites the inhabitants of Gibeon; they took all in battle. For it was of the Eternal to harden their hearts, to come against Israel in battle, that they might be utterly destroyed</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">67</sup><i class="footnote">Joshua 11:19-20.</i> He attributes the sword and bow to himself<sup class="footnote-marker">68</sup><i class="footnote">Saying, <i>with ‘my’ sword and with ‘my’ bow</i>.</i> for it was his merit which waged war for them and fought on their behalf, not they themselves, even as the verse states it, <i>For not by their own sword did they get the land in possession, neither did their own arm save them, but Thy right hand, and Thine arm, and the light of Thy countenance, because Thou wast favorable unto them</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">69</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 44:4.</i> This is a reference to the merit of the patriarchs, for by way of the truth,<sup class="footnote-marker">70</sup><i class="footnote">The teaching of the Cabala.</i> <i>Thy right hand</i> [is a reference to the merit of] Abraham, <i>Thine arm</i> to that of Isaac, and <i>the light of Thy countenance</i> to that of Jacob.<br>It further appears reasonable to me that Jacob did as the prophets later on were wont to do. He inclined his hand with a sword towards the land of the Amorites and cast arrows there to symbolize that the land would be captured by his children, even as Elisha did: <i>And he laid his hands upon the king’s hands, and Elisha said, Shoot; and he shot</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">71</sup><i class="footnote">II Kings 13:16-17.</i> Now even though Scripture does not relate it here, it is alluded to in this verse. It is possible that this is the meaning of Jacob’s saying, <i>lakachti</i> (I took),<sup class="footnote-marker">72</sup><i class="footnote">This explains the use of the past tense “I took,” although the land was not actually captured until the time of Joshua.</i> for from that moment on the Land was taken for his sons.

Chapter 49



Verse 1

IN THE END OF DAYS. These are the days of the Messiah, for Jacob alludes to him in his words, even as he said, <i>Until Shiloh come, and his be the obedience of peoples</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">73</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 10 here.</i> Now our Rabbis have said<sup class="footnote-marker">74</sup><i class="footnote">Pesachim 56a.</i> that Jacob wished to reveal the end of Israel’s exile, but the <i>Shechinah</i> (the Divine Presence) departed from him. Thus in the opinion of all scholars, <i>the end of days</i> is a reference to the days of the Messiah.

Verse 2



Verse 3

REUBEN MY FIRSTBORN THOU ART.<sup class="footnote-marker">75</sup><i class="footnote">This is the order of the Hebrew words: <i>Reuven b’chori atah</i>. Ramban will transpose the order of the words for the purpose of deriving the meaning of the verse.</i> The sequence of this verse is, “Reuben, thou art my firstborn, my might, and the first-fruits of my strength, the excellence of majesty, and the excellence of power,” and its purport is as follows: “You are the first-born of my might and the first-fruits of my strength when I was the excellence of majesty (<i>se’eith</i>) and position” — the expression being similar to that found in the verses: <i>Shall not his excellency (‘se’eitho’) make you afraid?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">76</sup><i class="footnote">Job 13:11.</i> <i>When he raiseth himself up (‘mise’eitho’) the mighty are afraid</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">77</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 41:17.</i> <i>‘mise’eitho’</i> meaning ascendancy and power — “and when I was at the height of strength (<i>oz</i>) for war” — the expression being similar to that found in the verses: <i>And He will give strength (‘oz’) unto His king;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">78</sup><i class="footnote">I Samuel 2:10.</i> <i>And the strength (‘ve’izuz’) of battle</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">79</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 42:25.</i>

Verse 4

UNSTABLE (‘PACHAZ’) AS WATER, YOU HAVE NOT THE EXCELLENCY. <i>Pachaz</i> is a noun, derived from the expression, <i>Vain and reckless (‘upachazim’) fellows</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">80</sup><i class="footnote">Judges 9:4.</i> meaning “hasty and impulsive people.” Our Rabbis have made steady use of this word: “I was looking at my image in the water and my evil inclination rose (<i>pachaz</i>) within me,”<sup class="footnote-marker">81</sup><i class="footnote">Nedarim 9b.</i> that is “my evil inclination leaped upon me” They said further: “It is their recklessness (<i>apichzeihu</i>) which they are revealing,”<sup class="footnote-marker">82</sup><i class="footnote">Sanhedrin 57a. See Note 63 in my Hebrew commentary, p. 265.</i> meaning their impulsiveness. “A reckless (<i>p’chizah</i>) people, who spoke before listening, you still retain your recklessness (<i>‘b’pachzuteich’</i>),”<sup class="footnote-marker">83</sup><i class="footnote">Shabbath 88a.</i> meaning “hasty and impulsive.” It is possible that this word <i>pachaz</i> is a permutation of the word <i>chipazon</i> (hurry).<sup class="footnote-marker">84</sup><i class="footnote">As is the case with the words; <i>keves</i> and <i>kesev</i>, both of which mean “lamb,” and other similar words.</i> Jacob was thus saying: “Since you burst forth as water, you shall no longer excel <i>for thou wentest up to thy father’s place of repose</i> in thy haste and impulsiveness. <i>Then didst thou profane</i> them,<sup class="footnote-marker">85</sup><i class="footnote">The Hebrew is <i>mishk’vei</i> (places of repose), which is in the plural form. Hence Ramban writes <i>otham</i> (them).</i> when your recklessness ascended my couch like the rising and gushing water.” This is similar to the Scriptural description of water: <i>Now, therefore, behold, the Lord bringeth up upon them the waters of the river, mighty and many, even the king of Assyria and all his glory; and he shall come up over all his channels, and go over all his banks; and he shall sweep through Judah, overflowing as he passeth through</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">86</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 8:7-8.</i><br>Our Rabbis have said:<sup class="footnote-marker">87</sup><i class="footnote">Shabbath 55b. It is found here in Rashi in the form mentioned by Ramban.</i> “<i>Then didst thou profane He Who hovered over my couch</i>, meaning the <i>Shechinah</i>” that used to abide above my [Jacob’s] couch. Yet the verse says, <i>Forasmuch as he</i> [Reuben] <i>defiled his father’s couch</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">88</sup><i class="footnote">I Chronicles 5:1. This clearly shows that it was “the couch” which was defiled and not, as the comment of Rashi would have it, the <i>Shechina</i>. Ramban proceeds to answer that Scripture modifies the expression out of respect for the Divine Presence.</i> thus clearly stating that it was the couch which was defiled! But perhaps [out of respect for the Divine Presence, Scripture] modifies the expression there.<br>But if [we accept the explanation that Scripture modifies the expression], it is possible that the word <i>alah</i> (going up) refers to [Jacob, thus saying, “then didst thou profane my couch upon which I used to go up],” just as in the verse, <i>Nor go up into the bed that is spread for me</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">89</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 132:3.</i> Thus Jacob’s intent is to say: “Then thou didst defile me;” He spoke in the third person<sup class="footnote-marker">90</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Alah</i>, “he” went up.</i> only as a matter of respect. Similarly, the verse, <i>Forasmuch as he defiled his father’s couch</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">91</sup><i class="footnote">I Chronicles 5:1.</i> is a Scriptural modification, meaning “forasmuch as he [Reuben] defiled the one who goes up<sup class="footnote-marker">92</sup><i class="footnote">I.e., Jacob. His name though is not mentioned directly, as a matter of respect.</i> upon his father’s couch.”<br>From the literal meaning of this verse it would appear as I have explained it in <i>Seder Vayishlach</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">93</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 35:22.</i> i.e., that it was Reuben’s intention to disqualify Bilhah from his father so that she should no longer give birth to children, thus lessening his share as the firstborn. It was for this reason that Jacob said to him that it was reckless and impulsive to think that he would gain thereby, whereas he had no profit from it but only loss.

Verse 5

SIMEON AND LEVI ARE BRETHREN. Jacob is saying that they possess the attribute of kinship for their hearts were inflamed concerning their sister.<sup class="footnote-marker">94</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 34:25-26.</i> He is thus stating in their defense that they acted as they did out of their brotherly zeal, thus suggesting [that were it not for this extenuating circumstance], they would have been deserving of great punishment and their sin would have been unforgivable since what they did to the people of Shechem was an act of violence.<br>The correct interpretation appears to me to be that he is saying that Simeon and Levi are real brothers, uniting in fraternity and brotherhood in counsel and deed. Now I have already explained<sup class="footnote-marker">95</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 34:13.</i> that Jacob was angry with Simeon and Levi for having committed violence when they killed the people of the city of Shechem, for they<sup class="footnote-marker">96</sup><i class="footnote">The people of the city committed no wrong. It was Shechem who violated Dinah, and the people were not in a position to protest his action.</i> had not sinned against them at all. They even made a covenant with them and they were circumcised, thus being enabled to return to G-d and become included within the people of the household of Abraham, part of <i>the souls that they had gotten in Haran</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">97</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 12:5. A reference to the proselytes whom Abraham and Sarah had brought “beneath the sheltering wings of the <i>Shechina</i>” (Rashi, <i>ibid</i>.)</i> Jacob was additionally angry with them lest people say that the matter was done at his suggestion, thus creating a profaning of G-d’s Name, as people will say that the prophet has committed violence and plunder. This is the intent of the verse, <i>Let my soul not come into their council</i>—<sup class="footnote-marker">98</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 6 here.</i> this is an excuse for he was not in their council when they answered the people of Shechem <i>with subtlety</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">99</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 34:13.</i> and he was not united <i>in their assembly</i> when they came upon the people of the city and killed them. It was for this reason that he cursed their anger and wrath.<sup class="footnote-marker">100</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 7 here.</i> And so did Onkelos translate: “My soul was not in their council when they assembled to strike, etc.”
INSTRUMENTS OF VIOLENCE ‘M’CHEIROTHEIHEM.’ According to Onkelos and all commentators,<sup class="footnote-marker">101</sup><i class="footnote">Rashi and R’dak.</i> the meaning of the verse is as if it were written: <i>instruments of violence ‘m’garotheihem’</i> (in their sojournings). This is similar to the verses: <i>Thy sojourning (‘m’chorothayich’) and thy nativity</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">102</sup><i class="footnote">Ezekiel 16:3. There too <i>m’chorothayich</i> is as if it were written <i>m’gorothayich</i>.</i> <i>into the land of their sojourn (‘m’churatham’)</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">103</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 29:14.</i> Thus the commentators said that the meaning of the verse is that they did violence in the land of their sojourn.<sup class="footnote-marker">104</sup><i class="footnote">That is, the people lived with them in peace, and they did not act accordingly.</i> Now if so, the approximate sense of the verse is as follows: “They had instruments of violence in the land of their sojournings,” it being referred to as “the land of their sojournings” since they lived there afterwards.<sup class="footnote-marker">105</sup><i class="footnote">At the time when Simeon and Levi wrought punishment upon the city of Shechem, they had just entered the land. How then could Jacob refer to the event as having taken place in the land of their sojourning? Ramban answers that this is a reference to the future.</i><br>But in my opinion Jacob is saying that “the instruments of violence are their dwelling places,” i.e., the essence of their lives, even as the expression, <i>the days of my pilgrimage (‘m’gurai’)</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">106</sup><i class="footnote">See above, 47:9.</i> He is thus saying that the very instruments of violence are their dwelling places for they live and sustain themselves by them. A similar expression is found in the verse: <i>The desert yieldeth them bread for their children</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">107</sup><i class="footnote">Job 24:5. The word “yieldeth” is not in the Hebrew text. Ramban interprets the meaning of the verse as follows: “The desert is to him bread for his children,” for there he has the opportunity to rob and plunder. Similarly, the verse here says that the sword is their livelihood. Ramban’s interpretation of the above verse in the book of Job is also found in his commentary to that book. See Kitvei Haramban, I, p. 80.</i> And it is on account of this that their father <i>divided them in Jacob</i><sup class="footnote-marker">100</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 7 here.</i> so that they should not unite <i>and scattered them in Israel</i> so that they should not assemble. This was indeed so, for Simeon’s inheritance in the Land was contained in the inheritance of the children of Judah, as it is written, <i>And their inheritance was in the midst of the inheritance of the children of Judah</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">108</sup><i class="footnote">Joshua 19:1.</i> with the cities of Simeon set apart from one another throughout the entire tribe of Judah. And Levi’s inheritance consisted of the Cities of Refuge,<sup class="footnote-marker">109</sup><i class="footnote">See Numbers 35:1-8.</i> which were scattered through all Israel.<sup class="footnote-marker">110</sup><i class="footnote">See Joshua, Chapter 21.</i>

Verse 6

FOR IN THEIR ANGER THEY SLEW A MAN AND IN THEIR SELF-WILL THEY DISABLED AN OX (‘SHOR’). The meaning of this is that they committed violence in their wrath in that they were angry at Shechem, and it was to satisfy their own desire and not because of the guilt or sins of the slain.<br>Now Onkelos says that the word <i>shor</i> (ox) should be understood as <i>shur</i> (wall) with a <i>shuruk</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">111</sup><i class="footnote">The phonetic equivalent <i>oo</i>. Thus the word should be understood as <i>shur</i> (wall) rather than <i>shor</i> (ox). The Torah-script has no vowel signs, and for the sake of interpretation, a difficult word may sometimes be interpreted as if it were vowelled differently than the traditional reading.</i> as in the verse, <i>Daughters treaded on the wall (‘shur’)</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">112</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 22 here.</i> Thus Onkelos translated the word <i>shor</i> in the present verse as “the wall of the enemy,” similar in expression to the verse: <i>Mine eye also hath gazed on them that lie in wait for me (‘b’shuroi’)</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">113</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 92:12. Ramban is thus suggesting that the enemy lies in wait for me behind his fortified walls.</i> The meaning of the verse is thus: “and they uprooted a city surrounded with a wall, slaying their children and women after having killed the men of the city.” The word <i>ikru</i> (disabled) would then be similar in use to the verse, <i>Ekron shall be rooted up (‘tei’akeir’)</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">114</sup><i class="footnote">Zephaniah 2:4.</i><br>Others<sup class="footnote-marker">115</sup><i class="footnote">Mentioned in the commentary of R’dak in the name of Rabbi Yaakov the son of Rabbi Elazar.</i> have explained that the ox, which is the largest of cattle, is an allusion to Hamor and his son Shechem, the prince of the country,<sup class="footnote-marker">116</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 34:2.</i> just as in the verses: <i>His firstling bull, majesty is his;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">117</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 33:17.</i> <i>Ye kine of Bashan, that are in the mountain of Samaria</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">118</sup><i class="footnote">Amos 4:1.</i> Similarly do the verses surname the great princes “rams”<sup class="footnote-marker">119</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 15:15. <i>Eilei Moab</i> is generally translated, “the mighty men of Moab,” but literally it means “the rams of Moab.”</i> and “he-goats.”<sup class="footnote-marker">120</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 14:9. <i>Atudei eretz</i> is generally translated, “the chief ones of the earth,” but literally it means “the he-goats of the earth.”</i><br>The correct interpretation appears to me to be that the verse is to be understood in its usual sense as stating that <i>in their anger they killed</i> each <i>man</i> of whom they were wrathful; <i>and in their self-will</i>, after their anger had been calmed by the slaying of the men, <i>they uprooted</i> all <i>oxen</i>, this being an allusion to their cattle and their possessions, including everything that was in the home and everything in the field. Now Jacob mentioned this in order to state that he had no part in all these secret deliberations of theirs, even in the removal of the cattle and possessions, or any aspect of the spoiling and plundering of the people of the city of Shechem. The word <i>ikru</i> [in the expression, <i>ikru shor</i>], has the same meaning as in the verse: <i>Thou shalt hemstring (‘te’akeir’) their horses</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">121</sup><i class="footnote">Joshua 11:6.</i> But the expression and purport is all one.

Verse 7



Verse 8



Verse 9



Verse 10

THE SCEPTRE SHALL NOT DEPART FROM JUDAH. Its purport is not that the sceptre of royalty shall never depart from Judah, for it is written, <i>The Eternal will bring thee, and thy king whom thou shalt set over thee, unto a nation that thou hast not known, thou nor thy fathers</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">122</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 28:36.</i> with the result that the people and their king will be in exile, devoid of royalty and nobility, and for a long time there has not been a king in Israel! The prophet Jacob did not assure Israel that they would not enter captivity under any circumstances because Judah would rule over them. Instead, the purport of the verse before us is that the sceptre shall not depart from Judah to any of his brothers, for the king of Israel, who will rule over them, will be from the tribe of Judah, and none of his brothers will rule over him. The same meaning applies to the expression, <i>there shall not depart a lawgiver from between his feet</i>, which means that every lawgiver in Israel who carries the king’s signet shall be from Judah. It is he who will rule and command in all Israel, and he will have the seal of royalty until the coming of his son, who [will have] the obedience of all people, to do with all as he pleases, this being a reference to the Messiah. “The sceptre” is thus an allusion to David, who was the first king to have the sceptre of royalty, and “Shiloh”<sup class="footnote-marker">123</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ad ki yavo Shiloh</i>, “until Shiloh come, and his be the obedience of peoples.”</i> is his son, who will have the obedience of the peoples.<br>Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra’s assertion that “Shiloh” is a reference to David is impossible for Judah never possessed a royal sceptre prior to David. And even though the tribe of Judah was honored and marched first in the desert,<sup class="footnote-marker">124</sup><i class="footnote">See Numbers 2:9.</i> the word <i>sheivet</i> (sceptre) applies only to a king or prince, as it is written: <i>A sceptre (‘sheivet’) of equity is the sceptre of thy kingdom;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">125</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 45:7.</i> <i>the sceptre of the rulers;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">126</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 14:5.</i> <i>a sceptre to rule</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">127</sup><i class="footnote">Ezekiel 19:14.</i><br>Now this verse before us alludes to the fact that Jacob made the tribe of Judah king over his brothers and bequeathed to Judah sovereignty over Israel. This is what David said: <i>And the Eternal, the G-d of Israel, chose me out of all the house of my father to be king over Israel forever; for He has chosen Judah to be prince, and in the house of Judah, the house of my father, and among the sons of my father He took pleasure in me to make me king over all Israel</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">128</sup><i class="footnote">I Chronicles 28:4.</i><br>Jacob said, <i>It shall not depart</i>, in order to allude to the fact that another tribe<sup class="footnote-marker">129</sup><i class="footnote">Benjamin, for Saul was from the tribe of Benjamin.</i> will rule over Israel, but once the sceptre of royalty comes to Judah it will not depart from him to another tribe.
