This is the intent of the verse, <i>For the Eternal, the G-d of Israel, gave the kingdom over Israel to David forever, to him and to his sons</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">130</sup><i class="footnote">II Chronicles 13:5.</i> The reason for Saul [being appointed the first king over Israel] was that the request for royalty at that time was distasteful to the Holy One, blessed be He.<sup class="footnote-marker">131</sup><i class="footnote">See I Samuel 8:5-9. Ramban will explain why the people’s request for a king was unpleasing to G-d “at that time.”</i> He did not wish to appoint a king over them from the tribe to whom royalty belonged and from whom it was never to depart. He therefore granted them a temporary royalty. It is this which Scripture alludes to when it says, <i>I give thee a king in Mine anger, and take him away in My wrath</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">132</sup><i class="footnote">Hosea 13:11.</i> Having given him unwillingly, He therefore removed him in His wrath, as he and his children were killed<sup class="footnote-marker">133</sup><i class="footnote">I Samuel 31:6.</i> and his royal line was interrupted. The reason for all this was that at this time Samuel was judge and prophet who was fighting their battles according to the word of G-d, saving them in times of trouble, and it was improper for them to request a king during his lifetime, even as Samuel said to them, <i>And the Eternal your G-d is your king</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">134</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 12:12.</i> and Scripture further states, <i>They have not rejected thee, but they have rejected Me, that I should not be king over them</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">135</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 8:7.</i> It was for this reason that He did not grant them permanent royalty. The verse stating, <i>Thou hast done foolishly; thou hast not kept the commandment of the Eternal thy G-d, which He commanded thee; for now would the Eternal have established thy kingdom upon Israel forever</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">136</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 13:13. This verse clearly indicates that had Saul not sinned, his kingdom would have endured forever, which seems contrary to Ramban’s above thesis. Ramban’s answer is stated in the text.</i> means that had not Saul sinned, his descendants would have had sovereignty over some part of Israel, but not over all. This is the meaning of [the expression], <i>upon Israel</i>, [rather than “upon <i>all</i> Israel].” Perhaps Saul would have reigned over the tribes that were descended from his mother,<sup class="footnote-marker">137</sup><i class="footnote">Rachel. Joseph and Benjamin were her sons, and the tribes of Benjamin, Ephraim and Menasheh were her descendants.</i> namely, Benjamin, Ephraim and Menasheh, as Judah and Ephraim were considered as two nations in Israel.<sup class="footnote-marker">138</sup><i class="footnote">There would then have been no contradiction between the permanent sovereignty of both Saul and David, as Judah and Ephraim are separate nations.</i> Or again, Saul might have been king, subject to the king of Judah.<br>In my opinion, the kings from other tribes, who ruled over Israel after David, went against the wish of their father Jacob by diverting the inheritance of Judah to another tribe. Now they relied on the word of Achiyah the Shilonite, the prophet who anointed<sup class="footnote-marker">139</sup><i class="footnote">We do not find in Scripture that Jeroboam was anointed king. But see Horayoth 11 b, where it is stated that kings of Israel were anointed although not with the Oil of Anointment prepared by Moses.</i> Jeroboam, who said, <i>And I will for this afflict the seed of David, but not forever</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">140</sup><i class="footnote">I Kings 11:39.</i> But when [the ten tribes of] Israel continued to crown kings one after another of the rest of the tribes, and they did not revert to the kingdom of Judah, they transgressed the testament of the ancestor, and they were accordingly punished, just as Hosea said, <i>They have set up kings, but not from Me</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">141</sup><i class="footnote">Hosea 8:4.</i><br>This was also the reason for the punishment of the Hasmoneans, who reigned during the Second Temple. They were saints of the Most High, without whom the learning of Torah and the observance of Commandments would have been forgotten in Israel, and despite this, they suffered such great punishment. The four sons<sup class="footnote-marker">142</sup><i class="footnote">Judah the Maccabee, Elazar, Jonathan and Shimon, were all slain by the sword.</i> of the old Hasmonean Matithyahu, saintly men who ruled one after another, in spite of all their prowess and success, fell by the sword of their enemies. And ultimately the punishment reached the stage where our Rabbis, of blessed memory, said:<sup class="footnote-marker">143</sup><i class="footnote">Baba Bathra 3b.</i> “He who says, ‘I come from the house of the Hasmoneans,’ is a slave,” as they were all destroyed on account of this sin.<sup class="footnote-marker">144</sup><i class="footnote">The Hasmoneans were priests of the tribe of Levi. By assuming the crown of royalty, they transgressed the command of Jacob, who said as long as royalty exists in Israel it should not be removed from the tribe of Judah. All this is elucidated by Ramban further in the text.</i> Now although among the children of Shimon, there was cause for punishment on account of the Sadducees,<sup class="footnote-marker">145</sup><i class="footnote">Reference here is to Yochanan Hyrcanus, son of Shimon, who towards the end of his long reign became a member of the sect of the Sadducees, who, in opposition to the Pharisees, denied the Oral Traditions. See Kiddushin 66a.</i> all the children of the righteous Matithyahu the Hasmonean were deposed for this only: they ruled even though they were not of the seed of Judah and of the house of David, and thus they completely removed “the sceptre” and “the lawgiver” from Judah. And their punishment was measure for measure, as the Holy One, blessed be He, caused their slaves<sup class="footnote-marker">146</sup><i class="footnote">A reference to King Herod.</i> to rule over them, and it is they who destroyed them.<br>It is also possible that, [in addition to the Hasmoneans having sinned for assuming royalty when they were not of the tribe of Judah], they sinned in ruling on account of their being priests, who have been commanded: <i>Guard your priesthood in everything that pertaineth to the altar, and to within the veil; and ye shall serve; I give you the priesthood as a service of gift</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">147</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 18:7.</i> Thus it was not for them to rule, but only to perform the Service of G-d.<br>In Tractate Horayoth of the Jerusalem Talmud<sup class="footnote-marker">148</sup><i class="footnote">3:2.</i> I have seen the following text: “We do not anoint priests as kings. Rabbi Yehudah Anturya said that this is on account of the verse, <i>The sceptre shall not depart from Judah</i>. Rabbi Chiya the son of Rabbi Abba said [that Scripture states concerning the king], <i>To the end that he may prolong his days in his kingdom, he and his children, in the midst of Israel</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">149</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 17:20.</i> Now what is written afterwards? <i>The priests the Levites … shall have no portion</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">150</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 18:1. Thus taeching by juxtaposition that the priests are not to act as kings.</i> Thus the Sages have taught here that kings are not to be anointed from among the priests, the sons of Aaron. Now at first the above text explains that this is out of respect for the tribe of Judah since sovereignty is not to depart from that tribe. Therefore, even if Israel, out of temporary necessity, raises a king over itself from the other tribes, he is not to be anointed so that the glory of royalty should not be upon him. Instead, such kings are to be merely as judges or officers. The reason for mentioning “priests” [when the same stricture applies to all tribes other than Judah] is that even though the priests as such are suited for anointment,<sup class="footnote-marker">151</sup><i class="footnote">For any priest who is designated as the High Priest enters upon his new duties through anointment (Horayoth 11 b).</i> we are not to anoint them as kings, and the moreso the rest of the tribes. It is as the Rabbis said in the <i>Gemara:</i><sup class="footnote-marker">152</sup><i class="footnote">Horayoth 11b. The principle is mentioned there, but Ramban’s quote follows the text of Rambam (Mishneh Torah, Hilchoth Melachim I, 10).</i> we are to anoint only the kings of the house of David.<sup class="footnote-marker">153</sup><i class="footnote">See Note 139 above.</i> And Rabbi Chiya the son of Rabbi Abba, [who in the above text from the Jerusalem Talmud based the law upon a verse in the book of Deuteronomy], explained that anointing priests as kings is forbidden by a law of the Torah, which says that <i>the priests the Levites, even all the tribe of Levi, shall have no portion nor inheritance</i><sup class="footnote-marker">154</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 18:1.</i> in royalty. This comment is a matter which is fitting and proper.
AND UNTO HIM SHALL BE AN ASSEMBLAGE (‘YIKHATH’) OF PEOPLES. <i>Yikhath amim</i> means an assemblage of peoples, as it is said with reference to the Messiah, <i>Unto him shall the nations seek</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">155</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 11:10.</i> Of similar meaning is the verse, <i>The eye that mocketh at his father, and despiseth ‘likhath eim,’</i><sup class="footnote-marker">156</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 30:17.</i> meaning “the gathering of wrinkles in his mother’s face due to her old age.” In the Talmud<sup class="footnote-marker">157</sup><i class="footnote">Yebamoth 110b. Nehardea was a town in Babylonia, renowned as the seat of the academy founded by Shmuel. His colleague Rav was head of the academy in Sura.</i> we find a similar expression: “They gathered assemblies (<i>d’makhu k’hiatha</i>) in the streets of Nehardea.” It could also have said here in the verse, <i>kehiyath amim</i>, instead of <i>yikhath amim</i>. This is the language of Rashi.<br>Now it does not appear to me to be correct to explain, as Rashi does, <i>likhath eim</i> to mean the gathering of wrinkles in the mother’s face. And the expression, <i>makhu k’hiatha</i>, is nothing but a phrase to express disputes and questions, suggesting that the matter was disputed with many questions and interrogations, for in the language of the Sages, one who finds difficulty with a certain point of law is referred to as <i>kohah</i>. Such an example is found in the Midrash Chazit:<sup class="footnote-marker">158</sup><i class="footnote">Another name for Shir Hashirim Rabbah. The name Midrash Chazit is derived from the first word of the opening of this Midrash. It begins with the verse in Proverbs 22:29: “<i>Chazita</i> (Seest thou a man.…)” The Midrash quoted here is in 3:13.</i> “<i>They all handle the sword</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">159</sup><i class="footnote">Song of Songs 3:8.</i> as they all study the Law with minds sharpened as a sword, so that if any problem comes before them, the law should not be moot (<i>kohah</i>) to them.” There are many other similar examples of the usage of this word there in the Midrash Chazit. This is also the origin of the expression in the <i>Gemara:</i><sup class="footnote-marker">160</sup><i class="footnote">Negaim 4:11. See also Tosafoth Yebamoth 110b.</i> “Rabbi Yehoshua <i>kihah</i> and declared it to be clean,” meaning that he asked many questions and refuted all arguments of those who held it to be unclean until he was compelled to pronounce it to be clean. In many old texts in the <i>Gemara Baba Metzia</i><sup class="footnote-marker">161</sup><i class="footnote">52b.</i> we also find the saying: “He who <i>d’kohi</i> on coins is called a malevolent soul,” meaning that he who is strict and causes difficulty in accepting a coin from another [on the grounds that it is slightly worn shows himself to be stingy in his dealings].<br>Grammarians<sup class="footnote-marker">162</sup><i class="footnote">R’dak in his Book of Roots, under the root <i>yakah</i>.</i> have said concerning <i>yikhath</i> that its root is <i>yakah</i>, thus explaining it in the sense of obedience and acceptance of a command. Hence <i>yikhath amim</i> would mean that the peoples would listen to him and do whatever he commands them to do; and <i>despiseth ‘likhath eim’</i><sup class="footnote-marker">156</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 30:17.</i> means “despising accepting her command.”<br>The correct interpretation appears to me to be that the word <i>yikhath</i> is similar in expression to the verse, <i>He that eateth the sour grapes his teeth ‘tikhenah’ (shall be set on edge)</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">163</sup><i class="footnote">Jeremiah 31:29.</i> and its root is <i>kahah</i>, with the letter <i>yud</i> in the word <i>yikhath</i> being similar to the <i>yud</i> in the word <i>yitzhar</i>. The purport of all words having the root <i>kahah</i> is weakness and collapse. The verse before us is thus stating that the rod of the oppressor will not be removed from Judah until his son, who will bring about the meakness of the peoples and their collapse, will come, as he will weaken them all by sword. Similarly, the verse, <i>If the iron be ‘keihah,’</i><sup class="footnote-marker">164</sup><i class="footnote">Ecclesiastes 10:10.</i> means “if the iron be dull and unable to cut” — similar to [the expression] in the language of the Sages, <i>sakin she’amda</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">165</sup><i class="footnote">Beitza 28b. Literally, “a knife which has stood.”</i> (a knife which has become dull) “or has been partly broken and contains notches.”<br>Again I found a similar use of the word <i>kohah</i> there in Midrash Chazit,<sup class="footnote-marker">166</sup><i class="footnote">1:57. See Note 158 for derivation of the name Midrash Chazit.</i> [with reference to the period of the Exodus when Israel was to eat of the Passover-offering]: “The Holy One, blessed be He, directed at them a most pleasant odor from the Garden of Eden, and their souls were <i>koheh</i>, to eat. They said to Moses: ‘Our master Moses, give us something to eat.’ He answered them: ‘So did the Holy One, blessed be He, say to me: <i>There shall no alien eat thereof</i>.’<sup class="footnote-marker">167</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 12:43.</i> So the Israelites arose and separated the aliens from among them. Now their souls were <i>koheh</i> to eat, etc.” The purport of the word <i>koheh</i> here is that their souls were weakened and their bodies overcome on account of their desire to eat of the Passover-offering to which there had been attached this good odor from the Garden of Eden. In a similar vein are the expressions mentioned above: “The Law should not be <i>kohah</i> to them,”<sup class="footnote-marker">158</sup><i class="footnote">Another name for Shir Hashirim Rabbah. The name Midrash Chazit is derived from the first word of the opening of this Midrash. It begins with the verse in Proverbs 22:29: “<i>Chazita</i> (Seest thou a man.…)” The Midrash quoted here is in 3:13.</i> meaning “faint and deficient in their hand”; the expression, <i>makhu k’hiatha</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">157</sup><i class="footnote">Yebamoth 110b. Nehardea was a town in Babylonia, renowned as the seat of the academy founded by Shmuel. His colleague Rav was head of the academy in Sura.</i> means that they were asking questions which induce a weakening of the soul from the great pressure and concentration. It may be that it is an expression of disproof and smashing refutation, such as, “<i>Parich</i> Rav Acha.”<sup class="footnote-marker">168</sup><i class="footnote">Kiddushin 13a. “Rav Acha objected” Ramban is suggesting that it means: “Rav Acha asked a crushing question.”</i> They similarly use the expression [in connection with the question of the wicked son in the Passover Hagaddah]: “You too <i>hakheih</i> his teeth,”<sup class="footnote-marker">169</sup><i class="footnote">Mechilta Bo 18, toward the end.</i> meaning “break them or weaken them by your words,” for with respect to the flesh you can only use the term “weaken” but not “break” although the intent of weakening and breaking is alike, and the word <i>kehiyah</i> includes both.

Verse 11



Verse 12

HIS EYES ARE ‘CHACHLILI’ (FROM WINE). The Commentators<sup class="footnote-marker">170</sup><i class="footnote">Rashi, Ibn Ezra, and R’dak.</i> say that the word <i>chachlili</i> denotes redness, and it means that his eyes will become red from drinking much wine. Of similar meaning is the verse, <i>Who hath ‘chachliluth’ (redness) of the eyes?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">171</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 23:29.</i><br>Now it appears to me that this is a case of a word whose letters are transposed,<sup class="footnote-marker">172</sup><i class="footnote">Thus, instead of the order of the letters being <i>cheth, kaf, lamed</i>, it should be understood as if it were written: <i>kaf, cheth, lamed</i>, suggesting the act of painting, as will be explained further.</i> it being derived from the expression, <i>Thou didst paint (‘kachalt’) thine eyes</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">173</sup><i class="footnote">Ezekiel 23:40.</i> The <i>lamed</i> is doubled — [<i>chachlili</i>] — as is customary in many places, and it denotes the process of painting eyes which is known and frequently mentioned in the words of our Rabbis. In Arabic also its name is “al kachul.” The verse is thus stating that Judah’s eyes are colored with wine for just as others paint them with <i>puch</i> (eye-paint),<sup class="footnote-marker">174</sup><i class="footnote">Jeremiah 4:30.</i> which is the Arabic “al kachul,” so does he paint them with wine, and just as others whiten their teeth with ointments, so does he whiten them with milk, the comparison indicating the abundance of wine and milk in Judah’s land, just as Onkelos mentioned.<sup class="footnote-marker">175</sup><i class="footnote">“His mountains will be red with his vineyards, and his wine-presses will drip with wine” (Onkelos).</i> Similar in meaning is the verse, <i>Who hath ‘chachliluth’ of eyes</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">171</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 23:29.</i> [the letters in the word <i>chachliluth</i> are to be transposed to read] <i>kachliluth</i>” (paint), with the verse stating that the drunkard has his eyes painted by wine and he cannot hide his drunken state. It is possible that the verse is stating, “Who has coloring of eyes?” meaning “who needs to paint his eyes always? <i>They that tarry long at the wine</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">171</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 23:29.</i> since the wine dims their eyes, causing them to tear, <i>and be consumed away in their sockets</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">176</sup><i class="footnote">Zechariah 14:12.</i> thus making it necessary for him to have his eyes constantly painted.” Scripture, in the book of Proverbs, is thus speaking of the disgrace of wine and the external evils of contentions and wounds which befall he who drinks it in abundance, while in his house there will always be the cry of “Woe” and “Alas.”<sup class="footnote-marker">171</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 23:29.</i> It then also mentions this specific harm which affects his body, namely, the dimming of his vision, and many other sicknesses. This is a correct interpretation and elucidation of the subject.

Verse 13



Verse 14



Verse 15



Verse 16

DAN SHALL JUDGE ‘YADIN’ HIS PEOPLE. This has the same meaning as in the verse, <i>For the Eternal ‘yadin’ His people</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">177</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 32:36.</i> which Onkelos translates as, “For the Eternal will judge the judgment of His people,”<sup class="footnote-marker">178</sup><i class="footnote">Here also, the sense of the verse is: “Dan will judge the judgment of his people.”</i> just as in the expressions: <i>Be thou my judge, O G-d, and plead my cause against an ungodly nation;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">179</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 43:1.</i> <i>The cause of the widow</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">180</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 1:23. The reference should rather be to Verse 17 there: <i>rivu almanah</i> (plead for the widow), which means <i>rivu riv almanah</i> (plead the plea of the widow). Here, likewise, the sense of the verse is: “Dan will judge the judgment of his people.” (T’chelet Mordechai. See my Hebrew commentary, p. 270, Note 39.)</i> The verse is thus stating that Dan will avenge the cause of his people, all the tribes of Israel, as one.<sup class="footnote-marker">181</sup><i class="footnote">As explained further in the text, it is clear that Ramban is transposing the words of the verse and interpreting it in the following way: “Dan will judge his people,” that is, Samson, a descendant of the tribe of Dan, will avenge the cause of his people from the hands of the Philistines. And who are “his people?” All “the tribes of Israel.” And how will that help affect them? “As one,” that is, as one whole nation, for when, at the time of Samson’s death, the Philistines’ temple collapsed, all the lords of the Philistines (Judges 16:27) died, and thus all “the tribes of Israel as one” were delivered from their hands.</i> And the purport of it is as follows: The Philistines wronged all Israel many times. In the days of Shamgar the son of Anath<sup class="footnote-marker">182</sup><i class="footnote">Judges 3:31.</i> they began their oppression of Israel, and in the days of Jephthah it is written, <i>And He gave them over into the hand of the Philistines</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">183</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 10:7.</i> and after the days of Abdon the son of Hillel,<sup class="footnote-marker">184</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 12:13.</i> it is also written, <i>And the Eternal delivered them into the hand of the Philistines forty years</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">185</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 13:1.</i> There was none among the Judges who subdued them or had any victory at all over them. Now although it is written concerning Shamgar, <i>And he smote the Philistines six hundred men with an ox-goad</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">182</sup><i class="footnote">Judges 3:31.</i> this was not “vengeance,” relatively speaking, as it was not <i>a great slaughter</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">186</sup><i class="footnote">II Chronicles 13:17.</i> This is why it is written concerning Samson, <i>And he shall begin to save Israel out of the hand of the Philistines</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">187</sup><i class="footnote">Judges 13:5.</i> and he avenged the cause of Israel from them for he slew many people and killed all the lords of the Philistines.<sup class="footnote-marker">188</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>ibid.</i>, 16:27 and 30.</i> Scripture mentions <i>yadin</i> (he will judge), since this avenger was a judge, not a king. It is possible that this interpretation coincides with the opinion of Onkelos, who translated: “In his days his people will be delivered.”<sup class="footnote-marker">189</sup><i class="footnote">Thus it is clear that Onkelos also explained the word <i>yadin</i> as meaning “will avenge.” See also my Hebrew commentary, p. 270.</i><br>It is possible that the expression, <i>as one of the tribes of Israel</i>, means “as the outstanding one of the tribes,” namely, Judah, concerning whom it is said, <i>Thy hand shall be on the neck of thine enemies</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">190</sup><i class="footnote">Above, Verse 8.</i> thus implying that this one also<sup class="footnote-marker">191</sup><i class="footnote">The judge from the tribe of Dan, namely, Samson.</i> will be victorious over his enemies and subdue them.

Verse 17

SH’PHIPHON (SERPENT)<sup class="footnote-marker">192</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 17 here: <i>Dan shall be a serpent by the way, a ‘sh’phiphon’ on the path, that biteth the horse in the heels, so that his rider falleth backward</i>.</i> is the name of a snake which bites at the heel, with the second root-letter<sup class="footnote-marker">193</sup><i class="footnote">Namely, the <i>pei</i>.</i> being doubled.<sup class="footnote-marker">194</sup><i class="footnote">Ramban is suggesting that the root of <i>sh’phipon</i> is <i>shapha</i> which means “hissing while biting,” except that the letter <i>pei</i> is here doubled.</i> In the Jerusalem Talmud, Tractate Terumoth<sup class="footnote-marker">195</sup><i class="footnote">8:3.</i> the Rabbis said, “It is a small kind of serpent, its name is <i>sh’phiphon</i>, and it is as thin as a hair,” with the earth being permitted to crack before it. Samson is compared to a snake because Samson did not wage war against his enemies as did the other judges and kings. Rather he alone went out against them, just as the viper which leaves his hole to attack travellers on the road, or the small species of serpent of which the traveller is not at all aware.
THAT BITETH THE HORSE’s HEEL.<sup class="footnote-marker">192</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 17 here: <i>Dan shall be a serpent by the way, a ‘sh’phiphon’ on the path, that biteth the horse in the heels, so that his rider falleth backward</i>.</i> This alludes to the two pillars<sup class="footnote-marker">196</sup><i class="footnote">Judges 16:29.</i> upon which the house of Dagan, the Philistine god, rested, whereas the three thousand people who were upon its roof<sup class="footnote-marker">197</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 27.</i> are “the rider that falleth backward,”<sup class="footnote-marker">198</sup><i class="footnote">See Note 192.</i> for when the snake bites the horse’s heels, the horse lifts its head and his forefeet, causing the rider to fall backward.

Verse 18

I HOPE FOR THY AID, O ETERNAL. Among all the judges of Israel there was none who fell into the hands of his enemies except Samson, who is this “snake” [referred to in Jacob’s prophecy], just as it is written, <i>Then the Eternal was with the judge, and saved them out of the hand of their enemies all the days of the judge</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">199</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 2:18.</i> and Samson was the last of the judges since his successor Samuel was a prophet and he did not conduct war on the people’s behalf, and in his days the kings [Saul and David] reigned. Now when the prophet Jacob saw that the deliverance which was to come through Samson ceased [when he died together with the Philistines], he said, “<i>I hope for Thy aid, O Eternal</i>, not for the aid of ‘the snake’ or ‘the serpent,’ for it is by Thee that I will be helped, not by a judge, as Thy salvation is ‘an everlasting salvation.’”<sup class="footnote-marker">200</sup><i class="footnote">See Isaiah 45:17.</i>

Verse 19

‘GAD G’DUD Y’GUDENU.’ Rashi, in accordance with Onkelos, explained it as follows: A troop will troop out of him, and that troop will troop back upon its footsteps, meaning it will return in its own track back to its territory in peace [and not one of them will be missing].<sup class="footnote-marker">201</sup><i class="footnote">Reference here, according to Rashi and Onkelos, is to the time when the armed Gadites will cross the Jordan with their brethren, and they will remain with them until the land will have been conquered. When they will return to their land on the east side of the Jordan not one of them will be missing.</i><br>The correct interpretation [appears to be that the word <i>y’gudenu</i> here] is as in the verse: <i>When he cometh up against the people that he invadeth (‘y’gudenu’)</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">202</sup><i class="footnote">Habakkuk 3:16. Thus, “the troop” mentioned in the prophecy of Jacob is not a friendly troop, as Rashi and Onkelos would have it, but the enemy, as explained further.</i> The verse is thus stating that a troop will always assail Gad, that he will have many wars, with enemy troops spreading out over his land, and that he will follow the enemy in his track and be victorious over him and pursue him, returning on the heel of those who shame them. Jacob thus praised the Gadites for their valor and for their victory over all those who enter into battle against them. This is similar to the blessing which Moses our teacher gave them, as it is said, <i>Blessed be He that enlargeth Gad; he dwelleth as a lioness</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">203</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 33:20.</i> Since Gad inherited a very wide and large land which was across the Jordan, bands from Ammon and Moab, his evil neighbors, would always descend upon him, claiming the land and invading it. Yet Gad lurked like a lioness over its prey, fearing not their noise, nor showing any dismay at their shouting.<br>This fitting interpretation I learned from the Jerusalem Talmud, where in Tractate Sotah<sup class="footnote-marker">204</sup><i class="footnote">8:10.</i> they say: “<i>Gad g’dud y’gudenu</i>, a troop will come trooping upon him, but he shall troop upon it;” that is to say, bands will come to gather wealth and assail him, but he shall troop upon them and bring his troops into their land.<br>Perhaps the prophet Jacob was alluding to the war of Jephthah the Gileadite against the children of Ammon, as the children of Gad inherited all the cities of Gilead, and half of the land of the children of Ammon. The children of Ammon were always warring against the men of Gilead, and Jephthah scarcely passed over them and he smote them and their cities [with] <i>a very great slaughter</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">205</sup><i class="footnote">Judges 11:33.</i> This event was indeed a great miracle, and so the prophet Jacob mentioned it, even as he mentioned the matter of Samson.

Verse 20



Verse 21

NAPHTALI IS A HIND SENT FORTH. It was a custom among the rulers of countries to send hinds to one another, and this was the manner in which it was done: Hinds which were born in the territory of the king of the north country would be raised in the palaces of the king of the south country. They would attach a written message to its horns, and it would run speedily and return to its original habitat, and in this way the king of the north country would be apprised of the news. This is the meaning of the phrase, <i>He giveth goodly words</i>, meaning that he is a dispatched hind sent who bears good tidings.<br>This practice is known, and it is mentioned in the Jerusalem Talmud, in Tractate Shevi’ith:<sup class="footnote-marker">206</sup><i class="footnote">9:2.</i> “They said,<sup class="footnote-marker">207</sup><i class="footnote">In our Jerusalem Talmud the text reads: “The officers said to him.” The story told there is about Diocletian, the emperor who oppressed the people of a certain city with heavy taxes. When the people threatened to leave the place the officers said to Diocletian: “If they go they will return, for it is in the nature of people to return to their birthplace. And if you wish to prove it, etc.”</i> ‘If they go they will return, and if you wish to prove it, bring deer and send them to a land far away, and in the end they will return.’ He did so. He brought deer and covered their horns with silver<sup class="footnote-marker">208</sup><i class="footnote">So that they would be recognized upon their return.</i> and sent them to Africa, and at the end of thirteen years they returned to their place.” That is, they freed them after thirteen years, and they returned at once. The analogy is that <i>Naphtali is satisfied with favor, and full</i><sup class="footnote-marker">209</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 33:23.</i> with all good things, and from him tidings will come forth to all Israel that his land has produced fruits abundantly, even as our Rabbis have mentioned concerning the fruits of Genothar.<sup class="footnote-marker">210</sup><i class="footnote">Berachoth 44a. The fruits of Genessar (a district around the Sea of Kinnereth) were considered more nourishing than bread, so that if one eats them together with bread he recites the Benediction over the fruits, as they are the main food.</i>

Verse 22

‘BEIN PORATH YOSEPH.’ A graceful son. It is an expression used in Aramaic: “<i>Apiryon namtai</i> (Let us gracefully treat) Rabbi Shimon.”<sup class="footnote-marker">211</sup><i class="footnote">Baba Metzia 119a.</i> <i>Bein porath alei ayin</i>. His gracefulness attracts the eye that sees him. This is the language of Rashi.<br>Now it is farfetched to base the interpretation of the word <i>porath</i> upon this Aramaic expression, for such expressions in the Talmud — be they Greek, Persian, or other languages — have no kinship with the Sacred Language. Moreover, each example found of this word is only an expression of blessing and praise, not grace, and the letter <i>nun</i> [in the word <i>apiryon</i>] is a root letter.<sup class="footnote-marker">212</sup><i class="footnote">Whereas the Hebrew <i>porath</i> has no <i>nun</i>. How then can Rashi explain the word <i>porath</i> as being similar to <i>apiryon</i> in which the <i>nun</i> is a root letter?</i> It is so mentioned in Bereshith Rabbah:<sup class="footnote-marker">213</sup><i class="footnote">60:13.</i> “<i>And they blessed Rebekah</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">214</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 24:60.</i> They were depressed and mean. They were <i>m’pharnin</i> (blessing) only with their mouth.”<br>It appears to me that the meaning of <i>porath</i> is as in the expression, “<i>Purna</i> belongs to the orphans,”<sup class="footnote-marker">215</sup><i class="footnote">Kethuboth 54a.</i> where <i>purna</i> means the improvement in the value [of the orphans’ portion of the dowry which] belongs to the orphans. The Rabbis further called the <i>kethubah</i> (the written marriage-contract) <i>purna</i>, saying, “A woman collects the <i>purna</i> from them,”<sup class="footnote-marker">216</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 67a.</i> meaning the <i>kethubah</i> which constitutes the benefit from her father’s house. They similarly said that “<i>mohar</i><sup class="footnote-marker">217</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 22:16.</i> (dowry) means <i>pranun</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">218</sup><i class="footnote">It is so rendered there in Targum Jonathan.</i><br>But <i>bein porath</i> in the present verse is to be interpreted either as Onkelos has it as being an expression of fruitfulness and abundance, or as the grammarians<sup class="footnote-marker">219</sup><i class="footnote">Rabbi Yonah and Rabbi Yehudah, mentioned by R’dak in his Book of Roots, under the root <i>banah</i>.</i> — who derived the word <i>porath</i> from the phrase, <i>And its branches (‘p’orothav’) became long</i><sup class="footnote-marker">220</sup><i class="footnote">Ezekiel 31:5.</i> — would have it. They further said that the word <i>bein</i> is similar in meaning to “a plant” or “branch”, and they bring a similar verse as proof: <i>And of the stock which Thy right hand hath planted, and the branch (‘bein’) that Thou madest strong for Thyself</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">221</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 80:16.</i> Thus the purport of the verse is as if Jacob had said: “Joseph is a planting containing many branches.”<br>In my opinion, the word <i>bein</i> is to be understood in its ordinary sense, namely, “son,” with the verse stating that Joseph is a son who is similar to a many branched tree, planted beside a spring whose waters fail not, and whose branches in turn gave forth offspring, [i.e., other boughs]. [On account of their heaviness] these tread upon the sky-high walls.<sup class="footnote-marker">222</sup><i class="footnote">For lacking such support they would break under the weight of their abundant fruit.</i> He called the boughs which come forth from the branches as <i>banoth</i> (daughters), for they are “the daughters” of the great branches. This is stylistic elegance for the expression, <i>bein porath</i>. The word <i>bein</i>, accordingly, is not in the conjunctive mode to the word <i>porath</i>, but instead is like: <i>The Assyrian was a cedar in Lebanon;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">223</sup><i class="footnote">Ezekiel 31:3.</i> <i>Naphtali is a hind sent forth;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">224</sup><i class="footnote">Above, Verse 21.</i> <i>Benjamin is a wolf</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">225</sup><i class="footnote">Further, Verse 27.</i> It is for this reason that it is vowelled with a <i>tzeirei</i> — [<i>bein</i>] — for if its interpretation were “a plant of boughs,”<sup class="footnote-marker">226</sup><i class="footnote">As “the grammarians,” whose interpretation was discussed previously, would have it. See text above. According to their interpretation, since the two words <i>bein porath</i> are in the constructive mode (“a plant of…”), the word should have been <i>ben</i> and not <i>bein</i>, as is the rule.</i> the word <i>bein</i> should have been vowelled with a <i>segol</i>, [thus rendering it <i>ben</i> rather than <i>bein</i>]. The reason he uses the term <i>bein</i> (son) is to show affection, just as: <i>From the prey, my son, thou art gone up</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">227</sup><i class="footnote">Above, Verse 9.</i><br>In general it is proper to interpret Joseph’s blessing as alluding to the two tribes which came from him, and this could be based upon the words <i>porath</i> (branches) and <i>banoth</i> (boughs). However, since he mentioned Levi, and the tribes of Israel number only twelve, he did not treat them as two separate tribes in his blessing, but he does allude to them. Moses our teacher, likewise, in his blessing, compared Joseph to the bullock and the wild-ox, and mentioned “the horns”<sup class="footnote-marker">228</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 33:17.</i> in connection with him as each one constitutes a distinct body from which two horns branch out. There, however, because Moses our teacher did not mention Simeon by name, he explicitly said, <i>And they are the ten thousands of Ephraim, and they are the thousands of Menasheh</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">228</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 33:17.</i>

Verse 23



Verse 24

BY THE HANDS OF THE MIGHTY ONE OF JACOB. This befell him from the Holy One, blessed be He, Who is the Mighty One of Jacob. And from there [from his position as viceroy], he became worthy to be <i>the feeder of the foundation stone of Israel</i>, that is, the source of the tribes of Israel. The word <i>“even”</i> (stone) has the same meaning here as the word <i>“even”</i> in the expression, <i>the chief stone</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">229</sup><i class="footnote">Zechariah 4:7.</i> [where it means high position]. This is the language of Rashi. “<i>From the G-d of thy father</i> did this befall you, and He will help you. [<i>And with the Almighty</i>, i.e.,] and your heart was with the Holy One, blessed be He, when you did not hearken to the words of your mistress, and He will bless you.” This is also the language of Rashi.<br>Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra said that the letter <i>mem</i> in the expression, <i>mei’e-il avicha (‘from’ the G-d of thy father)</i>, is also to apply to the expression, <i>ve’eith Sha-dai</i>, [as if it read, <i>umei’eith Sha-dai (and ‘from’ the Almighty)</i>], <i>and He will bless thee.…</i>

Verse 25



Verse 26



Verse 27



Verse 28



Verse 29

BURY ME ‘EL AVOTHAI.’ With my fathers. This is the language of Rashi. However, Rashi did not explain the expression <i>el hame’arah</i> as meaning <i>‘with’ the cave</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">230</sup><i class="footnote">Ramban’s intent is to point out that the word <i>el</i> in the second expression could not mean “with,” which confronts us with the difficulty of having the same word assume different meanings in the same verse. Ramban will suggest various ways of resolving this difficulty.</i><br>It is possible that the expression of this verse is concise [and should be understood as if it said], “Bury me and carry me to my fathers to the cave,” for so Jacob said, <i>And thou shalt carry me out from Egypt</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">231</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 47:30.</i> and it further says, <i>And his sons carried him</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">232</sup><i class="footnote">50:13.</i><br>It is possible that the word <i>el</i> serves here to indicate many meanings:<sup class="footnote-marker">233</sup><i class="footnote">Since Ramban cites Scriptural references to justify each usage, he finds no difficulty in the fact that the word is used differently in the same verse.</i> <i>Bury me ‘with’ my fathers</i>, just as in the verse, <i>And thou shalt not take a woman ‘el’ her sister</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">234</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 18:18.</i> meaning “<i>with</i> her sister.” <i>El hame’arah</i> means “in the cave,” just as in the verses: <i>‘Ve’el’ (And in) the ark thou shalt put the testimony that I shall give thee;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">235</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 25:21.</i> <i>Behold, he hath hidden himself ‘el’ (among) the baggage</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">236</sup><i class="footnote">I Samuel 10:22.</i> Of similar usage is the expression, <i>And after this, Abraham buried Sarah his wife ‘el’ (in) the cave</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">237</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 23:19.</i><br>Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra said that the meaning of the expression, <i>Bury me</i><sup class="footnote-marker">238</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Kivru</i> (bury me) is in the plural form.</i> <i>with my fathers</i>, is that the brothers should go with Joseph.<br>Now Jacob really did not need to do that. However, he now commanded all of them to bury him in the cave, just as he had sworn Joseph, because he feared that Pharaoh might not give Joseph permission to leave the land lest he remain in his land [Canaan].<sup class="footnote-marker">239</sup><i class="footnote">Abarbanel comments that the reason Pharaoh sent a group of Egyptians to accompany the burial party was that he feared lest Joseph and his brothers be influenced by the attachment to Canaan demonstrated by their father in both life and death and decide to stay there.</i> Do you not see that it was necessary for Joseph to plead with the house of Pharaoh<sup class="footnote-marker">240</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 50:4-5.</i> that they should request Pharaoh to let him go, and he answered, <i>Go up, and bury thy father, as he made thee swear</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">241</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 6.</i> as he agreed to it only on account of the oath!

Verse 30



Verse 31

THERE THEY BURIED ISAAC AND REBEKAH. The reason for saying this rather than saying, “I buried,” was that Esau was with him at the burial of their father,<sup class="footnote-marker">242</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 35:29.</i> and he did not wish to mention him now. Furthermore, [he did not mention Esau’s name] as he would have been forced to extend the account, saying, “there <i>we</i> buried Isaac, and there <i>they</i> buried his wife Rebekah,” since Jacob was not present at the burial of his mother.<br>Now in his testament, Jacob mentioned the cave and those who were buried in it to his children on account of the eminence of the place so that they make a zealous effort to bury him there.<br><i>Which Abraham bought with the field… for a possession of a burying-place</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">243</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 30 here. To emphasize his thought on the eminence of the place, Ramban reverts to explain the preceding verse in the same light.</i> He said this in order to let it be known that Abraham commanded that that place be their burial ground as an everlasting possession. However, further on, when it says, <i>And they buried him in the cave of the field of Machpelah, which Abraham bought with the field for a burying-place</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">244</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 50:13.</i> the intent of the verse is to allude that the intention of the righteous one [Abraham] was completed with Jacob’s being buried there as he had bought it for the three of them, and no other person was to be buried there. It is for this reason that Joseph did not command that they bury him in the cave with his fathers.<br>Now I have seen in the Mechilta of Rabbi Shimon ben Yochai<sup class="footnote-marker">245</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Beshalach</i> 19. See also Midrash Hagadol, ed. Shechter, end of <i>Vayechi</i> 25, and Notes. — The Mechilta is a Midrash on the Book of Exodus, the standard Mechilta is that of Rabbi Yishmael. Ramban here refers to another Mechilta, namely, that of Rabbi Shimon ben Yochai. That is why he specifies it by name.</i> that Joseph said to them: “And when you bring me up to the land of Canaan bury me anywhere you wish. I have received a tradition that I will not be buried with my fathers for no one is permitted there for burial except the three patriarchs and the three matriarchs, as it is said, <i>There they buried Abraham</i>, etc., and it further says, <i>In my burying-place which I digged for me</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">246</sup><i class="footnote">Further 50:5.</i> as he [Jacob] terminates [the group of people who are to be buried there].<br>It is possible that by saying, <i>And there I buried Leah</i>, Jacob hinted to them that he had already taken possession of the cave. This he said with respect to Esau, lest he and his children protest his [Jacob’s] being buried there by claiming that the cave is his as he was the firstborn and he is deserving of being buried with his ancestors. Now even though Esau had already left for another country,<sup class="footnote-marker">247</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 36:6.</i> his sons might transport him from there, just as Jacob’s sons carried him. Jacob longed to be buried with his sacred ancestors and to be united with them in burial, and if Esau were to be buried there, Jacob could not be buried there for one burial-place does not serve two families. This is also the purport of his words, <i>In my burying-place which I digged for me</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">246</sup><i class="footnote">Further 50:5.</i> meaning that he had already dug the grave in order to take possession of it. This is also the reason that it says, <i>And there went up with him both chariots and horsemen</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">248</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 50:9.</i> as Joseph knew the presumptuousness of Esau and his sons.<br>This is actually what occurred. We find in the Book of Chronicles of Joseph ben Gorion<sup class="footnote-marker">249</sup><i class="footnote">The book is known as Josippon. This was an anonymous popular Hebrew medieval work containing the ancient history of the Jews. It was based in part upon the work of the historian Josephus. The story related here is told at length in Chapter 2.</i> and in other books of ancient history that Zepho the son of Eliphaz the son of Esau<sup class="footnote-marker">250</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 36:11.</i> came and quarrelled with the children of Jacob concerning this burial, with the result that they waged war. But the power of Joseph prevailed, and they captured him together with his choice army, and they brought them to Egypt. There, Zepho remained in prison all the days of Joseph, but upon his death he escaped from there and went to the land of Compagna [in Italy] and there he ruled over the Caetheans in Rome, and ultimately was crowned [ruler] over the land of Italy. It was he who first reigned over Rome, and it was he who built the first and largest palace ever built in Rome.<br>Our Rabbis also mentioned this matter of the quarrel<sup class="footnote-marker">251</sup><i class="footnote">Sotah 13a.</i> with Esau at the cave. The verse which states here, <i>And Joseph returned into Egypt, he and his brethren, and all that went up with him to bury his father, after he had buried his father</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">252</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 50:14. It would appear that Ramban wishes to finish his commentary on the entire book of Genesis with the death of Jacob (for reasons made clear further). Hence Ramban explains first the oath of Joseph, although it is not mentioned in Scripture till further on (at the end of Chapter 50), and then he reverts to Verse 33, (of the present Chapter 49), in order to explain the nature of the demise of the patriarch which mirrors as well the life of the hereafter, thus confirming the statement of the Sages: “Jacob our father did not die.” The Commentary thus ends on the high note of the deathlessness of the righteous.</i> alludes to the fact that not one of them died in the war or on the way, as the merit of the prophet Jacob and the merit of Joseph stood by those who went up with him.<br>Joseph did not command that he be carried and buried now in the Land as his father had commanded, for the house of Pharaoh would not permit it since he was a source of honor to them. Furthermore, if his brothers and his father’s house were to accompany him, the people of the Land would rob and steal whatever they had, and it would not be respectful behavior for others to transport him there.
AND JOSEPH SAID TO HIS BRETHREN, I DIE.<sup class="footnote-marker">253</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 50:24. Ramban here attempts to remove this difficulty: Why did Joseph address himself first to his brothers, and then made the children of Israel swear to bring his remains to the land of his ancestors (as stated in the following verse.)</i> All of his brothers were still alive for they all survived him, as you see in the case of Levi.<sup class="footnote-marker">254</sup><i class="footnote">Seder Olam, Chapter 3: “None among the tribes lived less than Joseph, and none among them lived longer than Levi.”</i> <i>And Joseph made the children of Israel swear</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">255</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 50:25.</i> Upon seeing that his brothers were old, he made their children and all his father’s household swear that they too would command their children’s children [to take up his bones with them] at the moment of redemption, as they all knew of the impending exile.

Verse 32



Verse 33

AND HE EXPIRED, AND WAS GATHERED TO HIS PEOPLE. But the word “death” is not mentioned in his case. Our Rabbis therefore said, “Jacob, our father, did not die.” This is the language of Rashi.<br>Now according to this opinion of our Rabbis, the difficulty arises: Now Jacob applied the term “death” to himself, as it is written, <i>Behold, I die, but G-d shall be with you!</i><sup class="footnote-marker">256</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 48:21.</i> Now perhaps he did not know it himself, or it may be that he did not wish to pay honor to himself. Similarly, with respect to the verse, <i>And when Joseph’s brethren saw that their father was dead</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">257</sup><i class="footnote">50:15.</i> we must say that to them he was dead, or it may be that they did not at all know of this. Now the purport of this Midrash [which states that “Jacob, our father, did not die],” is that the souls of the righteous <i>are bound in the bind of life with the Eternal</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">258</sup><i class="footnote">I Samuel 25:29.</i> and his soul <i>covereth him all the day</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">259</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 33:12.</i> “wearing a scarlet garment”<sup class="footnote-marker">260</sup><i class="footnote">A Cabalistic term indicating “the garment” which the soul dons after the death of the physical body.</i> so that she not be stripped naked, as Jacob’s [soul was privileged to do continually], or which she dons at certain occasions [as do the souls of lesser righteous individuals]. This matter will be understood in the light of what is told in Tractate Shabbath<sup class="footnote-marker">261</sup><i class="footnote">There (152 b) the story is told of certain grave-diggers who were digging in the ground when they heard the voice of Rabbi Acho’ie the son of Yoshiyahu, who had been buried there previously, rebuking them. He was yet alive in the sense which the Rabbis refer to when they say Jacob did not die.</i> and Tractate Kethuboth.<sup class="footnote-marker">262</sup><i class="footnote">There (103 b) the story is told of Rabbeinu Hakadosh who, after his demise, would come home every Sabbath eve and pronounce the <i>Kiddush</i>.</i>
Thus concludes the book <i>Bereshith</i>, containing the story of the accounts of the patriarchs. It tells of what has occurred and of new things that will occur<sup class="footnote-marker">263</sup><i class="footnote">Here we have Ramban’s recurrent theme that the book of Genesis alludes to the future events in the story of Israel.</i> even before they spring up in the hearts of people.<br>And to the Creator of all beginnings,<br>Him that rideth the skies,<sup class="footnote-marker">264</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 68:5.</i><br>Many praises and myriads of thanksgivings.<br><i>By Him actions and causes are weighed;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">265</sup><i class="footnote">I Samuel 2:3.</i><br><i>He uncovereth deep things</i><sup class="footnote-marker">266</sup><i class="footnote">Job 12:22.</i> and lofty opinions,<br>And brings the thoughts to light.<br>It is He Who leadeth me in the path of righteousness,<br>In the midst of the path of justice,<sup class="footnote-marker">267</sup><i class="footnote">See Proverbs 8:20.</i><br>Who vouchsafest benefits unto the undeserving.”<sup class="footnote-marker">268</sup><i class="footnote">From the benediction upon deliverance from peril or recovery from sickness (Berachoth 54 b).</i>
